title: Differential-Privacy-Preserving Distributed ADMM Using Load-Balanced Sparse Allreduce Communication_supp1-3638741.pdf
authors: Jingxin Luo
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) enables efficient machine learning by connecting terminal devices to coordinate distributed model training. In typical scenarios, each device is treated as a computing node, training local models with its local data and updating the global model by exchanging parameters with neighbors. However, as the dataset scales grow, communication costs limit the scalability of distributed machine-learning algorithms. Moreover, parameters sharing increases the risk of privacy leakage. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a distributed alternating direction method of multipliers based on load balancing sparse allreduce (LBSA-ADMM). Unlike traditional distributed ADMM algorithms, LBSA-ADMM requires each node to compute and communicate only its associated features, drastically reducing overhead. More importantly, LBSA is tailored for performing allreduce on transmission parameters of all nodes. LBSA divides transmission parameters according to the weight of each feature, effectively balancing communication overhead across nodes. Furthermore, the paper proposes a differential privacy ADMM (DP-LBSA-ADMM) to enhance the security of LBSA-ADMM by injecting noise into penalty parameters. This algorithm dynamically adjusts penalty parameters to balance accuracy and privacy, with convergence guaranteed theoretically and empirically. Experimental results demonstrate that LBSA significantly reduces communication costs compared to state-of-the-art methods, DP-LBSA-ADMM achieves faster convergence than comparable ADMM algorithms.

title: Exploiting SIMD-ified Bit-Parallelism for High-Performance Complex Event Matching
authors: Tao Qiu, Ying Liu, Chuanyu Zong, Xiaochun Yang, Bin Wang, Mengxiang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: The advent of Single Instruction Multiple Data (SIMD) instructions in modern processors has revolutionized data processing by enabling simultaneous computation across multiple data elements. While database systems have extensively adopted SIMD for traditional operations, its potential for complex event pattern matching remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a novel approach that bridges this gap through bit-parallel processing enhanced with AVX-512 vectorization. Our approach encodes event streams into compact bit sequences, where each bit corresponds to a time slice, and an event's presence is marked by a 1-bit when its timestamp falls within the respective slice. This representation enables the formulation of bit-parallel operations that natively enforce complex event constraints, including temporal window requirements and event ordering relationships. We develop a family of bit-parallel algorithms that leverage this representation for continuous event matching, and further optimize their performance through SIMD vectorization (AVX-512 instructions) to exploit modern hardware parallelism. Experimental evaluations on both real-world and synthetic datasets demonstrate the superiority of our method, achieving at least 35.7x improvement in query efficiency compared to state-of-the-art alternatives.

title: OSRNet: A One-Step Learned Spatial Redistribution Convolutional Neural Network for satellite SIF downscaling
authors: Jiaochan Hu, Zihan Ma, Liangyun Liu, Haoyang Yu, Mengqiu Wang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) is a direct proxy for photosynthetic activity, yet existing satellite SIF products are constrained by coarse spatial resolution, limiting their application in ecological and agricultural studies. In this work, we propose a One-Step Learned Spatial Redistribution Convolutional Neural Network (OSRNet) that downscales 0.05° TROPOMI SIF to 0.005° by learning spatially adaptive redistribution fields from high-resolution drivers, which allocate coarse-resolution satellite SIF into fine-resolution grids. Based on this framework, we generate RSIF, a global 16-day 0.005° SIF dataset for 2018–2020. Comprehensive evaluation against both satellite and tower-based SIF shows that RSIF maintains strong consistency with TROPOMI observations (R² = 0.976, RMSE = 0.036) while recovering fine-scale spatial details. OSRNet substantially outperforms established direct prediction methods such as RF and SIFNet, and, compared with post hoc corrected RF approach from prior studies, achieves the highest R² across all tower sites and generally the lowest RMSE, enabling more accurate representation of seasonal dynamics with improved spatial fidelity.

title: A Wideband and High-Density Integration Microwave Transceiver Component for Tile-Style Phased Array With SiP Technology
authors: Taifu Zhou, Guo Guo, Zeyuan Yang, Hongchao Wang, Zhigang Wang, Bo Yan, Yanyu Wei
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: A novel K-band transceiver component is introduced in this letter, featured with high-density integration, wide band, and miniaturization. The advanced system-in-package (SiP) technology and double-sided slotted (DS) packaging technology are employed to integrate the core chip and GaAs transceiver chip circuits with four channels together, and therefore to achieve the lightening and thinning of the component. After structure design and thermal design, an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$8\times 12$</tex-math> </inline-formula> tile style module in K-band has been manufactured and tested. Test results show that the active transmission gains are more than 5 dB, with the input and output reflection loss more than 10 dB from 20.5 to 25 GHz within the relative bandwidth of 21.7%. For the total 96 channels, phase consistency is less than 8.5°, and the amplitude consistency is better than 0.59 dB, demonstrating excellent channel consistency. Additionally, the total dimensions of the fabricated module are only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$104\times 78$</tex-math> </inline-formula> mm, and the total weight is only 290 g. The architecture design and processing technologies indicate significant potential for miniaturizing and high-density integrated tile-style phased array antennas.

title: Intelligent Edge Data Integrity Verification with Dynamic Unreliable Data Replica Selection_supp1-3638138.pdf
authors: Yao Zhao
abstract: With the advancement of Mobile Edge Computing (MEC), App vendors are increasingly motivated to cache multiple data replicas on geographically distributed edge servers to ensure rapid responses for latency-sensitive applications. However, the security of data replicas is a critical concern due to the dynamic nature and resource limitations of MEC environments. To this end, data replicas’ integrity must be regularly verified to maintain the accuracy of data-driven decision-making. Existing Edge Data Integrity (EDI) verification solutions suffer from low efficiency due to relying on indiscriminative verification, where all data replicas are checked at each round without considering their inherent reliability characteristics. This paper designs an Intelligent framework called I-EDI, which enables discriminative EDI verification by integrating a novel Long-term Unreliable data Replica Selection (L-URS) mechanism. This framework aims to reduce verification costs without compromising accuracy, while resisting spoofing, forgery, outsourcing, collusion, alteration-before-verification, delayed-response, and adaptive attacks. Specifically, each data replica is associated with a reliability representation by evaluating its long-term performance. Based on that, the L-URS problem is defined as stochastically minimizing the global reliability representation over time, subject to constraints on the number of data replicas to be verified. To make it easy-to-handle, the L-URS problem is decomposed into a series of online minimization problems. An Online Opportunistic-based Replica Selection approach called O<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>RS is developed. O<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>RS allows App vendors to significantly decrease verification costs by targetedly inspecting unreliable data replicas. Moreover, this work provides a thorough theoretical analysis of O<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>RS’s time complexity and approximation bound, as well as I-EDI’s security. Extensive experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness and efficiency of O<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>RS and I-EDI. The results demonstrate that, compared to commonly used alternatives, O<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>RS achieves an approximate 50% improvement in selection efficiency, while I-EDI reduces verification costs by 1.23 times on average.

title: VersaAccel: A Versatile Configurable Accelerator for Diverse Sparse-Dense Matrix Operators
authors: Minjin Tang, Mei Wen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Matrix operators are fundamental to various applications, particularly in deep learning. While early models relied on dense operations, techniques like pruning have introduced sparsity, leading to a mix of dense and sparse operator types. Most existing accelerators are specialized for specific operators and perform poorly in mixed scenarios, while those supporting multiple operators often lack flexibility and suffer from suboptimal performance. To overcome these limitations, we propose VersaAccel, a configurable accelerator for sparse and dense matrix operators. It supports four distinct configurations, each optimized for a set of operators. A key feature of our design is its adaptive configuration selection mechanism, driven by a lightweight cost model that explicitly evaluates the performance-energy trade-off between available options. This allows VersaAccel to dynamically choose the most efficient configuration—opting for higher performance when the gain outweighs the energy cost, or prioritizing energy efficiency when appropriate. Experimental results demonstrate that VersaAccel achieves an average performance/area improvement of 3.10× across multiple operators (MV, MM, SPMV, SpMM, SpMSpM) and 4.06× on full model evaluations (ResNet18, VGG16, LLaMA2-7B, BERT-Base), compared to mainstream accelerators.

title: Spectral Calibration of the Microwave Electrojet Magnetogram Radiometer Instrument on the Electrojet Zeeman Imaging Explorer Mission
authors: Sidharth Misra, Sharmila Padmanabhan, Pekka Kangaslahti, Rick Cofield, Oliver Montes, Isaac Ramos, Aram Dergevorkian, Ryan White, Joelle Cooperrider, Heather Lim, Hamid Javadi, Xavi Bosch-Lluis, Mandy Wang, Omkar Pradhan, Albin Gasiewski, Jeng-Hwa Yee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The EZIE mission is a first of its kind to measure the temporal and spatial characteristics of Earth’s ionospheric auroral electrojet currents remotely using a mm-wave radiometer called the Microwave Electrojet Magnetogram (MEM). EZIE measures the 118 GHz oxygen emission line that splits in frequency in the presence of a magnetic field. This effect is known as the Zeeman effect. From these measurements of the 50 km spatial resolution magnetic fields at 80 km altitude the ionospheric currents that caused them can be calculated. The EZIE mission consists of three MEM payloads on three spacecrafts, each MEM contains four polarimetric radiometer receivers with a polyphase filter bank spectrometer. MEM can indirectly measure magnetic field strength and direction. In this paper we present the unique calibration design of the MEM payload that does not include any internal or external calibration sources. We discuss the MEM payload and present results from pre-launch testing and calibration of the MEM system.

title: Population Historical Information-Driven Evolutionary Multitask Neural Architecture Search
authors: Kunjie Yu, Hao Tang, Jing Liang, Chao Li, Mingyuan Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has achieved significant success in automating neural network design, particularly through evolutionary NAS. To address the critical need for efficient architecture discovery across diverse scenarios, such as computer vision and natural language processing, multitask NAS (MT-NAS) methods have emerged. Nevertheless, existing MT-NAS approaches still face critical challenges, including redundant search arising from insufficient exploitation of population historical information across generations and negative transfer caused by unguided interactions between tasks. To address these limitations, a population historical information-driven evolutionary multitask neural architecture search (HIMT-NAS) algorithm is proposed. For each generation, the population historical information is recorded, which includes the operation information and the topology information. In the search process, systematic utilization of population historical information to guide evolutionary search directions, preventing redundant search. Furthermore, the proposed method adjusts cross-task knowledge transfer probability by measuring task similarity through patterns in population historical information, and then updates transfer probabilities when the information proves useful across multiple tasks. Extensive experiments on MedMNIST, CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and Tiny-ImageNet demonstrate consistent advantages of the proposed method over both single-task NAS methods and recent MT-NAS methods.

title: Fuzzy Membership-Driven Adaptive Sample Mining for Facial Expression Recognition
authors: Xuxiong Liu, Liuwei An, Kang Shen, Ziyang Zhang, Xiao Sun
abstract: Facial expression recognition (FER) datasets are plagued by fuzzy label uncertainty due to interclass similarities, compound emotions, and annotation subjectivity. Moreover, the complexity of recognition differs across various expression categories, making an undifferentiated method inequitable for each expression. In this work, we propose adaptive sample mining (ASM), a fuzzy membership-driven framework with two innovations: it constructs a category-specific dynamic threshold set as the average probabilities of samples that are correctly predicted, through which it explicitly separates clean and noisy subsets while leaving ambiguous samples as the intermediate fuzzy region between them. In addition, it introduces a rule based on multilocal region prediction consistency to reclassify samples from the clean subset into the ambiguous subset when local predictions conflict. Finally, the triregularization module implements tailored training approaches for these three subsets: the clean subset is trained using a supervised learning strategy to maximize the utility of high-quality annotations, the ambiguous subset adopts a mutual learning strategy to enhance discrimination capability, and the noisy subset employs an unsupervised learning technique so that it can minimize the influence from noisy labels. We performed comprehensive experiments on the RAF-DB, FERPlus, and AffectNet. The proposed ASM achieved 90.94% accuracy on RAF-DB and 86.81% on its synthetic noisy version. The ablation experiment and analysis demonstrate that our method can efficiently identify ambiguous and noisy labels. By weighting the classification loss based on fuzzy membership, it helps to make efficient use of the labels. This results in an improvement in accuracy.

title: An Adaptive Protection Scheme for DC Micro-grid
authors: Nareddy Nageswara Reddy, Hanumantha Rao Bokkisam, Anil Annamraju, Ravi Kumar Avvari, N V Phanendra Babu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Recently, the direct current (DC) microgrid has gained prominence as a more efficient power system, driven by the growing demand for DC loads and the improved efficiency. Protection is a critical challenge in DC microgrid operation, as the absence of zero crossings renders traditional protection schemes ineffective. Additionally, the protection design is further complicated in a DC microgrid with a ring configuration and bidirectional power flow. Recent studies on DC microgrid protection are mostly focused on fault detection methodology but identifying the accurate location of fault in the line is also needed for the system restoration and maintenance. In this work a fault location algorithm is proposed based on the line parameter approach. By using the current characteristics during the fault, the frequency is computed. Based on the correlation between inductance of the line and frequency, the fault location is determined. The performance of the proposed algorithm is verified in MATLAB/Simulink simulation flat form for various fault conditions.

title: Loss Modeling and Harmonic Analysis of Five Phase VSI Driven IM for EV Applications
authors: Snehil Verma, Devara Vijaya Bhaskar, Alok Ranjan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents the loss modeling of a five-phase voltage source inverter, including the thermal dependency of semiconductor parameters to capture the non-idealities of practical operations. Among various PWM methodologies, the medium-large space vector PWM technique is employed to operate the five-phase induction motor under free acceleration conditions. A comprehensive THD analysis of the ideal and proposed models reveals a slight increment of THD in the practical model attributed to the non-linear behavior of power semiconductor switches. This research lays a solid groundwork for the effective integration of practical five-phase VSIs driving five-phase induction motors into advanced applications such as electric vehicles and renewable energy systems. The inverter output current THD is 1.45 %, and harmonic analysis for different cases is mentioned in Table II.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Quantum Phase Estimation Using Deep Q-Network
authors: Sundharess B, Vikash Krishna R, Gopika SS, Somnath Sinha, Cecil Donald, Aditi Paul
abstract: Quantum Phase Estimation(QPE) is a fundamental quantum algorithm that is used for the estimation of eigenphases of unitary operators. Its main goal is to determine the phase associated with each eigenstate. Usually, it take steps such as prepare quantum states, apply controlled unitaries, inverse quantum fourier transformation, and measurement. This study uses the OpenAI Gym framework to build a customized QPE environment. Here, the phase of a randomly generated target unitary operator is estimated using a quantum circuit. Through interaction with this environment, the DQN agent learns the best course of action to increase phase estimation accuracy. It exhibits more flexibility in noisy environments and reduces estimating mistakes. With its insights and approaches for further study in this area, this effort represents a significant advancement in the use of Deep Reinforcement Learning in quantum computing. A Comparative analysis between IBM Quantum(ibm kyiv) and the Aer Simulator on the OpenAI Gym environment using RL agents has been done.

title: Order Reduction of Flyback Converter Using Direct Truncation and Routh Approximation Method
authors: Jamna Bishnoi, Bhavnesh Kumar, V. P. Singh, Akhilesh Mathur, S. K. Maurya, R. S. Meena
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: A flyback Converter, consisting of a transformer and a capacitor, is ideally a second-order system but is often analyzed as a higher-order system in practical calculations due to real-world effects. In this paper, the flyback converter model is developed using the state-space averaging technique. The system is then simplified to a lower-order model by applying the direct truncation method to reduce the numerator and the Routh approximation method to simplify the denominator. Further, step response, Bode, and Nyquist plots are plotted for all the flyback converter’s reduced-order transfer functions and models to visualize the system’s behaviour. By comparing the responses and time-domain specifications of the reduced-order model with the original system, the accuracy of the reduction technique is validated.

title: Inverted BER Trends for Energy-Detected GRSM-MQAM Massive MIMO Downlink
authors: Oshin Daoud, Haïfa Farès, Yahia Medjahdi, Laurent Clavier, Amor Nafkha
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: This work investigates Generalized Receiver Spatial Modulation (GRSM) in a massive MIMO downlink scenario over millimetre wave channels. While GRSM enhances spectral efficiency (SE) and reduces power consumption, indexing additional bits using the spatial dimension increases the vulnerability to detection errors. These errors primarily stem from thresholddependent spatial detection. We propose a novel predefined threshold computation method minimizing spatial detection errors, rigorously validated through the Maximum A Posteriori (MAP) criterion. Furthermore, we derive an analytical Average Bit Error Probability (ABEP) expression tailored for energy detection, exploiting inherent constellation energy distributions. The analytical derivation was validated via link-level simulations under two scenarios: (i) perfect spatial detection, and (ii) practical spatial detection. The results show spatial errors dominating overall performance, shifted from theoretical values by practical spatial detection using multiple thresholds for different energy levels in 16QAM. Crucially, an inverted error trend revealed between GRSM-4QAM and GRSM-16QAM, highlighting a tradeoff between error resilience, complexity, and energy efficiency.

title: Green Bot: An Intelligent Chat-Based Assistant for Agricultural Support
authors: Talari Nagamani, Mohebbanaaz, G Fayaz Hussain
abstract: Creating a farming chatbot powered by AI involves important steps to give farmers helpful and precise assistance. The chatbot uses a variety of data types, such as scientific research, current weather and soil information, pest and disease data, market trends, and local farming advice. This ensures that all the information it provides is useful and relevant to each farmer's unique situation. The chatbot applies specific computer techniques to handle data accurately. It uses Z-score normalization for data adjustment, TF-IDF for language processing, and cosine similarity to identify the best answers to farmers' questions. Machine learning models like the Naive Bayes Classifier enable the chatbot to interpret what the farmer is asking. Additionally, a method known as cross-entropy loss helps make its predictions more exact. These combined techniques ensure the chatbot's fast and accurate responses. There is a structured database that serves as a storage space for all this knowledge. It logs conversations and continually analyzes information, allowing the system to get updates and improvements over time. The chatbot is designed to comprehend farmers’ questions, provide customized responses, and generate useful reports. This bridges scientific expertise with everyday farming needs. With these comprehensive measures, the chatbot becomes a significant digital tool for farmers, offering real-time, adaptable assistance. As it interacts with more users, it keeps learning and becomes more effective, providing even better support over time.

title: Breast Cancer Classification Using Machine Learning Technique
authors: Divyansh Sharma, Aditya Dubey, Dhananjay Bisen
abstract: Breast cancer continues to be a major health concern worldwide, posing a serious trouble to the lives of millions of women each time. Timely opinion plays a pivotal part in perfecting the liability of survival, as early- stage discovery significantly increases the chances of successful treatment. With recent advancements in computational wisdom, machine literacy has come an effective approach for supporting medical opinion and complaint bracket. This design introduces an intelligent bracket system grounded on machine literacy ways aimed at relating breast excrescences as either nasty or benign. The system leverages the Wisconsin breast Cancer Dataset (WBCD), an extensively honored clinical dataset that includes multiple features uprooted from breast cell samples. To perform the bracket task, several supervised literacy algorithms are enforced, including Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest, and K- Nearest Neighbors (KNN). Each model is assessed using standard evaluation criteria similar as delicacy, perfection, recall, and F1- score to insure trustability and performance. The primary ideal of this design is to help medical interpreters by furnishing a presto, harmonious, and data-informed system of excrescence bracket. By reducing the chances of mortal error and perfecting individual reversal time, this system serves as a precious tool in the ongoing trouble to enhance cancer discovery practices. Overall, the design showcases the promising part of machine literacy in supporting healthcare systems and transubstantiating traditional individual workflows.

title: DeNSAINet: DDoS Attack Detection using Neuro-Symbolic AI in Softwarized Networks
authors: Srishti Dey, Aishik Paul, Arijit Mukherjee, Deborsi Basu, Uttam Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This article aims to investigate DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) identification techniques in software-defined network (SDN) systems by using DeNSAINet-an emerging AI (Artificial Intelligence) framework that leverages Neuro-Symbolic AI. Neuro-Symbolic AI is a cutting-edge technique that offers better performance when detecting DDoS attacks in an SDN system. In the application of DDoS attack detection, the framework is divided into symbolic reasoning and neural networks. Symbolic reasoning is used to determine whether a particular traffic is normal or malicious, and neural AI based on a knowledge graph is designed to specifically differentiate between DDoS attacks and other types of attacks. We have considered a benchmark dataset, namely InSDN, collected from Kaggle to conduct this research. Our performance metrics remain high, with an accuracy of 99.8% for detecting Metasploit DDoS attacks. The evaluation of other performance parameters was conducted using precision, recall, F1-score, and a confusion matrix.

title: A Multilingual Handwritten OCR System Using CNN-BiLSTM-CTC
authors: Dadapeer, Yeresime Suresh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: An Optical Character Recognition (OCR) system for multilingual handwritten character recognition, including English and Kannada scripts, is proposed in this work. Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is essential for translating handwritten input into digital format, streamlining data access, storage, and automation in fields like education, public administration, and healthcare. The proposed system uses a deep learning approach combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Bidirectional LSTMs, optimized with Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) loss, to handle sequences of varying lengths. Preprocessing steps are applied to enhance the clarity of input images before recognition. The model is trained and tested on a custom dataset built from IAM (for English) and a word-level Kannada dataset derived from Char74K. To assess the system's performance, metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, Character Error Rate (CER), Word Error Rate (WER), and text similarity are employed. Results from the experiments demonstrate the model's capability to accurately recognize handwritten words in both scripts.

title: Design and Analysis of an MPP-Operated Single-Stage Grid-Forming Photovoltaic Inverter Using Virtual Synchronous Generator Control
authors: Arvind Kumar, Prakirty Kumari, Dushyant Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and performance analysis of a virtual synchronous generator (VSG)-controlled single-stage grid-forming (GFM) photovoltaic (PV) inverter (GFPVI) operating at maximum power point (MPP). The proposed inverter integrates a VSG-based power control strategy and a virtual impedance-based current limiting method to enhance stability and maintain grid connectivity during extreme grid conditions, including transient disturbances. The novel approach addresses the challenges of achieving both MPP operation and GFM capabilities in a single-stage PV inverter. The system's performance is evaluated under rigorous test scenarios in compliance with grid code standards, such as severe voltage and frequency fluctuations and fault conditions. Results validate the efficacy of the proposed design in improving transient response, limiting current during faults, and maintaining voltage and frequency stability. This study contributes to advancing grid-compatible PV inverter technologies for renewable energy systems in low-inertia grids.

title: Tuberculosis Lesion Classification and Detection Method Guided by Attention Mechanism
authors: Mingling Lu, Haojie Xie, Benlian Xu, Mingming Wang, Jing Liu, Jinliang Cong
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: The precise classification of the detected lesions can help doctors further determine the type of lesions and implement treatment plans, which is of great importance for the later treatment of the disease. Due to the diverse morphology and complex structure of pulmonary tuberculosis lesions, the classification accuracy of the general network is low in the classification process. Aimed to these problems, a method is proposed to classify and detect pulmonary tuberculosis lesions guided by a normalized attention mechanism. The NA-YOLO precise classification network for lesions was constructed. Firstly, in terms of data augmentation, a multi-scale image label synchronous data augmentation scheme is proposed to balance the number of various lesions. In terms of network construction, the attention modules of the channel and space branches guide the network to focus on the lesion feature areas, further enhancing the extraction of inter-channel and local spatial information. Secondly, the loss function is optimized through Scylla-IoU Loss Function(SIoU) to reduce the total degree of freedom between images. Ultimately, achieving a precise classification of four common types of pulmonary tuberculosis lesions. The high-precision classification performance of the proposed method was further verified through ablation and comparative experiments.

title: From Static Benchmarks to Online Reality Dynamics: Contextual UCB for Movie Recommendations with Drift and Forgetting
authors: Ziting Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper focuses on the Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB) algorithm in online recommendation systems, specifically comparing the performance of UCB1, LinUCB, V-LinUCB, and NeuralUCB across static environments. It also introduces the concepts of conceptual drift and exponential decay in dynamic, non-steady scenarios. The paper presents extended experiments using DecayLinUCB and DecayVLinUCB. First, using the MovieLens dataset, the cumulative regret values and CTR@1 of each algorithm under a fixed distribution are simulated offline, demonstrating that NeuralUCB has advantages in long-term recommendation quality, while UCB1 is lighter for real-time use and resource consumption. Furthermore, V-LinUCB shows convergence advantages in the later stages. Secondly, a protocol for data drift and historical parameter decay is designed to occur every 20,000 rounds. This method evaluates the algorithm's adaptability and its recovery effect during sudden changes in user preferences. During the scenarios involving conceptual drift, NeuralUCB and DecayVLinUCB achieve the lowest regret and the highest CTR recovery level, respectively. Additionally, DecayLinUCB demonstrates rapid convergence after a drift, achieving zero new regrets. The findings offer practical insights into applying MAB algorithms under dynamic conditions and suggest directions for future work on adaptive decay strategies.

title: Physical Adversarial Attack Technique Based on Fractal against Infrared Object Detector
authors: Guanxiao Liu, Lin Li, Bohan Liang, Jiafeng Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Thermal infrared object detection has been widely used in autonomous driving and safety monitoring, and modern deep learning techniques together with the availability of massive labeled data largely promote its advancements. However, recent deep learning approaches for thermal infrared object detection are vulnerable to well-designed sample attacks and have potential safety risks. Existing adversarial attack methods of introducing pixel-level perturbation in the white-box manners are mainly designed for visible light scenes and challenging to apply in infrared scenes for two reasons. Firstly, it is difficult to model the attacks in the physical world that originate from the sensor level. Secondly, the introduced patterns may be inadequate for adversarial training because infrared sensors with limited resolution could not resolve intricate and fine-grained patterns. To this end, this study firstly examines the existing challenges from the perspective of fractal theory, and then proposes an innovative adversarial attack strategy based on fractal geometry-inspired self-similarity pattern loss function. The proposed loss function is based on a universal observation that the resolution of the adversarial pattern received by the sensors decreases with the increase of attack range, which can be well modeled by fractal-geometry-based self-similarity measurement. Empirical evidence indicates that patches trained with fractal loss exhibit an effective attack distance approximately doubled compared with the original one.

title: Real-Time Detection and Extraction of Invasive Aquatic Weeds Using YOLO and Autonomous Robotics: A Sustainable Solution
authors: Mrunal Pawar, Nihar Ranjan, Vaibhav Patil, Sanika Naik, Rutika Shetty, Pravin Bhoyar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Water hyacinth (Eichhornia crassipes) is among the most invasive aquatic weeds worldwide, posing significant ecological, economic, and health threats. This paper introduces an autonomous robotic system powered by artificial intelligence for detecting and removing water hyacinth in real time. The system integrates deep learning models, including YOLOv5 for rapid object detection and CNNs for robust classification, deployed on a Raspberry Pi-based platform with a high-resolution camera and mechanical extraction unit. The hardware design incorporates lightweight, corrosion-resistant materials and precision-actuated conveyor mechanisms. Extensive field testing under diverse environmental conditions demonstrates a mean average precision (mAP) of $96.8 \%$, with robust adaptability, low energy consumption, and effective biomass removal. This solution presents a scalable, chemical-free alternative to traditional control methods and establishes a blueprint for AI-powered environmental robotics.

title: Research on the Current Situation, Core Challenges and Countermeasures for High-Quality Development of China's Nanomaterials Industry
authors: Xiaolin Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The global nanomaterials industry continued to expand. China has become one of the largest nanomaterials markets in the world. The industrial chain covers the entire process from raw material preparation to terminal applications, and a healthy competitive ecosystem has been formed with the support of policies. This study systematically analyzes the current situation, innovation trends and challenges of the nanomaterials industry development. To break through the development barriers, the following measures were taken: first, strengthening policy guidance and top-level design; second, promoting breakthroughs in core technologies and process upgrades; third, optimizing the industrial ecosystem and service system; fourth, building a green circular industrial system. With the accelerated integration of interdisciplinary technologies, nanomaterials will evolve towards high-performance, low-cost and environmental friendly directions, further empowering intelligent manufacturing and sustainable development.

title: Research on Digital Image Correlation (DIC) & Key Technologies Driven by AI: A Review
authors: Lei Liu, Ruifa Feng, Bin Li, Huazan Zhong, Wei Xiao, Ruihan Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper reviews the current status of DIC technology and the research progress of its integration with artificial intelligence (AI). First, the basic principles and development history of DIC technology are introduced, focusing on the core steps such as image acquisition, feature matching and deformation analysis, and its application in aerospace and biomedicine is discussed. Secondly, focusing on the AI-driven DIC technology innovation, it points out the key role of deep learning in high-precision image matching, complex data analysis and automated processing, such as convolutional neural network (CNN) to improve matching efficiency and recurrent neural network (RNN) to optimize time series analysis. Current research faces challenges such as matching accuracy of complex deformation scenes, real-time processing of large-scale data and lack of annotated data. Future development directions include using transfer learning to reduce training costs, multimodal data fusion to improve generalization ability, and cloud computing and edge computing to support real-time monitoring systems. The deep integration of AI and DIC has significantly expanded the boundaries of technology application and has broad prospects in the field of intelligent manufacturing.

title: Research on Personal Information Security Protection Mechanisms Driven by Encrypted Blockchain
authors: Yuan Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of digitization, issues such as information leakage, tampering, and misuse have become increasingly prominent. Against this backdrop, this paper focuses on security mechanisms represented by encrypted blockchain technology. It proposes a personal information storage and transmission model based on blockchain, leveraging its decentralized, tamper-proof, and traceable characteristics. The entire process is protected using cryptographic techniques including hashing and asymmetric encryption, thereby forming a comprehensive scheme for safeguarding personal privacy data. Simulation experiments were conducted to evaluate the proposed scheme, and its validity was demonstrated. The results show that the scheme offers strong capabilities in protecting data security and resisting hacking attacks, effectively ensuring the integrity, confidentiality, and traceability of information. Moreover, it achieves a well-balanced trade-off between security and system efficiency. This study introduces a novel approach to addressing data security challenges in the digital era, providing theoretical support for building a reliable ecosystem for personal information protection.

title: A Unified EKF Framework for SOC and Parameter Estimation in NCR type Lithium-Ion Batteries: Modeling and Comparison with Coulomb Counting
authors: Haimavatinandan Pati, Anup Ashish Dash, Ayush Kumar Sahu, Subham Shibasis Ghose, Mainak Biswas, Arnab Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In the current scenario of the vehicle industry, there is a growing demand for electric vehicles. Electric vehicles work on batteries that require a battery management system for better battery life. The performance of the battery decreases as the number of charging-discharging cycles increases. For a battery management system, it is essential to estimate the state of charge of a battery. To enhance the performance of the battery, proper estimation of the state of charge is necessary. There are various methods for state of charge estimation like the coulomb counting method, open-circuit voltage method, and Kalman filters. In this paper, we propose a unified dual extended Kalman filtering framework for estimation of battery parameters and state of charge of a lithium-ion battery. Additionally, a comparison has been shown between the above framework and other commonly used estimation methods in industries like extended Kalman filter with recursive least squares, and enhanced coulomb counting method. The results show that the dual extended Kalman filtering method is by far the best option for state of charge estimation as compared with the other methods discussed in this paper.

title: Low-Resource Language Identification Using Convolutional Recurrent Neural Networks for Indian Languages
authors: Sneha V Naik, Arpita M Angadi, Pallavi Annappa Sampangi, Satish Chikkamath, Suneeta.V. Budihal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Language identification is critical in facilitating effective communication, particularly in multilingual regions like India, where many languages and dialects exist. However, the challenge becomes more pronounced when dealing with region-specific low-resource languages, which are underrepresented in global datasets and often overlooked in research. This study addresses the gap in language identification for such low-resource languages, with a specific focus on Indian languages. While existing literature highlights the importance of language identification, little work has been done for low-resource languages, especially in the Indian context. To tackle this issue, we propose a deep learning-based solution using a Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN) model to identify low-resource languages from audio datasets. We focus on four languages—Sindhi, Assamese, Manipuri, and Malayalam—and use Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) features extracted from audio samples collected from sources like Kaggle and AI4 Bharat. The CRNN model is trained on these features to accurately identify the language, overcoming the limitations of the scarcity of labeled data. The results demonstrate the model's potential in addressing language identification challenges for low-resource languages, ultimately contributing to better communication in linguistically diverse regions.

title: Majority Logic Based Hybrid Nonvolatile Full Adder for CIM Architecture
authors: Vijayalatha Devadiga, Prashanth Barla, Somashekara Bhat
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) based computation-in-memory (CIM) architecture has emerged as the most promising alternative to the conventional vonNeumann architecture for future digital integrated circuits. It addresses critical challenges such as the memory wall and excessive standby power dissipation. Leveraging this architecture, we have developed a hybrid non-volatile full adder (HNVFA) based on majority logic. The operational behavior of the proposed HNVFA is presented in detail, followed by a comprehensive performance analysis. HNVFA has been compared against a conventional counterpart with respect to power dissipation, worst-case read delay, and device count. Results indicate that the proposed HNVFA outperforms the conventional design, particularly in terms of reduced power consumption.

title: Optimizing Data Availability and Performance in Cloud Storage with Hybrid Network-Coding and Object-Based Storage Systems
authors: Chintan Pamnani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: As cloud storage systems scale to handle increasing data volumes, balancing high availability and efficient resource use becomes critical. Traditional replication methods are storage-heavy and underutilize distributed parallelism. I propose NCVFS, a Network-Coding-based Distributed Video File System, that integrates network coding with object-based storage to enhance cloud storage efficiency and fault tolerance. NCVFS supports large video file storage using efficient coding techniques while preserving existing storage logic. It introduces a centralized metadata system to avoid bottlenecks and features a lightweight recovery mechanism to reduce downtime during node failures. By decoupling metadata management from the data path and supporting flexible coding schemes, NCVFS improves availability, scalability, and storage efficiency. Experimental results show that NCVFS significantly outperforms replication-based systems in terms of resource utilization and reliability, offering a viable solution for modern cloud storage needs.

title: Evaluating Hallucinations in Large Language Models(LLM):Metrics and Mitigation
authors: Thrilok. Koll, Tina Babu, Rekha R Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Large Language Models’ (LLMs’) quick development has transformed natural language processing and made it possible to produce content that appears human in a variety of applications. One major issue that still exists, though, is the problem of hallucinations, in which LLMs generate information that is not supported by the incoming data or empirical knowledge. These hallucinations pose hazards in crucial applications, including the legal, medical, and educational fields, by compromising the quality and dependability of AIgenerated content. Resolving this issue is essential for enhancing the reliability and practical applications of LLMs. Through a thorough approach that incorporates quantitative measures and visualization techniques, this study seeks to assess hallucinations in LLMs. The overall objective is to establish robust methods for identifying, quantifying, and comparing hallucination patterns across different models and applications. Through the scrutiny of the performance of different large language models (LLMs), the research seeks to determine patterns and causative factors of hallucinations. Developing more accurate and dependable models will be facilitated in the process. The findings of the investigation should enable us to better comprehend the mechanisms of hallucinations and develop effective mitigation strategies.

title: An Assembly Instruction-Based Machine Learning Approach for Detecting Cryptocurrency Malware
authors: Liu Jiannan, Dang Lina, Liu Xinning
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of cryptojacking malware incurred a serious threat to network security. The traditional signature-based detection method is difficult to cope with new cryptojacking malware variants. In this paper, we propose a detection method based on malware assembly instruction feature extraction and machine learning. First, the assembly instruction sequences of malware are extracted through disassembly techniques; second, the assembly instruction sequences are processed using the n-gram algorithmic to generate feature vectors; finally, the classification model is trained using machine learning algorithms. Experimental results show that Random Forest model with 3-gram or 4-gram features can effectively detect cryptojacking malware with high accuracy and F-score.

title: Image Encryption and Decryption using Deep Learning: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Varnika Sharma, Laxmi Shrivastava, Neeraj Shrivastava
abstract: Image encryption and decryption is one of the sensitive components in modern data security by safeguarding the integrity, confidentiality, and privacy of sensitive visual information. In this work, a comprehensive review of various image encryption and decryption approaches using deep learning is presented. It begins with an overview of traditional image encryption schemes, followed by an in-depth discussion of various deep learning-based image encryption schemes. The review explores the application of recurrent neural networks (RNNs), auto-encoders, long Short Term Memory (LSTMs), conventional neural networks (CNNs), and generative adversarial networks (GANs) in the field of image cryptography. Additionally, a comparative analysis of these schemes is provided, highlighting their strengths and weaknesses. This comparative analysis demonstrates that auto-encoder based schemes are more suitable for image encryption and decryption in terms of time and space complexity, especially for lightweight or smart devices that requires high speed communication and low space requirement.

title: Energy management of fuel cell-battery hybrid electric vehicle in mountainous regions using real time dynamic rule-based approach
authors: Sandeep Kumar, Ankur Bhattacharjee
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: For the fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs), environmental factors, especially in mountainous areas with steep slopes, significantly affect the vehicle energy demand and corresponding fuel consumption, thus impacting fuel efficiency and longevity. The current research falls short of providing energy management strategies tailored to these demanding terrains. The energy management strategy (EMS) for fuel cell battery hybrid electric vehicle (FCBHEV) in mountainous regions is designed to optimize the required power distribution, enhance energy efficiency, and ensure vehicle reliability under challenging terrains. By dynamically managing energy flow between the fuel cell system, traction battery, and regenerative braking, the EMS minimizes fuel consumption and maximizes battery longevity. Tailored for steep gradients and fluctuating demands, this system improves overall vehicle performance and offers sustainable mobility solutions for rugged landscapes.

title: Performance Evaluation of Routing Algorithms in FANETs for Disaster Management System: A Lab-Based Study
authors: Nitin Madhu, Vishnuvarthan R, Vishnu S
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In recent years, UAVs have been used for disaster relief operations, search and rescue operations, military patrols, ecological surveys, and many other applications. One of the most exciting developments in this area is the emergence of Flying Ad-hoc Networks (FANETs). FANETs resemble Mobile Ad-hoc Networks (MANETs) and Vehicle Ad-hoc Networks (VANETS), where the drones can form a communication network with no pre-established fixed infrastructure. Creating their communication network can be very useful in civilian and defence contexts where real-time exchange of timely information between the UAVs can be a life-or-death determination. However, those simple acts of flying drones around are not enough to create useful communication networks between them. The same two characteristics of FANETs that make them attractive, the mobility and continually changing topology of drones, make the development of routing protocols that are reliable but timely problematic. Given that the routing protocol will control the performance of the whole network, developing routing protocols that adequately balance cost, reliability, and timely delivery in the dynamic UAV environment remains a challenging problem. In this study, the effectiveness of several UAV routing protocols is examined, including Ad-Hoc On-Demand Distance Vector (AODV), Destination Sequenced Distance Vector (DSDV), and Dynamic Source Routing (DSR). These protocols’ performance is evaluated using a variety of measures, including Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR), Throughput, and End-to-End Delay. The findings estimate the effectiveness of routing processes. This research carefully explores how different routing protocols function under the given application of disaster management scenarios and search and rescue missions.

title: Inferring CAF-1/p60 Expression from Hematoxylin and Eosin Stained Images in Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma
authors: Cristian Tommasino, Cristiano Russo, Angela Crispino, Stefania Staibano, Antonio M. Rinaldi, Francesco Merolla
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining remains a standard of histopathological diagnostics due to its efficiency, affordability, and ubiquity. However, its lack of molecular specificity often necessitates complementary immunohistochemistry (IHC) to detect protein-level biomarkers critical for diagnosis and treatment planning. In scenarios where IHC is impractical, due to cost, limited tissue, or logistical constraints, computational alternatives may provide viable solutions. In this study, we investigate the feasibility of predicting CAF-1/p60 protein expression directly from H&E-stained slides using deep learning. Leveraging a curated dataset of oral squamous cell carcinoma samples with nucleus-level annotations, we classify nuclei into three categories: (i) Tumor-CAF-1/p60-positive, (ii) Tumor-CAF1/p 6 0-negative, and (iii) stromal. Our results demonstrate that Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) can learn morphological cues indicative of protein expression, achieving promising classification performance at the single-cell level. This approach may enable more accessible molecular profiling from routine H&E slides, reducing dependency on specialized staining procedures in resource-constrained or time-sensitive settings.

title: Modelling Electric Vehicle Energy Consumption for Smart Grid Management using AI
authors: Kunal Goyal, Dhiraj Matlani, Surbhit Pratik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Mass applications of Electric Vehicle (EV) necessitate the prediction of energy consumption during charging to prevent critical concerns regarding grid stability and infrastructure's optimisation, and enable renewable integration in the grid. This paper presents a machine learning based aggregate energy consumption predictor for single EV charge sessions with accuracy. Our strategy differs in two respects: first, in the use of a significant EV charge occasions dataset with varying diversity and the use of practice of wide-ranging feature engineering; and second, in the invention of new temporally biased indicators, i.e., day of the week and part of the day, and the use of advanced interaction features of the form charge-distance interaction, kWh-time interaction, and kWh-dollars ratio, which account for nonlinear inter-prts of EV charge inter-action omitted otherwise. After a complete comparative investigation with a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), a Support Vector Regressor (SVR), and a specially tuned Random Forest Regressor, the results indicate the specially tuned Random Forest Regressor dominating the rest of the state-of-the-art contenders in accuracy. Our tuned Random Forest-based estimator captures a larger <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> with a score of 0.765. This capability of explanation confirms the reasonableness of the model and its applicability in real-world scenarios. The findings of the research are of great significance for influential stakeholders like grid managers, energy suppliers, and urban planners. They enable the availability of data for the application of innovative charging policies with a proactive approach, optimization of grid load management, and acceleration of the shift toward a clean energy system. The study is not just the explanation of the rationale of the sound forecasting methodology, but also reaffirms the new field of AI-based energy management.

title: Near Zero Ripple Input Current Quadratic Boost Converter
authors: B. Charan, S. Raghavendran, K. Venkatesan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper presents a near-zero-ripple input current (NZQBC) with high voltage gain boost converter. The proposed converter is derived by incorporating an auxiliary inductor-capacitor cell to a quadratic boost converter to nullify the current through the input inductor to ensure a ripple-free input current and to achieve wide voltage transfer ratio between the source and load. The steady state analysis and design of passive components for the proposed converter is carried out. The converter circuit performance is validated through simulations.

title: Verification and Validation of Dynamic Reconfiguration in Integrated Modular Avionics With a Matlab/Simulink Arinc 653 Blockset
authors: Bojan Lukić, Umut Durak, Matthias Klimmek, Neelakanta Erabhovi, Umayr Jahagirdar, Manju Nanda
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The development of safety-critical avionics systems demands a great rigor for structured engineering practices. Model-Based Design (MBD) has emerged as a methodology, where models with their formal/semi-formal basis are not only used to specify and eventually automate the implementation of the systems but also provide means to produce evidence regarding their dependability. MBD fosters the tight coupling between system design and simulation. Simulation, the execution of the models, enables virtual verification and validation (V&V). Thereby the feedback cycles are shortened and faster design iterations are enabled. In this paper, we present a virtual V&V approach for the dynamic reconfiguration features in an Integrated Modular Avionics (IMA) system using MBD. The IMA platform and the applications are modeled using the MATLAB/Simulink ARINC 653 Blockset. The model simulation is used for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V \& V$</tex> of the reconfiguration mechanisms that are designed for fault adaptation. The demonstration consists of a model of the IMA platform and simulation for the reconfiguration of platform components during runtime. The fidelity of the simulation towards its intended hardware environment is increased with parameter considerations from an exemplary embedded system. We report agile development using MBD and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V \& V$</tex> in simulation with results matching tests from the referenced embedded hardware.

title: A Novel Two-Stage BiLSTM-XGBoost Hybrid Model for Drive Failure Prediction in Data Center
authors: Shilpi Gupta, George Asirvatharaj
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Hard Disk drive failures in data centers introduce significant challenges, including data loss, downtime, service outages and increased operational costs. Traditional ML (Machine learning) and DL (Deep Learning) models struggle to deliver satisfactory prediction due to poor generalization and high data imbalance issue. This study introduces novel hybrid model that combines Sequential Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) with Multi-head Attention (MHA) and an optimized XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) with an adaptive learning-rate scheduler. The model undergoes extensive data preprocessing using different polynomial feature interactions which capture non-linear relations among SMART data to achieve high degree correlation and failure pattern over the time. Additionally, we apply the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling technique (SMOTE) along with a class weighted loss function to tackle class imbalance. The two-stage approach is based on the strengths of both models: BiLSTM’s ability to learn sequential patterns and XGBoost’s capability to handle non-linear relationships. Further model training is enhanced by dynamically adjusting learning rate using adaptive learning rate scheduler to improve model’s accuracy and efficiency. Proposed model is tested using pivotal metrics including Accuracy, False Alarm Rate (FAR), Failure detection rate (FDR), F1-score and precision-recall. Experimental results show enhanced performance with accuracy, precision and F1-score in the range of $\sim 99 \%$, FDR/recall up to $97.86 \%$ and FAR reduced to $\sim 0.248 \%$ with bootstrap confidence interval of [0.9917, 0.9962].

title: Single-Stage Solar Photovoltaic-Based EV Battery Charging with MPPT and Charging Current Control
authors: Varsha Sahu, Rajan Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper proposes a single-stage power conversion in solar photovoltaic (PV) systems, focusing on its ability to perform maximum power point tracking (MPPT) and efficient charging of batteries. The proposed single-stage converter reduces the number of components by eliminating the need for multiple converters and improves system efficiency by streamlining the power conversion process during battery charging. For efficient MPPT, the design integrates a proportional-integral (PI) controller with a boost converter topology. This also optimizes the battery charging process. The system’s ability to reduce voltage fluctuations and maintain a steady-state voltage is demonstrated. The feasibility of this strategy with a PV system is demonstrated by simulation results that show enhanced energy harvesting from solar cells. Rapid climatic fluctuations are considered to analyze the steady-state, dynamic, and initial conditions of the suggested framework, which is simulated and displayed in MATLAB (R2018a). The system is thoroughly analysed through real-time experimental validation.

title: Ovarian Cancer Detection using Soft-Attention-Enhanced EfficientNet and Confidence Interval Evaluation
authors: K Deepthi Reddy, Guggilla Narender, Praveen Prakash, S Parvathi, N Samatha
abstract: Ovarian cancer is among the deadliest forms of gynecological cancers, primarily because it progresses without noticeable symptoms and is often detected only in its advanced stages. Recent improvements in the deep neural networks and their capability have shown significant potential in improving early detection by leveraging medical imaging analysis. We propose a novel soft-attention mechanism-enhanced EfficientNetB0 model for robust ovarian cancer detection. Furthermore, we present a robust analysis of best performing models, including EfficientNetB0, EfficientNetB1, VGG-16, VGG-19, and ResNet-50, applied to ovarian cancer diagnosis. By Utilizing publicly available datasets, we evaluate performance of these models', highlighting metrics such as accuracy, precision, and F1-score. Notably, this novel model demonstrates superior performance, outperforming EfficientNetB0, VGG-16, VGG-19, and ResNet-50 by an average margin of 7.45% in accuracy, 8.23% in F1-score, and 6.18% in precision. This enhancement is ascribed to the integration of attention processes with EfficientNetB0’s compound scaling and optimised architecture, facilitating greater feature extraction and model efficiency. This paper identifies shortcomings in current approaches and suggests future research areas, serving as a crucial resource for enhancing deep learning-based ovarian cancer diagnosis.

title: Enhancing Human-Computer Interaction Through Facial Electromyography: Analyzing Frontalis and Masseter Muscle Signals
authors: Sarah Lodhi, Hamza Ibrahim, Infal Rizwan, Atiqa Saleem
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: EMG signals from the frontalis and masseter muscles were employed in this research in an effort to enhance the knowledge in facial expressions and the accompanying physiological changes. The frontalis muscle which is the muscle that lifts eyebrows and causes wrinkles on the forehead is expected when one is shocked or inquisitive. The masseter muscle besides being a chewing muscle, is located at the jaw and is seen to clench in fatigue or stress and anger. The EMG data of these muscles in the human subjects was recorded through the BIOPAC Student Lab system while the subjects made certain facial movements.ical responses. The frontalis muscle, which is the eyebrow-lifting and forehead- wrinkling muscle, is expected when one is surprised or curious. The masseter muscle, besides serving as a chewing muscle, is situated at the jaw and clenches weary of stress and anger. Through the BIOPAC Student Lab system, the electrical activity was recorded of these muscles in the human subjects while they moved their faces in particular ways. The collected signals were then displayed and processed with LabVIEW so as to view both the time and frequency domains. This work shows the benefits of using EMG for such applications as emotion recognition and HCI, proving that EMG can improve the interaction between a user and a computer by recognizing the user's state and goals.

title: Design and Development of Intelligent Expressway using Edge Computing and Internet of Things
authors: Nitin Shukla, Rakesh Kumar
abstract: The rapid growth of vehicle traffic on expressways demands innovative approaches to ensure sustainability, efficiency, and safety. This paper presents the design and implementation of an Intelligent Expressway system leveraging Edge Computing and the Internet of Things (IoT). A network of distributed IoT sensors and edge devices enables real-time traffic monitoring, accident detection, and environmental sensing. Edge processing minimizes latency and reduces dependence on centralized cloud computing by handling initial data filtering and analysis locally. Machine learning models deployed at edge nodes identify congestion, anomalies, and potential hazards. Processed data is transmitted to the cloud for historical analysis and enhanced decision-making. The system integrates automated responses such as dynamic message signs, traffic signal control, and emergency alerts to ensure timely driver assistance. Prototype results demonstrate the system’s potential to reduce travel time, enhance road safety, and mitigate environmental impact, highlighting the promise of Edge-IoT integration in modern traffic infrastructure.

title: Weighted Ensemble Frameworks for Predictive Accuracy in Water Quality Classification
authors: Preet Singh, Taniya Hasija, Kr Ramkumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The water quality influences public health and environmental sustainability, and increased levels of pollution demand far more efficient methods of measurement and classification. This article applies machine learning algorithms; namely, CatBoost, XGBoost, and LGBoost, in a weighted voting ensemble for the classification of water quality across various safety levels. The ensemble approach achieved the highest accuracy at $\mathbf{9 4. 3 7}$ per cent, overtaking individual models such as CatBoost at 93.97 per cent and XGBoost at 93.45 per cent. Cross-validation results showed slight variations in the results, showing how stable the ensemble model is when different subsets of data are used. Hence, these results point to the benefit of using ensemble techniques that enhance predictive accuracy by balancing the strengths of each model. This study demonstrates the efficacy of ensemble methods for reliable water quality classification and provides a foundation for scalable environmental monitoring solutions. This approach may facilitate continuous, AI-driven water quality assessments, which can provide timely insights into sustainable water resource management.

title: Improved ARIMA-BP Algorithm for Safety Control of Railway Cable-Stayed Bridge Construction Under Uncertain Wind Loads
authors: Zeshui Hong, Guowei Liao, Guodong Mei, Chao Gao, Zhangbiao Long, Chen Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved ARIMA-BP combined algorithm to construct an integrated framework for wind load prediction and safety control. This algorithm combines the linear prediction capabilities of ARIMA with the nonlinear fitting advantages of a BP neural network through an adaptive weighting mechanism, and introduces an optimized control strategy based on the wind load fluctuation intensity index. Simulation experiments using a cable-stayed bridge at LWTL demonstrate that the improved algorithm achieves wind load predictions with RMSE of $0.82 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and MAE of $0.65 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, respectively, which are 41.4% and 42.0% lower than those of traditional ARIMA. The accuracy of extreme wind predictions reaches 85%. The prediction-based active control strategy limits the maximum horizontal displacement of the main girder to 0.15 m (a 53.1% reduction compared to passive control), the cable tension fluctuation amplitude to $\pm 2.8 \%(92 \%$ compliance rate), and the peak stress of the bridge tower to 21.3 MPa (within the design limit).

title: A Novel q-component Based Time-Voltage-Current Characteristics for Microgrid Protection Using Numerical Relays with FPGA Implementation
authors: N Praneeth, STP Srinivas, Alivelu M Parimi, M Balasubba Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The proliferation of inverter-based resources (IBRs) in microgrids pose considerable challenges in fault detection and protection, primarily due to low fault current availability and the operational transitions between grid-connected and islanded modes. This paper proposes a novel q-component based time-voltage-current characteristics (qTVCC) for coordinated numerical relaying for the protection of microgrids. The proposed qTVCC leverages the distinctive pre-fault and post-fault behavior of the q-component of bus voltage for enhanced fault detection. To facilitate seamless protection coordination, unified relay settings that remain effective in both grid-connected and islanded modes are derived. The proposed qTVCC is validated on a 12-bus microgrid test system through hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) testing using a field programmable gate array (FPGA) platform. Results demonstrate the effectiveness of the qTVCC in achieving reliable and coordinated fault protection in complex microgrid scenarios.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Neural Network Complexity in Constrained Hardware Environments
authors: Vladimir Sibinović, Anđela Jovanović, Boban Veselić
abstract: This paper focuses on the challenge of deploying a neural network to be used for precise localization capabilities on the constrained hardware by exploring a novel strategy, transforming raw magnetic field sensor readings into accurate real-time magnet position estimations within a defined workspace. The collected dataset of magnetic field readings, corresponding to known magnet position, was used to train different configurations of feed forward neural networks. These configurations vary in key architectural parameters, including the number of hidden layers and the number of neurons per layer. The trained networks are evaluated for their total memory footprint and execution time on an 8-bit microcontroller. This methodology, demonstrated through the localization problem, is applicable to other machine learning application, including data classification and can be adapted for different hardware constrained devices.

title: Artificial Synaptic Memristor Based on Ag-ChG Material
authors: Kristina O. Čajko, Petr Kostka, Dalibor L. Sekulić
abstract: In this paper, the artificial synaptic memristor based on the chalcogenide doped with silver (Ag-ChG) was investigated from the standpoint of its potential application in neuromorphic systems. Preparation of the Ag-ChG material was carried out using melt-quenching technique, and its morphological properties were analysed by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Biological synaptic properties of memristor such as synaptic weight and short-term plasticity were studied together with its memristive characteristics. Namely, the current-voltage characteristics of artificial synaptic memristor based on Ag-ChG material were experimentally determined at several voltage biases using different voltage sweeps. When applying several consecutive voltage sweeps, the obtained results showed that synaptic memristor exhibits a typical short-term depression and short-term potentiation. In addition, the observed increase in the synaptic weight could be attributed to strengthening the connection between two artificial neurons, when it would be realized by using the memristor based on the Ag-ChG material.

title: Design and Evaluation of a Modern Controller Working Position Using High-Fidelity Mock-Ups
authors: Lennard Nöhren, Lukas Tyburzy, Marco-Michael Temme, Kathleen Muth, Thomas Hofmann, Deike Heßler, Felix Tenberg, Eilert Viet, Michael Wimmer, Roy Norbart
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: One of the most important tools for air traffic controllers (ATCO) is the controller working position (CWP) software, whose human-machine interface (HMI) design is crucial for enabling ATCOs to work safely, efficiently, and with proper situational awareness. To ensure the CWP meets the ATCO's needs and achieves high user acceptance, it is essential to involve them in early design decisions and throughout the development process. This study presents approaches of a more modern CWP design that was developed in a user-centered approach using high fidelity mock-ups with the goal of improving existing CWP designs and integrating advanced features such as weather visualization and trajectory advisories. The design was validated in multiple workshops with ATCOs, focusing on both basic features (e.g., colors, track label design and layout) and more sophisticated functionalities. The quantitative user experience evaluation and qualitative feedback analysis showed very positive results in regards to usability and acceptance, particularly for the integration of conflict advisories and the overall air situation display design. The findings also revealed areas for further enhancement, such as the presentation of weather information and the layout preferences. The validation methodology proved to be an effective and cost-efficient way to evaluate designs with users in early software development stages. The findings of this research provide valuable insights for the development of future CWPs, highlighting the potential benefits of adopting a usercentered design approach. While the low number of participants limits the generalizability of the findings, the study demonstrates the feasibility and benefits of this design approach and the use of high-fidelity mockups in the safety-critical air traffic control domain.

title: Wind and Hydro Energy Forecasting using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Kamalasegaran A, Dheepan S B, Gopika S, Sriramalakshmi P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This research provides an in-depth comparison of machine learning models to enhance the prediction of wind and hydro energy generation across India’s diverse regions: Southern, Northern, Eastern, Western, and North-Eastern. Leveraging historical data spanning a decade (March 2013 to March 2023), it evaluates the performance of Linear Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine Regressor, Extreme Gradient Boosting, and Long Short-Term Memory networks. Key metrics, including predictive accuracy, Root Mean Square Error, Mean Absolute Error, Coefficient of Determination, and Mean Absolute Percentage Error, highlight Long Short-Term Memory as the superior model for predictive accuracy. Building upon these insights, a multivariate Long Short-Term Memory model was deployed to forecast energy production over the next 30 days, complemented by a regional energy generation analysis. This study underscores the transformative potential of advanced machine learning techniques in driving sustainable energy management and future grid planning. Accurate forecasting can lead to better grid management, reduced operational costs, and increased reliability, contributing to sustainable development and a more stable power supply for communities and industries alike.

title: Multidimensional Decision Analysis Based on Random Forest and AHP - CRITIC Algorithm
authors: Hao Ge, Lan Zhang, Jinhang Zheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In this paper, the construction and application of a multidimensional assessment model of urban positioning is investigated by comprehensively applying Random Forest, AHP (Hierarchical Analysis Method) and CRITIC algorithm model. Firstly, a comprehensive evaluation model with 12 sub- indicators is constructed from multiple dimensions such as urban economic development to measure the impact of tourism on urban development. Secondly, the AHP is used to analyze the city positioning, and the weights of the indicators are determined by constructing judgment matrix, consistency checking and combination weighting, and the CRITIC method is introduced to reconcile the conflict between subjective and objective weights; finally, the Random Forest algorithm is used to optimize the comprehensive weights, and the optimal weight coefficients are determined by cross-validation to validate the classification effectiveness of the model and to carry out the analysis of the key indexes.

title: Early Detection and Intervention of Students’ Depression Risk Factors using Predictive Models: Insights and Implications
authors: Subhash Mondal, Amitabh Thakur, Anirudh Iyer, Rutu Patil
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Depression is a growing concern among college students, representing a substantial public health risk that adversely affects their well-being and induces chronic misery. Timely identification is essential to tackle this escalating issue. Determining the major factors of depression is crucial for formulating effective therapies.
