This study explores how the advancement of technology in healthcare can tackle overlooked mental health issues, like depression, using advanced machine learning approaches. The key objective is to develop, employ, and compare the effectiveness of different machine learning models for predicting depression in students. Furthermore, it identifies the key features of depression, demonstrating the driving potential of technology across various methods for early detection and prevention of depression using minimal data and more efficiently. By identifying the correlation and the key features contributing to depression, it helps in the development of tailored and effective intervention strategies. The study observed that the effect of the advanced sampling technique SMOTEENN and the feature importance by LGBM classifier found that boosting algorithms along with KNN showcased high accuracy in predicting student depression. Moreover, it showcased the significant impact of feature engineering and data balancing in improving the model’s performance. Also, a comparative analysis of different models offers insights into different algorithms’ strengths and weaknesses. This study successfully develops a machine learning-based prediction model that demonstrates strong capabilities in identifying key risk factors for student depression. This work paves the way for an advanced student depression monitoring system, facilitating better prevention and personalized intervention.

title: Electricity Price Forecasting based on Sliding Window BO-BiLSTM Framework considering Renewable Integration
authors: Ashish Prajesh, Prerna Jain, Satish Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: After the deregulation of electricity market, Electricity Price Forecasting (EPF) has emerged as a crucial task for all stakeholders, including generation and retail companies. The inherent complexity and non-linear relationships among the features associated with electricity prices have rendered traditional statistical models to give less efficient forecasting accuracy. This limitation has led to the emergence of deep-learning models, particularly Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks, which has the unique ability to handle all the challenges faced by statistical approaches. In this study, we propose a Sliding Window-based BiLSTM (SW-BiLSTM) model, which incorporates a sliding window learning-based mechanism to update the weights of the BiLSTM network. This approach enhances the model's ability to capture temporal dependencies and the nonlinear, stochastic behaviour of electricity prices. Additionally, the hyperparameters of the BiLSTM model are tuned by Bayesian Optimization to improve its accuracy. To mitigate the issue of overfitting, Recursive Feature Elimination with Cross-Validation (RFECV) is applied for feature selection, ensuring the retention of the most relevant features while eliminating redundant ones. The effectiveness of the proposed model is validated through an experimental comparative analysis with state-of-the-art benchmark models. Experimental results demonstrate that the SW-BO-BiLSTM model outperforms existing methods, establishing it as a robust and reliable solution for short-term EPF.

title: Order Reduction of High-Frequency Flyback Converters Using Direct Truncation: A Trade-Off Between Computational Efficiency and Accuracy
authors: Anmol Saket, N. Patnana, V. P. Singh, T. K. Bashihshta, Akhilesh Mathur, R. S. Meena
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The flyback converter is an essential and widely used DC-DC converter, particularly in low-to medium power applications. It is valued for its simplicity, cost-effectiveness, and inherent electrical isolation. To analyze the characteristics of flyback converter, it is represented as mathematical model. However, due to its complexity and higher-order, studying these models become challenging. This paper presents direct truncation method as model order reduction technique for reduced-order modeling of the flyback converter. This technique helps in preserving its critical performance characteristics. Step response, Bode plot, and Nichols plot analysis are performed for each reduced model. Comparative analysis is performed using both time-domain and frequency-domain specifications. Simulation results validate that method suitable for lower-order models and demonstrating improvements in settling time, transient response, and overall system efficiency.

title: Research on Path Planning for All-Terrain Automated Guided Vehicles Based on an Improved RRT Algorithm
authors: Yi Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The RRT algorithm, as a widely used and mature algorithm in path planning, plays an important role in the path planning of AGVs. Since all-terrain AGVs have different demand focuses in path planning compared to traditional AGVs, algorithm improvements need to be made based on these focuses. At present, the improvement of the RRT algorithm in most studies lies in shortening the path length and improving the smoothness of the path. There is a certain gap in path simplification. The topic of this study is to improve the RRT algorithm to achieve the goal of planning the path with the least energy consumption. Based on the improvement of the RRT algorithm, the operation process of simplifying the path has been added. It can achieve smoother and shorter path planning with more efficient operations. Under the condition of meeting the short path, almost all redundant nodes are eliminated. The number of nodes in the path is reduced by 90%, the computational load is reduced by 75% (obtained by comparing the number of iterations of redundant nodes), and the distance length is shortened by 43%. It can be applied in path planning for field operations.

title: Evaluation of the Graphics Capabilities of Next Generation Avionics GPUs
authors: Josué Pedrajas, Xavier Caricchio, Leonidas Kosmidis
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In this work, we describe the design and implementation of an open source avionics widget library, which can be used as a benchmark for the graphics capabilities of avionics GPUs and their software stacks. Next, we use this benchmark to compare the graphics performance capabilities of several embedded GPUs from the automotive domain and compare them to an AMD E8860 which is used in modern aircraft. Our results show that embedded GPUs have closed the performance gap with discrete avionics GPUs on graphics rendering.

title: Experimental Investigation on Performance Characteristics of Pem Fuel Cell
authors: Raghulnath D, Arjun AR, Aditya Kumar, Jose Thankachan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents an experimental investigation of a 20W passive airflow PEM fuel cell. The effect of variations in hydrogen flow rates: 100 ml/min, 200 ml/min, 300 ml/min, and 400 ml/min on key operational parameters such as temperature, voltage, current, and power output have been investigated. Each of the flow rates was tested for two operation durations: 1.5 hours and 4 hours to compare the behaviour of the fuel cell towards short-term and extended periods of operation. It was found that the hydrogen flow rate is well correlated with output performance metric values. Hydrogen flow was seen to improve the electrical power of the fuel cells with maximum values at the flow rate of 400 ml/min. However, at the same time a noticeable temperature rise was observed in the top-side bipolar plates during the test condition of 400 ml/min of hydrogen flow rate. Interestingly, at a flow rate of 300 ml/min, the fuel cell stabilized the output power faster than at the other flow rates, thus this could be an optimal condition for the hydrogen supply in the setup tested. Further, the study brings out the need to optimize the hydrogen flow rate to obtain a balance between performance and thermal management. The longer test times enabled further investigation of the thermal stability and robustness of the fuel cell under changing flow conditions. In this context, the 4-hour tests focused more on the important aspect of sustaining thermal performance in practical applications. Although the system's performance was evaluated without considering power electronics, in the future, additional studies can incorporate DC-DC converters to have regulated output as well as flexibility of the load. The results highlight that both performance and stability factors need to be taken into consideration during design for practical applications involving PEM fuel cells.

title:
Simulation and Optimization of AlGaN/GaN HEMTs Using HfO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Gate Oxide and Fe Trap Layer for High Power Performance
authors: P Harikrishnan, B Mohan, V R Navinkumar, T Nalini, R Ranjani, R Augustian Isaac, S Mahalakshmi
abstract: This research presents a comprehensive TCAD-based simulation and optimization of AlGaN/GaN High Electron Mobility Transistors (HEMTs) integrating a high-κ HfO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> gate dielectric and a Fe-doped GaN buffer layer for high-power and high-frequency applications. The device architecture incorporates a triple-stacked graded AlGaN barrier on a SiC substrate, designed to enhance polarization-induced charge density and channel confinement. Adopting HfO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> as the gate oxide significantly improves gate electrostatics, reduces leakage currents, and increases transconductance due to its superior dielectric properties. To further enhance device robustness and breakdown characteristics, a Fe-doped buffer layer introduces deep-level acceptor traps, effectively suppressing parasitic conduction and electric field crowding. The proposed structure is evaluated through TCAD simulations for critical parameters including breakdown voltage, drain current density, and transconductance under various bias conditions. The results demonstrate marked improvements in electrical performance, with enhanced breakdown strength, reduced current collapse, and improved channel control. The integration of high-κ dielectric engineering and buffer trap optimization positions this research as a significant contribution toward developing thermally stable, high-efficiency GaN-based devices for advanced power electronics and RF applications.

title: A Deep Learning Framework using Attention Mechanism for Human Activity Recognition
authors: Ashwani Senapati, Payal Das, Sanchita Priyadarshinee, Samit Ari
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid deep learning model integrating Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with attention blocks in order to improve the precision and robustness of Human Activity Recognition (HAR). The suggested method makes advantage of the features of both architectures: While attention blocks dynamically recalibrate channel-wise feature responses to underline valuable features and suppress less relevant ones, CNNs are used for effective extraction of spatial dependencies and local patterns from raw sensor data. This mix helps the model to manage noisy input data more efficiently and to learn more significant feature representations for activity classification. Using an end-to-end learning approach, the model jointly maximises spatial and channel-wise characteristics. Because it shows great generalisation across many activities and subjects, this integrated architecture is well-suited for a wide spectrum of realworld HAR applications including fitness tracking, healthcare monitoring, and smart settings. In the WISDM data set, a commonly used benchmark in HAR research, the model obtains an outstanding overall accuracy of $99.61 \%$ indicating its efficacy and its possible implementation in pragmatic situations.

title: Mitigating Congestion in IoT-Driven SDN Environments: An Intelligent Traffic-Aware Flow Optimization Approach
authors: Lokesh Kumar, Manmohan Sharma, Avtar Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The fast growth of IoT devices in SDN systems creates dynamic and bursty traffic patterns, causing congestion. Static routing protocols, heuristic-based load balancing, and standalone machine learning models (e.g., LSTM or GNN) cannot capture spatial network dependencies and temporal traffic dynamics, making them unable to adapt to real-time traffic fluctuations. LSTM models forecast sequential traffic but lack topological awareness, while GNNs grasp network topology but cannot model time-varying traffic behaviour. We present a Hybrid GNN+LSTM model that synergistically incorporates graph neural networks (GNNs) to overcome these limitations, LSTM networks were used for traffic prediction in time and spatial feature extraction. An attention method dynamically network conditions and traffic need to optimise path selection for Low, High, and Critical traffic classes in our model. Experimental data show that the hybrid technique outperforms standalone LSTM ($95 \%$ accuracy, 88.7 Mbps), GNN ($92 \%$ accuracy, 91.2 Mbps), and ViT ($90 \%$ accuracy, 86.9 Mbps) models with $97 \%$ accuracy, 95.4 Mbps throughput, and $1.82 \%$ packet. This reduces flow setup latency to 18.6 ms and ensures $97.1 \% \mathrm{QoS}$ adherence, making it effective for real-time congestion mitigation. The results show that spatial and temporal learning in SDN-based IoT networks provides a scalable and intelligent solution for traffic-aware flow optimisation.

title: A Method for Determining the Saliency of 3D Point Cloud Based on Lightweight Artificial Neural Network
authors: Huiting Wang, Pengfei Liu, Zhu Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In environments with sparse features, obstacles serve dual roles: they are not only potential hazards that mobile robots must evade but also critical navigation landmarks that provide salient point cloud information. To enhance the acquisition of informative and discriminative point cloud data by mobile robots, a quantitative assessment of 3D obstacle point cloud saliency is essential. Addressing the computational constraints of onboard systems, a method for determining the saliency of 3D point cloud based on lightweight artificial neural network is proposed. A typical unstructured simulation scenario was established to further validate the method proposed in the paper. The simulation results show that the classification accuracy of the network model on the test set reached 83%. Furthermore, when implemented in the simulated environment, the method effectively identifies environmental obstacle landmarks and accurately assesses their saliency levels.

title: A Hybrid Federated Learning and Deep Learning Approach for Time Series Forecasting in Distributed System
authors: K.Ramyalakshmi, Shweta Bansal, Vasujadevi Midasala, Paresh Tanna, Udutala Mahender, L. Bhagyalakshmi
abstract: Attempts by conventional recommendations to provide accurate customization have been thwarted by the proliferation of internet-based content and the increasing variety of users. Incorporating multi-preference models with methods for deep learning, this study presents an AI-enhanced suggestion engine. The platform uses a combination of neural network structure involving CNNs and RNNs to constantly collect customer preferences along multiple levels, including behavior, information, and historical trends. The algorithm uses a method of attention to give preferences evaluations and significant interactions between items and users greater significance, which improves suggestion correctness and customization. The multi-preference integrated layer is a game-changer because it unifies different kinds of info into one embedded distance, making it more flexible to respond to changing user preferences. The model has outstanding training capability with little excessive fitting, when developed and verified on freely available prescription samples. With respect to accuracy, exactness, recollection, and F1-score, the suggested system outperforms matrix factorizing, group filtering, and a content-driven approaches. The model achieves an accuracy of 91.4%, which is additional 5% superior to the cutting-edge comparisons. An improvement over previous recommendation methods, the suggested AI-enhanced suggester system shows increased computing efficacy, customisation, and resilience.

title: Simulation of Directional Droplet Spreading on Tri-Directionally Anisotropic Slippery Surface
authors: Meng Wang, Faze Chen, Minghao Li, Yanling Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Directional manipulation of liquid droplets is central to the advancement of microfluidics, thermal management, and water harvesting technologies. Here, we elucidate the mechanism underlying directional droplet growth and transport on a bioinspired tri-directional anisotropic slippery surface (TASS) through time-resolved imaging and numerical simulations. Our results reveal that droplets initially expand symmetrically but, upon reaching a critical volume, preferentially spread toward the lower step along the “down” gradient, where geometric asymmetry induces contact and a localized pinning effect. This pinning, coupled with an internal pressure gradient biased toward the “down” direction, drives directional droplet growth. As the droplet propagates, a vapor cavity emerges adjacent to the lower step, generating a transient pressure differential that lifts part of the droplet and facilitates step-to-step transition. We identify two primary factors governing this anisotropic transport: (i) structural asymmetry between adjacent steps that promotes early contact and spreading toward the lower step, and (ii) a persistent internal pressure gradient that reinforces unidirectional motion. The additional role of vapor-induced pressure differentials further enhances droplet elevation and mobility. These insights provide a mechanistic foundation for the design of next-generation anisotropic surfaces with tunable wetting properties, enabling precise control over droplet behavior in diverse technological contexts.

title: A distributed energy generation scheduling algorithm based on reinforcement learning
authors: Yunfei Tian, Huihui Xu, Jing Peng, Yi Chai
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the high proportion of distributed energy (DER) access, traditional centralized scheduling methods can not cope with the randomness and system complexity of renewable energy. In this paper, an optimization method for distributed energy generation scheduling based on reinforcement learning (RL) is proposed, which combines multi-agent near end strategy optimization (MAPPO) and flexible actor-critic (SAC) algorithm to achieve efficient and collaborative energy management. For centralized microgrid scenarios, SAC algorithm is used to optimize the combined output of photovoltaic, energy storage and traditional units, and its entropy maximization mechanism enhances exploration capabilities and effectively balances economic and environmental objectives. For distributed virtual power plants or multi-microgrid systems, MAPPO framework is used to realize cooperative scheduling among agents, and the contradiction between local observation and global optimization is solved through centralized training-distributed execution strategy. The simulation results show that the proposed method is significantly superior to the traditional optimization algorithm in reducing the operating cost, improving the consumption rate of renewable energy and ensuring the security of power grid. In addition, the convergence speed and strategy robustness of the algorithm are further improved by introducing preferential experience playback and hierarchical reinforcement learning. This study provides a scalable solution for intelligent scheduling of high-proportion renewable energy grids.

title: Cascaded Hybrid 19-Level Three-Phase Inverter with Small-Sized Switched-Capacitors
authors: Niraj Kishore, Kapil Shukla, Nitin Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: A new switched-capacitors (SCs)-based three-phase 19-level (19L) hybrid multi-level inverter (HMLI) has been proposed in this paper. The proposed topology features self-charging and voltage-balancing capabilities of the SCs, without adding any auxiliary circuit/sensor. A modified PWM (MPWM) technique is utilised to modulate the system. The MPWM results in improved output voltage profile and reduction in voltage ripple across the SCs. Moreover, the phase difference of 30-degree between the peak discharging current of the SCs and the peak line voltage further reduces the size of SCs by the factor of $\sqrt 3 /2$. The proposed structure is quantitatively compared with the latest similar topologies to demonstrate the advantages in the terms of less components count, low maximum blocking voltage (MBV), low total standing voltage (TSV), lessened total harmonic distortion (THD), lowered cost function (CF) per level, and boosted output voltage. MATLAB/Simulink environment is utilised to verify the proposed topology and to confirm the feasibility of its operations at steady-state and dynamic conditions, a laboratory prototype is developed.

title: Quantum Enhanced Anomaly Detection for ADS-B Data Using Hybrid Deep Learning
authors: Rani Naaman, Felipe Gohring de Magalhaes, Jean-Yves Ouattara, Gabriela Nicolescu
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The emerging field of Quantum Machine Learning (QML) has shown promising advantages in accelerating processing speed and effectively handling the high dimensionality associated with complex datasets. Quantum Computing (QC) enables more efficient data manipulation through the quantum properties of superposition and entanglement. In this paper, we present a novel approach combining quantum and classical machine learning techniques to explore the impact of quantum properties for anomaly detection in Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B) data. We compare the performance of a Hybrid-Fully Connected Quantum Neural Network (H-FQNN) with different loss functions and use a publicly available ADSB dataset to evaluate the performance. The results demonstrate competitive performance in detecting anomalies, with accuracies ranging from 90.17% to 94.05%, comparable to the performance of a traditional Fully Connected Neural Network (FNN) model, which achieved accuracies between 91.50% and 93.37%.

title: Translation of Artificial Intelligence-Based Virtual Reality Interaction Design Optimization Model
authors: Wei Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of Virtual Reality (VR) technology, its applications have become increasingly widespread across multiple domains including education, healthcare, entertainment, and industry. However, current virtual reality systems still face issues such as interaction lag, insufficient personalization, and weak user immersion. To enhance virtual reality interaction experiences, this paper proposes an artificial intelligence-based virtual reality interaction design optimization model. By incorporating deep learning and behavior recognition algorithms, the model can collect and intelligently analyze user behavior data in real-time within virtual environments, dynamically adjusting interaction interfaces and methods to achieve personalized, intelligent interaction experiences. Additionally, the model employs reinforcement learning mechanisms to continuously optimize interaction strategies through user feedback. Experimental validation was conducted across multiple typical virtual reality application scenarios, with results showing that the model effectively improves system response speed and interaction naturalness, enhancing user immersion and satisfaction. The research findings provide theoretical foundations and technical support for intelligent optimization of virtual reality interaction design, offering broad application prospects.

title: Tomato Leaf Disease Detection Using EfficientNetB3
authors: Manogna Velamakanni, Satya Sandeep Kanumalli, Arepalli Peda Gopi, Vejendla Lakshman Narayana, Visramsetty Sujatha, Alapati Naresh
abstract: Tomato farming is an important agricultural activity, but leaf diseases in tomato plants can cause extraordinary yield loss. Tomato leaf disease has an important impact on agricultural production, and thus early and precise detection is essential. Deep learning architectures have been used to replace human inspection, minimizing errors and inefficiencies and enhancing disease detection. The models utilize neural networks to automatically extract relevant patterns from images, enhancing detection rates. But conventional models VGG19 (Visual Geometry Group), ResNet50 (Residual Network), and CNNs (Convolutional Neural Networks) are plagued by high computational complexity and overfitting, hindering real-world applications. These drawbacks result in inefficient feature extraction, rendering them inappropriate for resource-limited environments and large-scale deployment. To overcome these limitations, we introduce an EfficientNetB3-based model optimized for maximum feature extraction and computational efficiency. Our model utilizes depth-wise convolution and improved parameter efficiency to enhance accuracy and robustness. With 95.8% classification accuracy, it outperforms current architectures significantly in the detection of tomato leaf disease.

title: Improving Fruit Detection and Quality Analysis via HSI and Deep Learning
authors: Hari Krishna H, Aradhana D, Azhar Baig M, Manjunath Y Kammar, Jagadish R M, Hayath T M
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Fruits include necessary elements such as vitamins, pro-vitamins, organic acids, and natural sugars that promote immunity, eyesight, and general health, making them an indispensable part of human nutrition. Fruit quality must be maintained since it influences handling, storage, marketing, and consumer acceptance after harvest. The fruit detection and quality evaluation process may be delayed and inconsistent if manual inspection is used exclusively. For accurate fruit evaluation, HSI offers a non-destructive substitute because of its capacity to gather both spectral and spatial information. However, HSI data often suffers from noise, uneven lighting, and artifacts, necessitating effective pre-processing. Techniques such as Nearest Neighbor Interpolation (NNI) for normalization, CLAHE for contrast enhancement, and Median Filtering(MF) for noise removal help improve image clarity and reliability. Following pre-processing, the You Only Look Once(YOLO) algorithm is applied for fast and accurate fruit detection and quality. This conceptual approach enhances the precision, efficiency of fruit detection and quality evaluation in agricultural applications.

title: Simulation Study on Human-Like Decision-Making and Planning for Intelligent Vehicles Based on Deep Learning
authors: Dengqiang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The rapid evolution of emerging intelligent technologies notably cloud computing, big data, and artificial intelligence has catalyzed a paradigm shift in vehicular intelligence. Targeting autonomous driving systems, this study proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework leveraging single-step momentum updates. By engineering human-inspired reward functions and optimizing hyper parameters for the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm, our approach achieves human-like spatiotemporal decision-making for lane-changing targets, with extensive validation in The Open Racing Car Simulator (TORCS) demonstrating that the strategy generates lane-changing spatiotemporal targets exhibiting >93% behavioral consistency versus human drivers (measured by DTW distance); and enables adaptive-duration trajectory planning that dynamically adjusts maneuver timing based on traffic context for smoother integration into mixed traffic flows.

title: Early Detection of Breast Cancer Using Supervised Machine Learning: A Comparative Analysis of Classifiers
authors: Prajwal Hegde N, Sanjana, Shridevi Bhat, Prathiksha Shetty, Srinidhi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: This research investigates the role of machine learning techniques in the early diagnosis of breast cancer. The Breast Cancer Wisconsin (Diagnostic) dataset, consisting of 569 records with 30 tumor-related features, was used to evaluate four classifiers: Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, and Naïve Bayes. Prior to training, the data underwent preprocessing and normalization. Among the models, the Support Vector Machine demonstrated superior performance, achieving an accuracy of 98% with precision, recall, and F1-score values approaching 0.99. The results emphasize the effectiveness of machine learning, particularly SVM, in supporting clinicians with accurate and dependable breast cancer diagnosis.

title: Rapid diagnosis of osteosarcoma and bone callus through convolutional neural networks and image processing
authors: Jiaxin Lv, Yulong Yan, Yihan Xu, Yuhan Wang, Xiaming Gu, Minmin Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge posed by the high morphological similarity between osteosarcoma and bone callus in pathological images. We developed a deep learning diagnostic approach that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) with a Transformer encoder to enable rapid and accurate classification of osteosarcoma and bone callus in high-resolution whole slide images (WSIs). A retrospective analysis was performed on 62 cases (29 osteosarcoma and 33 bone callus) confirmed between April 2022 and December 2024 at the Shandong Provincial Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine. From these cases, 274 regions of interest (ROIs) measuring 256×256 pixels were annotated. To enhance data quality, we designed a rigorous image preprocessing pipeline—which included Gaussian filtering for denoising, Reinhard color normalization, and horizontal flipping—to ensure consistency in color and brightness across different slides. The model initially extracts local features using a multi-layer convolutional module, then flattens the resultant feature maps into a sequence of tokens. Positional encoding is used to preserve spatial information, and the Transformer encoder subsequently employs a self-attention mechanism to capture global contextual features. Finally, global average pooling and a fully connected layer complete the classification task. Experimental results demonstrated that our model achieved an accuracy of 0.80, a sensitivity of 0.89, and a specificity of 0.71 in distinguishing osteosarcoma from bone callus in pathological images. These performance metrics surpass those of comparative models such as ResNet50, SVM, and a basic CNN, underscoring the high diagnostic efficiency and objectivity of this deep learning-based multi-level feature fusion method. This technique provides robust technical support for the rapid diagnosis of bone tumors and informed clinical decision-making.

title: MGA-KGF: A Multi-Granularity Adaptive Knowledge Graph Fusion Framework for Heterogeneous Multi-Source Smart Grid Data
authors: Zhongyan Chai, Zhongjun Wang, Weiwei Li, Yang Yang, Dazhong Wu, Fengbo Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: Smart grids generate heterogeneous data streams that span real-time operation and long-horizon planning. However, Transaction Processing (TP) data and Analytical Processing (AP) data differ markedly in timeliness, structure, and semantics, creating persistent barriers to end-to-end intelligence. We propose MGA-KGF, a multi-granularity, layered framework for knowledge-graph-centric fusion of heterogeneous multi-source smart-grid data. MGA-KGF (i) performs unified multi-source access and quality assurance, (ii) constructs fine-grained, mediumgrained, and coarse-grained knowledge units with explicit spatiotemporal alignment, and (iii) realizes bidirectional TP/AP fusion via an event-driven TransE-GAT pipeline with temporal and statistical attention. A load-aware storage and indexing scheme dynamically balances query latency and compression by migrating hot and cold knowledge. Deployed across core scenarios-equipment lifecycle management, rapid fault localization and traceability, regional load forecasting and resilience assessment, and O&M risk evaluation-MGA-KGF improves timeliness, semantic consistency, and cross-granularity reasoning quality, while remaining modular and extensible. The framework offers a practical path toward knowledge-reliable, real-time-toplanning integration in modern power systems and lays the groundwork for future incorporation of large language models and renewable-rich operating contexts.

title: A Passive Wi-Fi Radar Human Activity Recognition Algorithm Based on BiLSTM Time-Frequency Analysis
authors: Xinghao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Aiming to eliminate the limitations of traditional human activity recognition, this study proposes an innovative deep learning method using Wi-Fi CSI 3D spectrograms. This study establishes a process for converting raw CSI time series data into information-rich 3D multi-channel spectrograms, which lays the foundation for detailed feature extraction. This paper also introduces a composite deep learning architecture, which is enable to identify spatial patterns of spectrograms and understand temporal sequences. The model was evaluated on the public OPERAnet dataset with an oversampling strategy to manage data imbalance and achieved an average accuracy of 71.50% on an independent test set. This performance of the model is above the benchmark and on par with state-of-the-art methods, especially in dynamic activities such as "walking" and "body rotation" where it achieved excellent F1 scores above 0.9, suggesting that the method has non-invasive, high-accuracy HAR with great potential. This research overcomes the key limitations of traditional methods.

title: Sliding Mode Control Based Analysis of Photovoltaic and Fuel Cell Integrated Hybrid Electric System
authors: Somesh Lahiri Chakravarty, Kalpana Chaudhary
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents an intensive analysis on the control topology of a DC microgrid powered by a 2kW Photovoltaic (PV) array, a 2kW Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) stack and a battery pack of 25Ah rating. A sliding mode based controller topology has been used to control the switching of the PV based and bidirectional DC-DC converters. To analyze the performance and stability of the system under different operating conditions, three separate case studies are presented: a purely resistive load, a resistive load with fixed inductance, and an EV-equivalent load which has been replicated by a separately excited DC motor. Each case highlights the impact of load characteristics on the overall stability and response of the DC microgrid, providing insights into optimal control strategies for energy management in real-time applications. A comparative study is also carried out with a classical PI controller and Sliding Mode Controller for the EV type of load in a MATLAB-Simulink environment over a 3 second simulation window. The results illustrate the improved performance of the sliding mode based controller topology and its potential for integration into hybrid renewable energy systems and electric vehicle applications.

title: Solving Data Aggregation in Wireless Sensor Networks Using Policy Iteration and Value Iteration
authors: Sai Tarun Vemuganti, Abhiram Varma Penumetsa, Jagadeep Varma Penmetsa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Efficient data aggregation is a central challenge in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs), where nodes must balance limited energy resources with the need for reliable information delivery. In environmental monitoring tasks such as wind speed measurement, these challenges are intensified by finite battery capacity, stochastic solar recharging, noisy communication channels, and restricted transmission schedules. While rule-based aggregation and greedy heuristics have been widely used, they optimize only short-term performance and degrade under uncertainty. To address this, we present a simple yet effective solution by modeling WSN transmission scheduling as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) and applying classical dynamic programming-based reinforcement learning algorithms, namely Value Iteration and Policy Iteration. Simulation results show that these methods significantly reduce long-term estimation error and conserve energy compared to greedy baselines, highlighting their effectiveness in balancing accuracy and sustainability in resourceconstrained environments.

title: Enhancing SAP Predictive Maintenance and Industrial Analytics with LLM-Driven Automation
authors: Ashwini Chandrakumaran
abstract: The emergence of Industry 4.0 has revolutionized real-time process monitoring, predictive maintenance, and industrial analytics, with SAP playing a key role in digital transformation. However, implementing AI-driven analytics in SAP S/4HANA, SAP BTP, and SAP Predictive Maintenance & Service (PdMS) remains a challenge due to the complexity of machine learning tools and the need for programming expertise. To address this, I introduce SAP-LLM Analytica, an AI-powered framework that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate fault detection, process optimization, and predictive maintenance within SAP environments. By leveraging pre-trained AI models, iterative prompting strategies, and 60+ expert-designed analytics modules, SAP-LLM Analytica enhances decision-making in manufacturing, supply chain, and asset management. The system seamlessly integrates with SAP Digital Manufacturing Cloud (DMC) and SAP IoT to improve efficiency, reliability, and product quality through real-time anomaly detection and process recommendations. Empirical evaluations using real-world SAP industrial datasets demonstrate improved KPI performance, reduced downtime, and enhanced automation of analytics workflows. This research highlights how SAP-LLM Analytica can accelerate smart factory initiatives and digital twin development, transforming industrial analytics within the SAP ecosystem.

title: Performance Evaluation of a Pitch Controller to Protect an E 115/3 MW Wind Turbine under Strong Wind Conditions in Benin
authors: Assane Ogoubiyi, Richard G. Agbokpanzo, K. B. Audace Didavi, Arouna Oloulade, Taohidi Alamou Lamidi, François Xavier Fifatin
abstract: Pitch controllers are used in wind turbines to limit electrical power in strong and violent winds and can be complex, limited, and costly, whereas they should be robust, simple, and low-cost. They aim to facilitate the integration of wind energy into the electrical grid and optimize the stability of wind turbines. It is in this context that we evaluated the performance of a simple pitch angle regulator for an E 115/3 MW wind turbine under wind conditions in Benin. The pitch regulator is based on a simple proportional corrector with memory that controls the entire range of wind speeds allowed for turbine operation. The efficiency of the corrector is evaluated by applying realistic and strong winds to the turbine inlet. Our regulator limits electrical power to its nominal value for all wind speeds between 11.5 m/s and 25 m/s and optimizes power at low winds. This capability of the regulator demonstrates its robustness. Based on a proportional corrector, it is simple and inexpensive. It is suitable for high-power variable-speed wind turbines and facilitates their integration into a stability optimization algorithm.

title: Generative Explainability for Next-Generation Networks: Llm-Augmented Xai with Mutual Feature Interactions
authors: Kiarash Rezaei, Omran Ayoub, Sebastian Troia, Francesco Lelli, Paolo Monti, Carlos Natalino
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: As artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) models become integral to network operations, their lack of transparency poses a significant barrier to operator trust. Existing explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) techniques often fail to bridge this gap for non-specialists, producing technical outputs that are difficult to translate into actionable insights. This paper presents a framework specifically designed to address this shortcoming. It leverages a moderately sized large language model (LLM) and extends beyond the standard use of SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) feature influence values. The framework employs a structured prompt enriched with mutual feature interaction data to generate human-understandable natural language explanations. To validate our framework, we performed an empirical evaluation on an optical quality of transmission (QoT) estimation use case with human evaluators. We collected independent performance evaluations from specialists, which showed a high inter-evaluator agreement. Compared to a state-of-the-art baseline that uses only SHAP feature influence values in a straightforward prompt, our approach improves the explanation usefulness and scope by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 2 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6. 2 \%}$</tex>, while achieving 97.5% correctness.

title: Adapting a Large Diffusion Transformer with Conditional Flow Matching for the Synthesis of Realistic Sri Lankan Faces
authors: Ismail Lujain Jaleel, Ivan Lysikov, Rasika Rajapaksha, Hassan Ugail
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Contemporary text-to-image diffusion models, including FLUX.1-Dev and Stable Diffusion, exhibit representational bias stemming from their reliance on large-scale datasets that are potentially skewed towards certain ethnic distributions or rather lack of such diverse data in the training datasets. This imbalance results in systematic misrepresentation of underrepresented populations, such as Sri Lankans, in synthesised imagery. To address this gap, we construct a culturally curated dataset comprising 200 high-resolution facial images of Sri Lankan individuals, capturing intra-ethnic diversity across morphological features, skin tones, and traditional attire. We then perform full-parameter fine-tuning of the FLUX.1-Dev architecture-an advanced diffusion transformer model-on this dataset, employing conditional flow-matching objectives and a high-fidelity training pipeline optimised for cultural fidelity. Quantitative and qualitative evaluations reveal that the fine-tuned model exhibits markedly improved performance in generating faces consistent with Sri Lankan ethnomorphological characteristics. As part of this work, a human perceptual study (n <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=134)$</tex> was conducted to assess the realism and cultural alignment of generated images. Statistical analysis via the Mann-Whitney U test confirms a significant improvement in perceived authenticity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<10^{-48}$</tex>) over the baseline model. These results show marked efficacy of culturally grounded fine-tuning for mitigating demographic bias in generative vision models and highlight the necessity of domain-specific data for equitable machine learning pipelines.

title: Research on the authentication method of distributed energy storage charging pile entry based on quantum encryption technology
authors: Yan He, Xiangjian Du, Xuqian Lu, Diandian Huang, Fangyuan Deng, Zhanjun Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: As a vital component of the "Ubiquitous Power Internet of Things" communication network, the key management of distributed energy storage charging pile communication systems is pivotal to the successful implementation of information security measures. Consequently, achieving lightweight security authentication and communication protection across vast numbers of heterogeneous devices has become an urgent priority. This paper proposes a lightweight network authentication scheme for distributed energy, energy storage, and charging pile systems based on quantum cryptography technology (Charging Pile Key Management Scheme, CPKMS). By integrating pre-shared symmetric keys with public key certificate mechanisms, it ensures efficient and secure network authentication and data transmission for terminal devices operating in resource-constrained environments. Analysis demonstrates that this scheme possesses resistance to forgery attacks, man-in-the-middle attacks, and replay attacks, balancing security and efficiency to meet the security requirements for network access key management in distributed energy storage and charging pile systems.

title: Multi Junction Photovoltaic Cell Modeling and Performance Enhancement using MPPT
authors: Sneha P. Sontakke, S. P. Adhau, V. S. Rajguru
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This research is focused on modelling of MultiJunction Photo Voltaic cells (MJPV) and how Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) be competent to elevate the performance of Photovoltaic Module component. By dividing the light spectrum, a multi-junction (MJ) solar cell (GaInP/GaInAs/Ge) can harvest additional radiant power harnessed from the sunlight than a monojunction PV module. When two or more single-junction cells are stacked to produce MJSCs, the productivity of the cell is increased. The MPPT mode in the MATLAB/Simulink environment is utilized to enhance the conversion efficiency and maximize the PV modules’ output power. By modifying various environmental parameters such as temperature and irradiance within a MATLAB/Simulink platform, and utilizing the I-V and P-V characteristics of MJSCs, maximum performance potentially achieved. Perturb and Observe ($\mathbf{P}$ and $\mathbf{O}$) MPPT algorithm is used, which is the simplest, easiest, and suitable for PV applications. At the end, the procedure was used to determine how temperature and irradiance influence the production of power. Additionally, the effect of resistance and the ideality factor on conversion efficiency has been studied.

title: A Low-Loss Wideband mmWave Filter Chip With Slot-Loaded Harmonic Suppression Based on Multimode Quarter-Mode SIW
authors: Shiyu Xie, Weimin Wang, Yongle Wu, Yuhao Yang, Xinyu Zhang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a U-shaped slot structure that achieves mode regulation and harmonic suppression by altering the electrical field distribution. The slot pair is symmetrically etched on the top metal of the quarter-mode substrate integrated waveguide (QMSIW) resonator, occupying no additional area. Its well-designed configuration avoids radiation loss while generating transmission zeros (TZs). By combining perturbation vias with the slot pair in a single QMSIW cavity, multiple modes are effectively exploited to construct a wideband response. A compact GaAs-based integrated passive devices (IPDs) filter chip was fabricated, with a footprint of only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.46\times 2.46$</tex-math> </inline-formula> mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Measurements demonstrate a 31.7–50.8 GHz passband with 47.7% 3-dB fractional bandwidth (FBW), a minimum insertion loss (IL) of 0.4 dB with variations less than 0.9 dB, and stopband suppression better than 18.5 dB. These results verify an efficient solution for multimode wideband, low loss, good harmonic suppression, and highly integrated on-chip filters in millimeter-wave (mmWave) applications.

title: Enhanced Multi-Scale PoseNet for Self-Supervised Monocular Depth Estimation
authors: Chao Zhang, Tian Tian, Cheng Han, Tiancheng Shao, Mi Zhou, Shichao Zhao
abstract: Monocular depth estimation is essential for 3D perception in applications such as autonomous driving and robotics. Self-supervised methods avoid depth labels but often rely on shallow pose networks with weak temporal modeling, leading to unstable predictions. We propose EMSP-Net, an Enhanced Multi-Scale PoseNet for self-supervised monocular depth estimation. It introduces a hierarchical feature fusion encoder, a temporal attention-context decoder, and a pose consistency loss to jointly improve feature extraction, temporal stability, and geometric constraints. On the KITTI dataset, EMSP-Net achieved an absolute relative error of 0.105 and a squared relative error of 0.708. In the Make3D cross-domain test, its strong robustness was further demonstrated.

title: Inverse Design of Bend-Resistant Photonic Crystal Fibers Based on DNN with Feature Analysis
authors: Dan Yang, Zhenzhen Ma, Hong Liu, Jiaqi Liu, Bin Xu
abstract: In this paper, a bend-resistant photonic crystal fiber inverse design using a deep neural network (DNN) with feature analysis is proposed for higher efficiency. First, a DNN model is trained to design structures of the bend-resistant PCF according to the given optical performance. Then, Shapley additive interpretation (SHAP), a kind of XAI algorithm is employed to optimize the pre-trained DNN model with feature analysis. The features with higher SHAP values are selected from the original input data to reduce the input data dimension of the pre-trained DNN. When the input data dimension is reduced from 33 to 11, the number of model parameters is decreased by 87.9%. The design accuracy of the optimized DNN is 94.4%, and the total design time of the optimized model is only 0.024 seconds. The results show that the proposed method reduces the computational load and improves the efficiency of photonic crystal fiber design. The designed bend-resistant photonic crystal fibers have excellent performance and are easy to be manufactured. This can also offer an alternative method for the design of various optical devices.

title: Statistical Models of Battery Packs Considering Cell-to-Cell Variations for Degradation Characteristics and Reliability Analysis_supp1-3638459.pdf
authors: Chenghui Zhang
abstract: Quantifying and assessing the degradation characteristics and reliability of packs under cell-to-cell variations are essential for ensuring the safe and reliable operation of electric vehicles (EVs). Therefore, based on statistical theory and a thorough investigation of cell degradation mechanisms and models, the statistical degradation models of packs for any configurations are pioneeringly developed through theoretical derivation. These models consider cell-to-cell variations, apply to various lithium-ion battery types and operating conditions, and are verified through Monte Carlo simulation. Based on these models, the pack state-of-health (SOH) statistics can be quickly and accurately obtained to quantify their degradation characteristics. Furthermore, the pack reliability can be efficiently assessed by integrating these models with the universal generating function (UGF) method. The results demonstrate that both parallel and series configurations enhance the pack-level SOH consistency. The SOH consistency in parallel modules with four cells is improved by 50% over cell-to-cell. After 3,000 cycles, a 10°C temperature variation caused pack reliability to decrease from 0.9343 to 0 (the lower the reliability, the greater the probability of failure occurring in a batch of packs). Moreover, packs with cells firstly connected in parallel and then in series exhibit superior SOH statistical performance and reliability. It has significant applications in pack configuration optimization, cell screening, and echelon utilization of retired packs.

title: Hybrid Statistical Model and Rule-based Algorithm for Legal Analysis: A Case Study on Thai Offences against Property
authors: Sirawit Chokphantavee, Sorawit Chokphantavee, Somrudee Deepaisarn
abstract: Legal analysis utilizing natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) technologies is a difficult undertaking that has recently sparked the interest of many academics and industries. Using a human-annotated dataset summarized into colloquial Thai from Supreme Court decisions, this work investigates a different combination of NLP, ML, and rule-based techniques for accurate legal case analysis as per Thai law, especially property-related offences, with the intuition to imitate the lawyer’s cognitive process. We experimented with two major tasks, binary and multi-label classification, evaluated using a five-fold cross-validation method. The binary classification was performed to discern property-related cases from other criminal offences, while the multi-label task associates the case with specific property-related offences, including theft, snatching, robbery, and gang robbery. We achieved exceptional performance for the former task for average accuracy and F1-score, reaching 94.2% and 96.7%, respectively, together with an intriguing finding that solely vanilla fastText, a static embedding, is enough for such a task. For the part of multi-label classification, we obtained a remarkable result of 82.0% in average zero-one accuracy and 92.0% in average Hamming accuracy, with the fine-tuned joint embedding classification pipeline incorporating rulebased post-processing, showing an improvement from without the rule-based technique. This highlights the possibility of integrating the symbolic information from a rule-based algorithm together with the statistical computation from machine learning techniques in performing a complex legal analysis task.

title: An Efficient Adaptive Fringe Projection Framework for High Dynamic Range 3D Measurement via Phase Differential Mapping and Residual-Robust Optimization
authors: Hongling Luo, Song Wan, Jiale Shen, Zhuojiang Nan, Fei Tian, Wei Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Fringe projection profilometry (FPP) suffers from reduced accuracy when measuring surfaces with complex reflectivity, resulting from image saturation in high-reflectivity regions and low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in low-reflectivity regions. Although adaptive fringe projection (AFP) methods effectively mitigate these issues, existing approaches still face two critical limitations: spatial misalignment caused by oversimplified pixel mapping paradigms, and low efficiency due to excessive pattern projections. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes an efficient adaptive fringe projection framework for high dynamic range (HDR) 3D measurement, which combines phase differential mapping with residual-robust optimization. First, we introduce a two-stage mapping method: an initial coarse one-to-one mapping using low‑grayscale uniaxial fringe patterns, followed by a refined many-to-many correspondence established via phase differential matrices. This significantly alleviates spatial misalignment while reducing the number of required projection patterns. Second, we develop a residual-robust optimization framework for estimating the projector’s pixel-wise maximum input gray level (MIGL) directly from mapped intensity pairs, without the need for additional uniform grayscale projections. The framework incorporates residual-adaptive weighting and spatial smoothing to ensure robust estimation under limited and low-SNR data conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that our method reduces projection patterns to 14, compared to over 27 in existing HDR techniques, while achieving competitive performance and superior point cloud completeness across various complex reflective surfaces.

title: DRL-Driven STAR-RIS Assisted Secure Communication with HPPP Eavesdroppers
authors: Gaurav K. Pandey, Devendra S. Gurjar, Suneel Yadav, Ranjay Hazra, Xingwang Li
abstract: This letter explores a secure communication system assisted by simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (STAR-RIS) with coupled phase-shift design. Here, a multi-antenna base station (BS) transmits confidential information to both indoor and outdoor users via STAR-RIS using an energy-splitting protocol. We consider multiple terrestrial homogeneous Poisson point process eavesdroppers located in reflecting and transmitting regions that can intercept the BS’s transmitted signal. To ensure secure communication, we formulate a secrecy rate maximization problem by jointly optimizing the BS beamforming vectors and the transmission and reflection coefficients of the STAR-RIS. Furthermore, we reformulate the optimization problem as a constrained Markov decision process, considering both system dynamics and problem tractability. To solve it efficiently, we employ a deep reinforcement learning technique, i.e., the constrained soft actor-critic algorithm. Numerical analysis confirms that the proposed framework achieves superior secrecy performance compared to benchmark methods.

title: Modelling Covalent Inhibitors of Protein Kinases Using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: R Niranjan, N Sukumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Protein kinases play an important role in cellular activities like cell division, growth, metabolism, etc, implicating diseases, particularly cancer. Covalent inhibitors are promising inhibitors due to their higher specificity and permanent binding with the protein. Predicting a covalent inhibitor with specific kinase proteins is a challenge. This paper compares different methods for classifying covalent and non-covalent inhibitors of P0DTD1 (replicase polyprotein 1ab), including traditional fingerprint-based models, Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), and Large Language Models (LLMs). Various methods to handle the class imbalance of 365 molecules in covalent and 5892 molecules in non-covalent class, with upsampling, class weights, and transfer learning were experimented. The results indicate that LLM with upsampling and transfer learning has the highest performance (F1 scores of 0.95+), but GNN architectures with relevant class balancing techniques showed concrete results despite dataset imbalance. The experiments provides valuable insight for development of computational methods in drug discovery, particularly in identifying potential covalent inhibitors.

title: Comparison of Different TinyML Implementations for an Industrial Control System
authors: Emilija Ćojbašić, Dejan Rančić, Anđela Jovanović, Vladimir Sibinović, Žarko Ćojbašić
abstract: Requirements regarding security, trustworthiness and low latency in modern industrial control and robotic systems have led to implemented machine learning solutions considerably shifting from cloud computing to edge computing. In this context, the emerging concepts of Edge Artificial Intelligence and Tiny Machine Learning are becoming essential for implementing machine learning based industrial control solutions using resource-constrained devices. In this paper Tiny Machine Learning is used to solve the industrial control problem of apple classification using two small edge devices. Several versions are compared while presented experimental results and comparisons with our previously published results demonstrate that Tiny Machine Learning can provide a viable solution even for complex industrial grade control problems in the food industry.

title: HRCyolo: High-Resolution Cell Detection via Super-Resolution and Attention Mechanisms
authors: Du Zhang, Chunfeng Liu, Xianping Liu, Yanling Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Object detection plays a crucial role in the fields of biophysics, cell detection, and organelle counting. Existing cell detection models struggle with low accuracy due to Blurred images and low resolution of tiny targets in images, which makes it difficult to detect and locate cells and organelles. This paper This paper combines super-resolution technology of ESRGAN with object detection technology of yololl. Firstly, a high resolution and training method is raised to improve the training quality of object detection models. Secondly, a ROI-Guided Super-Resolution for Inference method is introduced to fuse yolo and ESRGAN, which optimized the detection methods for blurred and tiny targets. Finally, the neck part of yolo is modified with a multi-directional neck to enhance the perception ability of detection models for tiny targets. Experimental results show that using a 4x super-resolution dataset for training, combined with a 2x super-resolution training strategy and detection data preprocessing method, can achieve the best performance of the optimized HRCyolo object detection model. Compared to the baseline model, HRCyolo achieves an overall improvement of 6.5% in mAP50-95 on the DR-Narin-2 dataset, with notable gains of 21.7% and 3.06% specifically for Blasts and Erythrocytes. This approach effectively breaks through the bottleneck of traditional detection models in recognizing small targets such as blast and Erythrocyte in fuzzy scenes, and improves the detection accuracy of multi-scale cell datasets.

title: Machine Learning-Powered Decision Support for Fetal Health Assessment Using CTG Data
authors: Aritro Saha, Deepak Singh, Anish Kumar Vishwakarma, Devanshi Jain, Shivang Mangal, Panduranga Ravi Teja
abstract: Fetal diseases often lead to complications, but with the help of machine learning models in modern healthcare, early-stage assessment and detection are now possible. The quality of care (QoC) provided to expectant mothers may be risked by human error, biases, and high operational costs, along with traditional diagnostic procedures, which frequently rely on clinical judgment. The women in underprivileged areas, where access to professional medical experts is limited, these issues are a serious concern. This study introduces a computer system that uses machine learning (ML) to predict fetal health by analyzing cardiotocographic (CTG) data and classifying fetal conditions as normal, suspicious, or abnormal. Fetal heart rate (FHR), uterine contractions (UC), accelerations, decelerations, and statistical metrics like histogram width and variance are among the crucial physiological data that the system examines. We thoroughly assessed numerous ML methods using public datasets from the popular CTG dataset, obtained from the UCI repository. The SVM classifier had the highest prediction accuracy among all of the models tested, indicating that it was better at detecting risk in pregnancies with the negligible error. This strategy improves access to high-quality prenatal care by lowering reliance on the availability of specialists. It also helps to make timely, evidence-based decisions. The resulting technique will enhance maternal healthcare services by enabling faster, more inclusive, and reliable fetal health evaluations.

title: Mitigation of Current Harmonics in Electric Vehicle Chargers
authors: Charan R Naik, Ganesh Kudva, Divya Shetty, Jayalakshmi N S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: The rapid increase in the use of electric vehicles (EVs) has made household and commercial EV charging stations major contributors to power quality problems. Power electronic converters used in EV chargers are nonlinear in nature. These nonlinear loads put more strain on the electrical distribution system, lower power factor, and create current harmonics. To reduce current harmonics and control reactive power in a single-phase EV charging system, this research introduces a shunt active power filter (SAPF) based on model predictive control (MPC). MATLAB/Simulink is used to model and simulate the suggested system. By minimizing a cost function based on reference current tracking error, a MPC method is created to choose inverter switching states as efficiently as possible. A fuzzy logic controller (FLC) is used to control the DC link voltage, guaranteeing energy balance throughout the filter. The SAPF improves source current and complies with IEEE 519 harmonic requirements by injecting compensating currents that eliminate harmonic components drawn by the charger. When compared with the traditional filtering techniques, a considerable reduction in total harmonic distortion (THD), an improvement in power factor, and improved dynamic performance are observed in the simulation results.

title: Implicit Hate Speech Detection Based on Sentiment and Common Sense Knowledge Enhancement
authors: Zhong Zhang, Yushan Jiang, Weiwei Ouyang, Lei Tian, Xuechen Zhao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: We propose a novel method for implicit hate speech detection that integrates sentiment and common sense knowledge. By using a pre-trained language model to learn the textual content representation of the original tweets, and combining the two dimensions of sentiment and hate for contrastive learning, the multi-dimensional hate expression features are learned. Furthermore, to fully incorporate relevant external knowledge, our method retrieves common sense knowledge concepts from the semantic network to combine with the text to construct a directed isomorphic graph for each sample. Finally, an attention mechanism is used to fuse the learned feature representations from the two modules for implicit hate speech detection. Experimental results demonstrate that our method performs well in terms of both accuracy and efficiency, offering an effective solution for detecting implicit hate speech on social media.

title: Explainable and Adversarially Evaluated CNN for Visual Phishing Detection
authors: Shruthi Vishwajeeth, Devikrishna K S, Shruthi K Anchan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Phishing websites are increasingly designed to copy legitimate interfaces with high visual accuracy. This can lead to tricking users into revealing sensitive information. Traditional defenses based on URLs or blacklists often fail against such visual mimicry. This paper presents an explainable CNN-based model for visual phishing detection, trained on a combination of Mendeley Data and a curated screenshot dataset. We use MobileNetV2 for efficient classification and apply LIME (Local Interpretable ModelAgnostic Explanations) to highlight visual elements influencing the model's decisions. To assess resilience, We evaluate the model against adversarial perturbations generated using FGSM and PGD. Our contributions include dataset curation, LIME- based interpretability, adversarial robustness evaluation, and performance comparison with baseline models.

title: CC-CV Control of Single Phase Single Stage Isolated Boost PFC Converter for Electric Vehicle Charging
authors: Suman Saurav, Yogesh Likhar, Ritesh Kumar Keshri, Manoj R. Ramteke
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Present paper presents a single phase single stage boost Power Factor Correction (PFC) rectifier based isolated charger to charge on board batteries of an electric vehicle in constant current (CC) constant voltage (CV) mode. The close loop control strategy for operating the charger in two loops, constant current and constant voltage of boost PFC rectifier is discussed. The total harmonics distortion of current drawn by the charger from the grid is reduced below 8%. The charger is designed for 3kW@320V DC for maximum charging current in CC mode 8A. The proposed strategy is validated through circuit simulation to comment on its effectiveness.

title: MVReID-Former: Multi-View Vision Transformer for Cross-Camera Person and Vehicle Re-Identification in Surveillance Networks
authors: Onyekachukwu Ojumah, Arinzechukwu H. Madukasi, Nabeela T. Adebola, Olusegun Akinfenwa, Timileyin Daso, Ilemona Abutu, Akinyemi S. Akintola, Folasayo Agunbiade
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Cross-camera person and vehicle re-identification in surveillance networks remains a challenging task due to variations in camera viewpoints, image quality, and environmental conditions. Traditional methods using hand-crafted features show limited performance in real-world scenarios. We propose MVReID-Former, a novel Multi-View Vision Transformer architecture specifically designed for cross-camera re-identification in surveillance networks. Our approach introduces three key innovations: (1) a Cross-View Attention Mechanism that learns discriminative features across different camera viewpoints and qualities, (2) Camera-Aware Positional Encoding that incorporates camera metadata including resolution, vantage point, and quality into attention computation, and (3) Adaptive Quality Weighting that handles varying image quality from VGA to 3MP resolutions. Experiments on the Dana36 dataset demonstrate improvements over existing methods, with our approach showing promising results for multi-camera surveillance scenarios. The hierarchical transformer design effectively captures both finegrained patch-level details and global cross-view correspondences, enabling robust identity matching across challenging scenarios.

title: Robust Optimization of Service Deployment in Edge Computing Environments
authors: Run Liu, Lan Shen, Chenxin Huang, Xuemei Zhu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: In edge computing environments, edge servers are often subject to uncertainties such as hardware failures and link interruptions, which can degrade the quality of user experience (QoE). As a result, service robustness—the ability to maintain service continuity when servers fail—becomes particularly critical under limited budget constraints K. Existing studies predominantly adopt greedy algorithms, which offer computational efficiency but lack sufficient global search capability and adaptability. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an enhanced algorithm that integrates Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) with a Top-K refinement strategy. Specifically, PSO leverages its strong global search capability to explore a diverse set of candidate deployment solutions, while the subsequent Top-K refinement mechanism performs localized optimization and selection to retain and reinforce high-quality solutions. This synergistic approach effectively combines the complementary strengths of global exploration and local exploitation, significantly improving the robustness of deployment solutions in uncertain environments. Experimental results on public datasets demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms three baseline approaches in terms of robustness, thereby validating its effectiveness in enhancing the stability and reliability of edge network services.

title: Design, Analysis, and Experimental Validation of Surface-Modified Inchworm-Based Piezoelectric Actuators
authors: Yunkai Liu, Zhongjing Ren, Erchao Li, Binsheng Li, Ruilei Chen, Peng Yan, Qijie Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The bionic piezoelectric inchworm actuator mimics the driving principle of biological inchworms and exhibits such characteristics as high load-bearing capacity and positioning accuracy, but it suffers from relatively low movement speed. Previous research efforts usually focus on structural design improvements for inchworm actuators, while little attention is paid to enhancing their performance via surface modification technologies. Herein, flexible contact surfaces with different materials and topography were applied to a piezoelectric inchworm actuator, and experimental tests revealed that the actuator achieved maximum velocity of 17821.1 μm/s after laser surface treatment, representing a nearly 78% enhancement compared to its original aluminum alloy surface. Similarly, surface modifications with polyimide and shape memory alloy demonstrated velocity improvements of 21% and 57% respectively. The laser-processed surface and spin-coated polyimide surface also enhanced load capacity, reaching a maximum payload of 240 g. These results demonstrate that significant performance improvements in piezoelectric actuators can be achieved through proper surface modifications

title: Receding Horizon Weather Navigation Using Learned Navigation Policies
authors: Moslem Kazemi, Tim Burns
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Navigating weather presents a significant challenge for pilots, demanding substantial training and experience. Prior research has explored using imitation learning to learn navigation policies that generate weather-aware flight routes based on off-line pilot demonstrations. However, the dynamic nature of weather and the evolving aircraft state make executing these learned policies difficult. This paper proposes an iterative method for generating and implementing learned policies over a receding horizon. By employing a receding horizon strategy, a new route is generated at each cycle, considering the latest environmental and aircraft conditions. Only a small segment of the route is executed before the process repeats until the destination is reached. This frequent updating of states enhances adaptability and resilience to weather variations and update delays, as demonstrated in simulations using NEXRAD data. Initial findings, reviewed and evaluated by our test pilots, suggest a promising avenue for this research.

title: Optimal Control Design for UAV Systems using Whale Optimization Enhanced LQR Approach
authors: R U Surya, Devara Sandesh Reddy, Nadhindla Chandramouli, Putta Dinesh, Vineet Kumar, Manoj Kumar Debnath
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The positioning control of a quadrotor is finding numerous applications in defense, surveillance, electric transportation and unmanned delivery. Accurate control of position and altitude is essential for ensuring smooth UAV operation. This work demonstrates the modeling and control of a quadrotor using an advanced Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR). The cost function weight parameters of LQR are optimized using the Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) to improve control accuracy. Performance comparison between the conventional LQR and the proposed LQR-WOA method reveals significant improvements in key time-domain metrics. For instance, the LQR-WOA achieves a rise time of 0.877 s, settling time of 2.89 s, compared to 2.369 s, 4.077 s, respectively for conventional LQR in the X-axis. Similar improvements are observed for other axes, highlighting the effectiveness of the proposed method. Simulation results confirm that the LQR-WOA framework provides enhanced performance, making it a robust approach for UAV applications.

title: Secondary Disease Detection of Bridges via YOLO11n Model and UAV Path Planning
authors: Hongchang Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: As the structural safety concerns of aging bridge infrastructure grow more prominent globally, traditional manual inspection approaches have failed to keep pace with modern traffic maintenance requirements. This is primarily due to inherent limitations like low efficiency, high costs, and operational hazards, which render them inadequate for contemporary needs. The breakthrough development of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) technology provides an efficient solution for high-precision image acquisition of bridge surfaces, but the intelligent analysis of massive detection data still faces major challenges. The research innovatively proposes an intelligent detection framework integrating deep learning and reinforcement learning: through convolutional neural networks, damage features such as cracks, peeling, and corrosion in unmanned aerial vehicle aerial images are automatically extracted, and reinforcement learning is applied to construct a dynamic decision-making model to achieve the autonomous optimal configuration of the detection workflow. This system effectively solves key technical problems such as multi-scale feature recognition of bridge structures and adaptive detection of irregular components under complex lighting conditions. Its self-optimization learning mechanism significantly improves the accuracy and generalization ability of defect recognition. The research results will provide a next-generation detection paradigm that is safer, more efficient, and has evolutionary capabilities for the maintenance of intelligent infrastructure.

title: Low Power ALU Design using Pre-Computational LUT for RV32M Processor
authors: Mirza Amanullah Baig, Adyasha Mishra, Santanu Sarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper presents a Look Up Table (LUT) based pre-computational (PC) Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) for RV32M. The proposed ALU provides low power consumption and high speed for application specific purpose where the input of the ALU is repeated several times. The proposed ALU integrates LUT based on pre-computational mechanism with the multiplier and control logic unit which store the computational results of frequent operands. The system avoids unnecessary arithmetic operations, thereby reducing the real time computations allowing to increase speed and reduce dynamic power consumption.
