Simulation results shows substantial reduction in power consumption without compromising much in the operational speed proposed ALU design making it suitable for energy-constrained applications with frequent operands such as DSP and CNN based application. This pre-computation technique gives promising direction for enhancing energy efficiency in processor design.

title: Model Predictive Control of DC Bus Voltage in a Solar PV-Battery System Using a Bidirectional DC-DC Converter
authors: Shaswat Chandra Mishra, Pranati Rani Purohit, Arnab Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In modern renewable energy systems, regulating the DC bus voltage is crucial for ensuring stable power delivery and efficient integration with energy storage devices. This paper presents a Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy for regulating the DC bus voltage in a solar photovoltaic (PV) system integrated with a battery through a bidirectional DC-DC converter. The solar PV module operates under an Incremental Conductance (IC) Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm to extract maximum available power. The battery is interfaced via a bidirectional converter to either absorb or supply power based on the DC bus voltage deviation. The proposed MPC algorithm predicts future system behaviour and optimizes the control action to maintain the DC bus voltage at a constant 48 V under varying irradiance and load conditions. The control approach eliminates the need for conventional PID controllers, providing faster dynamic response and improved voltage regulation. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme, demonstrating its robustness and accuracy in maintaining DC bus stability in a PV-battery energy system.

title: Research on the Construction of Computer-Aided Design System in University Visual Communication
authors: Liangyi Li, Kai Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes a design optimization and creative feedback algorithm (DL-DOF) based on deep learning, and applies it to the computer-aided design system, aiming to optimize the design creation process and improve the quality of design works. The system uses deep learning technology to extract image features of design works, and generates personalized creative optimization and feedback suggestions based on design rules and trends. Specifically, the system analyzes the design image through CNN, extracts its visual features, and then provides real-time creative feedback to designers to help adjust the design plan and improve the creativity and technical accuracy of the work. The system also combines GAN and DRL algorithms to optimize design suggestions and promote the innovation and adaptability of design styles. Experimental results show that after applying the system, the creativity and technical accuracy of the design works are improved by 15% and 20% respectively. Through comparative experiments and user feedback analysis, the significant advantages of the system in optimizing the design creation process, improving design efficiency, and enhancing design inspiration are verified. The proposal of this algorithm and system provides an efficient and intelligent design tool for the design field, laying a foundation for further promoting the intelligence and automation of design creation.

title: Multi-regional power grid anomaly detection coordination mechanism based on federated transfer learning
authors: Guichen Huang, Qian Lv, Biao Quan, Yanmei He, Jing Li, Xue Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of data heterogeneity, abnormal pattern differences and collaborative detection difficulties in multi-regional power grids, this paper proposes a distributed anomaly detection mechanism based on federated transfer learning. First, by constructing abnormal characteristics and disturbance models under regional division, multi-type abnormal scenario simulation and data difference modeling are realized. Secondly, a federated migration framework including maximum mean difference (MMD) and personalized output structure is designed to effectively improve cross-regional model sharing and robustness. Finally, the comprehensive advantages of the proposed method in accuracy, communication efficiency and generalization ability are verified under the IEEE 118 node system, providing technical support for collaborative perception of smart grids.

title: Potential and Challenges of Large Baseline Distributed Systems for Space-Based Space Surveillance
authors: Giorgio Isoletta, Annarita Argirò, Pasquale Bencivenga, Roberto Opromolla, Giancarmine Fasano
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The overpopulation of the Earth orbital environment due to space debris and deployment of satellite mega-constellations requires advanced Space Situational Awareness capabilities. Space-based space surveillance (SBSS) systems represent a promising solution to complement traditional ground-based tracking systems. This paper investigates an innovative SBSS concept employing large baseline Distributed Satellite Systems (DSS) equipped with optical sensors to improve space object detection and orbit determination. The proposed system may enhance surveillance performance by exploiting sensor spatial diversity for accurate triangulation, thus enabling direct range measurements while ensuring similar illumination conditions. The paper discusses the basic requirements of the proposed concept and presents observability analyses in terms of the observation volume. The potential contribution of a large baseline DSS to improve surveillance performance and orbit determination capabilities is assessed considering synthetic test cases that exploit realistic simulations including detectability constraints.

title: Model-Based Safety Assessment of a Hybrid Fly-by-Wire Flight Control System for a Light Sport Aircraft
authors: Johannes Bender, Julian Rhein, Nils Schlautmann, Evangelos Huber, Florian Holzapfel
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This work presents the Model-based Safety Assessment of a novel hybrid fly-by-wire flight control system. The system enhances a conventional mechanically-controlled light sport aircraft with fly-by-wire, enabling modern flight control functionalities. Due to its full control authority, potentially severe malfunctions must be evaluated in a safety assessment. First, a potential certification path is investigated, from which safetyrelevant certification requirements are derived. Then, a System Functional Hazard Assessment is performed, adding additional quantitative and qualitative requirements. Finally, it is verified whether the preliminary system architecture meets all qualitative requirements as part of a Preliminary System Safety Assessment. For the Preliminary System Safety Assessment, the novel Modelbased Safety Assessment tool Xcuse is utilized to construct a model that simulates fault behavior and propagation within the system architecture. A potential certification path for the safety assessment of the flight control system has been successfully established. The novel Model-based Safety Assessment approach is utilized to qualitatively assess the system's compliance with established requirements and to derive additional safety requirements and recommendations for the final system. Model-based Safety Assessment (specifically Xcuse) offers advantages to traditional safety assessment methods, such as decreased manual effort and intuitive model verification.

title: Simulation of Photovoltaic Green Hydrogen Production: A Case Study for Howrah Junction
authors: Mohammed Rehan Raza, Souparna Chakraborty, Chirodeep Bakli
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The variability of renewable energy sources necessitates energy storage to meet consistent supply and balancing requirements of the grid. Green hydrogen serves as a chemical energy carrier that can be used in a flexible manner and a clean and flexible energy storage medium. The techno-economic analysis investigates hydrogen production from PVs, which can be installed at commercial locations such as platform sheds at Howrah junction, where hydrogen can be utilized as fuel; the location is selected due to the difficulty in storage and transportation, therefore to be used as continuously running fuel. With a 55.61 kW PV system, the hydrogen produced can power trains for 1631.81 km annually with an estimated energy value of 47.4 MWh. The work demonstrates the viability of integrating hydrogen as flexible, clean fuel source for stationery and transport applications.

title: STATCOM Integrated DC Microgrid based EV Charging Infrastructure - FA Controller Tuning for Optimal Response
authors: Babita Faujdar, Rajendra Kumar Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper proposes a firefly algorithm (FA), optimized control strategy for a STATCOM-integrated DC microgrid-based EV charging infrastructure powered by photovoltaic (PV) array and energy storage (ES), seamlessly interfaced with the AC grid. Maintaining the DC bus voltage stability is critical challenge under the fluctuations in solar power and load demand. By enabling real-time reactive power compensation, the STATCOM enhances AC voltage stability, which in turn ensures steady DC bus performance and improved system reliability. To capture the system’s dynamic behaviour, an integrated homogeneous small-signal model is developed. The FA is utilized to fine-tune the state feedback control matrix k, delivering rapid state regulation, superior damping of oscillations, and reduced settling time. The MATLAB simulation results demonstrate that the FA-optimized control significantly outperforms over conventional state feedback methods, with improvements in transient response, reduced overshoot and undershoot, and enhanced overall stability. The proposed control framework not only ensures uninterrupted and efficient EV charging but also offers remarkable flexibility and resilience under real-world dynamic conditions, positioning it as a robust solution for next-generation EV charging systems.

title: SG-VAE: Explainable Semi-Generative Model for Attack Detection in IoT Healthcare Systems
authors: Komal Ghafoor, Furquan Rustam, Anca Delia Jurcut, Devis Bianchiniè
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The integration of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies in healthcare has revolutionized patient monitoring and medical data collection, but it has also introduced new vulnerabilities to cyberattacks. Ensuring the security of these connected medical devices is essential to maintain patient safety and system reliability. In this study, we propose a lightweight semi-generative deep learning framework based on a Variational Autoencoder (SG-VAE) for detecting attacks in IoT-based healthcare systems. The model compresses high-dimensional network traffic into a latent representation using the VAE encoder and employs a classification head to detect potential cyber threats directly from the latent space. Unlike conventional generative models focused on input reconstruction, our SG-VAE leverages the generative structure purely for efficient and effective classification, resulting in a high-throughput, real-time system in resource-constrained environments. To enhance transparency and interpretability, we integrate two eXplainable AI (XAI) techniques, SHAP and LIME, to provide insights into model decisions, helping stakeholders understand which features influence predictions most. Experimental results on a publicly available IoT-based ICU healthcare security dataset demonstrate that our model achieves near-perfect accuracy, 1.00, and high throughput, 54,286 samples/second, making it both highly effective and practical for deployment in real-world healthcare systems. All code required to reproduce the experiments is publicly available on Dropbox <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>1https://rb.gy/5y3kuh.

title: Review of MPPT Techniques for Dynamic Partial Shading in Solar PV Systems
authors: Saqib Asgar Kanth, Neeraj Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Dynamic Partial Shading Conditions (DPSC) significantly impact the energy output of solar photovoltaic systems, leading to multiple local maxima in the power-voltage (P-V) curve and reducing energy efficiency. To resolve this challenge, advanced Maximum Power Point Tracking techniques have been developed to ensure optimal power extraction. This review focuses on three cutting-edge MPPT —Incremental Conductance with Differential Optimization (INC-DFO), Sovereign Butterfly Optimization (SBO), and Whale Optimization with Differential Evolution (WODE)—which have shown promising results in handling rapid shading transitions. These techniques are evaluated based on key performance parameters, including tracking speed, accuracy, adaptability to shading patterns, robustness, computational complexity, and convergence behavior. The analysis highlights that while INC-DFO offers moderate tracking speed and reliability, SBO provides the fastest and most robust convergence. WODE achieves a balance between precision and computational efficiency, making it an ideal choice for real-time applications. This review serves as a critical resource for researchers and engineers seeking efficient MPPT strategies to enhance PV system performance under dynamic shading scenarios.

title: Adaptive Neural Relaying for Rural Networks Integrated with PV and Wind Distributed Generations
authors: Amritjot Kaur, Manjeet Singh, Rishabh Dev Shukla, Praveen Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The rural distribution networks integrated with renewable energy sources like photovoltaic and wind distributed generations face serious challenges in terms of reliable and efficient power distribution due to power production volatility and varying grid conditions. This paper explores an Adaptive Neural Relaying system for rural power systems integrated with Photovoltaic and Wind Distributed Generations. The proposed methodology forces Artificial Neural Networks to enhance fault detection, classification, and system reliability under dynamic environmental and operational conditions with adaptive protection coordination. Traditional protection systems fight with inconsistency in renewable energy generation, leads to false trips and miscoordination. The proposed method dynamically controls relay settings built on real-time system circumstances, increasing grid stability, reliability, and fault-handling expertise.

title: Power and Area Efficient Processing Element (PE) of CNN Accelerator for Object Detection
authors: Abinash Kumar Pala, Swastik Behera, Raghunandan Swain, Dinesh Kumar Dash, Sandipan Mallik
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The proposed Research presents the architecture of an ASIC-based Processing Element (PE) designed to support and increasingly advance the computational needs of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) as they extend to real-time applications of image processing, object recognition, and autonomous systems. The PE is specifically developed for convolution operations and has a pipelined datapath composed of a multiplier; three-layer convolution engine; first-in-first-out (FIFO) buffer; and an output register. The control elements of the component are computed using D-Flip Flops and include overflow detection, set-bounds logic, a counter and a MUX to enable step-level control and dynamic limits on the computation limits. The novel features ensure synchronized access and perform data transformations through convolution, pooling, and activation functions efficiently. It is a modular and scalable implementation, and can be integrated into larger CNN accelerators capable of performing multiple convolution operations in parallel across multiple PE’s. Synthesis and simulation results substantiate that the architecture works effectively and shows significant gains in power, area, and performance when compared to conventional GPU-based systems.

title: Advanced Autocorrelation Spectral Density Analysis for Signal Contamination Mitigation in Radiosonde Data
authors: Sujit Kumar Chakravarty, Amul Batra, Neeti Singh, Vijay Kumar Soni
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Radiosonde data are essential for atmospheric profiling; however they frequently include signal contamination from external turbulence, balloon motion, and device noise. Conventional filtering methods don’t sufficiently strike a compromise between preserving ambient features and suppressing noise. This work suggests a unique technique for improved radiosonde signal processing and contaminant removal that makes use of autocorrelation spectral density (ASD). In order to identify and suppress non-physical spectrum components while maintaining fine-scale atmospheric structures, we estimate the ASD directly from the autocorrelation functions of radiosonde measurements (wind speed, temperature, and humidity). Using the distinctive frequency signatures of identified contaminants, a dynamic spectral mask is created. Better vertical resolution of wind shear, more distinct cloud boundary identification, and increased data quality for integration into numerical weather prediction models are all demonstrated by the results of radiosonde datasets collected throughout a variety of weather scenarios.

title: Thermal analysis of underground vegetable storage in extreme cold climate of Leh
authors: Sanjaya Sena, Rahul Goyal, S. K. Tyagi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study presents a detailed thermal load analysis of a underground potato storage facility for cold climate applications, with storage capacity of 10.5 metric tonnes and indoor setpoint of 5<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">°</sup>C. Respiration, and ventilation loads are estimated by following standards, while envelope heat loads are calculated using equivalent thermal conductance and sol-air temperature approach for ambient-coupled sections, and by Mitalas method for ground-coupled sections. Local ambient and ground surface temperature is modeled using a first-order Fourier series, and a constant lower boundary temperature of 10°C is considered. Soil stratification and thermal properties are adopted from established literature. The energy performance of underground storage facility (USF) is compared with similar-sized above-grade storage facility, highlighting the superior thermal buffering and load reduction potential of USF in cold climates. Results show envelope loads dominate over ventilation and respiration loads for USF. Further analysis is carried out to optimize envelope load through strategic insulation placement. Additionally, a humidity control mechanism based on adiabatic mixing of indoor air and ambient air is developed and validated to address high humidity levels. Overall, the study offers practical design insights and a robust thermal performance assessment of UBs for cold-climate storage applications.

title: V2G and Delayed Charging for EV Battery Longevity
authors: Suraj S, Subramanian P J, Narayan S. Manjarekar, Soumyabrata Barik, Sudarshan Swain
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Electric Vehicle (EV) remains idle for more than 16 hours a day and with high storage State of Charge (SoC). The EV battery gets fully charged and stays idle with 100% SoC for hours before its need of use. These two scenarios add up to the Calendar Aging (CA) and resulting in capacity fade and battery degradation. In this paper Vehicle to Grid (V2G) based discharging and delayed charging is proposed for reducing the CaA and thereby improving the battery longevity. The V2G is utilized during the peak demand time and aiding the demand response management. The delayed charging is employed by accessing the user’s need of use date and time with IoT. The charging and V2G is implemented with a bidirectional charger. The SoC estimation with combination of Open Circuit Voltage (OCV) method and Coulomb Counting (CoC) method is used for implementing V2G and delayed charging effectively. The proposed methodology is validated with a hardware experimental setup comprising 120V, 30Ah Li-Ion battery, bidirectional charger, WAVECT WCU300 FPGA ARM based controller to control the bidirectional converter and ESP32 for implementing IoT supported with Blynk Server. The proposed Delayed Charging and V2G is found to reduce capacity loss by 5%.

title: Implementation of Talkative Power Conversion with PWM FSK and PSK in Three-Level T-type Inverter
authors: Ch. Rajender, A. Kirubakaran
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Talkative power conversion (TPC) is a revolutionary digital power and power system digitization technique that enables power electronics converters to communicate energy and data simultaneously without requiring extra communication infrastructure. In this study, a three-level T-type inverter is equipped with TPC technology, which simultaneously modulates power and data using the switching frequency and phase as degrees of control freedom. PWM-frequency shift keying (PWM-FSK) and phase shift keying (PWM-PSK) are two straightforward and efficient TPC approaches in the grid integration of a three-level T-type inverter. The transmitted data is obtained using a demodulation technique using the fast Fourier transform (FFT) method. The simulation results clearly show the effectiveness and precision of the theoretical analysis.

title: Closed Loop Control of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM) Drive
authors: Yawer Abbas Khan, B. Harinika, N. Kavya, Vimlesh Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In order to improve the Maximum Torque Per Ampere (MTPA) control strategy in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM) drives, especially for electric vehicle (EV) applications. In this paper, a Model Reference Adaptive System (MRAS)-based approach is proposed. In order to increase overall drive efficiency-a crucial component of EV performance and range-MTPA control is frequently used to produce the maximum torque with a minimum amount of current. However, due to the variation in the q axis inductance, which cause a deviation from the optimal current trajectory, its efficiency declines under dynamic operating conditions. An MRAS-based online estimation mechanism that adjusts to variations in the motor’s ‘ $\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{q}}$ ‘, has been integrated into a closed-loop MTPA control framework in order to overcome this constraint. To keep the machine under MTPA condition of operation, the MRAS observer dynamically modifies the reference current vector and estimates the fluctuating inductance. The proposed model’s suitability for high-performance EV drive systems is demonstrated by simulation results, which confirm its robustness and effectiveness under varying load and speed conditions.

title: Towards Explainable Retinal Vessel Segmentation: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Sounak Sadhukhan, Susmita Das, Arunabha Tarafdar, Aparna Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Retinal fundus image analysis has been broadly used to identify numerous cardiovascular and eye-related diseases. In ophthalmology, fundus image segmentation is a crucial step in the automated identification and description of blood vessels. As the encoder-decoder architecture based on convolutional neural networks (U-Net) was created for pixel-wise segmentation problems and has already been applied in several fields, it has been used here for retinal blood vessel segmentation. It successfully blends efficient learning, spatial information preservation, and feature extraction. The U-Net’s encoder path captures semantic features, and its decoder refines those features for precise localization. This method has been assessed on two different datasets, and encouraging outcomes were found. Because our model generates higher validation accuracy, it produces findings on these datasets that are equivalent to the state-of-the-art approaches. Gradientweighted class activation mapping is also used to increase this model’s explainability. The mapping tool assists us in identifying the areas of the images that have the most influence on the segmentation process and in comprehending the decision-making process.

title: Multi-objective dung beetle optimisation algorithm
authors: Ziyue Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The dung beetle optimization algorithm, as an emerging metaheuristic algorithm, is currently only applicable to single-objective optimization problems. However, practical problems usually involve multiple conflicting objectives, and a multi-objective optimization approach is needed to address them. To this end, a multi-objective dung beetle optimization algorithm is proposed in this paper, which extends the ability of the dung beetle optimization algorithm to be applied in multi-objective scenarios by introducing strategies such as non-dominated sorting strategy and congestion distance. To evaluate the multi-objective dung beetle optimizer's performance, this paper selects the ZDT series of standard test functions for experiments and compares and analyzes them with other multi-objective algorithms. The experimental results show that the Pareto solution sets generated by the multi-objective dung beetle optimization algorithm are excellent in both convergence and distribution: in the objective space, their solution sets approximate the theoretical Pareto front better than the comparison algorithms, and the inverted generational distance is significantly lower. These results fully demonstrate that the multi-objective dung beetle optimization algorithm possesses stronger global exploration capability and stable performance when addressing complex multi-objective problems.

title: Creative Product Modeling and Design to Revitalize the Inheritance of Intangible Cultural Heritage
authors: Yixin Shao, Fangze Cui, Ruiqi Xiong, Yutong Guo, Xinwang Zhao, Ziyue Cheng, Yingyue Xia, Luyao Guan, Chen Liang, Long He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH) across regions includes traditional music, crafts, folk customs, and performing art, with traditional crafts and visual arts falling in behind. They carry strong historical memories and regional identities. However, the acceleration of modernization and industrialization has made it difficult for them to be passed on, applied in the market and accepted by the society. Through the theoretical framework of Earthbound Culture, this paper explores the function of product design as an intermediary in protecting and revitalizing ICH. We conduct in-depth case studies on university-enterprise collaborations involving regional heritage projects to analyze how site-specific design can revitalize cultural heritage and integrate it with modern industry. Research shows that through the design intervention of the Earth Culture Paradigm, combined with cooperation, educational mechanisms and narrative techniques, the communication, business and innovation capabilities of ICH projects have been greatly enhanced, providing a replicable model for the inheritance of ICH.

title: Research on Regional Geological Hazard Susceptibility Model Based on Frequency Ratio Support Vector Machine
authors: Yukun Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Landslide disasters pose a serious threat to regional security and sustainable development, and accurate assessment of their susceptibility is a key aspect of disaster prevention and reduction. To overcome the limitations of traditional models in evaluation accuracy, this study relies on Geographic Information System (GIS) technology and innovatively integrates the factor weight quantification advantages of the Frequency Ratio (FR) model with the nonlinear data processing capabilities of the Support Vector Machine (SVM) model, establishing a Frequency Ratio-Support Vector Machine coupling model (FR-SVM). A systematic landslide susceptibility evaluation study is conducted for Shaanxi Province. This model can more accurately identify the areas prone to landslides, which can provide an important basis for the planning and implementation of targeted preventive measures.

title: DEL: A Fine-Grained Power Consumption Estimation Model Integrating Deep & Cross Network with LSTM
authors: Zhu Chunqiang, Wang Jing, Quan Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: Accurately estimating energy consumption is critical for effective energy management and policy-making, with highgranularity electricity data offering a promising foundation for this task. However, traditional methods are often limited by data silos, fixed conversion coefficients, and an inability to model the complex, high-dimensional factors influencing energy use. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel hybrid deep learning model, the Deep & Cross LSTM (DEL), for fine-grained electricity consumption estimation. The DEL model synergistically combines a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network to capture temporal dynamics from time-series data with a Deep & Cross Network (DCN) to model complex interactions among static features like industry type and company attributes. Validated on a real-world dataset, the DEL model, supported by a comprehensive feature engineering scheme, is shown to significantly outperform multiple baseline models in prediction accuracy. This work provides a powerful new tool for precise energy consumption analysis, offering robust technical support for fine-grained energy management.

title: A Comb Filter-PLL based Rotor Position Estimation Method for Switched Reluctance Motor Drives
authors: Chetan S. Matwankar, Bhim Singh, Sumit Pramanick
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Position-sensorless control of medium-speed and high-speed switched reluctance motor drives conventionally depends on flux linkage-based techniques that require pre-measured magnetic characteristics. These characteristics are generally obtained offline and require a significant digital signal processor (DSP) memory. Furthermore, they are prone to errors arising due to online calculation of the flux-linkage and other disturbances. This work presents an alternate methodology employing a comb filter-based method to extract the fundamental flux component while effectively rejecting dominant harmonics and DC offset. The rotor position and speed are then approximated utilizing a Phase-Locked Loop (PLL), eliminating the need for stored flux characteristics. The presented technique is validated by simulation for an 8/6 switched reluctance motor to demonstrate its high estimation accuracy during steady state and dynamic operating conditions.

title: Data Security and Consumer Trust in FinTech
authors: Ruchin Kumar, Sharvan Kumar Garg, Vivek Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The rapid evolution of financial technology (FinTech) is being fueled by the exponential growth and widespread use of mobile devices worldwide. Both start-ups and established financial institutions now view FinTech as a strategic avenue for scaling their businesses. However, this potential can only be unlocked through the development of advanced mobile applications and the deployment of secure, robust digital infrastructures. In parallel, the rise in mobile application security threats has created significant challenges for both users and service providers, exposing them to heightened risks. This research offers concrete, data driven insights into the factors that drive both individuals and organizations to embrace FinTech solutions. We focus on five critical elements - customer trust, robust data security measures, perceived value enhancements, user interface design, and marketing tactics - and analyze how each one contributes to adoption decisions. Our results demonstrate that establishing trust, implementing strong security protocols, and delivering a seamless user experience through intuitive interfaces are essential for encouraging FinTech uptake. The work builds on the Technology Acceptance Model, extending and adapting it to the German banking context with these five core drivers. Insights from this study aims to support financial institutions in enhancing their FinTech strategies, ultimately enabling them to achieve substantial cost efficiencies and greater market penetration across their global operations.

title: Vision Transformer (ViT)-based Approach for Accurate Detection of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
authors: Vivek C. Joshi, Mayuri A. Mehta
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The classification of white blood cells is crucial for precise diagnosis of hematological disorders, particularly Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), which is a fast-growing type of blood cancer. Traditional ALL diagnostic methods rely on lengthy and manual microscopic tests, which are also vulnerable to human error. In this paper, we propose a Vision Transformer (ViT)-based ALL detection approach to improve the performance and reliability of automated ALL diagnosis systems. The proposed approach is evaluated using multiple performance metrics, which include loss, accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score. The results are compared with state-of-the-art classification models, which include Swin Transformer (SwinT) and CNN-based models such as ResNet, EfficientNet, and VGG16. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach effectively reduces training and testing loss, achieving 6.64% and 35.20%, respectively. Additionally, the proposed approach attains superior performance across all key evaluation metrics, with training accuracy of 96.43%, validation accuracy of 87.95%, and testing accuracy of 88.50%. Additionally, the proposed approach achieves a precision of 85.50%, a recall of 89.70%, and an F1 score of 87.30%. The proposed approach offers a robust and efficient solution for ALL detection, potentially leading to more accurate and timely diagnoses, thus improving patient outcomes in clinical practice.

title: Assessment of Cognitive Load during Hand Gesture Based Computer Interaction Using Galvanic Skin Response Attached to Foot
authors: Durgesh Lohar, Surajit Dutta, Anupam Basu, Bibhash Sen
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The importance of computers is increasing among people with special abilities, to become part of technological advancements. Human-computer interaction (HCI) ensures the design and accessibility of technologies to increase the participation of people. However, people struggling with visual ability suffer more than others while interacting with digital devices. Towards this direction, gesture-based computer interaction is popularising among visually impaired people (VIP). To improve HCI, it is essential to minimize the level of cognitive load experienced by VIP. In this context, a novel approach using galvanic skin response (GSR) attached to the VIP foot has been used to assess the real-time cognitive load while interacting with hand gesture-based applications. The experiment is carried out with 19 participants and numerous classifiers to identify the level of cognitive load. It has been found that XGBoost and CatBoost classifiers classify the binary classification with $86.15 \%$ and $86.79 \%$ accuracy. The results advocate that GSR attached to the foot is a potential physiological measurement to classify the cognitive load while interacting with hand dominated applications. This is evident that, the effectiveness of GSR and foot-based features is excellent in real time classification of the cognitive load.

title: Design and Implementation of Multimodal Sensor Fusion in Environmental Monitoring System
authors: Junrui Guo, Zebin Deng, Haonan Yu, Lushen Zhao, Ling Chen, Keqiang Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The design and implementation of computerized sensor systems are presented, with emphasis placed on exploring the application of multimodal sensors in environmental monitoring and intelligent control. First, during sensor selection and integration, multiple sensor types are carefully chosen to construct a multimodal sensor network, considering both performance and cost-effectiveness. Second, for data processing and fusion, a closed-loop sensor-controller architecture is designed, where analog signals are converted to digital form using a digital-to-analog converter. An innovative vibration threshold setting, and attenuation mechanism are implemented to effectively mitigate false alarms and enhance data processing accuracy and reliability. Finally, comprehensive system testing, and optimization are conducted. Sensor and controller functions are verified through benchmark tests to ensure accurate data transmission and equipment control. System parameters are adjusted based on test results to optimize performance, improving response speed and operational stability.

title: Modelling and Performance Analysis of a 33/11kV Substation with Solar Integration Using ETAP: A Case Study of Vishrambag Substation
authors: Sarvesh A. Kulkarni, Vijay Mohale, Prajyot M. Tonape, P. G. Bapat, A. M. Khandekar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: With an exponentially increased adoption of renewable energy sources, integration of solar power into electrical Indian grid has become a crucial step to achieve sustainable and efficient power systems. This paper focuses on the load flow and short circuit analysis of the 33/11kV Vishrambag substation, simulated with help of ETAP software, while incorporation of solar panels into the grid. The study aims to evaluate the operational performance of the substation, which includes voltage profiles, power losses, and fault current levels, under different operational scenarios. The single line diagram of the substation is updated to include solar power generation, allows an in-depth assessment of its impact on the distribution network. The load flow analysis disclosed significant improvements in voltage regulation and reduced power losses due to the integration of solar energy, which supplements conventional sources while peak demand. The short circuit analysis highlighted changes in fault current levels, necessitates a review of current protective equipment to ensure operational safety and reliability. The results emphasize the potential of solar integration in improvement of grid performance and also address challenges like higher fault currents and system upgrades required for efficient operation. This study provides valuable insights into the technical implications of renewable energy integration, which serves as a reference for utility Engineer and researchers who work on similar tasks. To demonstrate the feasibility and benefits of solar adoption, this paper contributes to the efforts to modernize substations and promote sustainable energy solutions in power distribution systems..

title: Impact of Dynamic Channel Coding Performance in Indoor Visible Light Communication
authors: Syed Agha Hassnain Mohsan, Abdelrahman Elfikky, Qian Li, H. Y. Fu
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of dynamic motion on indoor visible light communication (VLC) channels in both static and dynamic scenarios. Channel gain variations are analyzed through realistic Zemax Optics Studio simulations, employing Monte Carlo ray tracing to capture intricate channel characteristics. We model dynamic channel gain variations using R-programming, thoroughly examining bit error rate (BER) performance for coded and uncoded schemes. Results show channel coding significantly improves SNR, achieving 30 dB (dynamic) and 11 dB (static) gains, rigorously validated via goodness-of-fit (GoF) tests (AD, KS, CVM) and power distribution analysis.

title: Structural Changes in Immune Cells Following Sepsis and IRF5 Knockdown: An Atomic Force Microscopy Study
authors: Viktoria Sergunova, Alexander Grechko, Maxim E. Dokukin, Vladimir Inozemtsev
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The present study aimed to analyze the morphological and mechanical changes in neutrophils associated with infectious septic complications and IRF5 gene knockdown in macrophages. In our study, we evaluated the morphological properties of neutrophils, including the areas of the nucleus and the membrane, as well as the membrane roughness (Ra) and the degree of NET activation. Concurrently, the phenotypic and biomechanical changes occurring in macrophages were investigated subsequent to IRF5 knockdown. The expression levels of macrophage markers (iNOS, CD206), the mitochondrial content, and the mechanical properties were analyzed.

title: Harmonic-Model-Based Wiggling Correction for Robust Indirect Time-of-Flight Imaging
authors: Jaehyeok Kim, Jaehwa Jeong
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: Three-dimensional spatial information is widely used across many fields, and the need for measurement techniques that provide high accuracy, precision, and robustness to environmental variation is increasingly critical. This paper addresses wiggling caused by harmonics of the modulation wave-form in Indirect Time-of-Flight (iToF) and proposes a method that simultaneously corrects distance and amplitude without hardware modification. We employ a harmonic model designed for real signals and estimate residual harmonic components via prior calibration. We then use Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), with the Interior Point Method (IPM) applied as post-processing, to estimate the model parameters from the calibration data. In the online stage, we apply Newton's method to a single frame, thereby removing wiggling in both distance and amplitude. Experiments at modulation frequencies of 12, 18, and 24 MHz confirm consistency between the model and measurements. At 12 MHz the distance Mean Absolute Error (MAE) decreases from 7.30 cm to 0.89 cm after 1 iteration and converges to 0.87 cm within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2-3$</tex> iterations, demonstrating convergence speed and reproducibility. Because only four parameters per pixel are stored, memory demand is lower than prior-data-based corrections, and convergence within two or three iterations per frame supports practicality. The approach is also expected to be effective when combined with Multi-Path Interference (MPI) mitigation.

title: Application of Artificial Neural Networks for Weather Forecasting and Photovoltaic Power Prediction Using Local Meteorological and Meteosat Satellite Data
authors: Aleksandar Pantić, Adriana Petković, Neda Branković, Sanja Aleksić, Dragan Pantić
abstract: Accurate forecasting of meteorological parameters and photovoltaic (PV) power output is essential for reliable grid integration of renewable energy. This paper presents a MATLAB-based framework for short-term PV power prediction using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) trained on local weather station measurements and Meteosat satellite data. The dataset includes irradiance components, cloud index, albedo, air temperature, wind speed, and cyclic time features. Preprocessing involves synchronization, resampling, normalization, and performance ratio (PR)-based energy yield calculation. A Multi-Layer Perceptron ANN trained with the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm is employed. Experimental results show that the ANN significantly outperforms a conventional GHI-PR baseline, reducing mean absolute error from 48.6~Wh to 12.4~Wh and root mean squared error from 65.2~Wh to 18.7~Wh, while capturing both seasonal variability and intra-day fluctuations. The proposed framework demonstrates that ANN-based approaches provide accurate and flexible PV forecasts and can be extended with advanced irradiance models, explicit temperature corrections, and deep learning architectures for multi-horizon prediction.

title: Hybrid Artificial Intelligence-Based Control of Standalone PV Systems: A Resilient Energy Management Framework for Indian Climates
authors: N. P. Vishnu Pandi, K. Kumar, Lakshmi Devi, Ramji Tiwari
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The increasing demand for sustainable and autonomous energy systems has positioned standalone solar photovoltaic (PV) installations as a key solution for rural electrification and off-grid applications. However, their effectiveness is often constrained by fluctuating environmental conditions, unpredictable load profiles, and the limitations of traditional control mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel hybrid artificial intelligence (AI) control strategy that integrates Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference Systems (ANFIS), Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), and Fuzzy Logic Controllers (FLCs) to enhance the operational efficiency of standalone PV systems. The framework dynamically regulates maximum power point tracking (MPPT), manages battery charging and discharging, and improves load prioritization in real time. Simulations conducted using meteorological data from representative Indian cities demonstrate a significant improvement in energy conversion efficiency, battery longevity, and system responsiveness when compared to conventional control strategies. The proposed hybrid AI model offers a scalable, intelligent control approach suitable for deployment in diverse climatic and load scenarios.

title: A Layered Blockchain Architecture for Unbiased and Trustworthy Internet Voting Systems
authors: Ashmita Bhattacharjee, Arnav Das, Sayan Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Internet voting (I-voting) is emerging as a critical tool to enhance democratic participation by offering accessibility, convenience, and scalability, especially for remote or marginalized populations. However, its adoption is hindered by serious concerns around security, transparency, and trust. To address these challenges, a modular multi-layered blockchain architecture is proposed for online voting platforms with a focus on fairness, decentralization, and auditability. Blockchain’s inherent properties: immutability, distributed consensus, and transparency, make it a promising foundation for ensuring tamper-evident, verifiable, and secure voting systems. Encompassing the most sensitive functionalities within independent layers such as data, network, consensus, incentive, and application allows for scalability, interoperability, and the safe processing of votes, irrespective of computeintensive or stake-based validator selection. The architecture supports heterogeneous node involvement (validator, full, light nodes) with a regulating Voting Authority to enforce compliance without restricting decentralization. Decoupling validation policy and consensus rules enables the integration of fairness-aware validation procedures without compromising crypto-integrity or voter anonymity. This system addresses fundamental flaws in existing consensus protocols and provides a blueprint for a secure, transparent, and trustworthy digital electoral foundation.

title: Distributed Large Strain Sensing System Based on Image Filtering for Earthquake Disaster Monitoring
authors: Qiang Li, Jinyun Yu, Shihong Zhang, Yinan Qiu, Yue Ma, Xiaohang Luo, Yingfei Li, Peng Li
abstract: In this study, a large dynamic range distributed strain sensing technology based on a positional self-correction algorithm and non-uniform Gaussian image filtering is presented. The dynamic adjustment of the reference signal by the measured signal is implemented to achieve self-compensation between the reference and measured signals in the range domain. To eliminate the pseudo-peak interference caused by large strain in OFDR distributed sensing systems, a non-uniform Gaussian filtering image processing method is introduced. While noise interference is effectively suppressed, the detailed features of real strain signals are maximally preserved, avoiding the signal distortion problems prone to occur in traditional filtering methods when processing complex strain scenarios. The reliability of system measurement data and the accuracy of strain demodulation are significantly improved, enabling distributed strain sensing with a large range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8000 \mu \varepsilon$</tex> at a spatial resolution of 4 mm.

title: 3D Ground Truth Reconstruction from Multi-Camera Annotations Using UKF
authors: Linh Van Ma, Unse Fatima, Tepy Sokun Chriv, Haroon Imran, Moongu Jeon
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: Accurate 3D ground truth estimation is critical for applications such as autonomous navigation, surveillance, and robotics. This paper introduces a novel method that uses an Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) to fuse 2D bounding box or pose keypoint ground truth annotations from multiple calibrated cameras into accurate 3D ground truth. By leveraging human-annotated ground-truth 2D, our proposed method, a multi-camera single-object tracking algorithm, transforms 2D image coordinates into robust 3D world coordinates through homography-based projection and UKF-based fusion. Our proposed algorithm processes multi-view data to estimate object positions and shapes while effectively handling challenges such as occlusion. We evaluate our method on the CMC, Wildtrack, and Panoptic datasets, demonstrating high accuracy in 3D localization compared to the available 3D ground truth. Unlike existing approaches that provide only ground-plane information, our method also outputs the full 3D shape of each object. Additionally, the algorithm offers a scalable and fully automatic solution for multi-camera systems using only 2D image annotations.

title: Tailoring 2D and 3D Interference Structures via Multi-Parameter Control in a $3+1$ Beam Laser Interference System
authors: Amir Hamza, Li Li, Zuobin Wang, Dayou Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Achieving precise 3D geometric control in Laser Interference Lithography (LIL) is vital. This study simulates a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3+1$</tex> beam LIL system, exploring how wave vector, polarization, and phase modulation impact 2D/3D pattern symmetry and morphology. We found phase shifts translate patterns, polarization rotation reshapes motifs, and wave vector changes alter lattice symmetry. Thus, wave vector governs periodicity/symmetry, polarization controls morphology, and phase tunes position. This decoupled parameter control in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3+1$</tex> LIL allows fabrication of programmable structures for advanced photonics and materials.

title: Design and Implementation of Intelligent HVAC Control System Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jianfeng Lu, Jianhua Li, Ruijie Ma, Hao Wang
abstract: Aiming at the problem of excessive energy consumption and insufficient comfort caused by dynamic changes in the environment and uncertainty in personnel behavior in traditional HVAC systems, this paper aims to design and implement an intelligent control system based on reinforcement learning to simultaneously reduce system energy consumption and improve indoor environmental comfort. First, an accurate building thermodynamic model is constructed based on the historical operation data of the building and the principles of thermodynamics. Secondly, the Q-Learning algorithm is designed as the core control strategy. Its state space is defined as a multivariate vector covering indoor and outdoor temperature and humidity, CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentration, personnel density and equipment status, and the action space covers the opening of the cold water valve, the setting of the supply air temperature and the adjustment instructions of the fresh air volume. The reward function adopts a weighted fusion method to quantitatively evaluate the energy consumption cost and the deviation of comfort. The model training and strategy optimization are first carried out on the EnergyPlus simulation platform, and then deployed to the actual HVAC system for online learning and real-time control. During the three-month winter heating season, the system reduced the overall energy consumption by 24.6% and the average time of comfort exceeding the limit is reduced by 41.9%. This reinforcement learning control system effectively solves the problem of dynamic optimization of the HVAC system, significantly achieves the dual-objective coordinated optimization of energy saving and comfort, and has good engineering application value and economic benefits.

title: An AI-Driven Acoustic Monitoring Framework for Comprehensive Bee Hive Health Assessment
authors: M Raksha Kini, Navaneeth Bhaskar, Rhea Dmello, Vaishnavi J Bangera, Sanjana Bokde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: In this paper, we have designed a system for assessing beehive health through beehive monitoring using audio recordings of the bees in the hives. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model was used for the purpose, which was trained on Mel-spectrogram images obtained by converting the audio recordings into corresponding images. The system was also compared and evaluated with other models such as ResNet90 and MobileNetV2. The model obtained an accuracy of 98.1%, precision of 97.9% and recall of 98.3% which showed excellent metrics that outperformed the other popular models. During the ROC analysis, the AUC obtained was 0.97 which showed that the model has a good classification performance. The model could also identify the subtle differences in the sounds produced by the bees in healthy and unhealthy hive states. This helped to enable non-invasive hive monitoring. We developed a user-friendly web interface which would help the users to easily interact with the system. This solution helps to reduce human intervention and promote a non-invasive, intelligent approach to beekeeping to encourage healthier beekeeping practices. The proposed approach is beneficial for both small-scale and commercial beekeepers, providing them with an efficient and practical solution for hive monitoring.

title: Impact of Land Lease Prices on the Levelized Cost of Electricity of Solar PV Projects in Indian Cities
authors: Sagnik Bhattacharya, Pradip Kumar Sadhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Conventional ground-mounted photovoltaic (PV) systems require vast land resources. Urban development causes price escalation of land value, resulting in high lease costs. Therefore, a comparative analysis of the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) for ground-mounted PV systems, along with other land-saving alternatives such as rooftop PV, floating PV, and building-integrated PV (BIPV) systems, is necessary. The present research work calculates and compares the LCOE of PV systems in 8 different Indian cities. A 1 MW PV system is considered the benchmark for simulation. Weather files and PV cost components are collected and utilized for LCOE calculations. Ground-mounted PV systems are affordable in smaller cities like Dhanbad (5.07 INR/kWh to 9.14 INR/kWh). In large cities like Mumbai and Delhi, the LCOE of land-based PV varies from 5.2 INR/kWh to 73.09 INR/kWh. The floating PV systems have LCOE between 4.44 INR/kWh and 6.64 INR/kWh. The LCOE of BIPV systems varies from 7.83 INR/kWh to 10.61 INR/kWh. PV rooftop systems are the most economical alternatives with LCOE from 4.89 INR/kWh to 5.23 INR/kWh. LCOE varies nonlinearly with the Lease escalation factor and degradation rate. The results are compared with grid electricity prices. The relative order of economic feasibility is dependent on land lease and waterbody lease cost, the presence of residential subsidy, and degradation rate. This comparative framework is aimed at helping government bodies, engineers, and researchers to enable informed decision-making in urban PV system planning.

title: Isoelectric Focusing of Type I Collagen for Creating an Artificial Cornea
authors: Alexey Nashchekin, Yuliya Nashchekina, Alexey Lihachev, Danila Markov, Sergey Pavlov, Mariya Sirotkina, Oleg Temnikov
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Collagen is one of the main components of the extracellular matrix, inherent in various types of tissues, in each of which it has a certain structure. It is widely used to prepare carriers (scaffolds) for culturing and transplanting various types of cells during the restoration of damaged tissues. In the body, the extracellular matrix mainly consists of microand nanopatterns that are isotropic or anisotropic. Thus, the corneal stroma of the eye is a tissue with a pronounced topographic structure. There are various physical approaches to creating a native stroma structure, such as: magnetic fields, mechanical alignment, structuring in an electric field, etc. The paper describes a technique for forming a structured tissue like structure based on collagen, with pronounced negative properties. The value of the isofocusing point for collagen genus in an external electric field is experimentally demonstrated, confirmed on the basis of calculation of the charge state of the collagen molecule, with visualization of the formation process using both polarization microscopy and by attaching a fluorescent label.

title: A Cross-Layer Design of Directional Antenna MAC and Opportunistic Routing Protocols for Shipborne Ad-Hoc Networks
authors: Wu Ren, Shengming Jiang, Jinyu Duan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Shipborne ad hoc networks are an essential component of maritime communication systems, playing a pivotal role in fleet coordination, offshore operations, and civilian maritime communications. However, vessels often need to maintain safety distances of several kilometers, far exceeding the effective communication range of conventional IEEE 802.11 standards. Furthermore, traditional routing mechanisms, such as AODV, struggle to maintain communication stability in highly dynamic topologies and opportunistic network environments. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a cross-layer design: at the MAC layer, directional antennas, a polling mechanism, and P-NAV table maintenance are employed to extend communication range and effectively mitigate hidden terminal and deafness issues; at the network layer, AODV routing is enhanced with an opportunistic network forwarding mechanism, dynamically selecting the optimal next-hop node when conventional paths are unavailable. Simulation results demonstrate that this approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of packet loss, latency, and throughput, significantly improving the communication performance and reliability of shipborne ad hoc networks in complex maritime environments.

title: InGaAs/AlGaAsSb Avalanche Photodiodes with Sub $100 \text{fW} / \sqrt{ } \text{Hz}$ Noise Equivlent Power at 22 to 52 °C
authors: Longyan Li, Jonathan D. Petticrew, Jonathan Taylor-Mew, Jo Shien Ng, Chee Hing Tan
abstract: Separate - Absorption - Multiplication Avalanche Photodiode (SAM-APD) made from Al0.85Ga0.15As0.56Sb0.44 (AlGaAsSb) avalanche region and InGaAs absorption region exhibits low dark current, excess noise, and Noise Equivalent Power (NEP) at room temperature. However, its performance at elevated temperatures has not been reported. In this work we performed comprehensive measurements of dark current, avalanche gain and noise spectrum of three InGaAs/AlGaAsSb SAM-APDs at 22 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$52{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. We observed a weak temperature dependence of dark current and breakdown voltage has a temperature coefficient of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.9 (\pm 0.5) \text{mV} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, which is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6-15$</tex> times better than a number of commercial 1550 nm APD modules. The best NEP ranges between 78 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$92 \text{fW} / \sqrt{ } \text{Hz}$</tex> at 22 to 52° C with NEP at 52° C outperforming a number of commercial 1550 nm APD modules at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$22{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. The low NEP value enable the InGaAs/AlGaAsSb SAM-APDs to detect optical pulse with as few as 78 photons per pulse at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$22{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, increasing to 100 photons at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$52{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. These results demonstrate that InGaAs/AlGaAsSb SAMAPDs have a superior temperature tolerance to maintain gain, NEP and low photon detection compared to typical 1550 nm SAMAPDs. Therefore, they can potentially increase the range and sensitivity of gas sensing, free space optical communication and ranging instruments.

title: Comparative Study of SoC Estimation Technique: Coulomb Counting Method and Kalman Filter Method
authors: Gaurav Daberao, Aakash Gupta, Aman Khan, Tushar Nautiyal, Avisha Tah
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: A Battery Management SystemS (BMS) manages and monitors the performance, safety, and health of a battery pack. One of its key function is estimating the State-of-Charge (SoC), which indicates the remaining energy in the battery. Monitoring the SoC of a battery is crucial for ensuring the efficient operation of energy storage systems. Since SoC cannot be directly measured, achieving accurate estimation plays a pivotal role in enhancing both system performance and operational flexibility. Furthermore, the information provided by SoC is instrumental in ensuring the safe functioning of the storage system and prolonging the battery's lifespan by avoiding overcharging or excessive discharging. Selecting a suitable SoC estimation algorithm often involves balancing the trade-off between the complexity of the algorithm and its accuracy. Among various available methods of SoC estimation, in this paper, emphasis is given on two basic methods i. e., the Kalman Filter Method and Coulomb Counting Method. Furthermore results from both these techniques are compared to give a better overview of efficient technique. These techniques are implemented on different battery models starting from the very basic single RC model to double RC model and compared on Matlab/Simulink.

title: Enhanced Gauss-Seidel approach for Power Flow Analysis in Islanded AC Microgrids Considering EV Models
authors: Ghanshyam Meena, Tarun Varshney, Akhilesh Mathur, V. P. Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The growing reliance on decentralised energy resources has fuelled interest in microgrids (MGs), which may run independently in islanded mode or in conjunction with the main power grid. Analysing load flow in MGs provides unique issues, especially in islanded mode, when typical approaches based on a slack bus are inadequate. This work presents a Modified Gauss-Seidel (MGS) approach for incorporating droop control parameters into load flow analysis while treating voltage and frequency as dynamic variables. This technique improves power sharing across Distributed Generators (DGs), maintains voltage and frequency stability, and reduces system losses. The effectiveness of the proposed approach was validated on 6-bus microgrid system comprising both voltage dependent loads and EV Loads, demonstrating its ability to improve stability, reduce power losses, and achieve balanced load distribution.

title: Real-time Data Fusion Design with High Performance
authors: Lei Rong, Haibo Wang, Qijun Xi, Jie Li, Bo Zeng, Min Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper mainly introduces a method of implementation of a combination algorithm. By using multistage fusion strategy, Shared memory, non-locking loop memory, multi-process concurrency processing, memory prepartition, establishing query chain table, etc., the design assurance of the data fusion algorithm is more real-time. At the same time, the design of spatial matching, batch number management and other solutions have been designed to implement the complete data processing frame.

title: Research on ICP Etching of GaAs-Based Vertical Cavity Surface Emitting Lasers
authors: Lilai Zhang, Yongqin Hao, Evgeny A Viktorov, Haoxuan Fan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: In the fabrication of oxide-limited vertical cavity surface emitting lasers (VCSELs)., the etching of GaAs/AIGaAs is a key step., which directly affects the subsequent process and the quality of VCSEL. The research mainly focus on the effect of VCSEL's etching side wall steepness., non-selective etching and dirty problem during deep etching. Using intermittent etching method to solve the problem of surface dirty caused by the by-production generated by ICP etching. According to modulate Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) power and Radio Frequency (RF) power., improve the side wall steepness and bottom flatness. With the ICP power at 380W and RF power at 120W., the side wall steepness reach to 85° and depth with 7.6 μ m.

title: Research on photovoltaic abnormal data correction based on K-means and CNN-LSSVM
authors: Tao Sun, Hai Wang, Qiang Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of abnormal photovoltaic data, an abnormal data identification and correction algorithm based on K-means and CNN-LSSVM is proposed. Firstly, the data is denoised, and the K-Means algorithm is used to cluster the photovoltaic output data. By calculating the abnormal score and superimposing the threshold screening algorithm, the abnormal data is finally identified, which improves the accuracy of identification. Secondly, in order to realize the correction of abnormal data, a prediction correction method based on CNNLSSVM is proposed. The feature extraction ability of convolutional neural network (CNN) and the sample regression prediction advantage of least squares support vector machine (LSSVM) are combined to improve the prediction accuracy of the model and realize the correction of abnormal photovoltaic power data. The simulation test was carried out using the photovoltaic data set of a certain area. The results show that this method can effectively deal with abnormal photovoltaic data to a certain extent, so as to improve the quality of photovoltaic data.

title: Integrating Ground Communication for Extended Drone Visual Line of Sight
authors: Francesco Betti Sorbelli, Sajjad Ghobadi, Lorenzo Palazzetti, Cristina M. Pinotti
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly permitted to operate within Visual Line of Sight (VLoS) under EU and US regulations. However, Beyond Visual Line of Sight (BVLoS) operations remain restricted, with waivers or certifications required. Extended Visual Line of Sight (EVLoS) offers a transitional solution, involving trained observers to assist pilots when visibility is obstructed. We propose enhancing EVLoS by integrating ground infrastructure, specifically city cameras and wireless communication networks already available on the ground, to replace human observers and enable BVLoS capabilities. Fixed and mobile cameras track drones to ensure regulatory compliance, while real-time data transmission via communication networks provides indirect oversight. The approach increases operational range, reliability, and redundancy through multi-hop connectivity. We introduce the Minimum Latency Problem (MLP), a UAV multi-trajectory optimization problem where UAVs are constantly tracked and monitored through ground antennas and city cameras, mimicking the human observers in EVLoS. Our goal is to minimize communication latency while ensuring that the number of antennas used for coverage is minimum. We prove MLP is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N P$</tex>-hard and propose an algorithm to solve it. Experiments on synthetic data demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in matching coverage and latency requirements.

title: 12V-5V/3.3V SIMO DC-DC Buck Converter
authors: Paranjay Garg, Harishwar Prasad, Naveen Yalla, Narendra Babu, Sukanta Halder
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper discusses the high-efficiency Single-Input Multiple-Output (SIMO) DC-DC buck converter for power electronics applications. The single-input multi-output (SIMO) converters can be used to reduce the cost and switching losses and hence improve system efficiency. This buck converter has two loops: one outer loop gives an output of 5 volts and another inner loop gives an output of 3.3 volts with one PI controller each. The 5V and 3.3V are used in the driver circuit, telemetry, and microcontroller. In this work, the general structure of a SIMO converter, design principles, small signal and stability analysis, and control steps are explained. The 5-watt converter is designed for hardware implementation and Matlab / Simulink.

title: Stability-Preserving Model Order Reduction using Eigen Permutation and Dandelion Optimization
authors: Akhilesh Kumar Gupta, Khushboo Kumari, Deepak Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Model order reduction (MOR) streamlines higher-order systems (HOSs) by creating lower-order approximations while preserving essential dynamics, aiding in efficient analysis and control design. Despite advancements in MOR techniques, achieving an optimal balance among accuracy, stability, and computational efficiency continues to pose a challenge, particularly for complex multi-input-multioutput (MIMO) systems. In this paper, a novel approach is introduced to determine the reduced-order model (ROM) of HOSs by integrating the Eigen permutation with the dandelion optimisation algorithm. This approach yields a stable ROM for a stable HOS. The efficiency of the presented approach is evaluated through numerical simulations of single-input singleoutput and MIMO systems. Furthermore, the proposed results are benchmarked against existing approaches, demonstrating their effectiveness.

title: Reasoned Rule Mining: Precision-Optimised Weighted LogProb Classification
authors: Jack Preuveneers, Yigit Ihlamur
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: We present Reasoned Rule Mining (RRM), a twostage framework for predicting startup founder success that (i) produces stage-wise evidence as scores, (ii) calibrates those scores to posterior probabilities via logistic calibration, (iii) fuses calibrated evidence additively on the log-odds scale in line with Bayes under conditional independence, and (iv) selects the operating point to maximise a precision-weighted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{0.5}$</tex> objective appropriate for asymmetric investment costs. On a reviewed subset of 8,000 founders with 160 labelled successes drawn from a pool of 9,892, the selected operating point attains 0.245 precision (12.25 x the market index) and 0.15 recall.

title: Cricinator: An AI-Driven Cricketer Guessing Game Leveraging Reinforcement Learning
authors: Govind Kumar, S. Thenmozhi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Cricinator is an AI-powered web application designed to guess the cricket player a user is thinking of by asking a series of yes/no questions, similar to Akinator but tailored for cricket. It uses a combination of decision trees, natural language processing, T5 transformers, and reinforcement learning to select the most informative questions based on a player attribute database. The system starts with key factors like batting style or country of origin, formulates natural-sounding questions, and refines its strategy through user interaction. The system has shown high accuracy in initial tests with 100 cricketers. If a player is unrecognized, CRICINATOR learns new attributes during the session and updates its database by requesting the player's name at the end. CRICINATOR not only entertains but also demonstrates how AI can drive interactive, domain-specific learning experiences.

title: Sensor-Driven Soil Nutrient Prediction via Machine Learning
authors: Sneha Dattatreya, Archit Khurana, Kanjalochan Jena, T. R. Lenka, Gaurav Chatterjee
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models for predicting soil primary nutrients—Nitrogen (N), Phosphorus (P), and Potassium (K)—using key soil parameters, including electrical conductivity (EC), pH, humidity (Hum), and temperature (Tem). Different models including Linear regression (LR), Random Forest Regression (RFR), Gradient Boosting (GB), Support vector Machine (SVM), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) were employed as representative ML techniques, while a deep neural network (DNN) was used to benchmark DL performance. While linear regression showed marginal improvement with additional features, random forest regression outperformed by achieving an $R^{2}$ score of 0.99 and demonstrating robustness across diverse soil conditions. Although the DNN captured nonlinear relationships, it required larger datasets and greater tuning efforts, making ML models more practical for real-time applications. The findings highlight the effectiveness of random forest regression as a lightweight yet powerful alternative to deep learning for IoTenabled precision agriculture, enabling scalable and real-time soil nutrient estimation.

title: Research on the Application of Random Forest Algorithm in Students Comprehensive Evaluation
authors: Hanzhou Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Traditional student evaluation methods often rely on subjective judgment and lack objectivity and comprehensiveness. This study proposes a comprehensive student evaluation model based on random forest. This model integrates multi-dimensional data such as students' academic performance, extracurricular activities, mental health, and social abilities, and realizes the scientific assessment of students' comprehensive qualities through machine learning algorithms. The research collected data of 3,500 students from universities in five different regions as experimental samples and constructed a multi-dimensional evaluation index system containing 42 characteristics. The experimental results show that the proposed random forest model has an accuracy rate of 87.3% in predicting students' comprehensive qualities, which is significantly better than traditional evaluation methods and other machine learning algorithms.

title: Performance Analysis of Proportional Integral,Sliding Mode and Super Twisting Sliding Mode Controller for Photovoltaic Applications
authors: Gopal Chandra Mahato, Neelbrata Roy, Tanmoy Roy Choudhury
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The adoption of photovoltaic (PV) systems is growing at a fast pace. To maximize power extraction from PV panels, Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithms play a crucial role. Extensive research literature explores various MPPT algorithms. Simultaneously, controllers designed to minimize tracking errors are equally important. Among them Proportional-Integral (PI) controller is popular due to its simplicity and effectivenes particularly for linear control systems. However, these controllers do not adapt well to the non- linear and dynamic nature of PV environment. In these scenarios, Sliding Mode Control (SMC) demonstrates greater robustness. However, the SMC utilizes a discontinous control law thereby causing chattering. On the other hand the super twisting sliding mode control (ST-SMC) provides continous control signals thereby eliminating chattering. This paper studies the performance of PI, SMC, and ST-SMC in a $\mathbf{1 0 0 ~ k W}$ MPPT-operated PV system. The system’s performance is analyzed through simulations conducted in MATLAB.

title: Digital Implementation of Grid-Forming Control for Power Converters Using Artificial Delays
authors: Jing Shi, Jin Zhang, Chen Peng, Minrui Fei
abstract: Dear Editor, This letter investigates the grid-forming control for power converters.
