Recently, grid-forming control based on matching of synchronous machines was suggested by using continuous measurements. In the present letter, we suggest a digital implementation using artificial delays where the controller employs the discrete-time measurements only. The resulting closed-loop system has additional terms due to the sampling compared with the case using the continuous measurements. We suggest appropriate Lyapunov functionals to obtain linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) for finding the upper bounds on the sampling that guarantees the globally exponential stability of a shifted equilibrium. Numerical case study illustrates the efficiency of the method.

title: A Bidirectional LSTM-Based Approach for Multi-Label Toxic Comment Classification
authors: Swati Soni, Vasujadevi Midasala, S Naga Kishore Bhavanam
abstract: A deep learning-based approach is presented for multi-label toxic comment classification on online platforms using the Jigsaw Toxic Comment Classification Challenge dataset, which includes 159,571 training and 153,164 test samples. A Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) model is designed to classify six toxicity categories: toxic, severe toxic, obscene, threat, insult, and identity hate. Class imbalance is addressed using a custom weighted binary cross-entropy loss function, enhancing the model’s sensitivity to underrepresented classes. Evaluation using precision, recall, and F1-score metrics yields a macro-average F1-score of 0.30 and a micro-average F1-score of 0.38. F1-scores for rare classes such as threat, identity hate, and severe toxic are 0.06, 0.15, and 0.12 respectively, indicating room for improvement. A Gradio-based web interface enables real-time comment evaluation, demonstrating practical utility in content moderation. The proposed solution is effective, scalable, and suitable for real-world deployment with scope for enhancement in rare class detection.

title: Energy-Efficient Depthwise Separable CNNs for Classification and Segmentation of Lung Cancer Nodules
authors: Vivaan Sharma, N.V.J.K Kartik, Vinayak, Aarsh Desai, Priyesh Gupta, Manjunath K. Vanahalli, B.M. Prabhu Prasad, Sanjay S. Bankapur, G.N. Girish
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Lung cancer remains a major global health issue, with early detection being critical for better outcomes. While deep learning models have shown strong results in lung nodule segmentation and cancer classification, their high computational demands limit use in real-world healthcare—especially in low-resource settings. This study introduces energy-efficient CNN architectures using depthwise separable convolutions for classification and segmentation of lung cancer. By replacing standard convolutions, our models reduce computational complexity by over 90% while maintaining strong performance. Tested on the LIDC-IDRI dataset (E2MIP challenge, MICCAI 2024), our models achieved an F1-score of 81.13% for classification and a Dice score of 0.55 for 2D segmentation. These results highlight the potential of lightweight CNNs for sustainable deployment in medical imaging.

title: Smart Segway: An IoT-Driven towards Autonomous vehicle with Optimized Design for Urban Navigation
authors: Khader Zaahid Umar, Bl Sharan Karthick, Raja Vara Prasad Yerra, Purav Shah, Hrishikesh Venkataraman
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: As cities grow and gated communities thrive, the need for smart, practical transport solutions becomes ever more pressing. Current Segways, with their low ground clearance, bulky designs, and lack of connectivity, often struggle to keep up with modern demands. Our paper presents a fresh take on the Segway, designed to tackle these issues head-on. It features a raised platform for better navigation over rough terrain, a novel lightweight honeycomb chassis built for strength and efficiency and a foldable shaft for easy storage. With IoT technology, it offers real-time tracking through an inertial measurement (IMU) unit, GPS, and obstacle detection using Time-of-Flight (ToF), ultrasonic, and proximity sensors. Powered by an ESP32 S3 microcontroller and Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) algorithms, its semi-autonomous navigation adapts smoothly to different environments. Testing shows the chassis handles heavy loads well, while IoT features support pothole detection, obstacle avoidance and vehicle-to-vehicle communication. This user-friendly, connected design is perfect for bustling cities and gated communities like campuses and neighborhoods, making mobility safer and smarter.

title: Optimal Allocation of Distributed Generation, Capacitor Banks and Electric Vehicle Charging Stations in Hybrid Distribution Networks
authors: Sravanthi Pagidipala, Sandeep Vuddanti
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Due to the intermittent nature of renewable energy (RE) based distributed generation (DG) and electric vehicles (EVs), optimal allocation of these entities remains a critical task. This work proposes a new methodology for addressing the planning of optimal allocation of RE-based DGs, EV charging stations (EVCSs), and capacitor banks (CBs) by considering uncertainties of wind, solar generators, and EV loads. The proposed optimization problem is developed by considering three objectives, including minimization of active power losses, voltage deviation, and voltage stability index (VSI), and they are solved by considering the various operational constraints. This work aims to implement the RE-based DG, which reduces the impact of load demands of EVCSs. The proposed optimal allocation problem has been tested on a 33-bus radial distribution system (RDS) by using a self-adaptive firefly algorithm (SAFA). The obtained results offer the most optimal solution for all the simulation scenarios considered in this paper in terms of power loss, minimum voltage, and minimum voltage deviation over other algorithms reported in the existing literature.

title: Low-Power Smart Sensor Module for Real-Time Threat Monitoring and Warning in Unattended Vehicles for Vandalism
authors: Pallab Maji, Rohan Kumar Singh, Satyendra Singh Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Detecting potential damage to unattended vehicles is crucial in urban environments where vandalism and harm are common. This paper introduces a low-power, real-time threat detection system combining ultrasonic sensors and artificial intelligence (AI) powered red, green, and blue (RGB) cameras. The system uses an NVIDIA Jetson Orin Nano and STM32 microcontroller for efficient operation. Ultrasonic sensors activate the Jetson platform upon detecting threats, triggering object detection, pose estimation and action recognition algorithms. A live video feed is streamed via the web real-time communication (WebRTC) protocol for high-quality, low-latency remote monitoring and alerts. This paper intends to demonstrate how a modular architecture can integrate multi-modal sensor data acquisition and recognition for incident logging while implementing power optimization techniques that ensure energy-efficient operation suitable for prolonged use, making them ideal for operation even during the vacation mode of electric vehicles (EVs) [1]. This research highlights the significance of real-time monitoring and demonstrates the potential of AI-powered embedded systems that enhance parking safety. It also proposes future enhancements to optimize detection capabilities further and provide a foundation for future enhancements, such as autonomous response systems.

title: Design of a Coordinated Control System for Flying Bars Based on Digital Twin Technology
authors: Huiqin Wang, Huiya Cao, Louyawen Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of coordinated control and safety monitoring in flying bar systems used in stage performance environments. A digital twin–enabled control framework is proposed to achieve real-time synchronization and fault warning through closed-loop interaction among physical devices, virtual models, and service layers. The system integrates 3D visualization, predictive diagnostics, and multi-bar coordination algorithms to support immersive applications, such as augmented reality (AR)–assisted rehearsals. Experimental results demonstrate high-precision motion synchronization and effective sensor anomaly detection, validating the system's applicability to intelligent stage control scenarios.

title: Spatiotemporal Topology-Informed Multiagent Reinforcement Learning Framework for Structured Multiprocess Collaborative Optimization
authors: Diju Liu, Yalin Wang, Chenliang Liu, Biao Luo, Biao Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Industrial multiprocess collaborative optimization presents significant challenges due to the intricate spatiotemporal dependencies inherent in modern process industries. Traditional optimization and reinforcement learning often treat subprocesses as independent entities, neglecting the fine-grained interdependencies among operational variables across different subprocesses. To fundamentally address this limitation, we introduce, a novel spatiotemporal topology-informed multiprocess collaborative optimization (STI-MCO) framework, which pioneers action-level interdependency modeling through an innovative spatiotemporal graph architecture. Rather than treating subprocesses as monolithic entities, STI-MCO operates at the operational variable level, enabling precise representation of both interprocess relationships and intraprocess dependencies through a hierarchical two-stage decision framework. This approach enables more precise coordination through fine-grained variable interactions, better temporal consistency via dynamic graph structures, and enhanced scalability compared with conventional agent-level methods. This paradigm shift from subprocess-level to variable-level collaboration, combined with dynamic graph-based coordination, enables extensive simulations and experiments conducted across three benchmark environments with progressively complex topologies to demonstrate that STI-MCO consistently outperforms baseline methods, achieving up to 38.9% improvement over centralized methods and 171.9% improvement over existing multiagent strategies. In addition, STI-MCO exhibits superior convergence efficiency, requiring significantly fewer training steps to achieve high performance. Its practical applicability is further validated through deployment in a real-world Salt Lake chemical process. By fundamentally shifting the optimization paradigm from holistic subprocess control to fine-grained variable-level collaboration, this work establishes a new framework for more effective optimization in complex industrial processes, particularly those with strong interunit coupling.

title: Coarse alignment method using manifold optimization for SINS on a rocking base
authors: Fujun Pei, Haoyang Li
abstract: This paper proposed a coarse alignment method using manifold optimization to solve the initial alignment problem of the strapdown inertial navigation system (SINS) on a rocking base. In this method, the initial coarse alignment of SINS is transformed from the constrained optimization problem in Euclidean space to an unconstrained optimization problem in Manifold space. There are two innovations in this method: the first is the optimization method of gradient descent in Euclidean space, which is reviewed and extended to manifold space. By combining the trust region method with the Barzilai-Borwein method, the optimal selection of the iterative update step on the tangent space of the manifold is realized, which ensures the efficient and stable convergence of the algorithm. Secondly, the Cayley transform is used to construct the retraction mapping, and its closed form analytic solution and structure preservation characteristics are used to effectively suppress the error accumulation caused by numerical approximation, so as to ensure that the iterative points on the tangent space of the manifold are mapped to the manifold space. The experiment results indicate that the proposed coarse alignment method performs better than the existing methods.

title: Model-Based Offline Reinforcement Learning With Adversarial Data Augmentation
authors: Hongye Cao, Fan Feng, Jing Huo, Shangdong Yang, Meng Fang, Tianpei Yang, Yang Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Model-based offline reinforcement learning (RL) constructs environment models from offline datasets to perform conservative policy optimization. Existing approaches focus on learning state transitions through ensemble models, rolling out conservative estimation to mitigate extrapolation errors. However, the static data makes it challenging to develop a robust policy, and offline agents cannot access the environment to gather new data. To address these challenges, we introduce Model-based Offline Reinforcement learning with AdversariaL data augmentation (MORAL). In MORAL, we replace the fixed horizon rollout by employing adversarial data augmentation to execute alternating sampling with ensemble models to enrich training data. Specifically, this adversarial process dynamically selects ensemble models against policy for biased sampling, mitigating the optimistic estimation of fixed models, thus robustly expanding the training data for policy optimization. Moreover, a differential factor (DF) is integrated into the adversarial process for regularization, ensuring error minimization in extrapolations. This data-augmented optimization adapts to diverse offline tasks without rollout horizon tuning, showing remarkable applicability. Extensive experiments on the D4RL benchmark demonstrate that MORAL outperforms other model-based offline RL methods in terms of policy learning and sample efficiency.

title: Low Complexity Waveform PAPR Reduction in Uplink ISAC System
authors: Yangyang Niu, Zhiqing Wei, Yuhan Long, Luyang Sun, Zhiyong Feng
abstract: Waveform design is expected as the core of uplink integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) to provide distributed sensing capability in the 6th generation (6G) mobile communication. The widely used orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) waveform in communication systems suffers from a high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR), while conventional PAPR reduction methods overlook the performance trade-offs between PAPR reduction and dual functionalities of sensing and communication. In this letter, we propose a low-PAPR waveform design method based on joint optimization of time-frequency domain statistical characteristics for uplink ISAC system, where the phase and amplitude are jointly optimized to enhance the PAPR performance without compromising sensing performance. Specifically, a low-complexity particle swarm optimization (PSO) method is derived for phase optimization, demonstrating the same sensing capability as OFDM. An exponential transformation is further applied to optimize the amplitude characteristics, achieving about 4 dB PAPR reduction compared to discrete Fourier transform spread OFDM (DFT-s-OFDM), with minimal impact on the communication bit error rate (BER). Simulation results validate the effectiveness of PAPR reduction and analyze the periodic autocorrelation function (ACF) and BER performance for dual-functionality evaluation.

title: On the Reversibility of Locality-Sensitive Hashing-based Biometric Template Protections_supp1-3637307.pdf
authors: Jae Hong Seo
abstract: With the extensive deployment of biometric authentication systems, the need for biometric template protection (BTP) has been widely recognized. Designing a secure yet efficient BTP is still a long-lasting challenge, and locality-sensitive hashing (LSH) is a promising building block for designing BTPs. In this study, we propose a novel pre-image attack applicable to lots of existing LSH-based BTPs, showing that many of them are in fact reversible. Our attack leverages structural properties shared by several LSH-based BTPs. Through investigation, we formalize a certain class of LSHs vulnerable to our attack, called PMA-LSH, which contains several known LSH-based BTPs, even not-yet-cryptanalyzed ones. Furthermore, the recovered pre-image from our attack is much closer to the original template compared to previous attacks, facilitating recovery of the original biometrics via reconstruction attacks. With existing reconstruction methods, we successfully recovered biometrics from templates protected by several LSH-based BTPs. The recovered biometrics sufficiently resemble the original ones, so they can be further exploited to impersonate other recognition systems, including commercial APIs. To facilitate further study, our source code is publicly available at https://github.com/Cryptology-Algorithm-Lab/Analysis_LSH.

title: A Broadband Low Sidelobe High-Efficiency Linear-to-Circular Polarization Conversion Metasurface With Independent Amplitude/Phase Control
authors: Yangkun Zhu, Wenquan Cao, Huangshu Zhou, Yixin Tong, Jiemin Jing, Chuang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A broadband low sidelobe high-efficiency linear-to-circular polarization conversion metasurface with independent amplitude and phase control is proposed in this communication. Based on the receive-transmit (R-T) structure, a guided-wave layer with a multi-stage stepped impedance stripline is introduced in the middle layer. This structure exploits the impedance mismatch mechanism to achieve independent regulation of transmission amplitude. At the same time, continuous phase adjustment across a wide frequency range is enabled by rotating the transmitter patch (TP). Additionally, the design offers adaptability to various incident wave polarizations by replacing the receiver patch (RP) with one exhibiting suitable polarization characteristics, without modifying the amplitude-phase control mode and the polarization state of the transmitted wave. Measured results demonstrate that the proposed metasurface (MS) antenna achieves a gain of 27 dBic, with a 3-dB gain bandwidth of 36.1%, and achieves low side lobe levels (SLLs) of −26.9 dB (xoz-plane)/−27.1 dB (yoz-plane) at 14.5 GHz, while obtaining a high aperture efficiency (AE) of 40.8%. The proposed transmissive MS exhibits significant potential in radar and future wireless communication systems.

title: Incremental Data-Driven Fault Diagnosis for Conveyor Rollers With Prior Drift Adaptation: An Online Active Kernel Learning Approach
authors: Han Zhou, Hao Ren, Hongpeng Yin, Guoxiang Zhong, Guangxia Xu, Chunhua Yang, Weihua Gui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: Conveyor rollers are essential components in the hot steel milling process, responsible for transporting products between various stages of production throughout the entire process. Due to the development of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT), conveyors are now equipped with sensors to collect real-time data, facilitating data-driven fault diagnosis models. While many well-trained data-driven diagnostic models initially demonstrate accurate performance, their effectiveness may decline over time due to unexpected changes, such as the emergence of new faults. This causes the prior distribution of fault data to change over time, and we refer to this as prior drift. In this study, we provide a mathematical definition of prior drift within the context of fault diagnosis and then develop a general learning criterion to guide the incremental updating of fault diagnosis models under such conditions. Building on this criterion, we propose an online active kernel learning-based fault diagnosis model (OAKL) for conveyor rollers. OAKL updates the diagnosis model in an incremental manner and adapts to prior drift. Particularly, it leverages selective querying and labeling of the most informative samples to facilitate early detection of novel faults, avoid performance bias, and reduce the number of incremental samples required. A rigorous theoretical analysis is conducted to demonstrate the theoretical validity of OAKL. The experimental results on a practical industrial case demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in fault diagnosis.

title: DM-VSR: Depth-Aware Diffusion Models With Adaptive Modulation for Video Super-Resolution
authors: Linlin Liu, Yifan Wang, Yize Wang, Zhen Xu, Jun Tang, Yong Ding
abstract: Video Super-Resolution (VSR) is essential for enhancing the quality of low-resolution (LR) videos in practical applications. Recent studies have explored diffusion models (DMs) for VSR due to their ability to generate realistic details. However, existing methods overlook spatiotemporal object-scale variations and dynamic control demands during denoising. This leads to visual distortion and quality degradation, severely limiting its practical applications. To address these limitations, we propose DM-VSR, a novel DM-based framework that incorporates depth-aware guidance and adaptive modulation for precise content reconstruction. Specifically, a Depth-aware Multimodal Fusion (DMF) module integrates depth maps, LR inputs, and flow-warped frames to provide unified depth-aware guidance. A Timestep Adaptive Modulation (TAM) module dynamically adjusts the control feature injection according to demand at each denoising step. Additionally, a Dynamic Consistency Loss (DCL) is introduced to align training objectives with the evolving semantic focus. Extensive experiments on the REDS4 and Vid4 benchmarks demonstrate that DM-VSR achieves competitive performance, surpassing state-of-the-art methods in both perceptual quality and temporal consistency. Moreover, DM-VSR generates more visually realistic results, emphasizing its effectiveness in real-world applications. The code will be released at https://github.com/aigcvsr/DM-VSR

title: Order-Preserving Kernel Contrastive Learning With Applications to Cross-Domain RUL Prediction
authors: Yifan Zhu, Fode Zhang, Wenyu Chen, Zhe Cheng, Lijuan Shen
abstract: Cross-domain remaining useful life prediction is a critical task for industrial applications, and existing domain adaptation (DA) techniques typically focus on mitigating domain shift by learning domain-invariant features. These methods help transfer knowledge from a labeled source domain to an unlabeled target domain, thus improving prediction accuracy and robustness. However, the alignment strategies used are often coarse-grained, which can lead to the disruption of inherent temporal dependencies in degradation data. In this article, we introduce the novel order-preserving kernel contrastive (OPKC) learning, which leverages the concept that samples with smaller label differences should exhibit higher kernel similarities in the reproducing Kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), irrespective of their domain origin. This kernel-enhanced, regression-aware contrastive learning technique enables fine-grained instance-level pairwise alignment between the source and target domains, ensuring that label difference information is preserved while maintaining the temporal order information inherent in the data. In addition, OPKC can be seamlessly integrated with adversarial DA methods to further enhance both prediction performance and training stability. Extensive experiments on two widely used industrial benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art transfer learning and contrastive learning methods, achieving relative improvement of 16.9% on the PHM 2012 dataset and 13.2% on the C-MAPSS dataset.

title: Thermal Stability Optimization for Full-Color Micro-LEDs With QDs and SU-8 Patterns
authors: Ting Zhi, Yang Zhang, Yong Li, Dejiang Zhao, Jianjun Bai, Li Liu, Cheng Qu, Jin Wang, Junjun Xue, Feifan Xu, Bin Sun, Tao Tao, Bin Liu
abstract: Quantum dots (QDs) serve as high-performance nanoscale color conversion materials, offering remarkable advantages for full-color micro-light-emitting diode (Micro-LED) displays. However, two critical challenges hinder practical applications: the integration of high-resolution patterned QDs with Micro-LED and the preservation of thermal stability under operational conditions. By the sidewall repair process, the Micro-LED devices can maintain approximately 75% of their performance when the temperature increased from 20<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C to 100<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C. Additionally, a systematic investigation into the effect of SU-8 on the luminescent properties demonstrated that integrating QDs with SU-8 offers a promising approach to achieve efficient color conversion without altering electrical performance. These advantages in temperature stability and overall performance also provide critical insights for developing full-color Micro-LED displays.

title: Unified Accelerated Life Testing for One-Shot Devices With Weibull Lifetime Distributions
authors: Hung-Ping Tung, Man Ho Ling
abstract: In traditional testing paradigms, step-stress accelerated life testing (SSALT) employs a single test group subjected to a single stress-change pattern, while constant-stress accelerated life testing (CSALT) utilizes multiple test groups exposed to uniform stress levels without variation. This article introduces a novel testing methodology, termed unified accelerated life testing (UALT), which integrates the principles of CSALT and SSALT. The UALT framework incorporates multiple test groups, each subjected to distinct stress-change patterns. By applying multiple stress-change patterns to test items, the UALT framework enhances data collection efficiency and provides a more accurate reliability estimation. The study conducts a detailed comparative analysis of these three optimal designs. Simulation results demonstrate that UALT with step-down-stress patterns achieves superior efficiency in data collection, as evidenced by smaller bias and standard deviation of reliability estimates. This innovative approach offers a nuanced understanding of how diverse stress-change patterns influence product reliability assessment. To illustrate its practical applicability, this article presents a real-world case study involving grease-based magnetorheological fluids, showcasing the effectiveness of optimal UALT design in reliability testing.

title: A Compact Ku-Band Multibeam Relativistic Klystron Amplifier Packaged With Permanent Magnets
authors: Zhenbang Liu, Lurong Lei, Chao Wang, Xuanming Zhang, Ke He, Dongwenlong Wu, Hua Huang, Shifeng Li
abstract: A compact Ku-band multibeam relativistic klystron amplifier (MBRKA) packaged with permanent magnets is proposed for the sake of producing repetitive high-power microwave (HPM) with good phase stability. A three-gap output cavity is designed. HPM is output from the internal channel, and the electron beams are bombarded to the external water-cooled collector. Then, the radial size of the output cavity is reduced, thereby reducing the volume and weight of the permanent magnet. At the same time, the output structure can reduce the intensity of the gap electric field to avoid RF breakdown, and on the other hand, the outer collector structure increases the cross section of the electron beams bombardment, reduces the generation of plasma, and improves the stability of the device’s repetition frequency operation. Besides, the improved diode structure with an inner anode is designed to realize the stable transmission of intense relativistic multiple electron beams (IRMEBs). The typical experimental results show that the Ku-band HPM with a power of 570 MW is generated, corresponding to an efficiency of 36% and a gain of 48 dB, when the guiding magnetic field is about 0.45 T produced by the permanent magnets. The result of continuous operation for 200 s at a repetition rate of 30 Hz indicates that the MBRKA has the capability of operating at a high repetition rate with good phase stability.

title: STV2YOLO: An improved method for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle time sensitive target detection in YOLOv5 based on SwinTransforerV2
authors: Bin Wang, JiaJun Luo, Yali Lv, Wen Zhang, Heng Yang, Heng Zhang, Kai Guo
abstract: Addressing the challenges of large-scale, diverse, and densely distributed targets, as well as the limited resources of edge computing devices in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) aerial imagery, this paper proposes an enhanced STV2YOLO target detection framework. First, a dynamic multi-scale feature pyramid is constructed by integrating the cross-window attention mechanism from Swin Transformer V2, along with a hierarchical window partitioning strategy to improve the feature representation of small targets. Second, a lightweight backbone network is developed using depthwise separable convolution, the C3-Inception module to enable parallel and efficient extraction of multi-scale features. Finally, a dynamic weighted WIoU loss function is introduced to optimize the bounding box localization accuracy for small targets. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves 60.5% in detection accuracy (mAP@0.5), which is 9.2 percentage points higher than the baseline YOLOv5 model and significantly outperforms mainstream models such as TPH-YOLOv5 and YOLOv5. Additionally, the framework achieves an inference speed of 32.5 FPS, balancing detection accuracy with real-time performance requirements. The code for this work has been open-sourced at https://github.com/Crazy-Create/STV2YOLO.git.

title: ASIC Flow of AXI Interface for ADPLL Module using SCL180nm
authors: M.L.N Charyulu, R. Mounika, Mohd Ziauddin Jahangir, Vivek Singh Kushwah
abstract: In today's technologically advanced world, microelectronics plays a crucial role in nearly every aspect of daily life. As a result, the demand for microelectronic components has significantly increased. This surge in demand can lead to longer production times and a higher likelihood of failures in final products. Therefore, it is essential to adopt methods that enhance both the efficiency and effectiveness of hardware design and verification processes. The Advanced Microcontroller Bus Architecture (AMBA) is an open standard for on-chip communication interfaces. It defines a set of rules that enable structured and efficient communication within a System on Chip (SoC). One of the prominent protocols within the AMBA family is the Advanced extensible Interface (AXI). AXI is designed to facilitate high-speed data transfers between IP cores using a master-slave configuration. Known for supporting high-frequency and high-performance system architectures, AXI is well-suited for designs that require low latency and high bandwidth. Additionally, AXI maintains compatibility with other AMBA protocols such as APB (Advanced Peripheral Bus) and AHB (Advanced High-performance Bus). A key feature of the AXI protocol is its separation of address, data, and control phases, which contributes to its flexibility and efficiency.

title: LSTM-Based Modeling of Temperature Drift and Repeatability in TMR Sensors
authors: He Wang, Xu Yin, Weixun Zhang, Zhong Liu, Zhenliang Ye, Zhengkai Li, Junyi Lin, Liang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper presents an LSTM-based modeling approach to address temperature drift and repeatability issues in Tunnel Magnetoresistance (TMR) sensors, which are critical in high-precision magnetic field measurement applications. A comprehensive dataset is constructed, covering both temperature drift tests and repeatability tests under varying environmental conditions. Separate LSTM models are trained on each subset to perform time series forecasting of the sensor’s output voltage. For the repeatability dataset, repeated training is conducted, and prediction error distributions are analyzed to assess model consistency. Furthermore, baseline models are used to demonstrate the LSTM model’s superior accuracy and stability in learning temporal dependencies. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing TMR sensor output reliability and its potential application in real-time temperature compensation and self-calibration systems.

title: Influence of the Mover Mass on Stepping Characteristics of Stick-Slip Piezoelectric Actuators
authors: Zhaochen Ding, Xiaoqin Zhou, Ke Wang, Zhi Xu, Jingshi Dong, Yuqing Fan, Huadong Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Stick-slip piezoelectric actuators have attracted significant attention for applications requiring excellent comprehensive performance and simple structure. Among various performance-limiting factors, backward motion during stepping poses a major challenge, reducing positioning accuracy and speed. Although factors such as driving signal and initial preload have been extensively studied, the influence of the mover mass on stepping characteristics remains underexplored. To investigate the effect of mover mass on output performance, a typical stick-slip actuator was designed and its feasibility is verified through working principle analysis and finite element simulation. Experimental results reveal that mover mass interacts with preload, driving voltage, and frequency to jointly affect output performance. A lighter mover tends to exhibit greater backward displacement due to reduced inertia, whereas increasing the mover mass effectively enhances the smoothness of the displacement curve and improves both motion linearity and stepping stability under varying input conditions. However, excessive mover mass leads to larger actuator size, slower dynamic response, and reduced energy efficiency. By selecting appropriate design parameters, an optimal balance between mass and performance can be achieved. These findings provide theoretical and experimental guidance for improving the structure and performance of stick-slip actuators in high-precision applications.

title: Driving Behaviour based Energy Consumption Estimation for Electric Vehicles using Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Anyuti Tiwary, Sukumar Mishra, Yashasvi Bansal
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Electric Vehicles (EVs) are gaining popularity due to reduced fuel consumption and emissions, yet challenges like limited battery range and charging infrastructure hinder wider adoption. Driving behaviors, such as speed variations, acceleration, and distance, significantly impact energy consumption. This research focuses on precise energy consumption estimation for routes like Ring, Campus, Urban-city, and Market, using velocity, acceleration, and distance as inputs. A convolutional neural network (CNN) is employed for efficient prediction, leveraging real-world data from Blu Smart Cab Mobility services in Delhi-NCR. The approach demonstrates high accuracy and generalization capabilities.

title: Sum-Rate Optimization in IRS-Assisted Multi-User OFDMA with PS-scheme enabled SWIPT
authors: Mahendra Tyagi, Sumit Gautam
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The sixth generation (6 G) wireless communication technology aims to address the growing demand for secure, low-latency wireless communication. The Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces (IRS) seem to be a promising solution to tackle the above-mentioned concerns. In this paper, we examine the allocation of resources and a single-IRS-assisted multi-user orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA) based network where destination nodes/users are capable of realizing Simultaneous Wireless Information and Power Transfer (SWIPT) by employing a Power Splitting (PS) technique. Our goal is to optimize the power splitting ratio, subcarrier, and power assignment to the destination nodes in order to maximize the sum-rate of the entire system while adhering to the constraints of total transmit power and harvested energy. The aforementioned issue is resolved by employing a divide-and-conquer methodology in an alternating (iterative) optimization algorithm (AO). It is evident that more IRS elements and sub-carriers are required to achieve a higher sum data rate, as indicated by our findings.

title: A Planar Magnetics based V2V Connector
authors: Vrundesh Shirish Pawde, Suman Saurav, Ritesh Kumar Keshri
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper introduces an innovative vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) charging connector based on planar magnetics, designed to facilitate efficient energy transfer between electric vehicles. The system leverages planar magnetic components and seamlessly integrates with the onboard charger power electronics while incorporating an embedded communication channel for effective power management. Using dual active bridge (DAB) phase-shift control, the charging process is precisely regulated, ensuring stable and controlled power flow. The key advancement of this approach lies in its compact architecture, reduced component count, and integration of both power transfer and communication within a single system. Unlike conventional V2V charging methods that require additional converters, this design enhances efficiency and reliability. Simulations were conducted to evaluate the performance of the system, gaining favorable results, while experimental validation further demonstrated its effectiveness by successfully delivering a 3.3 kW charge to the battery of the receiving vehicle.

title: Integrating Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning for Enhanced Market Forecasting Using Social Media Insights
authors: Mili Jaiswal, S. Nagakishore Bhavanam, Vasujadevi Midalasa
abstract: The rapid growth of social networking platforms has revolutionized the generation, consumption, and analysis of market attitudes. This study introduces a sophisticated methodology for forecasting markets that utilizes Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning (ML) to derive practical insights from extensive unorganized social networking data. In contrast to conventional forecasting methods that mostly depend on past market patterns and quantitative data, our suggested methodology integrates real-time emotions and opinion evaluation from structures such as Twitter, Reddit, and finance forums. The structure utilizes advanced NLP approaches, such as transformer-based modelling of languages (e.g., BERT, RoBERTa) and specialized sentimental analysis, to derive contextual and emotional attributes from generated by users material. These characteristics are then included into a hybrid ML pipeline that amalgamates ensemble models, including Random Forest (RF) and Gradient Boosting(GB), with algorithms for deep learning such as LSTM and focus systems. The integration improves the system's capacity to identify subtle mood changes and market-relevant trends. The system employs selecting features, noise filtration, and time-aligned normalizing of data approaches to guarantee strong predicting efficiency. Comprehensive preparation processes manage slang normalizing, hashtag interpretation, and bot identification, guaranteeing that only superior data impacts predictions. This research establishes the basis for a scalable and versatile forecasts system that surpasses traditional models, facilitating more precise, prompt, and data-informed decision-making in turbulent markets influenced by public emotion. The suggested technique attained an overall accuracy of 94.4%, exhibiting enhanced prediction performance relative to current models.

title: Cyber-Physical-Digital Twin Application for Bus Fault Protection
authors: Pasela Ramtej, K Shanti Swarup
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel Cyber-Physical Digital Twin (CPDT) framework integrating low-cost Arduino hardware with MATLAB/Simulink for real-time fault detection, protection, and visualization in power systems. It uses a MATLAB/Simulink-based IEEE 3-bus model connected to Arduino via bidirectional USB communication for detecting and isolating various fault types, including single line-to-ground (SLG), line-to-line (LL), double line-to-ground (LLG), three-phase (LLL), and three-phase-to-ground (LLLG) faults, using instantaneous overcurrent relays. A distinctive feature of this framework is its dual-mode monitoring system, which combines a real-time Simulink dashboard with Arduino-controlled LED indicators, enhancing operator situational awareness. Experimental results demonstrate a closed-loop synchronization latency of 20.55 to 24.4 milliseconds (ms), validating the framework’s effectiveness for real-time applications. Unlike existing Digital Twin implementations, which are often simulation-centric, this CPDT laboratory prototype is tightly coupled with hardware and is designed to be cost-effective, modular, and scalable. Future research will focus on incorporating standardized communication protocols and advanced techniques for predictive analytics, with the aim of developing a resilient and self-adaptive power system infrastructure.

authors: Raushan Kumar, Sunil Kumar, Alok Priyadarshi, Anjali Rai, Shivam Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: In order to maximize hole capture rates and reduce minority carrier loss in photovoltaic (PV) cells, the selection of hole transport layer (HTL) materials plays a crucial role in CZTS/BaSi<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> PV cells. Historically, CZTS cells have utilized HTLs designed to minimize minority carrier loss. To further improve the performance of CZTS-based PV cells, extensive research is focusing on HTL materials with wide energy bandgaps. This paper presents a novel wide bandgap BaSi2 as an HTL nanomaterial for high-efficiency PV cells. The study covers a comprehensive analysis of energy band alignment, optimization of layer thickness and doping density, as well as the design of the proposed PV cell structure. The CZTS/BaSi<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> PV cell shows exceptional performance, with VOC = 1231 mV, JSC = 26.23, FF = 80.77%, efficiency = 26.09%, and EQE = 88%.

title: Audio-Video Dual-Modality Robust Watermarking
authors: Guangyi Pan, Mengxin Song, Ying Huang, Jie Liu, Guixuan Zhang, Shuwu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Video has become a core medium for information dissemination and entertainment, but the surging demand has led to frequent infringement, posing severe challenges to copyright protection. Existing video watermarking methods face limitations such as quality degradation, neglect of encoding/decoding impacts, and lack of audio copyright protection. To address these, we propose an FFmpeg-based audio-visual dual watermarking framework deeply integrated into the video encoding/decoding pipeline. Our framework employs the joint selection method of interval k frames and key frames based on DINOv2 for image embedding, which leverages DINOv2's self-supervised features to jointly optimize frame selection, while adopting averageamplitude threshold screening for audio segments to ensure watermark imperceptibility. In addition, we propose a twostage voting verification that optimizes extraction accuracy via confidence voting. Our approach achieves dual-watermark crossvalidation, significantly enhancing robustness against complex attacks. Experimental results demonstrate that the method achieves a 0 Bit Error Rate (BER) under various attack scenarios, providing an innovative solution for multimodal digital copyright protection with notable theoretical and practical value.

title: An Aviation Manned-Unmanned Teaming Simulation in Urban Environments to Compare Autonomous Flight Formations
authors: Uicheon Lee, Taehwan Kim, Seonah Lee
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In response to the growing importance of urban drone operations and the strategic potential of aviation mannedunmanned teaming (MUM-T), we propose a high-fidelity simulation platform for MUM-T operations in urban environments. The platform integrates Unreal Engine 5, Cesium for geospatial data, Colosseum (an AirSim fork), and PX4 SITL to provide realistic flight dynamics, sensor modeling, and immersive cityscapes. It supports the testing of MUM-T strategies in dense, obstacle-rich urban settings with high physical and visual fidelity. To demonstrate its capabilities, we simulated eight threequadrotor formation patterns: Column, Line Abreast, Echelon, Vshape, Inverted-V, Triangle, Circular, and Arrow. Each formation consisted of one human-operated leader and two autonomous followers. The results revealed trade-offs between coverage, collision risk, and formation stability. Wider formations improved coverage but caused more collisions, while compact ones enhanced safety with reduced coverage. These findings highlight the platform's utility for evaluating urban MUM-T strategies under realistic conditions.

title: DO-377B and its Application in Automated Air Taxi Scenario
authors: Peng Ji, Craig Scheffler
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This article discusses the regulatory recognition, limitations and possible improvements of the current revision B of DO-377, for its application in Automated Air Taxi scenario. It aims at fostering a consistent approach for C2 link system certification.

title: A Landscape of Commercial On-Board Computers and Payload Processing Computers for CubeSats: Fault Tolerance and Implementation Challenges
authors: Mauren W. D'Avila, Vinicius H. Schreiner, Victor O. Costa, Denis S. Loubach, Lidia S. Shibuya, Luis Loures, Fernanda L. Kastensmidt
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Small satellites, particularly CubeSats, rely increasingly on Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) components to meet tight cost, volume, and schedule constraints. However, these systems must face the challenges of the space environment, especially radiation-induced faults. This paper presents a survey and analysis of over 130 commercial On-Board Computers (OBCs) and Payload Processing Computers (PPCs) intended for CubeSat applications, focusing on their fault tolerance embedded techniques. Using selection criteria based on CubeSat constraints such as size, power, and available documentation, we identified 34 viable computing platforms, that meet the requirements of the projects under development at the ITA Space Center (CEI). These were evaluated in terms of fault tolerance strategies, including redundancy, error correction, and hardening techniques. Our findings highlight common fault tolerance techniques implemented, key trade-offs, and information access limitations due to export restrictions, and supplier responsiveness. The paper aims to guide future developments in reliable small satellite computing.

title: Optimal Energy Management for Renewable Energy-based EVCS using Fuzzy Inference System
authors: P Hemalatha, Akula Vennela, S Kayalvizhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents an energy management system (EMS) for an electric vehicle charging station (EVCS) that integrates solar and wind energy with battery storage. The system considers technical and economic factors to maximize renewable energy usage and minimize grid dependency. Wind energy complements solar generation, while the battery stores excess power for use during low renewable generation periods. A fuzzy inference system is established to effectively manage renewable energy generation, battery operation, EV charging demand, and charging schedules. This has been implemented on the MATLAB SIMULINK platform. The EMS aims to reduce real-time charging costs and ensure efficient energy utilization. By balancing supply and demand, the system enhances grid stability and promotes sustainable EV charging. Simulation results demonstrate the feasibility of optimizing charging costs and renewable energy usage in dynamic conditions.

title: Enhancement of X-Rays via Hybrid Denoising and Adaptive Contrast
authors: Richa Gupta, Mohamed Siddiq
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Medical imaging is required for proper diagnosis and treatment planning, but image quality is usually compromised by noise, low contrast, and artifacts hiding clinically significant information. The following article proposes a new method of image enhancement incorporating anisotropic diffusion filtering for edge-preserving smoothing, non-local means (NLM) denoising for effective removal of noise, and Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE) for local contrast enhancement. The suggested hybrid method solves certain key problems of medical imaging with enhanced visibility at the same time with fine anatomical details intact. Experimental evidence supports that our algorithm greatly enhances image quality, especially in X-rays, by better noise elimination and detail retention than current methods. The system’s modularity ensures its ease of integration into clinical use, making it a useful tool for radiologists and researchers for more accurate diagnostic interpretation. Our findings prove the potential of the method to improve examination of medical images in radiology and computer-aided diagnosis.

title: Integrated UWB and LIDAR Assisted Localization and Navigation System for Automated Platooning
authors: Tushar Dupga, Ashutosh Deshwal, Sudiksha Navik, Amitangshu Pal
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Accurate localization and robust navigation are crucial for autonomous robots or vehicles in GPS-denied environments, where traditional methods face signal obstructions and infrastructure limitations. This paper presents an integrated UltraWideband (UWB) based Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) framework, implemented on a Robot Operating System (ROS) based Jetbot platform. The system utilizes UWB Time of Flight (ToF) and Angle of Arrival (AoA) for precise localization, along with LiDAR data for real-time mapping and obstacle avoidance. By fusing UWB and LiDAR data, the system tracks a moving target, along with accurate path planning. Experimental results show that the solution achieves a median tracking and navigation error of 18 cm, with 80 % of error remains below 20 cm, demonstrating its reliability. This study highlights the feasibility of UWB-based localization for autonomous platooning, offering a scalable and adaptable solution for real-time navigation in dynamic and infrastructure-limited environments.

title: Analysis of Health Indicators for Lithium-Ion Battery
authors: Tushar Shikhola, Bijaya Ketan Panigrahi, Saurabh Saxena
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Identification and extraction of health indicators/features from lithium-ion battery sensor data is critical for their safety and health management in electric vehicles (EVs). This article presents a methodology for feature extraction using the NASA Prognostics Centre of Excellence (PCoE) battery dataset. Key Health Indicators, including Equal Voltage Charge Interval Time (EVCIT), Constant Current Charge Interval Time (CCCIT), Equal Voltage Discharge Interval Time (EVDIT), and Constant Current Discharge Interval Time (CCDIT), which are obtained from the voltage and current profiles of battery derived during its charging and discharging process. The relationships between these features and battery health (capacity degradation) are analyzed using Pearson's correlation coefficient to determine their effectiveness in capturing Lithium-Ion battery (LIB) degradation mechanism. The value of correlation between various Health Indicators (HIs) and State of Health (SOH) lies between 0.97 to 0.99 with Equal Voltage Discharge Interval Time exhibiting strongest Pearson correlation with SOH.

title: Symmetry Detection in Thermal Eye Images: A Study Using Instant Segmentation for Eye Health Insights
authors: J Persiya, A Sasithradevi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Thermal imaging is a non-invasive method for detecting health anomalies through ocular temperature analysis. This study examines eye segmentation in thermal facial images using deep learning-based instance segmentation, with a focus on the YOLO family. A novel thermal image dataset of 327 healthy participants, captured with a FLIR-E75 camera, is introduced. Various segmentation models are evaluated using precision, recall, and mAP50-95. GradCAM, GradCAM++, and ScoreCAM are used to analyze model behavior and segmentation results. YOLOv8 achieved the highest mAP50-95 of 0.756, with sharper activations, confirming its superior thermal eye segmentation performance. The extracted eye temperatures are analyzed for symmetry, demonstrating the approach’s potential for non-invasive thermal diagnostics in ophthalmology and disease detection.

title: Machine Learning-Based Classification of Oils Using Dielectric Properties and Microwave Resonant Sensing
authors: Amit Baran Dey, Wasim Arif, Rakhesh Singh Kshetrimayum
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper proposes a machine learning-based methodology for the classification of various oil samples based on their dielectric properties, utilizing a microwave resonant sensor. The dielectric behavior of oils, governed by their molecular composition, induces distinct shifts in the sensor’s resonant frequency and amplitude response. These variations are systematically captured and processed to extract salient features, which serve as inputs for multiple machine learning classifiers. The microwave resonant sensor operates in a non-destructive, lowpower manner, making it particularly well-suited for real-time industrial applications. A comprehensive dataset is developed by varying the permittivity of oil samples and acquiring the corresponding sensor responses. Several classifiers are trained and evaluated using the extracted resonant features to assess their capability in distinguishing between oil types. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves a high classification accuracy of $99.41 \%$ with the random forest classifier, highlighting its strong potential for automated oil identification. The system’s compact form factor, efficiency, and high performance underscore its viability for fast and reliable oil characterization in industrial environments.

title: Efficient Classification of Fruits and Vegetables in Extensive Agricultural Fields Using Transform Techniques and KNN
authors: Aadarsh S Nair, Panyam Narahari Sastry, Vivek Singh Kushwah
abstract: The main aim of detecting objects is to detect all instances of objects in an image that belong to a known class of objects, such as people, cars, or faces, the shape of fruits and vegetables, and so on. The goal of this research work is to automatically detect and classify images of fruits and vegetables, captured by drone which is flown over a large agricultural field. This data is used for various agricultural applications such as spraying pesticides, sprinkling water and estimating the crop yield. This work begins with collecting images (or video) and selecting the distinguishable features in each image for classification using K-NN. The 2D DCT features for fruits and vegetables gave a recognition accuracy of 90%. The 2D FFT features for fruits and vegetables gave a recognition accuracy of 91.6%. The hybrid model approach in which recognition accuracy obtained for 2D DCT is 90% was improved to 95%, while the samples that 2D DCT did not recognize were given as input in the second stage where 2D FFT features were used to improve the recognition accuracy.

title: Trends and Techniques in Mental Fatigue Detection Using Keystroke and Mouse Dynamics in Human-Computer Interaction
authors: Sahana K, Ananda Babu J
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Mental fatigue is a critical challenge in humancomputer interaction, reducing cognitive performance, productivity, and decision-making ability. Traditional methods for fatigue detection often rely on intrusive physiological sensors, which are unsuitable for real-time, large-scale deployment. This study reviews recent trends and techniques that utilize keystroke dynamics and mouse movement patterns as non-intrusive behavioral indicators of fatigue. The proposed framework integrates data acquisition, feature extraction, normalization, and classification using machine learning models such as Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and Logistic Regression. Comparative analysis of existing approaches shows that multimodal behavioral features can achieve accuracies between 85% and 93% in distinguishing fatigue states, with keystroke-only models achieving up to 88%. Our results highlight the trade-off between lightweight models that are suitable for real-time applications and more complex deep learning models that achieve higher accuracy but require significant computational resources. The study contributes by consolidating recent advances, highlighting dataset limitations, and identifying research gaps that guide future work toward robust, scalable fatigue detection systems.

title: Solar Power Prediction using LSTM and XGBoost
authors: Asha Ali, Jerin James, Jasmin E. A., Suhara E. M.
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Renewable energy sources, particularly solar power, help in smooth transition to sustainable energy systems. However, solar power generation is inherently uncertain and requires accurate forecasting for efficient and reliable smart grid management. This study investigates the use of machine learning and deep learning techniques to forecast the amount of solar power generated in a specific area. The Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) method and Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) model is modeled to predict the solar power generated. LSTM is well suited to capture temporal relationships in time series data, and XGBoost works well for effectively managing structured data. The performance of the models are compared using performance evaluation metrics like Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Coefficient of Determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>). The data set for this study was obtained from the Pecan Street Dataport, which provides real-world information on the performance and applicability of the model.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of Single Material and Triple Material Cylindrical Gate All Around Gate Stack Silicon Nanowire FET at 7 nm Technology node
authors: Shankhamitra Sunani, Satya Sopan Mahato, Raghunandan Swain
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In this work, we examine single material (SM) and triple material (TM) cylindrical gate all around (CGAA) silicon nanowire field effect transistor (Si-NWFET), and simulation findings are presented using Cogenda 3D TCAD tool. The analysis encompasses an evaluation of essential electrical characteristics such as drain-induced barrier lowering (DIBL), subthreshold swing (SS), on current ($I_{\text {ON }}$), off current ($I_{\text {OFF }}$), on-off current ratio $\left(\frac{I_{O N}}{I_{O F F}}\right)$, transconductance $\left(g_{m}\right)$, transconductance generation factor (TGF), output conductance $\left(g_{d}\right)$, and early voltage ($V_{E A}$), which are assessed for both the SM and TM CGAA NWFET. The device shows a DIBL of $88 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{V}$ and $44 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{V}$, with SS of $120 \mathrm{mV} /$ dec and $100 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{dec}$, while $\boldsymbol{I}_{\boldsymbol{O} \boldsymbol{N}} / \boldsymbol{I}_{\boldsymbol{O F F}}$ Values of $10^{\mathbf{5}}$ and $10^{\mathbf{6}}$ are obtained for SM CGAA NWFET and TM CGAA NWFET, respectively. Further, the device demonstrates RF performance metrics with $g_{m}$ of $56.67 \mu \mathrm{~S}$ and $38.33 \mu \mathrm{~S}$ at $\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{GS}}=0.9 \mathrm{~V}$ and 1 V, TGF of $18.85 \mathrm{~V}^{-1}$ and $18.30 \mathrm{~V}^{-1}$ for SM and TM CGAA NWFET. Additionally, a $37 \%$ reduction of $g_{d}$ and a $41 \%$ enhancement in $V_{E A}$ are noted in TM CGAA NWFET in comparison to SM CGAA NWFET. Therefore, the well-designed TM CGAA NWFET emerges as a promising option for low power consumption and improved linearity in future technologies.

title: Comparative Analysis of Control Strategies for Enhancing the Performance of DC-DC Luo Converters
authors: Sanat Subhro Jena, Chandan Kumar Behera, Ashutosh Biswal, Riju Nandi, Arnab Ghosh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In this study, we take a look at the DC-DC Luo Converter and compare three distinct control strategies. Various control methods are used to the Luo converter’s output voltage, including PID, 2-DOF PID, and 3-DOF PID. The outcomes prove that control strategies can enhance the operation of the converters described earlier. A number of control strategies are employed to achieve the converter’s performance, which is affected by variations in the supply voltage and the load. With its fast reaction, low overshoot, and exceptional steady-state performance, 3-DOF PID control stands out among the algorithms that were tested.

title: An Optimized Method for Route Scheduling of Small Commercial Electric Vehicles
authors: Maneesh Yadav, Satyaranjan Jena, Chinmoy Kumar Panigrahi, Amiya Kumar Naik
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Small commercial electric vehicles (SCVs) used for urban logistics create multiple operational hurdles because of their increasing adoption for commercial purpose. The key problem occurs in designing efficient route schedules. Efficient coordination of charging operations remains a challenging task in this system. Electric vehicles have restricted storage capacity, which causes these issues to develop. The restricted charging infrastructure availability creates additional complications in the process. The use of small commercial electric vehicles (SCVs) in last-mile logistics has recently increased dramatically. However, this growth has led to complicated issues with scheduling the best routes between energy consumption, charging limitations, and delivery time constraints. A system combines Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) with the Nearest Neighbor Algorithm (NNA) to function. The method finds optimum assignments for SCVs between charging stops and routes. Such optimization reduces both operational and energy- related costs. This technique provides enhanced capabilities for managing vehicle weight as well as performing delivery restriction assessment. The optimized route distances, together with improved charging station efficiency and minimized vehicle downtime, are all achieved better through the MILP-based method compared to heuristic methods. MATLAB serves as the implementation platform of the proposed framework while data from real-world logistics is used for validation through tests with different fleet sizes for scalability assessment.

title: Speed and Current Sensor Fault-Tolerant Control of DTC-SVM Based Induction Motor Drive
authors: Murli Manohar, Abhisek Pal, Mukesh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This article investigates a fault-tolerant control (FTC) technique for space-vector modulation based direct torque control (DTC-SVM) of induction motor (IM) drives, addressing speed and current sensor faults. The three essential steps for achieving fault tolerance in a drive system are: detecting a faulty sensor, localizing the fault, and reconfiguring the control scheme using appropriate signal estimation techniques. A third-difference operator applied to the motor line current effectively detect the sensor fault while a flux-linkage observer and model reference adaptive system (MRAS)-based estimation methods reconstruct the current and speed signals, respectively after the fault. Moreover, a decision-making logic unit pinpoints the faulty sensor and automatically switches over to its corresponding estimated current or speed signal, guaranteeing uninterrupted and dependable drive system performance. The proposed FTC scheme is simple, flexible, and compatible with any IM speed control technique. Simulation and extensive testing in MATLAB/Simulink validate its effectiveness in ensuring drive system resilience against current and speed sensor failures.

title: Damping Sinusoidal Reaching Law based Integral Terminal Sliding Mode Control for A Small Wind Turbine with Blade Geometry Effect
authors: Vijay Prakash, Bikash Kumar Sarkar, Paladugu Venkaiah, Amitava Chatterjee
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The recent increased demand for power with improved technological and social status of human beings has led to the development of renewable power generation systems. The wind power system is one of the fastest-growing sectors among renewable power generation systems. In the last few decades, researchers have focused on the development of large wind turbines and studied their operation and control. However small wind turbines are effective where less wind speed potential is available like in northeast India. Therefore, improving the efficiency of the small wind turbines is one of the major tasks to enhance power generation in low-intensity wind conditions. In the present study effect of the chord solidity on the pitch control of a small wind turbine is studied. A novel integral terminal sliding mode controller is designed here using damping sinusoidal-based reaching law (termed as DSRL-ITSMC) for wind turbine pitch control with variations in blade shapes. Comprehensive performance evaluations have been carried out over a wide range of speed variations, with sinusoidal and random variations in wind speed. The performance of the proposed DSRL-ITSMC controller is tested using different turbine blades and compared using established performance indices. Finally, the proposed controller performance is compared vis-à-vis a fractional order proportional-integral-derivative controller (FO-PID) controller to demonstrate the utility of our proposal.

title: Research on Contact AFM Surface Topography Measurement Based on Molecular Dynamics Simulation
authors: Xinhao Tian, Yanling Tian, Guangwei Zhu, Fujun Wang, Dawei Zhang, Chunfeng Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Atomic force microscopy, as a high-resolution surface analysis tool, has unique advantages in fields such as nanotechnology, materials science, and biology. It does not rely on conductive samples, has a wider range of applications, can work in liquid environments, and has a multifunctional measurement mode. In this paper, molecular dynamics (MD) simulation is performed to investigate the atomic-scale imaging of a typical single crystal material copper in contact atomic force microscopy measurement process. Because of the interaction between cantilever tip and sample, the bending process of cantilever is simulated by passive feedback adjustment of force, and the surface topography of sample is obtained. By establishing MD model of step-like sample, the effects of scanning speed, tip shape and scanning direction on scanning accuracy are simulated, and the potential mechanism of interaction between tip and sample is explained. The above work is helpful to explore the measurement mechanism of contact AFM at atomic scale, and it is helpful for people to realize high resolution imaging with worn AFM tip.

title: Effect of surface texture of solar cells on their radiative cooling performance
authors: Avinash Kumar, Pabitra Kumar Biswas, Amartya Chowdhury
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper mainly focuses on the impact of the surface texture on the emission of the solar cell. Two different textures of solar cells with varying layers of ARC materials have been compared in the 300-1200 nm wavelength range. Further, the emission has been compared in the range of 4000 to 25000 nm wavelength range. In addition to SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> in an antireflective-coated solar cell, the temperature of the solar cell was reduced by 5.6°C in the pyramidal surface solar cell. An inverted pyramidal surface solar cell is able to reduce the temperature by 5.8°C at 30°C ambient temperature. The temperature reduction depends on the solar cell's operating location and weather conditions.

title: Integration of Electric Vehicle Charging Stations and Renewable Energy Sources in Distribution Systems Using COA Approach
authors: Hima Bindu A, V. Naga Bhaskar Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources (RES) and electric vehicles (EVs) into modern power networks introduces a high degree of unpredictability, potentially leading to voltage fluctuations, increased power losses, and reduced power quality. To maintain reliable network operation, it is essential to account for the variable output of RES and the additional load imposed by EV charging. This study proposes an optimal configuration and sizing of EV charging stations and renewable energy sources within smart grids using the Crayfish Optimization Algorithm (COA). The primary objective of the proposed method is to minimize power losses, voltage deviations, supply-demand imbalances, charging costs, and EV battery expenses. The COA-based approach enables simultaneous optimization of both EV charging infrastructure and RES integration. Its performance is benchmarked against existing techniques, including the Backtracking Search Algorithm (BSA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). Comparative results demonstrate that the proposed COA method achieves lower voltage fluctuations and reduced power losses, highlighting its effectiveness in enhancing smart grid performance.

title: A Novel Eleven-Level Quintuple Boost Switched-Capacitor Inverter with Self-Balancing Capability
authors: Md. Mohi Uddin Mohin, Md Ashraful Islam, Md. Sabbir Alam, Shahariar Ahmed Himo, Mohammad Ibrahim, Hera Chandra Das, Md. Zahid Hasan, Ahmed Al Mansur, Anorgul I. Ashirova, Yuldoshev Jushkinbek Erkaboy Ugli
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The integration of low-voltage renewable energy sources into the grid demands inverter topologies with high voltage gain and efficiency, particularly in transformerless configurations. Switched-capacitor multilevel inverters (SCMLIs) have emerged as a promising solution due to their ability to provide high-quality AC output with reduced power losses. However, existing designs often face challenges related to capacitor voltage balancing, high component count, and excessive switch voltage stress. This paper introduces a novel 11-level switched-capacitor inverter topology utilizing a single DC source, 12 switches, 4 capacitors, and 4 diodes, achieving a fivefold voltage gain while ensuring self-balancing of capacitor voltages without the need for additional sensors or auxiliary circuits. The proposed inverter operates with the Optimum Nearest Level Modulation (ONLM) technique, minimizing switching losses and enhancing overall efficiency. Simulation results using MATLAB/Simulink demonstrate the inverter’s performance, with a Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) of 7.34% without filtering, which is significantly reduced to 0.32% with the application of an LCL filter. The inverter exhibits stable operation under dynamic load variations, confirming its adaptability for real-world applications. A comparative analysis against conventional multilevel inverters further underscores its superior efficiency, reduced component count, and improved voltage quality, making it a viable and cost-effective solution for renewable energy systems, microgrids, and high-power applications.

title: Pilot Vector Perturbation Precoding for Scalable and Efficient Transmission in Ultra-Dense Massive MIMO 6G Networks
authors: N. Yuvaraj, Kousik Nalliyanna Goundar Veerappan, R. Arshath Raja
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: As the network traffic continues to grow manifold, the density of wireless networks gets tightly packed and eventually becomes ultra-dense in massive MIMO systems. Providing coverage with increased Spectral Efficiency in wireless backhaul networks to multi-users is challenging because of its higher deployment cost or complexity. Further, to reduce the complexity, various non-linear precoders are designed but at the expense of high spatial interference and low spectral efficiency. Hence, an optimized solution using Vector Perturbation (VP) Precoding is considered essential as it improves spectral efficiency, but it incurs increased complexity on the uplinks due to non-optimal selection of perturbing signal, which is required to scale up the transmission signals. This research proposes Pilot VP (PVP) precoding techniques in massive MIMO, where VP selection are optimized under finite/infinite lattice space, and these inputs to the baseband precoder minimize the total number of computations required to select the Radio Frequency (RF) chains for enabling scalable transmission.

title: Novel Technique for Detecting Localization of Acid and Base Lewis and Bronsted Surface Sites Based on Atomic Force Microscopy
authors: Julia M. Spivak, Alena Yu. Gagarina, Dmitry A. Kozodaev, Vyacheslav A. Moshnikov
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: We propose a novel technique for distinguishing the localization of surface adsorption sites of different types (acid and basic Lewis and Bronsted sites) in interdependence with the micro- and nanofeatures of surface morphology. Preliminary sorption of indicator of a chosen type onto the material surface is being carried out (as the same as in the classical Tanabe method) with subsequent analysis by atomic force microscopy (AFM) - lateral force microscopy and force spectroscopy to study the frictional and adhesive properties of the AFM probe and sample surface. An example of testing is given using porous silicon with a known integral concentration of adsorption centers.

title: Multi-regional collaborative fault diagnosis model for power equipment based on federated learning
authors: Zili Huang, Yuchen Zhao, Tianyuan Xu, Ziyi Song, Shanglin She, Shuo Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In order to solve the problems of data privacy leakage and collaborative modeling difficulties in multi-regional power equipment fault diagnosis, this paper proposes a collaborative diagnosis model based on federated learning. By designing a distributed training framework, a one-dimensional convolutional neural network is used locally for feature extraction, and global aggregation is achieved by combining FedAvg and dynamic weighting mechanism, which ensures the local management and feature sharing of data in each region. Aalto Gear Fault Dataset is used as the test data set, and experimental verification is carried out from the aspects of diagnostic accuracy, communication overhead and system robustness. The results show that the constructed model can achieve efficient and accurate fault identification while ensuring privacy protection, and has good application prospects in multi-regional complex power system environments.

title: Implementation of Q-Learning Algorithm For HVAC Control
authors: M.Krishna Paramathma, Atluri Tanuja, Shaik Nagur Mastan Vali, Kalepalli Sai Keerthi, Kamatham Suji
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The increasing demand for energy-efficient building systems necessitates intelligent solutions for managing HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) operations. This paper presents a Q-learning-based control framework for HVAC systems that optimizes energy consumption while maintaining indoor thermal comfort. The system simulates a dynamic environment without the use of physical sensors, using variables such as indoor temperature, outdoor temperature, occupancy, and AC status to define the state space. A discrete action set enables the agent to either turn off the AC, increase, or decrease the temperature setpoint. The Q-learning agent interacts with the simulated environment to learn optimal control strategies by maximizing long-term rewards defined through a comfort-aware and costsensitive reward function. The reward mechanism incorporates real-time electricity pricing models, occupancy patterns, and temperature thresholds to penalize energy waste and incentivize efficient cooling. Simulation modes including manual, auto, and batch execution facilitate diverse training and testing scenarios. A Q-table with 4,320 entries supports reinforcement learning across all state-action combinations, and a web-based interface enables visualization and user interaction. Experimental results demonstrate significant reductions in energy usage and operational cost, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach. This system provides a scalable and adaptable solution for smart HVAC control in simulated or real-world implementations.

title: Track-Before-Detect with Stereo Microphone Arrays
authors: Jiazheng Wang, Mohammad Fard, Amirali Khodadadian Gostar, Reza Hoseinnezhad
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
