abstract: Situational awareness of autonomous vehicles in urban environments heavily relies on line-of-sight sensors such as cameras, lidar, and radar. However, these visual sensors may fail to detect targets when they are occluded. In contrast, audio signals have stronger penetration capabilities, enabling human to perceive the direction-of-arrival (DoA) of sound. This directional information can also be extracted using beamforming techniques applied to multi-channel microphone arrays. In this work, we utilize a stereo microphone array to track the 2D position of a single vehicle. Such a minimal array configuration is susceptible to ambient noise and vehicle sounds leading to high variance in position estimation. To address this issue, we propose a track-before-detect (TBD) based particle filter algorithm that incorporates stereo microphone measurements for 2D vehicle tracking. The proposed method is validated using a custom dataset that includes scenarios where vehicles pass at various distances from the microphone array. Using bird's-eye view camera footage as ground truth, experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves accurate and low-variance 2D sound source tracking.

title: Predefined Time Consensus Control for Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Praveen Kumar, Amit Anand, Dipayan Guha, Shubhi Purwar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper proposes a predefined-time consensus control (PTCC) strategy for leader-follower multi-agent systems (MASs) with second-order dynamics. A novel time-varying sliding mode surface is designed to ensure that all follower agents achieve consensus with the leader exactly within a user-specified time of 5 seconds, independent of initial conditions. By embedding a time-dependent function into the sliding surface design, the proposed approach guarantees strict convergence at the predefined time, enhancing predictability for real-time and safety-critical applications. A rigorous Lyapunov-based analysis is conducted to establish predefined-time stability and convergence of position and velocity errors. Moreover, the controller is robust against matched external disturbances. Simulation results with one leader and four followers confirm the effectiveness, robustness, predefined-time convergence performance of the proposed method compared to existing finite-time approaches.

title: Artificial Neural Network-Assisted Simulation Framework for Process Optimization in L-PBF Manufacturing of Inconel 718 Spur Gears
authors: Vikram Gupta, Rajiv Nandan Rai, Sanjay Kumar Chaturvedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive thermo-mechanical simulation and investigation of additive manufacturing using the Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF) process, focusing on the fabrication of Inconel 718 (IN718) spur gear. The primary objective is to analyze the effects of critical process parameters laser power, scan speed, and layer thickness on the temperature-dependent yield strength and stress-strain behaviour of the printed gear. A central composite design (CCD) approach was applied to efficiently structure the simulation experiments, and the results were validated against existing literature, demonstrating reliable accuracy. Analysis of variance results provide the variability from the process parameters to accurately predict the yield strength of the materiaArtificial Neural Network (ANN) models were employed to yield strength and the strain-hardening factor, providing a robust framework for optimizing these key material properties. Additionally, a neural network model was tested for its predictive efficiency, yielding highly accurate correlations between the process parameters and mechanical outputs.The significance of this research lies in its integration of simulation and experimental analysis to maximize the tensile strength and elastic modulus of L-PBF-printed IN718 spur gears. Experimental validation revealed a significant improvement in material strength, which was further verified through existing studies, confirming the reliability of the simulation models. The paper also focusses on the three key process parameter that is laser power, layer thickness and scan speed and their effects on the yield strength of the gear. This enhanced strength not only demonstrates the potential of process parameter optimization in improving mechanical performance but also leads to a reduction in production costs. The findings of this research contribute valuable insights into the additive manufacturing of high-performance components, providing a pathway to increased efficiency and reduced costs in the production of metal parts.

title: Gesture and Voice-Enabled Game Interface for Accessible Human-Computer Interaction
authors: Vasantha Kini T, Tanishk Raj, S Meenatchisundaram, Aneesha Acharya K
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: This paper presents a gesture- and voice-controlled, offline-capable, real-time gaming interface inspired by the Chrome Dino game. MediaPipe and OpenCV are integrated into the system for hand tracking, with Kalman filtering used to smooth data on finger angle for accurate gesture recognition. The Vosk engine enables offline voice control and supports commands like “jump” and “exit.” The game, a live camera feed, and real-time overlays displaying finger angles, gesture accuracy, and recognized voice commands are all embedded in a PyQt5-based graphical user interface, which allows switching between control modes. Performance evaluation shows voice recognition success at an average of 66.1% and good gesture accuracy at 85%. The application is packaged as a Windows-compatible standalone executable. Designed with accessibility in mind, this system demonstrates the potential of multimodal interaction for gaming, assistive applications, and user-centric interface design.

title: A Communication-Efficient Federated Learning Approach for Intrusion Detection in IoT
authors: Oumaima Ennasri, Manal Abbassi, Yann Ben Maissa, Rachid El Mokadem
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: With the rapid growth of the Internet of Things, Intrusion Detection Systems (IDSs) have become critical to protect sensitive data. Conventional approaches collect all data on a central server, which poses privacy and security issues. Federated Learning (FL) provides a decentralized alternative by enabling collaborative model training without sharing raw data. Despite this, standard FL methods such as FedAvg still suffer from high communication overhead due to the transmission of full model weights at each iteration, which is problematic in resourceconstrained IoT environments. To address this problem, we build upon our previously proposed communication-efficient federated learning algorithm, eXtreme Federated Learning (XFL), and extend it to IoT IDSs by incorporating attack classification capabilities within the edge nodes. This work extends the original XFL with an IoT-oriented adaptation, attack detection, and hardware testbed evaluation. At each round, XFL optimizes and sends a single neural network layer per IDS client using the block coordinate gradient descent algorithm, thus lowering communication costs, a key factor in IoT applications. We evaluate both XFL and FedAvg on a hardware testbed (10 Raspberry Pi devices) using a real-world traffic dataset (UNSW-NB15), showing that XFL achieves a 60 % reduction in communication overhead with a comparable detection accuracy. Our implementation is publicly available on GitHub.

title: Uncovering Resilient Behavior in the Aviation Safety Reporting System Using Large Language Models
authors: Bryan Matthews
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Resiliency is present in everyday life, both in system design and exhibited by the operators that function within these systems. This includes the National Airspace System (NAS) where pilots and controllers make positive decisions and take preventative or corrective actions every day even in unsafe situations. Pilot safety reports filed after an event are rich text narratives that detail the conditions around an event and can provide additional context leading up to, during, and describe how the situation was resolved. This yields useful insights into the resilient positive actions and corrective steps that may have transpired to prevent a safety incident from degrading further. Analyzing large archives of these reports can be impractical for subject matter experts to properly extract evidence of resilient behavior. However, Large Language Models have demonstrated the potential to extract useful insights from extensive bodies of text. This work proposes to utilize the Llama3.1 Instruct model to identify examples of resilient behavior within four categories on over 250,000 narratives from NASA's Aviation Safety Reporting System (ASRS). The analysis will reveal how similar and different resilient behaviors are present within various ASRS anomaly categories such as airborne conflict, near mid air collision, altitude deviation overshoot, runway excursion/incursions, and responses to external factors such as weather turbulence. Additionally, the analysis will compare resilient behavior between general aviation and commercial operation events as well as temporal trends within the archive of reports. The analysis aims to uncover how operators are practicing positive resilient behavior in situations described within the corpus of the report archive. This method provides a new lens into these valuable safety reports that can be used to inform and improve safety monitoring systems from this human resiliency perspective. The benefit can potentially lead to highlighting operator proficiencies across the aviation community and identifying knowledge gaps between different types of operations to ultimately improve safety within the NAS.

title: Adaptive Scheduling of Computing Resources for Big Data in Arithmetic Networks
authors: Qiongfang Gui, Lixing Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The computing power network provides a new type of infrastructure environment for big data processing by integrating widely distributed computing and network resources. In this environment, resources exhibit highly heterogeneous and dynamic characteristics. Traditional centralized scheduling methods struggle to effectively coordinate resources across the entire domain, and there are bottlenecks in response latency and cost - efficiency. This research constructs a computing power resource scheduling model for cross - domain collaborative computing scenarios and proposes an intelligent scheduling and allocation mechanism that supports dynamic multi - dimensional constraints. Through two - way perception of the characteristics of networked computing power supply and the portraits of task requirements, this method innovatively designs a decision - making framework for the entire domain of resources based on utility function optimization, improves the efficiency and flexibility of computing resource scheduling under multi - objective constraints, realizes the precise scheduling of big data tasks in the computing power network with low cost and low latency, and significantly optimizes the configuration cost of fragmented resources.

title: Design of an RLC dv/dt Filter for WBG devices enabled Integrated Motor Drives
authors: Shambhunath Dutta, Apurv Kumar Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Integrated motor drives are conventionally used to address the issue of voltage doubling, which can degrade motor winding insulation due to long cable connections. However, even with the use of wide-bandgap (WBG) semiconductor devices, integrated motor drives still experience high voltage slew rates at the motor terminals. To mitigate this, dv/dt filters are implemented to reduce excessive voltage transients. This paper focuses on designing an analytically modelled optimized LRC-based dv/dt filter for a WBG devices-based inverter-fed integrated induction motor drive. A key challenge in filter design is the loading effect of motor impedance which leads to the dv/dt error (the deviation between the actual and target dv/dt). An algorithm is proposed to systematically design a dv/dt filter that effectively counteracts the impact of motor impedance loading. The proposed method is validated through a 2.2 kW, 415 V induction motor drive powered by a 650 V, 30 A GaN-based inverter (GS66508T).

title: Dynamic Feature Clustering for Anomaly Detection in Streaming Cybersecurity Data
authors: Christopher Hainzl, Sourav Dutta, Sheheeda Manakkadu, Ronny Bazan Antequera
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: In cybersecurity, real-time detection of anomalous behavior in streaming data such as logs from firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and network monitors is critical. Traditional feature clustering methods struggle with streaming data due to their static nature and inability to adapt to evolving feature relationships. To address this, we propose Adaptive Feature Clustering for Streaming Data (AFCSD), a dynamic clustering approach that incrementally updates feature groupings by tracking covariance matrix drift. AFCSD continuously refines clusters to maintain relevance as data distributions shift, enabling more accurate anomaly detection in non-stationary environments. Experimental results demonstrate that AFCSD outperforms batchmode clustering techniques in both adaptability and computational efficiency for streaming scenarios. This method provides a scalable solution for real-time cybersecurity monitoring where feature semantics change over time.

title: TABNET_STACKING: Hybrid ML and DL Model for Robust Phishing Detection
authors: Bhukya Hanumanthu, Reddy Rupasri Bhavana, Sanjana Mamindlapelli, Komali Pillalamarri, Simrani Gugulothu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Phishing is cybercrime that exploits digital platforms, and makes use of them to scam users into either sharing or stealing sensitive information, such as usernames, passwords, credentials and financial details etc., without their knowledge. It has become one of the greatest threats with increased reliance on mobile devices and digital services, making it a critical issue for individuals and organizations. Phishing attacks employ deceptive emails, URLs, and websites, taking advantage of user's trust to compromise security. Machine Learning and Deep Learning have proved to be efficient in phishing detection, discovering patterns based on URLs and activities of the site. Furthermore, they easily integrate into modern systems like filters in e-mail or browsers, which moves the fight against malware from reactive to proactive in real time, together with antivirus systems. This paper explores the combined strengths of them through a hybrid model to improve phishing detection. As a part of our work we explored a few Machine learning and Ensemble models and identified models like Random Forest, eXtreme Gradient Boosting, Support Vector Classifier, and Gradient Boosting Classifier have shown better results showcasing the ability to capture structured data patterns. In contrast, Deep learning models such as TabNet and LSTM outperformed other models as they learn complex, non-linear relationships, particularly in high-dimensional data with different features. Combining these approaches by stacking allows the hybrid model to leverage the complementary strengths of each approach to improve generalization and overall performance. The proposed hybrid model minimizes overfitting by adding the information of the insights of the Machine learning, Ensemble models and refining its predictions using the Deep learning models to achieve greater accuracy with balanced metrics while minimizing false positives. In this approach, our results were well balanced, having an accuracy of 97.97%, F1-score of 97.97%, recall of 98.05%, and a precision of 97.89%. The consistency of these values shows that the proposed model is stable. The minimum variation in the range of the metrics indicates a well balanced and stable model, with fewer false positives and false negatives demonstrating the potential for robust phishing detection.

title: Touching Voices: Enhancing Accessibility Through Hand Gestures Recognition
authors: Yogesh Kale, Siya Mundhada, Vaidehi Raut, Parth Singru, Dipanshu Zade, Prachi Gawande
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost interactive glove for assisting individuals with hearing and speech impairments. Using flex and accelerometer sensors with an Arduino Nano, it translates gestures into text on an LCD screen. Achieving over 90% accuracy, the system is reliable, user-friendly, and adaptable for applications like smart homes, gaming, and industrial control.

title: Green Diagnosis: Deep Learning-Based Guava Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Anurag Shrivastava, Mohammed I. Habelalmateen, Arpanpreet Kaur, RVS Praveen, Arti Badhoutiya, Aditya Kumar
abstract: This work uses a tweaked MobileNetV2 model to provide an accurate and efficient deep learning method for guava leaf disease classification. Many fungal and bacterial illnesses that seriously affect crop output and quality might find their way on guava leaves. Effective care and prevention of many diseases depend on early detection of them. We thus used transfer learning to develop a strong classification model fit for agricultural diagnostics by fine-tuning the MobileNetV2 architecture, renowned for its lightweight and high-performance qualities. The model was trained on a carefully selected collection including three guava leaf disease class photos. Maintaining a regularly low loss, the model showed fast convergence across ten-training epochs, with a peak training accuracy of 98.97% and a validation accuracy of 99.48%. High classification dependability was shown by the classification report showing accuracy, recall, and F1-scores surpassing 0.97 for all classes. Showing low misclassifications and strong prediction confidence across all categories, the confusion matrix confirmed this even more. Visual study using accuracy and loss curves revealed the model's capacity to generalize effectively free from overfitting. These outcomes highlight how well MobileNetV2 extracts discriminative features even in settings with limited resources. Perfect for real-time agricultural uses, the suggested model guarantees computing efficiency in addition to great accuracy. This work opens the path for the creation of sophisticated agricultural monitoring systems, therefore supporting sustainable farming methods and precision agriculture. Expanding the dataset and implementing the model in mobile or edge-based systems for on-field usage will be main priorities of next development.

title: AI-Enhanced DevOps Integration in Quantum Computing Environments: Optimizing Serverless Application Performance for Retail Systems
authors: Milankumar Rana, Nandita Giri
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI), DevOps techniques, quantum computing, and serverless architectures taken together offer hitherto unheard-of possibilities for retail system optimization. This work explores the possibilities and difficulties resulting from applying AI-driven DevOps techniques in quantum computing settings to improve serverless application performance in retail environments. By means of empirical analysis of hybrid quantum-classical deployment pipelines, we show that, under high availability for retail applications, AI-enhanced DevOps practices can attain up to 40% improvement in deployment efficiency and 35% reduction in quantum resource consumption. Important results show that combined with machine learning-based resource optimization, quantum-aware continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines greatly improve scalability and performance criteria. Evaluating three retail scenarios—dynamic pricing optimization, inventory management, and fraud detection—the research uses a mixed-methods approach combining controlled experiments with IBM Qiskit simulators and AWS Lambda serverless capabilities. Among all the scenarios, results show 51% deployment time reduction, 35% quantum resource optimization, and enhanced application performance. Challenges include, nevertheless, organizational skill gaps, hybrid system complexity, quantum decoherence management, and specialized toolchain needs. The paper offers a complete structure for companies trying to keep strong DevOps standards while using quantum computing benefits in retail serverless architectures. This study adds empirical data, useful recommendations, and performance criteria for real-world implementation scenarios, so supporting the developing field of quantum-enhanced enterprise systems.

title: Towards Secure and Transparent Cloud Auditing: A Blockchain and IPFS-Driven Framework with Batch Verification
authors: Houaida Ghanmi, Nasreddine Hajlaoui, Haifa Touati, Saadi Boudjit, Mohamed Hadded, Mohand Yazid Saidi, Paul Muhlethaler
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of cloud storage and the increasing use of connected devices, uploading data to the cloud results in the loss of physical control by data owners, making confidentiality and integrity entirely dependent on Cloud Service Providers (CSPs). This raises concerns about whether CSPs effectively safeguard outsourced data, as any malicious behavior can lead to data tampering or deviation. Traditional auditing schemes rely on Third Party Authorities (TPAs), which are not always trustworthy. Although various cloud data auditing mechanisms have been proposed, few effectively address the challenge of ensuring data integrity without relying on trusted third parties. To overcome this limitation, we propose a secure and efficient distributed blockchain-based data integrity auditing scheme. Specifically, our approach randomly assigns the audit task to a user selected from among the system participants via blockchain. Blockchain and InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) technologies are leveraged to enforce access control. Furthermore, the proposed scheme supports low-cost batch integrity verification without the need for a TPA. Theoretical analyses confirm that our solution ensures data traceability and auditability, and reduces reliance on third parties. Finally, our simulations show that proof generation remains under 0.7 seconds for 600 data blocks at 256-bit security, while verification costs remain negligible.

title: A Low-Power 10-bit SAR ADC with Splitting Decoder for Implantable Pacemakers
authors: Deepika Kumaradasan, Sougata Kumar Kar, Santanu Sarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Achieving high linearity and precise capacitive matching is a critical requirement in capacitive digital-to-analog converters (CDACs). To address this, the static and dynamic performance of a 10-bit, $833.33 \mathrm{kS} / \mathrm{s}$ low-power SAR ADC has been enhanced through the use of a split-decoded capacitive DAC architecture. The design is implemented using UMC 180 nm CMOS process technology and operates at a supply voltage of 1.8 V. A dual-path bootstrapped switch—comprising a main signal path and an auxiliary signal path—is employed to improve switching speed and linearity. Additionally, a triple-tail comparator is incorporated to achieve low noise and offset while maintaining low power consumption. Simulation results indicate that the proposed SAR ADC, featuring a split-decoded CDAC structure, consumes approximately $91.93 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ of power. It demonstrates excellent static performance, achieving a differential nonlinearity (DNL) of 0.12 LSB and an integral nonlinearity (INL) of 0.14 LSB. In terms of dynamic behavior, the ADC attains a signal-to-noise-and-distortion ratio (SNDR) of 61.41 dB, a spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of 79.41 dB, and an effective number of bits (ENoB) of 9.91 bits for an input frequency of 813.802 Hz sampled at $833.33 \mathrm{kS} / \mathrm{s}$. Furthermore, corner analysis and Monte Carlo simulations are conducted, and the ADC’s dynamic performance is evaluated for various input frequencies around the Nyquist rate of 416.66 kHz.

title: Hospital Management System Using Django Frameworks
authors: S Suganya, A.R. Kavitha, V M Thejashree, B Vidya
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The Hospital Management System project is a web application, developed with Django, that aims to increase the efficiency of hospital management. It provides three types of user roles: Admin, Doctor, and Patient. All of them have unique functionalities for effective management processes. The system enables patients to book appointments with their specific doctors by means of a friendly interface that displays available time slots and confirmation notifications. It also contains a more comprehensive billing system that sends automatic invoices to patients of various charges that they could download after discharge, leaving no room for billing-related ambiguity. Although the software project shows all the capabilities involved in managing a hospital operation, it lacks admin approval for account creation. It also does not encompass total patient management capabilities. In future such added features as AI and telemedicine may also be included for further maximization of these proposed service delivery and efficiency operation techniques. In this case, the system offers a prototype model with lots of promises for future evolution within this hospital management domain.

title: Advanced Air Mobility Simulation Tool for Airspace Capacity Estimation
authors: Antoni Kopyt, Kacper Kaczmarek, Mateusz Sochacki
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The Urban Air Mobility Traffic Analysis Tool (UAM TAT) is a versatile simulation platform designed to facilitate the safe and efficient integration of VTOL aircraft within urban environments. It enables users to explore various operational scenarios in a simulated airspace, focusing on optimizing traffic management and safety through effective risk mitigation strategies. The tool's modular architecture allows for customization of aircraft types, air traffic regulations, and operational parameters, making it adaptable to different urban mobility contexts. It provides valuable insights into airspace and vertiport capacity planning, as well as fleet sizing for VTOL operations. The results from five distinct simulations demonstrate the tool's capabilities, showing how different vertiport hub operations and air traffic management approaches influence aircraft conflicts and overall system performance. Overall, UAM TAT is a powerful resource for researchers, urban planners, and air traffic authorities aiming to develop and evaluate strategies for deploying urban air mobility solutions safely and efficiently.

title: Vibration Based Condition Monitoring of Stator Interturn Faults in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors Using a Machine Learning Approach
authors: Khushboo Ramawat, Bharat Singh Rajpurohit
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This work aims to explore machine learning based vibration condition monitoring techniques for interturn fault detection in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs). Although previous studies mainly focus on pattern detection for faults using current signature analysis, this research shifts focus to the underexplored domain of vibration based fault detection using machine learning. In this paper, a hybrid approach is proposed that integrates statistical and frequency domain feature extraction with machine learning models for fault detection in PMSMs. Initially, key features including mean, standard deviation, kurtosis, skewness, and fast Fourier transform based features are extracted from time-domain vibration signals, which are sensitive to mechanical and electrical faults. Principal Component Analysis is used for dimension reduction and retaining the most important features. The resulting principal features are then utilized as inputs to machine learning classifiers, including Random Forest, Decision Tree, K-nearest neighbor, and deep learning classifiers such as Convolutional Neural Networks and Multi-Layer Perceptron for fault classification. Comparative evaluations demonstrate that KNN and Random Forest classifiers achieve the highest fault classification accuracy of approximately 95%, highlighting the robustness of the proposed methodology. The results suggest that the developed approach offers a reliable and efficient solution for real-time condition monitoring of PMSMs, with significant implications for electric transportation and sustainable energy applications.

title: Smart IoT-Based Healthcare Systems for Continuous Health Monitoring and Predictive Analytics
authors: Ballari Supraja, Kiran Kumar V, Krishna Kumar N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: New healthcare systems arrived from IoT technological advancement that now allows health status tracking continuously and predictive analysis monitoring. This proposal delivers a fresh smart IoT healthcare solution which retrieves real-time data through edge computing and advanced machine learning to detect health anomalies precisely. The system utilizes the combination of CNN and LSTM networks to build a hybrid model that detects spatial along with temporal patterns in health-related data. By integrating edge computing the system becomes appropriate for real-time healthcare use because it decreases latency while improving energy efficiency. The experimental data shows that the hybrid CNN-LSTM model surpasses conventional models such as Decision Trees, Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) with 94.7% accuracy rate along with 93.5% precision and 92.8% recall and 93.1% F1-score. The system confirms its high prediction accuracy through its RMSE measurement of 0.09. The introduced framework serves as a reliable platform for continuous health surveillance and early condition monitoring which holds practical value for telemedicine systems and individual health care solutions.

title: A Scalable and Efficient Intrusion Detection System Based on a Shapley Value Driven Feature Selection
authors: Giovanni Rocca, Mattia G. Spina, Floriano De Rango
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices, amplified by 6G, has heightened security risks. To counter these, experts are improving Intrusion Detection Systems (IDSs) using Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) algorithms, which rely on Feature Selection (FS) to identify key features and optimize performance in detecting attacks. In this context, this paper proposes a novel informed FS technique that exploits XAI (eXplainable Artificial Intelligence). The proposed algorithm extends the use of Shapley Value in XAI by enhancing it with an accuracy-driven binary search with the aim of finding the most representative feature and therefore reducing the dimensionality of a Network Intrusion Dataset, improving its detection ability. Through a comprehensive experimental campaign, the proposal has been validated and its benefits, which are not only limited to reduced training and testing time, but also drastically streamlining the AI model complexity. Finally, a comparison with other standard FS techniques is also provided to further highlight the advantages of the proposed algorithm. The proposal has been validated through a comprehensive experimental campaign in which results show the benefits. The experimental section shows the performance of the model when trained on the set of features returned by DeepSHAP and on the set returned by our framework, showing a drastic reduction in training and testing time.

title: Advancing Fake News Detection: A Comparative Study of Traditional and BERT-Random Forest Hybrid Model
authors: Arun Kumar Kurakula, Sidda Deepika, N.C. Pavani, Sivakala Sridevi, Sivapuram Yagnika, Yallala Veera Nishitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Fake news is spreading quickly on digital channels, endangering public trust and the veracity of information. For efficient false news identification, this work suggests a hybrid model that combines the resilience of a Random Forest classifier with the contextual understanding power of BERT. Standard datasets containing important performance measures, including as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, are used to assess the model. Furthermore, this study compares classic machine learning methods like Linear Support Vector Classifier and Logistic Regression with more sophisticated models like BERT. By showing how transformer-based designs offer better context comprehension and detection accuracy than earlier methods, the comparison illustrates the development of false news detection technologies. The outcomes demonstrate how the combination strategy, which makes use of Random Forest's effective classification and BERT's profound semantic understanding, greatly increases detection accuracy. This hybrid approach provides a scalable and efficient way to detect fake news, particularly in settings where false information is changing quickly. The study highlights how crucial it is to incorporate cutting-edge models for detecting systems that are more precise and dependable.

title: Redundant Echo Path Estimation for an Adaptive Kernel-Linear Cascaded Structure
authors: Moctar Mossi Idrissa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: This work investigates a non-linear cascaded structure combining a kernel filter and a linear filter. We propose using a second, independent linear adaptive filter to support the estimation of the Hammerstein model parameters. Previous research on Hammerstein systems for non-linear applications, such as echo cancellation, typically relies on the linear filter's estimate to adapt the preceding non-linear filter. In contrast, our solution uses an independent linear filter for the kernel filter's adaptation, thus reducing the impact of the main linear filter. Additionally, to reduce adaptation complexity, we discard small coefficients of the linear acoustic path and apply a delay correction. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach successfully reduces complexity. With proper delay correction, our method yields performance improvements, including an approximately 7 dB improvement in System Distance (SD) compared to a purely linear filter and about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 ~ d B}$</tex> improvement in Echo Return Loss Enhancement (ERLE) during saturation periods.

title: Fake News Detection Using AI: A Hybrid Approach with ML, Deep Learning, and LLaMA Models
authors: Roopesh Ramesh, Sagar P Patil, Tejasvi Bellubbi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: This study provides an end-to-end overview of machine learning (ML), deep learning, and artificial intelligence (AI)-based methods to detect fake news. The suggested method is classified into a sequential pipeline including data collection, preprocessing, feature extraction, model training, and performance metrics. Different ML models such as Logistic Regression, XGBoost, and Support Vector Machines (SVM) and deep models such as Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) are used to classify news stories on the basis of both their text and context details. The LLaMA model is also fine-tuned for better classification results with the help of higher-level natural language processing (NLP) methods. Experimental results indicate that their combination with social context features and classical content-based analysis yields significant detection performance gains. The paper makes a contribution to ongoing research trends in the topic of fighting misinformation by designing AI-driven systems for fake news detection.

title: Model Order Reduction of Air Core Transformer Using Direct Truncation and Routh Array Method
authors: Subhashini Chauhan, Nitin Sundriyal, V. P. Singh, T. K. Bashihshta, Vimal Singh Bisht, Akhilesh Mathur
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: An air-core transformer is used in high-frequency applications because of its low core losses and minimal hysteresis effects. It has a higher-order transfer function (TF) that is difficult to analyze. This paper presents a reduction of the tenth-order TF of an air core transformer into various reduced-order models. The reduction of the numerator is made by the direct truncation method, and the reduction of the denominator is made by the Routh-approximation method. With the help of these methods, reduced order models are obtained, which are simpler and consist of dynamic features like stability and accuracy. After that, some qualitative and quantitative analyses were performed on various models that were obtained. For qualitative analysis, the step response, Bode, and Nyquist plots are plotted to compare the performance of the reduced order model with the original system. For quantitative analysis, time domain characteristics are tabulated.

title: Grid Integration of Parallel-Connected Self-Excited Induction Generators Using Adaptive Predictive Virtual Synchronous Generator Control
authors: Mrinal Kanti Rajak, Akash Singh, Rajen Pudur
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: A novel Adaptive Predictive Virtual Synchronous Generator (AP-VSG) control strategy is proposed for enhanced grid stability and renewable energy integration. The method introduces adaptive inertia and damping mechanisms combined with multi-objective predictive optimization, specifically designed for parallel-connected Self-Excited Induction Generators (SEIGs). Unlike conventional approaches requiring multiple DC conversion stages, the proposed system implements parallel operation directly in the AC domain, reducing system complexity and conversion losses. The AP-VSG control incorporates real-time adaptation of virtual inertia (H) ranging from 1 s to 4 s and damping coefficient (D) from 20 to 65 pu, responding to grid frequency deviations and Rate of Change of Frequency (RoCoF). Implementation results demonstrate a 56% reduction in maximum RoCoF (from ±0.48 Hz/s to 0.21 Hz/s), a 33% improvement in frequency nadir, and a ±41% enhancement in damping ratio. The multi-objective optimization approach achieves a 36.7% reduction in control effort while maintaining stability margins (PM > 45°, GM > 6 dB). Statistical analysis confirms a 95th percentile frequency regulation enhancement of 43.5% compared to conventional VSG control. The strategy effectively balances dynamic response and stability, validated through comprehensive metrics. Experimental results verify robust performance under various grid disturbances.

title: PH Sensing With a Balloon-Type Fiber Structure Integrated in a Fiber Ring Laser
authors: Weihao Lin, Fang Zhao, Zihan Huang, Keyu Cai, Lu Chen, Lifang Tu, Li-yang Shao, Perry Ping Shum
abstract: This work introduces a novel fiber-optic sensor for precise oral <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p H}$</tex> monitoring, addressing critical limitations of conventional methods. A balloon-shaped Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) was integrated into a ring laser cavity, leveraging its flexible, minimally invasive structure to achieve pH detection while minimizing microenvironmental disturbance. The sensor demonstrated high pH sensitivity equals to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 1. 5 5 2} \mathbf{n m} / \mathbf{p H}$</tex> within the clinically relevant range of 6.6-7.3, covering the enamel demineralization threshold linked to caries progression. Integration into the ring laser cavity significantly enhanced the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5 ~ d B}$</tex>. This approach provides a robust tool for continuous oral <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p H}$</tex> monitoring and offers new insights into the dynamic acid-base processes underlying caries pathogenesis, with potential applications in personalized risk assessment and intervention strategies.

title: Research on Multi-dimensional Security Event Association Model for Network Security of Substation in Power Dispatching System
authors: Yan Jin, Jianping Li, Shiyu Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper aims to construct a multi-dimensional security event association model to improve network security monitoring and defense capabilities. By deeply analyzing the network architecture and common security threats of the power dispatching system substation, a security event association algorithm based on improved graph neural network and dynamic time warping (IGNN-DTA) is proposed. The algorithm uses the powerful relationship modeling ability of graph neural network to extract features and mine relationships of security events, introduces dynamic time warping to optimize event sequence matching, and enhances the adaptability of the model to complex and changeable network environments. The experiment is based on the actual power dispatching system data set and is compared with the traditional association algorithm in simulating multiple attack scenarios. The results show that the detection accuracy of the IGNN-DTA algorithm reaches 95.3%, the false alarm rate is as low as 3.1%, and the F1 value is 0.94. Compared with the traditional algorithm, the accuracy is improved by 12.7%, and the false alarm rate is reduced by 8.6%. It effectively improves the accuracy and efficiency of security event association analysis, and provides strong support for network security protection of substations in power dispatching systems.

title: BirdSonic: An AI-Powered System for Real-Time Bird Species Detection Using Audio Classification
authors: Jeevan Bhandary, Spoorthi P Shetty, Bharath S Bhat, Mangala Shetty, Shreya Jaya Shetty
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: BirdSonic is a deep learning-based AI-powered system that uses sound recordings to identify and categorize different bird species, providing a fresh method of bird species identification. Conventional techniques for classifying bird species mostly rely on manual identification, which can be laborious, error-prone, and need a high level of skill. BirdSonic uses cuttingedge machine learning techniques, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), to examine bird call recordings in order to overcome these difficulties. The method facilitates accurate and efficient classification by converting these audio inputs into spectrogram images. Data gathering, preprocessing, spectrogram creation, model training, and an interactive interface for realtime species prediction are all steps that make up BirdSonic's core. Bird call datasets are gathered from both personal field recordings and open-source archives. These unprocessed audio files go through preprocessing, where data quality is guaranteed by segmentation and noise reduction methods. The CNN model uses the spectrogram image of sound frequencies that are created from the processed recordings. These spectrograms are used to train the deep learning model, which identifies unique audio patterns linked to various bird species. BirdSonic uses a number of data augmentation techniques, including time-shifting, pitch modulation, and background noise addition, to improve its accuracy to 93.34 % and resilience. Users can input audio recordings and get real-time bird species predictions using the final trained model, which is implemented in an interactive webbased interface.

title: Smart Meter Data Attacks Assessment: Evaluating Across Diverse Scenarios
authors: Nidhi Nidhi, Vikash Kumar Saini, Rajesh Kumar, Rajive Tiwari, Ameena S. Al-Sumaiti
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Smart meters play a crucial role in transferring information between customers and utility companies by utilizing bidirectional communication and introducing vulnerabilities to cyber-attacks. These cyber-attacks, such as data replay attacks (DRA) and false data injection into databases, introduce errors in power demand load forecasting, which further results in energy supply scheduling problems. This paper provides a learning framework for smart meter cyber attacks by implementing a supervised machine learning algorithm to detect any kind of data anomalies or manipulation. The machine learning model employed in this paper includes Decision Tree, Random Forest, AdaBoost, and XGBoost. The fraudulent dataset is generated by employing two types of attack scenarios, and the performance of each machine-learning model is evaluated across diverse attack scenarios. In this proposed work, the percentage of attack level have been employed as 50%, 30%, 15%, and 5%. The performance metrics employed in this study to analyze the performance of the machine learning model are recall, precision, accuracy, f1-score, and area under the curve. The simulation results show that the attack level or imbalanced data proportion has a significant impact on the performance metrics of AdaBoost as the recall score has decreased from 0.9940 to 0.2608 if the attack level is decreased from 50% to 5%.

title: DeFi Liquidity Provisioning with Reinforcement Learning and Dynamic Feature Selection
authors: Benoît-Marie Robaglia
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: This paper introduces a Deep Reinforcement Learning Algorithm for liquidity provision on Uniswap V3. This method augments Proximal Policy Optimization with 1) crossvalidated recursive feature elimination to build a volatilityaware state representation and 2) Bayesian Online Change-Point Detection for real-time regime shifts. Experiments on the FinAI Contest 2025 Task 3 benchmark show that our proposed solution outperforms both the vanilla PPO baseline and a passive fullrange strategy.

title: Diabetes Prediction Using Optimized Ensemble Techniques
authors: Mamunur Rashid Alex, Abdul Kadar Muhammad Masum, Dewan Md Farid, Touhid Bhuiyan, Md. Maruf Hassan
abstract: Among the most common chronic diseases worldwide, diabetes greatly increases morbidity and mortality. Notwithstanding developments in ensemble methods for medical diagnostics, problems such as class imbalance, high-dimensional data, and interpretability remain unresolved. This work suggests a methodical technique for diabetes prediction from a publicly available dataset. Robust data preprocessing (outlier removal, feature transformation, Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) for class imbalance), feature engineering, and hyperparameter optimization using GridSearch and Bayesian approaches form part of our approach. Stratified K-Fold ensures that the model can generalize better and reduce the chance of bias towards the more common class. With test accuracies of 97.18%, 97.21%, and 97.20%, respectively, assess and contrast three models: Random Forest (RF), Decision Tree (DT), and XGBoost, where XGBoost has good predictive performance. While it excels in interpretable feature selection, our results show XGBoost beats DT and RF in accuracy, precision, and F1-score. This study compares modern ensemble methods for disease prediction and emphasizes the need for preprocessing and optimization in improving model generalization.

title: Analysis of Hardware Trojan for Multilevel Cascaded Converters
authors: Anant K. Verma, Claudio B. Mellado, Catalina González Castaño, Sumit Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Hardware security is an increasingly critical area in safeguarding power electronic converter systems from malicious attacks targeting control platforms. These systems rely heavily on embedded control units, such as microcontrollers, digital signal processors, field-programmable gate arrays, and programmable logic controllers, to implement intelligent control, complex communication protocols, and protection mechanisms in real-time applications. With rising concerns over cyber threats, particular attention is being given to the risks posed by hardware-based intrusions, commonly referred to as hardware Trojans. These malicious circuits can be stealthily introduced during various stages, including design, fabrication, firmware development, and system configuration. This article investigates the specific impact of hardware Trojans in the context of cascaded H-bridge multilevel converters, which are widely used in medium- and high-voltage applications. A systematic approach is presented to mathematically model different types of hardware Trojans, analyze their activation mechanisms, and assess their effects on system performance. Special emphasis is placed on how these intrusions can disrupt the intended operation of phase-shifted pulse width modulation strategy. The study aims to categorize hardware Trojans based on their behavior and effects, thereby laying a foundational benchmark for future research into the detection and mitigation of hardware-level threats in power electronic control platforms.

title: Adaptive Periodic Disturbance Compensation for Continuous-Time Linear Systems with Input Delays
authors: Jiahao Zhu, Shujin Yuan, Lisheng Mou, Jun Luo, Huayan Pu
abstract: Unknown time-varying periodic disturbances and input delays can degrade control performance and even lead to system instability. This paper presents a novel direct adaptive output feedback controller based on the internal model principle (IMP) to compensate for the unknown time-varying periodic disturbance in input delay systems. To reduce the design difficulty of the controller, the input delay system is equivalent to an input delay-free system by constructing stable auxiliary systems. Next, all the stabilizing controllers of the input delay system are derived by using the Youla parameterization method. Based on the IMP, an interpolation condition to completely compensate for periodic disturbances is formulated. Then, to compensate for the unknown time-varying periodic disturbance, a parameter adaptive algorithm is designed to update the Q-parameters online. The convergence of adaptive algorithms is analyzed by the Lyapunov function theory. Simulation and experimental results validated the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: An Optimized Swarm Intelligence Approach for Fuzzy Clustering-Based Intrusive Behavior Detection in IoT and Network System
authors: Yatindra Kumar Gupta, Sasidhar Reddy Gaddam, Himanshu Gupta, Somnath Banerjee
abstract: In today’s digital age, intrusion detection systems help protect IoT (Internet of Things) systems from harmful activities. This study presents a new method using fuzzy clustering and swarm intelligence to spot hackers in wireless networks. More dependence on internet systems has caused a rise in cybersecurity threats, making it clear that traditional security methods are not enough. Swarm intelligence combined with fuzzy logic in the suggested approach allows the system to create flexible clusters that can spot unusual traffic in a network. With swarm intelligence, finding optimal ways to group data is enhanced and fuzzy logic helps cope with cases where things are unclear or share similar traits. With this method, you see more accurate detection and fewer false alarms which works well in the complicated and various settings of IoT environments. It outlines the design, explains how the algorithm works and shows the outcomes of the simulation, verifying that the approach is successful in early threat detection and responding rapidly which helps make IoT security systems more secure.

title: Advanced Cybersecurity Frameworks Leveraging AI for Threat Detection and Intrusion Prevention
authors: Vikas Prajapati
abstract: The widespread expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) networks makes cybersecurity challenging to manage because of sophisticated network traffic and advanced cyber threat methods. Higher sophistication rates of cyber threats and intrusion attempts require the creation of cybersecurity frameworks that use artificial intelligence approaches. A model based on an LSTM architecture serves as a threat detection system for cybersecurity applications using CICIDS2017 data. The data quality improved significantly through application of multiple data preprocessing methods, such as duplicate removal, missing value handling as well as one-hot encoding and Min-Max normalization. The model outperformed "Decision Tree" (DT), "Random Forest" (RF), and "Gaussian Naïve Bayes" (GNB) models, scoring 99.9% "accuracy" (acc), 99.6% "precision" (prec), 99% "recall" (recl), and 99.3% "F1score" (f-measure). The model identified known and undiscovered threats with low false positives and negatives, showing resilience. Overfitting issues in the performance emerged even after strong results were recorded, which led to the requirement for additional regularization techniques, including early stopping and dropout.

title: Investigation of a Novel Dual-Flux-Modulated Magnetically Geared Machine
authors: Jin Zhang, Weisong Xu, Dakai Chen, Huajie Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This research introduces a novel dual-flux-modulated magnetically geared machine (DFM-MGM) developed from the dual-flux-modulated coaxial magnetic gear (DFM-CMG) to enhance output performance. It is constructed by winding coils directly onto the DFM-CMG stator slots. This design achieves the electromechanical integration of a permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM) and a permanent magnet vernier machine (PMVM). Theoretical analysis reveals that the interactive flux modulation effects between stator and modulator result in an output torque given by T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">o_dfm</inf>=G<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rr</inf>T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">HE</inf>+T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RE</inf>, with gear ratio G<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rr</inf>=9.5. Spectral analysis of flux density in the outer air-gap demonstrates harmonic superposition from the decomposed PMSM and PMVM units. The DFM-MGM exhibits a torque capability of 22.38 Nm. The no-load back-EMF is 43.2 V at the HSR speed of n<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">h</inf>=1500 rpm. The output torque is 5.59 Nm at a current of I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rms</inf>=1 A.

title: Cycle-GAN Based Fish Disease Image Generation for Dataset Expansion and Blending
authors: Xujun Ye
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In the field of aquaculture, the early and accurate identification of fish diseases definitely be the crucial point for disease prevention and control. However, there are several reasons: the complex underwater environment and the strong light scattering in water etc. This results in common quality degradation issues in acquired fish disease images, such as blurriness, low contrast, and indistinct features, which severely restricts the development of diagnostic technologies. Focusing on the above challenge, this paper proposes an innovative image generation algorithm that fuses the self-attention mechanism with the Cyclic Generative Adversarial Network (Cycle-GAN) to solve the part of problems. This algorithm is built on the architecture of the classic GAN, embedding a multi-scale convolutional attention module to enhance the model's ability to extract subtle features of fish diseases, bringing in a multi-scale feature fusion strategy to improve the sensitivity of the model to multi-dimensional information. By using the proposed algorithm to perform style transfer on real-time images of healthy fish, bidirectional conversion between healthy and diseased images is achieved, thereby constructing a mixed dataset to enhance to its quality. Experiments have shown that mixed dataset can significantly improve the recognition accuracy of subsequent classification models, providing reliable data support and technical paths for intelligent diagnosis of fish diseases, and has an important application value in disease prevention and control in aquaculture.

title: An Approach to Integrated Charging, Scheduling and Resource Allocation for UAM Fleet Operations
authors: Zexuan Wu, Yan Xu, Hanlin Wu, Kaiquan Cai, Kam K.H. Ng
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The rapid growth of low-altitude urban air mobility (UAM) faces challenges in harmonizing the demands of hybrid missions, resource allocation, and airspace congestion, lacking the adaptability to address the spatiotemporal complexities of electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) operations. This work thereby proposes a fleet scheduling method that considers the objectives of minimizing delay costs, flight costs, and charging costs, while considering factors such as charging infrastructure, take-off and landing pad time, residual capacity, battery state, and flow balancing. Additionally, a hybrid UAM mission scheduling approach is used, taking as inputs the resource occupancy of vertical take-off and landing pads by other airlines. In ondemand missions during run-time operations, a rolling horizon mechanism is applied to adapt the baseline schedule to dynamic conditions. Experimental validation based on a vertiport cluster with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1 0}$</tex> missions discovered that selecting delay indicators and cost indicators can be explored for efficient scheduling options to reduce delays and costs by comparing different cases.

title: IK-PBFT: Dynamic Credit and Multi-Anomaly Detection Enhanced PBFT for Large-Scale Consortium Blockchain
authors: Yandong Qin, Ping Ling
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: To address low throughput and high communication latency of Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) in large-scale consortium blockchains, this paper proposes an improved consensus algorithm, IK-PBFT (Isolation Forest and K-Means-PBFT), based on credit evaluation and anomaly detection. It constructs a dynamic credit evaluation model integrating node activity, transaction success rate, response time ratio, and historical behavior attenuation factor to quantify node reliability. Additionally, it employs Isolation Forest-based anomaly detection, K-Means clustering, and delay fluctuation detection to classify nodes into three levels (advanced, intermediate, elementary), optimizing consensus node quality. Moreover, the algorithm reduces communication complexity by optimizing the consensus protocol process. Experimental results show that in a 100-node network, IK-PBFT achieves 5.7 times the throughput of PBFT; with 600 nodes, it reduces communication overhead by 73.37% and consensus latency by 90.42% compared to PBFT. The proposed algorithm effectively meets the high-throughput and low-latency requirements in large-scale consortium blockchains.

title: Research on the Construction of Thinking Chain Reasoning Model for Knowledge Question Answering System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Jialing Wu, Han He, Zhirui Tu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes a thinking chain reasoning model based on deep learning, which aims to enhance the intelligence and reasoning ability of knowledge question answering system in solving complex problems. The model combines deep learning technologies such as BERT and Transformer, and enables the system to understand and deduce implicit relationships in questions through a multi-level semantic understanding framework, thereby achieving more accurate answer reasoning. The thinking chain reasoning model simulates the reasoning process of human thinking through multi-step reasoning and step-by-step deduction of questions. When facing multi-level and complex question answering scenarios, it can dynamically build reasoning chains to ensure the accuracy and efficiency of the system when facing different types of questions. Experimental results show that compared with traditional rule-based question answering systems, the proposed thinking chain reasoning model has obvious advantages in dealing with multi-step reasoning, complex questions and long-tail questions. Experiments on the SQuAD dataset show that the accuracy of the model is improved by 15% and the F1 score is improved by 12%, which proves the good performance of the model in diverse problem scenarios.
