authors: Yisheng Dong, Zhen Tian, Chunmei Ouyang, Xieyu Chen
abstract: Metasurfaces have emerged as powerful platforms for manipulating electromagnetic waves at subwavelength scales, yet conventional designs are often limited by static functionalities. To address this constraint, we propose a dynamically tunable terahertz metasurface that integrates the phase-change material <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ge}_{2} \text{Sb}_{2} \text{Te}_{5}$</tex> (GST) to realize control over polarization-multiplexed holography and orbital angular momentum (OAM) manipulation. The device leverages a hybrid architecture of passive silicon-based meta-atoms and active GST-coated pillars, enabling switchable operation via GST's reversible phase transition. These functionalities are validated through full-wave simulations and OAM spectrum analysis. This work showcases a versatile strategy for dynamic light field modulation in the terahertz regime, with promising applications in reconfigurable photonic devices, high-capacity communication, and optical trapping.

title: Sharing of Energy Storage Through Storage Rights Considering Network Losses
authors: Shubham Patwari, Satish Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Energy storage (ES) plays a crucial role in the energy market by ensuring economic viability through energy balance and reliability services. A novel market instrument, known as ’physical storage rights (PSR),’ allows ES to be shared within a local energy community among various participants, such as wind producers and consumers. PSR enables market participants to access and utilize storage efficiently, helping to mitigate storage congestion and hedge against price volatility. This paper presents a generalized Nash equilibrium problem (GNEP) model for allocating PSR among all participant types in a local energy community while accounting for network losses. A case study is conducted to analyze the impact of network losses on total system profit during PSR allocation. Additionally, the study provides a quantitative comparison of system profit based on the availability of storage with PSR. The results indicate that an increase in network losses leads to a reduction in system profit within the local energy community.

title: Modular Reference Software Architecture (RECMMan) for RADAR ECM Effector Systems
authors: Mustafa Dursun, Erhan ÖRÜMLÜ
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In this paper, we present a modular reference software architecture (RECMMan) for Radar Electronic CM effector which decouples platform dependencies and system requirements to bound the software complexity and increase scalability and flexibility. RECMMan depends on FACE ® combined with IMA to manage the RECM effector system.

title: Adaptive and Intelligent Control Strategies for EV Induction motor: A Comparative Study of PID, FLC and ANN
authors: Sk. Shaheena, M. Vrunda, T. Harathi, C. Bhargava, P. Puhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In electric and hybrid vehicles (EVs and HEVs), improving the energy efficiency is crucial because of the limited capacity of onboard batteries. Although induction motors are popular owing to their reliability and cost advantages, they tend to use more energy than required, especially when running under light loads, which lowers the overall efficiency. To address this, this study explores smarter control methods such as Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control, Fuzzy Logic Control (FLC), and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN). Each method has its strengths;—PID handles precise error correction, FLC adapts to changing loads, and ANN predicts load shifts to adjust the motor behavior in real time. Together, they help reduce the starting current of motor, reduce energy losses, and boost overall performance across different conditions. Simulations using MATLAB/Simulink showed that these approaches, particularly an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) control strategy, significantly outperform traditional PID control by offering faster response times, better energy savings, and greater system stability. The results also highlight that rotor and stator core losses are greatly minimized, making the EV motor system more efficient and reliable.

title: CyberVigilance: A Deep Learning Framework for Cyber Attack Forecasting
authors: Aryaman Agarwal, Manthan Ayalwar, Rohit Baviskar, Swapnali Kurhade
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The growing complexity and frequency of cyber-attacks necessitate innovative solutions to predict and mitigate emerging threats effectively. The Cyber Vigilance Project introduces a robust framework that integrates advanced machine learning, real-time data analysis, and interactive visualization to address these challenges. Unlike traditional monitoring tools, this framework uniquely combines predictive modeling with conversational AI and a structured threat lifecycle model, making it highly adaptive to real-world conditions. By leveraging web scraping techniques, the system continuously gathers cyberattack data from sources like Hackmageddon, storing it in MongoDB Atlas for scalability and efficient processing. A combination of Bayesian LSTM (B-LSTM) and ARIMA models enables accurate forecasting of cyberattack trends, achieving an average MSMAPE of 0.25 across multiple attack types. The project also includes an interactive Power BI dashboard that provides dynamic insights into attack patterns across regions, sectors, and timelines, empowering users with actionable intelligence. The integration of a Threat Vulnerability Matrix and Traffic Light Protocol (TLP) categorization offers a structured view of potential risks, which is rarely seen in similar research. Key innovations such as a chatbot powered by advanced Natural Language Understanding (NLU) and a Threat Vulnerability Matrix further enhance usability by offering real-time guidance on threat mitigation strategies. This system combines automation, predictive modeling, and usercentric features to deliver a scalable and practical cybersecurity solution. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of the Cyber Vigilance Project in mitigating risks and providing organizations with tools to defend against evolving digital threats. Future developments include expanding the dataset, refining predictive algorithms, and applying the framework to emerging domains like IoT and cloud computing.

title: High Precision Signal Simulator for Aircraft Engine Oil Debris Sensors
authors: Jianping Zhao, Ruiqian Sun, Xiaoqiang Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: At present, the signal of the engine health management system is becoming more and more complex, which brings great inconvenience to testing, verification and maintenance. Aiming to address the difficulty of the electrical simulator of the signal of the lubricating oil metal chip sensor, a new method is designed that can simulate the change of lubricating oil flow rate, debris type, particle size, sensor base bias, and noise. The electrical simulator system architecture is studied, and key designs such as passive adder, low-ripple voltage regulator, and analogue multiplier are analyzed. Furthermore, a physical verification platform is built. The experimental verification shows that the designed sensor simulation system can effectively test and verify the lubricating oil metal chip signal detection system, which greatly improves the maintenance efficiency and has high practical value.

title: Multilevel Feature Fusion and Attention Enhancement for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
authors: Lianjie Zhang, Tingnian He, Bojia Chen, Shuan Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis integrates data from various modalities, such as text, audio, and images, to analyze and interpret human emotional states. However, insufficient multimodal feature extraction and inadequate fusion of intra-modal and inter-modal information can hinder further improvements in model performance. To address these issues, this paper presents a method for multimodal sentiment analysis based on multilevel feature fusion and attention enhancement. The approach employs cross-modal attention for primary feature interaction and uses self-attention mechanisms to generate advanced features. A gating mechanism is introduced to dynamically adjust the fusion of features across different levels, followed by the use of a Transformer to capture deep inter-modal relationships. Experiments are conducted on two publicly available multimodal sentiment analysis datasets, CMU-MOSI and CMU-MOSEI, and the method in this paper achieves better performance compared to the baseline model.

title: Implementation of Power-Optimized Transition Reduction Encoding Schemes for VLSI Interconnects
authors: Ajit Kumar Nayak, Manish Nagpal, Malathi. H, Nipun Sharma, Megalan Leo L, Abhinav Rathour
abstract: This research paper presents a new method of encode that reduces power loss and latency by minimizing the number of bus switching tasks. This memory-based method partitions data for selected inverting with the goal of minimizing the distance of Hamming among the current and prior transmits. The manuscript describes the decoder and encoder in depth, bringing attention to their straightforward design and the benefits of the suggested Upper-Lower bit inversion technique over more conventional approaches like XOR-XNOR and Even-Odd. This research paper lays out the case for the suggested method as a viable option for enhancing embedding system reliability by tackling power efficiency issues in contemporary VLSI architectures. The overall accuracy of the suggested technique is 97%, which is far higher than that of competing alternatives.

title: PowerGlide: An Open-Source Wheelchair Conversion System with Multi-Modal Control
authors: Michael Harris, Reta Gela, Alim Saidkhodjaev, Jerry Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Commercial powered wheelchairs present significant financial barriers, with systems often exceeding asset limits for individuals receiving disability benefits. This creates a critical need for affordable and accessible powered mobility solutions that do not require complete replacement of equipment. PowerGlide addresses this need through an opensource wheelchair conversion system. The system transforms standard manual wheelchairs into powered mobility devices using multi-modal control interfaces. Three control modalities are implemented via a React Native mobile application: virtual joystick control, facial gesture recognition, and voice command processing. All control inputs are transmitted to Vedder Electronic Speed Controller (VESC) motor controllers via Bluetooth Low Energy communication. Performance testing demonstrates differential response characteristics across control modalities. The complete PowerGlide system proved to be cost effective in comparison to similar products on the market while also offering modular scalability. Users can customize motor specifications and battery capacity based on individual performance requirements and budget constraints. Opensource architecture enables local maintenance and repair using standardized components, reducing long-term ownership costs and improving accessibility for underserved communities.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Skin Cancer Type Detection via CNN and SVM
authors: Prerna Take Rasika Petkar, Apeksha Sakhare, Anuradha Joshi, Vijaya Kamble
abstract: This paper investigates the application of Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for classifying and detecting skin cancers from dermoscopic images. SVM is applied for its effectiveness in binary type the use of handcrafted capabilities, while CNN leverages its superior capability in automatic characteristic extraction and hierarchical learning. This study contributes to the development of reliable and efficient automatic skin cancers detection systems, supporting dermatologists in early analysis and lowering mortality fees.

title: Machine Learning Optimization for Reducing Financial Bottlenecks in Global Logistics Networks
authors: Bala Murugan D, Harihara Shanmugam A R, M. Prabhakar Christopher David, P.R.Ramakrishnan, Sankar Singh.K, S. Balamuralitharan
abstract: The world logistic chains are very crucial in global trade and supply chains, but they are at times overwhelmed with very huge financial shackles that occur because of lack of effectiveness in the routing, inventory planning, and forecasting. The transformative machine learning solution that can help to solve this issue is the possibility to perform predictive analytics, real-time decision-making, and resource dynamics optimization. The proposed study proposes an intelligent optimization framework that utilizes both learning models that have supervision and those that are not with the use of which high-cost zones will be identified, as well as mismatched demand-supply situations and effective ways to achieve them will be recommended at the low costs. The way it works is that through the techniques such as reinforcement learning, deep neural networks and clustering algorithms, the system will learn itself per se and change settings based on the evolvement of trade patterns, geopolitical restrictions, and market shifts. It also unifies the real-time data feeds of IoT-connected nodes of logistics, to enhance better modelling accuracy and responsiveness. The use of these methodologies incurs major savings to the system in terms of operation cost, enhanced use of assets and a general increase of the efficiency of the logistics on a global basis. Simulations and comparative studies yielded significant results in saving costs and performance in delivering results relative to the traditional logistics optimization approaches. Compared to other algorithms, the proposed system achieved a maximum efficiency of 89.1% reduction in cost and rate of anomaly response of 93%.

title: Integration of Zinc-Air Batteries with PEM Fuel Cell-Lithium-Ion Battery Based Hybrid Energy System for Sustainable Rail Transport in Himachal Pradesh, India
authors: Reshav Sharma, Upasana Sarma, Ram Niwash Mahia
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper proposes the use of a zinc-air battery (ZaB), which is a type of metal-air battery, in integration with a proton exchange membrane fuel cell-lithium ion battery-based hybrid energy system (PEMFC-LiB-HES) to power the intercity passenger trains (ICPT) in the hilly provinces of Himachal Pradesh, India, aiming to replace the currently operational ZDM4A type diesel locomotives in the region. The objective behind this is to achieve the National target of net zero carbon emissions by 2070. A rule-based energy management strategy (EMS) is developed to regulate the power distribution in the proposed PEMFC-LiB-ZaB-HES to meet the locomotive power demand while simultaneously satisfying the operating conditions of the energy sources. To validate the efficacy of the proposed HES, a performance comparison between the HES1, i.e., PEMFC-LiBZaB, and an existing HES2, i.e., PEMFC-LiB, is carried out using the real-time data of the ICPT of Himachal Pradesh. The simulation results indicate that HES1 outperforms HES2, with higher efficiency, reduced fuel consumption, and better state-ofcharge (SOC) management of the batteries.

title: Linear Prediction Networks for Residual based Replay Speech Detection
authors: Suresh Veesa, Badugu Vamsi Krishna, Madhusudan Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The linear prediction residual(LPR) component of speech signal plays a crucial role in detecting replay attacks. Replay is the simplest method fraudsters use to deceive automatic speaker verification systems into accepting a fake speaker. The LPR signal conveys information about the excitation source, making it valuable for differentiating between spoofed and authentic speech samples. This work introduces a deep learning classifier called Linear Prediction Network (LPNet), which uses deep residual layers and takes LPR features as input. We explore various source features to evaluate the usefulness of LPR information in replay detection. The source features employed in this study include residual constant Q-cepstral coefficients(RCQCC), Residual mel-frequency cepstral coefficients(RMFCC), and residual phase constant Q cepstral coefficients(RPCQCC). These features serve as the front end for proposed models. Replay speech detection experiments were conducted using standard ASV spoof 2017 version2.0 database. With the LPNet classifier, the source features have provided $14.71 \%, 21.03 \%$, and 14.84% equal error rates (EERs), respectively. The score-level combinations of all three source features along with the popular CQCC feature achieved an 8.62% EER. The proposed combination outshines state-of-the-art replay detection techniques, thereby motivating readers to further explore in this direction.

title: A Self-improving Ensemble Learning Framework for Human Non-Speech Vocalization Classification
authors: Yonghai Wang, Gengshen Wu, Nana Shan
abstract: Human non-speech vocalization recognition and classification play a crucial role in emotional and health analysis, but they face significant challenges owing to data scarcity and noisy labels. Although ignoring noisy labels can improve model performance, it also reduces dataset size. To maximize utilization of all available audio data, we propose a self-improving, model-agnostic method based on an ensemble teacher-student framework. This approach leverages semi-supervised ensemble learning techniques to effectively guide student models in learning more features, while utilizing enhanced pseudo-labels derived from ensemble teacher models to significantly reduce the adverse effects of label noise and substantially enhance model performance. Additionally, integrating this method with data augmentation, weight averaging, transfer learning, and other complementary training strategies can further boost accuracy and overall effectiveness. Extensive experimental results on the VocalSound and other datasets confirm that the proposed method not only effectively mitigates label noise in audio datasets—leading to noticeable improvements in accuracy and stability—but also ensures strong generalization across various model architectures. The datasets and codes are available at https://github.com/helensnn/ELVS.

title: A Compact Electronically Reconfigurable Antenna with Polarization Agility and Beam-switching
authors: Jie Wu, Zhiyang Wang, Guoda Xie, Zhixiang Huang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter introduces a compact electronically tunable antenna capable of reconfiguring its polarization and beam direction. The designed antenna consists, from top to bottom, of a Circular Reconfigurable Metallic Wire (CRMW) layer, a parasitic patch layer, and a driven antenna multilayer board. By programming the FPGA to control the PIN diodes on the CRMW, the length distribution of the metallic segments can be changed, enabling beam reconfiguration. Additionally, the PIN diodes on the DC feeding network (DFN) allow for rapid switching among six polarization states. The effective overlapping operating frequency range for all beam states is 3.5 to 3.8 GHz. The radiation beam varies in two dimensions: with an azimuth range from 0 to 360° and an elevation range from -30° to +30°. The experimental results show excellent agreement with simulations for 18 different beam states. Furthermore, the antenna achieves an average peak gain of 7.1 dBi, with a total efficiency exceeding 55.9% across all reconfigurable states. The antenna has potential applications in multifunctional integrated systems for drone communications and anti-jamming systems.

title: GP-BO-Driven Ensemble Learning for High-Resolution Surface Soil Moisture Retrieval
authors: Jianhui Chen, Zuo Wang, Ping Wei, Chang Huang, Lisheng Song, Yuanhong You, Shuoqi Zhang, Zhijie Dong
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Surface soil moisture (SSM) plays a crucial role in hydrological processes, ecosystem dynamics, and agricultural management. Currently, high spatial resolution SSM estimation primarily relies on machine learning methods. However, in heterogeneous environments, the challenges associated with hyperparameter optimization, computational efficiency and uncertainty control compromise the robustness of these methods. To address this issue, this study introduces and evaluates an integrated strategy that combines Gaussian Process Bayesian Optimization (GP-BO) with machine learning for high-resolution SSM retrieval. The results demonstrate that the combined method significantly outperforms conventional optimization methods evaluated by the test sets from Heihe River Basin, Naqu, and Shandian River basins. Notably, the integration of GP-BO with XGBoost turned out to be the optimal combination, improving R² by 0.01–0.19 and reducing ubRMSE by 0.02–1.71 percentage points relative to conventional optimizers, while requiring the least training time for ensemble models. Furthermore, vegetation-specific GP-BO-tuned XGBoost models achieve varying degrees of accuracy improvement and reduced uncertainty across various vegetation, particularly in barren and grassland regions. These findings highlight the effectiveness of GP-BO hyperparameter optimization algorithm in reducing the uncertainties of SSM estimation in heterogeneous environments.

title: Siamese Feature Decoupling and Adaptive Prototype Alignment for Clothes Changed Person Re-identification_supp1-3638256.pdf
authors: Shanshan Zhang
abstract: The core to tackle clothes changed person re-identification is to extract clothes-irrelevant features. Previous methods typically decoupled the entire image features into clothes-relevant and ID-relevant ones via an auxiliary task of clothes classification, yet in this way, it is not guaranteed that the ID-relevant features fully get rid of clothes-relevant information, as the entire image feature also includes other information, such as posture. To enhance the purity of ID-relevant features, this letter proposes a simple yet effective siamese feature decoupling and adaptive prototype alignment framework (Decoupling and Alignment, D&A), which involves a reference branch and an alignment branch. Specifically, the reference branch first uses human parsing to remove clothes information at the image level to ensure that the ID prototype subsequently extracted by the image encoder is purely ID-relevant without clothes; the alignment branch excludes clothes information from the ID-relevant features by dual-token decoupling, and then aligns the ID-relevant features with the ID prototypes in the reference branch to enhance the purity of the identity information obtained after decoupling. Furthermore, we introduce an adaptive update strategy to update the ID prototypes to prevent the ID prototypes and the decoupled features from shifting in feature space. Extensive experiments on widely used benchmarks (PRCC, LTCC, and VC-Clothes) validate the effectiveness of our method, which achieves new state-of-the-art results across most metrics.

title: Real-time Image-based High Accuracy Tooth Measurement for Precision Orthodontics_supp1-3638645.mp4
authors: Zeyang Xia
abstract: Precision orthodontics relies heavily on timely precision measurement during an orthodontic treatment. However, the measurement done by orthodontists currently (i.e., calipers) cannot provide a fast and precise measurement. The study introduces a novel real-time automatic image-based system for precision tooth measurement, characterized by its high accuracy and efficiency. The video input of the dentures from a head-mounted camera was taken one frame at a time. Since 70% of orthodontal treatment is done using fixed brackets, we used an object detection algorithm to locate the position of the brackets within the frame. A novel multi-object tracking algorithm was developed to track and update the positions based on the long short-time memory information collected on the previous frames. A measurement module then measures and updates the distance between each bracket and saves it making sure the measurements are available even when the bracket is not visible in the current frame. The real-time tracking and measurement improved the efficiency and accuracy of tooth measurement. In clinical cases, the teeth were recognized with 97% accuracy and tracked without any loss within a video input of 60 FPS. This measurement achieves a resolution on the order of 0.01 mm, with a data error less than 50 μm. This real-time automatic tooth measurement proved to be efficient and easy to use compared to existing methods while improving accuracy. It can be used in aiding precision orthodontics and in the process of automating dental treatments.

title: A Robust Odor Mixture Quantification Method Based on Active Sensing Using Both QCM Frequency Shifts and Resistance Changes of Multiple Harmonics_supp1-3622147.pdf
authors: Takamichi Nakamoto
abstract: This work improves a previously proposed quantification framework by expanding its applicability to quaternary odor mixtures and optimizing the active-sensing process. The approach employs four quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) sensors, where both frequency shifts and resistance changes at multiple odd harmonics—measured by vector network analyzers (VNWA)—serve as virtual sensors to enhance selectivity. A selection strategy based on the condition number was introduced to identify informative harmonic responses. Experiments validated that the proposed method reduced the average root-mean-square error (RMSE) by 47.44%, with a statistically significant improvement (p = 0.0070) compared with the only fundamental responses. Among three feedback control algorithms, finite horizon linear–quadratic regulator (LQR) with time-varying gains achieved the best active-sensing performance. The experimental evaluations further confirmed short-term and long-term repeatabilities, as well as the capability to handle unstable sensor responses. Overall, the proposed method enables accurate and robust quantification of quaternary odor mixtures across a wide recipe range, demonstrating its potential as an easy-to-use solution for future odor recording systems.

title: Attention-Driven Interference Alignment for Multi-User Semantic Communications
authors: Ki-Ho Lee, Hyun-Ho Choi, Jung-Ryun Lee
abstract: This paper presents an attention-driven interference alignment (IA) scheme for multi-user semantic communications that operates in the semantic embedding domain, unlike conventional IA in the baseband domain. To realize this, user-specific masking and attention-driven decoding are employed over a shared embedding space, which is mathematically modeled to characterize attention-based IA in the embedding domain and to enable implicit user separation without explicit orthogonalization. Built on a conventional cross-entropy (CE) loss, the proposed orthogonalization regularization further reinforces interference alignment by aligning user-specific semantic subspaces and suppressing inter-user interference. Experiments under Rayleigh fading channels show that the proposed approach outperforms both a resource-partitioned baseline with separate embeddings and a CE-only loss model without orthogonalization regularization, showing the effectiveness of an attention-driven IA solution for multi-user semantic communication.

title: Adaptive Neural Network Iterative Learning PI Control of Fractional-Order Nonlinear Systems Using Generalized Barrier Lyapunov Function
authors: Xingyue Yang, Xiulan Zhang, Jinde Cao, Heng Liu
abstract: Note that the available barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) design considers that the precondition of the specified function must be a smooth convex function, which is relatively harsh for most models. In this article, built on proportional–integral (PI) theory, an adaptive neural network (ANN) PI iterative learning tracking control method for fractional-order nonlinear systems (FONSs) with full-state constraints is presented. A new type of BLF is built that only requires finding a derivative of this function needs to be monotonic under the fractional Lyapunov direct method. To meet the needs of reducing computational complexity and data volume, the designed backstepping controller based on PI control consists of a series of constant gains and dynamic variables with basic linkage relationships. Moreover, it also incorporates iterative learning algorithm that can achieve continuous or discontinuous self-learning and updating. The results indicate that all closed-loop signals of FONSs are semi-globally ultimately uniformly bounded and the constraint is not violated. Theoretical analysis and numerical simulation have verified the rationality of this study.

title: Artificially Accelerated Atmospheric Neutron-Induced Single-Event Burnout in Thyristors and Failure Rate Prediction Model
authors: Qiang Li, Mingbin Peng, Jiahe Liang, Jialin Song, Chunqiang Su, Yang Meng, Weidong Ding, Yongsheng Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: In this study, single-event burnout failure tests on high-voltage direct current thyristors are performed under varying bias voltages using artificial neutron irradiation. This study conducted accelerated irradiation experiments on thyristors using non-destructive SEB methodology. Substantial statistical samples confirm that the time intervals of non-destructive SEB events follow a Weibull distribution with shape parameters close to 1, indicating the protective SEB is still primarily driven by random neutron collision events. Additionally, the degradation of thyristor material was found to have no significant influence on the failure-rate-voltage relationship. These findings collectively validate the feasibility of substituting non-destructive SEB testing for destructive methods. Furthermore, the mathematical failure-rate-voltage model was validated through two independent high-altitude experiments. To the best of our knowledge, this represents the first mutual validation between accelerated testing and authentic high-altitude conditions. The findings of this study provide a valuable reference for the lifespan prediction of thyristors and the construction of high-voltage direct current converter stations in high-altitude environments.

title: Development of an Ultra-Fast Hybrid Circuit Breaker with a Novel Arc-Enhanced Lightweight Mechanical Switch for Low-Voltage DC Applications
authors: Tianpei Shan, Yifei Wu, Yi Wu, Heming Zhu, Yu Xiao, Mingzhe Rong
abstract: The hybrid DC circuit breaker (HCB) is crucial for clearing faults and ensuring a reliable power supply in DC grids. However, the fault current can rise rapidly in the low-voltage DC systems, and existing traditional HCB solutions cannot meet the demands of speed and size due to the structure design of the fast mechanical switch and additional assisted commutation devices. In this letter, a novel arc-enhanced lightweight ultra-fast mechanical switch is proposed for low-voltage HCBs. Compared to traditional fast mechanical switches designed for HCBs, the proposed ultrafast mechanical switch offers an extremely fast inherent opening time and current interruption time by eliminating the unnecessary arc extinguishing chamber and applying an innovative dual-stage motion design. Meanwhile, the structure of double-point contact enhances the arc voltage, enabling faster current commutation to the power electronic switch without any bulky auxiliary device. After parameter design and optimization, a compact 750 V HCB prototype based on the novel ultra-fast mechanical switch is built to verify the feasibility. The prototype has an inherent opening time of 70 μs and can interrupt a 26 kA current within 400 μs.

title: AMuSeD: An Attentive Deep Neural Network for Multimodal Sarcasm Detection Incorporating Bi-modal Data Augmentation
authors: Xiyuan Gao, Shubhi Bansal, Kushaan Gowda, Zhu Li, Shekhar Nayak, Nagendra Kumar, Matt Coler
abstract: Detecting sarcasm effectively requires a nuanced understanding of context, including vocal tones and facial expressions. The progression towards multimodal computational methods in sarcasm detection, however, faces challenges due to the scarcity of data. To address this, we present AMuSeD (Attentive deep neural network for MUltimodal Sarcasm dEtection incorporating bi-modal Data augmentation). This approach utilizes the Multimodal Sarcasm Detection Dataset (MUStARD) and introduces a two-phase bimodal data augmentation strategy. The first phase involves generating varied text samples through Back-Translation from several secondary languages. The second phase involves the refinement of a FastSpeech2-based speech synthesis system, tailored specifically for sarcasm to retain sarcastic intonations. Alongside a cloud-based Text-to-Speech (TTS) service, this Fine-tuned FastSpeech2 system produces corresponding audio for the text augmentations. We also evaluate various attention mechanisms for selectively enhancing sarcasm-relevant features, finding self-attention to be the most efficient. Our experiments reveal that the proposed approach achieves a significant F1-score of 81.0% in text-audio modalities, surpassing even models that use three modalities from the MUStARD dataset.

title: An Improved Multi-output Nine-Level Buck PFC Rectifier
authors: Ankush Koli, Sandeep N, Harpal Tiwari
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Research into multipurpose power converters has enormous potential in power electronics. This research proposes an improved nine-level buck power factor correction (PFC) rectifier to obtain a high power quality and enhanced efficiency for multiple output ports. The proposed topology efficiently generates nine-level voltages at a significant switching frequency. A multicarrier pulse width modulation control strategy is employed to facilitate the simultaneous feeding of multiple equal or unequal DC loads. Moreover, the design simplifies capacitor voltage balancing and ensures rectifier stability during dynamic operating situations. The proposed rectifier is designed with fewer components and examined under steady-state and transient conditions using MATLAB Simulink. The simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed rectifier, yielding an efficiency of 97.24% and a THD of 2.01% at 1 kW power.

title: Design of a Flyback Converter for Biomedical Application with USB Type-C PD Interface
authors: Vrundesh Shirish Pawde, Suman Saurav, Ritesh Kumar Keshri, Pratik Nachankar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper explores a novel application of USB-PD chargers in biomedical systems, specifically focusing on the design and implementation of a 60W charger with a USB Type-C interface and a flyback converter topology. The proposed system features a universal power supply input, allowing it to operate efficiently across a wide range of input voltages. It is designed to dynamically adjust its output voltage, enabling it to power an ECG monitor that operates in multiple modes with varying power requirements. The ECG monitor communicates its power requirements to the charger using the USB-PD 3.0 protocol, ensuring precise power delivery and efficient operation. A hardware prototype of the proposed charger rated for 60W was developed and tested to validate its performance. Experimental results confirm that the system achieves high efficiency, maintains voltage regulation, and effectively meets the operational demands of biomedical applications.

title: Research on Financial Risk Prediction Algorithm Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yixin Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In view of the limitations of traditional financial risk prediction models in dynamic and complex risk scenarios, this study proposes a new reinforcement learning framework that integrates multi-level collaborative mechanisms and privacy protection. This framework, through a dynamic weight allocation strategy, coordinates the decision-making priorities of credit risk, market risk and liquidity risk in real time to solve the problem of strategy conflicts in a multi-risk coupling environment. Combined with the federated learning method, cross-institutional knowledge sharing is achieved on the premise of ensuring data privacy, and the generalization ability of the model for extreme risk events is enhanced. Meanwhile, an interpretability enhancement module is designed to generate transparent decision-making rules that comply with financial regulatory requirements.

title: Impact Analysis of Network Reconfiguration on Aggregated Flexibility at the TSO-DSO Interface
authors: Sonam Mittal, B.V. Suryakiran, Ashu Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The rapid integration of distributed energy resources (DERs) within modern distribution networks has markedly enhanced system flexibility, offering significant potential for supporting ancillary grid services. In response, this paper introduces an optimization framework formulated as a Mixed-Integer Quadratic Programming (MIQP) model to compute a multi-period flexibility profile at the TSO-DSO interface. The MIQP formulation rigorously incorporates network constraints, operational limits, the dynamic interactions among DERs and tie switches. Additionally, this work investigates network reconfiguration strategies aimed at further optimizing the aggregated flexibility and improving voltage profiles of the distribution system. The efficacy of the proposed methodology is demonstrated through simulations on a modified IEEE 33-bus network, highlighting its practical applicability and potential for enhancing grid performance.

title: The performance and improvement of one-stage networks in intelligent driving environment
authors: Jinhao Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In the field of intelligent driving, vehicles must first perceive their surrounding environment to facilitate subsequent decision-making. Therefore, object detection for nearby entities (e.g., front-view vehicle images) becomes critically important. However, the stability and accuracy of current mainstream object detection algorithms still require improvement. To address this issue, this study deploys two industry-standard models in driving scenarios: the one-stage network YOLOv8 and the lightweight model YOLOv5, aiming to evaluate their robustness and generalization capabilities under varying instance quantity distributions. Furthermore, a Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) is integrated into YOLOv8m to enhance detection accuracy and recall rates in complex environments. Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8 outperforms YOLOv5 with varying degrees of improvement across different training instance quantities while exhibiting enhanced generalization capabilities. The BiFPN-enhanced YOLOv8m achieves approximately 13% higher accuracy than standard YOLOv8m, though it imposes stricter requirements on training sample quantity and distribution characteristics.

title: IoT-Based Smart Irrigation System for Optimized Water Usage in Agriculture
authors: Mani Prakash Yellaboina, Biswajit Bhowmik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Water scarcity and inefficient irrigation methods continue to be pressing challenges in modern agriculture, particularly in regions with highly variable climates. Traditional systems often irrigate based on fixed schedules, without accounting for real-time soil moisture or weather conditions, resulting in significant water wastage. This paper addresses this gap by developing a real-time, sensor-based smart irrigation system utilizing an ESP32 microcontroller integrated with ambient sensors, including soil moisture, temperature, humidity, and rainfall detectors. Based on field data, a rule-based decision model controls a water pump via a relay and concurrently transmits the sensor readings to the ThingSpeak cloud platform for monitoring and visualization. Experimental evaluations under varied simulated environmental conditions demonstrate that the system effectively conserves water by avoiding irrigation during rainfall or when the soil moisture is adequate. The proposed approach offers a low-cost, scalable, and minimally supervised solution for sustainable agriculture in water-stressed regions.

title: Comparison of Machine Learning and Deep Learning Techniques for Identifying Signals of Interest for Electronic Warfare
authors: Priyanshu Niranjan, Prateek Pande, M. Thenmozhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) techniques to enhance the categorization within electronic support measures (ESM) is a crucial component of modern electronic warfare (EW). ESM focuses on the passive interception, identification, and analysis of electromagnetic signals. By leveraging machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) algorithms, this study aims to improve the identification of signals of interest (SOI) captured by the ESM systems. The application of AI in signal processing is examined, with a review of traditional algorithms like support vector machines (SVMs) and elliptic Envelopes, alongside deep learning models including autoencoders and convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Advancements in EW significantly enhance ESM systems. The paper highlights the effectiveness of these algorithms in finding SOI from the clutter data.

title: Research on application of reinforcement learning in load dispatch optimization for smart grid
authors: Endong Xu, Ziqing Li, Wenyun Zhou, Bo Jiang, Zhongyuan Pang, Fan Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes a smart load dispatch optimization method based on reinforcement learning. First, a mathematical model of the dynamic changes of the power grid environment and load is established, the state space, action space and multi-objective reward mechanism are constructed, and an adaptive Actor-Critic network structure is designed. Subsequently, the model is trained and verified on an actual smart grid load monitoring dataset to evaluate the performance of the model in load balancing, system cost control and voltage deviation suppression. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms the traditional static optimization strategy in multiple evaluation indicators and has higher convergence speed and scheduling accuracy. Ablation experimental analysis further reveals the specific contribution of each component of the reward function to the system performance. Studies have shown that reinforcement learning technology has broad application prospects in the field of smart grid load optimization and can provide effective support for intelligent power system scheduling.

title: Gate Oxide Reliability Enhancement of 4H-SiC Trench MOSFETs Using Charge Sheet Super Junction
authors: Mohith Sai Bathina, Rachita Mohapatra, Kumar Prasannajit Pradhan, Akshay K
abstract: This paper proposes a novel 4H-SiC trench MOS-FET with a charge sheet superjunction based drift layer as a solution to mitigate the premature breakdown of gate oxide in conventional trench MOSFETs. Well calibrated TCAD simulations predict up to 6.7 times higher oxide breakdown voltage V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">BR,ox</inf> for the proposed structure over a conventional trench MOSFET thereby significantly enhancing the device reliability; this can be achieved at the expense of 1.6 times higher specific on-resistance, R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ONSP</inf>. This numerical study should provide strong motivation for the fabrication of the proposed device for enabling next generation power electronic applications.

title: Optimizing Cell Insert Structure for Enhanced Thermal Management in Air-Cooled Battery Packs
authors: Ajay Vishwakarma, Uttam Rana
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study employs Taguchi-Grey Relational Analysis to optimize the structural design of cell inserts in air-cooled cylindrical battery systems, aiming to enhance thermal management by minimizing maximum temperature (T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf>) and temperature gradient (ΔT). Through Design of Experiment (DOE)-driven ANSYS Fluent simulations, multi-objective optimization identified an optimal configuration with a 30° angle of shift, 28 mm row spacing, and asymmetric column spacing (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1-2</inf> = 26 mm, C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2-3</inf> = 24 mm), achieving T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> = 37.87 °C and ΔT = 3.35°C. ANOVA revealed the angle of shift as the dominant parameter, contributing 71.92% to T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> and 76.34% to ΔT variance. While C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2-3</inf> spacing exhibited a secondary influence (8.99% on ΔT), the synergy between angular adjustments and asymmetric spacing improved coolant distribution, mitigating thermal hotspots. These findings underscore the critical role of geometric parameter synergy in advancing thermal homogeneity, offering actionable insights for efficient battery thermal management system design.

title: Air Quality Index Forecasting Using Variable Weighted Ensembled Model with Gradient COA
authors: Jayanth Chowdam, Chinmaya Ranjan Padhan, Sibarama Panigrahi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Air quality is a critical concern in urban areas because of its negative implications on public health, biodiversity, and economic growth. This research involves advanced forecasting techniques for major Indian cities such as Mumbai and Chennai. Deep learning (DL) and machine learning (ML) models such as linear regression, bidirectional gated recurrent unit (BiGRU), and multi-layer perceptron (MLP) are used to predict the air quality index (AQI). A Gradient Crayfish Optimization Algorithm (GCOA) is introduced to optimize the performance of the individual models. This study proposed a variable-weighted ensemble model with Gradient COA to forecast the AQI of different cities. Additionally, five state-of-the-art swarm and evolutionary algorithms are studied to determine the ensemble forecasts. The individual forecasts of individual models are optimized using the GCOA model by determining the best weights for each model. Different accuracy matrices are considered to determine the accuracy of the models. The simulation results suggest that the proposed variable-weighted ensembled model with GCOA provides a statistically better deterministic forecast than other individual models and ensemble models for Mumbai and Chennai AQI time series data, with RMSE values of 8.6269 and 20.6198, respectively.

title: Implementation of PV Based Z Source Inverter for Residential Applications
authors: Nisha Gnanam, Raji Krishna
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive design framework for a three-phase impedance source inverter (ZSI) tailored for solar photovoltaic (PV) applications. Unlike conventional inverters, which face limitations such as restricted voltage boost capabilities and inefficiencies in handling variable DC inputs, the ZSI offers a robust solution by integrating an impedance network between the DC supply and the inverter's six-switch configuration. This unique topology enables the ZSI to overcome the drawbacks of traditional inverters, particularly in applications requiring voltage enhancement. The impedance network serves as an intermediate stage, allowing the inverter to efficiently boost the DC input voltage, making it highly suitable for renewable energy systems like solar PV. ZSI’s ability to handle wide variations in input voltage and its enhanced reliability under fluctuating conditions make it an attractive choice for integrating unconventional energy sources into the grid. This study focuses on the design and operational principles of the ZSI, emphasizing its advantages in solar PV systems, where maintaining stable and efficient power conversion is critical. The key contributions of this work are: (i) the formulation of a detailed design methodology for a three-phase ZSI specifically adapted for solar PV integration, (ii) analysis of the inverter's performance under variable irradiation conditions to ensure stability and efficiency, and (iii) validation of the proposed design through simulation results demonstrating improved voltage boosting capability and reliability over traditional inverter systems. These findings establish ZSI as a versatile and efficient solution for modern renewable energy applications.

title: Vehicle Behavior Recognition and Trajectory Prediction Based on Spatiotemporal Feature Fusion
authors: Caihua Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The interactive relationship between vehicles and their surrounding environment is crucial for the decision-making and planning of autonomous vehicles. Existing methods for vehicle behavior recognition suffer from issues such as inadequate modeling of vehicle-road relationships and insufficient consideration of the contextual influence among traffic participants, resulting in generally low recognition accuracy. To address this, this paper proposes an integrated vehicle behavior recognition and trajectory prediction model that synthesizes vehicle-road information interaction and a global social pool for vehicles. The model, composed of CNN, GRU, and Attention mechanisms, enables rapid and accurate prediction of vehicle behavior probabilities and corresponding trajectory distributions for the next 5 seconds. Experimental results demonstrate that the model achieves a prediction accuracy as high as 98% in our experiments.

title: A Hybrid Classical-Quantum Deep Learning Framework for MRI-Guided Alzheimer’s Disease Classification, Comparative Analysis & Explainable AI for Medical Interpretation
authors: Sumitro Barua, Dipon Deb Dipu, Tanjila Broti
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Over the past decade, exceptional progress has been made in deep learning and its applications to medical imaging including image analysis, disease classification, medical image segmentation, and a variety of other tasks. Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive cognitive disorder and the most common cause of dementia in the world. In this research, we present a lightweight hybrid classical-quantum framework leveraging quantum machine learning (QML) using the pennylane library. Consisting of classical convolutional neural network (CNN) and quantum circuits as quantum nodes wrapped in a torch layer of pytorch, the framework has a total of eight layers including the quantum layer, for the classification of Alzheimer’s disease stages from brain MRI images. Using this framework, the 4 -class Alzheimer’s MRI dataset is assessed. This dataset contains 6400 MRI images across four classes of disease stages, available in the Kaggle. The dataset has gone through the Pre-processing stage of augmentation to scale and balance the classes. The proposed hybrid framework achieves an accuracy of 96.26 % in classifying 4 stages of Alzheimer’s Disease, outperforming the classical deep learning models while utilizing substantially fewer parameters. The superior performance of the hybrid framework is compared with the performance of four other classical models: 1. VGG 2. Densenet 3. Enet and 4. Resnet. Grad-CAM (Explainable AI) is employed to assess the proposed framework’s focus on relevant brain regions and to validate its accuracy through consultation with a medical professional. By ensuring alignment between the framework’s attention and clinical expertise, this research enhances the potential for assisting medical professionals in accurately interpreting neurodegenerative disease states and thereby advancing the development of clinically applicable diagnostic tools. It also demonstrates the feasibility of adopting quantum machine learning in medical image analysis and medical AI.

title: Visual inertial trajectory alignment method based on ICP
authors: Yutie Wang, Junyang Zhao, Shenhua Lv, Huixin Zhu, Zeyuan Chu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: To address the challenges of low alignment accuracy and slow computational efficiency in the trajectory alignment of visual-inertial fusion data, a trajectory alignment method based on the Iterative Closest Point (ICP) algorithm is proposed. This method incorporates the multiple iteration characteristic of ICP into trajectory alignment, enhancing alignment accuracy by minimizing the spatial position error between corresponding points. Initially, the mathematical mechanism underlying the ambiguity problem inherent in current trajectory alignment methods is analyzed, and the mathematical derivation for ICPbased trajectory alignment is presented. Subsequently, an implementation approach for ICP-based trajectory alignment is introduced to mitigate the strong dependence on initial trajectory and the high computational complexity associated with the Umeyama algorithm. Experimental results on the EuroC dataset demonstrate that the estimated trajectory achieves high coincidence with the ground truth trajectory following ICP-based alignment.

title: Smith Predictor-Driven PID Controller Optimization for Liquid Level Control
authors: S. Rajasekaran, G.Md. Abdul Kalam, B. Dinesh Sai Naidu, N. Bhavana
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Safety and operational performance are directly impacted by efficient fluid level control in industrial tanks. In order to overcome inherent process delays, this study examines how to improve liquid level regulation in linear tank systems by fusing conventional PID control with a Smith Predictor framework. We started by using the Ziegler-Nichols and Cohen-Coon approaches to determine the ideal PID parameters. We then used extensive MATLAB simulations and experimental validation to assess performance. According to our research, the Smith Predictor mechanism significantly reduces key performance indicators such as overshoot percentage, settling time, and error indices (more especially, IAE and ISE values). When compared to traditional methods, this combination provides better system responsiveness and stability. The outcomes demonstrate how well Smith Predictor mitigates the effects of time delays, making it a useful addition to PID control systems for industrial liquid level applications for management.

title: Towards Reliable Real-Time Modelling of PV Cells: A Computational Perspective for Safe Inverter Control
authors: Martin Ćalasan, Snežana Vujošević, Mihailo Micev, Milutin Petronijević, Senad Huseinbegović
abstract: Reliable and computationally efficient modeling of photovoltaic (PV) cells is essential for real-time control of power electronic systems, especially in safety-critical applications such as inverter control in smart grids and defense-related infrastructures. This paper investigates the accuracy, speed, and robustness of several PV cell models — including the Single Diode Model (SDM), Double Diode Model (DDM), and Triple Diode Model (TDM) — using closed-form and semi-analytical parameter estimation techniques based on the Lambert W function. The performance of each model is evaluated with respect to estimation time, curve-fitting accuracy, and its impact on Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) behavior. The results demonstrate that, while more complex models offer higher fidelity, the computational burden may compromise real-time applicability.

title: Systematic Analysis of ML Techniques for Identifying DDoS Attacks in SDN Environments
authors: Ravi Harshitha, Nikitha Naralasetti, Pavan Kumar Kolipakula, Sailesh Guntamukkala, Syed Mohd Faisal
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The recent years have witnessed the advancement of smart security mechanisms significantly improving the strength of detection and response to cyber attacks in different network environments, particularly in software-defined networking (SDN). Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks continue to pose a serious threat to such programmable networks. The present paper is a systematic review of recent trends of utilization of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) methods in detection of DDoS attacks in SDN-based systems. Extensive literature search was undertaken, and papers between the years 2018 and November 2022 were taken into consideration. Academic journals and online archives like IEEE, ACM, Springer, and Google Scholar were searched for relevant research studies. The results are compiled into five broad categories: (i) classification of methods of DDoS detection by ML and DL; (ii) comparison of algorithms based on methodology, strength, and limitations; (iii) identification of benchmark datasets and attacks employed; (iv) comparison of means of data preprocessing, parameterization, test setup, and assessment measures; and ($\mathbf{v}$) identification of limitations of the existing work and areas of scope for innovation. The review also briefly comments on the real-world applicability of these models, their high-traffic network scalability, and the necessity for real-time detection capability. The paper aims to guide future work towards more efficient, adaptive, and scalable mechanisms of DDoS detection in SDN, and stimulate towards hybrid framework development as well as the use of newer datasets towards improved generalizability and strength.

title: Hybrid Global Peak Power Tracking (HGPPT) for PV Systems based on Particle Swarm Optimization & Support Vector Machines (PSOSVM)
authors: Abhishake Jain, Sumit Saini, Muralidhar Nayak Bhukya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Environmental conditions always effect the Photovoltaic Power Generation (PPG). Shading on solar panel is a major issue and also creates multiple peaks in the P-V characteristics. Therefore, metaheuristics algorithm based controllers are introduced to track the Global Peak Power (GPP) among the multiple peaks. Among the metaheuristics algorithms Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is widely recommended, but the global best solutions depends on number of particles, inertia weight, cognitive and social agents. Proportionally, it is well know that the irradiance, temperature and shading percentage on the solar panels changes simultaneously as well as dynamically. Therefore, there is a necessity to tune the parameters of PSO as per the operating conditions. Hence, this paper presents a novel Hybrid GPP Tracking (HGPPT) algorithm based on PSO and Support Vector Machines (PSOSVM). Simulation results benchmark the superiority of the proposed HGPPT scheme over PSO.

title: Revolutionizing Distributed Generation Allocation in Radial Networks via Pioneering PSO Strategies
authors: Bibhu Prasad Nanda, Debani Prasad Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The conventional radial distribution network is complicated and hard to control the electricity flow. However, the system must be controlled so that the quality of electricity remains within the required limit. This paper presents a way to devise and implement a distributed generation (DG) optimization way for reducing power distribution losses. The main objective of the algorithm lies with the finest size and position of the DG units within the network for dropping power losses while confirming voltage stability. Thus, the proposed algorithm actually uses the particle swarm optimization (PSO) method to govern its precise size and location. It also takes other constraints into account such as branch currents, voltage stability limits, and power balancing formulae. The PSO algorithm changes particle positions and velocities interactively in order to determine optimum search space values to reach the best solution. It again discusses data pre-treatment, network modeling, implementation of the PSO algorithm, and results analysis. Most importantly, it utilizes the MATLAB language to develop and implement algorithms. The simulations show that the suggested strategy can efficiently minimize power losses while improving voltage profiles when compared with the base case situation in the absence of DG integration. This work advances optimization strategies for integrated DG distribution in power distribution systems, which could be of utmost importance in reality for power grid management and planning.

title: A Method for Urban 3D Reconstruction and Dynamic Target Localization via Multi-UAV Collaboration
authors: Li Zhu, Qiwu Wu, Tao Tong, Hui Li, Jinfeng Li, Hang Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: To meet the real-time perception requirements for global situational awareness and dynamic targets (e.g., pedestrians, vehicles) in complex scenarios such as urban large-scale events and transportation hubs, this paper proposes a method for 3D real-scene reconstruction and target localization based on multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) collaboration. First, multiple UAVs equipped with optical sensors are utilized to rapidly construct a 3D base map of the scene through technologies such as point cloud reconstruction, structure from motion (SfM), and multi-view stereo (MVS). Second, the YOLOv5 model is improved to enhance the detection accuracy of dynamic targets, and the DeepSort algorithm is integrated to achieve real-time multi-target tracking. Furthermore, based on the principle of multi-view geometry, the precise 3D coordinate estimation and projection visualization of targets in the reconstructed scene are realized by fusing camera poses and 3D point cloud information. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively reconstruct complex urban scenes and localize dynamic targets in real time, providing reliable support for situational awareness.

title: Toward Fault-Tolerant Decoder Circuit in Quantum-Dot Cellular Automata (QCA) Technology
authors: Mohammadhossein Heydari, Abdalhossein Rezai, Farbod Javaheri
abstract: Quantum-dot Cellular Automata technology is a promising emerging technology in replacing future digital circuit technologies. On the other hand, the decoder circuit is a vital building block in digital circuits such as data-correction, multiplexing, decoding data and addressing of RAM. In the making of such small devices, some parts may be faulty due to production difficulty; Thus, Fault-tolerance becomes an important matter in the design of such circuits. This paper proposes a Fault-tolerant design of a 2:4 decoder circuit in single-layer. This design consists of 103 QCA cells, 0.05 um<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of area, and uses 0.5 clock cycles delay. It has over 87.5% improvement compared to similar works. The proposed design has 5.29 nW of power dissipation.

title: Power user behavior analysis method based on multi-source heterogeneous data fusion
authors: Qiushi Xu, Qingyuan Dong, Jianping Xu, Shitong Wang, Liman Gao, Yan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This study aims to propose a multi-source heterogeneous data fusion and behavior analysis method for the power user side to cope with the problem of complex sources and diverse structures of user data. First, a unified representation system of power user electricity consumption records, environmental variables and user attribute data is systematically constructed, and a feature extraction module based on GRU and CNN is designed. The Transformer attention mechanism is used to fuse the information of each modality to generate a shared feature space to achieve accurate classification of user behavior. The experimental part selects real smart meter data in 2023 for verification. The fused model is superior to the single modal and traditional classification algorithm in key indicators such as F1 value and AUC. The ablation experiment further proves the core role of multi-source fusion in improving the model's expression ability and behavior recognition accuracy. The research results show that this method has good engineering adaptability and promotion prospects in smart grids, and can provide effective data support for power optimization, load forecasting and demand response strategies.

title: End-to-End 2D Floor Plan to 3D Conversion Framework
authors: Prachi Chhabra, Aparna Shrivastava, Ujwala Thakur, Sunil Kumar, Shivang Singh, Abhishek Naula
abstract: Converting 2D architectural floor plans into 3D models is a critical yet difficult operation that has traditionally relied on manual efforts with CAD tools. This research provides an automated approach to conversion that combines deep learning and image processing approaches to improve efficiency. We use YOLOv8 for object detection and the Hough Line Transform for structural feature extraction, which greatly improves accuracy and efficiency. This technique requires less user interaction, improves real-time processing, and produces precise 3D models. The experimental findings show good object detection accuracy (mAP 92%) and economical processing time (<1.5s). The suggested framework simplifies architectural design, real estate visualization, and AR/VR applications, making advanced 3D modelling more accessible and scalable.

title: Assessing the influence of busbar and contact resistance on lithium-ion battery pack
authors: Subham Khange, Ashwini Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Auxiliary components beyond the cells themselves, such as busbars and contact points, play a crucial role in determining the thermal behavior of lithium-ion battery packs and modules. In particular, heat generation and transfer through these components can significantly affect the overall pack temperature distribution and operational safety. This study presents a transient electrothermal modeling and simulation analysis of cylindrical lithium-ion battery modules, evaluating thermal behavior both with and without the inclusion of busbars and electrical contact resistance effects. Results indicate that neglecting these components leads to a substantial underestimation of temperature gradients, with differences of approximately 10°C at a 1C discharge rate and 20°C at a 2C discharge rate for a 15s15p battery pack configuration. Furthermore, the influence of busbar materials and geometric parameters was investigated, and optimized configurations were identified to minimize temperature disparities. The findings highlight the importance of incorporating auxiliary component heat generation in battery pack thermal management and design optimization for electric vehicle applications.

title: Cost Optimization of Renewable Energy Installation in a Four-Microgrid System Using GBOML
authors: Bimal Kumar Dora, Nidhi Haribhau Gaikwad, Pranjali Kulkarni, Tarun Gangadhar, Ruchita Sunil Waghmare, Sudip Halder, Arghya Mitra, Damien Ernst, Sunil Bhat
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The electrical power generation sector is undergoing a profound transformation, shifting from traditional large, centralized generators to a more decentralized model that integrates smaller, distributed generators directly into distribution networks. Initially designed as independent backup systems, these distributed generators are now being synchronized with the grid and increasingly utilized as primary electricity sources. This transition, driven by advancements in renewable and non-conventional energy technologies, is accelerating the development and widespread adoption of Microgrids, reshaping the future of power systems. Furthermore, interconnecting multiple Microgrids offers significant benefits, such as optimizing surplus renewable energy by transferring it to neighboring Microgrids, thereby reducing reliance on energy storage systems and enhancing the overall stability and efficiency of power distribution. In this paper, the Graph-Based Optimization Modelling Language (GBOML) is employed to optimize the overall installation cost of renewable energy technologies. The results obtained from GBOML are compared with Pyomo to evaluate the effectiveness of GBOML. For the purposes of this study, the load data, as well as solar and wind energy data, were collected for four distinct regions in India: Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and West Bengal. These datasets serve as the foundation for analysing renewable energy integration and load management strategies within the proposed framework.

title: Mobility-Aware Adaptive Authentication for Enhanced Security in Medical IoT Systems
authors: Sachin Mittal, Sashikanta Prusty, Mukul Mishra, Manaswini R, Ebenezar Jebarani M R
abstract: The Medical Internet of Things (M-IoT) is intended to solve security and privacy problems in the medical sector, especially when consumers are mobile. This architecture offers a safe mechanism for identifying individuals as well as healthcare practitioners in a variety of settings, including interaction that take place locally and remotely. The efficacy of the protocols is assessed using parameters that include computing time as well as communication overhead, which demonstrates increased safety performance in comparison to approaches that were previously used. Additionally, the suggested approach is cost-effective, which makes it a feasible alternative for M-IoT implementations in healthcare facilities in real life. When compared to existing methods like Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE), Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC), the Adaptive Authentication Scheme method performs better in terms of accuracy of 96%.

title: SmartSafetyNet: A Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Predicting Traffic Accident Severity and Enhancing Road Safety Measures
authors: Ghulam Mustafa, Claudio Sartori, Abbas Hyder, Awais Anwer, Muhammad Adnan, Aurangzeb Magsi, Muhammad Younis
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Traffic accidents remain a significant concern for urban safety. This paper presents SmartSafetyNet, a hybrid deep learning model designed to predict accident severity using only pre-crash data. The framework integrates a multilayer perceptron (MLP) for processing structured tabular inputs and a long short-term memory (LSTM) network for capturing temporal patterns. Trained on real-world data from the City of Chicago (2015-2019) and evaluated on 2020 data, the model leverages environmental, temporal, and road condition features while explicitly excluding post-crash variables to prevent data leakage. Experimental results show that SmartSafetyNet outperforms multiple baseline models, achieving 95.03% accuracy, 91.88% precision, 96.55% recall, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of 93.44%. These findings highlight its potential for enhancing traffic safety planning and enabling future real-time applications.

title: Improving Skin Lesion Classification with Attention Based Deep Learning Approach
authors: S Abirami, R V Sankari, J Preethingeeswari, R Nagaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Skin cancer and other dermatological conditions pose significant health risks, necessitating an early and correct diagnosis for appropriate treatment. Traditional diagnosis approaches rely significantly on the dermatologist’s expertise, which may be time-consuming and subjective. This study presents a deep learning-based framework aimed at enhancing skin lesion classification using a Convolutional Neural Network with Convolutional Block Attention Module architecture (CNN-CBAM). The experimentation was performed on the HAM10000 dataset, which comprises diverse dermoscopic images of skin lesions. After extensive experimentation with model architecture and data augmentation techniques, the model provides an accuracy of 79% and an F1-score of $\mathbf{0. 7 5}$, showcasing strong performance in differentiating between various skin cancer types. The incorporation of CBAM enhanced the model’s feature extraction and localization abilities, leading to a notable improvement in classification accuracy. This method highlights the accurate skin cancer detection, supporting early diagnosis, and improving healthcare outcomes.

title: KVVP2 Control Cable Positioning Device Based on Intelligent Sensing Feedback System
authors: Lei Shi, Fan Yang, Jin Nie, Siyu Liu, Yujie Guo, Xiaolin Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of difficult identification and low dismantling efficiency of KVVP2 control cable in substation reconstruction, the paper discusses that manual vibration method is adopted to locate KVVP2 control cable in Yingkou area by analyzing the advantages, disadvantages and applicability of existing positioning equipment. In order to improve this method, this paper presents a positioning device for control cables based on RF signals and Fourier series algorithm. By transmitting adjustable radio frequency signals to achieve the target cable characteristic mark, combined with the anti-interference algorithm at the receiving end to cancel the power frequency interference, the technical bottleneck of accurately identifying the secondary loop control cable in the non-operating state and strong interference environment is solved. Experiments show that the device can make the accuracy of cable identification up to 100%, and the removal efficiency of waste cables increased by 71.2%. In addition, the device is equipped with an intelligent sensing feedback module, which can transmit the detected relevant data to the mobile phone of the tester and the background computer, realizing the intelligent feedback of the device and having great popularization and application value.

title: Power Quality Improvement of Permanent Magnet BLDC Motor Driven Air-conditioner using a Bridgeless SEPIC Converter
authors: Jarathi Akshaya, K. Krishnaveni, Pulluri Architha, M. Manipal Yadav, Mohammed Abdul Saboor
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper describes a system using a Bridgeless SingleEnded Primary-Inductor Converter (SEPIC) to improve power quality in an air conditioner powered by a Permanent Magnet Brushless DC Motor. A Bridgeless SEPIC converter can be utilized as a single-stage Power Factor Correction (PFC) rectifier without the need for a diode rectifier, increasing efficiency and reducing component usage. Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM) improves dependability by lowering the voltage stress on the switching elements and offering automatic power factor adjustment that is close to unity. A Voltage Source Inverter (VSI) is a power electronic circuit that is powered by the SEPIC converter’s DC link voltage. A Permanent Magnet Brushless DC Motor (PMBLDCM) will be managed by the inverter. To maximize system performance, a robust control technique that regulates both the motor speed and the DC link voltage will be used. In comparison to traditional air conditioning systems, the suggested system may guarantee a high-power factor, lower Total Harmonic Distortion (THD), and improved energy efficiency, according to simulation experiments conducted in MATLAB/Simulink. This technology addresses issues with power quality and energy usage while offering a small and effective solution for both residential and commercial applications.

title: Digital Twin-Enhanced Adaptive Control for Robust Power System Stability and Security
authors: Bilal Khan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: The modern power grid is enhanced by increased renewable generation and cyber-physical technologies to provide decentralized green energy solutions. These communication technologies become one of the vulnerabilities to false data injection (FDI) attacks that threaded the cyber-security of power grid. The cyber-security compromise when coupled with load variations and renewable intermittent that further compromise the power system stability. To overcome this limitation, a digital adaptive control technique is proposed to detect FDI attacks and ensure stable frequency regulation. The FDI attack detection is done using the digital twin, a real time virtual model of the power grids. The anomaly detection is done by comparing predicted state using digital twin with the actual state of the system. After digital twin detection, the adaptive controller based on detected states dynamically adjust control action to encounter both cyber-attacks and sudden load variation. The efficacy of the proposed design is assessed in comparison with the conventional proportional Integral (PI) control method, through simulations using a realistic step-variable load profile and a sustained sinusoidal FDI attack. The proposed design improves FDI detection accuracy, achieves rapid frequency stabilization, and increases system resilience.

title: Assessing the Effects of Donor Red Blood Cell Processing Methods Using AFM
