authors: Ekaterina Sherstyukova, Alexander Grechko, Alexander Kostin, Viktoria Sergunova
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: A study was conducted on a modified method of processing donor blood that combines partial leukoreduction and pathogen reduction using riboflavin and UVB light. Atomic force microscopy analysis confirmed that red blood cell morphology and mechanical properties were preserved. Partial leukoreduction effectively reduced leukocyte levels while retaining platelets, and the blood's hemostatic function remained within normal ranges. These results support the safe use of this technology for emergency transfusions in cases of massive blood loss.

title: Network Performance Optimization Using Huffman Compression
authors: Ambagouri Nambiar, Goukanapalli Siddartha Reddy, Anita J P
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Data transmission efficiency is a critical factor in network performance optimization. Effective compression techniques help reduce bandwidth usage and improve transmission speed without compromising data integrity. Among various lossless compression methods, Huffman encoding is notable for assigning variable-length codes based on symbol frequency, thereby optimizing data representation and minimizing transmission overhead. This paper presents an analysis of Huffman encoding's impact on network performance metrics such as memory usage, resource consumption, and power efficiency, compared with other encoding schemes like Run-Length Encoding (RLE) and Lempel-Ziv-Welch (LZW). To ensure data fidelity during transmission, a Huffman decoder is implemented for accurate reconstruction of the original data. The study further evaluates the compression ratio and overall effect on network throughput when applied to typical text-based network payloads.

title: Challenges and Opportunities in Communication Systems for Multi-Domain Air Traffic Management
authors: Nour El-Din Safwat, Kathiravan Thangavel, Roberto Sabatini
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The increasing complexity of Air Traffic Management (ATM) across multiple domains exposes the limitations of current aviation communication systems, which rely on ground-based infrastructure and legacy Very High Frequency (VHF) and High Frequency (HF) links. These systems face coverage gaps, limited bandwidth, and congestion, especially in remote and high-traffic areas. This paper proposes a Non-Terrestrial Network (NTN)-based communication architecture, integrating Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, High-Altitude Platform Stations (HAPS), and emerging 6G infrastructure through a Software-Defined Networking (SDN) framework. A centralized path selection algorithm within the SDN control plane is proposed that dynamically optimizes routing decisions based on key performance indicators such as delay, capacity, energy efficiency, and reliability. A simulation case study conducted across diverse operational environments, including the Terminal Maneuvering Area (TMA), Oceanic, and Urban regions, demonstrates that the proposed system reduces end-to-end delay and improves capacity. These improvements enable enhanced connectivity and meet the communication demands of scalable, multi-domain traffic management, addressing critical needs for next-generation aviation communication networks

title: A Deep Learning Approach Enhanced by Discrete Wavelet Transform for Precise Fault Classification in Rotating Machinery Systems
authors: Fadhel A. Jumaa, Hussein M. Hussein, Ahmed Mohammed Abdulkarem, Anas Fouad Ahmed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Effective and efficient fault diagnosis of rotating machinery is essential to provide a reliable operational machine that can also minimize maintenance costs. The proposed deep learning model, in this paper, is a robust adopting wavelet-based denoising of the signal along with an attention featuring CNN LSTM model overcoming predominantly faulty bearings. The Adam optimizer (learning rate: 0.001; batch size: 64) is used to train the model over 100 epochs. The benchmark Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) dataset, which includes both single and compound fault conditions, is used to assess it. Following convolutional, involuted, and LSTM layers for deep feature extraction and temporal modeling, a discrete wavelet transform (DWT) improves noise resilience in the preprocessing stage. The model reaches classification accuracies ranging from 98–100% across six fault classes, including compound types. The inference latency and power can be reduced to 12.6 ms and under 4.3 W respectively when implemented on a Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC which shows that it is applicable as a real time embedded application. Although the results on standard datasets are encouraging, it will need to be confirmed in further work that robustness extends to industrial environments with robust noise on a non-stationary dataset.

title: Multi-Band GAN-Augmented Deep Learning for Enhanced P300 Detection in RSVP EEG Signals for Assistive-Tech
authors: Srikruthi Neriyanuri, Manavi Das, Sanya Shree, Renu Kumawat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) leveraging Rapid Serial Visual Presentation (RSVP)-base Electroencephalography (EEG) signals offer promising avenues for direct neural communication and control. However, achieving high classification accuracy across diverse subjects and the class imbalance between sparse target and abundant non-target are challenging issues due to inter-subject variability and the complex spatiotemporal nature of EEG signals. In this study, we propose a novel approach by combining Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and a multi-band deep learning architecture to address the issue of class imbalance between target and non-target EEG events in RSVP paradigms. The preprocessing involves ‘multi-band’ filtering, dimensionality reduction, and class-specific augmentation using GANs trained on different frequency bands. The deep learning model consists of band-specific convolutional and LSTM layers along with an attention mechanism for spatiotemporal feature fusion. The evaluation is done on the basis of multiple key performance metrics including accuracy, recall, precision, F1 score, ROC-AUC and unweighted average recall (UAR). The results demonstrate the efficacy of deep learning architectures in decoding RSVP based EEG signals, offering a robust framework for real-time BCIs with reduced calibration demands. The findings in this paper contribute to the development of a scalable and an adaptive BCI system and enhance its applicability in realtime scenarios.

title: Designing of Intelligent Hardware System for Brain Tumor Detection
authors: Aniruddha Mallick, Subhajit Ghosh, Subhabrata Banerjee, Prasenjit Maji, Hemanta Kumar Mondal
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Gliomas, in particular, pose serious medical problems due to their high prevalence and death rates. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is crucial for a precise diagnosis. In order to classify brain cancers using MRI data, this study presents a system that incorporates convolutional neural network (CNN) models. Geometric transformations are among the data augmentation approaches that improve the model’s resilience. The detailed investigation shows that CNN and VGG16 models successfully differentiate between pituitary tumors, meningiomas, and gliomas with classification precisions greater than $\mathbf{7 5 \%}$. This method solves important computational problems in medical diagnostics while improving the accuracy of tumor classification.

title: An Edge-Aware Retinexformer for Robust Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Veera Sathvik Kuppam, Sanivarapu Raghu, Ruthala Thulasi Ram, Uday Jinna, P.V. Sudeep
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Real-world photography often suffers from inadequate lighting due to both the technical limitations of camera systems and uncontrollable external conditions. Low-light image enhancement algorithms improve the quality of images acquired in poor lighting conditions. Further, enhancing these images is crucial for improving performance in vision tasks such as object detection and image recognition. However, different image degradations, such as noise and bias, are unavoidable even in the enhanced images. To tackle them, the Retinexformer low-light image enhancement method integrates the principles of Retinex theory and the transformer model. In this paper, we present a variant of the Retinexformer model that includes an additional edge-guided parallel network to improve performance. Our method employs a dual-path corruption restoration framework to ensure better preservation of edge detail. To validate the approach, we conducted experiments using the LOL dataset, and the results were evaluated both qualitatively and quantitatively.

title: Dynamic safety fuse mechanism for intelligent agent API based on behavioral baseline modeling
authors: Hongxin Zhao, Guangqian Wei, Yeshen He, Ming Lei, Yiying Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Traditional circuit breaker mechanisms based on static thresholds or fixed rules struggle to cope with diverse and evolving API security threats in intelligent agent systems. To mitigate cascading failures caused by disordered API invocation behaviors in multi-agent environments, this paper proposes a dynamic safety fuse mechanism grounded in behavioral baseline modeling. The approach leverages unsupervised learning to establish adaptive service behavior baselines and incorporates reinforcement learning to dynamically optimize fuse strategies, enabling precise and real-time API security protection. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed mechanism significantly outperforms traditional circuit breaker methods in detection accuracy, false positive rate, and system stability, proving particularly effective in highly dynamic microservice architectures.

title: Local Enhancement and Semantic Alignment for Zero-Shot Anomaly Detection
authors: Xiaohong Qiu, Jing Huang, Jun Hu, Yangfen Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Zero-Shot Anomaly Detection (ZSAD) aims to identify anomalies without task-specific training samples and is widely applied in industrial defect inspection and medical image analysis. Recently, the vision-language model CLIP has shown strong performance in ZSAD due to its cross-modal alignment and generalization ability. However, CLIP is designed for natural image classification, relying on global semantics while being insensitive to local details. Its static text-image fusion also limits the use of textual prompts, reducing performance on small-scale, complex-texture, or weakly semantic anomalies. To address this, we propose LACLIP, an enhanced vision-language anomaly detection framework. We incorporate Local Self-Correlation Attention (LSC-Attention) to improve local context modeling and introduce an Anomaly Semantic Aggregation (ASA) module to guide text-image matching with more discriminative semantics. Experiments show that LACLIP achieves state-of-the-art results on MVTec AD and VisA for both image-level classification and pixel-level localization, highlighting its potential for real-world applications.

title: Telemedicine for the Management of Nasal Obstruction: An Innovative Approach to Remote Monitoring
authors: Giorgia Panico, Emanuele Raso, Lorenzo Bracciale, Francesco Bussu, Claudia Crescio, Davide Rizzo, Pierpaolo Loreti
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Nasal polyposis and chronic nasal obstruction significantly impact patients' quality of life and require continuous clinical monitoring. Traditional follow-up methods, based on frequent in-person visits, are often inefficient and burdensome for both patients and healthcare systems. This study presents a telemonitoring solution enabling remote assessment of nasal airflow using a customized version of the Spirobank Smart device. Mechanical and software adaptations were implemented to measure Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF) and transmit data in real time to clinicians via a secure digital infrastructure. The system was validated on 30 healthy volunteers by comparing measurements with those from a standard PNIF Meter. Statistical analysis showed no significant difference between the two devices. The proposed solution offers a reliable, accessible, and costeffective tool for managing chronic nasal conditions remotely, with potential to improve long-term care and patient autonomy.

title: BiFNCA-YOLOv8: Enhanced Construction Fence Detection
authors: Chunyu He, Wenjie Qian, Liyun Liu, Qikun Shi, Xiao Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Construction fence is an important facility to ensure the safety of construction and pedestrians, and detection errors will cause great safety hazards. Therefore, it is very important to study a method for detecting construction fences. However, due to the complexity of the construction site, the large number of similar construction objects and the occlusion problem, as well as the problems of different sizes in different scenes, the existing object detection model of the fence often performs poorly in the complex scene of construction. In this paper, we propose an improved object detection method based on YOLOv8, namely BiFNCA-YOLOv8. In order to reduce the scale and complexity of the model, improve the ability to extract the main features, and improve the accuracy, the traditional convolution and FPN are replaced with Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network to reduce the size and complexity of the model, and improve the accuracy without increasing the structural complexity and computational complexity. Then, Convolutional Block Attention Module is added to the fusion node to improve the fine-grained and detection accuracy of the model through the spatial attention mechanism. Compared with YOLOv8s, our BiFNCA-YOLOv8 improves the F1 score and mAP by 8.8 and 11.1, respectively, and the accuracy is increased to 93.7%, indicating that the bidirectional feature pyramid network and the convolutional attention module can effectively enhance the robustness of construction fence detection under real industrial conditions.

title: Potential of Hydrogen Propulsion in Indian Railways: A Pilot Study
authors: Shashi Kiran, Mahesh Kumar Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper explores the potential of hydrogen fuel cell technology as a sustainable alternative to diesel and electric-powered locomotives in Indian Railways (IR), in line with India's National Hydrogen Mission and broader sustainability goals. Focusing on a pilot project in the Jind–Sonipat railway section, the study assesses the economic feasibility and environmental impact of hydrogen-powered trains. A comparative cost analysis reveals that while hydrogen trains involve higher initial capital investment, their operational costs-estimated at ₹164.5 per 1000 passenger-km, are competitive, falling between diesel (₹79.78) and electric trains (₹256.2). Integrating hydrogen fuel cells with renewable energy sources offers significant emissions reductions and supports India's transition toward a low-carbon transport sector. However, large-scale adoption will require further research to address safety concerns related to hydrogen storage and refuelling and operational challenges arising from India's varied climate and topography. With continued technological progress and supportive policy frameworks, hydrogen propulsion presents a promising pathway for cleaner, more sustainable rail transport in India.

title: Isolation Improvement of Microstrip Patch Antenna Array for Fixed Head Doppler Radar Applications
authors: Navdeep Singh, Sankarsan Padhy, Anil Kumar Chaubey
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of isolation improvement for Fixed Head Doppler Radar Applications. Transmitting and receiving antenna of $4 \times 8$ microstrip patch antenna array has been designed by using RT/Duroid-5880 $\left(\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}=2.2\right)$ as a substrate. A novel metal slab isolator is proposed to reduce the mutual coupling between Transmitter and Receiver of two S-Band large Antenna Arrays. The obtained results show the maximum isolation of -92.39 dB and the improvement of 61 dB in isolation level by using metal slab having height of 40 mm and width of 20 mm between transmitting and receiving antenna of radar. The proposed structure is compared with the reported literature and the improved isolation is attained with the metal slab isolator.

title: Reduced Switch Count-Based Multioutput Multilevel Buck PFC Rectifier
authors: Ankush Koli, N. Sandeep, Harpal Tiwari
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper proposes a modified multilevel buck power factor correction (PFC) rectifier designed to deliver high power quality and efficiency across multiple output ports. The proposed topology efficiently generates 7-level voltages at a significant switching frequency while reducing the power losses. A simplified six-carrier pulse width modulation (PWM) control approach enables the simultaneous operation of multiple equal or unequal DC loads. With a reduced switch count, the rectifier is analyzed under steady-state and transient circumstances using MATLAB Simulink. Simulation results confirm its effectiveness, achieving 97.83% efficiency and a total harmonic distortion (THD) of 2.03% at a 1 kW power level.

title: An LSTM Based Data Driven Approach to Estimate EV Charging Demand Considering Uncertain Parameters
authors: Suresh Tejavath, Varsha A Shah, Akanksha Shukla
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The increasing adoption of Electric Vehicles (EVs) have heightened the need for accurate estimation of EV charging demand to optimize energy infrastructure and grid management. However, predicting charging demand is challenging due to uncertainties in user behavior, including charging frequency, time of charge, vehicle types, and external factors like weather, traffic, and regional characteristics. The current study addresses these challenges by developing a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) based deep learning model to forecast EV charging demand, leveraging field data collected from multiple cities across the United States. The model performance is evaluated using standard metrics such as Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE), with results demonstrating that LSTM model has high predictive accuracy and robustness in handling uncertainties. Comparative analysis highlights the superiority of the LSTM model over traditional methods for time series forecasting.

title: Fast Detection Algorithm for Coal Ash Content Based on Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Jingfang Li, Ming Geng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: To achieve efficient and non-destructive ash content detection, this article proposes an image recognition method based on Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). A dataset suitable for deep learning models was constructed by collecting coal sample images from multiple mining areas and preprocessing them. A lightweight CNN structure was designed in the study for regression prediction of ash content. The experimental results show that this method achieves excellent results with a mean square error (MSE) of 4.23% and a coefficient of determination (R <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of 0.93 on the test set. Compared with traditional methods such as support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), and shallow neural network, it has significant advantages. Moreover, in terms of actual operational efficiency, the average response time of the model has great advantages, with good real-time performance, which can meet the basic requirements of industrial scenarios for detection speed. Research has shown that CNN based methods can effectively extract coal sample image features and achieve fast and accurate prediction of ash content.

title: Infrared Thermal Image Aided Deep Transfer Learning Approach to Sense Contamination Grade for Non-contact monitoring of Overhead Line Insulator
authors: Arup Kumar Das, Shobhan Barua, Suhas Deb, Kaushik Sit, Sovan Dalai
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Contamination flashovers are the primary reason for insulator failure. Early and accurate prediction of insulator contamination severity can avert flashover incidents, thereby impacting the reliable operation of the electrical power system network. This paper introduces an innovative infrared image-aided deep transfer learning approach for remote monitoring of overhead line insulators. A large database is created based on the infrared image of artificially contaminated insulator samples captured at different environmental conditions. The infrared images were initially processed through a mask region- based convolutional neural network to mitigate the background effect. The infrared images corresponding to different contamination were fed to a benchmark convolutional neural network (CNN) model (Alex Net) for classification purposes. Transfer learning with a fine-tuning strategy was adopted to train the network. The result indicates that the proposed approach returns appreciably high classification performance with reduced computational time compared to existing techniques. This insight emphasizes the potential application of the proposed approach for non-contact monitoring overhead line insulators.

title: A Shared Neural Network-Based Method for Inverting Electromagnetic Resistivity Logging Data During Drilling
authors: Shaofan Di, Miaoyu Zhang, Jie Wu, Liqun Peng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: As one of the most widely used logging tools in horizontal well development, the logging-while-drilling (LWD) electromagnetic resistivity logging instrument provides rich subsurface information. However, conventional iterative inversion methods based on physical equations exhibit low computational efficiency, which to some extent limits the real-time geological steering capability of LWD logging. This paper proposes a neural network-based inversion method for LWD electromagnetic resistivity logging data. This method employs a shared neural network (Shared Net) composed of two linear layers and activation functions to predict stratigraphic resistivity intervals. Two output layers (Lower and Upper) are configured to output the upper and lower bounds of the predicted interval, respectively. During training, the quantile loss function is set to 0.05 and 0.95 to achieve a 90% confidence interval, while a width penalty term is added to prevent excessively wide intervals. The method demonstrated high accuracy in testing, achieving an average accuracy rate of 97%. Single-point prediction time is less than 0.1 seconds, enabling rapid and precise inversion of formation resistivity information. This provides a more effective method for real-time inversion of resistivity data acquired during drilling.

title: Feature - Enriched Brain Tumor Classification Using ViT in GCN
authors: Mohd Abdul Hameed, Pavani Padigala, Gone Preethi, Murali Mohan Boodidha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Brain tumors are one of the most life-threatening diseases in the world. A brain tumor is the abnormal growth of cells in or near the brain. In some cases, cancer spreads to the brain from other parts of the body. This paper presents, a hybrid model that combines Vision Transformers(ViT) and Graph Convolutional Neural Networks (GCN) for brain tumor detection. This fused approach predicts whether a person has a brain tumor and also classifies the type of tumor (Glioma, Meningioma, or Pituitary). Initially, we implemented a GCN model on our dataset, where features were extracted using the traditional Histogram method. However, this approach achieved an accuracy of only 66.96%, indicating poor performance of the model. This low accuracy is due to that the Histogram captures only pixel intensity distribution and lose important shape and texture information. To address this issue, we replaced the Histogram method with ResNET-18. a pretrained deep learning model. This change significantly improved the accuracy of the model to 94.04% as ResNET-18 effectively extracts local features. ResNET-18 extracts local features and less stable for large datasets. To overcome this limitation, we introduced Vision Transformers which is more stable for large datasets and captures global dependencies. The model performed well and the accuracy is 95.43<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>. This study demonstrates an improved approach for extraction of features, enhancing the performance of the base GCN model. The implementation of the proposed model is available at: https://github.com/PavaniPadigalaI23/Tumordetection-with-GCN

title: Multi-objective Optimization of Path Planning Based on Width Neural Network and Nash Equilibrium Strategy
authors: Weijian Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: As the autonomous driving technology continues to advance, the multi-objective optimization problem of path planning is increasingly receiving attention. Inspired by the biological principle of neural-based navigation in animals, a multi-objective optimization model based on the width neural network and Nash equilibrium strategy (N-WNN) is proposed to improve the reachability and flexibility of path planning. Specifically, the width neural network (WNN) is expanded to intensify feature extraction within hidden layers, without increasing network depth, thereby capturing crucial path information. Nash equilibrium strategy helps realize multi-objective optimization of path planning by making each objective in path planning reach an equilibrium state under the condition of mutual influence and restriction, so that each objective cannot be further optimized by unilaterally changing the strategy given by other objective strategies, thus helping to realize multi-objective optimization of path planning. Through experimental verification of path planning problems in different scenarios, the results show that the proposed method has significant advantages in multi-objective optimization, which can effectively balance the reachability and flexibility of path planning, and has been compared in detail with the two most advanced multi-objective optimization algorithms currently available, proving the superiority of the proposed algorithm.

title: A Rendez-Vous in Time: Frequency-Domain Precoding for LoS Alignment in Distributed MISO
authors: Thibaut Rolland, Matthieu Crussière, Marie Le Bot
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of Line-of-Sight (LoS) path misalignment in distributed Multiple-Input Single-Output (MISO) systems, particularly in millimeter-wave (mmWave) bands where phase synchronization and timing precision are critical. The goal is to validate a bit error rate model under practical OFDM transmission scenarios involving multiple access points communicating with user equipment. We highlight how time misalignment between LoS paths can degrade system performance and evaluate the effectiveness of various compensation strategies under such conditions. A key contribution of this work is the proposed compensation technique for LoS path misalignment. By applying a frequency-dependent linear phase shift to each subcarrier—an operation that is both low in complexity and easy to implement—we induce a circular rotation of the OFDM time-domain symbol. This rotation effectively aligns the various LoS contributions in time, as long as the path delays remain within the cyclic prefix duration. Notably, the method is fully compatible with analog beamforming architectures, which are essential in mmWave systems to reduce the number of costly RF chains. As a result, the proposed strategy enables efficient time compensation with minimal computational and hardware overhead, making it particularly attractive for distributed Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) deployments at mmWave frequencies.

title: Reduced Component Nine-Level Inverter (RCNLI) with Adaptive Nearest Level Control (ANLC)
authors: Saurav Sivaprasad, Muhammed Aman S P, Amruth Prakash, Vengateri Mobinjeeraj Rajeevan, Baburaj P., Anjali Anand K.
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Multilevel Inverters are suitable for high power applications and have reduced harmonics thereby catering to various real world applications. A Reduced Component Nine-Level Inverter (RCNLI) having eight switches and two DC sources is proposed in this paper. A detailed analysis of the output quality of the proposed inverter under various control and modulation schemes to reduce the harmonics are conducted. Current and voltage output along with Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) of the inverter under both low frequency and high frequency modulation schemes are studied for various modulation indices. It is observed that low-frequency modulation techniques results in lower harmonic distortion. The simulations have been conducted in the MATLAB/Simulink platform for various modulation indices and discussed. Among these, the Adaptive Nearest Level Control technique (ANLC) applied to the nine level inverter achieves the lowest voltage THD of 9.05%, which complies with IEEE 519 2022 standard.

title: Machine Learning Driven Cost and PHEV User Convenience Optimization in Smart City
authors: Gone Neelakantam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: In the digital era, intelligent transportation systems enhance urban mobility through plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) integration. This study identifies opportunities to improve PHEV utility by enabling productive activity during charging/discharging periods instead of idle waiting time. We address smart city PHEV service challenges through a machine learning-enabled fog computing platform featuring an Intelligent Decision Making System (IDMS). This system helps mobilityaware PHEV users optimize multiple services with minimal costs and decision-making delays. The IDMS offers precise predictions for accessing various services at single destinations. Performance evaluations confirm our decision tree-based algorithm delivers superior accuracy compared to existing solutions, significantly enhancing PHEV user experience in smart city environments. The approach successfully balances user convenience and cost efficiency.

title: Scheduling and Navigation Strategies in Coupled Power Traffic Networks: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Supriya Awasthi, Aaquib Firdous, Vivek Kumar Saini, Tushar Sharma, Parul Mathuria
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The rapid growing of Electric Vehicles (EVs) presents new challenges for power distribution and transportation systems. The interdependency of these systems gives rise to the concept of a Power Traffic Network (PTN). EV routing, navigation, charging optimization, and scheduling have gained traction to overcome the grid overloading and traffic congestion challenges in PTN. Innovative charging navigation strategies are required to improve efficiency, alleviate congestion and improvise the overall EV user experience. The present literature lacks a comprehensive detailing of these features in PTN, requiring due consideration. In this context this work systematically examines the recent advancements, challenges and future directions in EV routing and navigation techniques with scheduling optimization algorithms to overcome challenges, while offering insights into future research directions for sustainable EV operation.

title: A Novel Approach for Crowd Analysis and Density Estimation by using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Rachna Rathore, Yuvaraj Velusamy, Diana George, Bura Vijay Kumar, Premanand S Chauhan, Thella Preethi Priyanka
abstract: In an era characterized by urbanization and densely populated events, the ability to accurately analyze and estimate crowd density is paramount. From public safety measures in cities and event venues to strategies for retail optimization, understanding the flow and behavior of crowds can significantly improve decision-making processes and resource allocation. This research report delves into the realm of crowd analysis, emphasizing its significance across various sectors and highlighting contemporary techniques. At its core, the report focuses on three cutting-edge machine learning algorithms: Mobile net SSD, Yolov4, and Mask RCNN, dissecting their capabilities and potential applications. It also acknowledges the inherent challenges, from occlusions in densely packed areas to diverse environmental influences, and offers a perspective on how modern tools, combined with data from surveillance cameras, lidar, and thermal sensors, can overcome them. The integration of these technologies into a coherent, real-time system, driven by big data analytics and cloud computing, further underscores the potential of this research. While this study is grounded in current methodologies, it also looks forward, contemplating the ethical implications and considering the integration of multimodal data fusion and privacy preservation techniques as avenues for future exploration.

title: Optimal Placement of PMUs and PDCs using Parrot Optimization Algorithm
authors: Sruthi Ankam, Vedik Basetti, Sachidananda Sen, Chandan K Shiva
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: In recent years, many power utilities have been installing the phasor measurement units (PMUs) in the power grid due to their vast application in wide area monitoring systems (WAMSs). The main challenge of installing the PMUs at different parts of the power grid is its installation cost. Thus, researchers have proposed various optimal PMU placement solutions. The data generated by PMUs needs to be transferred to phasor data concentrators (PDCs). However, the cost of installation of communication links is higher than the cost of PMUs. Thus, in the present work, a new binary parrot optimization (PO) technique has been proposed to solve the simultaneous placement of optimal PMU and optimal PDC locations for WAMS. The proposed technique is then tested and validated by applying to IEEE 14- and IEEE 30-bus systems. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique in providing better solutions compared with the existing method, that reduces the number of PDCs and lower communication expenses while preserving both system observability and communication effectiveness.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of a BWO-Based MPPT Controller for Grid-Connected PMSG Wind Turbines
authors: Anish Kumar, Paresh Kumar Nayak, Alok Ranjan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The rising demand for energy, depletion of fossil fuel reserves, and increasing environmental concerns, has led to the adoption of renewable energy sources. To integrate these sources into conventional power systems some structural modifications are necessary to ensure seamless operation. This study presents a small wind turbine (SWT) system, connected to a utility grid. The main objective is to develop a 12.3 kW wind energy system that can supply power to three phase loads. The proposed system comprises a three-phase diode rectifier, a permanent magnet synchronous generator (PMSG)-based small wind turbine, a boost converter, bidirectional DC-DC converter (BDC), DC-link capacitor selection, and a utility grid. To optimize power output and regulate voltage, the Black Widow Optimization (BWO) algorithm is employed for maximum power extraction from the boost converter. Additionally, a BWO-based maximum power point tracking (MPPT) technique is implemented to ensure rapid MPPT convergence and maintain voltage stability despite wind speed variations. A mixed-order PLL is used for grid synchronization. The performance of the proposed system is validated under constant and sudden wind speed variation conditions.

title: Achieve a Dynamic and Reliable Web Service using Network Load Balancer on Cloud Platforms
authors: B Sunil Kamath, Mukesh Kamath B
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: High reliability and scalability are two of the key requirements for cloud-native applications. However, these can be efficiently managed only if proper traffic flow among the services is possible. This work demonstrates the use of a Network Load Balancer (NLB) using Docker and Kubernetes technologies along with how the NLB will distribute the traffic to the containerized application deployed within the pod of Kubernetes. Docker allows developers to package an application along with all of its dependencies so that it works correctly across various environments, making it seamless. That is complemented by Kubernetes, which takes responsibility for the creation, scaling, and management of containers using components like pods, deployments, and services. Our programs ensured that the incoming traffic of such pods is distributed evenly so that at least one instance doesn't work as a bottleneck and affect performance. This enables routing requests from an external NLB to appropriate pods. Such an approach in building applications helps in scalability, provides automatic failover in case of pod failures, and uses load- balancing algorithms such as round-robin, least connections, or IP hash. The results show that increasing the number of pods lead to reduced error rate. The offering also supports dynamic provisioning of load balancers by integrating itself with the cloud platform; thus, it allows applications to cope up with varying traffic levels with little human interference. The advantages of such a network load balancing is its use in microservices architecture, showing how it reduces scaling issues, improve reliability, and improve traffic management in a distributed system or cloud.

title: ST-GateNet: Gated Dual-Stream Transformer-CNN for Spatiotemporal Action Recognition
authors: Anil Kumar Koona, Harpreet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Action recognition in videos is a crucial task in computer vision with applications ranging from surveillance to interactive media, yet traditional methods have struggled to fully capture the complex temporal dynamics involved. Existing models often fail to effectively integrate spatial and temporal information, resulting in suboptimal performance in real-world scenarios where action contexts vary significantly. Conventional approaches primarily utilize either convolutional neural networks (CNNs) or recurrent neural networks (RNNs), which may not adequately handle long-term dependencies or require extensive computation. This paper introduces ST-GateNet, a dual-stream Transformer-CNN architecture that employs a gated fusion mechanism for dynamic integration of spatial and temporal features. The Transformer stream uses a Vision Transformer (ViT) with 12 layers and 768-dimensional embeddings for temporal encoding, while the CNN stream utilizes a 3D ResNet-50 for robust spatial feature extraction. The effectiveness of STGateNet is demonstrated on two benchmark datasets, UCF101 and HMDB51, which include diverse human actions captured in varied settings. ST-GateNet achieves an accuracy of 98.3% on UCF101 and 76.5 % on HMDB51, significantly outperforming existing models like TimeSformer and SlowFast Networks in both accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed ST-GateNet model significantly enhances action recognition performance by effectively synthesizing spatial and temporal data, proving to be a robust solution for real-time video analysis.

title: Prognostics of Li-ion Batteries Using a Novel C-rate Dependent Aging Model
authors: Bikky Routh, Arijit Guha, Siddhartha Mukhopadhyay, Amit Patra, Nilima Gadkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Some of the Battery energy storage systems (BESS), like battery-based solar cold storage systems operate with minimal fluctuation load current. A generalized aging model for this kind of system would be favorable for the predictive maintenance of Lithium-ion Batteries (LIBs). Considering this, a novel C-rate dependent aging model has been developed. The model developed is framed into the forecasting structure for the remaining useful life (RUL) prediction of LIBs using a particle filter (PF) framework. To validate the proposed methodology, comprehensive testing was conducted, including Cyclic Aging Tests (CAT) and Reference Performance Tests (RPT), on 2.6Ah LCO cells. The result shows a prediction error of just 18.60Ah, after training the model with the first 900Ah accumulated throughput.

title: Intelligent Fault Detection in Hybrid Microgrids: A Fuzzy Logic and Discrete Wavelet Transform Approach
authors: Aditya Singh, Ayushi Gupta, Saumendra Sarangi, Asheesh K. Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Integrating renewable energy sources in conventional grids increases stability challenges, transient stability, load shifting, peak shaving, and frequency regulation. Hence, there is a need to lead to a grid-scale battery storage system. However, current and voltage modulation occur during faults, making conventional fault detection techniques difficult. This paper proposes a fast fault detection method for hybrid microgrid using discrete wavelet transform (DWT) where local measurements are considered. Analyzing DC fault current and its rate of change ensures rapid detection without communication delays. A relay-based function assesses fault severity, accurately detecting and classifying PP and PG faults using Fuzzy Logic Control. MATLAB/Simulink simulation software is used to validate its effectiveness.

title: 3+1 Beam Laser Interference Lithography for Preparing 3D Nanostructures
authors: Xiaokun Liang, Litong Dong, Mengnan Liu, Dayou Li, Zuobin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Targeting the demand for three-dimensional (3D) micro/nanostructure fabrication, we systematically investigate the optical field formation mechanism in non-coplanar 3+1 beams interference. It specifically elucidates the governing role of the coherent beams' incidence angle in controlling the aspect ratio of the interference patterns. Based on this theoretical framework, the 3+1 beam laser interference lithography system was constructed for studying the 3D periodic nanostructures. -

title: Wireless Sensing Platform Using Flexible Loop Antennas and LC Sensors for Dielectric Characterization of Oral Care Media
authors: Igor Putnik, Bojan Petrović, Sanja Kojić, Andrej Ilić, Lazar Milić, Goran M. Stojanović
abstract: This study presents the design, fabrication and evaluation of a wireless sensing system, integrating flexible loop antennas and LC sensors for dielectric characterization of various oral care media. Unlike previous approaches focused on essential oil nanoemulsions, this work expands the application to clinically relevant substances, including deionized water, toothpaste slurry, anesthetic hydrogel, antiseptic hydrogel, and acyclovir ointment. Five small LC sensors, each fabricated in laminated and non-laminated design, were paired with flexible copper foil antennas to assess environmental dielectric influences. The dielectric constants of all test media were first measured independently using a vector network analyzer with a dielectric probe. Subsequent inductive coupling experiments were conducted to evaluate the resonant frequency shifts and S11 parameter variations when sensors were exposed to each medium.

title: Scalable Anomaly Detection in Big Data Logs Using Deep Autoencoders
authors: Syed Zarak Shah, Mansoor Iqbal, Samain Abid, Usama Abid, Muhammad Osama Malik, Farooq Azam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Anomaly detection in large-scale log data has become increasingly critical for ensuring complex systems' security, reliability, and operational efficiency. Traditional rulebased and statistical techniques often fall short in handling modern log environments' high dimensionality, noise, and scalability requirements. This study presents a simulation-based anomaly detection framework employing deep autoencoders to learn latent representations of normal log patterns and detect deviations via reconstruction loss. Synthetic log datasets were generated to mimic real-world formats, with various injected anomalies such as unauthorized access patterns, spikes, and missing entries. A dynamic thresholding mechanism based on statistical methods, including the interquartile range (IQR), was used to enhance the detection accuracy. Extensive simulations demonstrated that the proposed model achieves an F1-score of 0.908 and an AUC of 0.963 while maintaining low latency, indicating its potential for real-time deployment in large-scale systems. The results affirm that autoencoder-based approaches offer a scalable and effective solution for log-based anomaly detection.

title: Voltage Stability Margin Enhancement using the Progressive L-Index Method with Impact of Solar PV and Electric Vehicle load on Mesh Distribution System
authors: Bharat Singh, Jagnandan Negi, Ashwani Kumar, Kapil Chauhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The voltage stability in the distribution system has become a crucial issue in recent years. The determination of the voltage stability margin (VSM) has been essential in avoiding voltage collapse. In this context, the main contribution of the research is as follows. The placement of distributed generations (DGs) has been strategically optimized using the proposed progressive L-Index methodology to minimize voltage deviation and enhance the voltage stability margin. The impact of distributed generation (DG) and electric vehicle (EV) load modeling on the distribution system network (DSN) was analyzed, focusing on optimizing the size of the DG to improve the voltage stability margin (VSM) and reduce the voltage deviation (VD). The VD has been improved by 68.17% with the installation of Type-3 DG. The IEEE-69 bus test system for mesh distribution has been carried out for VSM analysis. The optimal location and size of the DG types were determined using MATLAB and GAMS optimization, employing the proposed Progressive L-Index method

title: Force Self-Sensing in a Four-DOF Microgripper
authors: Yu Wang, Yuguo Cui, Keke Dong, Xing Tang, Yiling Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: To reduce the design complexity and cost of micro/nano-positioning systems, a piezoelectric microgripper with four degrees of freedom motion is developed. A sensing-enabled approach is employed to accurately detect the grasping force exerted by the pincer fingers. Firstly, the proposed piezoelectric micro-clamp achieves four degrees of freedom in motion based on the inverse piezoelectric effect, that is, it can move simultaneously along the grasping direction and the normal grasping direction; Secondly, a current integration-based sensing-enabled method is proposed to measure the grasping force of the pincer fingers in the piezoelectric microgripper. Finally, experimental results demonstrate that the microgripper effectively achieves four degrees of freedom and accurately perceives grasping forces through the proposed sensing-enabled approach; In the grasping direction, the maximum measured force and self-sensed force of the pincer finger are 28.15 mN and 28.52 mN, respectively. In the normal to the grasping direction, the corresponding values are 6.32 mN and 6.52 mN.

title: Performance and Power Analysis of feed-forward Artificial Neural Network In Xilinx’s 7 Series Field Programmable Gate Array
authors: Pankaj Singh, Sandeep Bushani, Shilpi Bisht
abstract: This paper presents an analysis on performance and power consumption of a feed-forward artificial neural network (FFANN) implemented on field-programmable gate arrays (FPGA). For this analysis, we have used five of Xilinx’s 7 Series FPGAs. For implementation of FFANN on FPGA we first trained it using machine learning algorithm on TensorFlow which is discussed in subsequent sections. The implemented model provides the classification accuracy of 97.12%. The resource utilization of the FFANN implementation across all the considered FPGAs was examined, which revealed that the requirements for flip-flops and look-up tables changes among the FPGAs. However, all FPGAs under consideration requires equal numbers of Block RAM (BRAM), input/output (IO) pins, global clock buffers (BUFG), and digital signal processing (DSP) units. The performance analysis shows that the FFANN implementation on the Kintex-7 FPGA achieved the best performance, surpassing the lowest-performing Artix-7 low voltage FPGA by 81.84%. In terms of power consumption, FFANN is most power-efficient on Kintex-7 low voltage FPGA, with a total power consumption of 9.566 watts.

title: An Interference-Aware Radar Network Optimization Framework for AAM Surveillance
authors: Leonardo Milone, Flavia Causa, Giancarmine Fasano, Luca Manica, Giacomo Gentile, Michael Dubois
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper describes a framework to optimize the topology of a ground-based radar network aimed at providing surveillance functionality into Advanced Air Mobility scenarios. The envisaged solution determines the arrangement (i.e., optimal location, azimuth and elevation angles) of the network's sensor that optimizes the coverage of a predefined surveillance volume while meeting minimum surveillance requirements in terms of Cramer-Rao bound and detection probability. With respect to previously developed solutions, the proposed strategy determines the locations of the radar sensors considering not only the terrain topology and the sensor characteristics but also the mutual radar interference arising when different radars field of regard overlap. Results of the optimization algorithm in identifying optimal locations for the sensors are assessed by checking the main performance parameters (i.e., network coverage, Cramer-Rao Bound and probability of detection) in the whole environment. The strategy is validated using two real world scenarios and demonstrates that the optimized radar network is able to fulfill the required surveillance performance, while minimizing the radar mutual interference.

title: A Fault Tolerant Modular Multilevel Converter Topology for Electric Aircraft
authors: Kranthi Panuganti, Sheron Figarado, Akshay Kumar Rathore
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: More-electric aircrafts (MEAs) and all-electric aircrafts (AEAs) have gained significant attention over the last decade as a promising solution for low-emission and eco-friendly transportation. The transition towards electric aircraft requires higher bus voltages to meet increasing power demands. As bus voltages rise, high-voltage semiconductors become essential for propulsion, making traditional two-level converters unsuitable due to higher dv/dt, larger filter requirements, and increased switching losses. To address these challenges, neutral-point-clamped multilevel converters have been widely studied in the literature. However, ensuring fault-tolerant operation is critical for propulsion system reliability in electric aircraft. In light of this, this paper proposes a fault-tolerant modular multilevel converter (MMC). The proposed MMC consists of two submodules in the arm and operates without requiring a capacitor voltage balancing algorithm. Simulation results validate its effectiveness in fault-blocking capability.

title: Understanding what Federated Learning Models Learn: a Comparative Study with Traditional Models
authors: Rafael Teixeira, Leonardo Almeida, Pedro Rodrigues, Julio Corona, Mário Antunes, Rui L. Aguiar
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) offers a robust framework for training Machine Learning (ML) models across distributed devices while preserving data privacy. However, concerns remain about whether FL-trained models learn in the same way as their centralized-data counterparts. This paper examines the impact of FL on model behavior, utilizing Explainable AI (XAI) techniques and correlation metrics to compare feature importance. By applying two XAI metrics across four public datasets and evaluating multiple FL strategies, we assess how closely federated models align with traditionally trained ones. Although models often achieve similar classification performance (Matthews's Correlation Coefficient (MCC) > 0.9), we observe significant differences in attribution patterns, especially in async approaches, with correlation scores below 0.7 Spearman's Rank Correlation Coefficient (SRCC) on several occasions and below 0.4 SRCC for the worst scenario. These findings suggest that identical performance does not always imply equivalent learning. Furthermore, since these findings were obtained under Independent and Identically Distributed (IID) settings, it is expected that under non-IID settings, the results might be even worse, underscoring the need for explainability-driven validation tools to ensure the reliability, fairness, and trustworthiness of FL models in practice.

title: A High-Precision Electrochemical Analysis System Based on Vertical Graphene
authors: Siyu Liu, Hongyu Chen, Yan Liang, Chuan Liu, Xi Xie, Zixin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Electrochemistry is a discipline focused on the interconversion of electrical and chemical energy at electrode-electrolyte boundaries, but the conductivity and sensitivity of current electrode materials are still insufficient. As an emerging material, vertical graphene with a petal-like upright structure has high specific surface area and excellent electron transport efficiency, while its chemical inertness and structural stability reduce interference in electrochemical processes, enabling high-precision measurements. In this work, an electrochemical analysis system based on vertical graphene is developed. The system with new circuit topology and algorithm is able to fully utilize the performance of the vertical graphene and measure solution-based electrochemical reactions with high precision. Through different electrochemical test methods, the whole system is demonstrated to have the potential to become a valuable platform for widespread applications.

title: AOD-Assisted Maskless Laser-Induced Micro-Components Transfer
authors: Kuai Yang, Yuxuan Cao, Yaoyu Liu, Zhen Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Laser-induced forward transfer (LIFT) has emerged as a key technology for the assembly of next-generation microelectronics due to its non-contact nature and high controllability. In this work, a maskless LIFT strategy is developed based on reactive ion etching (RIE) and laser ablation to support highthroughput and high-efficiency micro-component transfer. Moreover, to address the bottleneck of beam steering speed, an acoustooptic deflector (AOD)-assisted transfer system is introduced to significantly enhance dynamic beam steering performance and increases transfer throughput. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed process and system, achieving reliable transfer of micro-LEDs onto deformable substrates. These results highlight the potential of the proposed approach for scalable applications in advanced displays and flexible electronics.

title: Optimal Planning of Renewable-Based Microgrids Considering Loading and Generation Uncertainties
authors: Nour M. Shabar, Hatem H. Zeineldin, Ehab F. El-Saadany, Khaled Al Jaafari
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Microgrids are the solution for integrating renewable distributed generation units (DGs) into the distribution systems. However, improper microgrid planning may result in excessive energy losses or voltage deviation beyond the limit. Therefore, this paper proposes an optimal planning method for renewable-based microgrids under the uncertainty of loading levels and renewable generation. A multi-objective mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model is established to minimize annual energy losses and voltage deviations under planning and operational constraints. The model integrates photovoltaic (PV) plants and biomass DGs (BMDGs) into the IEEE 33-bus system. The loading and PV generation uncertainties are modeled by a data-driven probabilistic state-based approach instead of general probability distribution functions (PDFs) to improve the planning reliability. The proposed optimization model is solved using the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, incorporating operational constraints using the optimal power flow (OPF) analysis. The results demonstrate significant reductions in energy losses and improvements in voltage profiles, indicating the efficacy of the proposed probabilistic modeling and optimization method.

title: Towards Better APE: Improving Neural Machine Translation for Under-Resourced Languages via Hybrid-Attention Dual-Encoder Post Editing
authors: Asha Hegde, Shashirekha Hosahalli Lakshmaiah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Automatic Post Editing (APE) is a crucial method focused on enhancing the quality of machine-translated text through learning from human post-edited pairs. Although research into APE has progressed for Machine Translation (MT) of numerous high-resource languages, it is rarely explored for under-resourced languages like Kannada, Tamil, and Malayalam. To bridge this gap, this paper presents a novel hybrid-attention dual-encoder model specifically designed for APE. The designed method is compared with the classical concatenation and crossattention mechanisms. The Kannada-Sanskrit (Kan-San) and Kannada-Tulu (Kan-Tul) language pairs are used as a case study to train APE models in both the directions. Results show that the hybrid-attention model produces better translation quality with Bilingual Evaluation Understudy (BLEU) scores of 14.80 and 36.58 for Sanskrit-Kannada (San-Kan) and Tulu-Kannada (Tul-Kan) language pairs, respectively.

title: A Comprehensive Spectral Investigation of Flux Density of Mixed-Grade Permanent Magnet Configurations for Surface Mounted Brushless PM Motors
authors: Vaibhav Bhardwaj, Amit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The demand for high power-dense motors has increased with the growing adoption of terrestrial electric vehicles (EVs) and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), driving the widespread use of brushless permanent magnet (PM) machines. However, achieving high power density in these motors often requires expensive rare-earth magnets, leading to significant cost implications. Additionally, rare-earth magnet grades exhibit substantial price variations due to differences in their remanence (Br) and coercivity (Hc). While NdFeB magnets are widely used, SmCo offers better thermal stability, and ferrite magnets provide a cost-effective alternative. This paper explores the impact of hybrid magnet combinations on fundamental flux density, harmonic content, and total harmonic distortion (THD) in brushless PM motors. By varying the magnet segmentation ratio (α<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>) and analyzing the harmonic spectrum, the study provides insights into optimizing performance and cost. A comparative cost analysis is conducted to guide magnet selection for mixed grade PM designs. The findings offer a practical framework for balancing magnetic performance, rare-earth content, and cost-effectiveness in surface mount brushless PM motors.

title: A Generalized Feature-Based Approach to Dynamic Planning for Airborne Reconnaissance Missions
authors: Bening Sebastian, Stütz Peter
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: We propose a generalized system concept applicable to Airborne Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) missions involving multiple UAVs. Concretely, the system consist of a centralized manager able to perform simultaneous task allocation, sensor scheduling, path planning and task reassignment in dynamic environments by monitoring platform states and environmental conditions. This is in contrast to most existing approaches, which focus on one or few of these aspects in isolation. The central manager exploits characteristic target features to distribute mission tasks - derived from a mission order - across both homogeneous and heterogeneous airborne sensor platforms, continuously adapts to dynamic events during mission execution, and offers high flexibility by supporting the integration of different methods for the task allocation and scheduling subcomponents.

title: Satellite Pose Estimation Using Attention Learning Without GPU Acceleration
authors: Mohammad Tanvir Mahmud Habib, Shahnewaz Siddique
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: One of the most critical problems in space situational awareness (SSA) is the precise assessment of satellite pose, relative position and orientation, especially for unidentified spacecraft. Conventional approaches frequently depend on GPU acceleration and computationally demanding algorithms, which might be impractical in settings with limited resources. In this paper, we propose a GPU-free attention-based deep learning model that can accurately predict satellite pose with performance comparable to that of existing GPU-accelerated methods. Using attention-based learning models that function well without GPU acceleration, this research suggests a unique method for satellite pose estimates. By focusing on the most essential elements of the satellite trajectory, the attention mechanisms in the model enable accurate pose estimates with minimal processing cost. Our experiments show that the proposed approach provides competitive accuracy while drastically reducing processing requirements compared to the state-of-the-art method. The potential of attention-based learning for real-time, GPU-free satellite pose estimations is demonstrated in this work.

title: Pneumothorax Detection via Chest Radiographs
authors: Mangala Shetty, Spoorthi P. Shetty, Ashwini K M, Jenisha Sequiera, G Karthik, Dhananjaya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Pneumothorax, the abnormal presence of air in the pleural cavity leading to lung collapse, requires rapid and reliable diagnosis. Manual interpretation of chest radiographs can be time-consuming and prone to inter-observer variability. In this paper, we propose a unified deep learning pipeline that integrates four modules: (i) automated image quality control using blur detection, (ii) ResNet50-based classification of pneumothorax versus normal cases, (iii) mask-based localization of affected regions, and (iv) an explainability layer using LIME to highlight clinically relevant areas. Trained and evaluated on the SIIM-ACR Pneumothorax Segmentation dataset (12,000+annotated radiographs), the system achieved 99.7% classification accuracy, 99.5% precision, 99.3% recall, and a Dice coefficient of 0.91 for segmentation. Unlike prior works that focus solely on classification or segmentation, our novelty lies in the integration of model-agnostic interpretability (LIME) within a complete diagnostic pipeline, thereby improving both accuracy and trustworthiness. By combining performance, robustness, and interpretability, the proposed framework offers a practical tool for deployment in real-world clinical settings.

title: Laser-Structured Zinc Anode with Silica-Based Interfaces for Robust Zinc-Ion Batteries
authors: Hongyu Wang, Bingyu Li, Chengjuan Yang, Xinyao Zhu, Yanling Tian, Zhen Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The hydrogen evolution reaction and dendritic growth at zinc electrodes severely limit the development of aqueous zinc-ion batteries despite their intrinsic safety, high capacity, and cost-effectiveness. Herein, we report a dual-strategy approach combining laser lithography with protective layer engineering to address these challenges. Periodic concave-convex structures are created on zinc foil via laser patterning to enhance interfacial adhesion, then nano-SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, artificial coating is applied as ion-conducting channels for homogeneous zinc deposition, simultaneously providing sufficient mechanical robustness to inhibit dendrite formation. This hierarchical design enables exceptional electrochemical performance, with symmetric cells demonstrating stable cycling for more than 120 hours at aggressive conditions (50 mA cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−2</sup>), which is three times more than the 30-hour lifespan of the SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>@Zn ∥SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>@Zn symmetric cell with only the coating. The robust coating-substrate interface withstands high current impacts without degradation, offering a scalable strategy for high-performance zinc anodes in next-generation energy storage.

title: Composition Analysis and Antibacterial/Antioxidant Activity Evaluation of Rendered Meles Meles Oil in Changbai Mountain Area
authors: Yao Dong, Hui Zhang, Hao Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: To investigate the fatty acid composition, antibacterial activity, and antioxidant activity of badger oil, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) was used to analyze the components of badger oil after methylation treatment with potassium hydroxide-methanol alkaline catalysis. Antibacterial activity was evaluated via gradient dilution against six microbial strains. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) was determined to evaluate its antibacterial spectrum and capacity. Antioxidant activity was assessed by measuring DPPH, ABTS, hydroxyl radical scavenging activity, and total reducing power. A total of 14 fatty acids were detected in badger oil, with the main components being oleic acid, linoleic acid, and palmitic acid. Unsaturated fatty acids accounted for 65.27 % of the total, with oleic acid being the most abundant. Different concentrations of badger oil exhibited varying antibacterial activities. The MIC values for E. coli and B. subtilis were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$600 \text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex> and 2.5 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex>, respectively; for S. aureus, they were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$700 \text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex> and 5 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex>; and for B. pumilus, they were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$800 \text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex> and 20 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{m g} / \text{m L}$</tex>. The MIC for C. albicans was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{6 0 0 ~ m g} / \text{m L}$</tex>. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{I C}_{\text{5 0}}$</tex> values of badger oil for scavenging DPPH, ABTS, hydroxyl radicals, and total reducing power were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 7. 1 0} \text{~ m g} / \text{m L}, 9.12 \text{mg} / \text{mL}, 0.78 \text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.21 \text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex>, respectively. This indicates that badger oil exhibited the strongest scavenging ability for hydroxyl radicals and the weakest for DPPH radicals. This suggests that badger oil has potential as a natural preservative or therapeutic agent in food and pharmaceutical industries.

title: Leveraging LLMs for Detecting Security Threats in Virtual Network Functions
authors: Ibrahim Khalil Mejri, Sara Sutton
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: Securing dynamic virtual network environments poses a significant challenge for traditional intrusion detection systems. This paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to more effectively identify security threats in these complex settings. We introduce two complementary LLM-based approaches. The first, a “deep inspection” method, performs a highly detailed analysis of network traffic, achieving up to 97% accuracy in detecting malicious activity. The second, an “aggregated analysis” workflow, is designed for high-throughput environments and maintains 86.2% accuracy by analyzing statistical trends in traffic data. Evaluated on the VNFCYBERDATA dataset, our fine-tuned models outperform traditional methods. A combined model that dynamically switches between the two LLM workflows achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 2 \%}$</tex> overall accuracy, surpassing the performance of a traditional DNN baseline while effectively managing real-time processing demands. These findings highlight the potential of LLMs to enhance security in virtualized networks, augmenting the capabilities of traditional systems.

title: Tomato Classification Using EfficientNet-B7
authors: Deborina Barman, Amrita Parashar
abstract: Tomato quality analysis is a complex task in the agricultural market for ensuring quality of products in consumer markets. In this study, we propose tomato classification using EfficientNet-B7, a pretrained model. The framework was built to categorize tomatoes into three categories that are ripe, unripe, and reject with an accuracy of 98.4%. Previous research has investigated hybrid approaches such as CNN-SVM and Efficient-NetB0, for the classification of agricultural products. This study builds on this foundation by employing EfficientNet-B7 to develop a more streamlined end-to-end solution for tomato classification. The results demonstrated the potential of deep learning models to transform quality control systems in the food industry.

title: Cost-Centric Optimal Framework for PHEV Integrated Microgrid System Considering Shiftable Loads
authors: Bishwajit Dey, Gulshan Sharma, Pitshou N. Bokoro, Rajesh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Plugged-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) are crucial for enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of microgrid (MG) operations. PHEVs can optimize energy use and lessen dependency on grid electricity by serving as mobile energy storage units that can store excess renewable energy and release it during periods of high demand. Their bi-directional power transaction capability commonly termed as grid-to-vehicle (G2V) and vehicle-to-grid (V2G) facilitates frequency regulation and load balancing, and their incorporation with demand side management (DSM) programs reduces operating expenses, encourages the use of renewable energy sources, and guarantees a dependable, sustainable microgrid system. This paper proposes a recently developed one-to-one based optimizer (OOBO) to minimize the operation cost of a MG system for varying arrival state-of-charge (SOC) and arrival-departure period of PHEV. Two different load shifting strategies are also implemented and their impact on cost-effective operation of the MG system is compared. Numerical results show that higher arrival SOC and price dependent optimal load shifting method are economic practices among the others.

title: Detection and Recognition of Daylily Maturity Based on Deep Learning
authors: Tianyi Zhang, Yang Jian
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Deep learning and object detection technologies have been widely applied in agricultural automation to assist people in completing labor-intensive tasks. This paper focuses on daylily (Hemerocallis citrina) and employs deep learning-based object detection algorithms to recognize daylily buds at multiple maturity stages under field conditions. Experimental results show that the YOLOv5s-M model improves real-time detection capability compared to the original YOLOv5s model, and demonstrates significant practical value.

title: Development of Automatic Testing System for Electric Power Special Switches
authors: Pan Li, Jiahui Zhu, Diancai Shi, Xinyu Yang, Xinyu Wu, Jin Guang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In the power grid control system, the quality of switches as information hubs is crucial, but traditional manual testing methods are complex to operate and time-consuming. To this end, this article has developed an automatic testing system for power dedicated switches, which integrates TestCenter and Selenium Web technology to achieve automatic configuration of switch parameters, automatic construction and transmission of message traffic, and significantly improves testing efficiency and accuracy, providing more efficient and accurate testing methods for the quality assurance of power dedicated switches.

title: Reverse Throttle Regeneration for Seamless Single- Control Driving in Electric Three-Wheelers
authors: Suvodip Das, Ranjithkumar M, Anoop Lamba, Nedumthaly Syrus, Ramesh Thirumalasetti, Vigneswaran P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: 3Wheeler industry in India is a moving based industry where the customers’ demands that the vehicle capability comprises of meeting characteristics like load carrying capacity, performance, range and easy of riding in harsh terrain conditions. 3-Wheeler EV sales are rapidly gaining the momentum in the market and are mostly used in urban and sub-urban areas and can be designed to use for both cargo operation and passenger carrier. This industry is a highly cost driven market where major OEMs in India are fighting to strive in the Indian market. In a day-to-day operation of 3-Wheeler EV more that 10 % of the vehicle kinetic energy can be converted back into useful electrical energy back into the battery under urban driving cycle.A reverse throttle mechanism which will enable single throttle operation i.e. both acceleration and deceleration has been proposed to further enhance the driving operation and simultaneously prompts energy recovery. A Reverse throttle regeneration control strategy has been developed and integrated in the Vehicle Control Unit which is based daily driving operation. Typical Real World Usage Pattern driving cycles are simulated to understand the effectiveness of the reverse throttle control strategy. Results shows that using the reverse throttle regeneration operation there is a substantial increase in the ease of driving, enhanced energy recovery rate and ensuring safety while braking. The other advantages of using reverse throttle are also highlighted in this research.

title: Scalable Cloud Architecture for Computational Microscopy: A Microservices Approach with Dynamic Resource Management
authors: Moran Xu, Aman Garg, Felix Scheffler, Shiqi Xu, Faguo Yang, Matthew Andrew, Andriy Andreyev
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: Computational Microscopy applications require substantial computing resources that local infrastructure cannot efficiently provide. Cloud-based virtual machines (VMs) can provide computing resources on demand. However, traditional one-on-one VM assignment has the issue of capacity availability especially for high-performance GPUs. This paper presents a novel cloud-based microservices architecture for the ZEISS X-ray Microscopy Advanced Reconstruction Toolbox (ART) 5.0 [1], featuring dynamic virtual machine (VM) pool allocation and intelligent resource management.
