Our system employs two specialized services: a deployment service for VM lifecycle management, and a restart service for runtime operations. The deployment service implements Microsoft Entra ID SSO for administrative access while the restart service uses JSON Web Token (JWT)-based authentication with client certificates for customer operations. The key innovation is a dynamic VM pool allocation system that allocates pre-provisioned VMs from multiple regions and data centers. Experimental results demonstrate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$33-40 \%$</tex> provisioning time reduction and 66 % cost reduction. The architecture supports seamless third-party integration through comprehensive REST APIs for system management and gRPC for real-time, large-data streaming applications, enabling automated workflows for enterprise deployment. This architecture is based on Microsoft Azure cloud infrastructure but can be potentially migrated to other major cloud providers, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud Platform (GCP), etc.

title: Comparative Analysis of Plasma-Based Nitrogen Fixation With ICP/RF Systems
authors: Igor B. Matveev, Anton E. Zinchenko
abstract: A comprehensive assessment of plasma-based nitrogen fixation technologies is presented, focusing on atmospheric-pressure operation with air as the primary reactant. The study examines NO x synthesis performance across different plasma configurations, highlighting the advantages of radio-frequency (RF) driven inductively coupled plasma (ICP) systems (abbreviated as ICP/RF), which achieve 3.8 vol.% NO x yield at 2.06–2.2 MJ/mol N−1 energy consumption with throughput 532 L/min. Enhancement strategies demonstrate the potential for optimizing process parameters to achieve NO x concentrations up to 6.8 vol.% and reduced energy costs of 1.3 MJ/mol N−1 through oxygen enrichment and elevated pressure. Results indicate promising opportunities for implementing plasma technologies in decentralized nitrogen fixation scenarios with scalability potential up to megawatt-level operation.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Integrated VLC-RF System for Secure Industrial IoT Applications
authors: Ryo Harada, Wasiu O. Popoola
abstract: This paper proposes a novel integrated visible light communication (VLC) and radio frequency (RF) system using an angular diversity receiver (ADR) for Internet of Things (IoT) sensor networks in industrial contexts. The prototype, including the transceiver’s analog front end (AFE), is designed for microcontroller unit (MCU) operation and is implemented for experimental demonstrations. The VLC coverage of the proposed system is improved with a coverage rate of 50% compared to 37% in our previous work, and the physical layer security (PLS) performance is also enhanced with double security capacity (SC) compared to a single photodiode (PD) receiver. Furthermore, to evaluate the feasibility of industrial IoT (IIoT) applications, real-time sensor network applications are demonstrated using the proposed integrated VLC-RF system. Experiments of real-time sensor transmission, image transmission and integration of the robot arm system indicate benefits in a practical scenario by showing millisecond-order latency via VLC, such as response time, round-trip time (RTT) and one-way latency.

title: Scheduling Jobs Under a Variable Number of Processors_supp1-3638703.pdf
authors: Joachim Cendrier
abstract: Even though it is usually assumed that data centers can always operate at maximum capacity, there have been recent scenarios where the amount of electricity that can be used by data centers evolve over time. Hence, the number of available processors is not a constant anymore. In this work, we assume that jobs can be checkpointed before a resource change. Indeed, in the scenarios that we consider, the resource provider warns the user before a change in the number of processors. It is thus possible to anticipate and take checkpoints before the change happens, such that no work is ever lost. The goal is then to maximize the goodput and/or the minimum yield of jobs within the next section (time between two changes in the number of processors). We model the problem and design greedy solutions and sophisticated dynamic programming algorithms with some optimality results for jobs of infinite duration, and adapt the algorithms to finite jobs. A comprehensive set of simulations, building on real-life job sets, demonstrates the performance of the proposed algorithms. Most algorithms achieve a useful platform utilization (goodput) of over 95%. With infinite jobs, the algorithms also keep fairness by having a relative minimum yield above 0.8, meaning that each job gets a good access to the platform (80% of the time that it would have had if each job had its perfect share of the platform). For finite jobs, the minimum yield can be low since very short new jobs may have to wait until the beginning of the next section to start (and finish), significantly impacting their yield. However, for 75% of the jobs within each workload, the yield ratio between these jobs is at most at a factor two, hence demonstrating the fairness of the proposed algorithms.

title: AutoAI-IDS: A Meta-Learning-Based Approach for Automating Model Selection Process for Network Intrusion Detection Tasks
authors: Tanish Guntur, Kevin P. Grimes, Naren Velnambi, Walaa Alayed, Mustafa Abdallah
abstract: The selection of the appropriate artificial intelligence (AI) model from a variety of different classes of models for network security is a challenging and time-consuming task. In this study, we introduce a meta-learning approach for optimizing model selection for network intrusion detection tasks that eliminates the necessity of repetitively training and evaluating each model on new tasks. The first phase of our framework involves training an ensemble of seven state-of-the-art AI models, each with varied hyperparameters resulting in a total of 64 unique model configurations. By leveraging the output probabilities of these models as inputs to train our meta-learning regressor, we generate expected probabilities that predict the performance of each model configuration on unseen data. Our meta-learning mechanism streamlines model selection by using a regressor to identify the optimal configuration, avoiding costly evaluations. Our comprehensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, showcasing superior performance on the NSL-KDD and CICIDS-2017 datasets with significantly lower inference time compared to conventional model selection strategies. We evaluated our regressor models using frequency analysis to rank model configurations based on their top-1, top-5, and top-10 performance across datasets. We also used the Hit-at-k metric to precisely measure how well our approach selects the suitable AI model for unseen samples and how predicted probabilities align with true class probabilities. We apply paired t-tests to determine whether the performance differences among the proposed meta-learners are statistically significant. We also conduct a benchmark evaluation of two prominent automated machine learning (ML) frameworks, H2O AutoML and Auto-sklearn, using our two datasets. We have released our source codes for the community to access as a baseline framework for meta-learning in network intrusion detection tasks.

title: Low Altitude UAV Detection in Complex Contexts
authors: Zhengwei Tang, Wen Lu, Weihua Tang, Dong He, Yongmei Huang, Qiang Wang
abstract: With the rapid development of drone technology and its widespread application in various fields, low-altitude drone detection has become an important technological approach for ensuring public safety and implementing effective supervision. This paper addresses issues such as small drone targets, object occlusions, and environmental interference leading to missed detections and false alarms in complex backgrounds by proposing a solution based on the YOLOv10n algorithm. The algorithm first introduces a BiFPN module into the neck of the YOLOv10n model, combining the advantages of PANet (Path Aggregation Network) and weighted feature fusion to promote efficient integration of feature information at different levels. It also employs a Concatenation module within the same layer to enhance the network’s ability to detect small targets. Additionally, in the Backbone section, the C2f module is replaced with the C2fCIB module to increase the capability to capture features at different scales and improve small target detection performance. Finally, inspired by the TOOD structure, the Head part incorporates a DCNv2 module to boost the network’s ability to handle complex environments and multi-scale targets. Experimental results show that the improved YOLOv10 model achieved mAP@50 of 93.8% and mAP@50:95 of 65.5%, with a model size of 1.6M parameters. Compared to the baseline YOLOv10n model, this represents accuracy improvements of 2.3% and 5.6% respectively, while reducing the parameter count by 42.5%. In summary, the enhanced model effectively handles low-altitude drone detection tasks under diverse environments, providing robust technical support for public safety, intelligent decision-making, and regulatory requirements.

title: Stacked Intelligent Metasurface-Enabled Satellite Integrated Sensing and Communications Systems
authors: Chengjun Jiang, Hao Yuan, Chensi Zhang, Jiancheng An, Chongwen Huang, Chau Yuen
abstract: Stacked intelligent metasurfaces (SIM) is a new technology that can achieve beamforming in the electromagnetic wave domain, which greatly benefits the reduction of processing delays. Motivated by the constraints of limited satellite resources, this letter proposes a SIM-enabled satellite integrated sensing and communication system. Specifically, the SIM-equipped satellite conducts dual-function precoding in the wave domain, without traditional digital beamformers, to simultaneously sense multiple aerial targets and serve multiple downlink communication users. To realize this, we employ a penalty function-based gradient ascent algorithm to maximize the sum rate of communication while ensuring the sensing performance. Simulation results validate the high compatibility of SIM technology with satellite systems, highlighting its potential for future applications.

title: Adaptive Nonlinear Digital Self-Interference Cancellation for Full-Duplex Wireless Systems Using Hypernetwork based Incremental Learning
authors: Sheikh Islam, Xin Ma, Chunxiao Chigan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking
abstract: Achieving effective self-interference cancellation (SIC) in full-duplex (FD) wireless communication systems under time-varying channel conditions remains a significant challenge. To address this challenge, we propose a novel adaptive SIC solution through leveraging Hyper Neural Networks (HyperNet) and incremental learning (IL). Unlike the existing methods that rely on offline training or lack real-time adaptability, our approach enables autonomous learning and fast adaptation to the complex, nonlinear, and time-varying nature of self-interference (SI) channels. It effectively addresses dynamic adaptation challenges, such as catastrophic forgetting, through the use of experience replay (ER). Our experimental results show that traditional model-based methods exhibit limited adaptability under dynamic channel conditions, while conventional data-driven models fail to maintain consistent performance without the adaptive capabilities provided by IL. In contrast, the proposed HyperNet-based IL model reduces training time by 33% and achieves three times faster convergence compared to a standalone HyperNet trained separately for each static condition. Extensive evaluations using simulated datasets that emulate real-world scenarios demonstrate that our approach consistently achieves SI suppression down to the noise floor. It also delivers significantly lower computational complexity and training time. These improvements collectively enhance the efficiency and reliability of FD communication systems operating in dynamic wireless environments.

title: Model Predictive Control-Based Active Cell Balancing for Battery Energy Equalization Using Converter Topologies
authors: Satish Toram, Ilango Karuppasamy
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) have battery packs consisting of several cells, where state-of-charge (SoC) differences among individual cells can trigger effects like overcharging, deep discharging, and degradation acceleration. Therefore, active cell balancing is important for safe operation and long life of the batteries. In this study, active cell balancing is simulated with Model Predictive Control (MPC) in MATLAB/Simulink, and its comparison with the performance of conventional balancing methods in load and no-load situations is analyzed. The two balancing topologies analyzed were ćuk converter-based balancing and bidirectional multiple transformer-based balancing. The study aimed to look into how effective MPC was in optimizing the charge transfer with regard to balancing time and efficiency. Simulation results showed that MPC offered advantages over the others in terms of SoC equalization time, thus confirming the efficacy of MPC towards EV battery applications and performance.

title: Code Search with RAG: A Systematic Comparison of Retrieval Performance
authors: Rama Satya, Raghu Kisore. N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Buffer overflow attacks remain a critical threat to software security, with existing defenses like ASLR and stack canaries proving insufficient against sophisticated exploits. Nvariant systems, which execute diverse program variants to thwart coordinated attacks, offer a promising solution. However, manually generating such variants is costly and unscalable. To address this, we propose an AI-driven pipeline that automates the creation of N-secure code variants by leveraging programming expertise embedded in existing code repositories. As a foundational step, this work benchmarks the ability of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models to identify semantically similar code snippets from a repository that match the coding constructs of a given human-written code. We evaluate multiple RAG architectures on their retrieval accuracy, diversity of returned snippets, and ability to surface distinct coding expertise (e.g., security-aware implementations). Our analysis reveals how RAG models can systematically curate programming variants that preserve functionality while differing in structure, libraries, or security practices. The retrieved snippets will later train a modelfree reinforcement learning (RL) agent to generate N diverse variants, introducing security by diversity against buffer overflow attacks. By rigorously assessing RAG models now, we ensure the subsequent RL phase has high-quality, relevant exemplars that are critical for generating robust variants. We evaluate two different RAG models: Code specific RAG model and a Generalized RAG model. L2 distance and cosine similarity metrics are used to measure the ability of RAG model identify code segments from a given human code repository that capture diverse coding human expertise. We believe our work bridges AI-powered code retrieval and generative security, offering a scalable path to N-variant systems. Our proposed scalable path to N-variant systems involves feeding the output of RAG to a model free Reinforcement Learning algorithm.

title: AI-Enhanced Identity-Based Authentication for Secure Node Communication in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: M R Hima Bindu Kanety, Bidush Kumar Sahoo, Md. Sirajuddin
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Node authentication in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) is essential for ensuring security, data integrity, and efficient operation in resource-constrained environments. It helps to prevent malicious node attacks, such as impersonation and data tampering, by verifying the identities of participating nodes. In this paper we propose an innovative authentication framework which combines artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities with Identity-Based Authentication (IBA) methods to bolster security in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). While traditional cryptographic techniques are valuable, they often fall short in adapting to the changing threat landscapes commonly found in resourcelimited WSN settings. Our methodology utilizes machine learning algorithms to scrutinize the behavioral patterns of sensor nodes, resulting in a multi-layered authentication architecture that merges the benefits of cryptographic validation with behavioral analysis. This new framework shows marked improvements in identifying unusual authentication attempts, all while keeping energy consumption in check-a vital factor for WSNs. Experimental findings indicate a detection rate of 93.2% for complex attack vectors, accompanied by a mere 2.5% false positive rate. These results imply that integrating AI with IBA is a promising strategy for enhancing the security of future WSNs while simultaneously extending their operational lifespan.

title: FinAI-Trader: Sentiment-Enhanced Reinforcement Learning for Bitcoin Trading in the FinAI Contest 2025 Task 1
authors: Taimoor Ahmed, Nikhar Azhar, Sahar Arshad, Mehwish Fatima
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: Automated cryptocurrency trading requires strategies that adapt to high volatility, sparse rewards, and rapidly shifting market conditions. We present FinAI-Trader, a reinforcement learning framework that integrates Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) with Large Language Models (LLMs) for decision support in financial markets. The framework is developed for the FinAI Contest 2025 Task 1, which focuses on portfolio optimization, risk-aware Bitcoin trading, and strategy generalization across unseen assets. FinAI-Trader leverages the FinRL environment and incorporates sentiment and risk features generated by the DeepSeek LLM to enrich representations and enable dynamic strategy adaptation. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that FinAI-Trader exhibits enhanced adaptability and risk-adjusted performance compared to baseline methods under realistic market conditions. This work establishes a transparent benchmark for the contest and demonstrates the potential of hybrid RL-LLM approaches for advancing next-generation finAI systems.

title: Zero-Day Gps Attack Detection and Classification in Uav Networks
authors: Seyyedeh Maryam Mazloom, Wei-Ping Zhu, Wessam Ajib
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) face escalating cybersecurity threats, particularly from GPS spoofing and jamming attacks, which endanger flight safety and mission integrity. This paper introduces a novel UAV cybersecurity framework that integrates statistical extreme value meta-learning (EVML) with a dual-path classifier to detect and classify GPS attacks. The method overcomes the key limitations of some existing approaches, such as excessive training data needs, zero-day threat vulnerability, and disjointed detection/classification. In particular, the proposed framework includes two stages. The first one enables zero-day attack detection through few-shot meta-learning with prototype-based anomaly detection where support sets contain only benign flight data while query sets include both benign samples and synthetically generated attack patterns. Moreover, a prototypical OpenMax layer and extreme value theory are exploited to identify suspicious patterns in GPS telemetry data. The second stage utilizes a novel dual-path architecture that independently processes position-related and signal-related features to classify detected attacks as spoofing or jamming. Our results on real-world attack data demonstrates that the proposed method has exceptional performance with 97.33 % detection accuracy and 0% false alarm rate, which significantly outperform the state-of-the-art. Furthermore, attack classification achieves 82.33 % accuracy for spoofing and 94.31 % for jamming attacks, with an overall F1 score of 0.88.

title: Comparative Analysis of NCF, SVD-MF, Graph and Hypergraph Neural Network for Rating Prediction
authors: Tarun Narula, Sateesh Kumar Awasthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Recommendation systems play a vital role in various digital platforms, including e-commerce, movie streaming, and online learning environments. Their primary function is to predict user preferences and provide personalized suggestions. In a recommendation system, rating prediction is a core task that aims to predict the rating or score a user would give to an item (e.g., movie, product, etc.) based on their past behavior or preferences, as well as the behavior of other users. The goal is to make personalized recommendations by predicting which items users are likely to rate highly or engage with in the future. In this study, we will discuss four models: Neural Collaborative Filtering (NCF), Singular Value Decomposition-Based Matrix Factorization (SVD-MF), Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and Hypergraph Neural Networks (HGNNs) to figure out how well they predict ratings. We used the MovieLens dataset to check which one of these models performs best for rating prediction. We trained each model using Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss to track mistakes, adjusted them with the Adam optimizer, and checked their scores with Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). The results show that SVD-MF performed worst, NCF performed somewhat better but GNNs and HGNNs give the best results, with HGNNs having the least RMSE.

title: Cross-Cultural Sarcasm Detection Using Transformer Models: A Study on Linguistic and Cultural Adaptation
authors: J. Vijaya, Arunkumar Gopu, Heena Painkra, Paridhi Chauhan, Mamta Nag
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper studies transformer models, especially Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT), to identify sarcasm in text. Detecting sarcasm is difficult because it depends heavily on understanding the specific context, which makes it an implicit challenge. Sarcasm often relies on subtle cues, such as tone, word choice, and contextual references, making it difficult for traditional machine learning models to identify accurately. The primary goal is to enhance the model’s ability to effectively distinguish sarcastic expressions by leveraging BERT’s deep contextual understanding. This capability helps the model grasp the complex connections between words and their context, both from left to right and right to left. This approach is particularly valuable in sarcasm detection, where the meaning often contradicts the literal text. Additionally, the research explores BERT’s cross-cultural adaptability by evaluating its performance on datasets in various languages and cultural contexts. This is achieved through transfer learning, where a model trained on one dataset (e.g., English) is adapted to a new dataset in a different language or cultural context without requiring extensive retraining. The goal is to assess how well BERT can generalize across different social and cultural norms, which may affect how sarcasm is expressed and understood. The findings demonstrate that BERT holds significant potential for cross-cultural sarcasm detection, showing that transformer-based models can be effective in diverse settings.

title: A Comprehensive Review on District Cooling Systems for Demand Response Applications
authors: Vaibhav Rathore, Chandra Prakash Barala, Parul Mathuria
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: India's residential and commercial cooling demand has steadily increased due to rapid urbanization, rising temperatures, and improved living standards. District cooling systems have emerged as a promising solution to meet this growing demand, offering significant benefits in energy efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and environmental sustainability. In addition to these benefits, District Cooling Systems (DCSs) are essential in enhancing grid flexibility by providing Demand Response (DR) capabilities through Thermal Energy Storage (TES) and load shifting. The pipeline network also acts as a TES medium, using its dynamic thermal properties and inherent thermal inertia to absorb, store, and slowly release cooling energy. Therefore, this paper explores the potential of district cooling systems as a DR mechanism, highlighting various DR strategies that can be implemented, such as load curtailment, real-time pricing, and automated demand-side management. It also examines how these strategies can be integrated into energy infrastructure to optimize grid performance. Furthermore, this paper reviews national and international pilot projects demonstrating district cooling systems' effectiveness in supporting DR initiatives. Additionally, it addresses the technical challenges associated with integrating district cooling systems as DR.

title: Research on intelligent geology based on BP neural network technology
authors: Zhaoyang Ma, Peng Yue, Jie Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The field of geology has long called for the reform of traditional data analysis methods, and geological decision-making increasingly relies on new technologies. Intelligent geology is the goal of geological data transformation, which needs in-depth research, and artificial intelligence provides technical support. This paper analyzes the advantages of BP neural network technology, discusses its relationship with intelligent geology, puts forward the construction of intelligent geology application scenarios such as resource exploration and hazard prediction, and takes LA Geological Survey Company as an example to provide reference for intelligent geology reform.

title: Evaluating AI-Assisted Motion Tracking for Knee Rehabilitation: A Comparative Analysis of You Only Look Once Version 8 (YOLOv8) and MediaPipe
authors: Ing Teck Phang, Asnor Juraiza Ishak, Siti Anom Ahmad, Tomohiro Shibata
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Conventional methods for measuring joint angles and body movement, such as goniometers and inertial measurement units (IMUs), can be impractical for home-based use due to the need for physical setup, calibration, or supervision. This has led to a growing interest in AI-based, markerless pose estimation techniques as a more convenient alternative. This study compares two real-time AI-powered computer vision models—MediaPipe and You Only Look Once (YOLOv8), specifically the YOLOv8n and YOLOv8s variants for their reliability, error percentage, and inference time in tracking knee joint angles during three rehabilitation exercises: Seated Knee Extension, Half Squat, and Sit-to-Stand. During the rehabilitation exercises, the knee was connected to a goniometer and performed by one participant while another person supervised to compare its readings with computer-based measurements. Each exercise set was repeated four times under supervision. The objective of this study is to develop a non-invasive and low-cost motion tracking framework suitable for remote rehabilitation, aiming to improve patient monitoring and exercise compliance. MediaPipe outperformed both YOLOv8 models, demonstrating the lowest error at full extension <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(180^{\circ}\right)$</tex> at 0.7779 % and the fastest inference time (approximately 35 ms). YOLOv8n performed well at 90° flexion (error: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 0 5 \%}$</tex>) but showed a higher error at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{180}^{\circ} \boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{4.94 \%} \boldsymbol{)}$</tex>. YOLOv8s showed the highest error at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{180}^{\circ} \boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{8.87 \%)}$</tex> due to landmark misalignment. Inference times were also significantly higher for YOLOv8n (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 3. 7 9 m s}$</tex>) and YOLOv8s (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 9 1. 3 4 m s}$</tex>), compared to MediaPipe <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(36.45 \text{ms})$</tex>, with increased noise and jitter during dynamic motion. Overall, MediaPipe's lightweight and Central Processing Unit (CPU)-optimized design makes it the most suitable for real-time, non-invasive, and low-cost motion tracking in remote rehabilitation, while the YOLOv8 models offer better spatial detail at the expense of speed and stability.

title: Intelligent Video Surveillance Systems With Violence Detection
authors: R.R Ishivardhan Reddy, P Kirubanantham, D Neeraj Kumar Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In recent years, the increasing prevalence of security threats and acts of human Violence has necessitated the development of advanced video surveillance systems capable of real-time detection and response. This project presents an innovative approach to enhancing the capabilities of video surveillance systems through the integration of YOLO (You Only Look Once), a state-of-the-art object detection algorithm, for the specific task of human Violence detection. The proposed Intelligent Video Surveillance System leverages the speed and accuracy of YOLOv8 to detect violent activities in live video streams. YOLO’s ability to simultaneously identify and classify objects within a single pass through the network makes it particularly well-suited for real-time surveillance applications. The system employs a YOLOv8 model that has been fine-tuned on a diverse dataset of violence and normal activities, enabling it to distinguish between various forms of human Violence, such as physical altercations, aggressive gestures, and unmannered Pose. Key components of the system include video feed acquisition, preprocessing, YOLOv8-based object detection, and post-processing techniques to reduce false positives. The proposed system offers several advantages over traditional surveillance approaches. It significantly reduces the workload of human operators by automating the detection process, ensuring continuous monitoring, and responding promptly to potentially dangerous situations. Moreover, the integration of YOLOv8 allows for scalability and adaptability, making it suitable for deployment in various surveillance environments, from public spaces and transportation hubs to private facilities.

title: Behavior Recognition Based on Multimodal Information of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Swarm of DeepSeek V3
authors: Xuanyuan Shi, Weifeng Liu, Wanyu Li
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: This study proposes a method for behavior recognition of UAV swarms based on multimodal information using the DeepSeek-V3 large model, aiming to address the issues of accuracy and robustness in UAV swarm behavior recognition in complex dynamic scenarios. By fusing static attributes with dynamic radar measurement data, a unified input representation framework is constructed, and the self-attention mechanism of DeepSeek-V3 is used to model spatiotemporal dependencies. Innovatively, the DeepSeek-V3 large model is proposed for recognizing the behavior of UAV swarms, and a prompt optimization strategy is adopted instead of traditional fine-tuning methods to guide the model to output results of behavior classification, formation matching, and anomaly detection. Experiments show that in a swarm composed of 4 Matrice 300 RTK UAVs, the average accuracy of this method in behavior classification tasks reaches 89.3 %, the formation pattern matching degree is 84.7 %, the comprehensive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex> score for anomaly detection is 0.84, and the mean absolute error (MAE) for trajectory prediction is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 1 5}$</tex> meters, providing an efficient solution for intelligent collaborative control of UAV swarms.

title: Note-Bert: Medical report classification method based on feature fusion and memory enhancement
authors: Chaolei He, Li Fang, Chenglong Song, Chen Qiang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Medical text categorization is an important task in Natural Language Processing (NLP). Current training data for large language models usually come from the Internet, and thus the generalization ability of large language models is poor when it comes to domains such as healthcare. To address this problem, we propose a DL framework called Note-BERT to improve the model’s classification effect in the case of sparse samples. Current mainstream language models usually use a single feature extraction algorithm to convert textual information into signals, which is not sufficient to fully extract the information in text. Therefore, we propose to fuse the features extracted from text by basic BERT and pre-trained RNN feature extraction modules. A small amount of data is not enough to support a transformer model to perform the classification task correctly. Based on this problem we also designed a keyword extraction module to enhance the weight of disease-related words on the feature vector. In addition, we expanded the dataset using the masking mechanism of BERT to improve the robustness of the Note-BERT model. Experimental results show that our Note-BERT tests 3% more correctly on the congenital heart disease ultrasound report dataset compared to the BERT model. This shows its potential as a classification framework for sparse datasets.

title: A Study of IGC Creation Based on Algorithmic Imaginary on Rednote
authors: Weisu Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Against the background of digital media, this study explores Influencer-Generated Content (IGC) creation on Xiaohongshu (Rednote) through semi-structured interviews with 11 influencers. This study aims to reveal how influencers adapt their content to fit algorithmic imaginary. It indicates that they adopt data-driven strategies, structured optimization, and expressions of “real sense”. Such practices lead to real-time iteration but cause content homogenization, exaggeration, and authenticity compromise. Influencers, driven by traffic anxiety, commercial pressure, and recognition of fans, navigate tensions between algorithmic expectations and ethical content creation. It constructs an interaction framework between the algorithmic imaginary and IGC creation, identifies core characteristics of IGC creation and the reverse shaping pathway, and clarifies psychological motivations, offering references for platform algorithm optimization and ethical creation.

title: III-Nitride Optical Devices with Epoxy Lenses for Braille Character Recognition
authors: Hongyu Cheng, Sirui Li, Yilin He, Kai Ma, Jiahao Yin, Liang Chen, Kwai Hei Li
abstract: Real-time Braille recognition technology is critical for the vision-impaired to access tactile information and participate in communication. Traditional Braille learning poses significant challenges, particularly for late-onset blindness cases requiring prolonged training. This work presents a contactless Braille recognition system based on a fully integrated optical sensor platform. The monolithic GaN-on-sapphire chip serves dual functions as a light source and a photodetector, minimizing the device footprint. Through the ray-tracing simulation, the hemispheric epoxy lens with optimized geometric parameters is incorporated for consistent and excellent Braille detection. The integrated device demonstrates rapid response characteristics and operational stability when processing arranged Braille patterns, with extracted photocurrent signals processed by microcontroller circuitry. The line-scanning results undergo wireless transmission via Bluetooth to portable mobile devices, enabling the conversion into accessible audio-visual formats. This innovative design not only enables efficient Braille recognition but also offers potential for advanced human-machine interfaces with broad applicability in assistive technologies and beyond.

title: Preparation of Mg Salt-Modified Fly Ash and its Adsorption Performance on Congo Red Dye
authors: Dong Xue, Yuanfeng Hui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Effective removal of dyes from wastewater is important to curb their harmful effects on the environment and human health. In this study, MgCl<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> combined with NaOH was used to modify fly ash (FA) and utilize it as an adsorbent for Congo red (CR) dye. The response surface method was used to optimize the determination of the optimal adsorption conditions: the maximum CR removal rate of 98.12% was achieved at a CR concentration of 30 mg/L, pH value of 8.5, temperature of 35.73°C, adsorption time of 60 min, and adsorbent dose of 0.849 g/L. The adsorption isotherms and adsorption kinetic curves were fitted with Langmuir and pseudo-second-order kinetic models, respectively, showing the chemisorption of CR on FA. This study presents a new, cost-effective and energy-efficient method to modify fly ash (RFA) to produce an efficient adsorbent with potential for industrial dye wastewater treatment.

title: Microfluidic Biosensor Response Model Considering Two-Layer Adsorption
authors: Ivana Jokić, Miloš Frantlović, Olga Jakšić, Katarina Radulović, Predrag Krstajić, Koushik Guha
abstract: Specific attributes of microfluidic adsorption-based sensors of biomolecules are the process of convection of the analyzed sample in a flow-through reaction chamber, and slow diffusion of large analyte molecules in the sample toward the adsorption sites on the sensing surface and away from them. Apart from that, some biomolecules (e.g. proteins) interact between themselves, thus forming multilayer adsorbed structures, while some experiments are designed so that target molecules capturing and signal amplification are achieved through multilayer adsorption. Therefore, it is important to take into account mass transfer (convection and diffusion), and multilayer adsorption in the analysis of microfluidic biosensor response. In this paper, we present a simple model of sensor response in the case of two-layer adsorption coupled with mass transfer. The developed model is an important result, because it enables the analysis of the influence of mass transfer processes on the sensor response. This is useful for the optimization of sensor design and experiments, which are aimed to decrease the influence of mass transfer on the response kinetics. The model also enables correct interpretation of measurement results. Additionally, the model is devised in a convenient form for future analyses of stochastic fluctuations of sensor response, and for the development of a theoretical model of sensor adsorption-desorption noise.

title: Multi-Stage Intelligent Control Scheme for Frequency Regulation of Time Delayed Multi-Area Power System
authors: Pawan Kumar Pathak, Anil Kumar Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This article presents a cascaded multistage control architecture termed as PID with filter in combination with one plus proportional-derivative (PIDn-(1+PD)) for frequency regulation of multi-area power systems (PSs) with communication time delay (CTD). To obtain a more realistic design, nonlinearities such as dead bands, rate constraints and CTD of one second in each area are considered. A bio-inspired metaheuristic termed as starfish optimization algorithm (SOA) is chosen to select the optimal solution of the PIDn-(1+PD) controller. To assess the superiority of the proposed control scheme, a comparative analysis with SOA-tuned PID and SOA-tuned PIDn controller is performed. Robust operation of the proposed SOA: PIDn-(1+PD) controller is evaluated under parametric variations of PS’s gain and time constant of each area. Finally, to showcase the performance, overshoot (OS), undershoot (US), settling time (t<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf>) and maximum frequency deviation (Δf) is considered against step load perturbations in each area.

title: Impact of Preamble Sequence Design on Device Activity Detection in mMTC: A Comparison of Zadoff-Chu, Gold, and PN Sequences
authors: Divya Yadav, Saikat Majumder, Ajay Singh Raghuvanshi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Massive machine-type communication (mMTC) is a foundational technology for the Internet of Things (IoT), where reliable Device Activity Detection (DAD) is critical, especially in grant-free random access environments. This study explores how different preamble sequences influence DAD performance by evaluating Zadoff-Chu (ZC), Gold, and Pseudo-Noise (PN) sequences. The findings reveal that sequence selection plays a vital role in detection performance, particularly across varying device activation levels. The results demonstrate that ZC-based preambles, with their inherently structured and deterministic design, deliver outstanding correlation properties that significantly enhance device activity detection accuracy, outperforming the more random-like sequences when leveraged with the proposed Deep Multilayer Perceptron (DMLP) model.

title: Reduced Order Modelling of Hybrid Power Plant Using Differentiation and Routh Array
authors: V. P. Sharma, Ankit Bhatt, A. Mathur, V. P. Singh, T. K. Bashishtha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This research develops model minimization method to create simplified models from higher-order systems. This method is applied in both single input-single output (SISO) and multiple input-multiple output (MIMO) systems. The proposed method integrates differentiation with the Routh array method to perform model order reduction. Routh array method determines the denominator polynomial coefficients while differentiation method providing the numerator polynomial coefficients. The main strength of model minimization method lies in preserving model stability if the original system maintains stability. The validity of this approach is demonstrated through its application to transfer function of 13<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>-order hybrid power plant, which produces five reduced order models ranging from sixth to second order. The analysis includes step responses along with Bode diagrams and Nyquist responses from high-level systems and lower-level models that follow a comparative presentation. The performance assessment includes a tabulation of metrics such as rise time, peak value, transient time, settling time, undershoot, and overshoot.

title: A Predictive Analysis of lap time in Formula 1 using Machine Learning
authors: Amitesh Ranjan Patro, Rajapurohitham Sahana, Shivansh Gautam, R Sapna
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Forecasting lap time in Formula 1 is challenging because of the nature of the data to have complex relationships between the features. This research paper discusses various machine learning models like Decision Tree Regression, Random Forest Regression, Gradient Boosting Regression(GBR), K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), and XGBoosting(Extreme Gradient Boosting) to forecast the lap times of races. The data were curated by removing the outliers in the data set and normalizing the data, improving the models’ accuracy. Each model uniquely deals with the dataset, with Random Forest Regression giving the best results, having an $\mathrm{R}^{2}$ score for the training data equal to 0.9969 and the $\mathrm{R}^{2}$ score of the test data equal to 0.9927 while having low MSE and MAE. This shows the predictive potential of ensemble-based machine learning models, especially the Random Forest Regression, when making predictions on complex data sets such as that of Formula 1. This can have several applications and can benefit teams in building better strategies and performing performance analyses.

title: ORCHID: Tessellation-Based Cylindrical Deployment Protocol for Energy-Efficient Coverage in Three-Dimensional Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: David W. Starr, Habib M. Ammari
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) play a critical role in environmental monitoring, surveillance, and battlefield communications. There has been an increasing demand for WSNs that optimize network lifetime and energy consumption, a critical design challenge. Previous research has made use of two separate optimization paths: global deployment geometry to reduce communication costs to transmit to the Base Station (BS), or optimization of local network topology to improve routing efficiency. In this paper, we introduce the Optimal Rhombic Cylindrical Hybrid Intelligent Deployment (ORCHID) protocol that will synergize the two optimization paths. ORCHID operates by considering tessellation within a geometrically optimized cylinder. This structure enables an intelligent protocol architecture, featuring a deterministic, energy-aware cluster head selection process that replaces probabilistic mechanisms found in other protocols. We will compare the performance of this protocol to a previously proposed cylindrical LEACH implementation. Through simulations, ORCHID shows improvements in network lifetime, cumulative throughput, and energy consumption. The protocol has very low overhead, which will be scaled along with performance to compare to the most recent similar protocols such as PEG-GA-VC(3) (2019), a Hybrid k-means clustering algorithm (2017), and LEACH3D (2015).

title: Efficient Privacy-Preserving Record Linkage Method Based on Attribute Encryption
authors: Yinan Song, Shumin Han, Yizi Wang, Fengyan Sun
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: With the rapid growth of information in recent years, privacy leakage has become a pressing concern. Privacy-Preserving Record Linkage has received increasing attention for its ability to enable data matching while protecting security and confidentiality. However, existing multi-party PPRL methods, though efficient in data integration, suffer from risks of private key leakage and involve overly complex processes. To address these limitations, we propose an Attribute-Based Encryption approach for PPRL. In our scheme, private keys are generated based on user attributes, ensuring that only users whose attributes satisfy the predefined access policy can decrypt the data. This effectively mitigates the risk of private key leakage by means of an efficient access control policy. Experiments show that this method has higher linkage quality and data matching accuracy than other PPRL methods, better privacy protection, and is more suitable for secure computing.

title: Lossless and Scalable Secret Image Sharing with Extended Bit-Depth Support using Polynomial Interpolation
authors: Rahul M. Bagdi, Jibi Abraham, Digambar Padulkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Secret Image Sharing (SIS) has become a powerful technique for safeguarding sensitive images by splitting them into multiple shares, each individually meaningless yet collectively capable of reconstructing the original when a threshold number of shares is provided. This paper presents an Enhanced Lossless Secret Image Sharing (SIS) scheme designed to securely divide grayscale, color, and high-bit-depth medical images into multiple shares. The method employs polynomial interpolation over large prime fields combined with efficient bit-packing to achieve exact recovery without pixel distortion or truncation. By supporting extended bit-depths such as 24-bit color and 32-bit medical imaging, the scheme overcomes traditional limitations in lossless reconstruction, security, and computational efficiency. The proposed approach simplifies share generation while maintaining strict threshold-based secrecy, making it highly suitable for secure image sharing across critical domains like healthcare, defense, and secure multimedia transmission.

title: Secure V2P Risk Prediction: A Decentralized Federated Deep Learning Approach
authors: Rihab Hmaied, Takoua Kefi, Ryma Abassi
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is increasingly adopted to tackle privacy concerns in Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), particularly within Vehicle-to-Pedestrian (V2P) communication frameworks. Extending our previous research on decentralized federated learning frameworks using classical machine learning algorithms, this study investigates the efficacy of advanced Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), specifically ResNet18, ResNet34, MobileNetV2, and EfficientNetB0, within a decentralized FL context. We comparatively evaluate these models using performance metrics such as accuracy, loss, training time, and communication delay. Our experimental results demonstrate that ResNet34 achieves superior overall performance, offering the best trade-off between accuracy, convergence efficiency, and reduced communication overhead. This research confirms the applicability and advantages of CNN-based decentralized federated learning as a robust solution for secure and efficient V2P communication.

title: Coherent Vibration Measurement Using a Fabry-Pérot Mode Locked Laser Diodes
authors: Wang Zi, Hao Song, Fei Guo, Dan Lu
abstract: A multiwavelength coherent vibration measurement scheme using a mode-locked laser diode is demonstrated. Non-contact measurement of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40-\text{Hz}$</tex> vibrating target is successfully achieved.

title: Cross-Modal Transformer-Based Tri-Modal Joint Representation Learning Model for Evaluating Toastmasters Public Speaking Skills
authors: Deng Mian
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Most of people engaged in public speaking to large or small groups who often experienced severe physical symptoms of anxiety such as blushing, shaking, pounding heart, and quivering voice et al. Some organizations such as Toastmaster international try to help people to improve their public speaking skills by providing a supportive and positive environment for individual to practice, and speakers could receive feedback from their peers on their performance during each meeting. It is expected that there is a tool which could provide assessment more often, easy and without anybody help. Assessing speaking ability is complex, involving both feature extraction from unimodal data such as text, speech, and images, and fusion of cross-modal data, and is a challenging problem to be solved in the field of multimodal learning analytics. In this paper, we first design different feature extraction models for the three modalities of visual, auditory and textual information. The proposed facial feature extraction model based on improved PFLD is able to use a multi-scale region learning strategy to better capture the details and differences of facial features and enhance the extraction of visual features. The proposed Transformer-TCN speech feature extraction model consists of an encoder module, a feature fusion module, and a time-domain convolutional network, which improves the accuracy and reliability when processing time-series data. Thirdly, we used a pre-trained BERT model with a 12-layer Transformer structure for text feature extraction. Based on the extracted features from three modalities, this paper proposes a TMJP(Tri-Modal Joint Representation) learning method based on the cross-modal Transformer, which is centered on the cross-modal attention mechanism. The cross-modal attention mechanism adapts the flow from one modality to another by focusing on information from different modalities. Comparative experiments demonstrate that the proposed TMJP public speech evaluation model achieves the best performance in all three metrics compared to other multimodal analysis models, and could be used for Toastmasters students public speaking evaluation tool. When more modal data are available in the future, it is flexible to extend to four, five modal data or even more based on the design principle of the method.

title: Site Suitability Analysis for Optimal EV Charging Station Deployment
authors: Garima Panwar, Sunanda Sinha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The rapid growth in EV adoption calls for a well-planned charging infrastructure to support their widespread use. This study presents a GIS-based site suitability analysis aimed at identifying optimal locations for EV charging stations. Key spatial and environmental factors, including proximity to major roads, railway stations, petrol stations, public amenities, population density, slope, and normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), were considered in the site selection process. The spatial and non-spatial data related to these criteria were collected and analyzed in ArcGIS. Based on this, a suitability map was generated that categorizes the study area into different suitability zones. The results offer a strategic framework for urban planners and policymakers to optimize EV charging infrastructure placement, ensuring enhanced accessibility, economic feasibility, and promoting sustainable urban mobility.

title: Hybrid Ensemble Learning Model for Fraud Detection in Ethereum Transactions
authors: Vasavi Chithanuru, Mangayarkarasi Ramaiah, Vanmathi Chandrasekaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Ethereum's distributed ledger technology operates on decentralized principles that have transformed how digital assets are exchanged. Yet the platform's underlying design contains security weaknesses that expose users to multiple forms of malicious activity, such as fraudulent wallet schemes, network identity manipulation, pyramid financial structures, and service interruption attacks. This study aims to address the cyber-attacks on the Ethereum platform by developing an innovative ensemble machine-learning framework based on a refined feature set derived from real-time Ethereum transactions. The proposed framework employed a method that encapsulates the feature selection process, leveraging the advantages of machine learning algorithms to derive the refined feature set. The conducted experiment employs Random Forest and XGBoost, to identify the significant features. To mitigate the overfitting issue in the proposed machine learning model, the SMOTEENN (Synthetic Minority Oversampling Edited Nearest Neighbors) technique, has applied. The experimental results reveal that the proposed model exceeds the performance of existing fraud detection approaches, achieving a 99.4% accuracy and a Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC) of 94.9%.

title: Assessment of Factors Influencing Consumer Behaviour in Electric Vehicle Adoption in India
authors: Amit Kumar Bansal, Ayush Kumar Pandey, Garima Panwar, Sonia Chahar Srivastava, Aneesh Prabhakar, Kapil Pareek
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: India has strong initiatives towards energy security, environmental pollution, and reducing the use of fossil fuels. Furthermore, moving to electric vehicles (EVs) is an essential step toward sustainable transportation. Even with government programs and increased awareness, EV adoption is still quite low. The growth of the EV industry and consumer preferences are influenced by several factors, including technological, policy, infrastructure, and economic considerations. In this study, thirteen main factors influencing EV adoption in India are carefully analyzed and ranked using the Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process (FAHP). FAHP is a popular multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) technique that utilizes expert opinions and pairwise comparisons to provide a systematic assessment of multiple elements. Major drivers examined in the study include battery technology, car performance, government incentives, charging infrastructure, and upfront expenses. By giving these parameters relative weights, the study determines which enablers and barriers are most important in affecting the adoption of EVs. Policy awareness and lack of Government Incentives and Financial Support are the primary factors influencing EV adoption, according to the study, with Battery technology, high upfront cost, and coming of age being of less priority. Consumers' worries about high upfront costs and a lack of charging infrastructure continue to highlight the need for new financing options and battery innovations.

title: Optimization of a Smart Campus System Based on Data Visualization Concepts
authors: Yuanhao Liu, Xinran Ba, Mingyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Classroom resource management is a critical component of smart campus development. Traditional classroom reservation systems often rely on manual operations or simplistic web-based mechanisms, resulting in inefficient resource utilization and poor management practices. This study introduces a smart classroom scheduling system that integrates data visualization techniques, database management, and a greedy optimization algorithm to improve user experience and resource allocation. By employing front-end and back-end separation, interactive interfaces, and intelligent recommendations, the system significantly enhances reservation efficiency.

title: Deep Learning-Based Classification of Brain Tumors in MRI Using CNNs and Transfer Learning
authors: Dhruv Choudhary, Aditya Dubey, Dhananjay Bisen
abstract: Brain tumor are a significant health issue, and early discovery is pivotal in deciding effective treatment strategies. This design introduces a deep literacy- grounded system for brain tumor discovery and bracket from glamorous resonance imaging (MRI). With the operation of folding networks (CNNS) along with transfer literacy, the system is suitable to descry a broad diapason of brain tumors similar as gliomas, meningiomas, and pituitary tumors. This involves pivotal preprocessing way like data addition and normalization for making the model robust and generalizable. Measures like delicacy, delicacy, recall, and F1 score are employed to dissect the performance of the model. The findings indicate that this model yields believable individual prognostications and can grease well- observed clinical opinions of health occupational cousins. This exploration reveals the eventuality of deep literacy styles for enhancing medical imaging and individual protocols. This design involves the bracket of brain tumors through deep literacy styles, in this case, using a CNN stationed in PyTorch. The model was trained on a dataset of labeled MRI images representing colorful types of tumors, similar as glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumors, and no tumor.

title: Noise-aware Speech Separation Based on Dual-Path RNN Model
authors: Tongkun Xing, Ding Ding, Nan Liu, Xudong Zhou, Fengming Liu, Yu Wang, Jing Zhang, Guozheng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Deep learning-based speech separation has made remarkable progress recently, especially in time-domain methods such as dual-path recurrent neural networks (DPRNN). Despite these advancements, existing methods encounter significant challenges when addressing highly complex acoustic environments or meeting increasingly stringent separation quality requirements. In this paper, we propose improvements to the DPRNN framework, including optimized convolutional parallelism, an attention module for feature enhancement, and an improved residual module. Evaluations on the self-synthesized dataset and the widely adopted LibriMix benchmark show that our improved DPRNN outperforms the original model in terms of signal-to-distortion ratio (SDRi) and scale-invariant signal-to-noise ratio (SI-SNRi) with limited increase in model size. Its practical applicability is further verified in challenging environments, which will help develop efficient and robust speech separation systems.

title: Ensuring Fair Credit Access with Algorithmic Transparency
authors: Leela Krishna Yenigalla
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: The integration of cloud-native data engineering into credit decision-making systems has transformed financial services, enabled unprecedented processing efficiency while raising significant concerns regarding algorithmic bias. As financial institutions increasingly rely on sophisticated machine learning models for credit evaluation, hidden patterns in historical data, proxy variables, and sampling biases can perpetuate discrimination against protected groups. This article examines current approaches to algorithmic transparency by reviewing technical, operational, and governance components implemented across financial institutions. The paper synthesizes best practices from existing literature on comprehensive decision logging, realtime monitoring dashboards, statistical methodologies for bias assessment, and integration with cloud-native observability stacks. Through this systematic review, we identify how financial institutions are working to ensure fair credit access while leveraging advanced analytics capabilities. We discuss documented improvements in key fairness metrics, including disparate impact ratio and equal opportunity difference across diverse demographic groups, and highlight areas where further research is needed to address remaining challenges in algorithmic fairness.

title: Enhancing UAV Communication Security Through HSM-Based Cryptographic Key Protection
authors: Salah Dine Maham, Guy Pujolle, Atiq Ahmed, Dominique Gaiti, Ali Remili
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have seen extensive growth in both civilian and military sectors, driven by their versatility, ease of deployment, and expanding range of applications. However, this expansion has also exposed UAV systems to a growing number of cybersecurity threats. The MAVLink protocol, widely adopted for UAV-ground station communication, lacks native encryption, making it susceptible to interception and manipulation. This paper proposes a comprehensive solution based on the use of Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect cryptographic keys and secure data transmission using the ChaCha20 encryption algorithm. Our approach integrates the HSM into the drone system, ensuring that sensitive keys are securely generated, stored, and accessed. We present the architecture, implementation details, and simulation results that confirm the feasibility and efficiency of the proposed solution, highlighting its potential to significantly enhance the security of UAV communications with minimal performance overhead.

title: A Simplified Approach of Capacitor Sizing in FC-MLC for Wind Turbine based Smart Grid
authors: Rishabh Kumar Sharma, Sumit K. Chattopadhyay
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents a method for reducing the capacitor size in Flying Capacitor Multilevel Converters (FCMLCs) used in Wind Energy Conversion Systems (WECS), specifically for Type-4 WECS. The proposed approach optimizes the energy storage capacity and voltage balancing mechanisms within the inverter, eliminating the need for closed-loop control. This results in a simplified system that effectively addresses the space and weight constraints typically encountered in offshore wind turbine applications. A comprehensive analysis of Type-4 WECS is conducted to explore its key components and associated challenges, including an examination of the worst-case capacitor requirements. To validate the concept, a simulation model is developed in MATLAB/Simulink, demonstrating the feasibility of the method.

title: Simulation Analysis of Thermal Environment in Learning Areas Based on the Climate of Cold Regions
authors: Xubo Xiao, Yaodan Chi, Yao Zhang, Junxi Wang, Qingcai Zhou, Chao Wang, Ning Sun, Wenqi Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: With the advancement of education modernization and the promotion of green building philosophies, optimizing learning environments to enhance learning efficiency has become a critical issue in educational facility construction. This study, grounded in cold climate characteristics, creatively investigated the quantitative impact of fan placement within Personalized Thermal Comfort Systems (PCS) on localized thermal environment regulation in learning areas using Cradle CFD software. A room model incorporating a human body, desk, and fan was constructed. Simulations of three typical fan configurations-front-facing, left, and right-were conducted using the RNG turbulence model, monitoring the temperature and thermal distribution at key human body parts. Results demonstrated that fan placement significantly influenced personalized thermal comfort and cooling efficiency across different human body parts. The research revealed that the forced convection heat transfer mechanism, driven by direct airflow, is crucial for enhancing heat transfer efficiency. The front-facing placement, by fully leveraging forced convection, exhibited a significant advantage in cooling effectiveness for the face, chest, and legs. Its overall temperature reduction was substantially superior to side placements; specifically, face cooling effectiveness decreased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32-76 {\%}$</tex> when using side placements compared to the front-facing setup. This study provides quantitative technical support for indoor thermal environment regulation in educational buildings in cold regions, holding significant importance for enhancing indoor environmental quality and promoting building energy efficiency.

title: Neural Network-Based Optimization of Radiant Heat for Three-Layer Glass
authors: Yezheng Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Building windows in northern winters exhibit significant heat loss in the 1000-2000 nm thermal radiation band, where heating systems primarily radiate. The insufficient spectral selectivity of traditional glass leads to low heating energy efficiency. Existing research reveals insufficient fine-grained optimization of multilayer glass for this specific band and a lack of precise quantification of the nonlinear coupling effects between thickness combinations and thermal radiation transmittance. This paper aims to minimize radiant heat transmission through a three-layer glass structure in the 1000-2000 nm band by optimizing the thickness of each layer. Inspired by neural network training principles, the study parameterizes glass thicknesses and constructs a forward model from thickness to spectral transmission characteristics based on thin-film optics theory. The total transmitted radiant energy within the target band is defined as the optimization objective function. Automatic differentiation is employed to calculate gradients, and the Adam optimization algorithm, combined with a multi-start strategy, is used for iterative optimization of the thickness combination. The results indicate that the optimal three-layer glass thickness combination is L1* ≈ 9.39mm, L2* ≈ 8.61mm, and L3* ≈ 9.49mm. With this structure, the total transmitted radiant energy in the 1000-2000 nm band is reduced to 126.79 W/m,<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> approximately 32.11% lower than that of a single-layer glass of equivalent total thickness, significantly enhancing the blockage of specific-band thermal radiation. The proposed neural network strategy solves the nonlinear optimization of thickness and radiation transmittance in multilayer glass, providing a data-driven basis and efficient pathway for designing energy-saving glass.

title: Energy-Aware Deep Neural Networks with Intelligent Adaptive Inference for Sustainable IoT Deployments
authors: Laxman Kisan Lonkar, B. Malarkodi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: An adaptive Long Short-Term Memory (Adaptive LSTM) is proposed in this paper to provide real-time energy efficient anomaly detection in resource-limited Internet of Things (IoT) healthcare systems. The model is designed to adjust the learning complexity in a dynamic manner by using optimized gating mechanisms and dropout regularization to balance accuracy and energy efficiency. The developed model is evaluated on the balanced IoT healthcare dataset, comprising of 67, 545 instances and 5 physiological features labelled with binary anomaly indicators. The Adaptive-LSTM architecture integrates dual-layer LSTM blocks with a dropout rate of 40% which is followed by a dense sigmoid classifier. The proposed model is compared against standard LSTM, GRU, CNN, Autoencoder and Transformer. Results show that the Adaptive-LSTM achieved a classification accuracy of 99.68%, while maintaining a latency as low as 0.89 seconds. The simulated energy consumption is 1.05 mJ. While GRU offer faster inference time of 0.78 seconds, its accuracy is $\mathbf{9 7. 4 5 \%}$. Adaptive-LSTM provides a strong trade-off between the classification accuracy, computation time and energy efficiency. This makes the model suitable for edge-based IoT devices where the operation precision and power consumption are crucial performance factor. The model provides seamless scalability across other temporal and anomaly-based IoT applications.

title: Secure Cloud-Based Encryption Scheme for User Access Control with Revocation and Searchability
authors: Aoran Di, Jinguo Li, Chengming Li, Jifei Xiao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: In the context of searchable encryption, the semi-trusted nature of cloud servers can result in incorrect or incomplete search results. To address this issue and tackle problems in traditional CP-ABE schemes where plaintext access policies may lead to sensitive information leakage and complex revocation processes for malicious users, the paper introduces a fine-grained result verifiable searchable encryption scheme with forward and backward security, revocability, and partial policy concealment. This scheme allows data users to query keywords on encrypted datasets to retrieve files and employs a verification mechanism to ensure data privacy protection and the reliability of search results. By incorporating Merkle hash trees with Rank values and counting Bloom filters, the scheme not only validates the correctness of the dataset but also enables precise filtering of correct results and indicates the number of eligible files not returned, ensuring the integrity of the dataset.

title: NA-AEKF: A NLOS-Aware Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter for Robust Indoor Localization
authors: Moussa Taha, Olivier Berder, Antoine Courtay, Mickaël Le Gentil
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Accurate indoor localization remains challenging due to frequent Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) conditions, which degrade the performance of Ultra-Wideband (UWB)-based positioning systems. Traditional filters like the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and its variants assume ideal Line-of-Sight (LOS) scenarios and struggle in complex indoor environments. To address this, we propose the NLOS-Aware Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter (NA-AEKF), designed to improve robustness and accuracy under dynamic conditions. NA-AEKF uses machine learning to classify real-time measurements as LOS or NLOS, adjusting filter parameters accordingly. This integration improves adaptability to changing conditions and mitigates NLOS-related errors. Simulations show that NA-AEKF outperforms EKF, the Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF), the Adaptive EKF (AEKF) and the Improved adaptive EKF (I-AEKF) [1], achieving higher precision in complex indoor settings.

title: Optimal positioning method for books on high-density bookshelves based on YOLOv7
authors: Cheng Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In order to improve the retrieval efficiency of massive book resources, it is necessary to realize the accurate positioning of high-density bookshelf books, and an optimal positioning method of high-density bookshelf books based on YOLO v7 is proposed. The image global information dependence model of high-density bookshelf books is constructed, the grid module of book query is established by sparse query mechanism, the SENet structure of attention mechanism module is embedded in YOLOv7, the shallowest ELAN module is incorporated into the feature pyramid of high-density bookshelf books, and the shallow features and deep features are integrated across layers by jumping connection, so that the information exchange between different channels is effectively enhanced. The feature fusion of high-density bookshelf books between different convolution groups is realized. The image features of high-density bookshelf books are extracted by the backbone network, and the feature fusion is carried out by the neck network. Finally, the detection and classification of specific targets of high-density bookshelf books are completed at the output end. The simulation results show that this method can effectively realize the accurate positioning of high-density bookshelf books, and the positioning accuracy and learning efficiency are significantly improved compared with traditional methods.

title: PneuNet: A Compact Deep CNN Architecture for Pneumonia Classification in Chest Radiographs
authors: Meet Sadariya, Kumar Parmar, Nevil Vasani, Hiren Kukadiya, Pranav Gediya
abstract: This paper introduces PneuNet, which is a specialized lightweight CNN model aimed at the binary classification of pneumonia in chest X-rays of children. Unlike other models, he existing deep learning models apply a computational burden and require a pre-trained network, so they utilize large scale frameworks which are not efficient. Thus, PneuNet's design adopts a seven-layered structure that achieves a better balance between functionality and efficiency. The model has been trained and tested for a clinically verified dataset containing 5856 publicly available images. There is a systematic algorithmic approach to preprocessing aimed at high-quality data augmentation and standardization. With PneuNet, the accuracy reached is of 96% in the test set with good precision and recall particularly in cases of pneumonia. PneuNet's structure offers progressive filter scaling, global average pooling, and dropout regularization, enabling its use in resource-constrained environments. The results suggest that PneuNet significantly improves diagnostic support for health systems that lack radiologists or high-end systems making it a practical solution.

title: Physics-Informed Adaptive Attention Mechanism for Multi-Type Battery Health State Prediction
authors: Xudong Liu
abstract: Accurate battery health forecasting is vital for energy storage system reliability and efficiency. However, forecasting health states of various battery chemistries remains challenging due to differences in electrochemical characteristics and degradation modes. This work presents a new Physics-Informed Adaptive Attention (PIAA) mechanism, integrating electrochemical knowledge with deep learning for multi-type battery health forecasting. It involves three innovative designs: an encoder merging voltage, current, and capacity degradation features; a Wasserstein distance-based layer retrieving geometric features of performance evolution; and a convolution-attention temporal extractor aggregating local and global processing. Large-scale validation on four chemistries shows PIAA’s superiority: a 12.4% MAPE and a 71.2% ACC on CALB cells, outperforming MLP and CNN. It exhibits significant cross-domain transfer abilities from lab to industrial cells. Future work will enhance universality, optimize the encoder, and propose lightweight designs for limited-resource systems.

title: Design and Control of Self Adjusting PID controller using Support Vector Machine Technique
authors: Himanshu Bhagwan Gupta, Usha Tiwari, V. P. Singh, Nirmal Saini
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents PID control approach based on the support vector machine (SVM) to effectively track the speed of turbine engine. The dynamics of a turbine engine are represented in tranfer function form and further SVM’s nonlinear function approximation capabilities are utilized to accurately track the engine’s speed. An objective function is defined for tracking the engine’s speed using the SVM based PID model. To obtain the best performance, the PID controller’s parameters are adjusted using SVM based technique. Comparative analysis is performed by plotting speed of engine with and without SVM based controllers.

title: RASE-SQUNO: Relation-Aware Single Q-Network with Uncertainty-guided Exploration
authors: Xiangcheng Xiao, Tao Deng
