publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: UNO is a challenging card game with incomplete information, large state space, sparse rewards, and randomness. Based on the Deep Monte Carlo (DMC) method, the DMC-Self agent was first applied, and Multi-DMC further improved efficiency through expert strategies and multi-stage learning. SQUNO later introduced a single Q-network to enhance convergence and generalization. Building on SQUNO, this paper proposes RASE-SQUNO, which achieves faster convergence, higher win rates $(\approx 58 \%-60 \%)$, and improved weighted scores $\boldsymbol{(} \boldsymbol{\approx} \mathbf{2 5}$) in the UNO $\mathbf{2 v} \mathbf{2}$ mode, outperforming SQUNO and Multi-DMC.

title: Research on the Energy Storage Capacity Substitution Effect of Electric Vehicle V2G in Industrial Parks Based on Monte Carlo Simulation
authors: Chenxin Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of electric vehicles (EVs), the disorderly large-scale integration of EVs into the power grid has imposed pressure on its safe and stable operation. However, leveraging the "mobile energy storage" capability of EVs, combined with an orderly charging/discharging strategy, can not only assist microgrids in peak shaving and valley filling—enhancing economic efficiency and stability—but also substitute traditional energy storage systems, thereby reducing microgrid operation and investment costs. This study proposes a V2G capacity substitution factor to quantify EVs' energy storage substitution effect and establishes an optimization model to minimize total power supply costs. The model considers time-of-use electricity pricing, actual EV travel demands, EV usage patterns in industrial parks, and other uncertainties to optimize energy storage configuration in a PV-storage-charging integrated microgrid. Probabilistic analysis is employed to mitigate source-load uncertainty, and Monte Carlo simulation is utilized to derive the V2G capacity substitution factor and the system’s minimal electricity procurement cost.

title: A Non-Isolated Switched capacitor- inductor based Modified Quadratic boost Converter
authors: Jayasri Boda, A V Giridhar, B L Narasimharaju, M F Baba, P. Raviteja
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper introduces a Modified high gain-Quadratic boost converter (MQBC) that is integrated with a boost structure at the front end, followed by switched capacitor-inductor (SCI) is presented in this article. In addition to this, a high gain is achieved due to the presence of SCI cell at the output side and reduces the voltage stress on semi-conductor devices. The main features of proposed (MQBC-SCI) converter has high voltage gain, continuous source current with less input/output current ripple, common ground and low voltage stress across the power devices. The brief discussion on proposed (MQBC-SCI) converter covers the steady state analysis, modes of operation, electric stress across the Semi-Conductor elements are presented in this article. Further a 40/400V, 300W converter is validated with simulation results.

title: Optimized Data Gathering in WSNs Using Multi-Fold Gravitational Search Algorithm with Mobile Agent Integration
authors: D. Bhanu, Arpit Arora, Laxminath Tripathy, Amritpal Sidhu, Satish Kumar R, Md Akram Ahmad
abstract: Regarding the field of precision agriculture, wireless sensor networks (WSN) make it possible to exercise control over a variety of environmental factors and crop conditions. An Internet of Things wireless sensor network (WSN) may make use of a mobile agent and the multi-fold gravitational search technique (MFGSA). That which is gravitational the cluster head (CH) is selected by the search algorithm (GSA), which also enhances the MA route to sensor nodes are involved. The allocation of the MA source for clustering nodes, and GSA improved the route to the destination. A comparison of the network efficiency and durability of the recommended technique with that of prior techniques is made. Using the GSA as a basis for MA itinerary preparation as contrasted to the ways of energy usage for duties. The innovative approach makes MA more effective achieving success, maintaining network stability, and using energy.

title: EMAT-Net: An Efficient Morphology-Aware Transformer Network for Alzheimer’s Disease Diagnosis with Limited Data
authors: Yanbing Lin, Meimei Li, Borui Chen, Wenjin Qin, Junjie Wang, Jiatong Xu, Wenjie Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Early and accurate diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is critical for patient care. However, deep learning models designed for this task often face two major challenges. First, hospitals may be unable to provide large-scale annotated medical datasets with regional characteristics. Second, the heterogeneous morphological features of brain atrophy, which are highly indicative of AD, have not been fully exploited in existing diagnostic tasks. To address these challenges, we propose an Efficient Morphology-Aware Transformer Network (EMAT-Net). This method leverages a pretrained Transformer-in-Transformer (TNT) model and introduces two key architectural innovations: a Morphology-Aware Patch Encoder (MAPE) and a Convolutional Feed-Forward Network (ConvFFN). In addition, a two-stage training strategy is employed, enabling the model to be finetuned with limited data while incorporating feature extraction capabilities that adapt to regional characteristics. Extensive experiments on the publicly available ADNI dataset demonstrate the significant advantages of EMAT-Net, which achieves performance comparable to state-of-the-art models trained on the full dataset while using only 20% of the labeled data.

title: Design and Implementation of Four-channel DC Output AC-DC-DC Power Supply for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Launch Vehicle
authors: Le Shang, Jie Zhang, Yujia Ge, Yuerong Sun, Xiaojuan Zhang, Danyu Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: To meet the stable power supply requirements for multi-vehicle drone swarm launch operations in high-altitude regions, this study addresses limitations of existing vehicle-mounted AC-DC power supplies, such as large output ripple, poor EMC, low conversion efficiency, unstable output, limited voltage types, large size, weak load capacity, and high thermal losses. An integrated multi-output AC-DC-DC power supply is developed. The design uses a forward-boost LLC topology and PWM modulation to convert AC 220V to DC 28V, which is further converted into four regulated outputs: DC +5V/1A, DC -5V/1.5A, and DC ±12V/1A. A three-level cascaded topology and a feedforward-feedback compound control circuit are used to suppress low-frequency ripple. Dual power supply parallel superposition and PWM modulation reduce high-frequency ripple. Active ripple compensation, multi-level π-type Chebyshev filtering, and three-dimensional layered differential shielding improve EMC performance. Experimental results show conversion efficiency exceeds 88%, with peak-to-peak ripple ≤28mV. The design meets GJB151B EMC standards and ensures reliable power delivery for drone swarm launch systems in high-altitude environments.

title: Mission-Driven Embedded Autonomy and Control Software Development: Digital Engineering Approaches to Bridge the Gap
authors: Vincent Rossignol, Ludovic Oddos, Robert Etter, Guilherme Goretkin, Cédric Pasteur
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper explores the integration of digital engineering approaches in the development of mission-driven embedded autonomy and control software. It addresses the challenges faced by engineers and operational experts due to the increasing automation in air operations. The proposed methodology leverages digital reference models to bridge the gap between operational needs and system development. By simulating mission environments, engineers can validate their designs early, while operators provide timely feedback. The paper highlights the use of tools like Ansys STK for mission analysis, AVxcelerate Sensors for sensor simulation, and SCADE for mission and control software development. It emphasizes a model-based digital engineering process that spans the entire lifecycle, from concept to deployment, ensuring efficient collaboration and accurate system representation. Case studies in space, commercial aviation and defense illustrate the practical applications and benefits of this approach, including cost reduction, enhanced accuracy, and improved system performance.

title: Differential-Linear Cryptanalysis of Block Cipher uBlock
authors: Xiaojuan Lu, Zixin Tan, Xuanrui Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Block, a flexible family of block ciphers, secured the top award in the inaugural National Cryptographic Algorithm Design Competition (2018) for its robust security, exceptional efficiency on both software and hardware platforms. Based on differential cryptanalysis and linear cryptanalysis, Langford and Hellman in 1994 introduced differential-linear cryptanalysis-a powerful hybrid technique now widely recognized and actively studied by cryptographers worldwide. In this paper, we present the differential-linear cryptanalysis of the uBlock128/128 from an algebraic perspective. Applying differential algebraic transitional form technique and imposing conditions technique, we exhaustively enumerated 1-bit input differences on reduced-round uBlock128/128 and derived a 3round differential-linear distinguisher. By exploiting this distinguisher, a partial key recovery attack can be performed that recovers 2 key bits with time and data complexities of $2^{\wedge} 22$ each. The distinguisher of 3-round uBlock128/128 has been fully verified by practical experiments conducted on a 4.20 GHz AMD 7950X3D CPU. As far as we know, this is the first differentiallinear attack and the first practical attack on this cipher.

title: Power Quality Enhancement of Weak Grid by UVT Theory-Based PV-DSTATCOM
authors: Mritunjaiya Mani Tripathi, Seethalekshmi K., Kuldeep Sahay
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Incorporating distributed energy sources (DER) and rectifier-based loads contributes to power quality (PQ) issues in a weak grid. One of the popular methods for tackling the PQ issue in the power system is the integration of a distribution static compensator (DSTATCOM) with solar PV. In this article, PV-DSTATCOM is linked with a three-phase weak grid under unbalanced and non-linear loading circumstances. This study proposes a control technique derived from unit vector templates (UVT). The UVT approach regulates the PV-DSTATCOM, and the maximum power point technique (MPPT) is utilized for controlling the boost converter. The grid and PV-DSTATCOM system have been designed and implemented using the MATLAB/Simulink platform, and the simulation results have been authenticated on a real-time simulator based on OPAL-RT. This control method enhances voltage quality at the point of common coupling (PCC) during grid voltage variations, effectively reduces the harmonic components in the grid current, under nonlinear load condition and under unbalanced load conditions, the grid current remains balanced. The findings show the efficacy of the UVT-based control over the synchronous reference frame-based controller.

title: Improvement in power sharing performance in an AC microgrid through PI controller approach under different load condition
authors: Sameer Bhambri, Vivek Shrivastava, Manoj Kumawat
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Droop characteristics based control approach is common in an operation of multiple inverters working conjunctively in an AC microgrid. The paper proposes a strategy for accurate proportional power sharing among inverters with less transients and fast dynamics in case of CIL (constant impedance load) and CPL (constant power load). A modified robust droop controller based strategy is proposed for voltage source inverter and small signal stability based modelling is used to identify and determine the control parameters to achieve reasonable damping using eigenvalue analysis. An equivalent thevenin model of VSI is formed and bode plots are drawn for corresponding transfer functions to select appropriate value of virtual resistor. The improved steady state and transient performance are achieved simultaneously with the proposed strategy thereby contributing better dynamics. Simulations with proposed approach are done in the MATLAB/SIMULINK plateform and its comparison is done to justify the efficacy of the proposed approach.

title: A Novel Framework for Focal EEG Classification Using Hybrid 2D Visualizations and Signal-Level Features
authors: Nikshitha, Rajani Rai B, Karunakara Rai B, A S Mamatha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Accurate classification of focal and non-focal EEG signals is critical for effective diagnosis and management of epilepsy. This work presents a novel hybrid framework that uniquely integrates signal processing and image-based analysis to capture the complex, nonlinear nature of brain dynamics. Filtered EEG signals are converted into composite 2D visual representations by combining Poincare plots, spectrograms, and recurrence plots-offering a rich fusion of time-frequency and phase-space information. Unlike conventional methods, the proposed approach extracts discriminative features not only from these hybrid images using statistical, entropy, and texture-based techniques but also from signal-domain characteristics rooted in Poincare lag analysis. These two domains are strategically fused into a unified feature space that enhances model generalization. Among the evaluated classifiers, an ensemble combining XGBoost and AdaBoost achieved the highest classification accuracy of 99.87%, along with robust sensitivity, specificity, and calibration performance. The proposed methodology demonstrates significant potential as a reliable, automated tool for focal EEG detection and offers a novel direction for integrative, image-assisted neurodiagnostic systems.

title: A Surface Plasmon Resonance Gas Sensor Leveraging BP and MXene for Enhanced Sensitivity
authors: Trideep Deb, Puspa Devi Pukhrambam, Abinash Panda
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study presents a highly sensitive surface plasmon resonance (SPR) sensor utilizing a multilayer structure composed of aNaF prism/TiO2/Ag/MXene/Ag/BP/Sensing medium. The sensor operates within the Kretschmann configuration, and its performance was evaluated using the finite element method (FEM). Through meticulous layer-bylayer optimization, the sensor achieved a maximum sensitivity of 210° per refractive index unit (RIU) for refractive index variations between $\mathbf{1. 0 0}$ and $\mathbf{1. 0 3}$. The incorporation of BP and MXene significantly enhances the sensor’s sensitivity compared to conventional designs, highlighting its potential for advanced gas sensing applications in visible light region.

title: Brand-Level Sentiment Analysis in the Telecom Domain Using Large Language Models
authors: Burak Kaya, Ali Buğra Kanburoğlu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: In recent years, sentiment analysis has become a critical tool for understanding public perception of brands, particularly in dynamic industries such as telecommunications. This study explores brand-level sentiment analysis in the telecom domain using both open-source and closed-source large language models (LLMs). We constructed a domain-specific dataset by collecting user-generated content from social media platforms, focusing on telecom-related discussions. To ensure real-time applicability, we prioritized small-scale models in the closedsource category due to their lower inference latency. We finetuned the open-source models on the telecom dataset, resulting in significantly improved performance compared to their closedsource counterparts. Among the fine-tuned models, Gemma3-1B achieved the highest F1-score, reaching 87.67 %, demonstrating its effectiveness in capturing sentiment in telecom-specific contexts. Our findings highlight the potential of domain-adapted open-source LLMs for efficient and accurate sentiment analysis in industry-specific applications.

title: A Discrete Luenberger Observer-based State of Charge Estimation for BMS Under Dynamic Load Condition
authors: Rahul Sarker, Christiaan Johannes Fourie, Takumi Mori
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Battery management systems are a crucial part of electric vehicles (EVs). Rechargeable batteries are the main fuel source of modern motorized EVs. In commercial EV battery packs, two of the most important parameters are the State of Charge (SOC) and State of Health (SOH). Real-time charge estimation of the battery is a preliminary and integral part of the battery management system. Over the decade, accurate SOC estimation methods have been an important field of study as electric mobility becomes more prevalent around the world. This paper proposes a state space model of a lithium-ion battery and estimates the SOC using a discrete Luenberger observer in dynamic load conditions to observe the SOC variation with the real and estimated models in a noisy environment. Also, the equivalent circuit model (ECM) is considered for the battery to calculate the numerical equations of the state observer. With the help of the initial SOC, a piecewise linear interpolation is used to find the SOC-OCV (open circuit voltage) relationship. The terminal voltage is also estimated from the true voltage and a Luenberger observer. The gain of the Luenberger observer is calculated using the Ackermann method, which is easy to implement in the MATLAB 2023b software used for the validation of the model. The experiment was done with pulse current profiling and dynamic stress testing (DST) to observe the SOC estimation error. The error was observed with simulated Gaussian noise added to the true system to find the observability error distribution in the estimation. The results show minimum error with minimum estimation time.

title: Enhanced Detection of Intermittent Primary User Signals for Cognitive Radio-IoT Networks with Markov-Chain Modeled BPSK
authors: Khadija Lahrouni, Hayat Semlali, Guillaume Andrieux, Jean-François Diouris, Abdelilah Ghammaz
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: This paper addresses the spectrum sensing challenges in Cognitive Radio-based Internet of Things (CR-IoT) networks, which are characterized by intermittent primary user (PU) activities. Unlike conventional approaches relying on fixed detection thresholds, we propose and evaluate an adaptive thresholding method within an Energy Detection (ED) framework, dynamically optimized based on real-time noise and signal characteristics. The PU activity is realistically modeled as a two-state Markov chain, with signals transmitted via Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK) modulation over an Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) channel. Simulation results demonstrate that our adaptive threshold approach significantly enhances detection accuracy while reducing total error probability at low SNR conditions (from -25 dB to 0 dB), thus effectively increasing idle channel utilization compared to traditional fixed threshold techniques.

title: The Impact of Digital Reconstruction of Shanxi Scenes in Black Myth: Wukong on Players' Travel Intentions
authors: Yi Yu, Huan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: In recent years, digital cultural IPs like Genshin Impact and Assassin's Creed have introduced a new concept of “game tourism,” blending virtual environments with cultural heritage to create immersive experiences. Black Myth: Wukong takes this a step further by using advanced 3D scanning and realtime rendering technologies to digitally reconstruct 27 cultural heritage sites in Shanxi with remarkable detail. This has led to the rise of the popular “Follow Wukong to Explore Shanxi” travel trend. This study explores how the digital recreation of game scenes influences players' travel intentions, using the Stimulus Organism Response model (SOR) as a framework. To gather insights, we surveyed 300 players who had completed the main storyline of Black Myth: Wukong and had either travel experience or plans. The survey examined key factors such as scene realism, destination image, travel intentions, cultural interest, and game engagement. Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) was used to assess the effect of scene realism on the destination image, and the Bootstrap method helped test the mediating role of destination image between scene realism and travel intentions. Finally, multi-group comparisons and interaction analyses were conducted to understand how cultural interest and game engagement affect these relationships.

title: Automated Water Treatment Plant Using Schneider PLC with SCADA Interface
authors: Venkata Subrahmanya Sai Mungi, Srinivas Paruchuri, Anudeep Komaravalli Student, Naga Sankara Vara Prasad Urrinkala Student, Veera Kumari Battula Student
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Addressing pressing global water scarcity and contamination, this project details the design and development of an automated water treatment plant prototype. Utilizing Programmable Logic Controllers (PLC) and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA), the system simulates a multi-stage purification process, including coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection. It employs Schneider’s SoMachine Basic for PLC programming and Citect SCADA for real-time monitoring and control. Continuous water quality tracking via integrated sensors enables automated adjustments of valves and pumps based on live feedback, significantly enhancing operational efficiency and accuracy with swift response times. The SCADA interface further offers manual override, data logging, and alarm notifications for reliable industrial deployment. This cost-effective and scalable prototype reflects full-scale plant functionalities, emphasizing automation’s role in public utility. It is adaptable for diverse water treatment infrastructures, contributing to sustainable development.

title: AI-Powered UI Generation: Evaluating Interactive Design Paradigms with Vision-Language Models
authors: Suraj Davariya
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Automating UI design through artificial intelligence offers a transformative shift in digital prototyping workflows. This study introduces a novel benchmark for AI-driven UI generation, comparing two distinct interaction paradigms-feedbackbased refinement and question-asking AI models-to enhance user-driven design customization. Leveraging advanced VisionLanguage Models (VLMs), it assess their ability to translate hand-drawn sketches into structured UI code. A user study with design practitioners evaluates the efficiency, usability, and adaptability of AI-generated prototypes, highlighting key challenges in model interpretability and layout coherence. The findings provide insights into optimizing AI-assisted UI creation, bridging human-centered design with generative intelligence. The system achieved up to $78.6 \%$ syntactic accuracy on the Test-UI corpus and demonstrated a $3.0 \%$ average gain in layout fidelity through interactive refinement.

title: Golf Ball Collecting Robot for Driving Ranges
authors: Ashwin Anil, Udhith Narayan, Vidyasagar K. N.
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: This report presents a detailed study on the conceptualization, development, and iterative refinement of a Golf ball collecting robot engineered specifically for golf driving ranges. The project aims to automate the labor-intensive and timeconsuming process of collecting golf balls that are scattered across large open areas with a focus on terrain adaptability and efficient mechanical collection. The robot's mechanical platform features a four-wheel drive (4WD) chassis constructed from laser-cut mild steel, powder-coated for enhanced durability in outdoor conditions. This 4WD configuration, powered by 10 -inch BLDC hub motors, provides enhanced traction and stability on uneven terrains typically found in golf driving ranges. A key evolution in mechanical design was the replacement of polycarbonate ball picking components, which were found to cause surface scratches on golf balls, with modular 3D printed PETG discs. These discs offered a smoother finish, effectively eliminating damage to the balls during collection. The modular design also allows for easy assembly, repair, and scaling of the picking mechanism based on operational requirements. On the electronics and control side, the system features a distributed architecture that uses a Raspberry Pi 5 and an ESP32-S3 microcontroller. The Raspberry Pi handles high-level computational tasks such as ball detection and centering using computer vision, utilizing the ROS 2 framework for modular and scalable development. The ESP32-S3, equipped with Micro-ROS, manages real-time control tasks including PID-based motor speed regulation. Communication between the Raspberry Pi and the ESP32-S3 is handled via a serial UART interface, enabling fast and reliable command execution.

title: BAT-TEC: Battery Anomaly Tracking via Time Delay Embedding Features Clustering
authors: Sarthak Chopra, Sarnaduti Brahma, Rishi Relan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) is a dynamic system of systems with numerous intricacies and complexities. This paper introduces a novel, adaptable anomaly detection method in battery cells. It operates independently of specific battery chemistry, utilising voltage signals, and effectively handling noisy data. The algorithm reconstructs the signal’s phase space using time delay embeddings, extracts key features, and clusters them to identify anomalies. The algorithm is tested on noisy data from a validated cell model with multiple artificially induced anomaly cases. A comparison of the algorithm’s performance in incremental and batch mode is done. Additionally, a hyperparameter analysis is also presented. The proposed approach offers a computationally efficient and robust solution for enhancing battery safety and reliability by enabling proactive maintenance and improving lifespan.

title: Multi-source Meteorological Data Fusion Modeling Based on Spatiotemporal Transformer
authors: Yue Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the increasing demand for weather forecasting, traditional meteorological data processing methods face many challenges in the fusion of multi-source heterogeneous data and modeling of spatiotemporal features. In particular, it is difficult to effectively capture complex patterns across time and space in high-dimensional meteorological data with strong spatiotemporal dependencies. To address these problems, this paper proposes a multi-source meteorological data fusion modeling method based on spatiotemporal Transformer. First, in response to the spatiotemporal complexity of meteorological data, this paper designs a spatiotemporal modeling method based on the Transformer architecture, which captures the dependencies of different temporal and spatial scales through the self-attention mechanism, and effectively integrates meteorological data from different sources. Then, combined with the multi-head attention mechanism, this paper dynamically weights multiple meteorological variables, so that key information can be highlighted in the data fusion process while reducing the interference of redundancy and noise. Finally, in order to improve the generalization ability of the model, this paper also introduces residual connection and position encoding technology. The experimental results show that under the condition of single-source data, the mean squared error (MSE) of the spatiotemporal Transformer is 0.066 and the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value is 0.975. In addition, in the generalization ability test of different climate regions, the prediction effect of spatiotemporal Transformer in tropical, temperate and cold regions showed high accuracy and stability. In the above data conclusion, spatiotemporal Transformer can effectively capture the spatiotemporal dependencies in meteorological data, provide more accurate predictions, and has strong adaptability and generalization ability.

title: Iris Recognition Using Machine Learning Technique
authors: Kalva Nagaswathi, Mohebbanaaz, S Hupesh Naga Kethan
abstract: Organizations utilize iris recognition systems for authentication purposes because every human being has different iris pattern formations. The iris recognition technology in this project used machine learning technology to develop an efficient precise recognition system. The project used CNN and SVM as supporting performance by completing feature extraction and classification work together. The authentication systems achieve increased security through this research because it helps with both verification procedures and access control functionality. Additional developments should be implemented to enable real-time functionality as well as biometric system integration for the system

title: An Efficient Approach for Glaucoma Detection Using Deep Learning
authors: Sonam Karsoliya, Shikha Agrawal
abstract: Glaucoma is a progressive optic neuropathy marked by the degeneration of retinal ganglion cells and irreversible damage to the optic nerve head, often resulting in permanent vision loss. Conventional diagnostic techniques such as fundus photography and optical coherence tomography (OCT) are resource-intensive and subject to interobserver variability. To address these limitations, deep learning—particularly convolutional neural networks (CNNs)—has emerged as a powerful tool for automated glaucoma detection. A key enabler of deep learning in this domain is transfer learning, which allows the use of pre-trained models like VGG16, ResNet50, and InceptionV3 on smaller medical datasets. These models can be fine-tuned to enhance classification and segmentation performance while reducing training time and computational demand. Recent studies have explored strategies such as domain adaptation, self-supervised learning, and multimodal fusion. This paper has provided a review of various deep learning methods and has proposed a system with pretrained models. The proposed model has performed well in terms of loss reduction as well as improvements in precision and recall.

title: Research and Application of a Genetic Algorithm-Based Open-Loop Online Optimization Model for Refining and Petrochemical Production
authors: Liang Sun, Nan Wang, Yanming Cao, Fenglian Dong, Fei Luo, Tinggui Zong, Jin Li, Peng Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: As digitalization, intelligent manufacturing are trending in the process industry, refining/petrochemical plants inevitably encounter the conflicting goal problem, frequent operating conditions variation issue, increasing level of process complexity while maintaining manual experience as the way of process improvement becoming unfeasible for timely and accurate responses to process fluctuation, which further leads to unstable product quality and lower process reliability. Therefore, the current paper proposes an online optimization system based on Internet of Things in a data-driven way to tackle such problems; it integrates key quality prediction, operating condition clustering and classification techniques so as to achieve online recognition of the present operating mode;Specifically, 785 typical operating conditions were identified, and detailed variable statistics and principal component analysis (PCA) were performed to extract critical influencing factors. A genetic algorithm was applied for multi-objective optimization of key control variables such as reaction temperature, catalyst-to-oil ratio, reflux ratio, and draw-off flow rate, aiming to maximize BTX yield under process constraints.Validation through a five-day continuous optimization simulation demonstrated an average BTX yield improvement of 1.4%, confirming the model’s practical effectiveness in enhancing product quality and operational efficiency.

title: Efficient Methods for Achieving Data Coverage in Machine Learning Assurance
authors: Manuel Hirschle, Dmitrii Kirov, Jürgen Adamy
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Data quality plays an important role in the assurance of Machine Learning (ML) enabled components in safety-critical aviation applications. In this paper, we propose a coverage-driven method for sampling data points from multidimensional parameter spaces. These points effectively describe concrete scenarios that can be simulated to obtain (synthetic) datasets for training and testing ML models. Our method uses several strategies for splitting the input space and sampling from resulting subspaces, as well several coverage metrics that help to identify uncovered areas to guide the iterative sampling process. We demonstrate our approach on two use cases of different complexity: a neural network-based collision avoidance system, and a computer vision application for maritime search and rescue. Based on the benchmarking results, we devise recommendations for selecting appropriate coverage metrics and sampling strategies for use cases of different complexity. This would inform practitioners about identifying suitable tradeoffs between achieving input space coverage and data collection costs.

title: From ODD to Data: An End-to-End Toolchain for Synthetic Data Generation – A Case Study on AI-Based Runway Detection
authors: Saymon R. Gattnar, Henry Späth, Yassine Akhiat, Zamira Daw
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Machine Learning (ML) has the potential to significantly enhance safety-critical applications, particularly in aviation. However, the reliability of ML models depends on high-quality datasets that represent the full range of operational scope. In practice, collecting real-world data in general and especially for rare and safetycritical edge cases, is not only expensive but often unattainable due to safety, regulatory, and logistical constraints. This paper presents the framework ScenAIro, an end-to-end toolchain for the generation of high-fidelity synthetic datasets based on defined Operational Design Domains (ODDs) with automated high-precision labeling using georeferenced positional data. It utilizes Microsoft Flight Simulator for data generation. To assess the distributional validity and real-world transferability of the synthetic data, we trained a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) exclusively on ScenAIro-generated images and evaluated its performance on real-world data from the LARD dataset. The resulting model achieved 62% classification accuracy - marking a fourfold improvement over a baseline model trained directly on Lard's own synthetic data (14%).

title: Synchrophasor Technology for Situational Awareness in Microgrid Integrated Renewable Energy Powered Electric Vehicle Charging Stations (EVCS)
authors: Deepa B, Santoshkumar Hampannavar, Amrutha G E
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The Indian government is dedicated to raising the proportion of renewable energy (RE) from solar, wind, and biomass sources in light of the growing concerns about climate change and energy security. This study explores the economic and environmental benefits of renewable-powered, grid-integrated Electric Vehicle Charging Stations (EVCS) in typical location of India. Hybrid systems using PV-battery and wind-battery configurations show significant cost savings and revenue potential through surplus energy export. The integration of micro-Phasor Measurement Units (μPMUs) enhances situational awareness, resulting in improved voltage profiles and reduced power losses in EVCS-integrated microgrids.

title: Material Choice for Artificial Insect Wing Design by Mimicking Natural Insect Wings
authors: Xiao-Qing Bao, Shu Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: This paper presents artificial insect wing material choice from a biomimetic viewpoint. The materials and properties of natural insect wings were reviewed. Our experiments show that approximately doubling the wing size can lead to an increase in flexural stiffness by nearly an order of magnitude, and drying-induced mass loss of around 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup> can result in an approximate twofold enhancement in flexural stiffness. Material choice criteria for mimicking natural insect wings were discussed. This work may facilitate the design and fabrication of artificial insect wings from a material perspective.

title: Workflow Optimization of Landscape Design Based on Generative Artificial Intelligence
authors: Yilu Gong, Tianbo Zhu, Yu Li, Fan Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: This paper explores the application methods of generative artificial intelligence (AI) in the field of landscape design and proposes a generative AI-based design workflow. By comparing the traditional design workflow with the AI-assisted workflow, the study identifies key differences and validates the feasibility of the proposed method through case studies. The proposed workflow consists of three core stages: First, case analysis and design vocabulary generation are conducted using Deepseek, followed by the transformation of these design vocabularies into conceptual imagery via Midjourney. The proposed workflow consists of three main stages. In the first stage, case analysis and design vocabulary generation are conducted using Deepseek, and the extracted design vocabularies are then transformed into conceptual imagery via Midjourney. In the second stage, ControlNet, which utilizes line drawings and semantic segmentation, is employed to generate precise master plans. Finally, Stable Diffusion is applied to produce visual renderings of landscape nodes based on preliminary SketchUp models. The case studies demonstrate that generative AI significantly reshapes the traditional landscape design process, fostering a collaborative “designer decision-AI execution” model. By integrating generative AI tools throughout the entire design workflow, a comprehensive human-AI co-creation system is established, redefining the relationship between designers and technology and giving rise to a new form of productivity driven by complementary strengths.

title: Enhancing Sentiment Analysis Accuracy in Multi-Brand Cosmetic Reviews through Optimized Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Longjun Yao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: This research aims to enhance the precision of sentiment analysis within the realm of online reviews for the cosmetics sector. By systematically optimizing data preprocessing and feature engineering, and integrating various machine learning algorithms—such as Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Naive Bayes, Voting, and Stacking ensemble methods—this study significantly improves the Recall rate of sentiment polarity classification models. The empirical findings indicate that through refined text preprocessing and feature engineering—particularly measures such as dynamically updating stop words, safeguarding specific phrases, and optimizing TF-IDF parameter settings—the Recall rate was elevated from 30% to over 72%. Ultimately, the study ascertained that the Stacking model exhibited superior performance in sentiment detection tasks, thus satisfying the brand’s heightened sensitivity to negative reviews. This research not only furnishes brand proprietors with efficient and feasible sentiment analysis tools but also introduces novel methodologies and conceptual frameworks for subsequent research on sentiment analysis across multiple brands and platforms. Through a systematic optimization process, this study effectively substantiates the practical applicability of traditional machine learning methods within real-world business scenarios.

title: Quantifying Narrative Structure Using Word Embeddings in Fiction Text
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Word embeddings are very important in natural language processing as they let us represent words as vectors that hold the meaning and the relation of the words. In this study, a comparative analysis of three frequently used Word Embedding models, namely Word2Vec, GloVe, and FastText, is performed using three different fiction texts. A sample of the three major genres was selected for the study- the epic of Mahabharata, the Harry Potter fantasy series, and the detective narratives of Sherlock Holmes. The emphasis is made on how these models perform with regards to stylistic features of each particular genre, and in terms of capturing semantic relationships as well as coping with such words that hardly ever appear in different texts. Understanding the behavior of these models in various types of texts allows us to draw useful conclusions for those who use them for the tasks connected with certain genres in the field of NLP.

title: The Added Value of Cascaded Plane Wave Imaging for Autocorrelation- and Cross-Correlation-based Velocity Vector Imaging
authors: Joosje M.K. De Bakker, Ingvild K. Ekroll, Anne E.C.M. Saris, Jørgen Avdal
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Ultrasonics, Ferroelectrics, and Frequency Control
abstract: Velocity vector imaging (VVI) can suffer from poor signal-to-noise (SNR) conditions, eventually restricting the estimation of velocities at low SNRs. Cascaded dual-polarity wave (CDW) imaging has been shown to enhance blood-SNR, thereby improving cross-correlation-based VVI. However, the CDW decoding process is sensitive to motion, where imperfect summation and cancellation of pulses can lead to reduced amplitude gain and ghost pulses outside the main pulse. Multi/dual-angle transmits, combined with either autocorrelation- or cross-correlation-based axial velocity estimation, are commonly used for VVI. Both techniques have intrinsic limitations, such as speckle decorrelation and aliasing, and strengths, where autocorrelation is known to be more resistant to noise and cross-correlation results in more accurate estimates in high SNR conditions. This study evaluates the benefits of CDW imaging for both autocorrelation- and cross-correlation-based VVI using the FLUST simulation toolbox and experiments, including parabolic and rotational flow scenarios. The results indicate that autocorrelation performs consistently across the entire SNR range, while cross-correlation is more accurate and precise in high SNR conditions. CDW improves estimation performance in low SNR conditions, particularly for estimation of low velocities, with a more substantial performance boost for cross-correlation compared to autocorrelation. In general, CDW imaging shows to be beneficial for VVI, independent of the used velocity estimator.

title: UaBMA-OLPP: A Novel Manifold-Inspired Technique for sEMG-based Hand Movement and Object Grasp Recognition_supp1-3637058.pdf
authors: Saibal Ghosh
abstract: Hand-related impairments from stroke and neuromuscular diseases are rising globally, increasing the demand for prosthetic hands using surface electromyography (sEMG) for hand movement and grasp activities. sEMG systems also support human-robot interaction (HRI), aiding assistive robots in manipulator tasks. However, sEMG sensors often struggle to capture comprehensive muscle activity and are vulnerable to external hazards. In such scenarios, classical dimensionality reduction techniques often underperform, particularly when the intrinsic spatial structure of the data is overlooked. Addressing this limitation, local manifold-inspired learning techniques, such as locality preserving projection (LPP), are investigated in this study. In particular, orthogonal LPP (OLPP) helps extracting features from high-dimensional data by leveraging the orthogonal properties of nonlinear mappings from input to feature space. Nevertheless, traditional projection kernels are typically constructed based on Euclidean similarity between data points, making them highly sensitive to noise and outliers. To overcome this challenge, we have incorporated two additional similarity measures derived from the complex Euler space and Grassmannian manifold, which effectively explore the local structure in Riemannian spaces. A novel uncertainty-aware Bayesian model averaging (UaBMA) approach is proposed for integrating similarity weights from various manifolds, thereby enhancing the projection discriminability. Extensive experimental studies on both laboratory-acquired and benchmark NinaPro datasets demonstrate superior performance of the proposed technique over existing methods.

title: Track Optimization and Matching with Learnable Modules for LMB-based Distributed Resolvable Group Target Tracking
authors: Yue Yu, Mei Liu, Yuguan Hou
abstract: This paper integrates two data-driven learnable modules into the conventional distributed multi-sensor resolvable group target tracking (RGTT) framework based on the labeled multi-Bernoulli (LMB) filter to improve tracking performance. First, in RGTT scenarios with densely distributed targets, the LMB filter is prone to track fragmentation and label switching, which reduce accuracy and complicate multi-sensor data association. While some studies have attempted to address this, their methods typically overlook the group structure and are often offline and computationally intensive. To overcome this, we propose a track optimization module based on attention mechanism that alleviates these issues efficiently in an online setting. Second, we replace traditional data association algorithms, which rely on fixed similarity metrics, with a track matching module based on message passing network (MPN). This module leverages historical track data and learns to infer latent similarities across sensors, significantly improving matching accuracy. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed modules.

title: Quantitative Evaluation of Repeatability in Medical Microwave Imaging: A Systematic Review_supp1-3638248.pdf
authors: V. HENRIQUE LOPES
abstract: Medical microwave imaging (MMWI) prototypes have demonstrated potential in various clinical applications. For successful clinical translation, these systems must be reliable and yield consistent results, that is, they must demonstrate high repeatability. This systematic review critically appraises the existing literature on repeatability in MMWI, with particular attention to the protocols, metrics, and outcomes reported. A systematic search of Scopus, IEEE Xplore, Web of Science, and PubMed was conducted on April 29th 2025, identifying 21 studies that quantitatively evaluated repeatability in MMWI. Two reviewers independently performed full-text screening and data extraction, with disagreements resolved through consultation with a third reviewer. Descriptive analyses were performed using tables and figures to characterise study design, methodologies, and findings. Considerable heterogeneity was observed in sample size, imaging protocols, and the selection of repeatability metrics. Almost all studies were restricted to breast imaging applications. Frequently reported sources of variability included subject repositioning, tissue changes, and hardware-related factors. Although most studies reported acceptable repeatability, the absence of standardised protocols and metrics limits cross-study comparison and the establishment of benchmarks. The review concludes with recommendations to harmonise approaches that contribute to accelerate the clinical translation of MMWI systems.

title: Deep Tabular Representation Corrector_supp1-3637810.pdf
authors: Hangting Ye
abstract: Tabular data have been playing a mostly important role in diverse real-world fields, such as healthcare, engineering, finance, etc. The recent success of deep learning has fostered many deep networks (e.g., Transformer, ResNet) based tabular learning methods. Generally, existing deep tabular machine learning methods are along with the two paradigms, i.e., inlearning and pre-learning. In-learning methods need to train networks from scratch or impose extra constraints to regulate the representations which nonetheless train multiple tasks simultaneously and make learning more difficult, while prelearning methods design several pretext tasks for pre-training and then conduct task-specific fine-tuning, which however need much extra training effort with prior knowledge. In this paper, we introduce a novel deep Tabular Representation Corrector, TRC, to enhance any trained deep tabular model's representations without altering its parameters in a model-agnostic manner. Specifically, targeting the representation shift and representation redundancy that hinder prediction, we propose two tasks, i.e., (i) Tabular Representation Re-estimation, that involves training a shift estimator to calculate the inherent shift of tabular representations to subsequently mitigate it, thereby re-estimating the representations and (ii) Tabular Space Mapping, that transforms the above re-estimated representations into a light-embedding vector space via a coordinate estimator while preserves crucial predictive information to minimize redundancy. The two tasks jointly enhance the representations of deep tabular models without touching on the original models thus enjoying high efficiency. Finally, we conduct extensive experiments on state-of-the-art deep tabular machine learning models coupled with TRC on various tabular benchmarks which have shown consistent superiority.

title: Attacks and Detections in Recommender Systems: A Comprehensive Analysis for Models, Progresses, and Trends
authors: Yan Feng, Zhihai Yang, Kexin Li, Jianxin Li, Pinghui Wang, Zhiquan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Recommender systems (RSs), as crucial components of online services, can help users efficiently obtain information they may like. In reality, RSs face long-term threats. Attackers manipulate recommendation results by injecting malicious data in order to obtain benefits. At present, research on the security of RSs lacks a comprehensive understanding of attack capabilities. Moreover, existing defense strategies have not yet been systematically associated with attack characteristics. More importantly, existing defense methods rarely focus on real unlabeled data in practical application scenarios for anomaly detection and forensics. Therefore, this survey systematically analyzes the security of RSs and provides new insights. Specifically, we first categorize attack models from an attack perspective into: attack strategies based on targets, attack strategies against security and privacy, attack strategies based on prior knowledge, and attack strategies against other RSs. From a perspective of defense, existing detection models, second, can be divided into: behavioral representation based on statistics, detection based on hidden features, detection against privacy attacks, anomaly discovery based on association mining, and abnormality forensics for real-world data. Finally, we propose several potential research directions aimed at providing guidance for the security research of RSs. Additionally, to facilitate experimental reproducibility and comparative research, this survey also provides a repository of resources for attacks and defenses (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/xiaofengbbb/RS-Papers</uri>).

title: Waves Excitation in a Waveguide Filled With Inhomogeneous Magnetized Movable Plasma
authors: Khaled Hamed El-Shorbagy, A. M. Gouda
abstract: A new study investigates the interaction of a relativistic electron beam (REB) with plasma inside the waveguide. The filled plasma is characterized by magnetized, movable, warm, and cold inhomogeneous medium. The resultant dispersion relation helps describe the propagation of the electromagnetic waves (EM waves) and the associated damped rate. A comparison between the homogenous and inhomogeneous plasma with the same boundary condition occurred. REB plays an essential role in the field instability and controlling the attenuation thus leading to minimizing the energy loss across the waveguide.

title: Holographic Metasurface Based Modulation for Energy Efficient LEO Satellite Communication
authors: Arumjeni Mitayani, Qingchao Li, Robert G. Maunder, Mohammed El-Hajjar
abstract: Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN) have emerged as a key enabler for extending global connectivity, particularly in remote or infrastructure-limited regions. Given the stringent power constraints in satellite systems, especially in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, energy efficiency becomes a critical design requirement. In this paper, we propose a novel design for energy-efficient holographic metasurface-based modulation and beamforming for LEO satellite communication. Our approach employs a single radio frequency (RF) chain, significantly reducing power consumption compared to the conventional MIMO scheme while maintaining communication performance. To address the Lorentzian constraints inherent in holographic metasurfaces due to their magnetic polarizability, we introduce a beamforming strategy that effectively mitigates the impact of these physical limitations. Simulation results show that our proposed system achieves significant energy efficiency improvements over conventional fully digital and existing holographic beamforming architectures, with only a small trade-off in achievable data rate.

title: Modeling Evolutionary Processes in Biological Systems with Machine Learning
authors: Satish Singh, Pranavi Shukla, Aakash Shedge, Sankalp Sathe, Ekta Sarda
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Through the utilization of machine learning, this research endeavors to examine the modeling of evolutionary processes that occur inside biological systems at the same time. After initially concentrating on artificial genetics methods, the methodology eventually develops into a framework that is more scalable and predictive. This framework makes use of a collection of models, such as Random Forest, XGBoost, SVM, KNN, and Neural Networks, in order to evaluate genetic datasets that are derived from the actual world. With the use of genetic characteristics and environmental circumstances, these models attempt to forecast the results of evolutionary processes. There is a substantial focus put on performance evaluation, which makes use of a variety of measures to evaluate the effectiveness of the model. These metrics include accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, ROC-AUC, and confusion matrices. A better understanding of the performance of the model and the patterns in its evolution may be achieved via the application of visualization tools. The Random Forest algorithm comes out as the most successful among the models that were evaluated. It achieves a high level of accuracy and provides reliable predictions over a wide range of biological datasets. The work that has been done here establishes the framework for future advances, such as the incorporation of deeper learning models, the utilization of bigger datasets, and the possibility of real-time processing of evolutionary trend forecasts.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Dual Input Hybrid Converters for EV Battery Charging Applications
authors: Chandan Verma, Ashok Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The integration of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems with grid-powered electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure enhances reliability and operational flexibility. Traditionally, separate AC-DC and DC-DC converters interface the grid and solar PV with the common charging bus. However, this approach increases the number of passive components and semiconductor devices, leading to higher system complexity and losses. Hybrid converter topologies have gained significant attention in addressing these challenges. This paper comprehensively reviews recent hybrid input converter architectures for battery charging applications. Key attributes, such as isolation, power flow management between the grid, PV, and EV, and the number of passive components and switching devices, are critically analysed. This review aims to provide valuable insights for future research in developing more efficient and compact hybrid converters for EV charging systems.

title: An Open-Source Structural Coverage Tool for DO-178C Compliance
authors: Wentao Zhang, Andrew Oppelt, Ikjun Jeon, Minji Park, Steven H. VanderLeest, Chuck Wolber
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper presents enhancements to the opensource LLVM-Cov structural coverage tool to meet DO-178C Software Level A objectives in the Linux kernel for assuring safety-critical aerospace software. We contributed new features to Linux and made improvements to LLVM-Cov for measuring unique-cause Modified Condition/Decision Coverage (MC/DC) of privileged, complex, optimized code (e.g., the Linux kernel). We innovated on the collection of trace data and improved several coverage mechanisms. With our efforts, LLVM-Cov achieves a robust mapping of coverage to the source code with the support of compiler optimizations, measuring line, branch, and MC/DC coverage. We present the first comprehensive coverage results (including MC/DC) for the Linux kernel. The MC/DC coverage using the current Linux test suites is low (7 %). By contributing our work back to the open-source community, we enable test suites to be enhanced to improve MC/DC coverage over time. Moreover, we describe DO-330 qualification. We certified our usage of LLVM-Cov to meet Criterion 3 of the tool impact criteria in DO-178C §12.2.2. at a Tool Qualification Level of 5. We discuss major milestones of our LLVM-Cov tool qualification, including a Tool Qualification Plan, Tool Operational Requirements, Tool Operational Verification and Validation Cases and Procedures, and Tool Accomplishment Summary.

title: Wavelet Packet Decomposition and Random Forest for Efficient Fault Detection in PV Arrays
authors: Chidurala Sai Prakash, S Ramana Kumar Joga, Srikanth Velpula, Teki Vamsee Krishna, Alivarani Mohapatra, Buddhadeva Sahoo
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The performance of a photovoltaic (PV) system heavily relies on the optimal operation of the PV array, which can be compromised by various faults such as open circuits, short circuits, partial shading, and bypass diode failures. Faults in the system can significantly reduce power output and cause long-term damage, making early detection crucial for effective maintenance and system longevity. Traditional fault diagnosis methods often struggle with accurate and rapid fault detection. This paper proposes an advanced approach combining Wavelet Packet Decomposition (WPD) for detailed signal analysis and the Random Forest machine learning classifier for accurate fault detection and classification. The proposed method efficiently identifies subtle faults in PV arrays by analyzing both high and low-frequency components of the system’s signal at multiple levels. A 3x3 series-parallel PV array is modeled in MATLAB Simulink to test the proposed methodology, demonstrating its effectiveness in diagnosing faults and minimizing system downtime.

title: Open Sky, Open Threats: Replay Attacks in Space Launch and Re-Entry Phases
authors: Nesrine Benchoubane, Eray Güven, Gunes Karabulut Kurt
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper examines the effects of replay attacks on the integrity of both uplink and downlink communications during critical phases of spacecraft communication. By combining software-defined radios (SDRs) with a real-time channel emulator, we replicate realistic attack conditions on the Orion spacecraft's communication systems in both launch and reentry. Our evaluation shows that, under replay attacks, the attacker's signal can overpower legitimate transmissions, leading to a Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) difference of up to -7.8 dB during reentry and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-6.5 \mathbf{~ d B}$</tex> during launch. To mitigate these threats, we propose a more secure receiver design incorporating a phase-coherencydependent decision-directed (DD) equalizer with a narrowed phase-locked loop (PLL) bandwidth. This configuration enhances resilience by making synchronization more sensitive to phase distortions caused by replay interference.

title: Physics-Based “Realism Checks” for Ai Generated Synthetic Flight Tracks
authors: Shahab Aref, John Shortle, Lance Sherry
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Prior to deployment of new procedures and/or technologies to manage traffic flow in an airspace, air-to-air collision risk must be estimated. Collision risk for an airspace is required to meet a Target Level of Safety (TLS) such as 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−9</sup>. Collision Risk Models (CRM) for airspace operations use pairs of flight tracks for the proposed airspace procedures to assess the Actual Level of Safety (ALS). Since airborne collisions are rare events, a large number of pairs of flight tracks are required (e.g. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 10^{7}$</tex>) to achieve a reasonable confidence interval. Researchers have recently developed AI algorithms capable of generating flight tracks, known as synthetic flight tracks. One question that must be answered before the pairs of synthetic flight tracks can be used in the collision risk analysis, is do the synthetic flight tracks represent realistic aerodynamics? This paper describes “physics-based” realism checks for individual synthetic flight tracks to ensure that they abide by fixed wing aerodynamic properties. Metrics for the lateral profile and vertical profile are described. The metrics are demonstrated with a case study. Implications of these methods, limitations and future work are discussed.

title: Multi-Modal Semantic Communication Systems for Sustainability: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Shikha Baghel, Pratima Das, Anirban Bhowal, Rakhesh Singh Kshetrimayum
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The proliferation of wireless devices and the ever-growing demands for multimedia applications have resulted in bandwidth shortage and are putting a massive strain on the network resources. To overcome these shortcomings, semantic communication has come to the forefront, where only the important data features can be transmitted instead of the conventional bit-level transmission, thereby saving bandwidth and resources and achieving sustainability. Depending on the application and data, semantic features can be extracted with the help of deep learning (DL) techniques and embedded into the transmitted data. At the receiver end, the semantic features can be extracted to recover the original data or utilized to perform specific tasks. However, semantic communication research remains in its nascent stages, for which an exhaustive literature review has been presented in this domain, and the deep learning architectures employed for capturing semantics, along with the associated performance metrics, have been elaborated upon.

title: High-Performance Hearing Aid with Advanced Piezoelectric Bone Conduction
authors: Chandra Singh, Praveen Kumar M, Dhyan Rai M, Sanjana K. C, Keerthan I. Naik, K.V.S.S.S.S. Sairam, Erramsetti Yasha Sree
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: The major non-surgical treatment of conductive hearing loss comes in the form of bone conduction hearing aids. A piezoelectric multilayer structure is generally used in these devices which are composed of a two-layer piezoelectric structure with a passive layer in between the two piezoelectric layers. It is a multilayer aspect paired with mass component and a coupling mechanism that circulates the mechanical vibration generated in the piezoelectric layers to the skull associated with the user. Standard designs however have the transducer placed directly on the skin of the head hence the skin gets irritated or eroded and are therefore not useful in rare instances of long term use. Hearing implants Bone conduction hearing implants and active middle ear implants avoid these problems, but they require surgical implantation that can result in skin complications. With this study, the researcher focused on developing a new type of hearing aid based on bone conduction where the hearing aid does not require surgical interventions and does not place pressure on the skin. The novel method entails substituting a portion of the conventional piezoelectric device special electrode with pinna skin and, therefore, changing the piezoelectric product in a special and less intrusive manner.

title: Full-Duplex Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access in Relay-Assisted Power Line Communication
authors: Roopesh Ramesh, Sanjeev Gurugopinath, R. Muralishankar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: The performance of non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) in a full-duplex (FD) relay-assisted power line communication (PLC) network is analyzed in this paper. A cooperative PLC system involving a source, relay, and destination node where the relay node is in FD mode for enhancing the spectral efficiency is taken into account. The performance of the system is measured in terms of outage probability using the log-normal fading channel model. We also elaborate on the power distribution optimization between the relay and destination nodes in the FD-NOMA case for minimization of outage probability. Outcomes show that the FD-NOMA scheme enjoys superior performance gains over its half-duplex counterpart for outage probability reduction. The paper also introduces the significance of the relay location and self-interference cancellation efficiency in overall system performance.

title: Design and Evaluation of an Orchestrated E2E Cloud-Native Mobile Network with O-RAN
authors: Jorge Baranda, Albert Bel, Sergio Barrachina-Muñoz, Miquel Payaró, Josep Mangues-Bafalluy
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The architecture and management of nextgeneration mobile networks are integrating novel networking paradigms to support challenging scenarios. This paper presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of a fully cloud-native, end-to-end mobile network integrating O-RAN functionality. Built on top of open-source software, our proposed framework develops a set of cloud-native deployment artefacts-such as Helm Charts and Open Source MANO packages-also released as open-source. This framework supports highly disaggregated and distributed deployments of key network functions, including the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> core, gNodeB (with decoupled Centralised and Distributed Unit entities), near-RT RIC, and xApps, enabling agile, portable, and flexible instantiations. Experiments show that the full cloudnative mobile network can be instantiated in less than five minutes, achieving a throughput comparable to bare-metal setups. This work highlights significant improvements in deployment efficiency and adaptability, contributing towards automated and autonomous cloud-native Beyond 5G/6G networks.

title: Investigation of Secure Division Algorithms in Privacy-Preserving Graph Neural Networks
authors: G D Nithin, An Palaniappan, V Krishnamoorthy, K S Sree Hari Nathan, R Ramanathan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks are used in areas that contains graph structured data. However, these types of networks will have sensitive data and therefore doing an open access will put the security of the data under question. The existing works tell about the secure learning in GNNs using various methods such as Secure Multi-Party Computation, Additive Secret Sharing etc., In this paper, we employ secure multi party computation and specifically talking about different algorithms for secure division. We evaluate three division methods—Newton-Raphson, Goldschmidt, and Taylor Series—across different hyperparameters such as hidden nodes and learning rates. Our results show that Goldschmidt method consistently achieves faster convergence, particularly in larger hyperparameters, while Newton-Raphson provides more stable performance. The Taylor Series method underperforms in accuracy compared to the other methods. This paper provides comparison between accuracy, computational efficiency, and security, providing assistance on selecting the most appropriate algorithm based on specific application requirements.

title: Federated Learning for Activity Recognition and Face Mask Detection on Edge AI Infrastructure
authors: Dragan Stojanović, Teodora Kocić, Natalija Stojanović
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is a decentralized machine learning approach that facilitates model training across distributed edge devices while ensuring data privacy. This study investigates the application of FL within Edge AI contexts, where edge devices with limited computational resources collaboratively train models using local data, without relying on centralized data aggregation. We demonstrate two representative use cases: activity recognition and face mask detection. The experiments are conducted using the Flower FL framework, which enables orchestration and coordination across heterogeneous edge devices. The results confirm the practicality of deploying FL on resource-constrained devices and expose key challenges, including data and device heterogeneity, communication latency, and limited processing capabilities.

title: Network Simulation for Future Distributed Aircraft Cabin Platforms
authors: Vincent Starke, Frank Thielecke
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The evolution of aircraft cabin architectures necessitates scalable network concepts to support future high-bandwidth, low-latency applications such as active noise control, smart sensing, and real-time video streaming. This paper presents a network simulation framework using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{OMNeT}++$</tex> and the INET library to evaluate novel cabin network architectures. By modeling dataflows, network protocols, and computing modules, the simulation enables early validation of key performance metrics, including network load, end-to-end latency, and switch utilization. An exemplary case study on video streaming demonstrates the trade-offs between centralized and decentralized architectures, highlighting critical factors for optimized resource allocation.

title: Distributed Resource Allocation and Application Deployment in Mesh Edge Networks
authors: Antoine Bernard, Antoine Legrain, Maroua Ben Attia, Abdo Shabah
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Virtual Network Embedding (VNE) approaches typically assume static or slowly-changing network topologies, but emerging applications require deployment in mobile environments where traditional methods become insufficient. This work extends VNE to constrained mesh networks of mobile edge devices, addressing the unique challenges of rapid topology changes and limited resources. We develop models incorporating device capabilities, connectivity, mobility and energy constraints to evaluate optimal deployment strategies for mobile edge environments. Our approach handles the dynamic nature of mobile networks through three allocation strategies: an integer linear program for optimal allocation, a greedy heuristic for immediate deployment, and a multi-objective genetic algorithm for balanced optimization. Our initial evaluation analyzes application acceptance rates, resource utilization, and latency performance under resource limitations. Results demonstrate improvements over traditional approaches, providing a foundation for VNE deployment in highly mobile environments.

title: Mechanical Performance of Arranged Multilayer Inspired by Sagra Femorata Purpurea Lichtenstein Beetle Elytra
authors: Wei Wu, Kaixiao Huang, Li Liang, Chao Deng, Jun Dong, Zhengxuan Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: With the continuous evolution of living organisms, nature has produced an impressive range of innovative structures. Researchers have effectively replicated and utilized these designs, leading to significant advancements in various scientific fields. The elytra of beetles, for example, display outstanding mechanical strength, effectively protecting the soft tissues underneath from potential damage in their natural environments. Despite being composed of relatively common materials, the remarkable mechanical properties of beetle elytra can be attributed to their hierarchical, layered structure. This study focuses on the Sagra femorata purpurea Lichtenstein beetle, employing biomimetic modeling techniques to construct four layered models with interlayer angles of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90^{\circ}, 60^{\circ}$</tex>, and 0° for parallel bottom plates, as well as 0° for vertical bottom plates. A series of experiments and numerical simulations were conducted on these models to analyze the effects of varying fiber block orientations across the layers on the mechanical behavior of these multi-layered structures. The findings show that the structure with 0° parallel bottom plates demonstrates superior mechanical properties compared to other configurations, while the structure with 0° vertical bottom plates shows relatively lower performance. However, considering the multi-directional impact forces beetles endure in their natural environments, the configuration with a 60° interlayer angle offers superior overall performance in terms of multi-directional impact resistance.

authors: Milena Rašljić Rafajilović, Vladimir Rajić, Marko Bošković, Jovan Blanuša, Marija V. Pergal, Nikola Cvjetićanin, Dana Vasiljević-Radović
abstract: In this paper, we observed nanoparticle synthesis in a continuous flow microreactor made from silicon and Pyrex glass with an integrated heater at low temperature. The solvothermal method was employed for the synthesis of nanoparticles. After the synthesis, the sample underwent structural, morphological, and elemental characterization. We demonstrated that this type of microreactor was unsuitable for this reaction, as it became clogged within a short time. Despite this, it was shown that two minutes of reaction time in microreactors was insufficient to obtain the pure anatase phase of TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> nanoparticles. To obtain a pure anatase phase, samples were annealed at 400°C in air.

title: Analysis of the Group Blasting Accident of High-Voltage Parallel Capacitor Bank Fuses
authors: Ruitong Liu, Yibing Sui, Hongcheng Wang, Geng Qin, Huanhuan Jia, Yicheng Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper introduces a 220kV substation high-voltage capacitor bank capacitor fuse "group explosion" accident, the substation may cause capacitor bank fuse "group explosion" factor for detailed analysis, according to the phenomenon and characteristics of its presentation, point out the root cause of the failure and rectification program; through the implementation of the rectification program to avoid or reduce the occurrence of capacitor bank fuse "group explosion" fault. It also points out the root causes of failure and rectification program; through the implementation of the rectification program to avoid or reduce the occurrence of capacitor bank fuse "group explosion" faults in the substation.

title: Model Predictive Current Control of Induction Motor Drives Integrated with Rotor Speed Estimator
authors: Navneet Kumar Ray, Sukanta Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: In this research article, a novel model predictive current control (MPCC) strategy for high-power induction motor (IM) drives, specifically targeting industrial applications such as mills, marine propulsion and heavy industrial machinery, where speed sensorless operation offers significant advantages is proposed. The MPCC framework is integrated with a rotor speed estimator constituting reactive power (Q) based model reference adaptive system (MRAS) to ensure accurate control performance despite speed variations and load disturbances. Considering the challenging operational environment, eliminating speed sensors not only enhances system reliability and reduces maintenance requirements, additionally it minimizes overall system cost.
