abstract: As a strategic resource that supports the development of electric vehicles and renewable energy storage, lithium is driven by global carbon neutrality goals and has a significant impact on the sustainable development of the new energy system through supply-demand dynamics and technological advancements. This article systematically explores the multifaceted challenges discovered in the development, utilization, and recycling of lithium resources by methodically examining the mechanisms of lithium resources in the new energy system, the distribution characteristics of lithium raw materials, supply-demand contradictions, and recycling pathways. The study discovered that lithium-ion batteries have become a mainstream technology, but the geographic concentration, mining environmental costs, and geopolitical risks pose a serious threat to supply chain security in major consumer and producer countries such as China. The study suggests a three-pronged approach of “technological innovation, recycling economy, and policy synergy”, which involves improving the lithium battery lifecycle recycling system, strengthening policy guidance and international cooperation to create a green supply chain, and increasing self-sufficiency through innovations in lithium extraction from saline lakes and mining technology for hard rock ores, so as to provide resource security, and contribute to the achievement of global carbon neutrality.

title: Initial Field-Trial Experiments with Downscaled Prototype of Decision Support System for Airspace Traffic
authors: Carlos C. Insaurralde, Erik Blasch
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper presents experimental results from initial field-trial tests conducted outdoor using the UAV Avionics Analytics Ontology (U-AAO) prototype of a Decision Support System (DSS) framework. The prototype provides proof of concept to highlight the advantages of an ontology towards a community-wide avionics ontology. The prototype entails software application entails AAO, the user interface, and an Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B) data acquisition module. The hardware prototype consists of a fixedwing drone and two rotary-wing drones, both equipped with ADS-B devices, a computer to run the DSS and an ADS-B reception dongle. The initial field-trial experiments carried out demonstrate that the AAO-driven DSS can provide avionics situation awareness by means of the U-AAO prototype able to replicate downscaled scenarios such as aircraft takeoff in which small drones play the role of different air vehicles requiring collision avoidance.

title: Quantization Strategies for an Attention CapsNet Pneumonia Recognition Algorithm Based on $\text{Pd}/\text{HfO}_{2}/\text{Ag}$ RRAM
authors: Guoxiang Xu, Biyi Jiang, Jiayi Xu, Feichi Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The efficient deployment of deep learning models for pneumonia detection on resource-constrained edge computing platforms necessitates hardware-aware optimization. In this work, we propose an optimized weight quantization strategy for implementing an attention-enhanced Capsule Networks (CapsNet) using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Pd}/\text{HfO}_{2}/\text{Ag}$</tex> resistive random-access memories (RRAMs). We evaluate two post-training quantization approaches-dynamic range and fixed range to reduce model size while maintaining accuracy. Experimental results on the Pneumonia MNIST dataset demonstrate that dynamic range quantization achieves over 15% higher performance compared to fixed range quantization method, with a 3-bit quantized model achieving comparable or better performance relative to the full-precision counterpart. Furthermore, hardware-based simulations further reveal less than 6% accuracy degradation under device non-idealities, validating the robustness of the proposed system. These results highlight the potential of optimized quantized RRAM-based in-memory computing architectures for energy-efficient and accurate edge intelligence in medical image analysis.

title: Simultaneous Multi-Party Negotiation in Upper Class E Airspace: An Automated, Game-Theoretic Approach
authors: Tien Nguyen, Michael Korens, Wenbin Wei
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In navigating the complex dynamics of Upper Class <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{E}$</tex> airspace, which exceeds <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> feet and is used primarily for military operations, traditional air traffic management systems face significant challenges, such as the lack of established infrastructure for civil operations and the increasing diversity of vehicle types. To address these challenges, the Higher Airspace Operations concept has been introduced to allow decentralized traffic management, in which vehicle operators can cooperatively maintain safe separation through strategic conflict negotiation. Our paper introduces an enhanced multi-party negotiation model that shifts from resolving each conflict within the scenario sequentially to simultaneous conflict resolution. The model enables multiple operators to concurrently propose and respond to maneuvers using a multithreading technique. Automating this process reduces the biases and delays associated with manual coordination, which ensures rapid and reliable conflict resolution. We implement and simulate a scenario involving three aircraft with overlapping conflicts to illustrate how the system achieves valid, conflict-free outcomes over multiple negotiation rounds. This work demonstrates the feasibility of structured and scalable conflict resolution in Upper Class <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{E}$</tex> and lays the foundation for future decentralized air traffic operations.

title: Enhancing IoT Security: A Meta-Learning Approach to Adversarial Robustness
authors: Zil e Huma, Sana Ullah Jan, Jawad Ahmad, William J. Buchanan, Nikolaos Pitropakis
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The increasing connectivity of Internet of Things (IoT) devices and networks has significantly raised security concerns. Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) serve as a firstline defense mechanism to detect and identify various cyber threats. However, traditional IDSs frameworks come with their own challenges, such as high computational costs, limited generalization to evolving variants of cyberattacks, increasing complexity, and vulnerability to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a meta-learning-based IDS framework using Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) to particularly combat adversarial attacks in IoT networks. The designed architecture optimizes model initialization by performing inner-loop updates using adversarially perturbed data. It aggregates gradients from these adversarially adapted models in the outer loop to achieve a resilient initialization that generalizes well against adversarial attacks. The proposed approach is rigorously evaluated by training and testing the model on three major adversarial attacks: Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM), Projected Gradient Descent (PGD), and DeepFool. The experimental outcomes indicate the promising performance of the proposed architecture with an average attack detection accuracy of 95.97%. The compact model size of 0.06MB makes it suitable for deployment on resource-constrained IoT devices and networks. Furthermore, the lower inferencing time ensures the timely detection of intrusion, which is significant for real-time IDSs.

title: Enhancing Sentiments Analysis via Large Language Model Meet for Text-Centric Twitter Classification
authors: Dhruv Patel
abstract: The quick and widespread creation of user views on social media platforms, especially Twitter, has made them essential tools for gauging public opinion. Sentiment analysis has become essential for understanding user sentiments because social networking sites communicate views exclusively through text. Language representation models have multiplied in natural language processing (NLP) because pretrained language models were introduced. The research establishes a goal to enhance text-centric sentiment analysis through big language model processing of Twitter sentiment data. The research improves sentiment classification through the utilization of XLNet as a transformer-based model that analyzes Twitter-focused emotional content. The suggested approach begins with cleaning up the data and then uses XLNet for classification after extracting features using the Bag-of-Words (BoW) method. The results show that XLNet outperforms BERT-base-cased and RoBERTa when evaluating models using F1score, recall, accuracy, and precision. The results demonstrate that XLNet achieves superior performance in contextual sentiment recognition because it delivers 99.62% classification accuracy. The comparative analysis and performance metrics were provided to show that XLNet outperforms the others at refining sentiment analysis as a product of contextual learning, which establishes it as a viable solution for text-emotion detection on social media.

title: Enhanced State Estimation for Reconfigured Distribution Networks Using Micro-PMU Data
authors: Sukriti Tiwari, Soumyabrata Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Real-time monitoring of the distribution system (DS) is essential due to bidirectional power flow, ensuring system security and reliability. The micro-phasor measurement unit (μPMU) enhances DS observability which is further enhanced by network reconfiguration, improving state estimation accuracy. This research utilizes a Linear State Estimation Model (LSEM) that integrates state estimates from the Weighted Least Squares (WLS) method with μPMU voltage and current measurements. Both calculated states and μPMU measurements, expressed in rectangular coordinates, are used to predict the system's final state in a reconfigured network. The performance of LSEM with conventional as well as hybrid measurements is tested, validated, and compared before and after network reconfiguration for IEEE-69 bus DS. Results demonstrate that incorporating reconfiguration in hybrid measurement-based state estimation significantly enhances estimation accuracy, improving the reliability of DS monitoring.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Driven Forecasting Models for Demand Forecasting in Inventory Optimization
authors: Vinay Singh, Prashant Gupta, DhirajKumar Pathak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Forecasting demand for new items has always been difficult because of the proliferation of products, lengthier lead times, seasonal changes, and shifting trends. Consumer preferences have to be understood properly in order to make accurate forecasts of demand. This study proposes a machine learning model for demand forecasting and consumer preference analysis. This paper proposes two deep learning-based models Artificial Neural Network (ANN) and a hybrid Long Short-Term Memory-Gated Recurrent Unit (LSTM-GRU) to predict product demand in Inventory. The Retail Sales data contains the product, customer, economic, and sales attributes, and the preprocessing methods, such as normalization, one-hot encoding, and feature selection, are applied to improve the model performance. Based on experimental findings, the ANN model had <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of 90.31 and RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error) of 2.814, but it was highly surpassed by the LSTM-GRU model, having <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of 99.24 and RMSE of 0.0145. These findings prove the robustness and efficiency of deep learning models, especially the hybrid LSTM-GRU to capture complex time-related patterns that can be used to model accurate demand. The suggested framework will provide a scalable framework to address intelligent supply chain planning and decision-making.

title: BaM-CIM: A High Throughput Booth Algorithm-Based In-MRAM Computing Macro Using Hybrid VGSOT-MTJ/GAA-CNTFET
authors: Chenghang Li, Zhongzhen Tong, Yulong Qiu, Jiye Yao, Chao Wang, Zhaohao Wang, Xiaoyang Lin, Weisheng Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) and computational models grow in scale, the demand for computational power and storage has significantly increased. The computing-in-memory (CIM) architecture addresses this challenge by performing computations directly within the memory array, reducing data transfer between the processor and memory. This paper introduces a Booth algorithm-based In-MRAM computing architecture (BaM-CIM) using a hybrid voltage-gated spin-orbit torque MTJ (VGSOT-MTJ) and gate-all-around carbon nanotube field-effect transistors (GAA-CNTFETs) for efficient multiply-and-accumulate (MAC) computing. The key contributions of BaM-CIM are as follows: 1) A Voltage divider reference (VDR) cell is proposed, which enables read operations using only a 2T1M cell structure. Compared to complementary read cells, the VDR reduces the area by half and achieves robust data sensing without requiring precharge/discharge operations. 2) The BaM-CIM circuit is proposed to complete 8b-W/8b-IN/21b-OUT computations in only two cycles (1.6 ns), reducing the number of cycles by 75% compared to single-bit input serial operations and by 50% compared to two-bit serial operations. 3) A three-input 8b Booth computing adder (BCA), along with Modified computing shift adder (MCSA) and Modified computing post adder (MCPA), which can achieve higher energy efficiency. BaM-CIM with 128 Kb is simulated, achieving throughput and energy efficiency of 0.93 TOPS and 258.4 TOPS/W, respectively, at a 0.6 V supply voltage and 1.28 TOPS and 169.5 TOPS/W, respectively, at a 0.8 V supply voltage with 8b-IN, 8b-W, and 21b-OUT.

title: Incorporating Clustering for Joint 3D Localization and Environmental Sensing Method Using the Spherical-Wavefront Parametric Model
authors: Fan Yu, Mingqi Guo, Guangzheng Jing, Yixiao Tong, José Rodríguez-Pińeiro, Xuefeng yin
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) technology not only enables information transmission but also delivers accurate localization and environmental sensing capabilities. Existing spherical-wavefront model based Methods face two primary drawbacks. First, their underlying assumptions are often invalid in complex real-world scenarios, particularly under Non-Line-of-Sight (NLoS) conditions. This leads to inaccurate channel parameter estimation and subsequent errors in localization and environmental sensing. Second, they necessitate costly and complex MIMO systems, rendering them impractical for many deployments constrained by budget or hardware. Our proposed method directly addresses these limitations. Our proposed method directly addresses these limitations. It incorporates novel two-step suppression framework of clusters acquisition and preferred expected cluster selection to effectively eliminates the errors caused by non-conforming MPCs, thereby improving the accuracy of both localization and environmental sensing. Crucially, the system only requires a multi-antenna setup at one end, significantly reducing complexity and cost. Additionally, an iterative procedure is embedded in the method to enhance computational efficiency. Through indoor simulations and measurements in various LoS and NLoS scenarios, our method consistently demonstrates higher target localization accuracy and better environmental sensing than comparable benchmarks. This confirms that our solution is not only more robust and widely applicable but also maintains a high level of computational efficiency.

title: Adaptive Detection of Advanced Persistent Threats (APT) With Graph Neural Networks and Rehearsal-Based Continual Learning on Wazuh EDR Telemetry
authors: Auttapon Pomsathit
abstract: In the rapidly evolving cybersecurity landscape, Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) pose major challenges due to their stealthy and adaptive behavior. Traditional detection methods based on signatures or heuristics are limited in identifying novel and evolving attacks, while static deep learning models suffer from concept drift and catastrophic forgetting, leading to degraded performance over time. This paper proposes an adaptive APT detection framework that integrates Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with rehearsal-based continual learning using telemetry data from Wazuh, an open-source Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) and Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) platform. Endpoint telemetry is represented as graphs where nodes denote system components and edges describe behavioral interactions among them. Experimental evaluations on real-world Wazuh telemetry augmented with sandbox-executed APT scenarios demonstrate that the proposed approach consistently achieves F1-scores above 0.98, outperforming static and fine-tuned baselines in both adaptability and knowledge retention. These results confirm that combining graph-based representations with continual learning offers a scalable, interpretable, and resilient solution for modern SOC and EDR environments facing advanced and evolving cyber threats.

title: Adapting Educational Content to Student Emotions: A User Study With the Furhat Social Robot
authors: Rita Francese, Menes Buccino, Fabio Blaso, Laura De Santis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Emotional artificial intelligence (AI) can enhance personalization in computational social systems by enabling machines to respond to users’ affective states. In education, adapting instruction based on emotions such as engagement and stress may lead to more supportive learning experiences. This study examines whether an emotionally adaptive social robot, driven by real-time electroencephalography (EEG) signals, can improve learners’ engagement and perception of the robot. A between-subjects experiment is conducted with 30 undergraduate students during an XML lecture delivered by the Furhat social robot in one-to-one modality. In the empathetic condition, the robot adapts its behavior in response to EEG-detected engagement and stress levels; in the nonempathetic condition, the robot follows a fixed script. The empathetic robot significantly improved users’ perceptions across all Godspeed dimensions and enhanced perceived usability and reward. EEG data showed a significant increase in engagement. Learning outcomes were statistically similar across conditions. Real-time EEG-guided emotional adaptation improves user engagement and perception of social robots in educational contexts. These findings support the role of affect-driven adaptivity in enhancing user experience in intelligent tutoring systems.

title: Topology-Induced Low-Rank Tensor Representation for Spatio-Temporal Traffic Data Imputation_supp1-3638633.pdf
authors: Xi-Le Zhao
abstract: Spatio-temporal traffic data imputation is a fundamental component in intelligent transportation systems, which can significantly improve data quality and enhance the accuracy of downstream data mining tasks. Recently, low-rank tensor representation has shown great potential for spatio-temporal traffic data imputation. However, the low-rank assumption focuses on the global structure, neglecting the critical spatial topology and local temporal dependencies inherent in spatio-temporal data. To address these issues, we propose a topology-induced low-rank tensor representation (TILR), which can accurately capture the underlying low-rankness of the spatial multi-scale features induced by topology knowledge. Moreover, to exploit local temporal dependencies, we suggest a learnable convolutional regularization framework, which not only includes some classical convolution-based regularizers but also leads to the discovery of new convolutional regularizers. Equipped with the suggested TILR and convolutional regularizer, we build a unified low-rank tensor model harmonizing spatial topology and temporal dependencies for traffic data imputation, which is expected to deliver promising performance even under extreme and complex missing scenarios. To solve the proposed nonconvex model, we develop an efficient alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM)-based algorithm and analyze its computational complexity. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms state-of-the-art baselines for various missing scenarios. These results reveal the critical synergy between topology-aware low-rank constraint and temporal dynamic modeling for spatio-temporal data imputation.

title: Enabling Tile-Based Direct Query on Adaptively Compressed Data with GPU Acceleration
authors: Yu Zhang, Feng Zhang, Yani Liu, Huanchen Zhang, Jidong Zhai, Wenchao Zhou, Xiaoyong Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: The explosive growth of data poses significant challenges for GPU-based databases, which must balance limited memory capacity with the need for high-speed query execution. Compression has become an essential technique for optimizing memory utilization and reducing data movement. However, its benefits have been limited to the necessary data decompression. Querying compressed data conventionally requires decompression, which causes the query process to be significantly slower than a direct query on uncompressed data. To address this problem, this paper presents a novel GPU-accelerated tile-based direct query framework that successfully eliminates the limitation, significantly enhancing query performance. By employing direct query strategies, the framework minimizes data movement and maximizes memory bandwidth utilization. It incorporates tilebased hardware-conscious execution strategies for direct query, including memory management and control flow coordination, to improve execution efficiency. Additionally, adaptive data-driven compression formats are paired with tailored SQL operators to enable efficient support for diverse queries. Our experiments, conducted using the Star Schema Benchmark, show an average improvement of 3.5× compared to the state-of-the-art tilebased decompression scheme, while maintaining the space-saving advantages of compression. Notably, our solution consistently outperforms existing direct execution schemes for compressed data across all query types.

title: How AI-generated Summaries of Reviews Are Reshaping E-commerce with Competing Retailers?_supp1-3637769.pdf
authors: Fei Ye
abstract: With the rapid advancement of generative AI (Gen AI), e-commerce platforms like Amazon and Newegg are adopting AI-generated summaries (AIGS) to synthesize online reviews. We analytically study the transformative impact of AIGS one commerce with competing retailers by examining its two key effects: the convenience effect, which reduces consumers' reading costs to access review information, and the filtering effect, which aids consumers in making more informed purchase decisions. Retailers differ in their market reputation (MR), and not all consumers in the market trust AIGS. Our findings suggest that the convenience effect and the filtering effect influence competition in opposite ways. When consumer trust in AIGS is high, its adoption may intensify price competition. We further show that moderately high consumer trust in AIGS enables its adoption to create an all-win outcome for both the platform and competing retailers. Surprisingly, we find that while high trust in AIGS can reinforce high-MR retailers' advantages (a Matthew effect), the adoption of AIGS under low trust may instead reshape market competition by narrowing these advantages. Interestingly, when AIGS is fully trusted and adoption costs are moderate, it improves social welfare but may lower consumer surplus due to elevated prices.

title: Natural Language-Driven Viewpoint Navigation for Volume Exploration via Semantic Block Representation
authors: Xuan Zhao, Jun Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Exploring volumetric data is crucial for interpreting scientific datasets. However, selecting optimal viewpoints for effective navigation can be challenging, particularly for users without extensive domain expertise or familiarity with 3D navigation. In this paper, we propose a novel framework that leverages natural language interaction to enhance volumetric data exploration. Our approach encodes volumetric blocks to capture and differentiate underlying structures. It further incorporates a CLIP Score mechanism, which provides semantic information to the blocks to guide navigation. The navigation is empowered by a reinforcement learning framework that leverage these semantic cues to efficiently search for and identify desired viewpoints that align with the user's intent. The selected viewpoints are evaluated using CLIP Score to ensure that they best reflect the user queries. By automating viewpoint selection, our method improves the efficiency of volumetric data navigation and enhances the interpretability of complex scientific phenomena.

title: Analysis of 1064- and 532-nm GaAs PCSS Picosecond Pulse Output Characteristics
authors: Zhoulin Yan, Lei Hou, Cheng Ma, Wei Shi, Meilin Wu, Ziyang Dang
abstract: Low-power laser-triggered GaAs photoconductive switches generate high-power pulses, yet studies remain largely confined to the nanosecond regime, with limited insights into picosecond carrier dynamics. This study investigates the ultrafast output characteristics of a low-temperature gallium arsenide photoconductive semiconductor switch (LT-GaAs PCSS) grown to a thickness of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>m on a semi-insulating gallium arsenide photoconductive semiconductor switch (SI-GaAs PCSS) using two different wavelengths, 1064 and 532 nm. The experimental results showed that the 532-nm laser-triggered pulse has a rise time of 40 ps, a fall time of 87 ps, and a pulsewidth of 51 ps. Compared to the 1064-nm laser-triggered pulse, the 532-nm optically triggered pulse has a faster rise and fall time and narrower pulsewidth. Furthermore, triggering a GaAs PCSS under a bias voltage of 3 kV with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$230~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>J of 532-nm laser produces ultrafast high-voltage electrical pulses with an output voltage of 818 V, a rise time of 34 ps, a pulsewidth of 44 ps, and a fall time of 82.6 ps. A 2-D device simulation model, where a LT-GaAs PCSS and a SI-GaAs PCSS are irradiated by 532- and 1064-nm lasers, respectively, was established via the finite-element method using Multiphysics.

title: Interference Magnetic Field Compensation Method for Spacecraft Magnetic Testing in Geomagnetic Environments
authors: Ye Liu, Xingjian Shi, Wenzhe Yang, Zhiming Cai, Huawang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Magnetic field characterization is an essential process during spacecraft development to ensure magnetic cleanliness and accurate field modeling. Conventional testing approaches often rely on stable geomagnetic conditions and magnetic shielding facilities, which limit testing efficiency and scalability. Model-based interference compensation methods have emerged as an alternative, but their performance typically depends on large training datasets and careful hyperparameter tuning, reducing robustness across varying electromagnetic environments. To address these limitations, this study proposes an independent linear layer model with output channel isolation (ILinear-OCI) for interference magnetic field compensation during spacecraft magnetic testing in geomagnetic environments. The developed method achieves decoupled linear transformations across output channels through an innovative output-channel independent prediction mechanism while maintaining multi-channel input compatibility. By integrating linear layers with least squares optimization, the proposed approach enables rapid interference prediction without requiring extensive training datasets or hyperparameter tuning. Experiments for spacecraft magnetic moment modeling demonstrate that the model achieves a mean root mean square error of 0.38 nT between predicted and measured interference fields, reducing magnetic dipole moment modeling errors from 30.45% to 0.62%. In single-device magnetic field measurement trials, the average discrepancy between model outputs and baseline measurements in the near-zero magnetic environment reaches merely 0.33 nT. Furthermore, the model effectively suppress low-frequency geomagnetic noise (power spectral density reduced from 268.83 to 0.83 nT/√Hz at 0.01 Hz) while effectively mitigating interference from electrical equipment and the power line.

title: Preliminary Testing of a Continuous Cryopump for Primary Fusion Device Pumping and Direct Internal Recycling
authors: T. E. Gebhart, N. Adhikari, B. Quinlan, L. R. Baylor, C. Marcus, S. Matiauda, D. Ottinger
abstract: The concept of directly recirculating fusion machine exhaust gas, bypassing the tritium plant, to make fuel pellets was proposed in the 1990s and later termed direct internal recycling (DIR). In the DIR concept, the residual fusion fuel in the machine exhaust stream is separated from impurities locally and diverted directly to the fueling systems, bypassing isotopic separation and other processing equipment, and therefore significantly reducing the required size of the fuel processing plant, reducing plant inventory, and thus increasing the economic viability of fusion as an energy source. One concept for DIR consists of a series of cryogenic pumps to separate the impurities from the machine exhaust gas using different triple point temperatures and saturation curves of exhaust constituents. In this concept, the plasma exhaust is initially passed through an impurity trap operating at ~25–30 K to desublimate impurities such as hydrocarbons, argon, oxygen, and nitrogen. The resulting process stream will consist of DT fuel and helium. The process stream is then pumped by a continuous cryopump known as a “snail pump.” This pump is a steady-state continuous cryopump that desublimates all remaining exhaust gas constituents while allowing helium, a byproduct of the fusion reaction, to pass through. The helium is pumped to the tritium plant for processing while the desublimated material is continuously scraped off, heated up, and transported to the fueling system. This article will present the cryogenic DIR concept and outline the design and operation of the snail pump, along with results from preliminary testing. Tests to assess pumping and separation efficiency found that at D<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> flows below 50.7 Pa <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\cdot $</tex-math> </inline-formula> m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/s with 1% helium, the pump is capable of pumping and separating the gas with a resulting DIR fraction of >99%, with no helium entrained in the primary fuel exhaust stream. The main limitation is due to the thermal performance of the cryogenic circuits of the pump, which will be addressed in future testing.

title: Intelligent Reactive Power Management for Electricity Markets Using Metaheuristic Algorithms
authors: Punam Das, Raj Chakraborty, Sadhan Gope, Diptanu Das, Arvind Kumar Jain, Priyanath Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Modern power systems must increasingly balance technical efficiency with market-driven demands, especially in environments with high renewable energy penetration. This paper proposes a reactive power scheduling strategy based on the Multi-Objective Atomic Orbital Search (MOAOS) algorithm, alongside the Multi-Objective Dragonfly Algorithm (MODA), targeting the simultaneous minimization of Active Power Loss (APL) and Voltage Deviation (VD) within a pool-based electricity market framework. The IEEE 30-bus test system is used to validate the suggested methodology. Simulation results demonstrate that MOAOS achieves a $\mathbf{3 6 . 1 \%}$ reduction in APL and an $88.8 \%$ reduction in VD compared to the initial system conditions. Comparative evaluations with results reported in existing literature confirm the superior performance of the proposed algorithms, especially MOAOS, in terms of solution quality and rate of convergence. The findings highlight that integrating demand-side market participation significantly expands the Pareto-optimal solution space, enhancing flexibility for system operators to prioritize operational or economic objectives dynamically. Overall, the proposed method offers a robust and efficient tool for improving grid stability and economic efficiency in market-driven power systems.

title: Self-Driven Droplet Collisions on Micro/Nano Structured Surfaces with Patterned Wettability
authors: Zhirui Liu, Faze Chen, Minghao Li, Yanling Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Droplet collision has long been a focal area of research within the field of droplet dynamics. Currently, there is a lack of a detailed and comprehensive system or mechanism for investigating high-speed droplet collisions, which poses a challenge in addressing droplet collision issues encountered in practical engineering applications. In this study, we introduce a collision platform driven by a Superwetting wedge structure to examine the deformation process of droplets post-collision. We have devised three distinct wedge-shaped structures, leveraging the wettability gradient difference of the surface to accelerate droplets without relying on an external force field. Subsequently, we combined through a dual-structure pairing methodology to facilitate droplet collisions. The findings reveal that an increase in the velocity of the accelerated droplet corresponds to a greater degree of deformation in the fused droplet following collision. Furthermore, higher droplet counts produce greater deformation during collision events. The three driving structures and collision models we designed provide a new experimental method and platform for studying droplet driving and droplet collision.

title: Nanoscale Fabrication and Optimization of Liquid Crystal-Enhanced Resonant Waveguide Gratings for Tunable Mid-IR Filtering
authors: Kinza Arshad, Fozia Aslam, Sadaf Saeed, Matloob Hussain Bhatti, Tymish Y. Ohulchanskyy, Rida Nasir
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The design of sub-wavelength guided wave resonant structures integrated with Liquid Crystals (LCs) offers a promising approach for developing tunable optical filters with applications in sensing and photonics. This study investigates the design and simulation of such structure, utilizing advanced Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) simulations to model the performance of the grating design. By incorporating Liquid Crystals into the resonant waveguide grating, the structure achieves tunable transmission characteristics, with both sharp transmission peaks and significant tuning ranges for Transverse Electric (TE) and Transverse Magnetic (TM) modes. The design parameters, including grating depth, period, and fill factor, were optimized to enhance the resonance response. The electrical sensitivity of the structure was also explored, demonstrating its potential for high-precision electrical field sensing. These results highlight the significant advantages of using LC-based sub-wavelength gratings in Mid-IR photonics, offering new possibilities for advanced optical filtering and sensing applications.

title: Time-Multiplexed Fault-Tolerant Soft-Switched DC-DC Multiport Non-Isolated Converter
authors: Md. Modassir Masoom, Mayank Kumar, Narendra Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents a time-multiplexed fault-tolerant non-isolated soft-switched tri-port dc-dc converter (one input and two output ports). The proposed tri-port fault-tolerant dc-dc (TPFTDC) converter is developed for reliability and unremitting operation. The proposed converter is enriched with two output ports with step-up and step-down voltage gain capability, respectively. The interleaving nature of the circuit reduces the filter size and minimizes switching losses by adopting a resonant soft-switching. The time-multiplexing control for the buck operation is implemented using the switched boost action method to reduce the number of semiconductor devices. A detailed mode analysis of the proposed topology is presented. The proposed converter is simulated using MATLAB/Simulink software, and the results are verified.

title: Codoped Titanium Dioxide for Water Treatment
authors: Natalia V. Chirkunova, Amani Azaizia, Maksim V. Dorogov, Alexey E. Romanov
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Titanium dioxide nanoparticles co-doped with tin and sulfur were studied. It was noted that doping leads to a red shift of the absorption edge and a decrease in the band gap to 2.9 eV. Tin lowers the conduction band, while sulfur forms additional levels inside the band gap. When using DFT calculations, good convergence with experimental data is achieved using the HSE06 functional. It is shown that titanium dioxide samples with an average particle size of about 50 nm, doped with sulfur and tin (5 at.% Sn) have high photocatalytic activity in the decomposition of organic pollutants in the visible range of light.

title: LLM-Driven Approach to Automated Sustainability of IoT Systems
authors: Nenad Petrović, Dragana Krstić, Suad Suljović, Dario Javor
abstract: Due to huge number and heterogeneity of devices within Internet of Things (IoT)-based architectures, scalability and maintainability of such systems rise many challenges when it comes to long-term sustainability, especially regarding scalability and maintainability aspects. In this paper, we explore state-of-art Large Language Model (LLM)-based techniques as well as Agentic AI approaches in order to automate these aspects and reduce the cognitive load and need for human intervention. As intermediary step for system representation, we leverage Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) approach in order to ensure verifiability. As outcome, two case studies relying on GPT-40 model are presented.

title: Guidesphere: An Integrated Learning Material and Job Search Platform for Educational Enhancement
authors: Rani Shetty, Shreyas P Pawaskar, Vivek K Saklathi, Pranav S Gaonkar, Vishwa N Hegde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: The exponential growth of online educational resources has created significant challenges for students in identifying reliable and relevant study materials. This paper presents Guidesphere, an innovative web-based platform designed to streamline the educational resource discovery process for secondary school students and undergraduates. The platform integrates a sophisticated recommendation engine utilizing text vectorization and cosine similarity algorithms, coupled with a robust search mechanism to deliver personalized educational content. Additionally, Guidesphere incorporates job search functionality, connecting undergraduate students with potential employers. The system employs MongoDB for data storage, Flask for back-end processing, and Node.js with Express.js for authentication services. Performance evaluation demonstrates significant improvements in resource discovery efficiency and user engagement compared to traditional search methods, achieving 94% precision in recommendation accuracy. The platform successfully addresses the challenge of information overload while maintaining content quality and relevance through comprehensive evaluation metrics and user feedback analysis.

title: A Robust AI-Powered Anomaly Intrusion Detection and Classification Framework for Cloud Computing Networks
authors: Anila Gogineni, Bharath Kumar Reddy Janumpally, Swapnil Jagannath Wawge, Saurabh A. Pahune
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The widespread adoption of cloud computing services across different industries creates security risks which stem from probable cyberattacks. A comprehensive method for identifying cloud computing network intrusions utilizes the Inception V3 deep learning model and the UNSW-NB15 dataset. The dataset contains over 2.5 million network streams that include nine attack types and benign traffic while going through detailed processing that removes null values, eliminates duplicates, applies one-hot encoding, scales features and selects features to boost model performance. To determine that the classes are balanced or imbalanced and to infer relationships between the features, methods such as pie charts and heatmaps were applied. The Inception V3 model, trained on the above-said dataset, proved high efficiency with 0.984 accuracy, 0.99 precision, 0.99 recall and 0.985 of F1score, which out-competed traditional models like CNN + LSTM, IIDNet, ANN, DT, and CNN. Other graphics, such as the training and validation accuracy, the loss diagrams, and the confusion matrix, also explain how viable the model is for generalization. These results prove that the obtained Inception V3 architecture is very efficient and can be used effectively for identifying multifaceted attack patterns to boost cybersecurity in cloud networks.

title: Predictive Framework for Autism Spectrum Disorder Based on Age and Behavioral Data using Tuned XGBoost
authors: Dontha Madhusudhana Rao, Kolipakula Pujitha, Myla Dhanya Sri, Gogineni Venkata Maha Lakshmi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder(ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by social interaction, communication and behavior difficulties. Early diagnosis is crucial for timely intervention and improved quality of life. As most individuals affected by ASD are children between the age of 0 to 5, this study proposes a Machine Learning (ML) based predictive framework to facilitate the early detection of ASD by analyzing behavioral and demographic features. Emphasizing age-specific classification, the proposed framework using Tuned XGBoost model achieves the highest accuracy of $99.4 \%$ making it reliable choice for ASD prediction. Hence the proposed system provides a scalable, cost-effecient and objective diagnostic tool, supporting healthcare professionals in making informed decisions and promoting early intervention for individuals with ASD.

title: A Computational Framework for Stress Analysis in Robotic Joint Sensor
authors: Shrikant C. Mahadik, Vikas R. Deulgaonkar, Dinesh N. Washimkar, Sachin M. Bhosle, Shankar C. Vetal
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Robotic joints are essential for defining mobility and functionality in robotics, particularly in industrial, medical, and autonomous systems. These joints experience complex loads, including bending, torsion, and axial forces, which cause stress concentrations and fatigue over time. In high-precision tasks or high-load environments, such stress can lead to premature wear or catastrophic failure. Understanding stress distribution is critical for ensuring the structural integrity, efficiency, and longevity of robotic joints. This paper proposes a computational framework that integrates mathematical modeling, computational techniques, and sensor placement strategies to optimize robotic joint design and performance. The framework combines analytical, numerical, and experimental methods to enhance stress predictions, reduce computational costs, and ensure sensor reliability. The approach will be validated using case studies to demonstrate its versatility and accuracy in various robotic applications.

title: Functional Coverage Analysis of APB RAM Verification Using System Verilog
authors: Beulah Grace Nelam, N.V.S. Nagalakshmi, G. Gayathri, N. Vedajhna, D.P.S. Praveenya, P. Sharmila, M. Durga Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This project primarily aims to design and validate the APB (Advanced Peripheral Bus) RAM using System Verilog by generating user defined testcases and transactions thereby obtaining cent percent functional coverage. The design is for providing simple, faster data rate, speedy read-write transactions, energy-efficient and budget-friendly approach for interfacing with low-speed peripherals like Real-Time Clock (RTC), Temperature Sensors, Watchdog Timers, Touchscreen Controllers, Light Sensors, Proximity Sensors, Keypad Interfaces, EEPROM by using APB protocol. This mechanism is intended to improve inter-chip communication and memory read/write efficiency. The proposed architecture is developed for communication between master and slave devices. Multiple read write transactions are implemented using multiple agents by making use of semaphore for selecting required agent based on semaphore keys. The memory simulation and verification is performed using the GVIM Editor and Questa Sim simulator. The test bench is further enhanced by implementing advanced features like concurrent task execution and comprehensive functional coverage analysis.

title: Utilising Various Machine Learning Algorithms to Analyze IoT Temperature Readings and Forecast Future Temperatures
authors: Pushpanjali Pandey, K K Garg, Milankumar Rana, Laura Aldasheva, Ashish Kumar Singh, Ummi Azizah Rachmawati
abstract: In the era of climate changes and ever-changing daily temperatures, we want to know tomorrow's temperature so we may plan our work and dress to prepare ourselves well in advance. In this work, we have used a Random Forest classifier, a Support Vector classifier, a KNN classifier, a Logistic Regression classifier, a Gradient Boosting classifier, a Decision Tree classifier, and an AdaBoost classifier, and the dataset was created from readings of one of the most common IoT devices, i.e., a temperature sensor. When ranking these seven machine learning algorithms based on their accuracy for this specific temperature dataset, the decision tree classifier performs the best in predicting future temperatures. In contrast, the K-nearest neighbour classifier ranks the lowest. The other five machine learning classifiers perform at intermediate levels. When analysing results based on precision, KNN is performing better than the other six algorithms.

title: Optical Humidity Sensing Based on GaN Optoelectronic Devices with Glucose/Polystyrene Opal Composite Film
authors: Bin Wei, Yilin He, Liang Chen, Wenchao Ding, Yumeng Luo, Kwai Hei Li
abstract: Real-time humidity monitoring is critical for environmental sensing and wearable health applications. Here, we present a chip-scale GaN-based optical humidity sensor integrating a glucose-polystyrene opal composite film. The monolithic device integrates light emission and detection on a single chip, enabling compact optical sensing without external components. Humidity-induced refractive index changes in the composite film modulate light reflection, thereby altering the photocurrent measured by the photodetector. The composite film significantly enhances sensitivity, achieving a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 15 \mu ~\mathrm{A}$</tex> photocurrent change over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 0}-\text{9 0 \%} \text{R H}$</tex>, with lower hysteresis than polystyrene-only film. The sensing device exhibits two distinct linear response regions with elevated sensitivity at high humidity. It also achieves a fast response time of 12 s and a recovery time of 6 s, while maintaining stable performance through humidity cycling tests. Practical implementation in a face mask configuration distinguishes normal, rapid, and deep inspiration patterns, highlighting its potential for cost-effective, wearable respiratory monitoring.

title: Free Vertical Planning in a TBO Environment
authors: Alexander Kuenz
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper examines the effects of Free Vertical Planning (FVP), which avoids any fixed vertical constraints such as cruise flight level, intermediate level flights in climb or descent, or strategic deconfliction constraints. In addition to reducing fuel burn by allowing constant climb to compensate for weight loss, FVP also helps provide more continuous vertical optimization between wind, potential contrail areas, and separation violations with other aircraft. Simulation of FVP for large-scale scenarios that maintain today's separation requirements will show whether the number of potential conflicts is also reduced, as it was the case with the introduction of free route airspace. The paper provides recommendations on how to implement FVP and what benefits can be expected.

title: Adaptive Level Skip Data Compression for Lossy Image Compression Using VLSI-Based Systems
authors: Shuthanshu Marwaha, G. Padmapriya, Veena C S, Magthelin Therase Louis, Shreya Ghosal, Samuka Mohanty
abstract: This paper presents an Adaptive Level Skip Data Compressed System as a means of improving levels of both accuracy and efficiency in the compression of information. In order to perform fewer computation while compromising the data quality the system incorporates a scaled skip logic as an option that only deals with selected decomposition bands. To summarize, employing a hierarchical coding system helps to analyse data with various characteristics correctly in terms of optimised compression and use of operating resources. Its usefulness varies with bpp configurations and can in this respect be used in a variety of fields, which need top notch strategies for buttressing durability. In evaluating the performance, the proposed Adaptive Scale Level Skip Coding continuously achieves a mean success rate of 100% % participations, that greatly outperforms the Distributed Arithmetic Approaches and the Filter-Based Methods.

title: Design and Performance Evaluation of an Environmental Radiation Monitor for Rapid Emergency Response
authors: Yingchao Liang, Mingde Bi, Ye Ai, Yang Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The increasing need for robust public safety infrastructure in the face of potential nuclear and radiological emergencies has driven the development of advanced environmental monitoring systems. This paper presents the comprehensive design, implementation, and performance evaluation of a rapidly deployable environmental radiation monitor engineered for such scenarios. The system is based on a high-efficiency 3"×3" NaI(Tl) scintillation detector, managed by a low-power dual-core ARM Cortex-A7 processor running an embedded Linux operating system. Its architecture features a modular hardware design for reliability, a sophisticated power management unit with a supercapacitor for graceful shutdown to ensure data integrity, and an independent, solar-ready power supply for long-term autonomous field deployment. Performance was rigorously evaluated through a series of experiments. The results demonstrate that the device operates reliably across a wide ambient temperature range of -40°C to 60°C. Critically, it maintains excellent spectral linearity and energy resolution in high-flux radiation fields up to 301 uGy/h, which corresponds to a raw detector input pulse rate of 1.63 Mcps. This confirmed stability and high throughput validate the system's design, proving its suitability as a reliable and effective tool for emergency response, environmental surveying, and other applications requiring unattended, high-performance radiation monitoring.

title: Design and Analysis of V-shaped Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor for Electric Vehicle Application
authors: Satyam Mani Tripathi, Manoj Kumawat
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The growing need for high-performance and energy-efficient traction motors in Electric Vehicles has drawn a lot of attention to interior permanent magnet synchronous motors(IPMSM). V-shaped IPMSMs are commonly chosen among other rotor configurations because of their exceptional flux-weakening capabilities and high torque density. In order to determine the best configuration for EV applications, this study compares various V-shaped IPMSM designs using ANSYS MAXWELL FEA software. First, torque ripple is used to assess various pole configurations. In order to demonstrate torque performance and loss reduction, the best design is then chosen and contrasted with P3G IPMSM and DSER-PM motors. Through striking the ideal balance between energy effectiveness and operational performance, the study’s findings support the creation of high-performance traction motors for the future.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Maximum Power Point Tracking Using Conventional and Advanced Techniques
authors: Heetarth Josh, Harman Kaur, Chanakya Bhatt, M. T. Shah
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Maximum PowerPoint Tracking (MPPT) algorithms are key components in photovoltaic systems for optimizing energy extraction. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative analysis between two MPPT algorithms, namely the Jellyfish Search Algorithm and the Fractional Open Circuit Voltage method. The study evaluates the performance of both the algorithms under varying environmental conditions. The Jellyfish Search Optimization Algorithm utilizes a novel swarm-based approach while the Fractional Open Circuit Voltage leverages fractional calculus principles. The tracking accuracy, response time, and adaptability to dynamic environmental factors are assessed for both the algorithm are presented in this paper. The findings simulation results are able provide valuable insights into the suitability of these MPPT algorithms for diverse PV applications.

title: A Review on Application of Machine Learning Algorithms to Predict the Brain Stroke
authors: Bhavya S, Srikrishna Shastri C
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Early identification of stroke warning signs can help to lessen the severity of the condition. Machine learning (ML) algorithms hold enormous potential in comparison to conventional methods that are employed in stroke prediction. An investigation into an alternative machine learning algorithm designed to forecast the probability of a brain stroke is presented in this review article. Several parameters, including age, heart disease, average blood sugar, and hypertension, have been analyzed to determine the critical elements needed to use machine learning to predict stroke. We investigated 24 research studies that applied various machine learning algorithms to these key factors and also used different imaging techniques to predict stroke. This literature review aims to explore the current state of research on stroke prediction using AI, highlighting key methodologies, datasets, and performance metrics employed in various studies.

title: Decision Alignment Protocols: Harmonising AI Agents for Comprehensive Market Assessment
authors: Akinyemi Arabambi, Bisola Faith Kayode, Olamide Faroun, Fatimat Okeleye, Emereuwaonu Ezechukwu, Abiola Oludotun, Oluwatosin Oyeladun, Gabriel Aiyeetan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: As the complexity of global markets increases, the demand for coherent, high-fidelity decision-making in AI-driven investment analysis has intensified. This paper introduces Decision Alignment Protocols (DAPs), a novel framework that advances beyond existing multi-agent coordination approaches through structured negotiation protocols and formal alignment guarantees. Unlike current systems that rely on simple voting or averaging mechanisms, our approach introduces Weighted Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (WPBFT) consensus with evidence-based conflict resolution and systematic four-dimensional assessment integration (financial, technological, regulatory, sociocultural). We propose the Enhanced Decision Alignment Protocol (EDAP), which achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$95 \%+$</tex> alignment consistency and 99.7 % conflict resolution success rate through mathematically formalized negotiation processes, significantly outperforming existing trading systems that lack formal decision coherence guarantees. Our evaluation demonstrates that while traditional models achieve up to 85.1 % accuracy in single-dimension optimization, EDAP provides 91.2 % accuracy with superior long-term risk management through comprehensive perspective integration and formal alignment verification.

title: 10 Transistor Low Power CMOS STDP Circuit in GF 180nm PDK
authors: Mayank Chauhan, Vinay Kumar, Varun Sangwan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) are designed to mimic how real biological neurons work, using brain-inspired methods. Compared to traditional Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), SNNs are much more energy-efficient, especially when it comes to tasks like pattern recognition. Researchers are now working on enabling these networks to learn directly on hardware chips. One popular learning method is called SpikeTiming Dependent Plasticity (STDP), which follows the idea that “neurons that fire together, wire together.” By combining STDP circuits with some additional components, we can build hardware that learns efficiently and uses far less energy. In this article, we propose a STDP circuit design and study the functionality of the STDP circuit. The circuit was designed using GF180nm PDK in Ngspice. It works in sub-threshold regime hence it consumes ultra low energy per spike which is close to 0.2 pJ for potentiation and 0.03pJ for depression.

title: Emotion Recognition Through Handwriting Analysis in Examination Contexts: A Study on Student Emotions
authors: Shreyash Thakur, N Prabakaran, P Vishal Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study examines the possibility of handwriting analysis as a means of emotion detection among students under examination. Handwriting as a behavioural biometric is a distinctive behavioural trait that offers significant information about an individual’s emotional status through measurable differences in features like stroke pressure, writing slant, pen lift, speed, and letter spacing. With analysis of these attributes, it becomes possible to categorize emotions, which prevail among students during examination times. The research has a multidisciplinary perspective in that it utilizes image processing technology combined with machine learning algorithms for extracting and processing handwriting attributes of scanned examination sheets. The system proposed focuses on accuracy and reliability in identifying subtle emotional signals from handwriting patterns. The results are expected to offer greater insights into the psychological states of students during examinations, providing a new window of opportunity for educators, psychologists, and educational institutions. Such insights can help in developing emotionally supportive learning environments by identifying students experiencing emotional distress and taking timely interventions. This study provides the foundation for subsequent research in emotion detection via handwriting, with potential implications in education, mental health, and human-computer interaction fields.

title: Enhancing Uav Swarm Security Through an Rssi-based Protocol for Gnss-Compromised Environments
authors: Mauro Conti, Federico Corò, Giulio Rigoni
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The UAV market has experienced significant growth, with an expanding range of applications. However, the reliance of UAV missions on GNSS makes them vulnerable to attacks, particularly GNSS spoofing and jamming, which can cause mission failure or even physical damage. To mitigate this risk, we propose a lightweight fleet protocol designed to ensure that drones can complete their missions securely, even when under attack. Our system utilizes intra-fleet communication and Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) measurements for positioning, enabling the fleet to maintain formation and reach its destination even under GNSS attacks, or in a GNSS compromised scenario, thus avoiding its vulnerabilities. The proposed protocol was evaluated through extensive simulations using NS-3. The results reveal that the proposed protocol achieves a high mission success rate, reaching 100 % in most single-attack scenarios, and demonstrates robust attack identification even when multiple drones are attacked or compromised. The average attack detection delay was measured at 300 milliseconds for single-attacker scenarios, while the RSSI table was updated every 50 to 55 milliseconds, ensuring data freshness. These findings highlight the potential of our solution to improve the resilience of UAV swarms in GNSS-compromised environments.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Green Space Mapping in High-Resolution Satellite Imagery
authors: Ragini Mangali, Padmaja Mididoddi, Navyasri Rashmitha Tatineni, Aashritha Avula
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Urban green spaces are essential for improving air quality, mitigating the effects of heat in urban environments, promoting diversity, and enhancing a city’s standard of living in general. Monitoring and managing these green zones has become increasingly critical with the continuous expansion of urban areas worldwide. To map urban greenery effectively and cost-effectively, this research employs convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to perform semantic segmentation on highresolution satellite data. The focus is on accurately identifying and classifying green spaces, such as agricultural areas and forests, at the pixel level using deep learning techniques. Three widely recognized CNN models-FCN-8, SegNet, and U-Net-were applied and assessed for their performance in extracting green regions from satellite images. These models underwent training and evaluation on detailed imagery, enabling fine-grained, pixel-wise segmentation. The study compares the accuracy and the clarity of their segmentation outputs. Ultimately, the findings highlight the potential of CNN-based approaches in automating urban green space detection, supporting comprehensive environmental assessments and urban planning efforts.

title: A Six-Leg Coupled Inductor Based Regenerative Cascaded Multicell Converter
authors: Satyam Jha, Shambhu Sau
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The regenerative cascaded multicell converter (CMC) is a promising solution for variable-speed medium voltage (MV) drives. However, the two-level operation of pulse-width modulated (PWM) rectifiers on the grid side necessitates the use of a filter inductor and an oversized or K-rated transformer to mitigate the harmonics generated by the rectifiers and prevent overheating. This paper proposes a six-leg coupled inductor and PWM rectifier cell-based topology that attenuates the harmonics in transformer winding current to almost negligible value, which allows the use of a regular multi-winding transformer without overrating. The power cell includes a three-phase PWM rectifier that ensures balanced grid current even if there is unbalance at the output side. The performance of the proposed system, along with comparisons to existing topologies, is evaluated through MATLAB/Simulink simulations, and the results are discussed in this paper.

title: AI Based Analysis of Machine Learning Strategies for Client Retention
authors: Anupam Choudhary, Surendra Kumar Shukla, Sapna Jain Choudhary, Prateek Gupta, Sanchita Dubey
abstract: This paper conducts a comprehensive analysis of various machine learning (ML) strategies for client retention, a pivotal component in sustaining business growth. With the increasing cost-effectiveness of retaining existing customers compared to acquiring new ones, the significance of client retention is accentuated. Machine learning revolutionizes traditional client retention methods by utilizing advanced algorithms to predict customer churn. This study compares supervised, unsupervised, and hybrid ML models to determine their efficacy in predicting and optimizing client retention. Through rigorous examination, including cross-validation and Monte Carlo simulations, the study highlights the enhanced performance of ensemble methods like AdaBoost and Random Forest in predicting client behavior. Furthermore, the paper addresses the challenges of data quality, ethical considerations, and the interpretability of ML models in client retention strategies. The findings underscore the transformative potential of ML in client retention, offering actionable insights for businesses to proactively address customer churn.

title: Research on energy efficiency optimization of electrical equipment based on machine learning
authors: Liang Yue, Xiaolong Wang, Dongming Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In order to enhance the energy efficiency of electrical equipment under complex working conditions, an energy efficiency modeling and prediction method based on the XGBoost algorithm was developed. At the initial stage of the study, the factors affecting energy efficiency were analyzed. A multi-dimensional feature input system was built based on actual data sets. Annual power consumption was used as the prediction object to create a regression modeling pattern. In the model training implementation stage, five-fold cross-validation and hyperparameter optimization methods were used to improve generalization ability, and an error monitoring mechanism was added to ensure the stability of the prediction. The experimental results show that the average error rate of the constructed model in multiple samples does not exceed 1.2%, showing a strong fitting effect and robustness. Further analysis was carried out with the help of feature perturbation and strategy simulation, and the trend of energy efficiency changes before and after optimization was evaluated. The use of heat pump control and nighttime shutdown methods can reduce power consumption by more than 5%. The model can provide solid and reliable support for the energy-saving transformation of electrical equipment and the optimization of operation strategies, reflecting a high engineering application value.

title: Design of Multi-toned Piezoelectric Ultrasound Energy Harvester (PUEH) for Implanted Medical Devices
authors: Praveen Nunna, Pankaj Das, Sudip Kundu
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Implanted Medical Devices (IMDs), such as pacemakers and neural stimulators, significantly improve patients’ lives. However, frequent battery replacements via surgery pose health risks. This paper proposes a piezoelectric ultrasound energy harvester (PUEH) as a promising solution to prolong IMDs’ battery life. It is noteworthy that confined ultrasound within a small region, such as between human skin and IMDs, generates standing waves. As demonstrated in this paper, these standing waves induce significant oscillations in the output power of a single piezoelectric (PZ) diaphragm as the IMD’s depth varies. Consequently, single-diaphragm-based PUEHs are unsuitable for powering IMDs’ batteries. To address this issue, the proposed PUEH features a multi-diaphragm-based piezoelectric device with different resonant frequencies for each of the diaphragm structures. The performance of the proposed multi-diaphragmbased PUEH has been evaluated using COMSOL Multiphysics, simulating in an environment equivalent to the inside of the human body. The proposed multi-diaphragm-based PUEH optimized for operation in a multi-toned ultrasonic environment, is capable of generating a peak power output of approximately $140 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ at a tissue depth of around 1.6 mm. Additionally, it is capable to generate over $30 \mu \mathrm{~W}$ of power at tissue depths up to 6 mm. This makes it a viable solution for powering implanted medical devices, such as pacemakers.

title: Optimal Operation of Multi Carrier Energy System Considering IGDT Approach: A Multi Objective Framework
authors: Ankit Garg, K. R. Niazi, Md Fahim Ansari, S.S. Sahoo
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Reducing carbon emissions from electrical energy systems is a critical step toward climate change mitigation and the decarbonization of the power sector. In this context, green hydrogen—produced via electrolysis using renewable electricity—has gained prominence as a viable energy carrier. It offers a low-carbon alternative for sectors with high energy demand and limited electrification potential, thereby contributing to both energy system flexibility and long-term environmental sustainability. This study proposes an Multi-Carrier energy System (MCES) operational framework for biomass-derived green hydrogen production, incorporating photovoltaic (PV) and wind energy, along with biomass electrolyzers, battery energy storage (BES) and hydrogen storage (HS) to enhance system efficiency and reliability. To address uncertainties in renewable generation, energy demand and market fluctuations, an Information Gap Decision theory-based Normalized Weighted-Sum (IGDT-NWS) approach is employed. This approach is applied to solve a multi-objective optimization problem, aiming to optimize operational costs and minimize carbon emissions while addressing the inherent uncertainties in the system while addressing the impact of uncertainties. Additionally, this study highlights the advantages of integrating HS with BES to enhance overall energy efficiency. The results indicate that the proposed model achieves a 36.17% reduction in IEH operational costs by using the and a 33.63% decrease in environmental impact, demonstrating its effectiveness in promoting cost-efficient and sustainable energy system operation.

title: Analyzing the Effect of Text Vectorization and Word2vec on Bayesian Optimization for Mental Health Text Classification Using Deep Learning
authors: Esha Kunder, Praveen M Naik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: ental health is a major global concern. As people communicate more online, we have new chances to spot and help those at risk. Automated text classification helps detect mental health issues in digital conversations, making effective and accurate methods increasingly important.ental health is a major global concern. As people communicate more online, we have new chances to spot and help those at risk. Automated text classification helps detect mental health issues in digital conversations, making effective and accurate methods increasingly important.M This research explores the effect of different input embedding techniques on the performance and generalization capability of deep learning models trained on multiclass text classification for mental health detection. Models such as Bidirectional GRU (BiGRU), Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM), and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) are trained using two different embedding methods: Word2Vec and Text Vectorization. All models are optimized using Bayesian Optimization to tune hyperparameters. Despite this tuning, models trained with Text Vectorization embeddings showed poor performance and overfitting. In contrast, models trained using Word2Vec embeddings achieved a better performance indicating better learning and generalization. These findings highlights the fundamental importance of selecting input embeddings, as hyperparameter optimization alone cannot overcome the limitations of weak input representations.

title: Harnessing Digital Linguistics for Dynamic Analysis of Modern English Usage
authors: Myagmarsuren Orosoo, Sreela B, Shukur Ramadan Hama Sharif, M. Mythili, Afsana Anjum, R Saravanakumar
abstract: Contemporary English is facing rapid changes owing to its users communicating with one another electronically and building a distinct culture in the usages of language. Linguistics are often studied traditionally using manual and semi-automated means, which cannot fully scale and sometimes overlook the subtleties of a dynamic usage of a language. Thus, this research aims to develop a computational framework for the digital assessment of linguistic characteristics in modern English, using advanced NLP tools and a corpus-based perspective to highlight subtle variations in syntax, semantics, and pragmatics. Parties that previously researched the isolation of lexical or grammatical features thus explored an integrative approach-combining quantitative frequency analysis, post tagging, sentiment analysis, and contextual interpretation. The proposed hybrid model puts together any useful observations to gain a better understanding of modern in-the-field contextual applications of English, especially in digital and informal contexts. The framework relies on a tagged corpus of contemporary texts in line with NLP processing pipelines. It applies statistical modeling and machine learning classifiers with high precision to identify linguistic trends. The system achieved an overall classification accuracy of 92.4% in the detectable contextual appropriateness and linguistic shifts across genres. The evaluation demonstrated that there were clear distinctions in vocabulary richness, syntactic preferences, and sentiment inclinations for the formal compared to informal domains. Informal texts, it is worth noting, exhibit considerably higher present-past contrast between contractions, emoji use, and pragmatic markers. In conclusion, thus computational approach greatly advances digital evaluation of English language use by providing linguists, teachers, and AI developers with a simple tool for real-time observation of and analysis into the evolution of language.

title: Optimal Node Assignment for Blockchain Mining over IoT through Pareto Non-Dominance
authors: Santosh Das, Kounteya Sarkar, Sudip Misra, Parama Bhaumik
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In this work we provide an optimal assignment of edge IoT nodes to act as hash calculators for blockchain mining using Pareto dominance sorting. IoT nodes being resource constrained are not suited to execute intensive mining operations individually. But, collectively they can be used small parallel computation cores for hash calculation within a specific nonce range. We propose an assignment algorithm that selects a set of IoT nodes which are expected to consume the least amount of resources by assigning the mining tasks over those nodes. Assuming that a prior empirical relation is known for each node that can predict the expected amount of mining resources like energy and time of mining, before each mining epoch, the proposed algorithm calculates the expected resource consumption values for all the nodes. It then sorts the nodes into different Pareto fronts based on dominated sorting and further, for each front it calculates a cumulative inter-Pareto distance for each node. We show that by selecting the nodes as per the sorted inter-Pareto distance, an optimal selection is achieved that reduces the overall composite resource consumption for block mining. Through detailed experimental analysis, we have corroborated our claims, where we find that proposed algorithm achieves a benefit of $47.71 \%$ with respect to energy consumption and a benefit of $19.27 \%$ with respect to improvement in mining time over other selection algorithms.

title: Emotion Recognition in Multilingual Text Using BiLSTM-Based Approach for Indian Languages
authors: Sakshi G Pai, Afnan A Gudagi, Sarvesh R Hampali, Satish Chikkamath, Suneeta V. Budihal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Emotion detection from text is vital in understanding human communication and improving interactions across various platforms. While most existing work has focused on monolingual emotion recognition, multilingual emotion detection remains underexplored, particularly in India, where linguistic diversity plays a significant role in daily communication. This study aims to bridge this gap by addressing emotion detection in multilingual text, explicitly focusing on English, Hindi, and Kannada. The proposed approach uses a BiLSTM (Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory) network with an attention mechanism to effectively capture and classify a wide range of emotions from tweets. Unlike traditional sentiment analysis, which categorizes text into basic sentiment classes (positive, negative, neutral), emotion analysis in this work classifies text into 13 distinct emotions, including joy, sadness, anger, love, and more. The model reduces the feature space compactness by incorporating tokenization, enhancing its efficiency and accuracy. The results highlight the potential of BiLSTM-based models for multilingual emotion detection and emphasize the importance of understanding emotions in diverse linguistic settings, particularly for mental health monitoring and improving communication in multilingual societies.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Fault Classification in Electric Vehicle Drive Motors
authors: Zaid Abdulkareem Hussein, Aws M. Abdullah, Enas A. Zayid, Haneen A. Saleh, Anas Fouad Ahmed
