publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: A new and hybrid deep learning-based approach for diagnosing faults in electric vehicle (EV) drive motors is proposed in this article. This article presents a new and hybrid deep learning-based method of diagnosing faults in the drive motors of electric vehicles (EV). In contrast to standard CNNLSTM approaches that depend on SoftMax classification, the introduced framework combines a Random Forest (RF) classifier to enhance the generalization, interpretability, and robustness of fault prediction. Furthermore meant for use on edge computing equipment with IoT integration, the design allows for real-time monitoring in resource-limited settings. The introduced algorithm utilizes a Random Forest (RF) classifier for accurate fault classification after integrating the convolutional neural networks (CNN) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to extract both spatial and temporal features from motor data. The presented mechanism shows higher accuracy (98.1%) and computational efficiency compared to the state-of-the-art algorithms, and it can be implemented in real time on edge computing systems, facilitating continuous motor condition monitoring in electric vehicles.

title: Smart Farming Assistant for Crop Advice and Disease Detection
authors: Supriya Salian, Preethi Salian K, Ritesh, Ria Dsouza, Prathiksha S. Poojari, Khushi R. Haldankar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Agriculture remains the primary livelihood for millions in developing regions, yet smallholder and urban farmers continue to face persistent challenges such as low crop productivity, inefficient resource utilization, and limited access to modern agricultural technologies. This paper presents the Smart Farming Assistant, an integrated and cost-effective platform that leverages the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to enable data-driven decisionmaking in agriculture. The system collects real-time environmental data such as soil moisture, temperature, and humidity using IoT sensors, and applies machine learning models to deliver personalized crop and fertilizer recommendations. It also supports early plant disease detection through image analysis powered by deep learning. Designed with a focus on affordability, accessibility, and ease of use, the assistant empowers small-scale farmers to improve yield, optimize inputs, and adopt sustainable farming practices. This study details the system's architecture, implementation, experimental results, and outlines future enhancements to improve scalability and functionality.

title: Implementation of Linear Feedback Shift Register circuit (LFSR) Using Transmission Gate Diffusion Input(TGDI) Technique
authors: Amartya Roy, Neeta Pandey, Harikesh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study introduces a Linear Feedback Shift Register (LFSR) design that incorporates a Transmission Gate Diffusion Input (TGDI) based D flip-flop (DFF) as its primary sequential component. The proposed architecture capitalizes on the benefits of TGDI logic and Transmission Gate structures, improving the LFSR’s performance by enhancing both speed and power efficiency. By employing TGDI-based DFFs, the design demonstrates a $74.15 \%$ reduction in delay and an improvement of 38.33% in Power-Delay Product (PDP) when compared to conventional DFF-based LFSR implementations. Simulation results support these advancements, positioning the TGDI-based LFSR as an effective solution for high-performance, low-power digital applications. The compactness and bidirectional capabilities of TGDI logic play a crucial role in optimizing the design, emphasizing its potential for future cryptographic and communication system applications.

title: Edge-Cloud Collaborative Privacy-Preserving Motion-Based Authentication for XR Systems
authors: Mingrui Yin, Sohom Sen, Yongjie Guan, Xueyu Hou, Tao Han, Nirwan Ansari
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: Current extended reality (XR) systems predominantly rely on conventional authentication methods such as password entry or iris recognition. However, password-based login in immersive environments is cumbersome due to the difficulty of operating virtual keyboards, while iris recognition often fails for users wearing head-mounted displays or glasses. Inspired by the emerging use of companion devices for realtime authentication, we propose a novel edge-cloud collaborative motion-based authentication framework tailored for XR systems. In our approach, the edge device first employs a lightweight machine learning model to extract a user's action sequence in the form of SMPL-X parameters, which are then encoded into a compact motion-password representation. To ensure both privacy and robustness against motion variability, the encoded sequence is further protected using error correction coding (ECC), transforming it into a secure binary representation without exposing raw biometric features. Finally, the cloud server verifies the ECCprotected motion-password against stored references, enabling scalable, secure, and low-latency authentication for XR applications. We implement a prototype show superior performance to FMCode and MetaFL: 97.3% accuracy, 0.4% EER, stronger low-FPR behavior, and improved scalability. We also include a security analysis under practical threat models.

title: Securing IoT-Based Health and Environmental Data Using AI-Powered Cybersecurity Solutions
authors: P. Chinnaraj, V. Praveena, Nagalakshmi Yarlagadda, Richa Kashyap, Vivek Saurav, S. Balamuralitharan
abstract: The blistering integration of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies in health care and environmental monitoring has brought with it serious cybersecurity issues which have especially involved the safekeeping of sensitive and real-time data. The traditional centralized security architectures also suffer since they are vulnerable to single points of failure and scale poorly as there are more and more distributed IoT devices. To solve these problems, the paper would suggest an intelligent approach with the name Adaptive AI-Driven Federated Cyber Defense Framework (AA-FCDF). The model would merge federated learning with anomaly detection using reinforcement learning to provide real time decentralized real time threat identification without degrading privacy of data. Each IoT object has a lightweight local model that is trained on device-specific data and make encrypted model updates in a centralized aggregator periodically. This will facilitate the continued learning throughout the network and not compromise the information on health and the environment. Further, a scoring system based on trust performs a dynamic evaluation of the behaviour of the devices isolating or applying enhanced encryption protocols to potentially compromised nodes. The responsiveness to the two zero-day attack, internal attack, and spoofing issue is possible due to the flexibility of the system. Experiments on the simulation are showing higher accuracy of detection, less leakage of data, higher response speed than traditional models. The suggested AA-FCDF technique attained an overall accuracy of 97.4% in the assessment of cybersecurity efficiency inside IoT systems.

title: Exploring Depression Severity During Lockdown Through Explainable AI
authors: Stefania Zinno, Sayna Rotbei, Giovanni Stanco, Giorgio Ventre, Giordano D'Urso, Alessio Botta
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Depression and anxiety are among the most common responses to large-scale traumatic episodes (e.g. pandemics or armed conflicts), particularly when these involve prolonged restriction measures for the population. The goal of this study is to predict the extent of depressive symptoms, evaluated using the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) scale, during the COVID-19 lockdown, starting from scores of multiple psychological scales collected prior to the lockdown. More importantly, we aim to identify the most influential features driving these predictions through eXplainable AI (XAI) techniques. To this end, we selected Gradient Boosting as our predictive model and applied SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) to assess feature importance. We then generated Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs) on the topranking features identified by SHAP to further explore their impact on the model's output. Scores from Item 9, Item 3, and Item 1 of the BDI-II scales, regarding Suicidal Thoughts, Sadness and Failure emerged as key predictors in the model.

title: DP-HAR: Dual-Path Transformer-CNN Fusion for Robust Action Recognition
authors: Anil Kumar Koona, Harpreet Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Human action recognition plays a critical role in applications such as surveillance, sports analytics, and assistive technologies. With the increasing availability of video data, developing models that are both accurate and efficient has become essential. Despite progress, existing methods struggle to jointly capture fine-grained spatial semantics and long-range temporal dynamics, especially in real-world videos with motion blur, occlusions, and complex scenes. These challenges limit their robustness and scalability. Conventional CNNs efficiently encode spatial information but are insufficient for modeling temporal dependencies. In contrast, pure transformer-based models, though powerful for temporal reasoning, often incur high computational costs and underperform on spatially localized patterns. To address these limitations, this study propose a Dual-Path Hybrid Action Recognition (DP-HAR) framework that integrates a CNN path based on EfficientNet-B3 and a transformer path using MobileViT-S with 128-dimensional embeddings and 4-head attention. The outputs are fused via late concatenation followed by a lightweight 1D convolutional layer (kernel size = 3) for spatiotemporal integration. This work evaluate DP-HAR on the UCF101 and HMDB51 datasets, comprising 13,320 and 6,766 videos across 101 and 51 action classes, respectively. These benchmarks include challenging conditions like camera motion, occlusion, and background clutter. DP-HAR achieves 93.6% Top-1 accuracy on UCF101 and 71.5% on HMDB51, outperforming existing CNN and transformer models. It maintains real-time performance at 110 FPS with only 14.2 M parameters and 28.6 GFLOPs. In conclusion, DP-HAR offers an effective and lightweight solution for video-based action recognition, combining high accuracy with low latency for deployment in practical environments.

title: Optimization and implementation of edge intelligent terminals for distribution automation
authors: Zixin Yu, Feng Long, Qian Lv, Yan Zhang, Xue Yu, Jing Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimization and implementation method for edge intelligent terminals for distribution automation. First, the functional requirements of edge computing technology and distribution automation system are analyzed, and an integrated optimization architecture based on multi-source perception, local intelligent reasoning, elastic communication and security protection is designed. Subsequently, combined with the SoCal 28-Bus dataset, an experimental platform was built, and functional verification, performance evaluation and optimization effect analysis were carried out. The experimental results show that the optimized edge intelligent terminal is significantly superior to the traditional terminal in terms of fault response speed, load prediction accuracy, energy efficiency ratio and communication reliability. The research results provide theoretical support and practical reference for the design and deployment of edge intelligent terminals in intelligent distribution systems.

title: Correspondence Analysis for Vehicle Re-Identification Methods in Multi-Target Tracking
authors: Alexander Straube, Johannes Ostler, Peter Stütz
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In this work, we present a novel approach to evaluate lightweight vehicle Re-Identification (Re-ID) methods under real-world aerial surveillance conditions, with the goal of improving identity consistency within a Multi-Target Tracking (MTT) framework. Using data collected during manned Very Light Aircraft (VLA) flight experiments with an electro-optical (EO) payload, we created a structured aerial Re-ID dataset and implemented a modular evaluation pipeline. We establish a perceptual image hashing baseline followed by a grid-based color histogram descriptor capturing spatial appearance cues. By performing late fusion of perceptual and color distances, we improve retrieval robustness, achieving over 79 % Rank @ 1 accuracy on our own dataset. The proposed method remains lightweight and suitable for embedded onboard systems, supporting future integration into real-time airborne MTT systems.

title: Run-Time Assurance Based Flight Control System Architecture for a Hybrid Fly-by-Wire Light Sport Aircraft
authors: Nils Schlautmann, Viktor Sinitsyn, Johannes Bender, Evangelos Huber, Julius Hoffelner, Florian Holzapfel
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper proposes a Run-Time Assurance (RTA) based flight control system architecture for digital Fly-by-Wire (FBW) Light Sport Aircraft (LSA). The proposed approach offers a cost-effective, safe, and certifiable method to introduce FBW systems to an aircraft category previously excluded due to safety and financial concerns. This allows for functionalities such as handling quality improvements, envelope protection and turbulence alleviation to enhance safety and comfort in LSA. A hybrid concept with split control surfaces and mechanical backups, together with a novel “surface-following” mode, enables safe system deactivation at any time. The application of lean system development assurance processes boosts confidence in the system design while minimizing additional overhead. Certification considerations are identified and addressed during the system design. The inherently safe design helps regulators and manufacturers to build trust in RTA-based FBW systems, paving the way for more complex and capable designs in the future.

title: Design and Performance Evaluation of a Bridgeless PFC Based Pulse Power Supply
authors: Deepak Meena, Saravana Prakash P, Hemant Kumar Meena
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper introduces the design and analysis of a pulse power supply (PPS) based on a bridgeless power factor correction (BPFC) topology, a flyback converter to achieve high-voltage switching. The proposed system operates at a fixed pulse repetition frequency with a defined pulse width, delivering a high-voltage output and a regulated current. The BPFC topology is utilized to improve power quality by significantly reducing total harmonic distortion, minimizing input current ripple, and achieving near-unity power factor. The performance of the proposed PPS system is analyzed using MATLAB-Simulink simulations, where a resistive dummy load is employed to verify its capability of delivering the desired high-voltage output. The simulation results demonstrate the efficiency and reliability of the system, establishing it as a viable solution for applications requiring precise and efficient pulsed power supplies.

title: Development and Validation of Point-in-Space Approach Procedures for General Aviation at Essen-Mühlheim Aerodrome Using the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service
authors: Oliver Meyer, Thomas Dautermann
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper explores the potential of conducting precision approach training by using the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service instead of conventional landing systems. Our method allows flight schools to perform training precision approaches at their base airport, independent of navigation infrastructure only available at larger airports. The usage of a cost-effective satellite- to ground-based augmentation system converter enables aircraft to conduct localizer performance approaches with vertical guidance which are independent of an aircraft's database. To validate the operational concept, three point-in-space precision approach look-alike procedures were developed for Essen/Mühlheim Regional Airport respecting the surrounding complex airspace structure. Subsequently, the designed approaches were evaluated through flight trials using a prototype ground-based augmentation system receiver for general aviation. Results show sufficient performance of the technical equipment as well as the feasibility of the design of the developed procedures for precision approach training.

title: Autonomous mobile robot exploration in unknown environments and map construction based on reinforcement learning
authors: Guangyu Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Faced with the increasing uncertainty of global supply chain and the limitations of traditional demand forecasting and inventory management methods, this paper takes the core of big data analysis to supply chain management, combines literature research method, case analysis method and empirical verification, and systematically explores the application path and actual value of big data analysis in supply chain demand forecasting and inventory optimization. Firstly, it sorted out the relevant theoretical basis of big data analysis, demand forecasting and inventory optimization, and clarified the fitting logic of the three. Then, the specific practice of big data in demand forecasting was analyzed from the dimensions of multi-source data collection and preprocessing, algorithm model application (such as machine learning, deep learning), and effect evaluation. The results show that the prediction method based on big data can reduce the demand Prediction Error (MAPE) of retail and manufacturing enterprises by $\mathbf{1 8 \%} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{2 5 \%}$ on average. Then, optimization models such as dynamic safety inventory and multi-level collaborative inventory based on accurate prediction are constructed, and their effects are verified by cases in the fresh food and automobile industries. Empirical results show that the model can help enterprises reduce inventory holding cost by $\mathbf{1 2 \%} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{1 9 \%}$, increase inventory turnover rate by $\mathbf{2 0 \%} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{2 7 \%}$, and control the out-of-stock rate within 3%. The research results confirm that big data analysis can effectively solve the problems of supply chain demand forecasting lag, inventory redundancy or shortage through multisource data fusion, real-time dynamic adjustment and global collaborative optimization, and provide theoretical support and practical path for enterprises to improve supply chain resilience and operational efficiency.

title: Research on intelligent manufacturing production scheduling optimization based on artificial intelligence
authors: Zhihao Sheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In intelligent manufacturing systems, production scheduling issues have become the focus of optimization due to their direct impact on equipment resource coordination and production efficiency. Traditional scheduling methods are often limited in effectiveness due to the lack of global perception and adaptive capabilities when facing dynamic task loads and multi-equipment multi-constraint environments. To this end, this paper constructs a scheduling optimization model suitable for intelligent manufacturing scenarios based on deep reinforcement learning (Proximal Policy Optimization, PPO). The model integrates industrial constraints such as processing sequence, energy consumption, tool life and maintenance window, and forms an optimization closed loop through state modeling, policy learning and simulation experiments. Based on the 2024 FJCS-SDFSTs-ITTs public dataset, the experiment compares the differences between PPO and EDD, GA, PSO and other methods in terms of completion time, equipment utilization and energy consumption, and verifies the effectiveness and robustness of this method in multi-objective scheduling optimization. The research results provide a theoretical basis and practical support for the intelligent upgrade of manufacturing scheduling.

title: Attribute-based encryption access control method of multi-authorization center for smart power plant
authors: Fei Li, Zhiyuan Li, Ning Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Encryption of attribute-based parameters of multi-authorization centers in smart power plants is the key technology to improve the intelligent control and access of power plant data. An attribute-based encryption access control algorithm of multi-authorization centers in smart power plants based on knowledge map reconstruction and nonlinear iterative encryption is proposed. According to the existing equipment account and maintenance information of power grid, the knowledge association map feature library in multi-authorization of smart power plant is constructed. Combined with the analysis of power grid structure and equipment stability characteristics, the security key of authorization center access control is established. Combined with the analysis of operation management efficiency and production safety characteristics of power plant, the spatial encryption and nonlinear chaotic key reorganization of multi-dimensional authorization center of power plant are realized by using the method of knowledge map reconstruction, and the intelligent waybill expert system construction and attribute-based access control of smart power plant are realized by using object programming technology. The numerical simulation results show that this method can effectively realize the attribute-based encryption and dynamic access control of multi-authorization centers in smart power plants, and the encryption and decryption have higher security and lower bit error rate.

title: Research on intelligent auxiliary decision-making method based on knowledge graph in power system
authors: Bo Jiang, Wenyun Zhou, Ziqing Li, Zhongyuan Pang, Endong Xu, Xinjie Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In order to improve the intelligent assistance capability in the dispatching and operation of power systems, this paper proposes an intelligent auxiliary decision-making method based on knowledge graph. This method constructs a semantic graph of multi-source heterogeneous data and integrates logical rules and graph neural network reasoning mechanism to achieve accurate modeling of the relationship between power entities and efficient reasoning of decision-making knowledge. In terms of architectural design, the system is divided into a knowledge construction layer, a reasoning decision layer, and a business interaction layer to form a complete decision support closed loop. The experimental part is verified based on the 2023 PowerGraph dataset and evaluated from the dimensions of functional accuracy, reasoning efficiency, and comparative performance. The experimental results show that the proposed method shows excellent accuracy and interpretability in a variety of power tasks. The research results provide a feasible path and technical basis for promoting knowledge-driven intelligent dispatching in new power systems.

title: Early warning of abnormal operation data of power generation equipment based on data lake collaborative multi-core correlation vector
authors: Hongyan Meng, Xuejun Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The early warning of abnormal operation data of power generation equipment can further realize the overall goal of power system reform. This paper puts forward an early warning model of abnormal operation data of power generation equipment based on the data lake collaborative multi-core correlation vector, constructs the data lake collaborative multi-core correlation vector for the joint analysis of the production and consumption of power commodities, and realizes the reconstruction and feature combination control of the operation data of power generation equipment by using the joint analysis of market operation rules, market management methods and market operation models. Then, this study established a fair and open distribution model for the electricity trading market, and combined it with the geographical location factors of power generation equipment operation for transaction control. Based on the market coverage area, the market power of market participants will be monitored and controlled, so as to realize the data lake collaborative multi-core correlation analysis of abnormal early warning of power generation equipment operation data and realize intelligent early warning. The simulation results show that the model can effectively realize the early warning and control of abnormal operation data of power generation equipment, and realize the intelligent planning, stable operation control and dynamic management of power grid and power generation equipment.

title: A comparative analysis of Transformer life expectancy using DGA and ML models
authors: Ravindra B Kuhada, Ankit K Srivastava, Bharat S Rajpurohit
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Transformers are critical equipment in power substations and their operational reliability depends on improving grid stability. Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA), a diagnostic tool, and oil quality parameters can assess the health of the transformer and predict the failure condition of the transformer by analyzing dissolved gas in the transformer’s oil. This paper presents a comparative analysis of the life expectancy of transformers based on various DGA techniques. The authors also explore the characteristics and origins of gases that depend on transformer behaviour. Various machine learning approaches, such as Gradient Boosting Regressor, Random Forest Regressor, K-Nearest Neighbor Regressor, Linear SVR, and Lasso Regressor are evaluated to predict the transformer’s lifetime based on Kaggle’s data. The study concludes with a detailed comparison of the methods and highlights their effectiveness in predicting the life expectancy of transformers.

title: A Two-Stage Disruptive Technology Identification Framework Based on Knowledge Graph
authors: Yuchen Wu, Hao Qin, Shutong Liu, Yunhe Yang, Yanming Chen, Qiuqi Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Disruptive technologies, with their capacity to reshape industries, are crucial for global competitiveness. However, their early-stage identification is challenging due to latent trajectories and complex dynamics. Traditional forecasting methods often fall short. In this paper, a two-stage framework is proposed, integrating multi-feature indicator prediction with technological network structure analysis to identify disruptive technologies. First, we construct a tripartite assessment framework encompassing technological novelty, market impact, and social effects. Machine learning models are then utilised to initially screen for patents with high disruptive potential. Then, for these pre-selected candidates, we employ graph representation learning, constructing Graph Attention Networks (GATs) to analyze their core node status within the technological network, thereby validating their disruptive nature. Empirical validation using AI-domain patent data demonstrates the framework's effectiveness. The study identifies 8 categories of high-potential disruptive technologies in Artificial Intelligence (AI), quantifies feature contributions, and provides strategic implications.

title: Soft Kinematics-Constrained Smooth Trajectory Prediction Using a Diffusion Transformer-Based Architecture
authors: Vishnu Dev Tripathi, Vaibhav Malviya, Rahul Kala
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: Trajectory prediction is widely used in the navigation of social robotic systems. Model-driven approaches (or Physics-based algorithms) cannot capture the complexity of social compliance, and thus, data-driven approaches are widely used. We study a diffusion-based trajectory prediction algorithm that generates samples of trajectories from a learned distribution. We observe that while the generator keeps the trajectory close to the ground truth trajectory for at least one sample, most of the samples have zig-zag shapes, are kinematically infeasible and unrealistic. These attributes are absent in the model-driven approaches. As the first objective, we force the trajectory generator to output kinematically feasible and smooth trajectories. Since humans can kinematically take sharp turns, our notion of kinematic constraints is soft; smoother turns are preferable, while the model should allow sharp turns if necessary. As another objective, we also critically analyse the public datasets for algorithmic ease of handling corner cases like sharp turns, high densities, high/low travel speeds, a large number of people, etc. and thus characterize datasets by complexity in corner cases. High-interaction datasets have corner cases that are hard to learn, as they represent the heavy-tail problem. We evaluate the datasets specifically on those corner cases. We show that the inclusion of soft kinematics smoothness constraints is particularly valuable for high complexity datasets.

title: Joint Optimization of Task Offloading and Multicast Transmission Scheduling in MEC Networks
authors: Ismail Bagayoko, Gael S. Mubibya, Elmahdi Driouch
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The adoption of Multi-Access Edge Computing (MEC) stems from the need to overcome the limitations of mobile device resources and to optimize the performance of computation-intensive applications such as virtual and augmented reality. Additionally, by leveraging the content reuse property, multicast transmission emerges as an efficient strategy to alleviate network load, enabling the delivery of common content to multiple users simultaneously. This work investigates the challenges and opportunities associated with integrating multicast into MEC networks. We formulate a complex decision-making problem involving task offloading at the MEC level, designing multicast groups, and transmission scheduling. We develop a greedy heuristic solution along with a genetic algorithm-based approach. The simulation results provide valuable insights into the fundamental benefits of multicast in MEC networks, demonstrating its potential to optimize resource usage. They also highlight the superiority of our genetic approach as it efficiently balances multicast and unicast transmissions.

title: An Innovative and Economical Inverter Design for Rural Electrification Using Vehicle-To-Everything (V2X) Technology
authors: Pranav Sud, Madhav Krishna, Krishna Kumar Saini, Hitesh Datt Mathur
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative and economical inverter design aimed at providing a reliable and affordable source of electricity for rural communities. Leveraging Vehicle-To-Everything (V2X) technology, the proposed system integrates bidirectional power transfer capabilities, allowing electric vehicles (EVs) to serve as versatile energy sources. This design enables EVs to export unused energy to external loads, such as home appliances, when the vehicle is stationary. By utilizing renewable energy sources like solar power, the inverter discharges power back to the grid or directly to local loads. This approach offers a sustainable solution to rural electrification by reducing dependency on fossil fuels and aligning with global efforts to mitigate environmental pollution.

title: Research on Financial Risk Prediction System Based on Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Tao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Predicting financial risks accurately and quickly is crucial for maintaining economic stability. A novel system grounded in the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm has been developed to enhance financial risk prediction. The system employs the PSO algorithm, which mimics the behavior of swarms in nature, optimizing prediction models through iterative searches for the most efficient solutions. The system identifies patterns and anomalies that signal potential risks by processing large volumes of financial data. The PSO algorithm refines these predictions by dynamically adjusting the system's parameters, leading to a more accurate and timely detection of financial threats. Financial indicators such as market volatility, liquidity, and investment flows are analyzed to assess risk levels. The system's real-time capabilities allow for rapid response, significantly improving decision-making in risk management. Extensive simulations show the PSO-based model outperforming traditional methods regarding precision and computational efficiency. These advancements suggest that applying the Particle Swarm Optimization algorithm could transform financial risk management, offering institutions a reliable tool to mitigate emerging threats while ensuring stability in rapidly changing financial landscapes.

title: Research on Operation Optimization Model of Large Coal-fired Units Based on Digital Collaborative Analysis
authors: Xuejun Li, Jianxin Shi, Zhong Chen, Jienan Zhu, Hongyan Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The optimal design of operation and operation of type I coal-fired units can reduce energy consumption and promote the green and healthy development of coal-fired power industry. A large-scale coal-fired unit operation and operation optimization model based on system dynamics model optimization of digital collaborative analysis is proposed. The endogenous structural dynamic model of the operation and development of large-scale coal-fired units is constructed. The parameters of economic driving factors, environmental bearing factors and social development factors are selected as constraint variables, and the dynamic causality model and dynamic distribution model of flow stock of large-scale coal-fired units are constructed. By introducing the method of collaborative digital analysis of system cybernetics and information theory, the dynamic feedback system of coal-fired units is established, and the model parameter optimization and dynamic optimization control are realized by combining factor analysis. The empirical analysis and simulation results show that the model can dynamically and quantitatively analyze the operation mode of large coal-fired units, and the validity test and applicability test show the reliability of the model, and the total installed capacity of coal-fired units and coal-fired power generation have been significantly improved.

title: A Multi-Objective Predictive Control Approach for PV-MMC under Unbalanced Grid Operations
authors: Ankita Sharma, Rajashekharareddy Chilipi, Kunisetti V. Praveen Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: With modular multilevel converter (MMC) gaining prominence in large-scale photovoltaic (PV) applications and high-voltage grid integration, their sensitivity to unbalanced grid conditions introduces challenges such as double-frequency power oscillations, DC-link voltage oscillation, and submodule capacitor voltage unbalances. Therefore, this article presents a model predictive control (MPC) strategy for a PV-interfaced MMC (PV-MMC) aimed at mitigating the issues caused by an unbalanced grid, as mentioned above. The developed MPC simultaneously regulates positive- and negative-sequence currents, DC-link and submodule capacitor voltages of the PV-MMC without needing distinct cost functions. In addition, a variable-rate off maximum power point tracking algorithm is developed to limit solar power generation during grid unbalance. The developed MPC eliminates cascaded proportional-integral loops, complex parameter tuning, and double-frequency oscillations in power and DC-link voltage. It efficiently controls power output of the PV generating station, submodule capacitor voltages, and provides grid support under grid abnormalities. The developed MPC is tested and validated to showcase its effectiveness and robustness using MATLAB simulations under different operating conditions.

title: AI-Driven Cyber Threat Intelligence Sharing Platform with Real-Time Trust Validation and Tamper-Proof Logging
authors: Dhanush Satyavarapu, Satyanarayana Lodagala, Sravanthi Yenumula, Mahesh Kumar Kolla, Janjhyam Venkata Naga Ramesh
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) sharing depends on strong reliability factors in the context of fast-changing security threats. The document outlines a live CTI information sharing platform which implements federated AI models with three-factor trust metrics and cryptographic integrity verification. Honeypots combined with OSINT feeds alongside crowdsourced submissions that use GPG verification allow the system to gather data. A machine learning model validates threats by using honeypot-derived features that achieve $92.7 \%$ accuracy during validation. The scoring process determines threat values by analyzing reporter credibility and by matching honeypots against OSINT sources. All data events are secured through the hash algorithm SHA-256 together with Merkle trees for complete proof against tampering. The system features an administrative dashboard that enables real-time blocking functionalities in addition to a SQLite backend. The research shows both superior threat identification outcomes and decreased incorrect alerts in the analysis.

title: LLM-WOA: Large Language Model Assisted Whale Optimization Algorithm
authors: Jiguang Yang, Jiuyuan Huo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: In view of the limitations of the traditional Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA), such as fixed parameter adjustment rules, strategy switching dependent on random probability, and tendency to get trapped in local optima, this paper proposes a Whale Optimization Algorithm assisted by a Large Language Model (LLM), named LLM-WOA. The DeepSeek-V3.1 model is integrated into the core iterative process of WOA to achieve adaptive parameter adjustment and intelligent strategy adjustment. Specifically, LLM-WOA is designed with two core mechanisms: 1) The LLM-assisted parameter and strategy decision-making module, which enables LLM to dynamically output the contraction factor a, spiral coefficient b, and exploration/exploitation strategy probability based on the real-time optimization status through precise Prompt engineering; 2) The LLM-guided local optimal escape mechanism, which generates population perturbation strategies to restore search diversity when the algorithm stagnates. To validate the algorithm’s performance, a comparative experiment was conducted with the traditional WOA in the CEC2022 test set. The results show that LLM-WOA outperforms the traditional WOA in eleven test functions, indicating that the introduction of LLM can effectively solve the insufficient adaptive ability of the traditional WOA and provide a more efficient solution for complex optimization problems. The source code of this research is available for download at https://github.com/Drleach/LLMWOA.

title: An Active Switch Integrated Five-Level Switched-Capacitor Multilevel Inverter
authors: Hari Charan, Nongthombam Aditya Luwang, S. Adesh, Chandra Bhushan, M. Angel, Pothuraju Ramakrishna
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Multi-level inverters play a key role in day-to- day functions for renewable energy (RE), smart grids, grid-connected systems, high-voltage direct current (HVDC) systems, and many more. In this paper, an active switch-based Switched Capacitor Multi-Level Inverter (SC-MLI) is proposed to improve the efficiency. The proposed system comprises seven power semi-conductor switches, a DC source, and a capacitor. The proposed topology effectively reduces power loss in the system, enabling high-speed switching, enhancing efficiency, and providing active control capability. The Selected Harmonic Elimination Pulse Width Modulation (SHEPWM) technique is employed to reduce the total harmonic distortion by eliminating selected lower-order harmonics while maintaining the desired fundamental component of the output voltage. The proposed Switched-Capacitor Multi-Level Inverter (SC-MLI) is investigated with resistive (R) and resistive-inductive (R-L) loads on MATLAB/SIMULINK software. A laboratory prototype is designed to validate the simulation result.

title: Drug Recommendation via Graph Contrastive Learning and Path Reasoning for Medical Dialogues
authors: Zhen Diao, Zhen Ren, Ziqin Zhang, Huazheng Luo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Existing drug recommendation studies primarily rely on electronic health record data; however, they often lack detailed information on doctor-patient interactions, which makes it difficult to reflect patients’ actual conditions fully. Medical dialogues preserve complete interaction information and hold greater application potential, but their data generally suffers from sparse labeling. To address this, this paper proposes a dialogue-based drug recommendation method that combines contrastive learning with multi-hop reasoning on knowledge graphs to enhance the effectiveness of recommendations. First, we introduce a graph contrastive learning approach based on singular value decomposition. This method enhances data representation through global relationship modeling, mitigating label scarcity while preserving semantic structural stability. Second, we design a knowledge graph multi-hop reasoning model that integrates precursor paths and connecting paths. An attention mechanism distinguishes the importance of different entities and relationships, yielding more accurate semantic representations. Experimental results demonstrate the method’s superior performance in reducing noise interference, inferring missing knowledge, and improving recommendation accuracy. The path attention mechanism further enhances the interpretability of the results.

title: 4-D Aircraft Trajectory Prediction for ATM Capacity and Demand Optimization in a Strategic Time Horizon Using Artificial Intelligence Models
authors: César Gómez Arnaldo, Raquel Delgado-Aguilera Jurado, María Zamarreño Suárez, Javier Alberto Pérez Castán, Francisco Pérez Moreno
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The role of the ATM system is to ensure safety and efficiency in airspace operations. The increasing demand for aircraft in the airspace makes ATM management more and more complex. Thanks to technological advances in recent years, applications related to ATM automation are considered necessary to assist ATM. In this paper, a 4D trajectory prediction module is proposed for use in the strategic time horizon. This module will be based on trajectory prediction through the development of simple machine learning models that will be used sequentially. These models will allow, based on information present in the flight schedule, to predict the trajectory of the aircraft. The results of this paper can help the management of human and technical resources in the ATM system, by allowing to know how air traffic will be organized well in advance, and to take decisions on how to organize this traffic prior to the operations.

title: Optimal Train Drive Cycle Determination using Genetic Algorithm for Traction Network Analysis
authors: Prasanjit Kar, Biswarup Das, Bhaveshkumar R. Bhalja
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The train speed profile throughout the track provides the effective operation of trains. The speed profile curves can be adjusted within the drive cycle between two stoppages. This speed profile must incorporate track and train set parameters to ensure an optimum drive cycle. This study presents the optimal operation of trains between the stations using a Genetic Algorithm (GA). The optimal driving state organises the speed profile of the train running between the stations to match the track limits, train travelling schedule, and train set limits. The drive cycle provides the dynamic tractive effort requirement of the locomotives. Hence, the traction load is modelled as a dynamic load in an electrical traction network using the drive cycle results. Further, the proposed optimized drive cycle has been tested on the test model of EN50641 standard.

title: Data-Driven Machine Learning Approach for Accurate Chronic Kidney Disease Prediction
authors: Karanki Rakesh, Pramod Chowdary, Naba Krushna Sabat
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a critical global health issue, emphasizing the need for reliable detection methods to enable early intervention. This study explores the application of machine learning classifiers for CKD diagnosis, aiming to identify the most precise models for early disease detection. Eight classification algorithms, including ensemble and boosting methods, were assessed using metrics such as accuracy, cross validation performance, and analysis of feature significance. The Extra Trees Classifier achieved the highest accuracy at $99.29 \%$, followed by Random Forest with $98.93 \%$. XGBoost and AdaBoost recorded accuracies of 97.50%, while K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) showed the lowest performance at $70.00 \%$. Feature importance analysis revealed that serum creatinine, hemoglobin, and blood urea were the key predictors of CKD, consistent with clinical expertise. Correlation analysis further confirmed the strong relationship between these features and CKD classification. The findings emphasize the superior performance of ensemble methods, particularly Extra Trees and Random Forest, in CKD classification, highlighting their potential for clinical applications. Future studies could explore the integration of hybrid models and sophisticated feature selection methods to enhance prediction accuracy and model generalization for CKD detection.

title: Computational fluid-based analysis of submersible pressure hull for multimedium robots
authors: Siddhant Panigrahi, Harshit Moondra, Siddhant Erande, Aastha Mishra, Poongavanam Palani, Asokan Thondiyath
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Amphibious robots are multi-medium vehicles that operate in both aerial and underwater environments. Such vehicles are essential in applications such as inspection of offshore installations, water sampling, and surveying remote areas. Owing to the vast differences in the physical properties (density and viscosity) of the two media in which these robots operate, designing such a robot presents design conflicts. This research addresses one of those key challenges by focusing on designing a pressure vessel catered to reduce drag along the multiphase fluid flow conditions in the Surge (Horizontal) and Heave (Vertical) axes underwater, which can be extended to air. Optimising the design of the pressure hull plays an essential role in enhancing the efficiency of the overall system. Conventional pressure vessels in the literature focus on streamlining the flow along one of the axes, penalising those designs in their complementary mediums. In this research, multiple designs have been tested for drag coefficients in fluid flow and structural integrity using Static FEA on Solidworks. Simulation results demonstrate that characteristic bioinspired designs (for instance, Manta ray and Bulbous bow inspired pressure vessels) are structurally capable of withstanding the hydrostatic pressure, and these streamlined designs experience less drag when compared to the initial design of the cylindrical hull. This research presents a novel Manta ray-inspired design that significantly reduces drag compared to conventional pressure hulls. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed design can achieve a $74.92 \%$ reduction in surge motion and $64.26 \%$ in heave motion compared to existing pressure vessels as in the literature.

title: Design and Analysis of a Spatial 3-DOF Compliant Micro-Motion Platform
authors: Runqing Wang, Xianfeng Shi, Lingchen Meng, Zhiming Zhang, Pengbo Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The flexible platform can significantly enhance motion accuracy through reasonably design of flexible mechanisms, exhibiting unique advantages in precision motion applications. In this context, this study presents a spatial 3-DOF flexible micro-motion platform capable of high-precision, large-stroke motion. A two-stage displacement amplification mechanism driven by PZT is designed as the drive unit to convert in-plane input displacement into out-of-plane motion. a cross-shaped flexure Hooke joint at the output enables multi-DOF motion. The compliance matrix method was employed to analyze the force-deformation relationship, establishing analytical compliance models for both the driving limb and the overall platform. Finite element analysis of static and dynamic characteristics verifies the platform's superior mechanical performance.

title: Research on Tobacco Sales Forecasting Based on Integrated Learning Models
authors: Jinlin Yang, Jinxiong Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: China has implemented a monopoly system for tobacco to ensure that optimal economic and social benefits are realized through centralized control of the production, sale, import and export of tobacco. The industrial chain covers tobacco leaf procurement, processing, manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing, and all links are strictly licensed by the state. In this paper, a multi-model fusion framework is constructed to predict the sales data of tobacco. For brands A1 and A2, ARIMA and Prophet models were constructed to analyze the results, and it was found that Prophet model could better capture the seasonality. For brands A3 and A4, the prediction error was reduced to 0.02 using the combined LSTM-XGBoost model. The joint prediction of brand A5 by Stacking integrated ARIMA, Prophet, LSTM, and XGBoost achieved an accuracy of 95%. The results show that the integrated method effectively improves the prediction performance and provides decision support for tobacco monopoly management.

title: Investigation on Effect of Orbital Debris Impact on Tension Forces in Inflatable Membrane Reflector
authors: Swapnil D. Shinde, Sanjay H. Upadhyay
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Inflatable planar membrane reflectors offer a promising solution for spacecraft antenna systems, particularly in near-term missions where cost-effectiveness and packaging efficiency are critical. These lightweight, deployable structures significantly reduce launch mass and volume, making them attractive for small satellites and deep-space applications. However, the performance of such membrane reflectors is highly sensitive to surface accuracy, which in turn is governed by the tension forces applied at the anchor points. Any external disturbance, especially from space debris, can adversely affect these forces and thereby degrade antenna performance. The present study investigates numerically, the effect of the debris impact on the tension forces, deformations of the membrane reflector. The results provide insights into the structural vulnerabilities of inflatable antennas and highlight the need for improved design strategies to enhance resilience against orbital debris threats.

title: Dynamic Perception and Quantitative Method for Distribution Line Loss Fluctuations Based on Hybrid Network Deep Learning
authors: Changhua Huang, Meiqiang Huang, Guojia Peng, Liang Liang, Xiang Liao, Yitao Li, Jingmei Huang, Xiang Li, Yue Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This article focuses on the problem of fluctuation factors in distribution line losses and proposes a dynamic perception and quantification method for distribution line loss fluctuation factors based on hybrid network deep learning. In response to the complex influencing factors of distribution line loss and the limitations of existing quantification methods, multi-source data covering both numerical and textual types are first collected. After standardization, encoding, and other processing, multimodal feature fusion is performed to obtain comprehensive data features that reflect the relationship between line loss and influencing factors. Next, a model incorporating improved grey relational analysis, dual weight attention mechanism, and LSTM Transformer hybrid network is constructed to effectively capture the dynamic correlation between features and line loss rate, enhance attention to key features, improve line loss prediction accuracy, and establish a model parameter update mechanism to adapt to dynamic data changes. Finally, this article proposes a quantitative calculation method for dynamic impact factors and a rolling update mechanism. The simulation results show that this method has high accuracy in predicting line loss rate and can accurately quantify various influencing factors, providing strong support for reducing losses and increasing efficiency in the power system.

title: An Intelligent Indoor Plant Health Monitoring System Using Deep Learning and Computer Vision
authors: Mohammed Zakir Bellary, Savin S S, Ummar Farook Shahil, Joyline Dsilva, Aboobakkar Aqeef Ilal, Muhammed Nazal Razi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: This paper presents an intelligent system designed to automate the health assessment of indoor plants, a task traditionally reliant on time-intensive manual observation. Our approach integrates deep learning with computer vision to analyse foliage images, accurately identifying visual symptoms of disease, pest infestation, and nutrient deficiencies. The system provides immediate, actionable feedback by dispatching real-time SMS alerts upon detecting abnormalities and generates comprehensive diagnostic reports accessible through a dedicated web interface. To ensure reliability, the model was trained and validated on a diverse dataset representing multiple plant species and environmental variations, achieving a classification accuracy of 94.7%. Unlike conventional methods, the proposed framework emphasizes real-time monitoring, scalability for indoor environments, and ease of deployment using IoT-enabled sensors. This work contributes a practical, end-to-end solution that enhances proactive plant care, reduces the need for manual supervision, and supports both enthusiasts and experts in maintaining healthier plant ecosystems.

title: Improving Wheat Leaf Disease Management Using Convolutional Neural Networks and Random Forest
authors: Khushdeep Kaur, S Judah Ezekiel Enoch, Gaurika Pathania
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: A machine based learning model that deals with the classification of Stripe Rust, Stem Rust, Brown Rust, Powdery Mildew, Tan Spot, Fusarium Leaf Blight, Spot Blotch, and Septoria Leaf Blotch, that is the eight common weight leaf diseases. 10,520 photos made up the dataset applied in this study, and its total accuracy was $96.00 \%$. The performances of all metrics were extremely good. Precision values from $95.55 \%$ for Septoria Leaf Blotch to 96.43 % for Stripe Rust indicated that the model works well in terms of true predictions. Recall values were between $95.24 \%$ (Tan Spot) and 96.30% (Stem Rust), which suggests that the model is good at identifying actual cases of diseases. F1 scores, which take into consideration both precision and recall, were between $95.44 \%$ (Tan Spot) and 96.26% (Stripe Rust), which also showed that the results were consistent. In general the precision of the model was high at $99 \%$, while support proportions were between 0.11 (Tan Spot) and 0.13 (Stripe Rust). The result obtained here shows the robustness of this model in classifying wheat diseases with great accuracy and reliability. The paper displays the potential of machine learning with it’s ability to enhance early disease identification and contribute aid in better management of crop and increase agriculture productivity. This further confirms the applicability of this model in the field of disease management in wheat farming, given its multiple disease classes.

title: Modified Crow Search Algorithm based FOPID Controller Design for a Perturbed PHWR System
authors: Ayan Jain, Anushka Bhanot, Akshita Sharma, Utsav Raj, Saksham Bisht, A.K. Bhullar, Swati Sondhi, Ruchika Lamba
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In the current power generation landscape, Pressurized Heavy Water Reactor (PHWR) systems are of significant importance. Due to their intricate design and operational complexity, these reactors require advanced and dependable control strategies to effectively regulate output power. Among modern approaches, fractional-order control has gained notable interest for its ability to provide enhanced setpoint tracking, better disturbance handling, and improved system stability. Concurrent progress in optimization methods has further supported the creation of fractional-order PID controllers that deliver accurate results with reduced computational demands. This study integrates these advancements by proposing a robust and efficient control method for PHWR power regulation. The method applies the Distance Levy Flight-Based Crow Search Algorithm (DLCSA) to determine optimal parameters for a fractional-order PID controller. Comparative analysis using multiple integral error metrics shows that the DLCSA-based controller achieves superior performance over existing techniques.

title: A Simplified Low-Computational Strategy for Position Sensorless Control of Switched Reluctance Motor Drives
authors: Sumit Kumar Singh, Amit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The rotor position plays a crucial role in the operation of a switched reluctance motor (SRM) since torque generation depends on energizing the stator windings in synchronization with the rotor’s position. This rotor position data is essential for determining the phase commutation points and for calculating the speed. This article focuses on a position sensorless strategy of a three-phase 12/8 SRM. The turnoff angle position and the phase commutation position are determined by comparing the reference flux linkage with the phase flux linkage. The phase flux linkage is calculated without requiring a voltage sensor, as the phase voltages are estimated based on the applied switching pattern. The initial active phase, or the startup phase, is determined using the pulse injection method. The speed is estimated using the phase excitation sequence.

title: Fault Diagnosis and Condition Monitoring of Brushless DC Motor Drive for Electric Vehicle Applications
authors: Harshit Thakur, Rajesh M. Pindoriya, Surya Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the current state-of-the-art techniques in Fault Diagnosis (FD) and Condition Monitoring (CM) of Brushless Direct Current (BLDC) motor drives in EV applications. The BLDC motors are pivotal in electric vehicle (EV) drive systems due to their high efficiency, compact size, and reliability. However, their reliable operation is contingent upon robust FD and CM techniques to prevent unexpected failures and ensure optimal performance. An operational fault can significantly impair performance, safety, and longevity. This paper explores FD and CM strategies for BLDC motor drives, encompassing electrical, mechanical, and sensor-related faults. The paper also discusses future perspectives and emerging trends in this field, including advancements in sensor technology, machine learning-based diagnosis, and predictive maintenance strategies. The healthy and faulty BLDC motor drive with FD and CM is implemented in the MATLAB/Simulink environment to check the causes and effects of faults on the other parameters.

title: Maximal Separation-Based Histogram Estimation of Normalized Mutual Information for Unsupervised Feature Selection
authors: Namita Jain, Susmita Ghosh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: High-dimensional datasets often pose a significant challenge for learning algorithms due to the curse of dimensionality, leading to increased computational complexity, overfitting, and poor generalization. An effective way to address this issue is feature selection, which aims to identify and retain only the most informative features. In problems where label information is not available, unsupervised feature selection becomes crucial. To perform unsupervised feature selection, we can use normalized mutual information to identify features that carry similar information, allowing us to reduce dimensionality without significant loss of relevant information. Here, we present an efficient method for the estimation of normalized mutual information using maximal separation.

title: Generalized Concept of Second-Order Stator Shifting in Fractional-Slot Concentrated Windings Interior Permanent-Magnet Machines
authors: Sagar Gupta, Vaibhav Bhardwaj, Amit Kumar Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (TPMSMs) with Fractional Slot Concentrated Winding (FSCW) are widely used in electric vehicles, due to their high torque density, efficiency, and broad speed range. A major challenge stems from the subharmonic and superharmonic components of the stator’s magneto-motive force, which contribute to increased rotor losses and can also cause saturation effects. This paper examines the impact of introduction of two shifted stators, similar to the base stator but shifted by shift angles on the harmonic contents while maximizing the performance of the motor. Findings reveal that second order stator shifting can effectively minimize harmonics responsible for rotor losses while enhancing the performance parameters of fractional-slot concentrated winding designs. This approach introduces harmonic cancellation as a targeted method to reduce harmonics and reduce the machine’s phase inductance. The principle of stator shifting will be explored, with an analysis of how adjusting the shift angle influences harmonic components and winding factors. Several designs based on double-layer 12-slots/10-pole configurations are examined, each with different shift angles. These designs are compared in terms of power density, efficiency, and torque ripple to evaluate their performance.

title: DCA: Dual-branch Autoencoder Model for Denoising and Classification of MRI Images
authors: Yuhang Jiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: The diagnosis of brain tumors based on Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) images relies heavily on the doctor's personal experience and visible lesion features. At the same time, when faced with a large number of MRI images, the doctor's diagnostic speed and accuracy are easily affected. To achieve rapid screening and reduce misdiagnosis rates, artificial intelligence technology has gradually been applied to the diagnosis of brain tumors. This article proposes a dual branch autoencoder model, abbreviated as DCA, which uses the encoder of traditional denoising autoencoders to extract multi-level features, introduces a classifier model at the end of the encoder, and introduces skip connections between the encoder and decoder. Compared with completing two tasks independently, collaborative learning of denoising and classification tasks is achieved by sharing encoder features, effectively reducing the number of model parameters. At the same time, due to the ability of one training and inference to simultaneously complete both denoising and classification tasks, it has higher diagnostic efficiency. This article conducted extensive experiments on the brain tumor MRI dataset from Kaggle. The experimental results show that firstly, the DCA model exhibits good classification and denoising capabilities on images with different levels of noise; Secondly, under the same noise intensity, the classification and denoising performance of the DCA model is significantly better than that of a simple classification and denoising model.

title: Predicting and Analyzing Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) Using Machine Learning
authors: K Ankitha, Adithya S Nayak, Abhin Balakrishna, Ashiq, Ashmika
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: The increasing number of Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) has become a global concern due to the possibility of these objects colliding with Earth and causing serious damage. Traditionally, the risk evaluation of NEOs has depended on complex orbital calculations and physics-based models. However, with advancements in detection technologies, there is a growing need for faster and more efficient methods to assess the threat levels of these objects. The proposed system uses machine learning techniques to classify NEOs and predict their potential risk. The goal was to determine whether an object is potentially hazardous or not based on the patterns in this data. This study demonstrates the value of combining traditional scientific approaches with modern data-driven methods. As the volume of astronomical data continues to grow, machine learning techniques will play a key role in enhancing global safety from potential asteroid threats.

title: Unraveling Citric Acid-Mediated Self-Assembly Behavior of Zein by Atomic Force Microscopy
authors: Miaomiao Yu, Vladimir Kotev, Jing Hu, Mengnan Liu, Bowei Wang, Zuobin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Here in, the effect of citric acid on the self-assembly behavior of zein molecules was systematically investigated using atomic force microscopy (AFM). In the absence of citric acid, zein formed uniformly sized spherical structures. Treatment with 0.1% w/v citric acid preserved the spherical morphology but reduced the number of assemblies while increasing their size. In the presence of 0.4% w/v citric acid, zein assemblies exhibited a bimodal size distribution, with tightly packed small particles and loosely aggregated larger particles. Further increasing the citric acid concentration to 0.7% w/v resulted in a decrease in smaller zein self-assemblies and improved the average size and height. Notably, 1.0% w/v citric acid drastically reduced assembly quantity and generated exceptionally large structures. These results highlight that citric acid critically regulator the self-assembly dynamics of zein. This work provides a foundation for tailoring zein nanostructures via citric acid mediation.

title: Impact of Rain and Fog Coexistence on the Performance of Satellite Terrestrial Quantum Communication
authors: Xiaoyu Feng, Min Nie, Guang Yang
abstract: In order to study the effect of the coexistence of rain and fog on the communication performance of satellite terrestrial quantum link, the relationship between link attenuation and transmission distance and visibility was analyzed based on the attenuation model of optical quantum under the coexistence of rain and fog, and the influence of the coexistence of rain and fog on channel capacity, channel fidelity, channel survival function and channel bit error rate was studied. The findings reveal that at a visibility of 0.5 km and a transmission distance of 0.3 km, the link experiences an attenuation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 0. 2 2 d B} \cdot \text{k m}-\text{1}$</tex>. Furthermore, at the same visibility of 0.5 km and transmission distance of 0.25 km, the channel capacities for the amplitude damped and depolarized channels are recorded as 0.41 bit <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \mathrm{s}$</tex> and 0.29 bit/s respectively. When visibility is 0.5 km and transmission distance is 0.3 km, the survival function values of amplitude damped channel and depolarized channel are 0.901 and 0.979 respectively. At a visibility of 0.5 km and with a transmission distance of 1 km, the channel's bit error rate reaches 0.24. Consequently, the coexistence of rain and fog significantly affects the efficiency of satellite terrestrial quantum communication systems. System parameters should be adjusted adaptively according to different environmental parameters to ensure the stability and reliability of the system.

title: Analysis of Factors Influencing the Performance of Domestic Agricultural Listed Companies in the Artificial Intelligence Environment
authors: Pingshan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the development of artificial intelligence technology, its application in agriculture has gradually deepened, from initial monitoring and planting systems to later unmanned systems and fully automated equipment. The application of artificial intelligence technology has an increasingly profound impact on enterprise production. This article combines modern agricultural theory to explore the factors affecting the performance of agricultural listed enterprises in the context of artificial intelligence. Through empirical analysis, it is found that the application of artificial intelligence technology can effectively improve the operational performance of agricultural enterprises. The asset liability ratio has a significant negative impact on the asset return rate, and the proportion of highly skilled labor has a significant positive impact on enterprise performance. Based on the current situation and theory, as well as empirical analysis results, this article proposes strategies to promote the use of artificial intelligence technology and strengthen talent training mechanisms, aiming to help enterprises improve their performance in the artificial intelligence environment and provide guidance and reference for agricultural enterprises to deepen the application of artificial intelligence.

title: Risk-Aware UAS Path Planning Based on Four-Dimensional Operation Volume Construction and Dynamic Collision Avoidance
authors: Jinjiang Yu, Yan Xu, Jinpeng Zhang, Kaiquan Cai, Kam K.H. Ng
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: A core challenge in uncrewed aircraft system (UAS) path planning lies in the potentially high risks caused by deviations between planned paths and actual flight trajectories in complex dynamic environments. In this paper, we study path planning through two phases of pre-flight and in-flight planning. A ground risk map is constructed by integrating real-world spatial characteristics. Based on this map, a pre-flight path planning method combining BRESENHAM and A* algorithms (B-A*) is proposed, aiming at balancing the path distance with the risk cost, as well as achieving path optimization. Highfidelity simulations of actual flight trajectories are performed to calculate confidence intervals, thereby constructing an operation volume (OV) that ensures the actual flight path remains within a safe envelope. During the in-flight phase, a real-time collision avoidance strategy based on time windows is proposed for dynamic environments. Alternative paths are generated via a path offset model, and collision risks with dynamic obstacles are evaluated by calculating the closest point of approach (CPA). The optimal avoidance path is selected by comprehensively weighing risk and distance costs. A reverse fitting method is designed to recover the original path smoothly after collision avoidance. Experiments using simulations demonstrate its ability to significantly reduce flight risks in complex environments while enhancing path safety and execution stability.

title: Internal-Model-Control Based Efficient Control Design for Shipboard Microgrid Frequency Control
authors: A. V. Waghmare, V. P. Singh, A. Mathur, Richa Chaudhary
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study deals with the frequency control phenomenon of shipboard microgrid (ShMG) model, which integrates renewable, and energy storage sources, along with conventional sources. The ShMG model is first approximated in order to obtain its FOPDT model. PID controller is then designed using the parameters obtained from FOPDT model and further substituting these parameters in internal-model-control (IMC) tuning rules to obtained the tuned controller gains. For analysis, frequency deviation plots are exhibited for ShMG with and without controller and based on these plots the conclusions are derived. To further clarify these findings and support the conclusions drawn from the frequency deviation plots, comparisons based on error indices and time domain specifications are also provided.

title: Load shifting and price elastic load curtailing policies for economic operation of a microgrid system
authors: Bishwajit Dey, Srikant Mishra, Soham Dutta, Rangu Seshu Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) are essential for the economic functioning of microgrid systems by optimizing energy consumption, decreasing dependence on costly peak-hour electricity, and improving grid stability. They facilitate efficient load shifting, retain excess renewable energy, and enhance power quality, resulting in cost reductions and increased system resilience. BESS facilitates demand-side management (DSM) tactics by equilibrating supply and demand, reducing grid congestion, and enabling price-driven demand response. Integrating BESS enables microgrids to attain enhanced efficiency, reduced operational expenses, and increased energy autonomy, thereby aligning sustainability objectives and assuring a reliable power supply across many applications. This paper proposes a recently developed one-to-one based optimizer (OOBO) to minimize the operation cost of a microgrid with BESS. Two different DSM strategies and price-based demand response (PBDR) are also implemented and their impact on cost-effective operation of the microgrid system is compared. Numerical results show the effectiveness of DSM and PBDR in economic operation of the microgrid system.

title: A large Step Down Buck Converter for small scale Hydrogen Generation
authors: Shubham Priyadarshi, Anakshi Boruah, Preeti Sharma, Surojit Pande, Rajneesh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents a large step-down buck converter topology employing a coupled inductor and a singles-witch configuration to achieve efficient step-down voltage conversion with an extended conversion ratio. The proposed architecture mitigates the limitations of conventional buck converters by leveraging a coupled inductor to enhance voltage gain while maintaining a moderate duty cycle, thereby reducing conduction and switching losses. The developed single-switch topology is validated using MATLAB Simulation and comprehensive theoretical analysis is conducted, including steady-state operation, voltage gain expression, and component stress evaluation representing hydrogen electrolyser as resistive load in steady state.

title: An Interleaved Bridgeless Buck-Boost PFC Converter for Battery Charging Application
authors: Rahul Kumar, Jitendra Gupta, Bhim Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper describes an intermittently functioning bridgeless interleaved buck-boost converter with discontinuous inductor current. When running in discontinuous conduction mode, buck-boost converter offers built-in power factor adjustment and is appropriate for broad voltage operation. The bridgeless structure used here reduces the number of semiconductor devices conducting simultaneously. Due to discontinuous mode operation, number of sensor required is less and grid side synchronization is not required in order to operate at unity power factor. The interleaved structure reduces the ripple in the grid current resulting into improved power quality. The study of the converter operation and parameter design are presented in this paper. A simple control using a single current controller is used to regulate the converter output current for battery charging application. The presented converter is designed for a power capacity of 800 W and is simulated using Matlab-Simulink software to verify the both dynamic and stable states of the converter.
