title: Hypernymy Relation in NLP: Tasks, Approaches, Resources, and Future Directions - A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Randah Alharbi, Husni Al-Muhtaseb, Tarek Helmy
abstract: Hypernymy is a semantic relation between two terms, where a more specific term is entailed by a more general term—that is, the meaning of the more specific term is encompassed by the meaning of the more general term. This relation is crucial for many natural language processing (NLP) tasks, including textual entailment, search query expansion, and machine translation. In this systematic literature review, the hypernymy relation in the context of NLP is investigated, with a focus on identifying hypernymy-related tasks, employed approaches, available resources, and future research directions. The reviewed studies were extracted from five pre-defined databases, covering the period from 2018 to March 2023. The review process identified 75 primary studies that were analyzed to extract the targeted tasks, languages, approaches, representations, and datasets. The synthesized data were used to address the review questions. The review identifies the main hypernymy-related tasks, including hypernymy extraction, detection, directionality, graded lexical entailment, and discovery. The evaluation practices employed were summarized, including accuracy, F1, Mean Average Precision (MAP), and Spearman’s correlation coefficient. The targeted languages are highlighted, with English being the most studied; however, multilingual coverage is steadily growing. Several benchmark datasets for each task are presented, along with their statistics, characteristics, and construction techniques. Additionally, representation techniques are summarized, ranging from Word2Vec, FastText, and GloVe to hypernymy-specific representations. Finally, research gaps are discussed, and potential future directions are outlined. This review consolidates scattered findings and provides a practical map of tasks, resources, and techniques for researchers building hypernymy-aware NLP systems.

title: A Semi-Supervised Algorithm for Remote Sensing Road Segmentation Based on Dual-Branch Architecture
authors: Qinqin Tang, Tao Wu, Xiu’e Su, Chang Su
abstract: To address the challenges of road segmentation in remote sensing images—such as elongated structures, blurred boundaries, and the high cost of annotations—this paper proposes a semi-supervised segmentation framework tailored for low-label scenarios. The framework effectively reduces reliance on large-scale annotated datasets by fully leveraging latent structural information from unlabeled data. Specifically, a structure-aware reliability reweighting module (SRRM) is introduced to dynamically adjust the confidence of pseudo labels based on edge priors, improving label quality in boundary regions. In addition, a cross-fusion supervision (CFS) mechanism is designed to integrate predictions from different augmentation paths via channel-wise attention, enabling bidirectional optimization and complementary learning of pseudo labels. To enhance feature representation capabilities, a dual-branch network architecture combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and Transformers is constructed. The CNN branch focuses on capturing local textures and spatial details, while the Transformer branch models global contextual dependencies. These two branches work collaboratively to accommodate the complex structural characteristics of roads in remote sensing imagery. On top of this backbone, several task-specific modules are further introduced to address common challenges in road segmentation, such as elongated shapes, multi-scale variation, and ambiguous boundaries. Extensive experiments on two public datasets, DeepGlobe and Massachusetts, demonstrate that the proposed method achieves 80.51% and 81.67% MIoU, respectively, with only 1/32 of labeled data, significantly outperforming existing mainstream methods and showcasing strong generalization ability and practical value.

title: Graph Theory Approach for the Control of COVID-19 Diffusion
authors: Abdulyekeen T. Adebisi, Kalyana C. Veluvolu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Pandemics often arise from the diffusion of infectious diseases over large regions, spanning multiple continents. Effective non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) at the onset of an outbreak can significantly curb the spread. However, the complexity of human interactions can hinder the strict and timely imposition of such measures. Given the extensive damage caused by COVID-19, it is imperative to develop computational strategies that control and prevent the global spread of infectious diseases. This study proposes a model of COVID-19 spread networks, formulated based on daily confirmed cases per country, with mutual information as a measure of interdependence between countries. Utilizing graph theory, this approach identifies key nodes (countries) that play influential roles in the COVID-19 spread network. A control framework based on network theory is then introduced to mitigate and potentially eradicate further infection spread. Results demonstrate that the proposed framework holds substantial promise in preventing the transmission of COVID-19 and similar outbreaks when implemented promptly.

title: Dynamic Time-Bound Anonymous Complete Cross-Domain Authentication Scheme for IoT
authors: Xi Chen, Chunqiang Hu, Pengfei Hu, Xingwang Li, Jiguo Yu
abstract: The rapid proliferation of the Internet of Things (IoT) has made resource exchange and collaboration across diverse IoT domains commonplace, necessitating secure and privacy-preserving cross-domain authentication. However, existing schemes suffer from critical limitations: they lack time-bound access control, leading to persistent unauthorized access and heightened security risks, and most are incomplete, requiring resource-intensive redeployment of cryptographic mechanisms and increasing management overhead. To address these challenges, we propose a dynamic time-bound anonymous complete cross-domain authentication scheme that leverages consortium blockchain for decentralized trust, embeds dual temporal constraints, expiration time and permissible authentication periods, into credentials for fine-grained access control and automatic natural revocation, and employs accumulators and non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs (NIZKs) to enable anonymous authentication while ensuring strong privacy protection. Crucially, the proposed scheme achieves complete cross-domain authentication without modifying existing cryptographic mechanisms, significantly reducing overhead in computational, communication, and storage. Security and performance analyses confirm that the proposed scheme not only guarantees robust security and privacy but also outperforms existing schemes in efficiency.

title: VRGraspNet: Toward Viewpoint Robust 6-DoF Grasp Pose Estimation*
authors: Yuming Gao, Lichun Wang, Jiaqi Zheng, Kai Xu, Huayang Yao, Baocai Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: 6-DoF grasp pose estimation is crucial for achieving robust robot manipulation. Despite significant progress in data-driven methods, the cross-view adaptability of 6-DoF grasp pose estimation remains insufficient. Under the condition of observing some certain viewpoints, the performance of pose estimation is relatively low. In response, this paper introduces VRGraspNet, a novel 6-DoF grasp pose estimation model designed to enhance the robustness and performance of robotic grasping across diverse viewpoints. The key to the VRGraspNet lies in filling in the holes in the scene point cloud and learning multimodal features for seed points. The former provides dense neighborhood points for the seed point, while the latter provides richer information for extracting geometric features of the local area to which the seed point belongs. Furthermore, this paper proposes a Performance-Viewpoint jointly Weighted Loss (PVWL), with the key being two weight factors: a static viewpoint position dependent weight factor that focuses on challenging samples, and a dynamic performance related weight factor that focuses on samples difficult to learn. Extensive experiments on the GraspNet-1Billion dataset demonstrate that VRGraspNet achieves SOTA performance and strong cross-view robustness. Real-world robot experiments further validate its practicality in robotic manipulation tasks. Our source code is available at https://github.com/huamo555/VRGraspNet.

title: ECG-based Obstructive Sleep Apnea Detection using a Meta Classifier
authors: N. Mangathayaru, Pappula Venkata Narasimha Reddy, Nemami Srilekha, Prathapagiri Harish, Essapally Karthik
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Obstructive Sleep apnea(OSA) is a most widespread sleeping disorder. OSA is characterized by repeated pauses in breathing during sleep, leading to oxygen deficiency and disrupted sleep patterns. It produces irritation, daytime drowsiness, and various other disease states like cardiovascular illnesses. We are using Machine Learning algorithms like (XGBoost, Random Forest, KNN etc.), Deep Learning algorithms like (CNN, RNN, LSTM) and combined in a stacked ensemble. Diagnostic for detection of the Obstructive sleep apnea through the implementation of electrocardiogram (ECG) signals.Likewise, the traditional method Polysomnography (PSG) (PSG is a long study of sleep in which it considers more than one body sign like brain waves, heart beat, breathing, and blood oxygen level are monitored continuously while sleeping.) is utilized to detect sleep disorders but time-consuming, expensive, and always continuous patient monitoring. A cheaper, improved, and light detection method of OSA was conceived. ECG signals allow cardiac activity to be captured by a low-cost and non-invasive method. It can be a marker of sleep apnea event. We used publicly available Physionet CinC Challenge-2000 database for electrocardiogram signal-based detection of Obstructive sleep apnea. There are 70 original records. The duration of the ECG signal for all the patients ranges from 25,200 minutes to 36,000 minutes. We have designed a simple user interface to display Apnea-Hypopnea Index (AHI) results and visualize ECG data for real-time OSA detection.

title: Using Hybrid Large Model Technology to Build a Natural Language Interaction System for Power Big Data
authors: Ruixuan Lu, Jin Zhang, Zhen Yao, Cong Hu, Jiali Sun, Cuicui Zhang, Qi Sun, Cuiling Liu, Shichuan Ding
abstract: The power big data platform faces the challenge of how to process this data efficiently and intelligently and provide users with convenient interaction methods. This paper proposes a solution for building a natural language interaction system for the power big data platform based on hybrid large model technology. This paper adopts hybrid large model technology, which combines the general language understanding ability of Transformer and the power field adaptation module. This paper uses annotated power big data to train the model so that it can accurately understand power professional terms and natural language instructions. The core functional modules of the natural language interaction system are developed based on the hybrid large model, including natural language understanding, data query, result display, etc. A user-friendly interactive interface is designed to support users to input query commands through natural language. The developed system is integrated with the power big data center to achieve seamless connection and sharing of data. Compared with traditional interactive systems, the maximum query response time of the system in this paper is 776 milliseconds, which is much lower than that of traditional systems, and the bandwidth utilization and false recognition rate also show advantages. The natural language interactive system for the power big data platform based on hybrid large model technology proposed in this paper not only improves the efficiency of power data processing and interaction but also provides users with a more convenient and intelligent interactive experience. The system has achieved remarkable results in practical applications in the power industry, providing strong support for the digital transformation and intelligent upgrading of the power industry.

title: Abnormal Sound Detection in Mechanical Equipment Based on Adaptive Noise Reduction and Feature Fusion
authors: Zhidong Zhang, Chao Ma, Huageng Fan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: With the development of industrial automation, anomaly detection technology based on sound analysis has become a key non-invasive monitoring method. This technology achieves early fault warning by analyzing the acoustic characteristics of equipment, offering the dual benefits of reducing the risk of production downtime and economic losses. Given that sound signals in industrial settings are often accompanied by high-frequency noise interference and that fixed-bandwidth filter banks struggle to effectively capture features with significant time-frequency local characteristics, this paper proposes a model called ASLMgram (SCSA) for mechanical equipment anomaly sound detection based on adaptive noise reduction and frequency-domain feature fusion. The model’s performance was evaluated using the anomaly sound detection dataset provided by DCASE 2020 TASK 2. The results showed that the model achieved AUC, pAUC, and mAUC ($\min$ AUC) performance of 91.36%, 84.47%, and 81.14%, respectively. It particularly achieved a high level in three critical scenarios: conveying equipment, rotating equipment, and control equipment, demonstrating a significant improvement compared to various methods.

title: A SVC-Based Wide-Area Damping Controller for Inter-Area Oscillation using Fuzzy Logic
authors: Kapil Khinchi, Kundan Kumar, Kumar Abhinav, S. K. Parida, Abhineet Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Weak tie line connections in modern power networks can cause serious stability problems if they are not adequately damped against low-frequency inter-area oscillations. Various research endeavours aim to alleviate these oscillations through the utilization of Flexible AC Transmission System (FACTS) devices are conducted, providing efficacious remedies to enhance system stability. Complex nonlinear problems can be handled using fuzzy logic controllers, which apply human knowledge-based control principles. Consequently, in order to minimize inter-area oscillations in power systems, this work presents a unique Fuzzy Logic Wide-Area Damping Controller (FLWADC) based on the Static Var Compensator (SVC). To find the system’s critical inter-area mode, the suggested method is first linearizes the system around the equilibrium point and then performs eigenvalue analysis. The appropriate wide-area feedback signal is then chosen using a geometric approach. The controller parameters are tuned using a metaheuristic Fuzzy Logic (FL) apporach to achieve the desired damping for critical mode. The performance of the suggested control technique is validated on a two-area, four-machine test system. Time-domain simulations and frequency responses to small-scale disturbance demonstrate the effectiveness of the suggested controller. Furthermore, the effectiveness of the suggested controller is tested over a wide variety of time delays.

title: Secure Split and Classification Mechanism for LoRa Networks Against Active and Reactive Interference Attacks
authors: Omar Dario Delgado Brito, Floriano De Rango, Pasquale Pace
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: In the Internet of Things (IoT) domain, resource-constrained devices are highly susceptible to malicious interference due to limited duty cycles, finite energy reserves, and an inability to perform clear channel assessment. These vulnerabilities are further exacerbated in low-power wide-area networks (LPWANs), where the absence of centralized coordination renders the network an attractive target for jamming attacks. In this work, we introduce a novel split and classification mechanism designed to enhance LoRa packet delivery under both constant and reactive jamming conditions. Our approach partitions each LoRa frame into sub-packets and applies a realtime classification algorithm to identify and mitigate corrupted segments, thereby improving the effective data extraction ratio (DER). We validate the mechanism through extensive simulated scenarios across diverse network densities. Comparative analysis against the standard LoRa protocol demonstrates a significant increase in packet success rate and commensurate gain in DER, without incurring additional energy overhead.

title: Research on Intelligent Monitoring Algorithm for Tennis Training Based on Deep Learning
authors: Zou Heng, Zou Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This study focuses on developing an innovative intelligent monitoring algorithm for tennis training based on deep learning to meet the actual needs of accurate monitoring and analysis of athlete movements in tennis training. A feature extraction layer with an improved convolutional neural network structure that integrates spatiotemporal features is designed, which can more efficiently capture key features from tennis training data; at the same time, a dynamic decision-making module with an adaptive parameter adjustment mechanism based on reinforcement learning is introduced, so that the algorithm can flexibly optimize its own parameters according to different training scenarios. The study collects tennis training videos from multiple cameras and angles, and simultaneously collects sensor data to build a data set, and performs rigorous data preprocessing. In the experimental simulation stage, this algorithm is compared with the traditional monitoring algorithm. The data shows that the accuracy of this algorithm is improved by 15% to 92%; the recall rate is improved by 12% to 88%; and the F1 value is improved by 13% to 90%. Visual analysis intuitively presents the advantages of the algorithm in monitoring the details of athlete movements. In summary, the algorithm effectively improves the accuracy and efficiency of intelligent monitoring of tennis training, providing strong support for promoting the scientific process of tennis training.

title: Analysis of Fixed-Frequency Sliding Mode Controller based Maximum Power Point Tracking Scheme for Photovoltaic-fed DC Microgrid
authors: Tarun Naruka, Devendra Somwanshi, Ravindra Panchariya, Prangya Mohanty
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The power output of solar panel is a function of solar irradiance, ambient temperature, and the angle of orientation. To extract maximum power from solar panel, maximum power point tracking (MPPT) schemes are utilized. One of the widely used MPPT scheme is sliding mode control (SMC) scheme. The conventional SMC work on the basis of hysteresis comparator and variable switching frequency. The variable switching frequency makes the design of passive components of the converter challenging. Therefore, this paper provides the analysis of current controlled SMC-MPPT scheme for photovoltaic-fed boost converter. The current controlled SMC-MPPT scheme has constant switching frequency. The mathematical modelling and analysis of DC microgrid with current controlled SMC-MPPT is provided.

title: Flexible Energy Management Scheme with SRMDriven Electric Vehicle
authors: Subhashree Subhasmita Sahoo, Nutan Saha
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Electric Vehicles (EVs) present a compelling solution for lowering greenhouse gas emissions, with Switched Reluctance Motors (SRMs) gaining attention as a reliable and energy-efficient choice for EV integration.This study presents an innovative four-dock topology for energy management, designed to enhance EV driving range by incorporating photovoltaic (PV) panels into the vehicle system. The suggested framework manages energy flow across four main components: the photovoltaic (PV) panel, battery, electrical grid, and Switched Reluctance Motor (SRM). While the vehicle is in motion, the system supports independent energy control, simultaneously performing Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) for the photovoltaic panel and managing the speed of the Switched Reluctance Motor (SRM). When the vehicle is stationary, a bidirectional charging system enables seamless Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) and Grid-to-Vehicle (G2V) functionality without the need for additional hardware. Additionally, a segmented charging control method is applied when charging the battery directly from the PV panel, ensuring efficient energy usage. The system’s effectiveness is confirmed through simulations in Matlab/Simulink and practical experiments, showing enhanced performance, cost efficiency, and practical viability. This contribution supports the integration of renewable energy in EVs, promoting wider adoption and contributing to global efforts in carbon reduction.

title: VSADRC-MTPA-ASMO-CDSC Based Sensorless Vector Control of PV-Battery fed PMaSyRM for Enhanced Operation of LEV
authors: Sushant Kumar, Shailendra Kumar, Shashank Kurm, Utkarsh Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents the enhanced operation of a solar photovoltaic (SPV) and battery-fed permanent magnet-assisted synchronous reluctance motor (PMaSyRM) drive, tailored for light electric vehicle (LEV) applications. By utilizing clean energy for battery charging, the proposed SPV array promotes sustainable and eco-friendly operation. A bidirectional DC-DC converter (BDDC) is installed to improve operational efficiency by recuperating and storing braking energy during regenerative braking events, thereby enhancing the vehicle's driving range. In place of a conventional proportional-integral (PI) controller, a variable structure active disturbance rejection controller (VSADRC) is used to enhance the disturbance rejection and noise suppression capability of the system while estimating speed. To achieve optimized torque control by minimizing the currents, the maximum torque per ampere (MTPA) technique is applied. Accurate rotor position estimation is critical for vector control and it is obtained through an adaptive sliding mode observer (ASMO) coupled with a cascaded delayed signal cancellation (CDSC) technique. The ASMO demonstrates superior robustness against parameter variations and external disturbances in the estimation of back EMFs with minimal chattering. Meanwhile, the CDSC method efficiently acquires the rotor position and speed from the estimated electromotive force (EMF)s. The proposed control scheme integrates these advanced techniques to improve the dynamic performance, accuracy, and distortion-free operation of the PMaSyRM drive-based LEV. As a result, it also enables the smooth and efficient operation of the LEV.

title: Performance Assessment of the Made-in-India Aries v3 Development Platform for Motor Control Applications: A Comparative Study with Arduino UNO
authors: Nikhil Gautam, Kunwar Aditya, Binod Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study compares the performance of the domestically developed Aries v3 board and the Arduino Uno in a closed-loop DC motor control setup using an encoder and L298N driver. Target speeds of 8, 10, 12, 14, and 16 RPM were tested, evaluating steady-state errors, torque output, and control loop execution time. Results show that Aries v3 achieves higher torque and significantly lower error across all speeds, despite a slightly longer execution time due to its complex architecture. Its 32-bit RISC-V processor and higher clock speed enable precise control, establishing Aries v3 as a strong local alternative for accurate motor control applications, supporting the broader initiative of advancing indigenous hardware development.

title: Developing a performance measure for a Direct Current Electric Vehicle Charger
authors: Shouai Wang, Simon Lambert, Colin Herron, Heloise Deboil, Phil Blythe, Sanchari Deb, Anurag Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Investment in DC charging infrastructure is constrained by limited data on charge point utilisation and unclear performance under diverse conditions. This paper proposes an Operational Performance (OP) framework to evaluate DC charger efficiency beyond conventional metrics. The framework incorporates an operational function that models nonlinear factors such as grid availability, ambient temperature, and EV battery charging profiles—that affect charger performance. An Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE)-based metric is developed within this framework to provide a comprehensive assessment. This metric enables precise optimisation of charger deployment and operation, thereby improving DC charger efficiency.

title: Eradication of Electro-ocular EEG Artifacts Using Dyadic Boundary specific Filter-Bank Hybrid Approach
authors: Tamanna Jain, Ila Sharma, M.M. Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The electrical pursuit of the brain is apprehending by Electroencephalogram (EEG) and detection of neurological disorders is possible through the interpretation and illustration of EEG signals. The interpretation of the EEG signals is crucial. These interpretations are sometimes affected by the artifacts and lead to the incorrect diagnosis. During the recordings of the EEG signals, the movement of the eye balls and eye blinks leads to the ocular artifacts. Hence, elimination of the artifacts plays a major role in the diagnosis and illustration of the EEG signals. In the proposed work Empirical wavelet transform (EWT-FB) filter bank employing points of dyadic boundary is utilized for the segmentation of the artifact affected EEG signal. For the denoising application Savitzky-Goley Driven Total Variation (SGD-TV) filter is employed. The filter signal is obtained by applying SGDTV filter to the first subband generated from the segmented signal. The performance of the proposed model is analyzed using power spectral density (PSD) and computational time (Toc). Our proposed EWTSGDTV filter based hybrid approach achieve computational time of 0.417 seconds and outshine the existing literature techniques originate for rejection of electro-ocular artifact.

title: Decentralized Tiny Ensemble Learning for Privacy-Preserving Compliance Prediction in Operating Room Environments
authors: Imane Abrya, Safae Bouhaddou, Meryeme Ayache, Nidal Nasser, Amal Bouayad
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Healthcare environments, particularly operating rooms, face significant challenges in maintaining optimal conditions to prevent postoperative infections. These challenges include the absence of real-time monitoring systems, the limited availability of labeled medical data, and the difficulty of deploying intelligent solutions in resource-constrained settings. Additionally, there is a growing need to explore emerging technologies in IoT and TinyML to modernize healthcare monitoring and address existing gaps in system intelligence, scalability, and privacy. This paper presents a privacy-preserving intelligent system designed to predict the compliance of operating room environments with ISO standards by continuously monitoring key parameters such as temperature, humidity, air quality, and pressure. The system employs a decentralized Tiny ensemble learning architecture, utilizing ESP32 microcontrollers as edge learners and a Raspberry Pi 4 as the aggregator node. This approach improves prediction accuracy to 98.74 % while preserving data privacy through localized processing. To address data scarcity, recent synthetic data generation techniques from the literature are employed to create comprehensive datasets for training and validation.

title: Bridging High-Capacity Short-Reach Optical Interconnects Over C + L-Band AR-HCF with 200 Gb/s/λ and Beyond
authors: Yuru Tang, Peng Sun, Songyuan Hu, Yunhong Liu, Xumeng Liu, Shupeng Li, Ji Wang, H. Y. Fu, Zhixue He, Chao Li
abstract: Short-reach optical interconnects employing single-mode fiber (SMF) in the O-band are subject to inherent capacity limitations with the rapid growth of data-center traffic, whereas those operating in the C-band encounter severe chromatic dispersion and nonlinear impairments that restrict scaling beyond current capacities. Anti-resonant hollow-core fiber (AR-HCF) offers a compelling alternative, providing ultra-low group-velocity dispersion, orders-of-magnitude lower nonlinearity, and broad transmission bandwidth. This review explores recent advances in deploying high-capacity short-reach optical interconnects over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}+\mathrm{L}$</tex>-band AR-HCF with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$200 ~\text{Gb} / \mathrm{s} / \lambda$</tex> and beyond. Meanwhile, this paper presents a comprehensive review of the evolution from SMF to AR-HCF in short-reach intensity modulation and direct detection (IM/DD) systems, highlighting the crucial technologies and state-of-the-art experimental achievements. Future research challenges and directions are also discussed.

title: Performance Evaluation of Digital Multipliers for Application in Neural Network Accelerators
authors: Miloš Marjanović, Marko Andjelković, Danijel Danković, Jelena Nikolić, Fabian Vargas
abstract: This paper presents a performance analysis of three digital multiplier architectures—array, Wallace without carry-look-ahead (CLA), and Wallace with CLA logic—targeted for neural network (NN) accelerators. Simulations were performed using an IHP's 130 nm CMOS standard cell library in Cadence Spectre, focusing on propagation delay and power consumption across different supply voltages, temperatures and transistor dimensions. The Power Delay Product (PDP) was used to evaluate overall efficiency. Results show that the Wallace multiplier without CLA logic and the smallest cells offers the best trade-off in terms of delay and power, making it a strong candidate for low-power, high-performance applications.

title: Cybersecurity Challenges and Vulnerabilities in Grid-Tied PV System
authors: Mehnaz Shah, Ikhlaq Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: To be able to integrate solar power into the electrical grid successfully, grid-connected photovoltaic (PV) systems are critical to the shift towards renewable energy sources. Yet they are susceptible to cyberattacks, especially False Data Injection (FDI) attacks, due to their dependence on digital control and communication networks. By recognizing weak points along the power converter control system, i.e., along the MPPT and Voltage Source Converter (VSC) control loops, this paper explores the cyber-physical security of these systems. Specifically, the reference DC-link voltage and the PV current are two significant FDI attack vectors that are explored. The MATLAB/Simulink simulation results prove that attacks result in a drastic drop in system performance, such as distorted current of the grid, degraded MPPT functioning, instability of actual DC-link voltage and a peak rise in the total harmonic distortion (THD) of the grid current---far exceeding IEEE standards. The subsequent power quality problems, system losses and resultant damage to converter components from voltage stress are also analyzed in this study. These observations indicate an immediate need for effective detection and mitigation methods to ensure grid-integrated PV systems run reliably under situations of cyberattack.

title: SAFAAI: Deep Learning and Incentivized Recycling in an IoT Smart Bin Ecosystem
authors: Aiswarya M K, Karthika Raju, Dilshith T S, Nakul P, Aswathy B, Nisha K K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: This paper discusses SAFAAI, a smart plastic waste management system designed to increase waste segregation and encourage sustainable disposal by using deep learning and the Internet of Things (IoT). SAFAAI uses an object detection model based on the YOLOv5 architecture that is incorporated into a smart bin that contains sensors and a camera to correctly identify plastic waste. Users authenticate themselves using RFID cards and receive credit incentives for proper disposal, encouraging consistent recycling habits. Non-plastic waste is automatically redirected for separate handling. Additionally, real-time tracking of waste levels helps administrators streamline collection schedules and optimize bin capacity. The technologies that comprise SAFAAI can be applied at scale to resolve deficiencies in the previous models which only recognized certain types of plastics and a set of standards lacked systems of engagement to create user properties so that the user engages with the system when they were motivated to act, and not limited to using only a couple of types of plastics. On the whole, SAFAAI provides durable, data-driven, and user-centered framework for addressing plastic waste, while promoting a sense of environmental stewardship in both public and institutional contexts. There is also the added provision for a compression unit, which would shred the collected plastic waste to facilitate its recycling for repurposing in sustainable products, such as plastic bricks.

title: VLSI Architecture Implementation of Selective Level Skip Discrete Wavelet Transform for Efficient Lossy Image Compression
authors: Prabhat Ku.Sahu, Noel Prashant Ratchagar, Anubhav Bhalla, Thaj Mary Delsy T, Abhinav Mishra, Pallavi Pallavi
abstract: An innovative method for building a consistent 9/7 wavelet architecture based on the 2D-Discrete Wavelet Transform (2D-DWT) is presented in this section. The effective performance of the wavelet transformation approach is preserved while the computing expenses and requirements for the hardware are reduced using the suggested technique. A key component of the design is the uplifting system, which includes the following procedures: split up forecast that modify, and scale. These coefficients for intricacy and approximations can be efficiently computed by dividing the samples that are input between odd and even elements. The technique uses a block-based scanned technique for the updating component and an overlapping block-based scanned method for the forecasting block. There are fewer processes needed and less demand for temporary storage thanks to this architecture. In comparison to other approaches, the suggested methodology achieves a far greater overall accuracy of 99%.

publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Metal hydrides present a potentially viable approach for hydrogen compression, especially in scenarios where waste heat is accessible. A combination of medium pressure and high-pressure metal hydrides were chosen for the thermodynamic analyses of a dual stage metal hydride-based hydrogen compressor. PCIs of these hydrides are measured with varying temperatures and with the corresponding Van’t Hoff plots thermodynamic properties were assessed. Successively, compressor performance was analysed by varying the pressure and rate of hydrogen supply between metal hydride beds using thermodynamic properties and PCI data. Also, the accurate difference in the pressure caused during hydrogen transfer is presented in the form of a thermodynamic cycle. The calculated efficiency of the system was recorded as 17.65 and from the PCI data the maximum discharge pressure obtained was 123.70 bar. The current study also presents the performance comparison of the selected metal hydrides with 20 other lanthanum based metal hydride alloys.

title: Corn Leaf Disease Detection using Inception
authors: Satya Sandeep Kanumalli, P. Karuna Sri, N. Radhika, J. Kalyani, M. Sai Lakshmi Priya
abstract: Precision agriculture is critical to nurturing healthy plant growth and optimizing yields, and detecting corn leaf disease is a significant challenge. This work proposes the Inception model, a deep learning technique that was specifically designed for detecting Northern Leaf Blight, Gray Leaf Spot, and Common Rust are diseases of maize leaves—via image analysis. The unique Inception model architecture that employs parallel convolutional layers of different filter sizes allows it to extract both fine-grained and coarse-grained features from images of diverse corn leaves. This considerably enhances its ability to identify symptoms of disease at high accuracy. A labeled dataset of photos of corn leaves is used to train the model,which are subjected to preprocessing operations including resizing, normalization, and augmentation to enhance generalization. The model is guided by categorical cross-entropy as the loss function learning process while training.

title: Mission Profile Based Component-Wise Reliability Assessment of Grid-Connected Transformer-Based Nine-Level Multilevel Inverters
authors: Dinesh Kumar Tiwari, Abhishek Kumar Singh, Nalin Behari Dev Choudhury, Jiwanjot Singh, G. Ramudu
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Multilevel inverters (MLIs) are widely used in grid-tied renewable energy systems as a result of their superior power quality and efficiency. However, the reliability of MLIs is critical for ensuring long-term system performance. This paper uses mission profile data to present a component-wise reliability analysis of a nine-level multi-winding transformer (MWT) based grid-tied multilevel inverter. The study focuses on the impact of thermal stress on key components such as power semiconductor devices, capacitors, and transformers. A mission profile-based approach is employed to evaluate the lifetime of each component under real-world operating conditions. The results demonstrate that power semiconductor devices are the most vulnerable components, with their lifetime significantly influenced by temperature variations. The findings provide valuable information for improving the design and reliability of grid-tied MLIs. The detailed investigation is performed in the MATLAB/SIMULINK environment.

title: Simulation Study on the Performance of Frequency Self-Adjusting Piezoelectric Vibration Energy Harvester
authors: Weian Wang, Xu Yang, Shimin Guo, Yulai Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: With the rapid development of microelectronic devices and IoT technologies, there is a growing demand for passive self-powered systems. This paper proposes a piezoelectric vibration energy harvester with self-adjusting resonant frequency to address the narrow operating bandwidth and environmental adaptability limitations of conventional devices in responding to stochastic excitations. By integrating elastic elements at the initial fixed end of the cantilever beam, axial displacement constraints are released. When environmental excitation frequencies vary, the cantilever beam can elongate or contract through elastic element deformation to adapt to changing vibrational stimuli. A dynamic model of the energy harvester was established, and a simulation platform was developed in MATLAB to investigate the influence of equivalent stiffness parameters on output performance. Comparative experiments with conventional fixed-frequency harvesters demonstrate that the proposed self-adjusting device achieves 33.3% wider effective bandwidth and 20.61% higher peak output voltage.

title: A Multi-Modal Approach to Lip Reading: LLM-Augmented AutoAVSR Systems
authors: P Varsha, C J Sruthi, S Padmavathi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Visual Speech Recognition (VSR), commonly referred to as lip reading, plays a pivotal role in enhancing communication where audio is unavailable or compromised. Systems like LipNet and AutoAVSR have shown strong performance in translating lip movements into textual transcriptions using deep learning. However, challenges remain in sentence-level coherence, especially under noisy conditions or with open-vocabulary inputs. In this work, an LLM-augmented AutoAVSR method for lip reading is proposed and compared against the state-of-the-art LipNet model to enhance transcription accuracy. Experimental evaluations on the dataset like GRID, LRS3, and a custom noisy dataset (VideoVault) demonstrate that LLM-augmented AutoAVSR consistently outperforms the baseline models across all metrics, achieving the lowest Word Error Rates (WER) and highest sentence accuracy. These results underline the importance of coupling visual models with contextual reasoning capabilities for robust real-world lip-reading applications.

title: Source Transformation Based Parameter Tuning for DSLCC Compensated WPT for CC-CV Operation with ZPA
authors: Farhat Manzoor, Suvendu Samanta
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Wireless power transfer (WPT) facilitates efficient energy transmission without any physical connectors, utilising electromagnetic fields. Designing an inductive power transfer (IPT) charger that supports both constant current (CC) and constant voltage (CV) modes while maintaining a unity power factor offers difficulties due to fluctuating load conditions. This paper presents a new parameter tuning approach employing source transformation for the double-sided LCC (DS-LCC) compensation topology. Utilising symmetric LCC networks at both the transmitter and receiver, two resonant frequencies are analytically determined to achieve zero-phase angle (ZPA) operation in both CC and CV modes. A systematic design methodology is established for selecting compensation parameters that reduce reactive power and switching losses, thereby improving over-all efficiency. Time-domain simulations performed in MATLAB/Simulink corroborate the theoretical analysis, exhibiting stable CC and CV modes across diverse loads. The suggested methodology is validated by MATLAB Simulink simulations, illustrating its efficacy in attaining reliable and efficient WPT.

title: Non-linear Energy Operator and Multisynchrosqueezing Transform aided Multi-stage Anxiety Detection from ECG Signals
authors: Jyeshter, Saptarshi Chatterjee
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This paper presents a distinctive and robust framework for the automatic diagnosis of anxiety levels from single-channel ECG signals acquired using wearable ECG sensors, for accurate mental health monitoring and timely interventions. This work reports on a nonlinear energy operator-based R-peak detection technique with timefrequency analysis via the Iterative Multisynchrosqueezing Transform (I-MSST). R-peak detection provides precise extraction of heart rate variability (HRV) features, whereas the I-MSST offers an energy-focused time-frequency representation that depicts subtle, nonstationary features of the ECG signal at various anxiety states. Handcrafted features, combining statistical, entropy-based, and fractal features, are extracted and used to categorize four distinctive levels as normal controlled subject, light, moderate, and severe anxiety. The accuracy of 98.36% is achieved for both the XGBoost and random forest (RF) Classifiers.

title: Enhancing Brain MRI Super-Resolution: A Comparative Study of DCNN, GAN, and Vision Transformer Models
authors: Reeaa Rana, Aditya Guhagarkar, Vikas Khare
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study investigates the performance of three deep learning models-deep convolutional neural network (DCNN), generative adversarial network (GAN), and vision transformer (ViT)-for super-resolution (SR) of brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) images. The models were evaluated using mean squared error (MSE), peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), structural similarity index measure (SSIM), and learned perceptual image patch similarity (LPIPS) to assess both pixelwise accuracy and perceptual quality. Results show that the DCNN model outperformed the others in PSNR, achieving 21.24 dB, indicating better pixel-wise accuracy. The ViT model achieved the highest SSIM of 0.6424, reflecting the best structural similarity. Meanwhile, the GAN model showed the best LPIPS score of $\mathbf{0. 2 1 3 3}$, demonstrating superior perceptual quality. These findings suggest that each model excels in different aspects, highlighting the potential for optimizing MRI resolution in clinical workflows by selecting the most suitable model for specific needs.

title: Small Object Detection in High-Resolution Aerial Images: A Cascaded Zoom-In Detection Method Based on Adaptive Cropping and Score Enhancement
authors: Yulin Ren, Zhuoru Jiang, Yan Jiang, Pengchuan Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: High-resolution aerial image small object detection faces challenges such as varying scales, insufficient details, and low computational efficiency. This paper proposes a method called Enhanced Cascaded Zoom-in Detector (CZ Detector), which combines adaptive cropping and score enhancement for efficient detection. The method uses a two-stage cascade for detection: the first stage identifies basic targets and dense areas across the entire image, while the second stage applies adaptive cropping to select high-confidence regions for high-resolution zoom-in re-detection. The small object score enhancement strategy increases the classification score based on the relative area of the target, reducing missed detections. This method does not require additional learnable modules; it can be integrated into mainstream detection architectures (such as Faster R-CNN or FCOS) by simply adding “density cropping” auxiliary annotations. Tests on the VisDrone and DOTA datasets show significant improvements in small object detection performance (with the average precision for small objects increasing by up to 4.6%). Additionally, it maintains robustness even without relying on high-resolution feature layers (such as FPN-P2), providing an efficient and lightweight solution for small object detection in high-resolution images. title: Simulation Study on the Influence of Surface Curvature on the Mechanical Performance of Triply Periodic Minimal Surface Scaffolds
authors: Zhitong Li, Runchao Zhao, Xiang Zhang, Zhaobo Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The mechanical properties of the porous biomimetic scaffolds need to closely match those of the defective tissue. Triply periodic minimal surface (TPMS) have gained widespread application in tissue engineering because of their smooth surface transition and low stress concentration. It is worth noting that the influence mechanism of surface curvature on the mechanical properties of these scaffolds remains unclear. In this paper, two typical TPMS lattices are selected to construct structures with identical porosity but varying surface curvatures, and the influence mechanism of surface curvature on the mechanical properties of the scaffolds is revealed based on finite element analysis (FEA). At the same time, the intrinsic relationship between porosity and surface curvature is also discussed. The results show that for structures with the same porosity, a more concentrated surface curvature distribution correlates with enhanced mechanical properties. Taking the structure with porosity of 55% as an example, the elastic modulus of the I-WPT structure is 1.37 times that of the I-WP structure, and the elastic modulus of the GT structure is 1.38 times that of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$G$</tex> structure. Changes in porosity impact the surface curvature distribution, with higher porosity leading to a more dispersed curvature distribution, which can easily lead to stress concentration of the structure and weaken its bearing capacity. For different types of lattices, mechanical properties are less sensitive to surface curvature than macroscopic geometric features.

title: Effective Unconstrained Face Recognition from Images Using RFG: A review
authors: Ranbeer Tyagi, Geetam Singh Tomar, Laxmi Shrivastava
abstract: This paper represents the review of the Effective Unconstrained Face Recognition from Images Using Reference Face Graph an unconstrained face recognition environment. It provides the competencies like discrepancy, illumination, and expression difference strategies. It is probably useful for both verification and identity.
