However, actual-international face detection needs a hard works. The interest about unconstrained beneficial face recognition maintains growing utilizing the detonation of on-line press for example network methods. On this evaluation, we appear to handle popularity in the situation of chart assumption. We’re in a position to decide a paranormal revel in using a numerous technique. This examine light out the picks advised for unconstrained face popularity pleasant vicinity and suggesting the solution to be utilized by RFG (Reference Face Graph) targeted face recognition. RFG popularity is utilized is grouping with DCT locality sensitive hashing for green restoration to guarantee scalability. Our objective is RFG targeted unconstrained face recognition to enhance the demonstration quality.

title: A Single Input Dual Output DC-DC Converter for SRM Driven Solar Water Pump System
authors: Anjanee Kumar Mishra, Vipin Kumar Singh, Bhim Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: In order to efficiently harvest photovoltaic (PV) power for a water pump based on a switched reluctance motor (SRM), this research presents a novel topology for a dual output step-up/down converter. This converter provides a balanced dual output supply, minimal input current ripple, continuous power flow, and reduced size of its output capacitor, making system cost-effective and reliable. Moreover, presence of an inductor and capacitor at solar PV panel output effectively minimizes current and voltage fluctuations, smoothing the input supply to SRM drive. SRM converter is electronically commutated, and sensors are eliminated on drive side. Proposed scheme is found sustainable for low-cost and efficient spray irrigation and green-house water supply applications.

title: Widely Linear Momentum LMS Based Control Algorithm for Dual Stage SPVA Grid Coupled System With DAB
authors: Pavan Kumar Singh, Divyank Srivastava, Bhim Singh, Arunima Verma, Saurabh Mani Tripathi, Wazid Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This work deals with new control algorithm for grid tie solar photovoltaic array (SPVA) that incorporates a dual active bridge (DAB) converter and a battery storage for flexible power control and energy management. A voltage boost converter connects this PV system to grid through a voltage-source converter (VSC) controlled by a widely linear momentum least mean square (WLMLMS) algorithm—a revolutionary technique. WLMLMS algorithm provides adaptive control, ensuring efficient power conversion by minimizing errors in output voltage and current, thereby maintaining high-quality energy transfer to the grid. To provide effective battery charging and discharging, a DAB made power transfer in both direction among a battery and VSC DC link. The system also accommodates a nonlinear load link to grid side of VSC, with ensuring power quality and grid stability despite harmonic distortions. The integration of LMS-based control algorithm in VSC, along with a DAB converter and battery storage, provides an efficient solution for renewable energy integration, storage optimization, and grid compliance. This control offers a significant advancement in grid-connected PV system, particularly in environments with nonlinear loads, and demonstrates the potential of WLMLMS algorithm to enhance system performance in renewable energy applications. MATLAB/ Simulink is used to made simulation of system to show how well it performs in dynamic operating environments.

title: Performance Comparison of Gaussian and Weibull Distribution for Next-Day Solar Irradiance and PV Power Generation Forecasting
authors: Smriti Jain, Neeraj Kanwar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study presents a performance comparison of Gaussian and Weibull distributions for next-day forecasting of solar irradiance and photovoltaic (PV) power generation at the 2.5 GW Bhadla Solar Park in Jodhpur, Rajasthan, India. Stochastic modeling of forecasted irradiance and PV power is conducted within robust lower and upper bounds based on the availability of irradiance. A total of 1,000 scenarios are generated per hour using a Markov chain and subsequently reduced to 100 scenarios through Gaussian and Weibull clustering techniques. The 100 scenarios reduced by the Gaussian clustering technique are employed to determine the Gaussian probability of the forecasted irradiance and PV-generated power. The probability of the alternative set, reduced by the Weibull clustering technique, is evaluated using the Weibull probability density function (PDF). The forecasting accuracy of both models is assessed using performance metrics, specifically the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Results indicate that both Gaussian and Weibull distributions exhibit a reasonable level of predictive probability; however, the Weibull distribution yields lower error rates and higher accuracy. This study provides insights into the applicability of these statistical models for reliable short-term solar forecasting, expanding body of research aimed at improving forecasting techniques for large-scale solar energy projects.

title:
On the Growth of SrMoO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Films for UV-C LEDs Applications: Deposition Issues and Solutions
authors: Nitin Kamble, Rosalinda Inguanta, Bartolomeo Megna, Isodiana Crupi, Roberto Macaluso, Mauro Mosca
abstract: SrMoO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> (SMO) thin films offer exceptional UV transparency and metallic conductivity, making them ideal transparent electrodes for UV-C LEDs. However, their deposition is challenged by thermodynamic instability, where trace oxygen triggers oxidation to insulating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SrMoO}_{4}$</tex>. This study employs pulsed laser deposition (PLD) under either high vacuum or oxygen, or argon atmosphere, to grow epitaxial SMO on latticematched (001) LSAT and (110) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GdScO}_{3}$</tex> substrates. Structural and electrical characterization reveals that oxygen pressures induce <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SrMoO}_{4}$</tex> formation, increasing sheet resistance. Critically, postdeposition vacuum annealing at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8^{\circ} \mathbf{8 5}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> decomposes <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SrMoO}_{4}$</tex> inclusions, reducing resistance by three orders of magnitude. These results establish oxygen suppression during growth and corrective annealing as essential strategies for realizing highconductivity SMO electrodes in UV-C optoelectronics.

title: SOH Modulators Enable Ultra-Low Power Consumption and High Bandwidth Scaling in Silicon Photonics
authors: Tai-Cheng Yu, Chi-Wai Chow, Hao-Chung Kuo
abstract: Silicon-based optical modulators work well but fall short of InP, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LiNbO}_{3}$</tex>, and other advanced materials. Using organic electro-optic materials in silicon photonics, such as silicon-organic hybrid modulators, could boost performance while lowering costs.

title: Research and Implementation of Personalized Learning Path Recommendation Model Based on KNN Algorithm
authors: Binwen Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the rapid development of online education and adaptive learning systems, personalized learning path recommendation has become an important research direction in educational informatization. Based on the K-nearest neighbor algorithm, this study constructed a personalized learning path recommendation model that adopts the dataset of the online education platform (EdX-KDD) and the computer science learning dataset (CS-Learn). This model analyzes the characteristics of users' learning behaviors and learning resources, establishes a multi-dimensional feature space, uses the improved KNN algorithm for similar user matching, and generates personalized learning path recommendations. The experimental results of this study show that, compared with the traditional recommendation algorithms, this model has significant improvements in indicators such as recommendation accuracy, coverage rate and diversity. When the K value is 15, the model achieves the best performance, with an accuracy rate of 87.3%, which is 12.6 percentage points higher than that of the benchmark algorithm.

title: On the Contact Scaling and Issues of 2D Material Contacts
authors: Hei Wong, Wenhan Bao, Jieqiong Zhang, Jun Liu
abstract: Contacts are a complete and indispensable part of electronic devices., but have received relatively less attention historically. With the aggressive scaling of CMOS technology and the growing integration of two-dimensional (2D) materials., challenges come up. This review sheds light on various issues related to contact scaling and the challenges for ohmic contacts with 2D material. We shall examine the contact integrity resulting from the metal film and semiconductor film thinning., the increase of surface roughness., contact size, and doping density reduction. For 2D material/metal contacts, the review explores various types of interfaces, including van der Waals contacts, hybrid structures, and metal-insulator-semiconductor (MIS) contacts. Additionally, the advancements in junction doping, phase modification, and bandgap engineering for contact characteristic improvement will be discussed in detail.

title: Quantum Generative Adversarial Network for Network Traffic Prediction
authors: Yufan Cui, Han Qi, Hao Wang, Abdullah Gani, Lip Yee Por
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: With the wide application of 5G technology, the global Internet scale has grown sharply, putting forward higher requirements for both traditional network traffic prediction technology and network traffic prediction technology based on deep learning. Especially when dealing with large-scale data, the computational load and accuracy often fail to meet the actual demands. To overcome this problem, this paper introduces quantum technology and for the first time explores the challenge of applying quantum generative adversarial networks to network traffic prediction. Due to the advantage of efficient data processing capabilities of quantum generative adversarial networks (QGAN) and the sensitivity of long short-term memory networks (LSTM) to time series, the combination of the two provides a new research direction and application potential for time series analysis and prediction in the quantum field. This paper proposes a quantum generative adversarial network with an LSTM layer added to the generator. The temporal features extracted by LSTM are repeatedly embedded into the quantum circuit of the generator by using Angle encoding and data re-upload strategies. This enables quantum generative adversarial networks to handle temporal dependencies and enhances the expressive power of quantum circuits. Prediction experiments were conducted on the simulation platform using real network traffic data and compared with existing quantum neural network models for time series prediction such as QLSTM. The MAPE, $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$, MAE and RMSE indicators reached $3.4 \%, 98.6 \%, 0.018$ and 0.027 respectively, all showing significant advantages.

title: A Local Fault Detection Technique for DC Microgrid Using DC Components
authors: Ayushi Gupta, Saumendra Sarangi, Asheesh K. Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The increasing adoption of DC microgrids stems from their enhanced controllability, efficiency, and ease of integration with future DC loads. However, the rapid rise of fault currents caused by capacitor discharge and the variability of fault resistance pose significant challenges for fault detection. This work adopts the concept of DC components for identification of faults in DC microgrid. For this, current and voltage signal are pre-processed through Discrete Fourier Transform. Further, a detection index is introduced utilizing the dc components of line current and voltage to classify forward or backward faults. The effectiveness of proposed techniques is evaluated for various case scenarios on a 25kW, 500V DC microgrid system using MATLAB/Simulink<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup>. The result obtained reveals that scheme upholds its performance for all possible faults, including pole-pole, pole-ground, high resistance faults, close-in or line-end faults. The scheme accurately identifies the faulty section. Furthermore, the scheme shows strong robustness towards noise conditions as well as non-faulty transient events.

title: A New Approach to Discrete Linear Filter Design Using Metaheuristic Algorithms and Convolutional Techniques
authors: Kamil Pipka, Tomasz Talaśka, Rafał Długosz
abstract: In this work, we present selected aspects of the application of swarm algorithms to the design of finite impulse response (FIR) filters. In particular, we focus on the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, introducing some modifications to improve the algorithm's convergence. The PSO algorithm has already been used to design such filters, but in its basic form, it was insufficient to find global extrema for filters longer than about 20. Therefore, we adopted a different approach to the design of such filters. FIR filters of longer lengths can be divided into two or more shorter sections connected in series. Convolution of the impulse responses of these sections allows for the creation of filters with longer impulse responses and thus better frequency properties. In this approach, each section is designed separately by the PSO algorithm. Under certain conditions, it is also possible to design a single short filter and then connect several identical sections in series. This significantly simplifies the entire procedure. Firstly, only a single, short-length filter is designed, and secondly, the PSO algorithm operates in lower-dimensional spaces. This also allows for relatively fast convergence that leads to solutions close to optimal. In this work, we compared the results obtained for 60-length filters designed using the proposed approach and the Blackmann window.

title: A Novel Model for Air Quality Prediction With Graph Convolutional Networks and Transformers
authors: Rashmi Amin, B H Shekar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Accurate prediction of nitrogen dioxide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NO}_{2}$</tex>) is vital for urban air quality management and public health. This study evaluates hybrid deep learning models combining Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) with four temporal architectures-LSTM, GRU, TCN, and Transformer-using air quality and weather data from three Delhi cities (2017-2020). GCNs capture spatial links between cities, while temporal models learn time-dependent patterns. Among the models, GCN+LSTM performed best (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}=0.755$</tex>), followed by GCN+GRU (0.738), GCN+Transformer (0.692), and GCN+TCN (0.638). These results offer guidance for selecting effective spatiotemporal models for air quality forecasting.

title: Dynamic Modeling and Sensitivity Decoupling Control of a Macro-Micro Positionin Stage
authors: Beibei Hou, Zhiming Zhang, Shuaishuai Lu, Pengbo Liu, Peng Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: To align with the development trend of modern industry towards miniaturization and intelligence, this paper focuses on developing high-precision, long-stroke positioning systems. A mechanical structure based on Zigzag flexible hinges is proposed, with dynamic modeling conducted using pseudo-rigid body models, electromechanical coupling methods, and the Lagrange equation. Furthermore, master-slave control, parallel control, and sensitive decoupling control strategies are investigated. Systematic analysis and experiments verify the effectiveness of the sensitivity-decoupling strategy in suppressing stroke saturation of micro-motion actuators.

title: Time Driven and IoT Enabled Remote Controller for IR-Based Legacy Electronic Appliances
authors: G. S. R. Satyanarayana, B. Gowtham Praveen, N. Vinay Kumar, N. Narasimha Naidu, S. Srinivasa Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is making homes smarter by connecting everyday devices. This project shows how to control home appliances that use infrared (IR) remotes using a NodeMCU ESP8266 microcontroller, the MQTT communication protocol and Node-RED. First, the IR signals from a remote control are captured using an Arduino and an IR receiver (TSOP38238) and then decoded with the IRremote library. These decoded signals are sent to the NodeMCU, which uses an IR LED to control the appliance. A DHT11 sensor is also used to measure temperature and humidity, and it sends this information to Node-RED using MQTT. Node-RED’s Inject nodes are used to set up a schedule so the appliances can turn on or off automatically at certain times. This low-cost, flexible system adds smart features to old appliances and shows how different open-source tools can work together for real-life IoT projects.

title: Achieving Completeness in Multicore Interference Channel Identification
authors: Karl S Thyssen, Samuel R Thompson
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Following A(M)C 20-193 guidance for the assurance of multicore processors, multicore interference channels must be identified and their impact quantified. Demonstrating that the interference channel identification is complete (that is, no interference channels have been missed) is critical for meeting the objectives. A missed interference channel could impact hosted software, impacting verification results, as well as cause software failures or missed deadlines. In this paper, we identify some ‘simple’ and ‘complex’ interference channels and discuss how state-of-the-art methods identify them. This highlights the properties that are required of a methodology to claim that completeness has been achieved: a systematic methodology, traceability from documentation through to analysis, and on-target validation. This is supported by results from interference channel identification on avionicsrelevant multicore platforms.

title: Anti-Drosophila Habituation Clustering for Enhanced Anomaly Detection in Data Streams
authors: Hancheng Xiao, WeiFu Zhu, Zhipeng Qiu, Zhixia Zeng, Shi Zhang, Ruliang Xiao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: The challenge of anomaly detection in the fast-growing stream data. The lack of ground truth for anomalous data is unsupervised streaming clustering detection; additionally, the memory limitation on edge computing nodes still faces high computational costs and the “dimensional curse” problem. Inspired by the habituation loop mechanism of Drosophila, this paper proposes an anti-habituation stream clustering (AHSC) method, it is an enhanced streaming anomaly detection algorithm for data stream. The AHSC algorithm innovatively adopts a “winner-takes-all” strategy to alleviate the “curse of dimensionality” problem, presents an anti-habituation enhancement strategy to enhance the high aggregation of similarity data, and constructs a new cluster mapping scheme to reduce the computational complexity. This paper provides relevant theoretical proofs, and conducts extensive experiments on three large-scale datasets demonstrate the superiority of the AHSC algorithm.

title: Addressing the Pollination Crisis: the Current Situation and Prospects of Ground Pollination Technologies
authors: Wantong Zhang, Zijie Zhou, Jing Liu, Fuyu Sun, Han Li, Yueming Wang, Yitao Huang, Zexuan Yu, Jiyu Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Pollination is the most crucial link in the process of crop fruiting. However, animal pollinators, which are the main force among crop pollination agents, are constantly dying out under the influence of human activities. This will surely affect the security of the human food supply. Artificial supplementary pollination technology, as the main means of alleviating the shortage of crop pollination services, has evolved from the initial manual pollination to today's intelligent and precise mechanical pollination. Therefore, starting from the current situation of crop pollination and the difficult situation of pollinators, this article introduces the significance of the development of supplementary pollination technology, and conducts a detailed summary and analysis of existing ground pollination technologies, aiming to provide a basic reference for the design of ground pollination machinery.

title: YOLO-MSFF: A Multi-Scale Feature Fusion-Based Improved Algorithm for Ship Detection
authors: Renhou Huang, Xiuli Lü, Zhiming Cao, Xian Fang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Current ship detection methods suffer from inherent limitations, including excessive operational complexity, high false detection rates, and frequent missed detections—issues that severely hinder their practical application in real-world scenarios, particularly on resource-constrained devices. To address these challenges, this study proposes an enhanced lightweight detection algorithm based on YOLOv8, named YOLO-MSFF. First, a lightweight multi-scale hybrid convolution module is designed to mitigate feature redundancy in the downsampling process of the YOLOv8 backbone network, which strengthens the extraction of multi-scale features and thus lays a foundation for the accurate detection of ships with varying sizes. Second, an improved Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) with two cross-layer connections is developed in the neck network to optimize feature aggregation. Additionally, the C2f-Faster module is incorporated to reduce computational overhead during feature fusion, while the Coordinate Attention mechanism and an optimized loss function are introduced to improve the localization accuracy of small ships-a major challenge in ship detection, attributed to their low pixel ratio and weak feature representation. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that YOLO-MSFF outperforms the baseline YOLOv8 model: it achieves a $\mathbf{2. 2 1 \%}$ higher detection precision on the constructed ship dataset, with 36.66% fewer parameters and 18.47% lower computational complexity. Notably, the model size is merely a few megabytes, and this ultra-compact characteristic provides a novel and practical solution for deploying ship detection systems on mobile terminal devices with stringent resource constraints.

title: Transformer-Based Vertical Profile Optimization and Fuel Consumption Reduction
authors: Shicheng Li, Qiuli Wu, Leihong Li, Chao Zhang, Na Xing, Yiqi Li
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The rapid development of flight operation control technology has enhanced the efficiency of flight scheduling and management. However, insufficient route optimization still leads to excessive fuel consumption for aircraft. Based on the key research direction of Trajectory-Based Operations (TBO) in this emerging field, this paper proposes a vertical profile optimization method using the Transformer model. By learning speed and rate of climb/descent (ROCD) variation patterns in the original trajectory, the method predicts a more fuel-efficient speedaltitude strategy. The method models trajectory data according to flight phases, leveraging the Transformer model's powerful sequential capabilities and self-attention mechanism to predict speed and ROCD and reconstruct flight altitude. Subsequently, the fuel consumption of the optimized trajectory is calculated and compared with the original route. Simulation results show that the proposed method can reduce fuel consumption by approximately 5.9 % on average across multiple flight datasets.

title: Grape Leaf Disease Classification Based on Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Enyu Liu, Haiming Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: To address the issues associated with traditional manual diagnosis methods, such as low efficiency, high parameter count, and the need for high computational performance, an improved VGG16 model is proposed for classifying and identifying grape leaf disease and healthy leaf images. The fully connected layers of the VGG16 model are modified, and depthwise separable convolutions are used to replace some of the standard convolutions, resulting in a significant reduction in the number of parameters. Additionally, the ELU activation function is employed in place of the ReLU function to mitigate the problem of neuron death. The results demonstrate that, compared to the unmodified VGG16 model, the average accuracy increased by 1.03%, while the number of weight parameters was reduced by 91%. The average classification accuracy for the three types of grape leaf images reached 98.32%. The improved model outperforms other models such as AlexNet, ResNet50, and Inceptionv3 in terms of overall performance. This study provides a basis and technical support for the timely prevention and control of grape diseases.

title: Run Time Assurance for a Hybrid Actuated Fly-by-Wire Aircraft: A Control Barrier Function Approach
authors: Evangelos Huber, Muhammad Ahmed Hassan, Johannes Bender, Nils Schlautmann, Julius Hoffelner, Florian Holzapfel
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This work presents a safety filtering algorithm for an online Run Time Assurance function of a novel hybrid Fly-by-Wire lightweight aircraft. Control Barrier Functions are used to enforce safe envelope limits and prevent unsafe commands of the flight controller from reaching the actuators. Depending on the desired protected variable and considered dynamics, different order barrier functions are derived. In addition, the control barrier functions are combined with an unknown blackbox controller to balance safety with performance by means of a quadratic program. The benefits and drawbacks of the implementation are discussed, and the general approach is validated in a non-linear simulation environment. It is shown that the envelope is enforced successfully, even in the presence of actuator failures. Limitations for an online implementation are discussed and solutions are proposed.

title: Ad Hoc LLM-to-LLM Evaluation Framework
authors: Abdulaziz Almaslukh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have advanced tremendously in recent years. With a new major release every three months, evaluation often relies on fixed and sometimes outdated benchmarks. However, this approach is inadequate for evaluating performance due to several key issues: the potential for data contamination during training and the static nature of benchmark datasets, which often have a narrow scope. This work proposes a new framework that addresses these evaluation challenges by using multiple models to generate dynamic benchmark data sets with unrestricted scope and to assess model performance using other LLMs as judges. The implementation of the proposed framework has been developed and tested by evaluating five leading models on general Arabic question-answering tasks.

title: TS-WTAL: A Two-Stage Framework for Weakly Supervised Temporal Action Localization
authors: Shanzhen Lan, Shujun Wang, Wanting Wei, Yang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Weakly supervised temporal action localization uses video-level labels to locate action segments in unedited long videos, which is widely used in various scenarios, but faces the challenges of feature redundancy and boundary blur. Therefore, this paper adopts a two-stage optimization method to construct a proposal-based generation and classification network by integrating global-local context awareness mechanism and boundary dynamic optimization strategy, which is used to solve the problem of feature modeling redundancy and boundary location ambiguity in weakly supervised temporal action localization tasks.

title: Radar Detection and Tracking Method for Extended Target Based on Closed-Loop Feedback
authors: Yi Luo, Mingyu Zhong, Haiyang Liu, Qinyao Chang, Wujun Li, Wei Yi
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: Millimeter-wave radar systems are extensively applied in intelligent traffic systems (ITS) due to their superior sensing capabilities. As resolution improves, a single detected target may occupy several radar resolution cells simultaneously, known as the extended target (ET) effect. Conventional radar target detection and tracking systems employ the detect-before-track (DBT) framework. However, existing DBT frameworks treat detection and tracking algorithms as independent steps, and their performance degrades significantly when encountering complex scenarios with several nearby targets due to interference from both the ET's own neighboring cells and other ETs. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a closed-loop detection-tracking framework exploiting radar ET tracking information. By incorporating a feedback mechanism that utilizes the obtained target shape and motion information from tracking modules into the detection process, the proposed method effectively mitigates inter-target echo interference, achieving mutually reinforcing improvements in both detection and tracking performance. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly enhances detection and tracking capabilities in complex multi-extended-target scenarios compared to conventional DBT approaches.

title: A Conceptual Framework for Applying Large Language Models in Smart Grid Cybersecurity
authors: Rohini Haridas, Chenghong Gu, Satish Sharma, Rohit Bhakar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper proposes a conceptual framework that integrates the functionalities of Large Language Models (LLMs) with Digital Twins (DTs) to enhance the capabilities of Smart Grids (SG) in withstanding cybersecurity threats and improving their cybersecurity posture. Existing research primarily discusses LLMs and DTs independently within critical infrastructure, leaving a gap in understanding how their complementary capabilities can be effectively integrated to address the complex, evolving cybersecurity challenges specific to SG. This paper also analyzes the core functionalities of mainstream LLMs, mapping their strengths to specific cybersecurity applications. Given the limited publicly available data on implementing DTs and LLMs in SG security, this framework is presented as a theoretical starting point to provide an initial perspective on integration possibilities. Furthermore, the dual edged nature of this integration is also considered by offering a balanced perspective on its strengths and risks by exploring how these capabilities could be employed both by defenders to enhance defense and by attackers to exploit vulnerabilities. The Key implementation challenges are discussed, along with promising research directions.

title: Automatic Identification of Insulation Defects by Combining Image Processing and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Yanzhuo Li
abstract: In response to the problems of low precision and lack of real-time performance in the automatic identification of insulation defects in traditional methods, this study proposed a new automatic identification technology for insulation defects that combines artificial intelligence and image processing. Its main purpose is to realize the automatic identification of insulation defects. In the image preprocessing and defect feature extraction stage, noise removal, grayscale and contrast enhancement techniques are used to improve image quality and extract key features of defect areas. The model's capacity for generalization is further improved by the use of edge detection and data improvement. Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (DCNN) are used for defect classification, and the model performance is optimized through transfer learning. Experimental results show that this method performs well in accuracy, real-time and robustness, achieving 95% accuracy, 94% precision and 93% recall rate in crack defect identification, and also achieving good results in other types of defect identification, and can effectively identify various types of insulation defects.

title: Research on Performance Optimization of Aerospace Optoelectronic Materials Based on Computer Simulation
authors: Zhihui Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Research studies on the performance optimization of specified aerospace optoelectronic materials are widely facilitated through the use of advanced computer simulations. These simulations play a critical role in addressing the challenges that come with enhancing the reliability and efficiency of aerospace systems. This paper therefore explores the significant impact of different material properties on the system performance of an optoelectronic component widely used in varied aerospace system applications, a prospect that will leverage an array of computational tools in the simulation and the analysis of material behaviors under different operational conditions. References underscore the limitations of the traditional experimental models in the evaluation of the complexities found in aerospace materials. However, recent advancements in simulation systems and technologies that span from molecular dynamics (MD) and finite element analysis (FEA) provide promising solutions and alternatives to these issues. In this, the fundamental role of these simulations in the prediction of material performance as well as in the optimization of the aerospace optoelectronic design parameters remains essential. This paper therefore employs a combination of MD and FEA simulations in the modeling of the behaviors of the aerospace optoelectronic materials that include indium phosphide (InP) and Gallium Arsenide (GaAs) under different operational and environmental stresses. The findings establish that structural configurations and material composition significantly enhances the performance characteristics of aerospace optoelectronic materials. The simulations revealed that a 28% improvement in the systems thermal stability as well as a 12% increase in its optimal efficiency through modified GaAs structures were evident as compared to the conventional design. The findings therefore validated the efficiency of the simulations based on optimized models.

title: DPCoinShuffle: A flexible coin mixing protocol for enhanced blockchain privacy
authors: Liangsen Wang, Minsheng Tan, Bimeng Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: While the transparency of blockchain enhances security, it also exposes users' transaction privacy. While existing coin mixing protocols are effective in improving privacy, their fixed participation mechanisms and triggering methods have limitations in terms of flexibility and privacy. In this paper, we propose a flexible hybrid protocol, DPCoinShuffle, which combines a dynamic participation mechanism with an improved shuffling algorithm to enhance the anonymity, unlinkability, and efficiency of the protocol, and supports hybrid triggering strategies based on the number of transactions or time to ensure that the protocol can still operate effectively under the scenarios of uncertain number of participants or uneven transaction arrivals; at the same time, it combines the CLSAG ring with a fixed trigger method, and the CLSAG ring with the CLSAG ring. At the same time, it combines the CLSAG ring signature with the Fisher-Yates algorithm to disrupt the order of output addresses and enhance the perturbation ability of the output addresses. Experimental results show that DPCoinShuffle can enhance the privacy protection while maintaining performance.

title: Effect of Local Additive Manufacturing of Heterogeneous Alloys on the Performance of Flexible Tip Stage
authors: Xin Hou, Peng Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Flexible mechanisms are widely utilized in precision positioning, robotics, and other high-performance applications, with increasing demands on the strength and performance of the materials used. This study proposes the use of selective laser melting (SLM) technology to fabricate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 1 6 L} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{1 8 N i 3 0 0}$</tex> heterogeneous metal alloys and explores their integration with flexible mechanisms. Specifically, the work investigates the effects of replacing traditional articulated units and the local material configuration in bridge-type amplification mechanisms on the output performance of a flexible pendulum mechanism. Key performance indicators such as displacement, stress distribution, and deflection angle are analyzed to evaluate the mechanical behavior of the system.

title: GAIT- Based Authentication: A New Step to Verification
authors: Bhavya Jatolia, Ishika Singh, Aanya Gupta, Shreya Singhal, Shweta Jindal
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Behavioral biometrics is an emerging field that uses unique human interaction patterns, such as typing rhythms, gaits, and mouse movements, to enhance identity verification and security systems. A 2024 report by Yubico revealed that $54 \%$ of respondents still rely on username and password combinations for their work accounts, with $39 \%$ considering them the most secure form of authentication. This reliance persists despite the growing sophistication of cyberattacks exploiting these methods. The financial impact of such vulnerabilities is significant. In 2023, Ireland experienced €126 million worth of fraudulent payments, marking a 26% increase from the previous year. This rise is attributed to increasingly sophisticated methods fraudsters employ to bypass security systems and exploit digital marketplaces. This surge underscores the limitations of traditional authentication methods in the face of evolving cyber threats and hence proves the need for a new proficient method for enhancing security. This paper revolves around analyzing gait-based biometric authentication using the WISDM dataset. This is a type of biometric system that uses an individual’s walking pattern as a means of verifying their identity. Various machine learning models are applied to analyze gait patterns, and their performance is compared to determine the most effective approach. Random Forest was determined to be the most efficient, accurate, and precise gait identification system during the comparative examination, with 0.8941 testing accuracy.

title: Impact of Relative Permittivity on Four Wave Mixing (FWM) in Non Linear Kerr Materials for Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) Applications
authors: Sheela D
abstract: This work examines the effect of relative permittivity in nonlinear Kerr materials on four wave mixing for WDM applications. A three-channel system with identical spacing is taken into consideration. Three distinct wavelengths 1.4 μm, 1.55 μm and 1.6 μm are taken into account, and the output is analyzed using FFT and electric field distribution. The result is examined for different relative permittivity values of the nonlinear Kerr materials while taking into account the transverse electric field. The findings indicate that when the relative permittivity increases, the peak value of electric field increases. Furthermore, as the nonlinear Kerr material's relative permittivity rises, the concentration of high amplitude frequency components increases. In the context of four wave mixing, this work will be helpful in creating a framework that can serve as a guide for choosing nonlinear materials with particular relative permittivity values in order to maximize the performance of WDM systems.

title: Analysis of Brand Image Communication in Historical and Cultural Neighborhoods from the Perspective of Place Attachment
authors: Haifeng Chu, Ziqi Mi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: In the context of increasing emphasis on local cultural branding, this study explores strategies to enhance brand image communication for historical and cultural neighborhoods through the lens of place attachment. Using the Dazhong historical and cultural neighborhoods in Jiujiang City as a case study, it employs Scannell's place attachment scale and a brand image communication scale questionnaire to construct a Structural Equation Model (SEM), through which the factors influencing brand image communication in such districts are analyzed. The results indicate that the cognitive, behavioral, and affective dimensions all positively influence the district's brand image communication. Based on these findings, three communication strategies are proposed.

title: Sign Language Interpretation Using Hand Gestures
authors: Santha Azra Tabasum, Mohebbanaaz, G. Fayaz Hussain
abstract: The goal of Hand Gesture Recognition (HGR) is to convert sign language movements into speech and text which creates means for spoken communication between normal people and those who are deaf mute. The task holds major social impact despite proving challenging because of multiple hand movement styles. The current methods in HGR make use of custom-designed features for modelling sign language motion before building classification models using these extracted features. The implementation of stable features for broad changes in hand gestures remains a challenging task to achieve effectively. The latest CNN network allows automatic feature extraction from video data allowing direct learning of discriminative spatial-temporal features without manual human-designed features. Multiple video streams including colour information, depth clue and body joint location data are input to the CNN for creating combined colour, depth and trajectory information. The proposed model achieves better outcomes than handcrafted-feature-based approaches with actual data collected from Microsoft Kinect.

title: Multi-stakeholders Perspective for Smart Scheduling of Electric Vehicles
authors: Jyotsna Singh, Tanuj Rawat, Neeraj Kanwar, Rajive Tiwari
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of electric vehicle (EV) scheduling within a distribution network, where multiple objectives and constraints from different stakeholders—EV owners, EV aggregators, and Distribution Network Operators (DNOs) must be balanced. For this purpose, a two-stage multi-objective scheduling approach that integrates the economic interests of EV aggregators, the operational requirements of the DNO, and the monetary concerns of EV owners is proposed. In the first stage, EVs are scheduled to minimize the overall charging costs. In the second stage, EVs are rescheduled with the goal of reducing network losses and maximizing the profit of EV aggregator, while ensuring that the total charging cost does not exceed the optimal value determined in the first stage. The multi-objective problem of the second stage is solved using weighted-sum method. The proposed approach is tested on IEEE-33 bus distribution network and seeks to provide a balanced solution that benefits all parties involved. The simulation results shows efficacy of proposed method in terms of profit gain and reduced losses.

title: Characteristic Parameters Calculation of Shielded Two-Wire Line in Multilayer Dielectric Medium
authors: Dragana Vukić, Mirjana Perić, Ana Vučković
abstract: The characteristic impedance and effective relative permittivity of a shielded square two-wire line embedded in multilayer dielectric media are calculated using the Hybrid Boundary Element Method (HBEM). The results are validated using the Finite Element Method (FEM), showing close agreement.

title: AI System for Arabic Deepfake Detection
authors: Mjd Albishri, Fatima Asiri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: This research delves into how effective culturally adapted AI models are at spotting deepfake videos in Arabic. A combined CNN-LSTM model was crafted and tested using datasets and pre-processing methods tailored to the Arabic language. The findings indicate strong accuracy in distinguishing real videos, along with an improved match to the features present in videos from the region. Despite the continued complexity of spotting manipulated content, the study stresses the importance of localizing detection methods for languages that are often overlooked. The obtained outcomes stress the necessity of designing AI systems that account for linguistic and cultural nuances, particularly in regions with limited access to verification resources. By training models on Arabic-specific facial expressions and lipsync patterns, the developed system showcases how detection capabilities can be optimized for local environments. Expanding upon this research, our next steps entail broadening the Arabic dialect spectrum represented within the dataset. Simultaneously, incorporating audio-visual components is expected to improve recall performance. Furthermore, this methodological approach possesses the potential for adaptation across a wider range of languages. The overarching aim is to contribute to globally accessible and highly effective cybersecurity solutions.

title: Optimal Deception in Cognitive Radio Security: A Joint Nash Equilibrium Approach to Rate Adaptation and Frequency Hopping Under Jamming
authors: Muhammad Imran, Khalid Ibrahim, Ahmed Saleem, Athar Waseem, Rizwan Qureshi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Cognitive radio networks (CRNs) are highly vulnerable to intelligent jammers that adaptively exploit spectral dynamics to disrupt communication. This work proposes a joint deception-based anti-jamming framework that integrates pseudo secondary users (PSUs) with a non-cooperative game model of rate adaptation and frequency hopping. The interaction between secondary users (SUs) and an adaptive jammer is formulated as a mixed-strategy Nash equilibrium (NE), where the SU's utility function incorporates both channel capacity and risk-aversion, and the jammer optimizes disruption by targeting high-capacity channels. Closed-form equilibrium strategies are derived, showing that SUs probabilistically avoid high-risk channels, while PSUs increase the jammer's attraction probability, diverting attacks away from genuine users. Simulation results demonstrate that higher PSU attraction probabilities (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\delta_{p}= 0.7-0.9$</tex>) significantly reduce jamming probability across risk-aversion levels, enabling SUs to exploit high-capacity channels with improved robustness.

title: Femtosecond Laser Processing of Surfaces for Health-Related Applications
authors: Gemma G. Mandayo, Maria J. Fernández-Menéndez, Oihane Beldarrain, Jacobo Paredes, Mingdong Dong, Santiago M. Olaizola
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Surface structuring offers an effective strategy to modulate cell-material interactions. In this work, hierarchical micro- and nanostructures were fabricated on stainless steel using femtosecond laser ablation and subsequently replicated onto Norland Optical Adhesive 81 substrate. The process enabled precise control over both micrometer-scale grooves and Laser-Induced Periodic Surface Structures (LIPSS) with defined orientations. Surface characterization by optical profilometry, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and atomic force microscopy (AFM) confirmed the fidelity of the replicated patterns. C2C12 mouse myoblasts were cultured on the structured Norland Optical Adhesive 81 (NOA81) substrates to evaluate how surface topography influences myotube formation and alignment during myogenic differentiation. The role of micro- and nanoscale features in guiding cell behavior was assessed through analysis of myotube orientation. This approach provides a reproducible and controlled platform to study how surface architecture affects cellular organization, with potential applications in biomaterials development and skeletal muscle tissue engineering.

title: Secretary Bird Optimization based PV Reconfiguration for Maximum Power Extraction
authors: Boosa Venkatanarayana, K. Mercy Rosalina
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Extracting maximum output power from solar photovoltaic (PV) systems under partially shaded conditions (PSC) is a significant challenge because the power-voltage (P-V) curve has more than one local peak. This research paper presents the Secretary Bird Optimisation Algorithm (SBOA), which is used to reconfigure solar PV arrays. The SBOA is a nature-inspired meta-heuristic formulated on the unique hunting and survival habits of the secretary bird. By means of the powerful global search ability of SBOA, the complex nonlinear programming problem for the reconfiguration of the PV array can be solved without falling into local optima. In order to enhance power extraction and minimize mismatch losses, the proposed technique meticulously optimizes the PV module configuration. Simulations are carried out under standard and various shaded patterns. The proposed SBOA was compared with two popular algorithms, the particle swarm Optimisation (PSO) and the TCT-linked scheme. It is obvious from the data that SBOA outperforms the TCT, discharging 8.7% (TCT) and $\mathbf{6. 3 \%}$ (PSO) more power in severe shading scenarios. SBOA also shows better stability and quicker convergence, suggesting its availability in real-time implementation. This work also shows that SBOA is a new and possible Optimisation method for increasing the energy efficiency of PV systems, particularly under environmental varying conditions.

title: Impacts of Phase Noise on M-ary QAM THz Wireless Communications
authors: Bowen Liu, Takasumi Tanabe
abstract: THz technology is positioned as a key enabler for next-generation wireless links due to the extensive untapped bandwidth and inherent compatibility with silicon photonics. Here, the phase noise of THz sources is modeled to characterized its impacts on a QAM-based wireless communication system. Particularly, common and instantaneous phase errors are unveiled and presented via constellation diagrams. In addition, tolerance of phase noise under different M-ary modulation formats is explored. Meanwhile, a linear correlation between instantaneous component and EVM is revealed to define the errorfree boundary, where microcomb-driven scheme is highlighted as a highly promising candidate for error-resilient THz links under advanced M-QAM formats. The results intuitively illustrate the impacts of phase noise and offer practical insights for refining technical details on physical-layer protocols.

title: Trustworthy Machine Learning: Conformance Constraints for Enhancing Data Explainability
authors: S. S. R. M. Raju Paidi, D. Mabuni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: Ensuring the reliability of machine learning models requires that new data aligns with the assumptions made during training. Model predictions become less trustworthy when incoming data deviates from the original distribution. This paper introduces conformance constraints, a data profiling method that quantifies the degree of deviation and helps to assess when model inferences should not be trusted. Unlike traditional approaches such as functional dependencies and denial constraints, conformance constraints focus on numerical attributes and leverage low-variance components from principal component analysis (PCA) to establish stronger constraints. Furthermore, a scalable technique is proposed for efficiently discovering these constraints, growing linearly with data size and cubically with the number of attributes. Additionally, to evaluate the impact, a quantitative measure of non-conformance is introduced, aiding in applications such as trusted machine learning for identifying unreliable predictions and data drift detection for monitoring distributional shifts more accurately than existing methods. Moreover, the evaluation results demonstrate that conformance constraints enhance both the explainability and trustworthiness of machine learning models by providing a structured way to detect unreliable inferences and track data variations over time.

title: Design of autonomous navigation and path replanning algorithm for power inspection robot
authors: Ming Jiang, Hongyan Li, Dehui Zhang, Jing Li, Xue Yu, Yiru Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: As the power system develops towards intelligence and high automation, the traditional manual inspection method is gradually unable to meet the operation and maintenance needs in large-scale and complex environments. In order to improve the intelligence level of power inspection, this paper proposes and designs an autonomous navigation and path replanning system based on the fusion of improved A* and TEB algorithms. By building a hierarchical system architecture, integrating SLAM mapping, global and local path planning, dynamic obstacle avoidance and real-time replanning modules, the robot can achieve efficient autonomous inspection in complex power scenarios. In this paper, a typical substation simulation environment was constructed on the ROS and Gazebo platforms, and multiple groups of navigation experiments were conducted. A quantitative comparative analysis was conducted with the traditional path planning algorithm. The results show that the proposed algorithm is superior to the traditional scheme in terms of path length, navigation time, obstacle avoidance success rate and replanning response time, and has good real-time and robustness. Some functions were verified in the actual substation sample area, further proving that the system has engineering application potential.

title: Algorithm Using Machine Learning Open-Source Tools to Identify Handwritten Numbers: An Application in Aviation Maintenance
authors: Shayan Mairuf, Alejandro Murrieta-Mendoza, Antonios Paradeisanos
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: A major European airline seeks to utilize its historical maintenance data stored as PDF for predictive maintenance and data analysis. However, handwritten records stored as PDFs present challenges when manually capturing the data in terms of data accuracy and resource requirements. This paper proposes a new semi-automated algorithm for digitizing handwritten maintenance data within the aviation industry by combining open-source Optical Character Recognition tools, specifically PyTesseract in Python, with a Convolutional Neural Network trained on historical PDF data and the EMNIST digit database. Unique document words guide the extraction area recognition where to identify handwritten text. Preprocessing techniques mitigate challenges such as overlapping digits and segmentation errors. Results showed an accuracy of 93% for digit recognition, with overall database accuracy at 77.7%. A statistical t-test showed that the CNN predictions are significative. This algorithm reduces human effort, enhances data usability, and fulfills stakeholder requirements

title: Quantum-Aware Large Language Models: Taxonomy, Architectures, and Future Applications
authors: Reyhan Dede
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: The convergence of quantum computing and large language models (LLMs) represents a major milestone in computational intelligence, introducing novel paradigms for information processing, complexity modeling, and scientific advancement. This survey provides a comprehensive overview of the emerging interdisciplinary field that integrates quantum mechanics with natural language processing. We begin by presenting the foundational principles of quantum computing and LLMs, then examine their integration through automated quantum code generation, hybrid transformer architectures, and quantum natural language processing (QNLP) frameworks. State-of-the-art models, such as quantum-augmented attention mechanisms and circuit embedding strategies, are evaluated across domain-specific datasets and benchmarks. We also investigate the role of LLMs as quantum research assistants, educational tools, and simulation agents, particularly in resource-constrained environments. Furthermore, the survey explores challenges related to scalability, interpretability, and quantum data encoding, and outlines future research directions-especially the vision for fully quantum-native LLMs. Our goal is to guide researchers through the current landscape and to encourage continued exploration at the intersection of quantum technologies and advanced language models.

title: Designing an Optimised Gearbox for Energy-Efficient Electric Three-Wheelers
authors: Sandeep Vangapalli, Aishvaria Gorityala, Sudha Radhika
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Electric three-wheelers (L5 category) generally rely on high-power motors, which contribute to increased energy consumption and overall vehicle cost. This study introduces a two-speed gearbox designed to allow a 2 kW motor to deliver performance comparable to that of a standard 5 kW motor. The work involves the complete design, modeling, and performance evaluation of the gearbox, specifically tailored for electric three-wheeler applications. A prototype was developed and integrated into a retrofitted Bajaj RE electric three-wheeler. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in drivetrain efficiency, enabling the use of a smaller 1.6 kWh battery while achieving an energy consumption rate of 50 Wh/km. The optimized gear box improves acceleration and torque supply, causing in improved driving dynamics and consumer experience. Economically, the decreased battery size pulls down manufacturing costs and reduces the payback period, making the solution commercially attractive for fleet operations and last-mile mobility services.

title: Secure and Scalable AI Pipelines for Network Automation in Highly Regulated SaaS Environments
authors: Harika Rama Tulasi Karatapu, Vishal Gudhka
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: In highly controlled SaaS environments, network automation with AI has a tremendous positive impact on efficiency and stability. However, AI model attacks in SaaS CI/CD pipelines pose a significant security threat. This paper solves these problems by exploring evasion attacks on ML-based Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) and data poisoning at model training. We discuss defensive strategies that involve Zero Trust models, such as AI-based policy enforcement and micro-segmentation, and emphasize mitigation techniques like adversarial training, data sanitization, ensemble learning, and continuous retraining of the model in CI/CD pipelines. Our discussion also emphasizes AI-powered cyber resilience capabilities, such as automated threat identification, rapid response, and self-healing, that minimize downtime and ensure compliance in multi-tenant cloud environments. The resulting framework provides actionable guidelines for developing stable, AI-enabled network automation solutions that can withstand sophisticated adversarial attacks in today's SaaS implementations. Overall, this research offers a robust foundation for defending AI-enabled automation against cutting-edge threats and maintaining stringent regulatory compliance.

title: Augmented Reality in Industry 5.0: Customizing Production to Optimize Operational Processes and Technical Training of Operators
authors: William Aparecido Celestino Lopes, Sergio Miele Ruggero, Oduvaldo Vendrametto, Marcelo Tsuguio Okano
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: This study presents the development and evaluation of ARTechGuide, an Augmented Reality (AR)-based application designed for technical training of operators in an automotive industrial environment. The research was conducted using the Design Science Research (DSR) methodology, with application and validation in a real factory setting. The system uses mobile devices and visual recognition to provide audiovisual instructions in five critical operational scenarios. Compared to traditional methods, a 57 % reduction in setup time, a 25 % increase in execution accuracy, and a 75 % decrease in requests for help were observed. The system achieved an average of 9.25 on the User Experience (UX) scale and 4.5 on nine technical indicators evaluated by experts. Unlike commercial AR platforms, the solution adopts a local architecture, independent of constant connectivity, facilitating its adoption in environments with operational constraints. These benefits are aligned with the Industry 5.0 proposal, which values customization according to human needs.

title: Deriving Safety-related Performance Requirements for Machine Learnt Aeronautical Applications
authors: Ganesh J. Pai
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The prediction quality of machine learnt models and the functionality they ultimately enable (e.g., object detection), is typically evaluated using a variety of quantitative metrics that are specified in the associated model performance requirements. When integrating such models into aeronautical applications, a top-down safety assessment process must influence both the model performance metrics selected, and their acceptable range of values. Often, however, the relationship of system safety objectives to model performance requirements and the associated metrics is unclear. Using an example of an aircraft emergency braking system containing a machine learnt component (MLC) responsible for object detection and alerting, this paper first describes a simple abstraction of the required MLC behavior. Then, based on that abstraction, an initial method is given to derive the minimum safety-related performance requirements, the associated metrics, and their targets for the both MLC and its underlying deep neural network, such that they meet the quantitative safety objectives obtained from the safety assessment process. We give rationale as to why the proposed method should be considered valid, also clarifying the assumptions made, the constraints on applicability, and the implications for verification. Index Terms-Machine learning, Model performance, Performance requirements, Quantitative metrics, Safety performance, System safety objectives

title: Predicting User Immersion in Virtual Reality with Multiple Machine Learning Algorithms-based Ensemble Model
authors: Yunbing Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has become an increasingly popular medium across gaming, education, and healthcare. However, users often experience VR differently depending on personal and situational factors, making the concept of "immersion" highly subjective and difficult to measure. This study proposes a machine learning-based approach to predict user immersion levels using basic user and session data. We collected a public dataset from Kaggle consisting of 1000 VR users, with features such as age, gender, headset type, session duration, and motion sickness feedback. After preprocessing, we trained several baseline models including KNN, Random Forest, GBDT, SVM, and ANN. GBDT and KNN showed the strongest individual performance and were used to build an ensemble model based on predicted probabilities. SHAP analysis was applied to the best-performing model (GBDT) to interpret feature importance. Results show that the ensemble model achieved the highest accuracy and F1-score, and SHAP revealed that gender, headset type, and motion sickness are the most influential features. Our approach offers a data-driven method to estimate user immersion in VR, enabling potential applications in adaptive VR content delivery and personalized design.

title: Research on the application of multimodal emotion recognition based on deep neural network in human-computer interaction
authors: Ruifeng Li, Hanjiang Han, Haotian Ai
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In order to improve the perception ability of human-computer interaction systems on users' emotional states, this paper proposes a multimodal emotion recognition system based on deep neural networks. The system integrates three types of modalities: facial images, voice intonation, and physiological signals. It uses CNN, Bi-LSTM, and MLP for feature extraction respectively, and completes feature fusion through the attention mechanism. In the sentiment classification stage, a two-layer fully connected structure is constructed and combined with softmax to output sentiment labels. The experiment is based on the SEMAINE dataset, and the evaluation results show that the system is significantly better than traditional methods in terms of accuracy, F1-score and robustness. In human-computer interaction scenarios, the system demonstrates good real-time responsiveness and user satisfaction, and has broad application potential. This research provides technical support for building efficient and natural intelligent interaction systems, and also provides a feasible path for multimodal emotion understanding.

title: A High-Performance DC-DC Boost Converter with Enhanced Voltage Gain for Renewable Energy
authors: Vipin Kumar Chaudhary, R. K. Tripathi, Rajat Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The paper introduces a modified quadratic boost structure with an enhanced voltage gain, specifically tailored for renewable energy like solar photovoltaic and fuel cell applications. This design integrates the conventional quadratic boost converter with an additional boost module, leveraging its benefits including continuous input current. Due to its continuous input current and Enhanced voltage gain, the suggested converter is especially well-suited for solar photovoltaic systems and fuel cells. The modified quadratic boost converter (MQBC) attains an Enhanced voltage gain compared to other recently introduced converters that feature two controlled switches and the conventional quadratic boost converter. The analysis of voltage gain is conducted in continuous conduction mode (CCM), which takes into account the non-ideal characteristics of passive components and semiconductor devices in the MQBC. In addition, the selection of semiconductor devices and the design of reactive components according to voltage and current ratings are described in detail. The results of numerical simulation validate the suitability of the MQBC and support its theoretical foundations. Power electronics play a crucial role in renewable energy harvesting by enabling efficient conversion, control, and distribution of power generated from various renewable sources such as solar, wind, hydro, and fuel cells.

title: A Packaged Eight-Channel I/Q Receiver in 65-nm CMOS With Microstrip-to-Waveguide Transition for D-Band Applications
authors: Ning Jiang, Ze Shen, Pingyang He, Huiqi Liu, Guohua Zhao, Ming Zhao, Dalong Zhu, Dixian Zhao
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a compact eight-channel direct-conversion I/Q receiver (RX) for D-band application. For area and power efficiency, one compact local oscillator (LO) multiplication and distribution network is shared by all channels. The in-channel building blocks are carefully optimized for I/Q amplitude-phase balance and overall performance improvement. Fabricated in 65-nm complementary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS) with a fan-out wafer-level chip-scale packaging (WLCSP) process, the chip occupies a total area of 15.05 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. A microstrip-to-waveguide (WG) transition on the printed circuit board (PCB) is designed and measured, aiming to verify the packaging performance. The measured peak gain is 21.91 dB within the 3-dB bandwidth of 115–129.5 GHz. The measured double-sideband noise figure is 11.5–13.3 dB, and the image rejection is over 28 dBc. The RX consumes 674 mW during operation, including <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$8\times 71$</tex-math> </inline-formula>mW for eight channels and 106 mW for the common LO chain.

title: A Knowledge Intelligent Fault-tolerant Soft Robotic Operation Framework for Alterable Grasp Configuration Soft Gripper_supp1-3634324.docx
authors: Wenqing Chai
abstract: Soft robotic operation is a significant trend in daily life and industrial fields. However, soft manipulators are prone to failure during long-term operation under complex working conditions. This paper proposes a novel scheme merging with knowledge intelligent and fault-tolerant control into an alterable grasp configuration soft gripper (AGCSG). Firstly, a knowledge intelligent fault-tolerant soft robotic operation (KIFTSRO) framework with failure detection, knowledge reasoning, and fault-tolerant control is constructed. Next, the available gripper combinations are inferred from all the grasp configurations and different failure cases, and a progressive failure detection strategy is designed to assert the failure cases of sensing modules, and actuation modules as sensing modules are intact or failed. Then, a fault-tolerant soft robotic operation knowledge graph (FTSROKG) with dual input layers is designed to achieve available gripper combination reasoning with ACNet-ConvE algorithm. Finally, the UR5 robot guides the AGCSG to perform complex tasks under the fault-tolerant control scheme. The experimental results reveal that failure detection can be achieved regardless of whether the sensing modules are available or have failed. Moreover, the AGCSG can perform fault-tolerant grasping for different objects with different shapes and hardness, and accomplishes complex tasks including mobile phone charging, tea brewing, kitchen items organizing, daily objects sorting, and items arranging.

title: Listening for “You”: Enhancing Speech Image Retrieval via Target Speaker Extraction
authors: Wenhao Yang, Jianguo Wei, Wenhuan Lu, Xinyue Song, Xianghu Yue
abstract: Image retrieval using spoken language cues has emerged as a promising direction in multimodal perception, yet leveraging speech in multi-speaker scenarios remains challenging. We propose a novel Target Speaker Speech-Image Retrieval task and a framework that learns the relationship between images and multi-speaker speech signals in the presence of a target speaker. Our method integrates pre-trained self-supervised audio encoders with vision models via target speaker-aware contrastive learning, conditioned on a Target Speaker Retrieval Extractor (TSRE) module. This method enables the extraction of semantic content from the target speaker's speech and aligns it with images representing the corresponding semantic meaning. Experiments on SpokenCOCO2Mix and SpokenCOCO3Mix show that TSRE significantly outperforms existing methods, achieving 36.3% and 29.9% Recall@1 in 2- and 3-speaker scenarios, respectively-substantial improvements over single-speaker baselines and state-of-the-art models. Our approach demonstrates potential for real-world deployment in assistive robotics and multimodal interaction systems.

title: Passive BLE Backscatter with Low-Frequency-Shift and Duration-Controllable CW Excitation via Commercial Chips
authors: Jiawei He, Xiaoming Li, Xinkai Zhen, Hao Yang, Zitong Zhao
abstract: This work proposes a passive BLE backscatter system using commercial chips for duration-controllable continuous wave (CW) excitation. By leveraging the radio peripheral, we eliminate the duration limits of reverse-whitening sequences. This method reduces the required frequency shift to 1.5 MHz, minimizing tag power consumption. A batteryless tag implemented in 180nm CMOS demonstrates 6.5 μW power consumption. The system allows standard BLE signal backscattering without dedicated RF generators, enabling direct decoding by commodity BLE devices.
