title: Efficient Romanian Dialect Identification in Low-resource conditions using Transfer-Learning and Metric-Learning
authors: Aardra Shibu, Ananya Angra, H Muralikrishna, Krishnaraj Chadaga, A D Dileep, Prashanth Kannadaguli
abstract: Automatic spoken dialect identification (DID) is a challenging task as dialects of a given language have high similarities. Lack of sufficient training data to train deep learning (DL) based DID systems, which is common for low-resource languages like Romanian, makes it further challenging. While transfer-learning can be used to improve the performance in such low-resource conditions, it is not a trivial task to select a pre-trained model and a suitable layer for DID-specific feature extraction, as the ability to encode DID-specific content vary largely across models and their layers. Furthermore, due to high inter-class similarities, the features obtained from such pre-trained models may contain only limited dialect-discriminability, necessitating explicit methods to improve the discriminability of the learned features. Motivated by all these, we propose different methods to build efficient DID systems for identifying Romanian dialects, in low-resource settings. Specifically, we first explore pre-trained models like wav2vec2, HuBERT and XEUS for Romanian DID along with determining their optimum layer for this task. Furthermore, to address the performance degradation due to high inter-class similarities and intra-class variations, we employ metric learning techniques like center loss (CL) and centroid similarity loss (CSL). Obtained results indicate that DID system trained using 4th layer of XEUS model, when combined with CSL gives the best performance on Romanian DID.

title: Plasma-Activated Hydrogel Mask for Acne Treatment
authors: Jinkun Chen, Weiji Yang, Mengke Li, Xinwei Lu, Xian Wang, Shengduo Xu, Jishen Zhang, Zifeng Wang, Hao Zhang, Li Guo, Yuan Zhao, Dingxin Liu, Xiaohua Wang, Mingzhe Rong, Yumin Xia, Yongping Shao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Facial masks have a vast market in the cosmetic and medical fields. To enhance the therapeutic effects of facial masks, many additives are used, which inevitably leads to a series of problems, such as safety issues. Therefore, we proposed an efficient and safe antimicrobial plasma-activated hydrogel mask (PAHM). PAHM combines a plasma-activated ammonium acryloyldimethyltaurate/VP copolymer hydrogel (PAAH) and a plasma-activated mask substrate (PAMS). The plasma produced liquid-phase reactive species in PAAH which disrupted the cross-linking structure but had highly effective and short-term sterilizing effects. While plasma etching of cotton fibers can produce reactive functional groups, and PAMS has a long-term antimicrobial effect. Moreover, PAAH can load uniformly on PAMS and prevent water evaporation. The synergistic effect of them enhances the effectiveness and duration of PAHM. In vitro studies revealed that PAHM could kill more than 99.99% of S. aureus and P. acnes, and is effective for more than a week. In vivo experiments revealed that PAHM could effectively treat acne symptoms, inhibit the expression of inflammatory factors and reduce epidermal layer thickness without significant irritation. This work presents a novel approach to plasma application and, which has great potential for cosmetic and dermatological treatments and other applications.

title: StableV2V: Stabilizing Shape Consistency in Video-to-Video Editing
authors: Chang Liu, Rui Li, Kaidong Zhang, Yunwei Lan, Dong Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Recent advancements in generative artificial intelligence have significantly promoted content creation and editing, where prevailing studies further extend this exciting progress to video editing. These studies mainly transfer the inherent motion patterns from the source videos to the edited ones, where they often produce inferior results with inconsistency to user intentions, especially when shape changes between the edited and original objects might occur, due to the lack of particular alignments between the delivered motions and edited content. To address this limitation, we present a shape-consistent video editing method, namely StableV2V. Our method decomposes the entire editing pipeline into several sequential procedures, where we first edit the initial video frame, then simulate the shape-aware alignment between the delivered motions and edited sequence, and propagate the edited content to all other frames based on such alignment. Furthermore, we curate a testing benchmark, namely DAVIS-Edit, to offer a comprehensive evaluation of video editing, considering various types of prompts and difficulties. Experimental results and analyses illustrate the superior performance, visual consistency, and inference efficiency of our proposed method compared to existing state-of-the-art video editing studies.

title: Adaptive Thermal Management of Implantable Medical Devices
authors: Ayca Ermis, Yen-Pang Lai, Ying Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: A main obstacle to creating compact and advanced implantable medical devices (IMDs) is potential overheating in the surrounding tissue of IMDs in certain applications, such as neural prostheses like deep brain stimulators (DBSs). To overcome this challenge, a dual-mode nonlinear model predictive control (MPC) scheme for adaptive thermal management of IMDs is proposed. This proposed adaptive thermal management framework utilizes the previously developed online prediction algorithm to accurately model the thermal effects of IMDs, informed by data from spatially distributed heat sensors. The improvements in our approach are validated through both COMSOL software simulations and an in vitro experimental system. Results demonstrate that the proposed thermal management framework achieves higher power levels while preventing the risk of tissue overheating compared with the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Learning Deep ISP for High-Speed Cameras: Achieving DSLR-Quality Imaging Under High Frame Rates_supp2-3637771.mp4
authors: Jin Yi
abstract: High-speed imaging, which captures the fleeting dynamics of moving objects at extreme frame rates, has become an indispensable tool across a wide range of scientific disciplines. Yet, the pursuit of high temporal resolution often comes at the cost of significant image degradation, due to the inherent limitations of imaging sensors and the extreme conditions of ultra-short exposure and massive data throughput. As a result, high-speed cameras often produce images marred by strong noise and severe color distortions. In this work, we propose a deep image signal processing (ISP) paradigm that enables high-speed cameras to maintain extremely high frame rates while achieving image quality comparable to that of digital single-lens reflex (DSLR) cameras. To this end, we make two key contributions: 1) constructing RHID, the first large-scale real-world high-speed imaging ISP dataset, comprising 282,912 RAW images captured by high-speed cameras and corresponding sRGB images captured by DSLRs, featuring complex degradations intrinsic to high-speed acquisition; and 2) proposing a misalignment-robust ISP learning framework (MisISP), equipped with a prior mapper-guided image alignment module (PMIA) and a spectrum-guided weakly-aligned image supervisory loss, which effectively addresses inherent pixel misalignments caused by heterogeneous sensor characteristics. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our paradigm substantially advances the performance of existing deep ISP models for high-speed imaging, achieving remarkable improvements in noise suppression, brightness enhancement, and color preservation. Code and dataset are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/TIANLE233/RHID_code</uri>

title: Flexible Inter- and Intra-Switching Plane Resource Allocation in Data Center Networks
authors: Baojun Chen, Niangen Ye, Shuai Zhang, Jiawen Zhu, Weiqiang Sun, Weisheng Hu
abstract: Technologies such as intelligent reflective surface (IRS)-assisted free-space optics (FSO) systems, are capable of providing connectivity with varied bandwidth through flexibly allocating resources on a planer panel. This flexibility provides new opportunities in handling inter-rack traffic that is often unevenly distributed in space and time. In this paper, we explore a new type of resource allocation scheme by taking full advantage of this flexibility. The key ideas include: (1) dynamically divide the resource on the planar panel into two planes, such that the small and large flows can be handled separately; (2) in the plane serving small flows, use multi-hop routing with variable bandwidth connections to handle skewed traffic between source-destination pairs; (3) in the plane serving large flows, use direct links with variable bandwidth to schedule unevenly distributed demand. In essence, through flexible resource allocation in and between the two planes, this scheme is able to make more efficient use of resources. We theoretically analyze the capacities of the proposed scheme, where the effectiveness conditions and performance bounds for dynamic resource adaptation are derived and the traffic scheduling with flexible bandwidth in two planes is proved to be able to achieve constant factor approximation to the ideally optimal performance. We then propose a set of lightweight algorithms with performance guarantees in each of two planes, collectively called FlexAlloc, to realize the flexibility and adaptivity of the proposed scheme, and discuss an example of this scheme in the context of IRS-assisted FSO systems. Our simulation results show that FlexAlloc exhibits significant superiority over existing schemes for unevenly distributed traffic at low computational complexity, and can reduce the average flow completion time by 56-81%.

title: An Efficient EMI Reduction Method Through Harmonic Magnetic Field Balancing in Electric Vehicle Wireless Power Transfer System
authors: Hyunsoo Lee, Seongho Woo, Sungryul Huh, Sanguk Lee, Jaewon Rhee, Changmin Lee, Minseok Kang, Seungyoung Ahn
abstract: This article proposes a harmonic magnetic field balancing method to effectively reduce electromagnetic interference (EMI) problems caused by the leakage magnetic field in electric vehicle (EV) wireless power transfer systems. As the power level increases for fast-speed wireless charging of EVs, specific harmonics may significantly exceed EMI standards, and multiple harmonics are more likely to approach EMI standards. The proposed method provides a resonant circuit design method that enables adjustment of harmonic current magnitude and phase. Through this, a balance in the magnitude and phase of the harmonic magnetic field is achieved, which effectively reduces specific problematic harmonics while also reducing overall harmonics. The proposed method was validated through simulations and experiments. The experiment results showed that the third, fifth, and seventh harmonics, which significantly exceed the EMI standards, were reduced by 21.66, 15.58, and 18.38 dB, respectively, while an overall reduction of harmonics was also achieved.

title: Production Timing and Technology Licensing Under Competition and Demand Uncertainty
authors: Yu Liu, Manman Wang, Feng Yang
abstract: Abstract-Motivated by technology licensing practices in emerging technology industries with high demand uncertainty, we investigate firms' production timing decisions and technology licensing strategies in a supply chain consisting of two original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) and a common supplier. Both manufacturers source their key components from the common supplier, and the innovative manufacturer can license its quality-improving technology to the supplier. Considering the demand variability of quality-improving innovation, firms may adopt an ex-post production scheme (PS) to avoid market risk and choose an ex-ante production scheme (AS) to obtain market leadership. Our findings reveal that firms' production timing and technology licensing decisions depend on the demand variability and the market potential difference. Interestingly, if a low-quality manufacturer implements AS, the innovative manufacturer may benefit from AS under no licensing. However, neither firm will obtain more benefits if both implement AS under technology licensing. When the innovative manufacturer adopts AS and its competitor adopts PS, the technology licensing will hurt the common supplier. Technology licensing makes low-quality OEMs more cautious and prefer PS, while high-quality OEMs are more aggressive and prefer AS. Moreover, the innovative OEM and supplier can reach a technology licensing agreement when the difference in market potential is greater than a small threshold. The intensity of competition among two manufacturers will raise the threshold for technology licensing. The extended model of innovation costs and licensing fees verifies the robustness of production timing decisions and licensing strategy choices. Our study provides novel insights and contributes to the growing literature on technology licensing under demand uncertainty. licensing to the supplier may unintentionally reduce overall supply chain profit, especially when both OEMs choose AS. Managers of low-quality OEMs are advised to adopt ex-post production (PS) to hedge against market risk, especially when facing technology licensing. For suppliers, strategic acceptance or refusal of licensing contracts should be based on the specific combination of OEMs' timing strategies. Therefore, engineering leaders must jointly consider demand volatility, competition intensity, and partner behaviour to decide production timing that maximize long-term value across the supply chain.

title: Flight Centric ATC: Reshaping the Supervisor Role
authors: Mara Weber, Ana Paz Goncalves Martins, Verdiana Bottino, Birte Thomas-Friedrich
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: The Flight Centric Air Traffic Control (FCA) concept represents a paradigm shift from the conventional sector-based air traffic management approach which requires a high level of coordination and communication, and can lead to uneven workload distribution between sectors. FCA aims to address these challenges by eliminating sector boundaries and allowing multiple Air Traffic Control Officers (ATCOs) to work within the same airspace. Instead of being assigned to specific sectors, controllers are responsible for individual aircraft from entry to exit within the entire FCA airspace. This new approach promises significant benefits, including increased airspace capacity, longer lookahead time for conflict resolution, and efficient workload distribution among ATCOs, leading to a potential reduction in the number of required controllers and lower fuel consumption. The transition from a sector-based Air Traffic Control (ATC) system to the FCA concept fundamentally changes the tasks not only of the air traffic controllers, but of other roles such as the Supervisor, who traditionally oversees operations in an Area Control Center and assists controllers in managing challenging traffic situations. To define the role of the Supervisor in the FCA context, a dedicated workshop was conducted with Ukrainian air traffic controllers and Supervisors, as well as operational, safety and human performance experts. The workshop had three major goals. First, it aimed to explore how the Supervisor's general tasks and responsibilities change in FCA compared to a sector-based environment. Second, to assess the level of involvement of the Supervisors on FCA-specific operating procedures; finally, to determine which support tools are required to optimally carry out these tasks. The workshop discussions led to a clearer understanding of the impact of FCA on the Operational Supervisor. This paper summarizes the outcome of the discussions and describes the consensus reached by the group. In particular, one new task was identified, three required modifications, and two were considered obsolete. Participants also suggested that a new role might be required in FCA. Finally, three new tools or functions were discussed in some detail, and four might require major adaptations.

title: Sales Forecasting for Combined Merchandise Based on Association Rules in Supermarkets Using the Newsvendor Model
authors: Zihan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the growth of digital retail systems, supermarkets now generate large volumes of transactional data, offering opportunities to improve operational decisions through data-driven insights. However, traditional inventory models often treat items independently and fail to consider the interdependence of products commonly purchased together. This gap limits the ability of retailers to align procurement strategies with actual customer purchasing behaviors, especially in joint promotions or bundled sales scenarios. This study integrates association rule mining with an enhanced Newsvendor Model to improve joint procurement decisions for strongly associated product pairs in large supermarket settings. The co-purchase minimum is introduced as a proxy for bundled demand, representing the lower quantity sold when two items are purchased together. This value is used to model realistic paired demand, which traditional single-item inventory models often overlook. To account for seasonality and demand variability, rolling-window and seasonal segmentation techniques are applied during demand estimation. The proposed approach allows more accurate calculation of optimal order quantities, especially for items frequently sold together during promotional periods or holidays. Experimental results using real supermarket transaction data show that this method leads to higher service levels and a noticeable reduction in both overstocking and understocking risks compared to conventional models. The framework is practical, scalable, and well-suited for integration into retail decision-making systems.

title: Research on a Closed-Loop Self-Optimizing Electrochemical Synthesis System Based on Physics-Informed Neural Networks
authors: Yuting Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Electrochemical synthesis has gained wide application in organic and materials chemistry due to its environmentally benign and energy-efficient characteristics. However, challenges such as complex reaction pathways and difficulties in parameter regulation continue to hinder the development of precise and automated control strategies. This study proposes a closed-loop self-optimizing control system tailored for representative electrochemical transformations, particularly C(sp<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>)–C(sp<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>) cross-coupling reactions. The system integrates physics-informed neural networks with experimental data fitting and reinforcement learning–assisted parameter tuning to enable dynamic modeling and control of the reaction process. A dual-phase training strategy combining simulation pretraining with experimental fine-tuning enhances model adaptability and predictive capacity, while real-time feedback facilitates voltage optimization. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the system outperforms traditional methods in both control accuracy and stability, indicating its potential for managing complex electrochemical environments. This work presents a feasible pathway for integrating physics-based modeling with data-driven strategies in electrochemical synthesis optimization.

title: Experimental and SPICE-Based Modeling of NBTI and SHE in Power P-Channel VDMOS Transistors
authors: Lana Tasić, Nevena Veselinović, Marija Petrović, Dunja Đorđević, Miloš Marjanović, Vojkan Davidović, Sandra Veljković, Nikola Mitrović, Emilija Živanović, Danijel Danković
abstract: This paper presents an experimental and SPICE-based modeling approach for analyzing NBTI (Negative Bias Temperature Instability) and SHE (Self-Heating Effects) in power p-channel VDMOS transistors IRF9520. The objective is to enhance existing models and enable accurate prediction of device behavior under prolonged electrical and thermal stress, as well as during the recovery (relaxation) phase. Experiments were performed by applying a gate stress of - 45 V at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$175\,{}^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$</tex> for 96 hours, followed by relaxation at multiple temperatures ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-40\,{}^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$175\,{}^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$</tex>, based on which the degradation models were developed. Voltage shift data were fitted using power-law and exponential-law expressions, and implemented in SPICE for long-term performance estimation. Additionally, self-heating effects were characterized using thermal imaging under different signal shapes and current levels, and modeled using equivalent RC networks. The proposed models show good agreement with experimental data and can be used to predict degradation trends in power PMOS transistors for reliability-aware circuit design.

title: Nanomechanical and Optical Properties of Polyetherimide-Based Composite
authors: Houda Ali Gamoudi, Ivana Stajčić, Aleksandar Kojović, Dušica B. Stojanović, Aleksandar Stajčić, Vesna Radojević
abstract: Polyetherimide (PEI)-based composites are widely employed in electronic and optoelectronic components owing to their excellent thermal stability and mechanical strength. In addition to achieving high transparency, these materials must also withstand diverse stresses to ensure long-term reliability. Zirconia, as a refractory ceramic, offers excellent mechanical and chemical stability, with the added potential of modifying optical behavior when incorporated into polymer matrices. In this study, zirconia nanofibers were synthesized via electrospinning of a polyacrylonitrile/zirconium precursor solution, followed by calcination, and subsequently dispersed within a PEI matrix. As the miniaturization of components drives the need to investigate and enhance the nanomechanical properties of materials, the PEI-zirconia composite exhibits notable improvements in crucial properties. Nanoindentation revealed enhancements of 10% in hardness and 14% in reduced modulus of elasticity at 3 wt% zirconia loading, while nanoscratch testing indicated higher resistance to plastic deformation and improved wear performance despite slightly increased friction coefficients. UV-Vis analysis demonstrated that neat PEI retained high transmittance in the visible range, whereas the addition of zirconia at 3 wt%, led to an acceptable reduction. These results highlight the potential of PEI-zirconia composites as multifunctional materials that balance optical clarity with mechanical reliability, supporting their application in advanced optoelectronic and structural systems.

title: Microscale Intrinsic Fiber Photothermal Spectroscopy Gas Sensing
authors: Zhongke Zhao, Dang Hong, Chuanwen Qian, Sixiang Ran, Wenjun Ni, Ping Shen
abstract: This study introduces a novel intrinsic fiber photothermal Fabry-Perot interferometry (FPI) gas sensor. The sensor is fabricated by splicing the two ends of the Bragg hollowcore fiber (BHCF) with the single mode fiber and the suspended core fiber (SCF) without the need for coatings or nanofabrication. The eccentric splicing of the SCF and BHCF establishes an efficient natural gas channel for photothermal detection while enhancing the reflective surface area, thereby improving the contrast of the FPI cavity. The sensor demonstrates high sensitivity for acetylene gas detection with a 1 mm ultra-short cavity length, achieving a noise equivalent concentration of 114 parts per billion (ppb) with a 300 ms locking time constant. This work makes rational use of the features of special microstructure optical fibers, overcoming the limitations in sensitivity associated with traditional short-cavity intrinsic optical fiber gas sensors. The advantages of this sensor include long-term stability, fast response time, a wide measurement range, and low production costs, paving the way for broader applications of optical fiber gas sensors.

title: Engineering Design and Educational Application of Maijishan and Dunhuang Grottoes Restoration Blind Boxes
authors: Feng Wang, Weiqiang Lu, Qingyao Shi, Chengwei Fan, Haoxuan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: In response to conservation needs of Maijishan and Dunhuang grottoes, this study proposes an engineering-driven restoration blind box design. Using temperature-sensitive lithium chloride materials to simulate mural desiccation dynamics, and integrating 3D-printed models with laser mapping, it constructs a three-stage educational system including disease simulation, restoration practice, and ethical decision-making. The digital module links to “Digital Dunhuang” for injection technique virtualization, while integrating interdisciplinary technologies like ecopigment formulations, structural mechanics, and microclimate monitoring. Measurements show 45 % improvement in restoration tech cognition and 31 % enhancement in interdisciplinary skills, offering a quantifiable engineering model for cultural heritage education.

title: Multi-day Forecasting of Electricity Carbon Intensity in China: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Approaches for Low-Carbon Policy Support
authors: Yunting Du
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Electricity generation remains a major contributor to global CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions. Accurate forecasting of electricity carbon intensity is critical for supporting decarbonization efforts and optimizing low-carbon energy strategies. This study evaluated three machine learning methods and proposed the most suitable method for multi-day carbon intensity prediction, leveraging national-level data on the percentage of energy mix, electricity load, and weather conditions in China. Results demonstrate that Elastic Net outperforms tree-based methods (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.96 and MAPE = 0.69%), attributed to its effective handling of multicollinearity and linear relationships in the data. The SHAP analysis suggests the percentage of coal power is the dominant positive driver of carbon intensity, while wind power reveals the strongest mitigating effect. By employing percentage-based variables and lagged features to reduce reliance on absolute data, this study provides a transferable and replicable approach, especially for countries with limited data. Moreover, the achievement of multi-day forecasting encourages short-term response mechanisms for policymakers.

title: Ecological Carbon Sink and Economic Valuation for Binggou River Scenic Area
authors: Xuemei Yang, Weibao Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Binggou River Scenic Area, a vital ecotourism site in Qilian Mountain National Park, benefits from ecological carbon sink and economic value accounting to advance low-carbon tourism. This study employs the InVEST model, integrating 20002023 Landsat-based CLCD land use data and calibrated carbon density parameters, to assess carbon storage, valued using China's 2025 carbon exchange price (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$37.85 \text{CNY} / \mathrm{t}$</tex>). Carbon storage averaged <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$410,000 \mathrm{t}$</tex>, peaking at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$463,000 \mathrm{t}$</tex> in 2005 and reaching <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$415,000 t$</tex> in 2023, with an economic value of 15.7 million CNY in 2023. Land use changes and tourism drive fluctuations, highlighting carbon trading potential. This research supports lowcarbon tourism product development, ecological compensation, and “dual carbon” goals.

title: Compact Three-Section Mode Converter for Highlyefficient Light Coupling Between Glass Waveguide and Integrated Silicon Waveguide
authors: Junyan Wu, Hao Duan, Yizhe Wu, Shiguanqing Zheng, Wenyu Li, Zhenglong Zhu, Nan Ye, Yingxiong Song
abstract: In this paper, a low loss evanescent light coupling between ion-exchanged graded glass waveguide and topintegrated silicon waveguide is proposed by a three-section reversely-tapered mode converter structure. By using the EME simulation method, the coupling loss is limited to about 0.254 dB at a wavelength of 1550 nm, with total length of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$540 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> and starting tip width of 130 nm. Furthermore, it is shown that the horizontal misalignment tolerance of the designed structure is about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.825 \text{dB} (\pm 2 \mu \mathrm{m})$</tex>. This study provides a new design idea for achieving efficient optical coupling between glass waveguides and integrated silicon photonic devices, which is expected to be widely used in optical communications and optical interconnects.

title: A Lightweight Next-Unet Algorithm for Longdistance Speech Enhancement
authors: Ziqi Zhang, Dishi Yuan, Siyu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Recent advances in artificial intelligence have driven significant progress in speech enhancement (SE) technology. However current SE algorithms are not adequately suited to long-distance difficult acoustic situations. To address this issue, this paper creates a long-distance room impulse response (RIR) database, suggests a NeXt-Unet SE algorithm tailored to long-distance situations, and compares the effectiveness of the four common algorithms-including the NeXt-Unet algorithm-using both traditional subjective and objective evaluation experiments as well as Chinese clarity test perception evaluation experiments. According to the results, the NeXt-Unet algorithm performs exceptionally well at reducing noise in long-distance acoustic situations. In the 16 -meter long-distance scene, the perceptual evaluation of speech quality (PESQ) is enhanced by up to 47.5 % when the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is low, at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 5 ~ d B}$</tex>.

title: Robust VI-based Type-II Fuzzy-TID Control strategy for frequency monitoring of an Islanded AC Microgrid
authors: Prakash Chandra Sahu, Sumit Kumar Jha, Subhransu Ranja Samantaray, Buddhadeva Sahoo
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This research assignment intends a novel Type-II Fuzzy-tilt, integral and derivative (Type-II Fuzzy-TID) control method for frequency monitoring of an islanded AC Microgrid. The primary goal is to maintain the stability in grid frequency despite uncertainties in the system's damping and inertia, which are mostly brought on by the influx of renewable energy sources. The concept of virtual inertia (VI) serves as the foundation for the technique used to achieve this goal. The creation of an automated tie-line power scheduling in the two-area microgrid is the second goal. To concurrently accomplish these goals, the proposed Type-II Fuzzy-TID controller is modelled optimally with suggesting an improved Smell-agent optimizer (i-SAO) under several operating scenarios. By using the suggested approach, the errors occurred in microgrid frequency and tie-line power are reduced drastically in addition to offsetting the negative effects of uncertainties and disruptions. The results of the simulation demonstrate that, the suggested Type-II Fuzzy-TID control strategy can provide strong stability and performance and could able to improve the settling time area1 frequency deviation (ΔF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>) by 63.1%, 123.68% while compared to conventional Fuzzy PID controller and standard PID controller.

title: Drain Current Modeling in Tree-FETs Using Feedforward Neural Networks
authors: Dharavath Parvathi, P Prithvi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: This study investigates the application of a feedforward neural network (FNN) for predicting the drain current ($I_{D}$) in Tree-FET devices. Accurate modelling of $I_{D}$ is crucial for the design and optimisation of Tree-FET-based nanoscale circuits. This work’s originality resides in employing a neural network to model and forecast $I_{D}$ behaviour, utilising an extensive dataset derived from device-level measurements, which encompasses essential features such as gate-source voltage ($V_{G S}$), spacer material composition ($\mathrm{HfO}_{2}, \mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}, \mathrm{Si}_{3} \mathrm{~N}_{4}$, and SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), doping concentration, channel length ($L G$), and gate work function $\left(\Phi_{f}\right)$. This methodology is especially important for Tree-FETs, which exhibit intricate non-linear interactions that are difficult to explain using conventional techniques. The model’s effectiveness was evaluated by computing the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) between predicted and real drain current values. The findings demonstrate the potential of neural networks to clarify the complex, non-linear relationships governing $I_{D}$ behaviour in Tree-FET devices, hence supporting their use as predictive instruments for material-informed device design and optimisation in nanoscale circuits.

title: Hybrid SVM-XGBoost Model for Cancer Prediction: A Comparative Study of Classification Algorithms
authors: Anjali Dwivedi, Nagendra Patel, Kartikey Jaiswal, Aditya Bhushan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Cancer prediction using machine learning is pivotal in advancing early diagnosis and treatment. This study introduces a hybrid SVM-XGBoost model that leverages SVM for feature extraction and XGBoost for classification, combining their strengths for enhanced predictive performance. The hybrid model achieved the highest accuracy of $98.77 \%$, outperforming standalone models such as SVM ($98.25 \%$), XGBoost ($95.61 \%$), Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and KNN. It also demonstrated superior precision $(97.8 \%)$ and recall $(99.1 \%)$. These findings underline the effectiveness of hybrid models in improving diagnostic accuracy, emphasizing their potential applications in medical data analysis and healthcare systems.

title: Performance and Error Analysis of SOC Estimation Approach for Battery-Powered Electric Vehicles
authors: Alok Ranjan, Devara Vijaya Bhaskar, Mrutunjaya Panda, Utkal Ranjan Muduli
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The batteries are a key component of electric vehicles, and accurately estimating their State of Charge (SoC) is crucial for optimizing performance and extending the lifespan of battery. This study presents a comprehensive assessment of prominent SoC estimation approaches, focusing on both conventional model-based methods, and machine learning (ML)-based approaches. The study evaluates the effectiveness of Coulomb Counting, Extended Kalman Filter (EKF), and ML models in enhancing battery management system accuracy. Owing to the easy implementation and cost-effectiveness nature of CC predominantly used but suffers from accumulated errors over time. Moreover, the EKF provides better accuracy under system uncertainties, and the nonlinear characteristics of the battery, but its effectiveness depends on the precision of the battery model. Furthermore, the ML-based approach are capable of handling nonlinear characteristics, offering higher accuracy at the expense of computational complexity. The training data and comparative performance metrics are detailed in Table I, and II, respectively. The proposed model is validated using MATLAB/Simulink with a detailed equivalent circuit model of the battery. The outcomes highlight the effectiveness of numerous SoC estimation approaches with good accuracy and minimal error.

title: Leveraging Large Language Models and Database Integration for Compensating Micro-Anomaly in Automated SoC Verification
authors: Harsh Pandey, Gaurav Lodhi, Rajan Kumar Jha, Rajiv Kapoor
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: When System-on-Chip (SoC) projects move from concept to implementation, design intent is usually written in plain language by senior architects and then interpreted by several downstream teams. In practice, that hand-off is errorprone: small omissions or wording shifts “micro-anomalies” propagate into RTL code, where they become costly late-stage bugs. We present a verification pipeline that tackles the problem at its linguistic source. A first Large Language Model (LLM) layer converts free-form requirements into concrete artifacts such as module lists, interface definitions, and schematic fragments. A second LLM layer then validates every artifact against a knowledge base that combines relational tables, semantic embeddings, and historical metrics. Detected inconsistencies trigger an automatic feedback loop that refines the artifacts until they align with the stored golden specifications. Experiments across ten representative SoC subsystems show that the framework identifies $95 \%$ of requirement deviations versus $85 \%$ for a simulation only baseline and shortens verification turnaround by $33 \%$. In a case study on a 12-bit $250 \mathrm{MS} / \mathrm{s}$ ADC, the system uncovered twelve timing violations five missed by conventional flows while halving manual review effort. Engineers reported clearer traceability and faster convergence when requirements changed mid-project.These results indicate that language-aware, database backed reasoning can shift verification from a postdesign activity to a continuous, intent-preserving process, improving both reliability and schedule predictability for complex SoC developments.

title: A Numerical Approach of Reduction exploiting Reciprocated Differentiation Based Approximation for Electric Vehicle System
authors: Sameer Singh, Shaheen Naz, V. P. Singh, A. Mathur
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This article comprises of diminution of an electric vehicle (EV) higher order system using differentiation method (DM). Reduced models (RMs) of comparatively lower order are obtained for fifth order transfer function (TF) of EV system. DM is applied individually to the numerator and denominator part of higher order TF of EV system in order to get the coefficients of desired TF of RMs. The graphical analysis in terms of step, impulse, and Bode are presented to observe the qualitative effectiveness of RMs corresponding to higher order EV system. Time domain specifications are tabulated for quantitative analysis to support the efficacy of the obtained RMs.

title: Optimized SS-PIDA Control Approach based Frequency Regulation in an Interconnected Power Systems
authors: Anil Kumar, Mahendra Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents an optimized state-space PIDA (SS-PIDA) control design for frequency regulation in two-area power system. The SS-PIDA control design is modified version of active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) design. The key challenges in the presented control design are to select the observer frequency and PID gain parameters to obtain the desired response. Thus, this paper utilizes the recently develop an electric eel foraging optimization (EEFO) technique for the selection of design parameters in SS-PIDA control. The proposed control design is applied to regulate the load frequency in the pre-specified limits for the secure and reliable operation of the power system. The efficacy of presented control design is analyzed in comparison to the existing PID, PIDA and ADRC control designs. The performance of presented control design is examined under the sudden step load demand and parametric uncertainty.

title: A Study of Piezoelectric Sensors For Bio-Medical Applications
authors: Pavankumar Bikki, Soumya Karukula, Anuhya Jogu, K Manjusha, Korivi Alekhya, K Sowmithraj
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Piezoelectric sensors are now viable elements in biomedical devices, especially in pacemakers, because they can transform mechanical stress into electric signals. In this paper, the sensing potential of ten piezoelectric materials-PZT-5H, PZT-4, $\mathrm{BaTiO}_{3}, \mathrm{PVDF}$, Quartz, $\mathrm{LiNbO}_{3}, \mathrm{KNN}, \mathrm{AIN}, \mathrm{ZnO}$, and PMN-PT-is examined in terms of their voltage response to mechanical force application. MATLAB simulations are performed to analyze the voltage output under constant and sinusoidal force inputs, which imitate physiological environments. The findings show unique performance differences between materials, with PVDF and ZnO producing very high voltage outputs versus others. The differences are explained by changes in their piezoelectric coefficients (d<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">33</inf>) and material characteristics, which affect their efficiencies in biomedical sensing applications. The research brings to the forefront the need to choose the right materials for pacemaker sensors in order to maximize sensitivity, energy efficiency, and long-term reliability. The research gives insight into the possibilities of piezoelectric materials for developing nextgeneration pacemaker sensing units with advanced detection of physiological signals. This study is part of the ongoing progress in energy-efficient and highly responsive pacemaker technologies, leading to improved patient monitoring and cardiac health management.

title: Efficient Temperature Forecasting for High-Temperature Data Centers
authors: Safaa Hriez
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: As data centers continue to expand in scale and energy consumption, efficient thermal management has become crucial for reducing operational costs and environmental impact. Traditional cooling strategies often maintain low ambient temperatures, resulting in significant energy usage. This study investigates the feasibility of operating high-temperature data centers by predicting server temperatures under various thermal and workload conditions. A hybrid forecasting model combining SARIMAX and GRU is proposed to accurately capture both linear and nonlinear temperature dynamics. The model is evaluated using real-world data from a CFD-simulated testbed across nine distinct scenarios, combining varying server utilization levels and cooling setpoints. Experimental results, supported by the excellent RMSE values, demonstrate the model's high accuracy in forecasting temperature behavior. This research forms a strong basis for developing intelligent thermal management strategies to optimize cooling power demand and reduce carbon emissions.

title: A Real-Time Fall Detection System Based on Vision
authors: Yan Liu, Jihai Luo, Jerry Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: This paper presents a lightweight, pose-based fall detection system that combines offline training with real-time inference. The objective is to accurately identify human fall events using skeletal key point sequences extracted from video data. We first construct a dataset by extracting 2D pose landmarks from the UR Fall Detection dataset using MediaPipe Pose. These are organized into 30-frame sequences and used to train a custom convolutional neural network to distinguish fall from non-fall activities. Once trained, the model is deployed in a real-time pipeline that captures webcam video, continuously extracts pose key points, and classifies motion patterns using a sliding window buffer. Experimental validation shows that the system performs reliably in recognizing typical fall behaviors and is capable of operating in real time. The approach demonstrates a scalable, annotation-efficient framework suitable for ambient assisted living and elderly care applications.

title: Model Construction of Machine Vision in Automated Processing of Financial Documents
authors: Lili Zheng, Zheng Li, Junjie Zhang, Donglei Mei, Zexin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes a feature extraction algorithm for financial documents based on the fusion of attention mechanism and capsule network, and constructs a complete automated processing model. The improved attention mechanism accurately focuses on key information based on the semantic relevance of financial documents, and the optimized capsule network strengthens the expression of character spatial relationships. The fusion of the two improves the feature extraction capability. The experiment selects 2,000 financial documents covering invoices, reports and other types to construct a data set, and compares this model with traditional CNN and Transformer-Based models. The results show that in terms of character recognition accuracy, this model reaches 98.7%, which is 12.3% higher than the traditional CNN and 8.6% higher than the Transformer-Based model; in terms of processing speed, it only takes 1.2 seconds per document on average, which is 35% faster than the traditional CNN and 28% faster than the Transformer-Based model. At the same time, this model reduces the number of model parameters by 15% compared with the Transformer-Based model, and has higher resource utilization efficiency. The experiment shows that the model significantly improves the level of automated processing of financial documents and provides effective technical support for the intelligent development of the financial field.

title: Sliding Mode Control for Frequency Support in an Electric Vehicle Integrated Single-area Power System
authors: Sarwagya Singh, Sheetla Prasad, Vipin Chandra Pal, Manju Khurana
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a sliding mode control (SMC) strategy in the secondary loop of an electric vehicle (EV)-integrated single-area power system. The SMC switching law is formulated using frequency deviation as the primary control input for both the single-area power system and the EV system. The stability of the proposed control approach is ensured through the Lyapunov stability theorem, guaranteeing asymptotic convergence. The effectiveness of the SMC strategy is evaluated through MATLAB simulations under three different operating conditions: step load demand, random load demand, and a short-term EV power outage. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SMC scheme significantly improves frequency regulation by minimizing overshoot, undershoot, and settling time, even under system uncertainties caused by load and wind power variations. By utilizing EV flexibility, the proposed control method enhances grid stability and robustness towards frequency deviations.

title: Enhanced High-Gain DC-DC Converter fed Drive System for Performance Advances in Carbon Neutral Energy
authors: Nilanjan Das, Sukanta Halder, Sk Bittu, Gaurav, Avismit Dutta, Aurobinda Panda
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study introduces a novel multi-port, multi-operating DC-DC converter topology designed for high step-up voltage output, enabling Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs) performance analysis. The proposed topology features two input ports and four switches, achieving significant advantages over contemporary designs by utilizing fewer components while delivering high voltage gain. Additional benefits include modular design, a straightforward structure, continuous input current, and reduced input current ripple. Compared to other electric motor types, PMSMs are selected for superior dynamic response, efficient torque realization, and smooth speed control. The proposed High-Gain DC-DC Converter offers several inherent advantages, such as optimized switching, support for both step-up and step-down operations, high efficiency, and cost-effectiveness, making it an attractive solution for power systems. The proposed converter topology has been tested in four-quadrant operation, with a PMSM. Simulation results, obtained using MATLAB/Simulink, demonstrate effective multi-quadrant operation, particularly in battery charging during braking modes. Experimental validation was conducted using a dSPACE 1104 control platform, affirming the motor performance under the designed converter topology. The results underscore the efficacy of the topology, positioning it as a compelling solution for advanced motor drive systems.

title: A Hybrid LSTM-LGBM Approach for Optimized Electric Vehicle Charging Demand Forecasting
authors: Agniv Nath, Anirban Singha, Aman Yadav, Taniya Manzoor, Brejesh Lall
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: In the quest for more accurate time series forecasting, particularly in the context of electric vehicle (EV) load forecasting, the integration of deep learning and machine learning models presents a significant opportunity for improved performance. This work introduces a hybrid model that combines Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM) to leverage the strengths of both models. While LSTM excels at capturing sequential patterns and long-range dependencies, LightGBM complements it with its ability to model non-linear relationships and efficiently handle large datasets. The proposed hybrid approach enhances forecasting accuracy by utilizing LSTM-generated features as inputs for the LightGBM model, thereby combining the strengths of both models in a synergistic manner. To improve predictive performance, exogenous variables such as weather conditions, temperature, and traffic data were incorporated, enabling the model to capture complex external influences . Extensive experiments on real-world EV load datasets demonstrate that the hybrid model significantly outperforms individual models, with improved performance metrics like RMSE and MAE. This work underscores the potential of hybrid models in time series forecasting, especially when dealing with complex, multi-faceted data like EV load predictions.

title: Blind Detection of Image Splicing via Noise Level Functions with Three Channels of RGB
authors: Yuqing Zhuo
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the proliferation of digital image editing tools, image splicing has emerged as one of the most prevalent techniques for visual deception. Conventional passive blind forensic methods often exhibit elevated false detection rates in complex scenarios due to illumination variations, compression artifacts, and texture interference, particularly demonstrating insufficient sensitivity to spliced edges after blurring operations. This paper proposes a novel blind detection framework leveraging physical consistency verification, which integrates multi-channel noise analysis with an adaptive decision-making mechanism. The core workflow involves independently quantifying noise distribution characteristics in three channels of RGB to construct cross-channel noise synergy metrics for capturing device-source discrepancies in tampered regions; Employing dynamic threshold segmentation to enhance detection sensitivity for faint traces; Achieving pixel-level localization through morphological refinement. The proposed solution effectively addresses limitations of traditional methods in challenging scenarios such as low illumination and high texture complexity. Experimental validation on the UCID dataset demonstrates a precision of 79.75, providing new insights for image forensics in complex environments.

title: Analysis of the Importance of Cognitive Risk Factors in Professional RPAS Operations
authors: Cleopatra Profir, Nick Tepylo, Anita Paas, David St-Onge
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In the field of remotely piloted aircraft systems (RPAS), effective management of cognitive load is crucial to ensure the safety and efficiency of flight operations. This study focuses on exploring cognitive risk factors that contribute to the frequency of accidents involving these types of aircraft. A thorough understanding of these risks is essential for enhancing aviation safety through the implementation of preventive measures and the adoption of effective risk management strategies. For this research, thirty pilots, most with three years of experience or more, were recruited. Data were collected using semi-structured interviews or an online questionnaire that asked participants to compare cognitive risk factors in pairs, aiming to quantitatively assess their perception of these risks. The responses revealed low consistency in the answers provided by the participants, indicating discrepancies in risk factor weighting. Although professional experience appears to play a role in risk perception, no significant correlation was observed with the variables studied (individual pilot experience, total years of flight experience, average weekly flight hours, and engagement with video games). The main risk factors identified are distraction and reduced vigilance, consistent with the findings of previous reports.

title: Machine Learning based Multi-constellation Satellite Selection Algorithm in Urban Area
authors: Pin-Hsun Lee, Harry Leib
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: GNSS positioning in urban canyons is vulnerable to signal outage, non-line-of-sight (NLOS) and multipath effects from high-rise buildings. While the increasing number of satellites from multi-constellation GNSS enhances signal availability and possibly positioning accuracy, the presence of degraded signals can significantly deteriorate performance. In general, removing available signals from position calculation may increase the level of dilution of precision (DOP). This study proposes machine learning-aided satellite selection techniques that can identify and exclude low-quality signals while maintaining the DOP level. Several signal quality indicators are employed as input features to train ensemble learning algorithms. Based on the predicted scores from the machine learning output, novel satellite selection criteria are employed to exclude low-quality signals. Experimental results using measurement based realworld urban datasets demonstrate that the proposed method effectively reduces positioning errors in both single and multiconstellation cases compared to least squares positioning using all available satellites. This work indicates the effectiveness of machine learning techniques in satellite navigation.

title: Bio-Inspired Swarm Intelligence for Adaptive Route Optimization in Dynamic Environments
authors: Santosh Kumar S, Prakasha G, Sridhar Thota, Aarya P, Manohara K M, Sidhu N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ICETCI)
abstract: In dynamic environments such as intelligent transportation systems, autonomous vehicle navigation, and wireless communication networks, the ability to discover and adapt optimal routes in real-time is crucial. Traditional routing approaches often fall short when confronted with rapid changes in network topology, fluctuating traffic loads, or varying environmental constraints. To address these limitations, this study introduces a novel adaptive routing framework grounded in bio-inspired swarm intelligence principles. Drawing inspiration from the collective behavior of natural systems such as ant colonies and bird flocks, the proposed methodology integrates the strengths of Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) into a unified hybrid model. ACO offers exploration capabilities through pheromonebased feedback, while PSO contributes fast convergence by adjusting particle positions and velocities in the solution space. The hybrid algorithm dynamically balances exploitation and exploration to efficiently identify optimal or near-optimal paths in complex, changing environments. Mathematical models were formulated to govern pheromone evaporation, velocity updates, and probabilistic decision-making processes. The system was implemented and tested using a simulated network graph with varying levels of environmental dynamics, including congestion and node failure scenarios. Performance evaluation was conducted by comparing the proposed model against standard ACO, PSO, and Dijkstra's algorithm across metrics such as convergence speed, route stability, energy efficiency, and load distribution. Experimental results indicate that the hybrid swarm approach significantly outperforms existing models in terms of adaptability, reliability, and computational efficiency, especially in highly volatile conditions. Furthermore, the proposed method maintains lower energy consumption and better load balancing across network paths. This research highlights the potential of biologically inspired mechanisms in addressing complex optimization challenges and lays the groundwork for future development in real-time, intelligent routing systems for smart infrastructures and autonomous platforms.

title: BERTDiseComp: A Clinical Language Model for Detecting Disease Complications in EHRs
authors: Noha Alnazzawi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: The quick adoption of electronic health records (EHRs) highlights the need to extract valuable data from them. This data supports secondary applications and allows automated systems at the point of care, like clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) and evidence-based medicine. EHRs contain valuable data that can help guide doctors in understanding a patient's disease history, aiding in disease management, and preventing complications. Information extraction (IE) techniques automatically pull clinical details from the narrative text of EHRs, facilitating secondary use. Contextual word embedding models, such as BERT, have significantly enhanced performance across various natural language processing tasks. In this study, we present a BERTDisComp to extract disease complication details from the PrevComp corpus, which is annotated for complications stemming from the interaction between hypertension and diabetes, two prevalent diseases. The model is pre-trained on extensive clinical records from diverse corpora (ShARe/CLEF, the i2b2 obesity challenge, and PhenoCHF), known to contain abundant disease mentions. BERTDisComp employs the same architecture as BERT but is trained on text from similar clinical corpora, allowing it to comprehend clinical language nuances better. We compared BERTDisComp's performance with that of open-domain embeddings and pre-trained clinical and biomedical embeddings, and it demonstrated superior results based on the Fscore.

title: An Algorithm for Determining and Reducing Durations During the Management and Reconfiguration of High-Availability Distributed Systems in NGN, Full IP, Edge Computing, Cloud Computing and AI Infrastructures
authors: Soidridine Moussa Moindze, Massamba Lo, Samba Souare, Karim Konate
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of very long execution durations during the management activities in NGN, Full IP, IoT, Edge Computing and Cloud Computing as well as AI (Artificial Intelligent) infrastructures. This problem is a major challenge in the NGNM (Next Generation Networks Management) field. It is an optimization problem in the strong sense with resource constraints in the context of real-time reconfiguration systems. It is also related to the operability of distributed highavailability systems used in NGN communications networks (full IPv4, full IPv6, MPLS/IMS, VoIP/IPTV, FTTx/PON, Virtualization, Cloud Computing, Green Computing, 3G/4G/5G/6G, Edge Computing, WSN, VR/AR, and IoT) as well as AI (Artificial Intelligent) infrastructures. The resolution of such problems requires a significant and simultaneous reduction of several performance temporal criteria. The reduction of the execution durations allows optimizing performances of networks resources. From a practical point of view, the reduction of network resources consumption automatically decreases the overall energy consumption in the network. We propose thus an algorithm capable of determining and decreasing in real time the execution durations. This algorithm is based on minimal temporal criteria, lower and upper bounds, dominance rules, a branching scheme and an exploration strategy. Our experiments show that the results of the proposed algorithm are more efficient than those of the existing reference algorithms.

title: A Safety-Critical Control System for RPAS or UAS of the Category “Certified”
authors: Reinhard Reichel, Marco Dupper, Christian Block, Thorben Hoffmann
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: A platform-based control system for Remotely Piloted Air Systems (RPAS) or Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) has been developed to support operations under Instrument Flight Rules (IFR) in airspace classes C, D, E, and G. It is designed for application in CS-23/part-23 category aircraft, helicopters or (e)VTOLs. The control system is fully certifiable according to aeronautic standards and complies with the relevant safety requirements. The control system has been integrated in a CS-23/part-23 aircraft (Cirrus SR22). Flight tests started in July 2024 with a safety pilot on board. The next steps planned are the integration of airborne collision avoidance capability and flights without a safety pilot on board.

title: A Super-Resolution Technology Based on Introducing the Mona Module into the Backbone of the Swin-Transformer of the SinSR Model
authors: Yixuan Chen, Yufeng Qin, Bingcheng Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: Super-resolution technology is a technique that aims to reconstruct a high-resolution image from a low-resolution image. With the rapid development of deep learning, the existing Diffusion-Based Image Super-Resolution in a Single Step (SinSR) model achieves efficient super-resolution reconstruction via excellent single-step inference, but it still has certain limitations in high-frequency detail recovery. This research attempts to introduce the Multi-cognitive Visual Adapter (Mona) module into the SinSR model's Swin-Transformer backbone to enhance its ability to recover high-frequency details, and enhance the ability to extract high-frequency features through multi-scale convolution and dynamic weighting mechanism. Experimental results show that the improved model has better performance in texture detail recovery, and the subjective visual quality is significantly improved. Although the objective index (PSNR and SSIM) improvement is limited, this method verifies the feasibility of enhancing the detail recovery ability of single-step super-resolution model through structure optimization, and provides a new idea for subsequent research.

title: Research on Countermeasures for Low Accuracy of Automated Meter Reading in Qinghemen Area
authors: Xiran Zhou, Nan Cao, Xiaomei Lou, Ning Kan, Xiaoyi Zhu, Jinwei Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the advancement of smart grid construction, automated meter reading (AMR) technology, through the collaboration of smart meters, concentrators, and master station systems, realizes real-time collection and transmission of electrical energy data, significantly improving the operational efficiency of power supply enterprises. As a critical support for the intelligent management of power systems, the accuracy of AMR directly impacts the efficiency of electricity billing and user service quality. However, issues such as equipment aging, environmental interference, and human operation errors have caused the AMR accuracy in some regions to consistently fall below industry standards. Frequent meter reading errors not only trigger billing disputes but also increase operation and maintenance costs. Therefore, improving AMR accuracy has become a research hotspot in the current power industry. In this context, this study systematically analyzes the root causes of AMR anomalies through data statistics, fault diagnosis, and technical optimization. It identifies loose wiring in smart meters and meter-account mismatches as the primary influencing factors. By developing a portable bendable shim to optimize the wiring device and constructing a remote cross-connection detection model, the research ultimately increases the accuracy rate to 98.89%, yielding significant economic benefits. The findings provide reusable technical and management solutions for power enterprises to enhance meter reading efficiency and power supply reliability.

title: Integrated Planning of EV Infrastructure and Distributed Generators Using Hybrid Algorithm
authors: R. Divya Bharathi, M. Venkata Kirthiga
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: As the use of Electric Vehicles (EVs) grows in various nations, more experts are concentrating on problems pertaining to EV Charging Stations (EVCS). Only taking Distribution Networks (DNs) into account while designing EVCS optimally is not a reliable method. Additionally, the EVCS site must be suitable for the EV user within a specific EV driving range, considering the DN’s efficiency. The optimum model of EVCS and Distributed Generators (DG) in a DN connected to a Transportation Network (TN) is examined in this research. The suggested optimal planning approach seeks to minimize voltage variance, EV driving cost, and active power loss for efficient EVCS and DG planning. The distance between the demand region and EVCS region is determined using Bellman-Ford algorithm. The test system is a 25-node TN overlayed with an IEEE 33 bus and 69 bus DN. For optimization, the modified hybrid WTLBO-PSO method is used, and the outcomes are contrasted with those of the PSO algorithm.

title: Deep Learning Based Multi Class Epithelial Ovarian Cancer Classification From Histopathological Images
authors: Suma P, Suma K V, Shiva M C Mahan S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Distributed Computing, VLSI, Electrical Circuits and Robotics (DISCOVER)
abstract: Classification of medical images is a difficult, time-consuming and error-prone activity that demands for comprehensive subject knowledge. An approach is crucial for automatically classifying medical images. This study suggests unique Deep Learning systems to identify and categorize Epithelial ovarian cancer based on Histopathological images. Epithelial carcinoma, the type of ovarian cancer that is most prevalent, starts in the tissue surrounding the ovaries. The most prevalent sub-type of ovarian cancer, known as highgrade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC), frequently spreads without being noticed. To enhance patient care and longevity, this research attempts to classify the five different categories of Epithelial Ovarian cancer. This study uses a set of 4100 histopathology images, separated into training and validation subsets required to train the ResNet 50, VGG19 and DenseNet121 Deep Learning Models. Remarkably, the model's accuracy was 87% for the VGG19, 96 % for the ResNet 50 and 73 % for the DenseNet 121 model. This work is significant in overcoming the difficulties of the human expert assessment, including increased misinterpretation rates and lengthy analysis periods.

title: ML-DaaS: An Integrated ML Training and Deployment Framework for Hybrid Cloud
authors: Koushik Periyapatna Ravikumar, Noor Ahmed, Manas Satish Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: This paper presents ML-DaaS, a novel Deployment-as-a-Service framework designed for Machine Learning model training and deployment across hybrid cloud environments. Addressing the complexity of traditional MLOps workflows, ML-DaaS allows authenticated users to securely upload, train, finetune, and deploy ML models via an intuitive browser-based dashboard. The framework incorporates DevOps Tools such as Terraform, Ansible, Docker, and Jenkins, which automates infrastructure provisioning, system configuration, and CI/CD deployment, dynamically transitioning models from GPU-based training environments to cost-effective CPU-based inference. Experimental evaluations on OpenStack-based private clouds and AWS public cloud demonstrate the framework's consistent performance, secure isolation, and low-latency inference capabilities, thereby significantly reducing deployment complexity and operational overhead. Decoupling training from inference resulted in optimized resource utilization without sacrificing responsiveness, resulting in up to 40 % improvement in infrastructure turnaround time and a significant reduction in deployment complexity and operational overhead.

title: Performance Evaluation of the Julia Language for Recursive Solution Methods
authors: Akiyoshi Wakatani, Souma Hase
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: In modern software development, it is common to select and use an appropriate programming language according to the purpose and application. Julia is attracting attention as a language that offers both productivity and high performance, since it has the characteristics of a dynamic language and achieves high speed by JIT compilation. In this paper, we evaluate the performance of Julia compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C$</tex> and the effect of parallelization on an application that involves many recursive function calls. As an example of using a recursive solution method, we evaluated the performance of for a recursive implementation of the traveling salesman problem using the brute force method, and found that Julia is much slower than C, which uses a stack, because it acquires memory for each function call. Therefore, it is expected that reducing the number of function calls by converting function calls into a for loop will lead to speedup.

title: A Novel Coil Design Considerations for Wireless Charging under Vehicle-to-Vehicle technology
authors: Krishna Nag Arasavalli, S. Ramana Kumar Joga, J Ganesh Prasad Reddy, Lavanya Bobbari, Kakumanu V K Vasanthachari, Vegi Dhanraj
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The advent of V2V charging presents a promising solution to enhance electric vehicle (EV) charging efficiency and convenience. However, the design of the coils, which are crucial components for inductive power transfer, poses several challenges related to efficiency. This paper explores the key considerations in designing the coils for Wireless Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) electric charging systems using finite element analysis method. This paper also outlines the process of simulating and optimizing coil designs, focusing on factors such as coil geometry, material selection, and alignment to maximize Wireless power transfer. ANSYS Electronic Desktop, which integrates tools like Maxwell 3D components for electromagnetic simulations using 3D models for system-level modeling, is utilized to evaluate various coil configurations. The paper also discusses the impact of design parameters such as coil size, number of turns, and frequency on performance, highlighting the trade-offs between efficiency, cost, and practical constraints in a real-world V2V scenario. By providing insights into these design considerations, this work aims to contribute to the development of efficient and reliable V2V charging systems that could play a crucial role in the future of electric vehicle infrastructure.

title: On Robust Communication for Next-Gen Vehicle Platooning
authors: B S Subrahmanya Bharadwaaj, Sahaj Jain, S Ajay Joshua, Sovanjyoti Giri
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Reliable inter-vehicle communication is critical for autonomous vehicle platooning, where coordination failures can lead to delays or unsafe situations. In this paper, we propose a robust communication framework combining a Spider Webinspired network topology with an Ant Colony Optimization (ACO)-based routing algorithm. Unlike traditional star-topology systems that are prone to central node failures, the spider web model offers decentralized, redundant paths for resilient data transmission. Our ACO-based algorithm dynamically selects optimal communication paths by mimicking pheromone-based path selection, effectively reducing latency and offline error rates. We evaluate the system on parameters such as communication success rate, latency distribution, and redundancy. Results show a significant increase in success rate and reduced latency compared to baseline methods. This hybrid approach demonstrates scalability, adaptability, and robustness for real-time vehicular networks, paving the way for safer and more reliable platooning systems.

title: Generation of Correlated Photon Pairs in Modal Phase-Matched Lithium Niobate Nanowaveguide
authors: Wen-Xiu Li, Yun-Ru Fan, Yuan-Jie Yang, Hai-Zhi Song, You Wang, Hao Li, Li-Xing You, Lei Wang, Guang-Can Guo, Qiang Zhou
abstract: We demonstrate the generation of correlated photon pairs in a modal phase-matched lithium niobate nanowaveguide via cascaded second-harmonic generation (SHG) and spontaneous parametric down conversion (SPDC). A pair generation rate (PGR) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.1 \times 10^{5} \text{Hz} \text{mW}^{-2}$</tex> and coincidence-toaccidental ratio (CAR) up to 188 are obtained.

title: Enhanced Brain Tumor Detection: Imposing Ensemble Machine Learning with Maximum Voting
authors: Suman Rekha Dip, Hemant Kumar Meena
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Brain tumor (BT) is one of the most aggressive and life-threatening cancers, necessitating accurate and efficient detection for timely medical intervention. Conventional techniques typically rely on a single classifier for BT detection. However, single classifiers operate with a fixed decision boundary, which may not be optimal for complex datasets. This limitation often results in poor generalization across different data distributions, leading to suboptimal performance on unseen samples. To overcome these challenges, we propose a novel ensemble machine learning model that incorporates contrast limited adaptive histogram equalization (CLAHE) for enhanced BT classification. Our methodology utilizes a publicly available Kaggle dataset, with preprocessing steps including CLAHE for contrast enhancement, Otsu thresholding for image binarization, and median filtering for noise reduction. A minimal yet effective set of features is extracted to improve classification efficiency while maintaining high performance. The ensemble model combines random forest (RF), logistic regression (LR), and support vector machine (SVM) using a hard voting mechanism, achieving an accuracy of $90 \%$ without requiring data augmentation. The model operates with a computational time of 5.17 seconds, and ROC curve analysis yields an AUC of 0.91, demonstrating its robustness and reliability. Additionally, K-means segmentation is applied post-classification for precise tumor localization. This study highlights the effectiveness of ensemble learning for BT classification, particularly in scenarios where manual labeling and data augmentation are challenging for medical professionals. The proposed approach offers a computationally efficient, accurate, and practical solution for real-time medical diagnostics.

title: An Enhanced Authentication Solution for Infrastructureless Vehicle Environments
authors: Marwa Slimene, Nathalie Mitton, Patrick Sondi, Ahmed Meddahi
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Robust vehicle authentication is essential in order to ensure an effective audit of vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communications. However, most existing approaches rely on a centralized infrastructure to access both authorities' certificates andrevocation lists, thus making them ineffective in dynamic and infrastructureless environments. In this paper, we highlight this critical limitation, and propose a method which enables the vehicles to update their local authentication databases independently from infrastructure availability. Our approach aim to allow vehicles to perform V2V authentication using locally stored data, in order to ensure continuity of secure communications even when disconnected from the Infrastructure. We further analyze the probability of successful authentication under two scenarios, which are the first with up-to-date databases, and the second with outdated ones.
