The analytical results show that the authentication probability decreases to below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 5 \%}$</tex> after <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0}$</tex> hours of disconnection with long-lived certificates, while updates keep it above 90% in highway scenarios, even with short-lived certificates. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of maintaining reliable V2V authentication outside the infrastructure coverage, and point out the necessary improvements for evolving towards secure and auditable V2V communications.

title: Real-Time Target Classification using mmWave Radar through Statistical Analysis of 1D FFT Data
authors: Yash Soni, Harshita Jangir, Pranabesh Maji, Dhiraj
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: In this research, we introduce an innovative methodology for target classification utilising the frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) radar operating within the millimeterwave (mmWave) spectrum, specifically in the $77-81 \mathrm{GHz}$ range. Our approach leverages machine learning techniques applied to statistical parameters extracted from the range Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) plots derived from raw radar data. We have extracted features like peak intensity, signal width, area under the curve, standard deviation, skewness, and some others. Our evaluation of lightweight classification models, specifically LightGBM and simple NN, reveals that the NN model achieves an impressive accuracy score of $\mathbf{0. 9 6}$. Additionally, the paper uses the SHapley-Additive exPlanations (SHAP) technique to provide insight into the most important features used for classification. Furthermore, a demonstration of practical deployment of our approach across five development boards was carried out, enhancing the deployability of the target classification approach using the statistical features. The Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense microcontroller provides inference time within 1ms with features like low power, cost and high performance. This research contributes significantly to the intersection of radar technology and machine learning, paving the way for future advancements in this field.

title: A Lightweight Face Quality Assessment Framework to Improve Face Verification Performance in Realtime Screening Applications
authors: Ahmed Aman Ibrahim, Hamad Mansour Alawar, AbdulNasser Abbas Zehi, Ahmed Mohammad Alkendi, Bilal Shafi Ashfaq Ahmed Mirza, Shan Ullah, Ismail Lujain Jaleel, Hassan Ugail
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Face image quality plays a critical role in determining the accuracy and reliability of face verification systems, particularly in real-time screening applications such as surveillance, identity verification, and access control. Low-quality face images, often caused by factors such as motion blur, poor lighting conditions, occlusions, and extreme pose variations, significantly degrade the performance of face recognition models, leading to higher false rejection and false acceptance rates. In this work, we propose a lightweight yet effective framework for automatic face quality assessment, which aims to pre-filter lowquality face images before they are passed to the verification pipeline. Our approach utilizes normalized facial landmarks in conjunction with a Random Forest Regression classifier to assess image quality, achieving an accuracy of 96.67 %. By integrating this quality assessment module into the face verification process, we observe a substantial improvement in performance, including a 99.7 % reduction in the false rejection rate and enhanced cosine similarity scores when paired with the ArcFace face verification model. To validate our approach, we have conducted experiments on a real-world dataset collected comprising over 600 subjects captured from CCTV footage in unconstrained environments within Dubai Police. Our results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively mitigates the impact of poor-quality face images, outperforming existing face quality assessment techniques while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Voronoi-Based Task Allocation and Dynamic Role Reassignment in Swarm Robotics Using ROS 2 DDS
authors: George David, Saurav Gupta, Dheeren Ku Mahapatra, Ranjeet Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Swarm robotics, inspired by natural systems, offers a compelling approach to managing large groups of simple robots for complex tasks, including surveillance and environmental monitoring. This study introduces a novel framework that enhances communication in swarm robotics using ROS 2 and MATLAB Simulink, focusing on Voronoibased task allocation and dynamic role reassignment. The proposed method addresses existing challenges in real-time coordination, particularly in environments susceptible to robot failures. By implementing Voronoi partitioning, the framework ensures efficient coverage and minimal overlap in operational areas. Additionally, an adaptive mechanism dynamically reallocates roles among robots, maintaining operational continuity and robustness in failure-prone scenarios. The integration of MATLAB Simulink allows for comprehensive simulation of swarm behaviors, validating the system’s performance and reliability. Simulation results demonstrate improved responsiveness and scalability, making this framework particularly suited for real-world applications where resilience is critical. The implications of this research extend to various fields requiring robust multi-robot coordination, highlighting the potential for enhanced efficiency in swarm robotic systems.

title: Towards Smart Agriculture: Deep Learning for Tea Plant Disease Identification
authors: Medha Bhargava, Babita Tiwari, Tripti Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Tea plant diseases are a menace for the global tea industry, which mandates the need to devise ways to identify the diseases accurately, and take preventive measures accordingly. This paper introduces a method utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for the categorization of tea leaf illnesses. The labelled dataset consists of annotated images of tea leaves, which are resized and augmented before being fed into the model. The hyperparameters are tuned to allow for stable training amidst computational constraints. The trained model demonstrates high accuracy in distinguishing between different categories of tea leaf diseases, thereby strengthening the stake of deep learning in automated agricultural diagnostics and subsequent management of tea plant diseases.

title: Blood Cell Detection: A Review
authors: He Wen, Tong Zhang, Tuoyu Ju, Yujuan Chen, Mengnan Liu, Zuobi Wang, Le Zhao, Can Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Blood cell detection is vital for diagnosing diseases like anemia and leukemia, monitoring health, and supporting research. Once reliant on manual microscopy, it now employs automated methods for greater accuracy and efficiency. This review covers flow cytometry for rapid cell analysis, image analysis using machine learning for automated classification, and emerging technologies like microfluidics and biosensors. These advancements aid disease diagnosis, drug development, and health monitoring. Artificial intelligence integration promises enhanced precision and point-of-care testing, paving the way for personalized healthcare. These innovations collectively improve diagnostic capabilities and patient care.

title: Research on Optimization Scheduling Scheme for Electric Vehicle Charging and Discharging Based on Advanced Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Zheng Li, Yuan Ma, Jin Li, Hao Chen, Liangliang Liu, Jingwei Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: In response to the problem of disorderly charging and discharging of electric vehicles exacerbating the peak valley difference in the distribution network, this paper aims to reduce user charging costs and the peak valley difference rate of the power grid, and constructs a charging and discharging optimization scheduling model. The model comprehensively considers the constraints of charging and discharging power and battery protection strategies, and adopts an improved particle swarm optimization algorithm to solve them. Nonlinear inertia weights, dynamic learning factors, and mutation factors are introduced to improve the algorithm performance, and the EV charging and discharging power matrix is used as the optimization variable (dimension N × 24). Simulation shows that under the time of use electricity pricing mechanism, orderly scheduling can significantly smooth out load fluctuations-the peak to valley difference rate is reduced by 11.86%/20.97% when the penetration rate is 15%/35%, The cost of charging has significantly decreased, achieving "peak shaving and valley filling"; Compared to fixed electricity prices, this strategy reduces user costs through the "valley charging and peak discharging" mechanism, and increases the load rate by 15.63% under high penetration rates, effectively improving the utilization rate of power equipment.

title: Identification of Diabetic foot ulcer using thermogram with Shallow and Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Rahul Mishra, Ajinkya Dholekar, Chandra Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Diabetes is one of the most prevalent diseases around the world, affecting the quality of life of millions of people and often leading to severe complications. One of the most severe complications is Diabetic Foot Ulcer (DFU), which can result in reduced mobility, infections, amputations, and even mortality if not properly managed. Early diagnosis and regular monitoring are critical for mitigating the risks associated with DFUs. However, these tasks pose substantial challenges due to the complexity of care and resource constraints. Among the various diagnostic approaches, thermography has emerged as a promising non-invasive technique for detecting abnormalities related to Diabetic Foot Ulcers. This work proposes two methodologies that leverage thermographic images of patients’ feet to determine whether they currently have or are at risk of developing diabetic foot ulcers. shallow learing approach yield accuracy of 0.85, and deep learning method yield 0.95, These methodologies aim to enhance early detection, improve patient outcomes, and reduce the burden on healthcare systems.

title: The Electrospinning of Resveratrol Encapsulated into the Matrix Based on Hyaluronic Acid
authors: Hao Wu, Svetlana N. Morozkina, Zuobin Wang, Jingran Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: Hyaluronic acid (HA) and resveratrol are widely recognized for their biocompatibility, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant and anti-cancer properties. However, combining hydrophobic resveratrol with hydrophilic HA into electrospun nanofibers without toxic crosslinking agents remains a challenge. In this study, resveratrol-loaded HA nanofibers with an average diameter of 129 nm were successfully fabricated via electrospinning using a binary solvent system of deionized water and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 50:50 v/v). The absence of carrier polymers and toxic catalysts ensured biocompatibility. The electrospinning process stability, fiber morphology and diameter distribution were systematically investigated under varying voltages (23 − 30 kV). SEM analysis revealed uniform at optimal conditions (28 kV). The presence of DMSO in the complex resveratrol-HA in the fibers is expected to enhance therapeutic efficacy through localized anti-inflammatory effects. This work demonstrates a promising strategy for fabrication of HA-based nanofibers for wound healing and drug delivery applications.

title: A Mathematical Approach for Detecting Electricity Theft Cyber-Attacks in Distributed Generation
authors: Sayak Mondal, Parimal Acharjee, Aniruddha Bhattacharya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Electricity theft is a significant concern in distributed generation (DG) systems, particularly with the integration of renewable energy sources, where cyber-attacks can manipulate generation data to falsely report higher energy supplies to the grid. Manipulation of distributed generation data may mislead the distribution system operator regarding the actual power balance in the distribution network. This paper presents a mathematical approach for detecting electricity theft cyber-attacks in DG systems, focusing on renewable-based energy generation. The proposed model applies a deterministic method to identify deviations in the power generation data by determining the multiplying factor of the maximum DG capacity. The model has been implemented and tested on a 118-bus Radial Distribution System (RDS), demonstrating its effectiveness in detecting anomalies indicative of cyber-attacks aimed at inflating energy generation values. By analyzing power and generation data, the model successfully identifies discrepancies suggesting unauthorized manipulation. The results show that the proposed mathematical approach offers a promising solution to enhance electricity theft detection in DG systems, offering a more accurate and reliable method compared to traditional machine learning-based techniques.

title: A Carbon Emission Reduction Enhancement Framework for Tourism Routes Based on Time Window Optimization
authors: Po-Cheng Chen, Xing Chen, Hong-Xi Shen, Chi-Hui Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Tourism transport contributes 70−80% of sector emissions, necessitating sustainable route optimization. This study presents an innovative Geographic Information System (GIS)-enhanced framework adapting the Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows (VRPTW) to minimize tourism carbon emissions while addressing critical temporal constraints (scenic spot hours, seasonality, transport frequency). We employ multi-objective optimization balancing travel cost, time penalties, and emission abatement. Case studies at Meihua Lake (Taiwan, China) and Sayram Lake (Xinjiang, China) demonstrate reduced travel distances <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(12.1 \%$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.8 \%)$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 9 \%$</tex>; Meihua: 4.998 kg to 4.548 kg; Sayram: 157.08 kg to 140.83 kg). Combining electric vehicles with temporal optimization achieves up to 55.7% lower emissions versus conventional transport. This first framework uniquely incorporating real-world complexities (attraction hours, preferences, capacity) simultaneously optimizes temporal constraints and environmental impact, offering practical applications for sustainable ecotourism and climate goals.

title: Airborne Optical Sensing: Implementing a Context-Sensitive Object Detection System for Multi-Target Tracking
authors: Johannes Ostler, Finn Fuchs, Peter Stütz
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: In this work, we present our novel two-stage approach to visually detect vehicles from a moving airborne observer equipped with a steerable optical sensor. After laying out the motivation of enabling robust and automated optical following of ground targets for airborne multi-target tracking (MTT), we describe the implementation in detail. Focusing on the performance requirements of an embedded system deployable on medium and small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), the system is designed to run in real-time on modern graphical processing unit (GPU) focused hardware. Leveraging the individual advantages and strengths of both fundamentally different approaches, we use a movement detector based on classical image processing methods alongside the already implemented machine learning (ML)-based object detector. Using image processing techniques such as feature detectors, optical flow, filtering, and clustering, the movement detector isolates true moving features from the also moving background in the scene and provides measurements usable in our data fusion stage. Using data collected with a manned ultralight aircraft equipped with a state-of-the-art surveillance sensor, we verify and explore the envelope of the integrated system in flight.

title: A Fire Allocation Model Based on an Improved Genetic Algorithm
authors: Jian Lin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Firepower operations are the fundamental form of modern warfare and a critical area of research for enhancing the battlefield combat capabilities of our military. To address the issues of slow evolution and premature convergence in genetic algorithms when solving the firepower allocation problem aimed at maximizing damage probability, this study improved the genetic algorithm by employing strategies such as defining a discrete feasible solution space, modifying the fitness function, and retaining superior individuals. The improved algorithm was then tested through simulation experiments, which demonstrated that the convergence speed of the algorithm was significantly improved, and its global optimization capability was markedly enhanced.

title: Enterprise bankruptcy prediction algorithm based on graph neural network
authors: Zhiyi He
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes an enterprise bankruptcy prediction model based on hierarchical graph neural networks. By collaboratively integrating the internal attributes of enterprises and the external correlation characteristics, the prediction performance and interpretability are significantly improved. The model innovatively combines the Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) and the Multi-head Graph Attention Mechanism (GAT). Among them, the GCN module extracts the inherent features of enterprises through two-layer convolution operations, and the GAT module dynamically models the influence of the correlation network using four attention heads, and designs a gated fusion mechanism to adaptively adjust the feature weights. The experimental results show that the model achieves an accuracy rate of 0.91 and an F1 value of 0.85 on the dataset of A-share listed companies, which is 8.97% higher than the traditional XGBoost method. Moreover, in A high-noise environment with σ=0.3, F1 only decreases by 6.8%, demonstrating excellent robustness. Although there is room for improvement in computational efficiency, its innovative multi-perspective feature fusion architecture not only achieves precise prediction but also identifies key risk transmission paths through attention weights, providing reliable support for financial risk control decisions.

title: Deep Learning for Sustainable Tourism: Enhancing Visitor Experience and Promoting Lesser-Known Heritage Sites in Bishnupur
authors: Apurba Nandi, Avik Kumar Das, Tuheena Bose, Divyanshi Srivastava, Sandip Mandal, Madhurya Chowdhury
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Many towns in India are rich in cultural and architectural heritage, with Bishnupur in West Bengal being a notable example for its stunning terracotta temples from the Malla dynasty. Despite their historical value, many of these architectural wonders remain overlooked due to limited digital documentation, language barriers, and a lack of informative tools for tourists. To address this, the paper propose an intelligent, image-based recognition system tailored for Bishnupur’s architectures. Tourists can capture or upload a photo of any site to instantly receive its name, historical background, geolocation, and recommendations for nearby attractions with google map locations. The system utilizes preprocessing techniques and a custom-trained CNN enhanced with data augmentation to ensure reliable classification from limited image data. By combining visual recognition with cultural storytelling and location-aware features, our model promotes equitable tourism, enhances visitor experience, and contributes to the sustainable digital preservation of Bishnupur’s rich architectural legacy.

title: Integration of Software-Defined Radios for Avionics into a Multi-Core IMA Architecture
authors: Lin Bao, Florian Reynaud, Christopher Fuhrman, René Jr Landry
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This paper describes research to integrate various software-defined radio-based communications, navigation, and surveillance systems into a system-on-chip platform. The platform is powered by a multi-core processor and operates on a real-time operating system designed with robust time and space partitioning capabilities, to ensure deterministic performance, fault isolation and secure multi-partition execution (in parallel) within a single hardware environment. As part of the validation process, a case study was conducted with an analysis of results from both laboratory tests and real-world flight tests. These evaluations aim to showcase the feasibility and stability of the proposed design while highlighting significant improvements in the performance and integration of the hardware and software systems and ensuring reliability and robustness in practical aviation scenarios.

title: Secure and Scalable Data Integrity Verification for Multi-Cloud Storage Using Blockchain-Integrated IPFS
authors: Swatisipra Das, Minati Mishra, Rojalina Priyadarshini
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Cloud storage provides unlimited data storage space, convenient and secure access to files, efficient data management, offsite backup capabilities, and cost-effective usage. However, dependence on a single Cloud Storage Provider ($CSP$) introduces challenges such as vendor lock-in, security vulnerabilities, and cost-related issues. Multi-Cloud Storage ($MCS$) provides strategic solutions to these issues by distributing data across different $CSP_{s}$ but suffers from data integrity, availability, and verifiability issues in the absence of trustworthy ThirdParty Auditors ($TPA_{s}$). To address trust issues among entities, blockchain-enabled solutions store metadata of data chunks directly on the blockchain, resulting in scalability challenges. The proposed model integrates blockchain with the Inter Planetary File System (IPFS) to provide a secure and scalable data integrity verification approach for MCS environments. Secure storage of metadata in IPFS improves scalability while effectively detecting malicious CSP in the event of data modification. Experimental results show that the solution is both cost- and storage-efficient, while security vulnerability assessments confirm that the deployed smart contracts are free from vulnerabilities.

title: RAG-Based Video Knowledge Retrieval: A Vector Database Approach to Video Summarization and Timestamped Q&A
authors: Mani Shankar Jha, Gananatha Bhuyan, Benazir Neha
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The extraction, summarization, and retrieval of knowledge from video content is a significant challenge due to the multimodal, unstructured, and temporally dispersed nature of information within videos. This paper presents a novel framework that combines Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with vector database indexing for efficient and accurate video-based knowledge access. The system extracts transcripts from YouTube videos, segments them into temporally-aligned chunks, and embeds these chunks using Sentence-Transformer models into high-dimensional vector space. These embeddings are stored in a vector database (e.g., FAISS or Pinecone) to enable low-latency similarity search. The framework includes an abstractive summarization module powered by ChatGPT to provide a high-level overview of the video content. Additionally, natural language queries are encoded, matched against the embedded transcript segments, and passed to ChatGPT for refined, context-aware answers with corresponding timestamps. This architecture enables users to navigate video content efficiently and interactively. Experimental results on a curated dataset of educational YouTube videos demonstrate that our system outperforms conventional baselines. It achieves a ROUGE-L score of 43.2 (vs. 35.7 using BART-CNN) and an MRR of 0.84 (vs. 0.67 using direct GPT-4). Furthermore, response latency is reduced by over $30 \%$ due to precomputed embedding vectors. This study confirms the effectiveness of combining RAG and vector search for timestamped video content summarization and retrieval. Future work will explore multimodal fusion techniques and domain-specific embedding fine-tuning.

title: Doppler-Assisted Automotive Radar Data Clustering Under Micro-Doppler Effect
authors: Jing Zeng, Aranee Balachandran, Ratnasingham Tharmarasa
publish: 2025 14th International Conference on Control, Automation and Information Sciences (ICCAIS)
abstract: Modern radars have high resolution and produce multiple measurements from each target in a measurement cycle. Clustering radar measurements is a significant and challenging problem. Utilizing Doppler information is an effective method to improve clustering accuracy, while the presence of the microDoppler effect could significantly affect the clustering accuracy. In this paper, a two-step clustering algorithm is proposed to group micro-Doppler measurements with those from the target body, accounting for tire position constraints and maximizing range rate likelihood. Matlab simulated results demonstrate that our proposed method significantly reduces computation time by 99 % while improving overall clustering accuracy by 2 % compared to our previous clustering approach.

title: Graph Neural Network Decoding of Surface Codes with Diagonally Correlated Two-Qubit Z Errors
authors: Yinghui Ge, Shuoying Wang, Mengxin Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Computer and Information Processing Technology (ISCIPT)
abstract: Fault-tolerant quantum computing critically relies on quantum error correction. We study surface-code decoding with diagonally correlated two-qubit $\mathbf{Z}$ errors, a structured noise model that breaks assumptions leveraged by MinimumWeight Perfect Matching (MWPM). We develop a graph neural network (GNN) decoder based on learned message passing and benchmark it against a tuned MWPM baseline informed by the same noise statistics. In code-capacity simulations at code distances 3, 5, and 7, the GNN achieves consistently lower logical error rates than MWPM across the tested range of pair-error probabilities. The GNN correction threshold is about 2.5%, surpassing the 2.4% achieved by the MWPM baseline. These results indicate that data-driven message passing can adapt to complex, geometry-dependent noise without hand-crafted correlation models, thereby reducing reliance on manual model specification for quantum error correction.

title: The Design and Implementation of Interactive Games Based on Unity3D
authors: Jizheng He
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: With the rise of games as the "ninth art" and the diversified development of interactive entertainment forms, creating a deep immersive experience has become one of the core goals of game design. However, existing interactive games often face problems such as insufficient interaction depth, fragmented narratives, and poor immersion, which limit the player's experience. To address this challenge, this study takes the immersive interactive game "Identity: Unknown" developed with the Unity3D engine as the research object, focusing on the optimization effect of interaction design on the player's immersion. By constructing a narrative framework centered on "a protagonist with amnesia exploring a closed room", core modules such as environmental physical interaction, multi-step item triggering, dynamic audio-visual effects, and exploratory plot were realized. The study innovatively adopted environmental narrative techniques (such as connecting the plot through interactive music players, tapes, cameras, etc.), and designed a control experiment to verify the effectiveness of interaction design: inviting 20 players to participate in two sets of control tests (simplified interaction version vs complete interaction version), and conducting quantitative analysis of satisfaction ratings. The results show that the optimized interaction design (such as layered sound effects, dynamic lighting, multi-step item interaction) significantly improved immersion scores, narrative coherence, and operational smoothness, proving that refined interaction elements can effectively enhance the immersive experience of the game. This study provides a quantifiable optimization path for interactive game design.

title: LFC of Two-Area Hybrid Power System Using AEPSO-Based PID Controller
authors: Alpana Barman, Souvik Dutta, Parimal Acharjee, Omkar Yadav, Aashish Kumar Bohre
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: To prevent issues like load-shedding and blackouts caused by unmanaged Frequency Deviations (FD), a power system must be designed to handle fluctuations and changing load demands effectively. For successful Load Frequency Control (LFC), it is essential to have precisely adjusted controllers that can minimize frequency fluctuations, including both overshoots and undershoots, as well as reduce the settling time. To mitigate frequency deviations and enhance the performance of a two-area power system, a Proportional-Integrative-Derivative (PID) controller optimized using Adaptive Exponential Particle Swarm Optimization (AEPSO) is proposed. The analysis involves a two-area interconnected hybrid power system, which includes thermal, nuclear, hydro, and wind turbines while taking into account physical limitations such as generation rate constraints (GRC) and governor dead band (GDB). The proposed controller's performance is compared with a linear PSO-optimized PID controller under a range of load conditions. Simulation results show that, compared to the linear approach commonly used in existing literature, the proposed control method yields substantial improvements in all areas.

title: A Brain-Inspired Intelligent Control Approach for Grid-Connected Hybrid Solar-Wind Energy Systems
authors: Kothapally Sanjeev, K. H Phani Shree
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Due to their intrinsic variability and unpredictability, photovoltaic (PV) along with wind energy integration into the power grid poses operational issues. Complexity of a grid-connected hybrid solar-wind energy system is addressed in this paper by suggesting the deployment of a Brain Emotional Learning-Based Intelligent Controller (BELBIC). BELBIC, which draws inspiration from human emotional learning mechanisms, improves system robustness and adaptability in real-time decision-making in dynamic and uncertain environments. The controller independently controls power flow and system operations to achieve balance when there are fluctuations in generation and demand. It is shown through comparative and power quality than conventional Proportional Integral (PI) controllers as it dynamically adjusts to the changes in the system conditions. Additionally, it optimizes energy distribution over the hybrid system to facilitate renewable energy sources. Implementation of BELBIC in the hybrid renewable systems is a significant step forward in developing the intelligent control strategies for modern power system for reliable as well as sustainable integration of clean energy in the grid.

title: Application of electrical image enhancement technology in defect recognition using generative adversarial networks
authors: Zili Huang, Yuchen Zhao, Zongjin Guo, Wenduo Yu, Shanglin She, Shuo Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated approach for electrical image enhancement and defect recognition based on generative adversarial networks (GANs). Firstly, an image enhancement submodule based on the Pix2Pix structure was constructed. Through the joint optimization of adversarial training and pixel-level reconstruction, effective restoration of electrical image details and quality improvement were achieved. Subsequently, a defect recognition submodule based on a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) was designed, and the accuracy and robustness of defect detection were improved by utilizing multi-scale feature extraction and dual-channel fusion mechanism. The experiment was verified using the InsPLAD dataset. The results showed that the enhanced images had significant improvements in indicators such as PSNR and SSIM, and the defect recognition accuracy was improved by more than 6.5% compared with the original images. Ablation experiments further verified the key role of image enhancement, data augmentation and feature fusion strategies in improving overall performance.

title: Fuel-Efficient Safe and Secure Formation Flying in Commercial Air Traffic: Procedures, Sensor Fusion, and Communication Strategies
authors: Leonardus J.A. Jansen, Thomas Ewert, Thomas Strang
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Civil aviation has a significant impact on climate change, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions from this sector is a critical goal. One promising approach to mitigating emissions is the use of wake vortex uplift in formation flying. Initial tests by test pilots have demonstrated the general feasibility of this maneuver. However, for the execution of formation flying, the current safety separation distances between aircraft, as defined by ICAO, must be temporarily suspended. The current separation distances are designed for collision avoidance and specifically to mitigate risks associated with wake turbulence, which can pose significant dangers to aircraft, crew, and passengers. To integrate formation flying into routine civil aviation operations, new procedures are required. These procedures must ensure the efficient utilization of wake vortex effects in formation flying while maintaining current safety standards. Currently, no such procedures exist. We propose a six-phase procedure to address the absence of such protocols and identify key challenges that must be overcome to enable the safe and efficient use of wake vortices in formation flying. The proposed procedure requires only minimal modifications to existing ICAO regulations, making it feasible for rapid integration into current air traffic management systems. Our solution involves several key components: sharing and negotiating adjusted flight plans, utilizing and fusing multiple types of sensors during the flight, and sharing the data collected by these sensors. For effective communication of flight plans, a high-throughput air-to-ground datalink is necessary. Additionally, for using and real-time sharing sensor data, a secure, low-latency air-to-air data link between formation partners is required, a technology that is currently unavailable. We define specific requirements for these datalink systems at various stages of the proposed procedure using heuristic values to guide the design of the communication infrastructure. By combining the proposed formation flying phases, sensor fusion strategies, and the necessary data link requirements, we present a novel framework for integrating formation flying into civil aviation operations.

title: Mask Detection for Smart Tourism: Enhancing Yolov5s with CBAM to Improve Public Safety in Tourist Attractions
authors: Shun Luo, Caihong Li, Zhiwen Chen, Yi Yang, Xiangquan Gui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: Real-time mask monitoring in public places is crucial for ensuring public safety, especially in the tourism industry where large crowds are common. Traditional detection methods rely heavily on manual annotation of target regions and feature points, resulting in low efficiency, high error rates, and limited real-world applicability. To address these issues, we propose an improved face mask detection approach based on deep learning, specifically tailored for tourism scenarios requiring intelligent monitoring of tourists' mask-wearing behavior.The proposed method is built upon the lightweight YOLOv5s object detection framework, enhanced with the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) to improve feature extraction and model adaptability. We trained and tested the model on a large-scale dataset of face and mask images. Experimental results show that our model outperforms the baseline YOLOv5s in detection accuracy, robustness, and inference speed, meeting the real-time requirements of public venues. Specifically, YOLOv5s-CBAM improves mean Average Precision <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{m A P})$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{7 5. 4 \%}$</tex> and Precision to 86.8 %, achieving increases of 5.1 % and 8.1 % respectively over the original YOLOv5s, without significantly reducing detection speed. Comparative experiments with multiple models further confirm that our method achieves a favorable balance between accuracy and efficiency, validating its applicability in smart tourism scenarios.

title: Modeling and Control of Single-Phase PLL using Enhanced Extended State Observer
authors: Vinay Kumar Singh, Narayana Prasad Padhy, Yogesh V. Hote
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This article introduces modeling and control framework for a single-phase, Phase-Locked Loop (SP-PLL) using an Enhanced Extended State Observer (EESO) controller. The proposed work improves the robustness and Grid synchronization of Grid Following Inverters (GFLI). Quadrature signal generator employs second-order harmonic elimination technique, using Dynamic Double Frequency Feedback (DDFF) signal to generate direct-quadrature axis (two-phase) signals. Initially, single-phase voltage signal is converted into two orthogonal components in stationary frame of reference i.e., in αβ, then using proposed method it is transformed into the synchronous reference frame (dq). Proposed EESO based observer controller effectively eliminates the double frequency oscillations, rejects the disturbances in real time; compared to conventional PI-controlled SRF-PLL. Furthermore, the proposed approach is simple in design, faster in implementation and it is favourable for real time engineering applications. The effectiveness of the proposed work is demonstrated through both simulation and experimental validations.

title: Short-Circuit Analysis of Droop-Controlled Islanded AC Microgrids
authors: Ghanshyam Meena, Tarun Varshney, Akhilesh Mathur, V. P. Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The study provides a unique Δ-circuit technique for rapid calculations of short-circuit currents in large microgrid (MG) networks supplied by inverter-based distributed generators (IBDGs), employing virtual impedance current limiters (VICLs). The Δ-circuit approach is widely used for calculating short-circuit currents in electrical networks due to its efficiency and ease of execution. However, the normal Δ-circuit is unsuited for islanded MGs because of their unique features, such as the lack of a slack bus. This method ensures precise simulations and fast computational performance while being applicable to various fault types, including single-line, two-line, and three-line faults. This approach is validated using MATLAB Simulink on a 6-bus test network of an islanded MG. The findings enhance the understanding of fault behavior in droop-controlled islanded AC microgrids and contribute to developing effective protection measures.

title: Explainable Machine Learning for Environment-Aware Channel State Prediction in UAV-Based 6G Networks
authors: Ladan Gholami, Pietro Ducange, Arcangela Rago, Pietro Cassará, Alberto Gotta
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The emergence of 6G networks demands environment-aware communication paradigms to ensure reliable and efficient connectivity, and Channel Knowledge Maps (CKMs) offer a promising solution by mapping spatial locations to detailed channel characteristics for proactive network optimization. In this context, this paper proposes an explainable Machine Learning (ML)-based framework that uses geometrical features to predict receiver state probabilities in UAV-based mmWave communication networks. Geometrical characteristics extracted from the environment surrounding each receiver are used to train ML models, namely Decision Tree (DT), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Deep Neural Network (DNN) models, to predict three receiver states probabilities: Line-of-Sight (LOS), No-Line-of-Sight (NLOS), and Blocked. Experimental results show that the DNN model outperforms DT and KNN, achieving higher accuracy across all states, albeit with no inherent explainability. To address this, the SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) method is applied to indicate feature contributions to each state prediction of the black-box DNN model. This improves the interpretability and reliability of the proposed environment-aware framework for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 G}$</tex> UAV-based networks.

title: Research Progress on Myopia Control Based on Eyeball Wall Tissue
authors: Siqi Li, He Wen, Tuoyu Ju, Qiuyang Deng, Hangze Song, Zuobin Wang, Weijun Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: In recent years, myopia has become a global public health issue, with its incidence rate continuously rising worldwide. Researchers generally believe that myopia is the result of the combined effect of environmental factors and genetic risk factors. As a precisely regulated optical system, the eye's in-depth exploration of its composition and structure is of great significance for clarifying the pathogenesis of myopia and provides key theoretical support for myopia treatment. This article expounds the changes in the ocular tissue structure during the onset of myopia, as well as the relevant approaches in the fields of micro-nano visual optics and ophthalmology for controlling the onset and progression of myopia, hoping that this review can contribute to the development of new myopia treatment strategies and drugs.

title: Fault Localization in DG-Integrated Radial Distribution Network Using ANN-Enhanced Impedance Method
authors: Abhilash Asit Kumar Majhi, Sanjeeb Mohanty
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Fault localization is a critical challenge in the operation and maintenance of distributed generation (DG)-integrated radial distribution networks. This paper proposes a fault localization approach that combines Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) with two-ended impedance-based method to enhance precision and reliability. The ANN is used for estimating during-fault load currents at unmonitored buses, which are essential inputs for impedance-based method. The ANN model is trained using dataset generated from simulated fault scenarios, considering various fault types and locations across the network. Performance evaluation of multiple ANN training algorithms revealed that the Bayesian Regularization (BR) algorithm achieves the required accuracy. The impedance-based method, augmented with ANN-estimated load currents, is employed to accurately identify both the faulty section and the fault distance. The proposed method is validated on DG-integrated IEEE 33 bus radial distribution network modelled using MATLAB/Simulink, demonstrating superior accuracy and efficiency compared to conventional methods.

title: Enhanced Solar Irradiance Forecasting Using Hybrid Models and Image Processing*
authors: Rajat, Banalaxmi Brahma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Accurate short-term solar irradiance forecasting is essential for optimizing solar energy systems and enhancing the reliability of renewable energy. This study evaluates and compares various forecasting models, including Linear Regression, Random Forest, Optimized Random Forest, XGBoost, LSTM, GRU, and a novel LSTM-GRU hybrid model. Key performance metrics, Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> were employed to assess the predictive accuracy and variance explanation of these models over 5-minute, 10-minute, and 15-minute intervals. The LSTM-GRU hybrid model consistently outperformed all baseline methods. Integration of features extracted from sky images along with time-series data further improved model performance, especially for advanced methods like XGBoost, Optimized Random Forest, and the LSTM-GRU hybrid model. This study emphasizes the importance of temporal data integration and enhanced feature representations to enhance forecasting dependability. The results highlight how hybrid approaches may be used to tackle the challenges of solar irradiance forecasting, opening the door to more precise and effective renewable energy solutions.

title: Comparative Study of Various 4x1 MUX using Different Logic Families
authors: Shambhavi Awasthi, Deep Chandra Upadhyay, M. Suresh, Ankur Beohar, Manas Ranjan Tripathy
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: A multiplexer is a fundamental combinational circuit that finds its use in various digital circuits. It has uses in a variety of domains, including data routing, communication systems, and computing where efficient and reliable data management is critical. Till now a lot of Multiplexer circuits have been considered and made. We have performed analytical and comparative study of propagation delay for various $\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x} \mathbf{1}$ MUX designs implemented using various logic families, including CMOS, PTL, CPL, and TGL. Using the GPDK-90 nm kit and the cadence tool, the circuits are designed in the Virtuoso platform. The circuits are effectively created, modelled, and analyzed for a number of factors, such as area (transistor count) and speed of operation (delay), and the best designs that meet the specified requirements are ultimately identified.

title: Design and Development of a Microstrip Patch Monopole Antenna for 3.4 GHz Spectrum with Forensic Electromagnetic Detection Applications
authors: Zakir Ali, Vinod Kumar Singh, Adya Sharma, Anu Singla, Neha Ahirwar, Shashi Shekhar
abstract: This paper presents the design, simulation, and the performance characteristics of a microstrip patch monopole antenna at 3.4 GHz. The antenna is intended to have very wide frequency range of 1200 – 9400 MHz to suit the expanding demand for communication systems that should be in different frequency bands. The suggested antenna offers a low profile and a small size suitable for the current communication devices. For the desired broad banding, the design process involves fine tuning of critical parameters, which includes, ground dimensions, patch dimensions, substrate parameters, and feed configuration. Analysis of the performance of the antenna is done and checked with the help of electromagnetic simulation solvers called CST Were variables like S-parameters, radiation pattern was taken into consideration as well as Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR).These results show how effectively the designed antenna is able to cover entire 3.4GHz band with a stable and efficient radiation pattern over a wide bandwidth. This obtained bandwidth of 1.2 GHz to 9.4 GHz shows that the proposed antenna is suitable for wide frequency range operations like cognitive radio, satellite communication and wireless communication. Due to compact size and ease of installation they are suited to be installed in areas of limited space.

title: Power Grid Upgrade Scheme under Clean Power Access Based on Multi-objective Optimization Algorithm
authors: Lei Dai, Guifen Jiang, Yuming Shen, Xu Gui, Jiayin Xu, Hao Yang, Xudong Hu
abstract: Based on the prominent problems of grid node voltage over-limit and line overload risks under the background of large-scale access of clean power sources, and the poor economic efficiency of traditional expansion plans, this study aims to design a grid upgrade plan optimization method that takes into account economic cost and safety and stability. First, a multi-objective optimization model with the goals of minimizing the total upgrade cost, minimizing the node voltage deviation, and optimizing the line load balance is constructed. The constraints include node voltage safety limits, line capacity restrictions, and topological connectivity. Secondly, in view of the lack of convergence and distribution of the NSGA-II algorithm when solving high-dimensional power grid problems, an adaptive crossover mutation probability mechanism is introduced and the congestion calculation strategy is improved. Finally, a simulation scenario with a high proportion of distributed photovoltaic and wind power access is constructed based on the IEEE 33-node system, and the improved NSGA-II algorithm is used to coordinately optimize and solve the combination of transformer expansion, line capacity increase, and reactive compensation device site selection and capacity determination. While reducing the average total investment cost to 3.21 million yuan, the optimization scheme reduces the voltage over-limit rate to 1.72%, and the number of overloaded lines is reduced to 1 at the minimum. The proposed algorithm can effectively coordinate the economic and technical aspects of power grid upgrades, and provide a quantitative decision-making basis for the adaptive transformation of power grids with a high proportion of clean energy access.

title: Performance Evaluation of an Indigenous Density Matrix Quantum Computer Simulator for Scalable Workloads
authors: Girish Belani, Pavan Kumar Kasina, Mirza Zuber Baig, Abhijith Tej Vaddeboina, Vivek Nainwal, Anoop Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: The superiority of Quantum algorithms over classical algorithms, wherein the quantum algorithms can provide an exponential speedup, is a well-proven phenomenon. Quantum computing simulations on classical computers are of utmost importance in preparing the research community for the quantum computing revolution, designing new algorithms, and validating the results obtained from the quantum hardware. This paper demonstrates the performance benchmarking results of the indigenously developed density-matrix-based quantum computing simulator QSim (qctoolkit.in). We have adopted a framework called “Application-Oriented Performance Benchmarks for Quantum Computing” for the benchmarking procedure and modified it for our cause. We evaluated the performance of the simulator on CPU, GPU, and the Vector Accelerator by running the quantum algorithms with varying numbers of qubits in each cycle, with and without the insertion of noise parameters, to evaluate various metrics. The results obtained will provide the performance aspects of the simulator on the described platforms.

title: Solitary Chaotic Semiconductor Laser Diode for Parallel Random Number Generation and Optical Decision Making_supp1-3638423.docx
authors: Fei Wang
abstract: Optical chaos is crucial in various applications, such as image encryption, secure communications, anti-jamming sensing, light detection and ranging, and reinforcement learning. External optical feedback represents the predominant configuration in laser diode chaos applications. However, various fixed external cavities introduce significant time delay signatures. The previously reported self-chaotic laser effectively addresses this issue; however, its utilization is limited due to the restricted number of output modes. In this paper, we propose a solitary chaotic comb source based on multimode interaction in a laser diode, providing 173 chaotic comb lines within a 100 nm spectral range, with a channel effective bandwidth of up to 8.4 GHz. The channels cross-correlation is consistently below 0.08, satisfying the orthogonality criteria. This scheme can generate an offline random number sequence with an expected data throughput of 32 Tbits/s and can resolve at least 256 multi-armed bandit issues. We have successfully opened a new way to develop low-cost, massively integrated, parallel chaotic comb sources, and this technology possesses the potential to revolutionize entire chaotic application systems.

title: Reconstruction Enhanced Prototype Network for Hyperspectral Image Open-Set Classification
authors: Ruijie Xu, Jiayu Yu, Xianghai Cao, Jing Zhao, Licheng Jiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: With the gradual maturity of deep learning technology and its extensive application in the field of remote sensing, hyperspectral image classification technology has made tremendous progress. The existing methods can achieve excellent classification performance in a closed-set environment (CSE), where the class distribution of the training and test set is consistent. However, in the open environment of the real world, many samples in the test set belong to the classes that never appear in the training set. Therefore, when unknown samples are present, existing closed-set classification methods will predict them as one of the known classes and cannot identify the unknown samples. Open Set Recognition (OSR) aims to solve this problem by simultaneously identifying unknown classes and distinguishing known classes. In this paper, we propose a reconstruction-enhanced prototype network (RePro) for HSI open-set classification. Specifically, the prototypes are constructed for each class in the embedding space, and the classification loss is also introduced to make the samples closer to the prototype of each class. Then the reconstruction loss based on L1 is adopted to fully exploit the spectral-spatial information of training samples to provide the auxiliary information to identify the samples of unknown classes. Finally,the reconstruction loss and prototype distance are combined to identify samples of unknown classes. Experiments on multiple datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Secure Q-Learning of Fuzzy Markov Jump Systems Under Malicious Attacks: A Homotopic Scheme
authors: Hao Shen, Zheng Huang, Jiacheng Wu, Jing Wang, Michael V. Basin
abstract: This article proposes a novel reinforcement learning (RL)-based secure control policy for nonlinear Markov jump systems (MJSs) subject to false data injection attacks (FDIAs). First, the Takagi–Sugeno (T–S) fuzzy model is applied to describe the nonlinear MJS. A min–max strategy and an off-policy homotopic Q-learning (HQ) scheme are then introduced to design a secure control policy without requiring knowledge of the system dynamics. The proposed approach offers two main advantages: it does not require an initial stabilizing control gain, and it guarantees unbiased learning under persistently excited conditions. Furthermore, a rigorous stability analysis of the overall closed-loop system under FDIAs is presented. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed approach is demonstrated using a tunnel diode circuit.

title: Direct Uplink Connectivity in Space MIMO Systems With THz and FSO Intersatellite Links
authors: Zohre Mashayekh Bakhsh, Yasaman Omid, Gaojie Chen, Yi Ma, Farbod Kayhan, Rahim Tafazolli
abstract: This article investigates uplink transmission from a single-antenna mobile phone to a cluster of satellites, emphasizing the role of intersatellite links (ISLs) in cooperative signal detection. We study nonideal ISLs, focusing on terahertz (THz) and free-space optical (FSO) links with respect to ergodic capacity. A scenario based on the recent 3GPP standard specifies the frequency band, bandwidth, antenna gains, power levels, and channel characteristics for nonterrestrial networks. We also propose a satellite selection method to identify the optimal master node for signal processing, considering both the user–satellite link and ISL channels. For THz ISLs, we derive a closed-form capacity approximation under instantaneous or statistical channel state information, while for FSO ISLs, we present a closed-form approximate upper bound incorporating pointing error loss. We further assess the impact of ISL frequency and pointing errors on spectral efficiency. Simulations show that multisatellite multiple-input multiple-output communications significantly outperforms single-satellite systems, and that the proposed upper bound closely matches Monte Carlo results.

title: Machine Learning-Based Prediction of Gas Discharge Electrode Structures Using Electroacoustic Signals
authors: Shiyu Lu, Yiheng Li, Shuai Jiang, Jingcong Wang, Yi Luo, Xuekai Pei
abstract: The accurate identification of electrode structures is critical for diagnosing discharges caused by insulation defects in power systems. This article proposes a machine learning-based diagnostic framework that links electroacoustic signatures to electrode geometries. A configurable discharge platform is developed, incorporating three power types (pulsed, dc, and ac) and eight electrode configurations to simulate common defect scenarios. Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and Hamming-windowed short-time Fourier transform (STFT) extract structure-sensitive acoustic features. Four classification models—deep neural network (DNN), convolutional neural network (CNN), k-nearest neighbor (KNN), and support vector machine (SVM)—are benchmarked using accuracy and F1 score. The DNN model achieves the highest prediction accuracy, enabling precise recognition of discharge source geometry. The proposed method offers a data-driven alternative to traditional physics-based modeling, supporting condition assessment and defect localization in high-voltage (HV) insulation systems. This approach enhances real-time monitoring capabilities and shows strong potential for industrial applications.

title: Implications of Public Charging Stations with Pay-Per-Use Service Mode on Electric Vehicle Adoption_supp1-3637399.doc
authors: Wei Yan
abstract: Although many researchers have found that EV adoption depends heavily on charging infrastructure, few studies have investigated whether and how additional public charging stations operating under the Pay-Per-Use (PPU) mode affect EV adoption. In this mode, consumers pay for usage but do not obtain ownership of the product. To fill this gap, we develop two theoretical models in which a manufacturer sells EVs and private charging piles, while an independent operator provides public charging stations via the PPU mode. We confirm that the entry of public charging stations improves EV adoption. However, contrary to conventional wisdom, our analysis reveals that, although the PPU mode reduces the optimal quantity of private charging piles, it may increase private charging piles' optimal prices and profits. Moreover, decreasing the operational costs of public charging stations benefits the manufacturer and consumers but may not always be profitable for the operator. To assess the robustness of our findings, we extend the models to two scenarios: including multiple EV manufacturers and considering consumer waiting at public charging stations. Besides confirming our main results, the extensions yield two additional findings: (i) As the number of manufacturers in the market increases, the operator's profits decrease. (ii) Consumer waiting costs, dependent on the proportion of public charging infrastructure, negatively affect the public charging and EV markets while benefiting the private charging pile market.

title: TCNet: Topological Consistency Network for Hyperspectral and Multispectral Image Fusion
authors: Changda Xing, Meiling Wang, Yongchang Xu, Cheng Wang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The fusion of hyperspectral images (HSIs) and multispectral images (MSIs) has been widely focused in the field of remote sensing image processing. Traditional fusion approaches have no consideration of the topological consistency between the target high-resolution HSI (HR-HSI) and the input HSI/MSI. To remedy such deficiency, in this letter, we propose a novel topological consistency network (TCNet) for HSI and MSI fusion. Specifically, two degradation models are firstly constructed to form the spatial mapping between the input HSI and the target HR-HSI as well as the spectral mapping between the MSI and the HR-HSI. With this way, the basic observation model is formulated. The spectral topological consistency loss and spatial topological consistency loss are then established by imposing graph construction on spectral vectors and spatial features, which are added into the basic observation model to acquire the overall loss of TCNet. Thirdly, the gradient descent based optimization strategy is designed to obtain the solutions of the overall loss and determine the final fusion mapping network. Extensive experiments have been implemented to validate that the proposed TCNet method achieves more competitive performance compared with several state-of-the-art approaches.

title: QMIP: Enhancing Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Coordination Through Macro Intention Prediction
authors: Yongzheng Cui, Biao Luo, Rui Tang, Chunhua Yang, Weihua Gui
abstract: The efficacy of the Centralized Training and Decentralized Execution (CTDE) framework in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) is fundamentally limited by the divergence between globally optimal strategies and agents’ local, often myopic, decisions during execution. This inconsistency frequently traps agents in local dilemmas, undermining team-level performance. We introduce QMIP, a new MARL method that directly confronts this challenge by explicitly aligning individual policies with a shared team goal. At the core of QMIP is the Macro Intention Prediction (MIP) module, which pioneers the use of a multi-head self-attention network to infer a dynamic, teamwide macro-intention. This intention acts as a powerful corrective signal, guiding agents to escape local optima and fostering robust, coherent collaboration. An average intent loss is designed to ensure stable and effective training of the MIP module. On challenging benchmarks including SMAC, GRF, and MPE, QMIP demonstrates superior performance, substantially outperforming current state-of-the-art methods in both convergence and final win rates. The pivotal role of the MIP module is confirmed through rigorous ablation studies. QMIP not only sets a new performance benchmark but also provides a novel architectural paradigm for developing highly coordinated intelligent agent systems.

title: Arbitrarily Small Execution-Time Certificate: What was Missed in Analog Optimization
authors: Liang Wu, Ambrose Adegbege, Yongduan Song, Richard D. Braatz
abstract: Numerical optimization (solving optimization problems using digital computers) currently dominates but has three drawbacks: high energy consumption, poor scalability, and lack of an execution time certificate. To address these challenges, this article explores the recent resurgence of analog computers, proposing a novel paradigm of arbitrarily small execution-time-certified analog optimization (solving optimization problems via analog computers). To achieve ultra-low energy consumption, this paradigm transforms optimization problems into ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and leverages the ability of analog computers to naturally solve ODEs (no need for time discretization) in physically real time. However, this transformation can fail if the optimization problem, such as the general convex nonlinear programs (NLPs) considered in this article, has no feasible solution. To avoid transformation failure and enable infeasibility detection, we introduce the homogeneous monotone complementarity problem formulation for convex NLPs. To achieve scalability and an execution time certificate, this article introduces the Newton-based fixed-time-stable scheme for the transformed ODE, whose settling time $T_{p}$ can be prescribed by choosing the ODE's time coefficient as $k=\frac{\pi }{2T_{p}}$. This equation certifies that the settling time (execution time) is independent of the dimension of the optimization problems and can be arbitrarily small if the analog computer allows.

title: Managing Interplant Competition in Prickly Pear Cactus Fields Using Microwave Technology
authors: Euzeli C. dos Santos, Josinaldo Lopes Araujo Rocha, Anielson dos Santos Souza, Fabiano Salvadori, Isaac Soares de Freitas
abstract: Microwave-based weed control offers a sustainable alternative to chemical herbicides. This study investigates the feasibility of applying microwave technology for selective weed management in prickly pear cactus plantations, with a focus on minimizing thermal damage to the crop while maximizing weed suppression. A chamber–waveguide device operating at 2.45 GHz was used under controlled conditions to evaluate plant physiological responses, heating dynamics, and optimal orientation for energy delivery. Comparative energy analyses were conducted between the proposed solar-powered autonomous microwave system and traditional tractor-based herbicide application. This analysis reveals that the traditional method requires substantially higher energy input than the proposed microwave-based approach, while relying exclusively on nonrenewable fossil resources. Indeed, the energy embodied in herbicide production, transportation, and tractor-based application contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and environmental degradation. On the other hand, the proposed system is powered by solar energy, a renewable and locally accessible resource that avoids the environmental burdens associated with fossil fuels.

title: Rapid Detection of Multiple Chemical Residues in Pure Cotton Fabric Using Hyperspectral Imaging and Deep Learning
authors: Rongchang Jiang, Dandan Qu, Ke Wang, Guijie Liu, Xianzhen Dou, Shuren Lu, Shijie Xie, Wanzhi Wen, Anchang Xu, Bo Liang
abstract: This study introduces a rapid and non-destructive method for detecting multiple chemical residues in pure cotton fabrics, utilizing hyperspectral imaging, discrete wavelet transform (DWT), and a one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D-CNN) to address limitations of traditional techniques, which have low efficiency and destructive nature. Initially, spectral data were collected from pure cotton fabric samples using a hyperspectral imaging system operating within the 400–1000 nm wavelength range , with each sample yielding one averaged spectrum from 100 pixels. The dataset was split 75:25 for training (9,000 spectra) and testing (3,000 spectra), using stratified sample-wise partitioning to prevent spectral leakage. Subsequently, DWT was applied for data dimensionality reduction, eliminating redundant information while retaining critical spectral characteristics. An optimized 1D-CNN model was developed to automatically extract spectral features and classify multiple residues, including formaldehyde, 4-aminobiphenyl, nonylphenol, melamine, and ethanol. The experimental findings demonstrated that the DWT preserved high information entropy (13.02) even after dimensionality reduction to 75 features. Furthermore, its computational efficiency significantly surpassed that of competitive adaptive reweighted sampling and kernel principal component analysis. In conjunction with DWT for dimensionality reduction, the 1D-CNN model achieved an overall classification accuracy of 99.76% and an F1 score of 0.99, exceeding the performance of the support vector machine and random forest models by 2.03% and 38.53%, respectively. This methodology facilitates non-destructive and rapid detection, achieving over 50% increase in detection speed while maintaining high accuracy in identifying formaldehyde residue. It represents an effective technological solution for ensuring textile quality and safety. Future work will focus on designing lightweight network architectures, implementing data augmentation strategies, and expanding the model’s applicability to detect multiple pollutants, aiming to enhance its practical deployment and generalization capability.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based IT-2 Fuzzy Fractional-Order Sliding Mode Control for Leader-Follower Formation Tracking of Flexible-Joint Robots
authors: G. Narayanan, Sangmoon Lee, Sangtae Ahn
abstract: This study presents a reinforcement learning-based interval type-2 (IT-2) fuzzy formation tracking control strategy for leader-follower flexible joint robots (FJRs), addressing challenges arising from nonlinearities, unmodeled dynamics, and unknown external disturbances. The proposed approach employs fractional-order sliding mode control (FOSMC) to guarantee finite-time convergence of the tracking error with rigorously proven stability. Unlike conventional backstepping methods, the IT-2 fuzzy FOSMC framework effectively addresses uncertainties and disturbances. By considering the memory effect of fractional calculus, a Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation for the formation tracking dynamics is derived using an auxiliary system and equivalent transformation. A novel cost function based on the derivative of the formation tracking error is introduced, resulting in a discounted cost that accounts for the Laplacian matrix <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\widehat{L}$</tex-math></inline-formula> under a performance constraint. The optimal cost function and formation sliding mode control policy are shown to be gradually approximable via policy iteration. To achieve intelligent near-optimal control, a reinforcement learning algorithm based on an actor-critic neural network architecture is implemented, enabling all agents to compensate for system uncertainties and maintain formation tracking with the leader. Lyapunov stability analysis confirms that all follower FJRs can track the leader using actor-critic update laws for neural network weights, with distributed tracking error designs ensuring convergence to optimal values. Simulation results validate the proposed approach, demonstrating reduced chattering, improved formation tracking, and enhanced robustness.
