title: Resonator Based on a Single ZnO Nanorod
authors: Vladimir G. Krishtop, Maria V. Evstafieva, Rashid R. Fakhrtdinov, Maxim A. Knyazev, Eugene E. Yakimov, Victor Koledov, Irek I. Musabirov, Andrey P. Orlov, Svetlana von Gratowski, Vitaly I. Korepanov
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: We investigated the growth conditions of ZnO nanorod arrays using the gas-phase chemical synthesis technology and we fabricated ZnO nanorod arrays. The nanorod arrays were characterized using electron microscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray diffractometry. We fabricated acoustic resonators based on single ZnO nanorod suspended between electrodes. We used modern electron lithography and FIB methods for the fabricating. The developed technique allows us to form practically significant devices on single ZnO nanorods, such as high-frequency resonators, promising for use in acoustooptics.

title: Design and Implementation of Conditional Transition Reduction Data Encoding for VLSI Power Optimization
authors: Sumeet Singh Sarpal, Suman Sau, Madhur Grover, Malatesh Akkur, Ajit Kumar, Muthiah M A
abstract: This proposed approach is an advancement over the current Upper-Lower Inversion approach. In order to constantly select the scenario that optimizes the loss of energy, the suggested method makes use of conditionally inverted strategies, such as Lower bit inversion, Upper-Lower bit inversion, and Upper bit inverted. This technology improves system effectiveness by lowering the amount of transition on interconnection buses, which results in significant electrical benefits. Through careful hardware optimization, the encoder design reduces latency and helps preserve fixed power. Research comparing the suggested technique to more conventional approaches reveals that it uses fewer resources and causes less delay than XOR-XNOR, Even-Odd inverting, and the earlier Upper-Lower Inverted technique with a predicted overall performance of around 96%.

title: Tourist-Tourist Interaction in Experience Co-Creation by Chinese Outbound Tourists: The Role of Cultural Operant Resources
authors: Xing Han, Carolus L. C. Praet, Liyong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: This study empirically explores the impact of personality, motivation, and operant resources on tourist-tourist interaction (TTI) in the co-creation of tourism experiences. A mixed-methods approach was adopted by first conducting qualitative interviews of 42 Chinese tourists to Japan and then using structural equation modeling (SEM) to analyze results of a quantitative survey among 300 Chinese tourists who had visited Japan. Extraversion is positively connected to social interaction as a motivation to travel and to physical operant resources, and these are also positively related to TTI. Extraversion was not related to cultural operant resources whereas cultural operant resources were negatively linked to TTI. Our results confirmed a positive impact of TTI on tourist satisfaction. Finally, Chinese culture may also explain a general reluctance to engage in TTI. The originality of this research lies in in its incorporation of Chinese cultural concepts to explain a general reluctance among Chinese tourists to engage in social interactions with strangers.

title: Performance Improvement of Solar Still Desalination System
authors: Sudhir Kumar Singh, Madhup Kumar Mittal, Deepak Sharma, Manish Kumar, Shubham Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: In coastal areas, solar desalination is an effective and cost-efficient approach for producing pure drinking water. A solar still works by using solar radiation as its primary heat source for the distillation process. As a result, water vapor is separated from contaminants in the salty, contaminated water within the basin. However, one major limitation of solar stills is their low distillate output. In this study, the water depth in the solar still’s basin was varied to assess its effect on performance. It was found that water depth significantly influenced the still’s efficiency, with a depth of 5 cm yielding the highest distillate production.

title: Enviro-Friendly BioSorbents for Energy Storage Applications: An Overview
authors: P. R. Chauhan, Ravita Lamba, Pranjali Sharma, S. K. Tyagi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Sustainable and energy-efficient energy storage systems are crucial in addressing current energy challenges. Biomass is increasingly recognized as a promising precursor for energy storage applications, particularly as activated carbon for supercapacitor electrodes. Therefore, the present study reviews existing literature on the synthesis of bio-adsorbents from waste biomass for energy storage purposes. It covers various strategies including single or multi-step physical or chemical activation for producing highly porous activated carbons and their composite materials, with a special focus on the impact of processing parameters such as carbonization temperature, heating rate, activating agent, activation time, activation temperature, and impregnation ratios on the electrochemical performance of supercapacitors. Additionally, a comprehensive comparison of the performance of recently developed bio-adsorbents is presented, based on specific capacitance values. The authors believe that this review contribution will offer valuable insights to future researchers, aiding in the development of more efficient and sustainable energy storage technologies.

title: Adaptive Mobility Control in LoRaWAN via Reinforcement Learning
authors: August F. Valentin, Simon K. Janum, F. Fernando Jurado-Lasso, Xenofon Fafoutis, Charalampos Orfanidis
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: Low-Power Wide Area Networks (LPWANs), such as LoRaWAN, are pivotal for large-scale IoT deployments. However, traditional stationary gateways (GWs) impose scalability and cost constraints. We propose an AI-driven mobile GW architecture that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to dynamically adapt GW mobility based on real-time network conditions. Our custom mobility module, integrated into OMNeT++ with FLoRa and TensorFlow Lite Micro, enables on-the-fly decision-making to optimize Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) and fairness. The results of the simulations show that the introduced RL-GW achieves up to 99.94 % PDR in high-fidelity simulations, outperforming static and heuristic mobile strategies. The RL policy generalizes robustly across network sizes and scenarios, offering a scalable, low-overhead solution for adaptive LPWAN infrastructure.

title: Towards a Serverless Intelligent Firewall: AI-Driven Security, and Zero-Trust Architectures
authors: Md Anisur Rahman Chowdhury, Hoang Nam Dang, Ronny Bazan-Antequera, Md. Sayham Khan, Md Razaul Karim, Sheheeda Manakkadu
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th International Conference on Cyber Security and Cloud Computing (CSCloud)
abstract: The stateful and transient nature of serverless computing environments presents significant challenges to traditional network security, particularly in implementing ZeroTrust Architecture (ZTA) principles. Rule-based intrusion detection systems and traditional firewalls tend to be inflexible and context-insensitive, with little ability to protect transient, stateless functions. This work proposes a Serverless Intelligent Firewall framework that combines deep learning-based intrusion detection with Zero-Trust enforcement for delivering adaptive, real-time threat detection in cloud-native systems. Drawing on the CICIDS2017 dataset, the novel approach employs a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model to capture temporal patterns in traffic behavior, thereby discovering thinly disguised anomalies and synchronized attacks that stateless models often miss. To address the inherent bias in class-imbalanced datasets, an undersampling approach was designed through preprocessing to mitigate model bias. The LSTM architecture achieved 98% accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, outperforming baseline models, including Decision Trees (DT), Support Vector Machines (SVM), and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). The results validate the efficacy of our suggested architecture in enabling innovative, scalable, and Zero-Trust-compliant security within serverless settings.

title: Modeling and Performance Analysis of a Fuel Cell System Under Pressure Variations
authors: Bansilal Bairwa, Sahebgouda, Santosh Byelle, Syed Faiz, Saad Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This study provides the evaluation and performance of the fuel cell system for the different pressures is presented. The investigation covers the electrical and thermal parameters as the current, voltage, power output, and temperature. The results show that, when increasing pressure from 2.50 bar to 5.00 bar, current increases from 8.26 A to 18.38 A, while voltage increases from 516.23 V to 1148.66 V, and power output increases from 4.26 kW to 21.11 kW, thus indicating significant improvement in energy conversion efficiency. Further, the operating temperature of the system exceeds from 21.49°C to 27.97°C, which shows the thermal impact of the increased pressure. Such findings gives us the insights for maximizing the performance of fuel cells for energy applications.

title: DeepRet: Residual Network for Effective Classification of Fundus Images
authors: Abir Deb Nath, Rapti Chaudhuri, Suman Deb
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Vision impairment and vision deteriorating diseases caused by diabetic condition is a growing problem around the world, particularly affecting individuals with prolonged, untreated diabetes. Early detection of diabetic retinopathy(DR) with computer aided systems and pro-active medical interventions can mitigate this problem. This paper explores the potential of CNN-based architectures for DR classification and proposes a unique residual network for effective classification of fundus images, which will enable edge computing systems to classify or grade fundus images. This paper tried to solve a persistent issue in research domain of fundus image processing in recent years, challenges like class imbalance of DR category in benchmark datasets. This has been done with selective down-sampling and blending of fundus images from multiple datasets. Smaller lesions like micronaneurysms are difficult to learn by neural networks because of less prominent spatial information and similarity to other healthy tissues. The proposed model achieves an average accuracy of $89 \%$ in multi-class DR classification. Image enhancement and removal of unnecessary background information has increased model performance and robustness to generalize across multi-ethnic data samples.

title: Fabrication of Hybrid Si Microwires-Holes Arrays for Emerging Applications
authors: Sadaf Saeed, Guo-Wei Lu, Anam Nigar, Kinza Arshad, Yiping Wang, Fozia Aslam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Manipulation, Manufacturing and Measurement on the Nanoscale (3M-NANO)
abstract: The fabrication of hybrid Si microwire-hole array Si(MWs-MH) arrays presents a novel approach for enhancing the performance of devices in various emerging applications, including sensors, photonics, and energy storage. This study investigates the design and fabrication of hybrid arrays that combine microwire structures with patterned holes using advanced lithographic techniques. The fabrication process involves precise deposition of metal layers followed by controlled etching to create arrays with customizable microwire geometries and hole distributions. The structural integrity and electrical, optical, and thermal properties of the hybrid arrays were characterized to assess their potential for novel applications. The results demonstrate that Si (MWs-MHs) hybrid structures exhibit significant improvements in device efficiency, sensitivity, and scalability. These findings provide new possibilities for the development of multifunctional materials and devices in areas such as environmental monitoring, optical communication, and energy harvesting.

title: Investigating the Effects of Irradiation on the Performance of Carbyne-Based Surface Acoustic Wave Sensors
authors: Mariya Aleksandrova, Rade Tomov, Danijel Danković, Vojkan S. Davidović, Srboljub Stanković
abstract: This study investigates the effects of irradiation on the performance of carbyne-based surface acoustic wave sensors for ethanol sensing. Carbyne, a carbon allotrope, shows promise in sensing applications, but its stability under radiation, relevant in nuclear and medical settings, is not investigated yet. SAW devices coated with carbyne-enriched films were exposed to 100 kRad of irradiation, and their ethanol-sensing performance was evaluated before and after exposure by measuring impedance, phase angle, resistance, capacitance, and signal response. After irradiation, a slight increase in impedance (approximately 1%) was observed across the frequency range, and the phase angle shifted, with a maximal deviation of approximately 10°. The contact resistance negligibly increased, while the interface capacitance decreased by almost one order of magnitude for some frequencies. Most importantly, the voltage difference between the output and the input signal increased from a 17 mV before irradiation to 172 mV after exposure to 100 kRad, indicating improved sensitivity. Results indicate that irradiation doesn't negatively impact sensor performance; in fact, it enhances sensitivity to ethanol. The study provides insights into the stability of carbyne coatings under harsh conditions and the reliability of carbyne-based SAW sensors following irradiation.

title: A Two-Stage MPPT Control Strategy For Standalone SPV System Based on FLC and VSG Control
authors: Amit Bharti, Harsh Wardhan Pandey, Md Irfan Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This work introduces the design and development of a stand-alone Solar Photovoltaic (SPV) system with Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) control. The system includes a PV array, MPPT controller, DC-DC boost converter, DC-AC inverter, and a Virtual Synchronous Generator (VSG) controller. A model of a PV array is introduced to study the impact of temperature and irradiance changes on power output. To boost the SPV system’s output to the desired DC link voltage, a DC-DC boost converter is employed. A Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC) for tracking the Maximum Power Point (MPP) is employed, wherein fuzzy rules provide the optimal duty cycle in response to different environmental conditions. A three-phase DC-AC inverter is used for converting the DC voltage to AC, and the VSG controller improves the inverter output to derive maximum power. The performance of the proposed system is tested under various load fluctuation conditions by using MATLAB/Simulink. Simulation results illustrate the robustness and efficiency of the developed control strategies to ensure stable operation and efficiency of the SPV system under dynamic loads.

title: Research on image synthesis algorithm based on depth generation model
authors: Shuangxin Yang, Dan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This research focuses on the innovative application of depth-generating models in image synthesis. A new algorithm named VGFNet (Variational Generative Flow Network) is proposed based on the fusion of three classical fundamental Models (variational autoencoder VAE, generative adversarial network GAN and Flow Models). Through in-depth analysis of the advantages and disadvantages of each basic model, we design a comprehensive new model that not only inherits the advantages of these basic models, but also shows significant advantages in the quality, diversity and computational efficiency of the generated images. VGFNet uses a novel feature extraction mechanism, in which the encoder part utilizes multi-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract deep features from input images, capable of capturing multi-level feature representations from low-level edges to high-level semantic information. At the same time, the flow model component processes latent variables through a series of reversible transformation layers, allowing the model to achieve accurate probability density estimates while maintaining efficient computation. This combination method not only enhances the learning ability of the model, but also improves the realism and diversity of the generated images. In terms of time series processing, although VGFNet is primarily optimized for static image generation tasks, the dynamic nature of its architecture also makes it possible to process data with a time dimension. For example, in application scenarios involving video frame generation or continuous image sequences, VGFNet can ensure visual consistency and coherence of the generated time-series images by imposing smoothing constraints on the underlying variables between successive frames. To verify the effectiveness of the new model, we conducted a series of rigorous experimental evaluations and compared them with current mainstream image synthesis methods. Experimental results show that VGFNet outperforms traditional methods on Inception Score (IS) and Frechet Inception Distance (FID), especially in high-resolution image synthesis and complex scene reconstruction tasks. The new model can provide more realistic and detailed image output. Therefore, the VGFNet proposed in this paper provides a new research idea and technical means for the field of image synthesis, and shows its great potential in practical application. Future research will further explore the potential of the model for processing time series data and its performance in a wider range of application scenarios.

title: Next Aircraft Hyperconnected System Platform
authors: Stéphane Poulain, Wolfgang Fischer, Fabian Maximilian Giertzsch
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: For future aircraft programs, ecological and economic sustainability will be one of the main design drivers. For the electronic systems on board such aircraft, this means on the one hand to minimize the footprint in terms of weight, power consumption, production and material efforts. On the other hand, following the general trends of digital transformation, the systems - and the aircraft in total - need to be much more intelligent and highly interconnected, enabling data-driven services on board and on ground for the whole aeronautic ecosystem, but potentially also beyond, e.g., to enable interaction with ground systems that are traditionally not part of the air transport system. This paper proposes an approach to meet these requirements by introducing a shared resources platform for power, processing, network and storage for aircraft electronics. With a focus on data management, the platform is composed of compute modules interconnected by Ethernetbased communication networks, namely IEEE TSN and Airbus AFDX. This approach enables an optimized implementation, with respect to design, production, operations and maintenance costs as well as environmental footprint, of functions across all design assurance levels. By introducing an updated version of the well-known ARINC 664 Part 5 security domain model, dataflows between trusted and untrusted entities and the increased attack surface due to the increased connectivity can be handled even more secure, while also aiming to comply with current security regulations such as CS25.1319 as well as Part-IS. In addition to low-level infrastructure features, the platform is complemented by a data-centric approach based on GAIA-X that allows decoupling hosted applications from each other while fostering a much better data exchange between them. This decoupling can also enable interaction between the aircraft and the ground to improve overall operation efficiency and to migrate function hosting from the aircraft to the ground. The viability of the platform is demonstrated by applying it to the refuelling process during the turnaround, integrating aircraft avionics, the electronic flight bag (EFB), the pilot, aircraft refueler and logging as well as accounting processes.

title: Agent-Based Modeling for Strategic Flight Delay Prediction in Multi-Layered Airport Network
authors: Shuce Wang, Minghua Hu, Xi Geng, Lei Yang
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: This study proposes a Multi-Layered Airport Network Dynamics Model (MANDM) to address strategic flight delay prediction in complex air traffic systems. Integrating an Agent-based Dynamic Airport Transfer Model (ADATM) for ground operations and a Fluid Queue Sector Network Model (FQSNM) for airspace dynamics, the framework simulates delay propagation through agent interactions and fluid queuing theory. ADATM captures granular state transitions of flights and airports, while FQSNM transforms discrete aircraft flows into continuum dynamics for scalable sector-level analysis. Validated on 11,452 Chinese flights, the model achieved precise predictions: individual flight departure/arrival delays averaged 2.32/2.31 minutes from actual values, with 1.2 minutes average deviations for the top 10 busiest airports. It identified systemic bottlenecks, such as capacity-driven delays at major hubs, and aligned congestion rankings for 17 of 21 critical sectors. The approach overcomes computational limitations of traditional methods, balancing operational granularity and efficiency for strategic scheduling. Future work will enhance adaptability to dynamic capacity fluctuations using machine learning.

title: Evaluation of fast charging protocols for battery pack module under natural convection cooling
authors: Alok Kumar Chaudhary, Vinod Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) are being seen as a crucial solution to address climate change and the rising gasoline price issue. However, one major limitation of electric vehicles that needs to be addressed is their long charging time. Fast charging methods have been introduced to overcome this issue. Nonetheless, fast charging has drawbacks, such as the gradual generation of heat that can influence battery performance and potentially contribute to long-term degradation. It is essential to develop strategies for safe, fast charging with less degradation. In this study, a numerical investigation was conducted to determine the optimal charging protocol for fast charging of a lithium-ion battery pack module equipped with an air-cooled thermal management system. The module was subjected to fast charging at different charging rates ranging from 1C to 7C using constant current-constant voltage (CC-CV) charging and pulse charging. Following the fast charging simulations using these protocols, the performance of these testing protocols is compared based on the time required to fully charge the battery pack module and the maximum temperature rise observed. The results indicated that the Pulse charging protocol performed better in terms of less temperature rise compared to the CC-CV charging protocols. On the other hand, CC-CV charging demonstrated good performance in terms of the time taken to fully charge the battery. Overall, this study contributes to understanding the role of charging protocols in managing battery thermal responses during fast charging and maintaining temperature within safe limits, which is an essential factor in addressing thermal, safety, and potential long-term degradation concerns.

title: Design and Simulation of Efficient Adders in 14nm FinFET Technology
authors: G Shailima, V Naveen Kumar, Ch Ganesh, Y Padma Sai, D Manikanta, G Harsha Vardhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th India Council International Subsections Conference (INDISCON)
abstract: Adders are crucial parts of arithmetic and data processing in contemporary digital circuits. As technology advances to more sophisticated nodes like 14 nm FinFET, there is a greater need than ever for fast and energy-efficient adders. Due to its enhanced switching speed and decreased leakage current, FinFET technology offers an excellent platform for creating high-performance circuits because of its exceptional control over short-channel effects. Design and analysis of certain high-speed adder architectures, such as ripple carry adders, carry look-ahead adders, carry select adders, and carry increment adders, on 14 nm FinFET technology using the Tanner tool are presented in this paper. The adder speed is enhanced, power consumption is minimized, and reliability is ensured even at low supply voltages by taking advantage of the three-dimensional gate structure of FinFETs. Simulation outputs reflect gains of around $20-30 \%$ in delay, $40-50 \%$ in power consumption, and considerable enhancement of the power-delay product (PDP) of different adder designs with respect to traditional methods.

title: Techno-Economic Feasibility of RE-based EV Charging Stations: A Case Study of Jaipur, India
authors: Garima Panwar, Sandeep Pilaniya, Sunanda Sinha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The transition to electric vehicles (EVs) necessitates the development of sustainable charging infrastructure to reduce reliance on fossil-fuel-based grids and mitigate environmental impacts. This study assesses the technical and economic viability of renewable energy (RE) based EV charging stations for Jaipur, India, using HOMER. Various configurations incorporating solar photovoltaic (SPV), wind turbines (WT), and battery energy storage systems (BSS) were analyzed. The SPV-only configuration emerged as the most cost-effective option, achieving a LCOE of ₹4.00/kWh, a NPC of ₹110M, and a payback period of 7.62 years. Hybrid configurations, such as SPV + WT, achieved lower LCOE (₹3.83/kWh) and greater emission reductions but required higher initial capital investment. The findings underscore the potential of RE based EV charging systems to support sustainable transportation infrastructure and contribute to India’s decarbonization objectives.

title: Remote International Exchange in Mathematics Education: Evaluating the Educational Impact of Real-Time Translation Technology Using Zoom
authors: Hidemichi Okamoto, Kyomi Takuma, Thomas Borys, Tetsushi Kawasaki
publish: 2025 International Conference on Culture-Oriented Science &amp; Technology (CoST)
abstract: This study examined the use of Zoom's automatic translation subtitles in a Remote International Exchange between pre-service teachers from Japan and Germany. It aimed to reduce language barriers and promote collaboration in mathematics education. Twelve students (six per country) presented and discussed lessons on reasoning, discovery-based learning, and cognitive activation. The presentations contained the students' native languages, bilingual slides, and Zoom subtitles. Japanese students reported high satisfaction and improved comprehension, especially during the Question and Answer sessions. German students, however, struggled with subtitle inaccuracies and the complexity of the bilingual material, which hindered understanding. Despite these challenges, all students expressed interest in future exchanges. The study showed that international collaboration is possible without a shared language like English. Although current translation tools have limitations, they can support inclusive and culturally responsive learning when used effectively. Enhancing translation accuracy and simplifying materials could further improve intercultural understanding.

title: Abnormal behavior detection method for medium and low voltage power grid based on autoencoder and migration mechanism
authors: Fei Chang, Pengxiang Zhu, Guoqiang Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: This paper proposes an anomaly detection method that integrates autoencoders and migration mechanisms. This method uses multi-layer stacked autoencoders to perform deep compression modeling on distribution network operation data, and introduces a migration learning module based on domain adversarial training to achieve feature alignment and unsupervised generalization between different regions. The experiment uses the measured data of the German distribution network in 2023 for evaluation. The results show that this method is superior to mainstream methods in terms of accuracy, recall, F1 value and AUC, and shows strong robustness in cross-regional migration scenarios. The research results provide theoretical support and engineering reference for building an anomaly detection system for smart distribution networks with broad adaptability.

title: Detection and Discrimination of Power Swings and Faults Using DWT, EMD, and VMD
authors: Allen Solly P Babu, Devesh Shukla, Ashish Awasthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The deployment of distributed energy resources and their integration into the grid introduces new challenges to power system stability. This induces the potential for power swings caused by intermittent generation, reduced inertia, and uncoordinated control actions. Considering the above scenario detection and mitigation of various events in the power system is a crucial task. This paper proposes a framework for discrete wavelet transform (DWT), empirical mode decomposition(EMD) and variational mode decomposition (VMD) based approach for power swing and fault classification. The method begins by measuring the current signals at the Point of Common Coupling (PCC) which are then processed by using the proposed signal processing techniques. In order to validate the same, the above cases are simulated in a IEEE 5 bus system using PSCAD software and signal processing analysis carried out using MATLAB platform. The extracted IMFs (Intrinsic Mode function) and detail coefficients are analyzed and it exhibit a promising method to differentiate various faults events from power swing.

title: Demonstration of Automated Payment Gateway Based Electric Vehicle Charging System
authors: Mohd Alam, Tanveer Singh Rajawat, Pratik Kumar Jha, Aditya Avhad, Aman Nahar, M. M. Renge, V.B. Borghate
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: The demand for effective and user-friendly electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure is rising in recent years. Its real-time monitoring of energy with automated payment facilities through QR code and smart control of load facilitates more convenience in use and hence leads to sustainability. The automated EV charging station is designed to address the scalability, efficiency, and user convenience. Equipped with components like a microcontroller unit-based on ESP32, a PZEM-004T energy meter, and a solid state relay (SSR), it makes quite precise monitoring possible for various electrical parameters i.e. voltage, current, power factor, and energy consumption. Users can track from anywhere the entire charge process, allowing payment processing with an energy use visualization. The design guarantees safe and robust operation. The scalability and intuitive design of the system make it a practical solution for advancing the EV ecosystem.

title: Small Target Vehicle Detection Algorithm for UAV Based on Improved YOLOv11
authors: Hong Zhu, Jiakang Zhao, Zixuan Chen, Dashuai Zhang, Huanrui Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Sensors, Electronics and Computer Engineering (ICSECE)
abstract: To address the challenge of insufficient detection accuracy for small targets (vehicles) in UAV-captured complex scenes, this paper proposes an improved YOLOv11 algorithm. The proposed method incorporates a multi-branch depthwise separable convolution module to enhance the C3K2 module, significantly enhancing the model's ability to detect targets of various sizes. Furthermore, a novel scalable pyramid atrous convolution module is designed to replace the SPPF module. This module utilizes dilated convolutions instead of pooling layers, effectively reducing the loss of detailed information and improving both operational flexibility and computational efficiency of feature extraction. Experimental results on the VisDrone2019 dataset demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves mAP@0.5 of 46.4%, surpassing mainstream models while maintaining the detection speed of 76 FPS, thus fulfilling real-time requirements. Compared with the benchmark model YOLOv11, the precision has increased by 4.7%. Ablation and comparative experiments further validate the effectiveness and high efficiency in small target detection tasks for UAV, while visual results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed algorithm in complex scenes.

title: Natural Language Understanding for Air Traffic Control – How Much Information is Lost Over the Atlantic?
authors: Hartmut Helmke, Stephen S. Clarke, Oliver Ohneiser, Matthias Kleinert, Shruthi Shetty, Krishna Kalyanam
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Rapid innovation has been made understanding and digitizing air traffic control instructions. However, to date, little has been done to harmonize work and understand differences across the globe. In this paper, we compare two ontologies - from US and Europe - for interpretation of semantics of controller and pilot radio telephony transcriptions. Overall, more than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 0 0}$</tex> ground control transmissions are evaluated from both sides of the Atlantic. Half of the transmissions, from the US side, are transformed into semantic concepts with the European ontology. These concepts contain the information, which the ontology claims as relevant. The concepts are transformed into sequences of words, which are then transformed back to semantic concepts by the US ontology, i.e., the US implementation of what information is relevant. Comparing the US concepts generated through this process against the original US concepts defines the European loss. The process is then executed the other way around on the second half of transmissions stemming from the European side, resulting in the US loss. The European command type loss is currently 2.6% absolute, whereas the US loss is 1.2%, i.e., the extraction rate of commands decreases by these losses over the Atlantic Ocean. In addition to loss comparison, the main contribution of this work is that the generalized approach enables comparison and evaluation of different ontologies and especially different implementations of the ontologies.

title: Free Route Airspace Trajectory Planning Using Conditional Diffusion Model
authors: Wentao Zhao, Peng Zhao, Kaiquan Cai, Zexuan Wu
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Enhancing the safety and efficiency of Free Route Airspace (FRA) operations requires a trajectory planning framework that simultaneously address aircraft dynamics, fuel efficiency, and airspace constraints. In this work, we present a multi-objective optimization approach that formulates trajectory planning as a conditional sampling problem, solved using a Conditional Diffusion Model (CDM). First, we derive an aircraft dynamics model and a fuel-consumption model from the Base of Aircraft Data (BADA), encoding hard constraints and cost objectives, respectively. Next, we employ the expert dataset, comprising state-action-reward tuples, as our training set to independently train both the diffusion model and the conditional function. Finally, we incorporate the conditional function into the diffusion denoising steps to steer trajectory samples toward low-cost, dynamically feasible paths while enforcing avoidance of unavailable airspace. Experiments conducted in both conventional fixed-route airspace and FRA demonstrate that our method significantly reduces overall flight cost, respects aircraft dynamic limits, and maintains compliance with airspace restrictions.

title: Smart Real-Time Obstacle Avoidance for Planetary Rovers Using Ultrasonic Sensing: Design, Hardware Integration, and Validation
authors: Naser Mobarki, Abdulmajeed Alshahrani, Atif Mahmood, Amil Daraz, Abrar-Ul-Haq Baluch, Ayman Muhammad Abdallah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering (ICECCE)
abstract: Autonomous navigation is a critical requirement for planetary rovers operating in Astro-biological exploration missions, where real-time human control is limited or unavailable. This paper presents the design, integration, and validation of a low-cost ultrasonic sensing system for smart obstacle avoidance in planetary rover platforms. The system employs the HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor interfaced with Raspberry Pi Pico microcontroller and a Turtle Board-based motor control unit. A reactive evasion algorithm, developed in Python using ROS-style message logic, enables the rover to detect obstacles at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 5 ~ c m}$</tex> range and execute immediate stop-and-turn maneuvers. The complete architecture includes sensor interfacing, motor control, power regulation, and onboard indicator feedback. Hardware validation was performed through indoor and outdoor field tests simulating planetary terrain conditions. Results demonstrated 100% successful obstacle detection and avoidance with a response delay of less than one second. The proposed system offers an energyefficient, modular solution that is suitable for integration in smallscale rovers intended for autonomous surface operations in extraterrestrial environments. This work lays the foundation for future upgrades involving multi-sensor fusion, vision support, and mapping capabilities. While the current system relies on rulebased logic, future iterations could integrate AI algorithms for adaptive obstacle prediction, terrain classification, and autonomous path planning.

title: A Precise, Fast, and Accurate Time-Varying Method of Frequency Estimation
authors: Ravindra Kumar, Manoj Tripathy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Control and protection applications require an accurate technique to estimate the frequency. However, existing frequency estimation algorithms for real-time power system data often encounter reliability issues. This paper introduces a fast, reliable, and precise method for estimating the frequency of power systems data. The proposed method is evaluated under conditions that involve DC decay components, harmonics, noise, and deviations from nominal frequencies. It employs a new frequency estimation algorithm in which linear regression and outlier filtering have been used for filtering purposes. Robust linear regression algorithms eliminates the noise, harmonics, and the DC decaying component from signals. The model’s validity is confirmed using power system data from specific sources. The outcomes of the proposed approach have been compared against alternative approaches such as Kalman pitch tracking, DFT interpolation, and least square frequency estimator, showing improved accuracy up to the fourth decimal place. This method demonstrates significantly enhanced accuracy compared to the aforementioned methods.

title: Identification and Quantification of Customer-Induced Harmonic Distortion at PCC Using Non-Fundamental Apparent Power
authors: Baru Chauhan, MD Sajid Alam, Premalata Jena
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Power quality (PQ) problems, including harmonics, unbalanced loads, and voltage fluctuations, have grown to be significant obstacles as active distribution systems (ADS) increasingly include renewable energy sources (RES), electric vehicles (EVs), and energy storage systems (ESS). This paper investigates and identifies disturbances in an ADS with high penetration of distributed energy resources (DERs). A comprehensive methodology is proposed for locating disturbances using Total Distortion Power (TDP) and the Harmonic Distortion Index (HDI). These calculations help energy providers identify which customers inject the most harmonics into the system, allowing for targeted solutions like filtering and better power management with IEEE 519-2014 standards. MATLAB/Simulink simulations, sophisticated monitoring tools, and data analysis methods are used to verify the research and increase correctness. The efficacy of this approach is evaluated using simulation case studies, which demonstrate its applicability to modern power networks. The results provide workable ways to enhance power quality and ensure adherence to electrical standards.

title: Small Signal Analysis and Closed-Loop Design of Constant Frequency Operated Single-Stage Bidirectional PFC-Based Converter for Plug-in G2VEV Charger
authors: Nil Patel, Sony Susan Varghese
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper describes a comprehensive small-signal analysis and closed-loop design of a single-stage isolated AC-DC converter with power factor correction (PFC) that is intended for use in charging Electric Vehicles (EVs) application. To achieve this, a state-space averaging method is utilized to derive a small-signal model, and a modified control technique is developed to enable soft-switching without the need for additional snubber circuits or passive circuitry. By utilizing this model, the proposed converter can be operated with fixed frequency bidirectionally in a four-quadrant operation, allowing for both active and reactive power transfer between the grid and the battery of EV, which helps to stabilize the grid. To ensure the functionality of the grid-to-vehicle (G2V) and vehicle-to-grid (V2G) modes of operation, a controller is designed based on the small-signal mathematical model, and its performance is evaluated using simulation PSIM 11.04 software. The results show that the proposed topology performs as per theoretical analysis and its claims, and also this is confirmed by experimental tests carried out on a 1.5 kVA hardware prototype.

title: Optimal Scheduling of Battery Swapping Stations Serving E-Buses with Ancillary Services Markets
authors: Manish Sharma, Deep Kiran
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Electrifying public buses is pivotal for advancing EV adoption as it can leverage their high energy demands and fixed operational schedules. This paper proposes an optimization model aimed at effectively managing the scheduling of battery swapping stations (BSSs) for electric public buses. Here, the BSS comprises of multiple battery modules that can be swapped with the partially charged or completely discharged ones of the electric buses (E-buses). The proposed model minimizes the BSS operational costs through two strategies by charging the battery modules during the low electricity prices and by providing ancillary services to the grid. These strategies ensure the fulfillment of the energy demands of the E-buses without disrupting their scheduled timetables. This proposed model is formulated as a MINLP model, which is subsequently transformed into a MILP model, and validates the operational feasibility of the BSS.

title: A Real time Performance study of Aluminium Oxide-based Spectral Splitting in De-coupled Photovoltaic/Thermal System
authors: Munna Kumar, Ashish Kumar, Sanjay Kumar, Satyender Singh, Nikhil Chander
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: Solar energy is a renewable energy source that is capable of meeting a large portion of the thermal and electrical energy required throughout the entire globe. In the past few years, there has been the subject of extensive research exploring a variety of spectral fluids that were used as beam splitters in photovoltaic/thermal systems referred to as de-coupled photovoltaic/thermal systems. The work reported here performed real-time experimentation and utilized Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>/Water nanofluid and de-ionized water as spectral fluids due to their tunable properties, making it an ambitious choice for beam-splitting applications. Furthermore, this work also considered the effect of the nanoparticle concentrations, i.e., 0.0004 wt.% and 0.0001 wt.% at a constant mass flow rate of 0.025 kg/s in the thermal receiver (spectral channel) of the novel photovoltaic/thermal system. Results of the present work showed that Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>/water nanofluid with 0.0004 wt.% gained a maximum temperature of 44 <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">o</sup>C. However, the lower PV surface temperature in a hybrid PV/T system was found to be 56.5 <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">o</sup>C against 60 <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">o</sup>C (standalone PV system) utilizing 0.0004 wt.% of Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> nanofluid as spectral fluid. The overall efficiency of work presented herein was found to be 40%, 37.5%, and 32%, utilizing 0.0004 wt.%, 0.0001 wt.%, and de-ionized water, respectively, at a constant mass flow rate of 0.025 kg/s.

title: Designing a Two-Stage PV-PEM Electrolyser with Sliding Mode Converter Control
authors: Raj Kapur Kumar, Paulson Samuel
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on Sustainable Energy and Future Electric Transportation (SEFET)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a two-stage photovoltaic (PV)-proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyser system utilizing a Sliding Mode Controller (SMC) for enhanced performance under dynamic operating conditions. The proposed system integrates Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) for efficient solar energy harvesting and a bidirectional charge controller for battery energy management. The SMC regulates the PEM electrolyser, which is responsible for hydrogen production, to ensure robust operation under varying solar irradiance and electrolyser voltage conditions. Additionally, a battery state-of-charge (SOC)-based gating mechanism is introduced to prevent both overcharging and deep discharging, thereby enhancing battery lifespan and system reliability. The proposed SMC-based control strategy is compared against a conventional Proportional-Integral (PI) controller using MATLAB/Simulink simulations. Performance metrics such as response time, stability, and robustness are evaluated under varying solar irradiance, electrolyser voltage, and load conditions. The results demonstrate that the SMC provides a faster dynamic response, reduced overshoot, and superior robustness compared to the PI controller, particularly in scenarios involving rapid environmental changes.

title: Unseen Attacks Identification in Intrusion Systems Using BERT and Logit Normalization
authors: Frédéric Adjewa, Moez Esseghir, Leïla Merghem-Boulahia, Cheikh Kacfah
publish: 2025 21th International Conference on Wireless and Mobile Computing, Networking and Communications (WiMob)
abstract: The exponential growth of internet-based services is enhancing human-machine interactions as we transition to nextgeneration networks. However, the threat landscape is also changing rapidly in tandem with this transformation, with increasingly complex cyberattacks that can pass through current security mechanisms because of their unidentified features. Identifying such novel threats is essential for an effective response, but existing AI-based intrusion detection systems methods often lack reliability when facing these unseen threats. Although transformer-based models have shown promise in threat detection and massive data volume management, they are prone to overconfident predictions on unfamiliar inputs, limiting their robustness. To address this, we propose a BERT-based intrusion detection approach trained with logit normalization, which enhances the model reliability by mitigating overconfidence in the model prediction, leading to better seen-unseen separation boundary. We evaluate our method on four benchmark datasets namely CICIDS2017, CICIoT2023, Edge-IIoTset and NSL-KDD, under intra- and cross-dataset conditions. Results show a substantial improvement in detecting unseen attacks, with accuracy rising from 3.9 % to almost 100 % while maintaining at least 95 % detection for seen threats. This work results in a robust and unified model capable of detecting seen attacks and identifying unseen ones.

title: Multi-Factor Modeling and Simulation of Firefighting Aircraft in Wildfire Flight Environment
authors: Huanyu Wang, Jiateng Chen, Chao Zhang
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Wildfires are complex events that arise from the interaction between the atmosphere and vegetation, with changing wind patterns posing significant challenges for aerial firefighting aircraft (FFA). This study presents a novel framework that integrates wildfire dynamics with flight simulation systems to examine aerodynamic characteristics under fire-induced turbulence. A multi-factor wildfire model was developed using FDS/PyroSim software, incorporating diverse geospatial and meteorological data, including satellite imagery, digital elevation maps, landuse classifications, and profiles of wind speed and direction. The methodology provides a means of modeling and simulating fireinduced wind fields on a large scale for a specific location and time, providing wind field simulation data for flight simulation device (FSD). The simulated fire-induced wind turbulence was dynamically integrated into a Level-D FSD, a real-time simulation platform, to assess the aerodynamic response of a typical fixedwing FFA during aerial rescue operations. The results indicate that additional pilot control inputs are necessary to maintain pitch stabilization in turbulent conditions. Future work will leverage the integrated FSD-based simulation system to enable scenario-based crew training for fire suppression tactics and to facilitate airborne system verification through pilot-in-loop testing.

title: Hybridized PSO-ACO Algorithm for Optimized VLSI Placement: Focusing on Area and Wirelength
authors: Beena Snehal Uphale, G. R. Vijayshankar, Guntaj J, Bhupendra Ku. Gupta, Deepak Minhas, Premkumar R
abstract: This work presents a PSACO algorithm optimized approach of chip placement where the impartial is to diminish area and wirelength. A sub-step of physical design, placement assigns cells to fixed locations in a netlist while fulfilling timing and connectivity constraints. PSO is adaptive in global search while ACO is efficient in local search; the use of both addresses’ layout design as a multi-objective problem. In comparison with MCNC and GSRC circuits, the proposed method achieves area utilization improvement of 5.41% and wirelength improvement of 32.73% over standalone PSO for MCNC benchmarks. Smaller areas were squeezed more tightly within the chip leading to a slight degradation in area utilization by 2.94%, but significantly improving the wirelength by 2.06% as compared with their corresponding GSRC benchmarks. These results confirm the competitiveness of PSACO in solving NP-hard problems in VLSI design, providing a more harmonious trade-off between conflicting objectives.

title: Signal Integrity Analysis of DDR4 Design in Avionics Systems: A Comparative Study of Simulation-Measurement Correlation Between EDA Tools
authors: Soazig LE Bihan, Tristan Dubois, Benjamin Ducombs, Marc Gatti, Jean-Baptiste Begueret, Adil EL Abbazi
publish: 2025 AIAA DATC/IEEE 44th Digital Avionics Systems Conference (DASC)
abstract: Signal integrity (SI) analysis becomes necessary as data rates, frequencies, density, and Printed Circuit Board (PCB) complexity grow. Double Data Rate (DDR) 4th generation memory is widely used in avionics systems, and each generation brings new design challenges. Recent developments in Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools from the Ansys, Siemens, and Keysight suites enable the simulation and optimization of DDR signals to ensure compliance with Joint Electron Device Engineering Council (JEDEC) standards. Many vendors have developed DDR wizards that automate signal integrity analysis to reduce simulation setup time. On the other hand, simulation tools have their limitations, and the reliability of their results has yet to be validated on a real avionic board design. Research in this study aims to compare the DDR wizards from various simulation tools available on the market and correlate the results with measurements. This will help build confidence in the selected tools, developing a simulation methodology that allows design times to be reduced by relying solely on simulations, without the need for further measurements or test vehicles for future avionic designs.
